original: vihāsinti tassa paṭhamābhisambuddhavihārassa padesena. Tattha padeso nāma khandhapadeso
analyzed: vihāsin ti tassa paṭhama abhisambuddha vihārassa padesena tattha padesaḥ nāma khandha padeso
translated: by the side of that place of the first enlightenment. There, the side is a part of a section,

original: āyatanadhātusaccaindriyapaccayākārasatipaṭṭhānajhānanāmarūpapadeso dhammapadesoti
analyzed: āyatana dhātu sacca aindriya paccaya ākāra sati paṭṭhāna jhāna nāma rūpa padeso dhamma padeso ti
translated: a part of the aggregates, sense-bases, elements, truths, faculties, conditions, aspects, foundations of mindfulness, jhānas, name-and-form,

original: nānāvidho. Taṃ sabbampi sandhāya – “tassa padesena vihāsi”nti āha. Bhagavā hi paṭhamabodhiyaṃ
analyzed: nānāvidhaḥ tam sabbam pi sandhāya tassa padesena vihāsin ti āha bhagavā hi paṭhama bodhiyam
translated: and the part of the Dhamma. There are many kinds of parts. Referring to all of that, he said: “By the side of that.” The Blessed One, during the first fifty-nine days of enlightenment,

original: ekūnapaññāsadivasabbhantare yathā nāma pattarajjo rājā attano vibhavasāradassanatthaṃ
analyzed: ekūna paññāsa divasa bbhantare yathā nāma pattarajjo rājā vibhava sāra dassana attham
translated: as if a king with a leather strap were to show his wealth and riches,

original: taṃ taṃ gabbhaṃ vivarāpetvā suvaṇṇarajatamuttāmaṇiādīni ratanāni paccavekkhanto vihareyya,🔽evameva pañcakkhandhe nippadese katvā sammasanto paccavekkhanto vihāsi. Imasmiṃ pana
analyzed: tam tam gabbham vivarāpetvā suvaṇṇa rajata muttāmaṇi ādīni ratanāni paccavekkhantaḥ vihareyya  evam eva pañca kkhandhe nippadese katvā sammasantaḥ paccavekkhantaḥ vihāsi imasmin pana
translated: and he would live contemplating the jewels such as gold, silver, pearls, gems, etc., that he saw there.🔽So too, the Exalted One, by making the five aggregates free from the concept of a person, contemplated and lived contemplating them. But in this half-month he lived contemplating the aggregates by way of the feeling aggregate alone.

original: aḍḍhamāse tesaṃ khandhānaṃ padesaṃ vedanākkhandhameva paccavekkhanto vihāsi. Tassa🔽“ime sattā evarūpaṃ nāma sukhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti, evarūpaṃ dukkha”nti olokayato yāva
analyzed: aḍḍha māse tesam khandhānam padesam vedanā kkhandham eva paccavekkhantaḥ vihāsi tassa  ime sattāḥ evarūpam nāma sukham paṭisaṃvedenti evarūpam dukkhanti olokayataḥ yāva
translated: As he contemplated,

original: bhavaggā pavattā sukhavedanā, yāva avīcito pavattā dukkhavedanā, sabbā sabbākārena
analyzed: bhavaggā pavattā sukha vedanā yāva avīcito pavattā dukkha vedanā sabbā sabba ākārena
translated: all the pleasant feelings occurring up to the highest plane of existence and all the painful feelings occurring down to the Avīci hell appeared to him in all their aspects.

original: upaṭṭhāsi. Atha naṃ “micchādiṭṭhipaccayāpi vedayita”ntiādinā nayena pariggaṇhanto vihāsi.🔽Tathā paṭhamabodhiyaṃ dvādasāyatanāni nippadesāneva katvā vihāsi, imasmiṃ pana aḍḍhamāse
analyzed: upaṭṭhāsi atha nam micchādiṭṭhi paccayā api vedayita nti ādinā nayena pariggaṇhantaḥ vihāsi  tathā dvādasa āyatanāni nippadesān eva katvā vihāsi imasmin pana aḍḍha māse
translated: Then he lived contemplating them by way of discerning their conditions, as follows: “Feeling has wrong view as its condition” and so on.

original: tesaṃ āyatanānaṃ padesaṃ vedanāvasena dhammāyatanekadesaṃ, dhātūnaṃ padesaṃ vedanāvasena
analyzed: tesam āyatanānam padesam vedanā vasena dhammāyatana ekadesam dhātūnam padesam vedanā vasena
translated: In the first half-month he lived by making the twelve sense bases free from the concept of a person. But in this half-month he lived by making the feeling aggregate, which is part of the mental data base and part of the mental data element, the object of his contemplation.

original: dhammadhātuekadesaṃ, saccānaṃ padesaṃ vedanākkhandhavaseneva dukkhasaccekadesaṃ,🔽paccayānaṃ padesaṃ phassapaccayā vedanāvasena paccayekadesaṃ jhānānaṃ padesaṃ vedanāvaseneva
analyzed: dhammadhātu eka desam saccānam padesam vedanā kkhandha vasena iva dukkha sacca eka desam  paccayānam padesam phassa paccayāḥ vedanā vasena paccaya ekadesam jhānānam padesam vedanā vasena iva
translated: One part of the element of mental objects, one part of the Truths, is the part of the Truth of Suffering as the feeling aggregate.🔽One part of the conditions, is the part of the condition of contact as feeling. One part of the Meditations, is the part of the Meditations as feeling.

original: jhānaṅgekadesaṃ, nāmarūpānaṃ padesaṃ vedanāvaseneva nāmekadesaṃ paccavekkhanto vihāsi.
analyzed: nāma rūpānam padesam vedanā vasena iva nāma eka desam paccavekkhantaḥ vihāsi
translated: He lived contemplating the fact that the element of mental objects is a part of the Truths, a part of the aggregates, a part of the bases, a part of the conditions, a part of the jhanas, a part of the path, a part of the powers, a part of the faculties, a part of the fruits, a part of the analytical knowledges, a part of the liberations, a part of the supreme efforts, a part of the bases of spiritual success, a part of the faculties, a part of the powers, a part of the enlightenment factors, a part of the path, a part of the jhanas, a part of the immaterial states, a part of the superknowledges, a part of the kinds of direct knowledge, a part of the kinds of awareness, a part of the kinds of existence, a part of the kinds of destiny, a part of the kinds of rebirth, a part of the kinds of becoming, a part of the kinds of suffering, a part of the kinds of craving, a part of the kinds of clinging, a part of the kinds of existence, a part of the kinds of birth, a part of the kinds of aging, a part of the kinds of sickness, a part of the kinds of death, a part of the kinds of sorrow, lamentation, pain, grief, and despair.

original: Paṭhamabodhiyañhi ekūnapaññāsadivasabbhantare kusalādidhamme nippadese katvā anantanayāni
analyzed: paṭhama bodhiyan hi ekūna paññāsa divasa bbhantare kusala ādi dhamme nippadese katvā ananta nayāni
translated: For in the first week he lived contemplating the fact that the profitable and so on are not divided up, and he lived contemplating the fact that the seven books of the Abhidhamma are of infinite meaning.

original: satta pakaraṇāni paccavekkhanto vihāsi. Imasmiṃ pana aḍḍhamāse sabbadhammānaṃ padesaṃ🔽vedanāttikameva paccavekkhanto vihāsi. Tasmiṃ tasmiṃ ṭhāne sā sā ca vihārasamāpatti
analyzed: satta pakaraṇāni paccavekkhantaḥ vihāsi imasmin pana aḍḍha māse sabba dhammānam padesam  vedanā ttikam eva paccavekkhantaḥ vihāsi tasmim tasmim ṭhāne sā sā ca vihāra samāpatti
translated: But in this second week he lived contemplating the fact that all states are divided up into the mere thirty-six kinds of feeling.

original: vedanānubhāvena jātā.
analyzed: vedanā anubhāvena jātā
translated: And in each case the attainment of the abiding was due to the influence of the feeling.

original: Idāni yenākārena vihāsi, taṃ dassento micchādiṭṭhipaccayāpītiādimāha. Tattha micchādiṭṭhipaccayāpīti
analyzed: idāni yena ākārena vihāsi tam dassentaḥ micchādiṭṭhi paccayā api iti ādim āha tattha micchādiṭṭhi paccayā api iti
translated: Now, showing in what way he lived, he said, “With the support of wrong view” and so on. Herein, with the support of wrong view:

original: diṭṭhisampayuttā vedanāpi vaṭṭati. Diṭṭhiṃ upanissayaṃ katvā uppannā kusalākusalavedanāpi
analyzed: diṭṭhi sampayuttā vedanā api vaṭṭati diṭṭhim upanissayam katvā uppannā kusala akusala vedanā api
translated: and feeling associated with wrong view is also so. And also the profitable and unprofitable feeling that arises contingent upon wrong view.

original: vaṭṭati vipākavedanāpi. Tattha micchādiṭṭhisampayuttā akusalāva hoti, diṭṭhiṃ pana🔽upanissāya kusalāpi uppajjanti akusalāpi. Micchādiṭṭhikā hi diṭṭhiṃ upanissāya pakkhadivasesu🔽yāgubhattādīni denti, addhikādīnaṃ vaṭṭaṃ paṭṭhapenti, catumahāpathe sālaṃ karonti,🔽pokkharaṇiñca khaṇāpenti, devakulādīsu mālāgacchaṃ ropenti, nadīviduggādīsu setuṃ🔽attharanti, visamaṃ samaṃ karonti, iti nesaṃ kusalavedanā uppajjati. Micchādiṭṭhiṃ🔽pana nissāya sammādiṭṭhike akkosanti paribhāsanti, vadhabandhanādīni karonti, pāṇaṃ
analyzed: vaṭṭati vipāka vedanā api tattha micchādiṭṭhi sampayuttā akusalā va hoti diṭṭhim pana  upanissāya kusalā api uppajjanti akusalā api micchādiṭṭhikāḥ hi diṭṭhim upanissāya pakkha divasesu  yāgu bhatta ādīni denti addhika ādīnam vaṭṭam paṭṭhapenti catu mahāpathe sālam karonti  pokkharaṇim ca khaṇāpenti devakula ādīsu mālāgaccham ropenti nadī vidugga ādīsu setum  attharanti visamam samam karonti iti na īsam kusala vedanā uppajjati micchādiṭṭhim  pana nissāya sammādiṭṭhike akkosanti paribhāsanti vadha bandhana ādīni karonti pāṇam
translated: and also feeling associated with wrong view. And also feeling that has arisen with wrong view as its condition, whether profitable or unprofitable,

original: vadhitvā devatānaṃ upahāraṃ upaharanti, iti nesaṃ akusalavedanā uppajjati. Vipākavedanā
analyzed: vadhitvā devatānam upahāram upaharanti iti na īsam akusala vedanā uppajjati vipāka vedanā
translated: is included. Herein, that associated with wrong view is only unprofitable. But also profitable feeling arises with wrong view as condition, and also unprofitable feeling. For those who hold wrong view, when they give gruel, rice, etc., on fast-day, or give a gift of a bull, or make a shelter at a cross-roads, or have a tank dug, or plant trees in a shrine’s precincts, or make a flower-garden, or build a bridge over a river where there is a ford, or make a road level where it is uneven, then profitable feeling arises in them with wrong view as condition. But when they abuse and revile those who hold right view, or imprison them, or inflict other punishments on them, or kill them, or offer them as slaves, then unprofitable feeling arises in them with wrong view as condition. And also resultant feeling is included.

original: pana bhavantaragatānaṃyeva hoti.🔽Sammādiṭṭhipaccayāti etthāpi sammādiṭṭhisampayuttā vedanāpi vaṭṭati, sammādiṭṭhiṃ🔽upanissayaṃ katvā uppannā kusalākusalavedanāpi vipākavedanāpi. Tattha sammādiṭṭhisampayuttā🔽kusalāva hoti, sammādiṭṭhiṃ pana upanissāya buddhapūjaṃ dīpamālaṃ mahādhammassavanaṃ🔽appatiṭṭhite disābhāge cetiyapatiṭṭhāpananti evamādīni puññāni karonti, iti nesaṃ
analyzed: ha uti  sammādiṭṭhi paccayā ti ettha api sammādiṭṭhi sampayuttā vedanā api vaṭṭati sammādiṭṭhim  upanissayam katvā uppannā kusala akusala vedanā api vipāka vedanā api tattha sammādiṭṭhi sampayuttā  kusalā ava hoti sammādiṭṭhim pana upanissāya buddha pūjam dīpa mālam mahā dhammassavanam  appatiṭṭhite disābhāge cetiya patiṭṭhāpananti evamādīni puññāni karonti iti na īsam
translated: but only in the case of those who have passed on to another existence.

original: kusalā vedanā uppajjati. Sammādiṭṭhiṃyeva nissāya micchādiṭṭhike akkosanti paribhāsanti,🔽attānaṃ ukkaṃsenti, paraṃ vambhenti, iti nesaṃ akusalavedanā uppajjati. Vipākavedanā🔽pana bhavantaragatānaṃyeva hoti. Micchāsaṅkappapaccayātiādīsupi eseva nayo. Chandapaccayātiādīsu
analyzed: kusalā vedanā uppajjati sammādiṭṭhiṃ yeva nissāya micchādiṭṭhike akkosanti paribhāsanti 🔽attānam ukkaṃsenti param vambhenti iti na īsam akusala vedanā uppajjati vipāka vedanā 🔽pana hoti micchā saṅkappa paccayā iti ādīsu pi esa iva nayo chanda paccayā iti ādīsu
translated: With right view as condition: here too feeling associated with right view is allowable, and also profitable and unprofitable feeling arisen with right view as its support. Herein, that associated with right view is only profitable. But when they make merit by way of the Buddha, by way of the Dhamma, by way of the Sangha, by way of the body, by way of the life, by way of the family, by way of merit, by way of the Dhamma, by way of the clan, by way of the field, by way of the world, by way of the world beyond, by way of the worlds of devas, of Maras, and of Brahmas, by way of the worlds of beings, of families, of clans, of Buddhas, of Buddhas’ disciples, by way of what is seen, heard, sensed, or cognized, by way of the six kinds of objects, by way of the four establishments of mindfulness, by way of the four right endeavours, by way of the four bases for spiritual success, by way of the five faculties, by way of the five powers, by way of the seven factors of enlightenment, by way of the Noble Eightfold Path, by way of the four paths, by way of the four fruits, by way of the four foundations for supernatural power, by way of the six kinds of direct knowledge, by way of the four discriminations, by way of the four analytical knowledges, by way of the three kinds of knowledge, by way of the three kinds of clear knowledge, by way of the three kinds of seclusion, by way of the three kinds of concentration, by way of the three kinds of insight, by way of the three kinds of deliverance, by way of the four inversions, by way of the four bases for spiritual power, by way of the four foundations of mindfulness, by way of the four right efforts, by way of the four paths, by way of the four fruits, by way of the five spiritual faculties, by way of the five spiritual powers, by way of the seven factors of enlightenment, by way of the Noble Eightfold Path, by way of the ten powers of a Tathagata, by way of the four kinds of intrepidity, by way of the four kinds of analytical knowledge, by way of the eighteen kinds of special knowledge of a Buddha, by way of the thirty-two marks of a Great Man, by way

original: pana chandapaccayā aṭṭhalobhasahagatacittasampayuttā vedanā veditabbā, vitakkapaccayā
analyzed: pana chanda paccayā aṭṭha lobha sahagata citta sampayuttā vedanā veditabbā vitakka paccayā
translated: But feeling associated with the eight types of consciousness accompanied by greed should be understood as due to the condition of zeal.🔽And feeling in the first jhāna is due to the condition of applied thought.

original: paṭhamajjhānavedanāva. Saññā paccayā ṭhapetvā paṭhamajjhānaṃ sesā cha saññāsamāpattivedanā.🔽Chando ca avūpasantotiādīsu tiṇṇaṃ avūpasame aṭṭhalobhasahagatacittasampayuttā vedanā
analyzed: paṭhama jhāna vedanā va saññā paccayā ṭhapetvā paṭhama jhānam sesā cha saññā samāpatti vedanā  chando ca avūpasanto tiādīsu avūpasame aṭṭha lobha sahagata citta sampayuttā vedanā
translated: And feeling in the six remaining sense-sphere resultant-consciousness attainments is due to the condition of perception.🔽As regards the passage beginning, “When three are unabandoned,” feeling associated with the eight types of consciousness accompanied by greed is due to the non-abandonment of three.🔽And feeling in the first jhāna is due to the non-abandonment of zeal alone.🔽And feeling in the second jhāna, etc., is due to the non-abandonment of both zeal and applied thought.🔽And feeling in the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception is due to the non-abandonment of all three.🔽As regards the passage beginning, “When one is unabandoned,” feeling in the attainment of the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception is due to the non-abandonment of the perception of the base consisting of nothingness.

original: hoti, chandamattassa vūpasame paṭhamajjhānavedanāva. Chandavitakkānaṃ vūpasame dutiyajjhānādivedanā
analyzed: hoti chanda mattassa vūpasame paṭhama jhāna vedanā va chanda vitakkānaṃ vūpasame dutiya jhāna ādi vedanā
translated: As regards the passage beginning, “When two are unabandoned,” feeling in the attainment of the base consisting of nothingness is due to the non-abandonment of the perception of the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception and of the perception of the base consisting of nothingness.

original: adhippetā, tiṇṇampi vūpasame nevasaññānāsaññāyatanavedanā. Appattassa pattiyāti arahattaphalassa🔽pattatthāya. Atthi āyāmanti atthi vīriyaṃ. Tasmimpi ṭhāne anuppatteti tassa vīriyārambhassa
analyzed: adhippetā tiṇṇam pi vūpasame na ivasaññā nāsañña āyatana vedanā appattassa pattiyā arahatta phalassa  patta tthāya atthi atthi vīriyam tasmim pi ṭhāne tassa vīriya ārambhassa
translated: As regards the passage beginning, “When three are unabandoned,” feeling in the attainment of the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception is due to the non-abandonment of the perception of the base consisting of nothingness and of the perception of the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception and of the perception of the base consisting of the infinity of consciousness.🔽As regards the passage beginning, “When four are unabandoned,” feeling in the attainment of the base consisting of the infinity of consciousness is due to the non-abandonment of the perception of the base consisting of nothingness and of the perception of the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception and of the perception of the base consisting of the infinity of space and of the perception of the base consisting of the infinity of consciousness.

original: vasena tassa arahattaphalassa kāraṇe anuppatte. Tappaccayāpi vedayitanti arahattassa
analyzed: vasena tassa arahatta phalassa kāraṇe an uppatte tad paccayā api vedayitanti arahattassa
translated: As regards the passage beginning, “When five are unabandoned,” feeling in the attainment of the base consisting of the infinity of space is due to the non-abandonment of the perception of the base consisting of nothingness and of the perception of the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception and of the perception of the base consisting of

original: ṭhānapaccayā vedayitaṃ. Etena catumaggasahajātā nibbattitalokuttaravedanāva gahitā.
analyzed: ṭhāna paccayā vedayitam etena catu magga sahajātā nibbattita lokuttara vedanā va gahitā
translated: thinking that it is too remote. This is what is meant by the words “feeling born of the path is included by the words ‘with a condition being a requisite’ .

original: 2. Dutiyavihārasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya vihāra sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The second section of the Discourse on the Kinds of Conduct is finished.

original: 12. Dutiye paṭisallānakāraṇaṃ vuttanayeneva veditabbaṃ. Micchādiṭṭhivūpasamapaccayāti
analyzed: dutiye paṭisallāna kāraṇam vutta nayena iva veditabbam micchādiṭṭhi vūpasama paccayā ti
translated: In the second, the reason for seclusion should be understood in the way already stated. With the stilling of wrong view as condition:🔽the stilling of wrong view is right view. So what is said with right view as condition should be understood here with the stilling of wrong view as condition. But in this sutta the feeling that is result is not mentioned,

original: micchādiṭṭhivūpasamo nāma sammādiṭṭhi. Tasmā yaṃ sammādiṭṭhipaccayā vedayitaṃ vuttaṃ,🔽tadeva micchādiṭṭhivūpasamapaccayā veditabbaṃ. Imasmiṃ pana sutte vipākavedanaṃ atidūreti
analyzed: micchādiṭṭhi vūpasamaḥ nāma sammādiṭṭhi tasmai yat sammādiṭṭhi paccayā vedayitam vuttam  tat eva micchādiṭṭhi vūpasama paccayā veditabbam imasmim pana sutte vipāka vedanam atidūra iti
translated: thinking that it is too remote. This is what is meant by the words “feeling born of the path is included by the words ‘with a condition being a requisite’ .🔽The second section of the Discourse on the Kinds of Conduct is finished.🔽In the second, the reason for seclusion should be understood in the way already stated. With the stilling of wrong view as condition:🔽the stilling of wrong view is right view. So what is said with right view as condition should be understood here with the stilling of wrong view as condition. But in this sutta the feeling that is result is not mentioned,

original: maññamānā na gaṇhantīti vuttaṃ. Iminā nayena sabbattha attho veditabbo. Yassa yassa🔽hi vūpasamapaccayāti vuccati, tassa tassa paṭipakkhadhammapaccayāva taṃ taṃ vedayitaṃ
analyzed: maññamānāḥ na gaṇhanti iti vuttam iminā nayena sabbattha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ yassa yassa  hi vūpasama paccayā ti vuccati tassa tassa paṭipakkha dhamma paccayā ava tam tam vedayitam
translated: thinking that it is too remote. This is what is meant by the words “feeling born of the path is included by the words ‘with a condition being a requisite’ .🔽The second section of the Discourse on the Kinds of Conduct is finished.🔽In the second, the reason for seclusion should be understood in the way already stated. With the stilling of wrong view as condition:🔽the stilling of wrong view is right view. So what is said with right view as condition should be understood here with the stilling of wrong view as condition. But in this sutta the feeling that is result is not mentioned,

original: adhippetaṃ. Chandavūpasamapaccayātiādīsu pana chandavūpasamapaccayā tāva paṭhamajjhānavedanā
analyzed: adhippetam chanda vūpasama paccayā tiādīsu pana chanda vūpasama paccayā tāva paṭhama jhāna vedanā
translated: thinking that it is too remote. This is what is meant by the words “feeling born of the

original: veditabbā. Vitakkavūpasamapaccayā dutiyajjhānavedanā. Saññāpaccayā chasamāpattivedanā.🔽Saññāvūpasamapaccayā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanavedanā. Chando ca vūpasantotiādīni vuttatthāneva.
analyzed: veditabbā vitakka vūpasama paccayā dutiya jhāna vedanā saññā paccayā cha samāpatti vedanā  saññā vūpasama paccayā nevasaññā nāsañña āyatana vedanā chando ca vūpasanto tiādīni vutta tthāni eva
translated: Feeling in the second jhāna is due to the condition of the stilling of applied thought. Feeling in the six attainments is due to the condition of perception.

original: 3-7. Sekkhasuttādivaṇṇanā🔽13-17. Tatiye sekkhoti sikkhanasīlo. Kiṃ sikkhatīti? Tisso sikkhā. Sekkhāyāti tīhi🔽phalehi catūhi ca maggehi saddhiṃ uppannāya. Sāpi hi aniṭṭhitakiccattā attano kiccaṃ
analyzed: tatiye sekkho ti sikkhana sīlo kim sikkhati iti tissaḥ sikkhā sekkhāya ati tīhi  phalehi catūhi ca maggehi saddhim uppannāya sā api hi aniṭṭhita kicca ttā attano kiccam
translated: Feeling in the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception is due to the condition of the stilling of perception. The meaning of the words “and the stilling of will” and so on has already been given.

original: sikkhatevāti sekkhā. Catutthapañcamachaṭṭhasattamāni uttānatthānevāti.🔽8-10. Paṭhamakukkuṭārāmasuttādivaṇṇanā🔽18-20. Aṭṭhame ummaṅgoti paññāummaṅgo, paññāvīmaṃsanaṃ, paññāgavesananti attho. Evañhi tvaṃ āvusoti idaṃ tassa pucchāpatiṭṭhāpanatthāya āha. Navamadasamāni uttānatthāmevāti.
analyzed: sikkhatā iva ati sekkhā catuttha pañcama chaṭṭha sattamāni uttāna tthānā iva ati            aṭṭhame ummaṅgo ti paññā ummaṅgo paññā vīmaṃsanam paññā gavesanam ti attho evam hi tvam āvuso ti idam tassa pucchā patiṭṭhāpana tthāya āha navama dasamāni uttāna tthām eva ati
translated: The explanation of the third, fourth, fifth, and seventh sikkhāpada is straightforward.🔽The explanation of the eighth sikkhāpada is straightforward.

original: Vihāravaggo dutiyo.🔽3. Micchattavaggavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vihāra vaggo dutiyo 🔽
translated: The explanation of the ninth sikkhāpada is straightforward.

original: 21-30. Tatiyavaggassa paṭhame micchattanti micchāsabhāvaṃ. Sammattanti sammāsabhāvaṃ.🔽Micchāpaṭipattādhikaraṇahetūti micchāpaṭipattikaraṇahetu. Yasmā micchāpaṭipattiṃ
analyzed: tatiya vaggassa paṭhame micchat tanti micchā sabhāvam sammat tanti sammā sabhāvam  micchā paṭipatta adhikaraṇa hetu uti micchā paṭipatti karaṇa hetu yasmai micchā paṭipattim
translated: In the first sutta of the third vagga , micchattanti micchāsabhāvaṃ = micchā is the nature of wrongness. Sammattanti sammāsabhāvaṃ = right is the nature of rightness.

original: karoti, tasmāti attho. Nārādhakoti na sampādako. Ñāyaṃ dhammanti ariyamaggadhammaṃ.
analyzed: karoti tasmā iti atthaḥ na ārādhako iti na sampādakaḥ ñāyam dhammanti ariya magga dhammaṃ
translated: Micchāpaṭipattādhikaraṇahetūti micchāpaṭipattikaraṇahetu = because of the reason for wrong practice. Because he practices wrongness, is the meaning. Nārādhako = he does not accomplish. Ñāyaṃ dhammanti ariyamaggadhammaṃ = the way of the Dhamma.

original: Micchāñāṇīti micchāviññāṇo micchāpaccavekkhaṇo. Micchāvimuttīti ayāthāvavimutti,
analyzed: micchāñāṇī iti micchā viññāṇaḥ micchā paccavekkhaṇaḥ micchā vimutti iti a yāthāva vimutti
translated: Micchāñāṇīti micchāviññāṇo micchāpaccavekkhaṇo = he has wrong knowledge, wrong perception, wrong reflection. Micchāvimuttīti ayāthāvavimutti = he has wrong liberation, liberation that is not in accordance with reality.

original: aniyyānikavimutti. Imesu tatiyādīsu catūsu suttesu vaṭṭavivaṭṭaṃ kathitaṃ, pacchimesu
analyzed: imesu tatiya ādīsu catūsu suttesu vaṭṭa vivaṭṭam kathitam pacchimesu
translated: In these three suttas, the round and the transcending of the round are explained. In the last two suttas,

original: panettha dvīsu puggalo pucchito dhammo vibhatto, evaṃ dhammena puggalo dassitoti.🔽Suppavattiyoti suppavattaniyo. Yathā icchiticchitaṃ disaṃ pavattento dhāvati, evaṃ
analyzed: pana ittha dvīsu puggalaḥ pucchitaḥ dhammo vibhattaḥ evam dhammena puggalaḥ dassito ti  su pavattiyaḥ ti su pavattaniyaḥ yathā icchiticchitam disam pavattentaḥ dhāvati evam
translated: the person is asked about and the Dhamma is explained. Thus the person is shown by means of the Dhamma.

original: pavattetuṃ sakkā hotīti attho. Saupanisaṃ saparikkhāranti sappaccayaṃ saparivāraṃ.
analyzed: pavattetum sakkā hoti iti attho sa upanisam sa parikkhāram ti sa paccayam sa parivāram
translated: Suppavattiyoti suppavattaniyo = it is to be practiced well. It is possible to practice it as one wishes, running in whatever direction one wishes, is the meaning. Saupanisaṃ saparikkhāranti sappaccayaṃ saparivāraṃ = it has conditions, it has requisites.

original: Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
analyzed: sesam sabbattha uttāna attham eva ati
translated: The rest is clear in all cases.

original: Micchattavaggo tatiyo.
analyzed: micchatta vaggaḥ tatiyaḥ
translated: The third chapter on Wrongness is finished.

original: 4. Paṭipattivaggavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paṭipatti vagga vaṇṇanā
translated: The chapter on practice

original: 31-40. Catutthe micchāpaṭipattinti ayāthāvapaṭipattiṃ. Micchāpaṭipannanti ayāthāvapaṭipannaṃ.
analyzed: catutthe micchā paṭipattim ti ayāthāva paṭipattim micchā paṭipannam ti ayāthāva paṭipannam
translated: In the fourth chapter: Wrong practice is unbeneficial practice. One with wrong practice is one with unbeneficial practice.🔽So one sutta is told in terms of the Dhamma, and one in terms of the person.

original: Iti ekaṃ suttaṃ dhammavasena kathitaṃ, ekaṃ puggalavasena. Apārā pāranti vaṭṭato🔽nibbānaṃ. Pāragāminoti ettha yepi pāraṅgatā, yepi gacchanti, yepi gamissanti, sabbe
analyzed: iti ekam suttam dhamma vasena kathitam ekam puggala vasena apārā pāranti vaṭṭataḥ  nibbānam pāra gāminaḥ ti ettha ye pi pāraṅgatāḥ ye pi gacchanti ye pi gamissanti sabbe
translated: The other shore is Nibbāna from the round of rebirths.

original: pāragāminotveva veditabbā.
analyzed: pāra gāminī uta eva veditabbā
translated: One who has gone to the other shore, one who is going, and one who will go should all be understood as one who has gone to the other shore.

original: Tīramevānudhāvatīti vaṭṭameva anudhāvati, vaṭṭe vicarati. Kaṇhanti akusaladhammaṃ.
analyzed: tīram eva anudhāvati iti vaṭṭam eva anudhāvati vaṭṭe vicarati kaṇhanti akusala dhammaṃ
translated: He runs only to the near shore: he runs only to the round of rebirths, he wanders only in the round of rebirths.🔽The black is unprofitable ideas.🔽The white is profitable ideas.

original: Sukkanti kusaladhammaṃ. Okā anokanti vaṭṭato nibbānaṃ. Āgammāti ārabbha sandhāya
analyzed: sukkanti kusala dhammam okā anokā ti vaṭṭataḥ nibbānam āgamma iti ārabbha sandhāya
translated: The near and the far: Nibbāna from the round of rebirths.🔽Having come: having approached, having taken as a basis, having depended on.🔽He would purify: he would make pure.

original: paṭicca. Pariyodapeyyāti parisuddhaṃ kareyya. Cittaklesehīti cittaṃ kilissāpentehi
analyzed: paṭicca pariyodapeyya ati parisuddham kareyya citta klesehi iti cittam kilissāpentehi
translated: By defilements of the mind: by hindrances that defile the mind.

original: nīvaraṇehi. Sambodhiyaṅgesūti sattasu bojjhaṅgesu.
analyzed: nīvaraṇehi sambodhiyaṅgesu iti sattasu bojjhaṅgesu
translated: In the enlightenment factors: in the seven enlightenment factors.

original: Sāmaññatthanti nibbānaṃ. Tañhi sāmaññena upagantabbato sāmaññatthoti vuccati. Brahmaññanti🔽seṭṭhabhāvaṃ. Brahmaññatthanti nibbānaṃ brahmaññena upagantabbato. Yattha yattha
analyzed: sāmañña atthanti nibbānam tat hi sāmaññena upagantabbataḥ sāmañña attho ti vuccati brahmaññanti  seṭṭha bhāvam brahmaññatthanti nibbānam brahmaññena upagantabbataḥ yattha yattha
translated: The “meaning of recluseship” is Nibbāna. For that is called the “meaning of recluseship” because it is to be reached by recluses. The “meaning of brahmanship” is

original: pana heṭṭhā ca imesu ca tīsu suttesu “rāgakkhayo”ti āgataṃ, tattha tattha arahattampi
analyzed: pana heṭṭhā ca imesu ca tīsu suttesu rāga kkhayo ti āgatam tattha tattha arahattam pi
translated: the state of being supreme. The “meaning of brahmanship” is Nibbāna. For that is called the “meaning of brahmanship” because it is to be reached by brahmans. But wherever in the three suttantas below the “destruction of lust” is given,

original: vaṭṭatiyevāti vadanti.
analyzed: vaṭṭatiyā iva iti vadanti
translated: there arahantship is also included, they say.

original: Paṭipattivaggo catuttho.
analyzed: paṭipatti vaggo catutthaḥ
translated: The fourth vagga is finished.

original: 5. Aññatitthiyapeyyālavaggavaṇṇanā🔽41-48. Aññatitthiyapeyyāle addhānapariññatthanti saṃsāraddhānaṃ nibbānaṃ patvā pariññātaṃ🔽nāma hoti. Tasmā nibbānaṃ “addhānapariññā”ti vuccati, tadatthanti attho. Anupādāparinibbānatthanti
analyzed: añña titthiya peyyāla vagga vaṇṇanā  añña titthiya peyyāle saṃsāra ddhānam nibbānam patvā pariññātam  nāma hoti tasmā nibbānam addhāna pariññā ti vuccati tad atthanti atthaḥ anupādā parinibbāna atthanti
translated: The section on the questions of the sectarians

original: apaccayaparinibbānatthaṃ. Iti imasmiṃ peyyāle vijjāvimuttiphalena arahattaṃ kathitaṃ.
analyzed: a paccaya parinibbāna attham iti imasmin peyyāle vijjā vimutti phalena arahattam kathitam
translated: In the questions of the sectarians, the “meaning of the end of the path” is Nibbāna, which is called the “end of the path” because it is the end of the path of samsara. Therefore Nibbāna is called the “end of the path.” The “meaning of that” is the meaning of Nibbāna. The “meaning of final Nibbāna without clinging” is the meaning of Nibbāna without conditions. Thus in this section the fruit of the knowledge and vision of liberation is arahantship.

original: Ñāṇadassanena paccavekkhaṇā, sesehi nibbānanti.
analyzed: ñāṇa dassanena paccavekkhaṇā sesehi nibbānam ti
translated: The contemplation is by knowledge and vision, and the rest are Nibbāna.

original: Aññatitthiyapeyyālavaggo.
analyzed: añña titthiya peyyāla vaggo
translated: The section on the questions of the sectarians.

original: 6. Sūriyapeyyālavaggavaṇṇanā🔽49-62. Sūriyapeyyāle aruṇuggaṃ viya kalyāṇamittattā, kalyāṇamittatāya ṭhatvā nibbattito🔽savipassanaariyamaggo sūriyapātubhāvo viyāti evaṃ sabbattha attho veditabbo. Sīlasampadāti
analyzed: sūriya peyyāle aruṇuggam viya kalyāṇa mitta ttā kalyāṇa mitta tāya ṭhatvā nibbattitaḥ  sa vipassana ariya maggo sūriya pātubhāvaḥ viyā ti evam sabbattha atthaḥ veditabbaḥ sīla sampadā ti
translated: 6. The Sun-simile

original: catupārisuddhisīlaṃ. Chandasampadāti kusalakattukamyatāchando. Attasampadāti sampannacittatā.
analyzed: catu pārisuddhi sīlam chanda sampadā ati kusala kattu kamya tā chandaḥ atta sampadā ati sampanna citta tā
translated: In the Sun-simile, the good friend is like the sun’s rising, and the path of insight leading to the noble paths is like the sun’s appearance. The meaning should be understood in this way in all cases. The perfection of virtue is the virtue of the fourfold purification. The perfection of desire is the desire to do what is skillful. The perfection of self is the perfection of mind.

original: Diṭṭhisampadāti ñāṇasampatti. Appamādasampadāti kārāpakaappamādasampatti. Yonisomanasikārasampadāti🔽upāyamanasikārasampatti. Puna kalyāṇamittatātiādīni sammādiṭṭhiādīnaṃ aññenapi ākārena
analyzed: diṭṭhi sampadā ati ñāṇa sampatti appamāda sampadā ati kārāpaka appamāda sampatti yoniso manasikāra sampadā ati  upāya manasikāra sampatti sammādiṭṭhi ādīnam aññena api ākārena
translated: The perfection of view is the perfection of knowledge. The perfection of energy is the perfection of indefatigability. The perfection of attention is the perfection of skillful attention.

original: bhāvadassanatthaṃ vuttāni. Sabbāneva cetāni suttāni pāṭiyekkaṃ puggalajjhāsayavasena vuttānīti.🔽Sūriyapeyyālavaggo.
analyzed: bhāva dassana tham vuttāni sabbāneva cetāni suttāni pāṭiyekkam puggala jhāsaya vasena vuttāni iti  sūriya peyyāla vaggo
translated: Again, the good friend and the rest are mentioned in order to show the existence of right view and the rest in another way. And all these suttas are spoken in terms of the inclinations of individuals.🔽The Sun-simile

original: 7. Ekadhammapeyyālavaggādivaṇṇanā
translated: The Single Quality, etc.

original: 63-138. Ekadhammapeyyālopi gaṅgāpeyyālopi pāṭiyekkaṃ puggalajjhāsayavaseneva tathā tathā vutte bujjhanakānaṃ ajjhāsayavasena kathito.
analyzed: eka dhamma peyyālopi gaṅgā peyyālopi pāṭiyekkam puggala jhāsaya vasena iva tathā tathā vutte bujjhanakānam ajjhāsaya vasena kathitaḥ
translated: The Single-Precept and the Ganges Pericope are also spoken of in this way, each according to the individual’s disposition to understand, as in the case of the Single-Trait Discourse.

original: 8. Appamādapeyyālavaggo
analyzed: appamāda peyyāla vaggaḥ
translated: The Chapter on the Pericope on Heedfulness

original: 1. Tathāgatasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tathāgata sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Discourse on the Tathāgata

original: 139. Appamādapeyyāle evameva khoti ettha yathā sabbasattānaṃ sammāsambuddho aggo,
analyzed: appamāda peyyāle evam eva kho ti ettha yathā sabba sattānam sammāsambuddhaḥ aggaḥ
translated: In the Pericope on Heedfulness, in the passage beginning “Just so, bhikkhus,” the Blessed One shows that just as the Perfectly Enlightened One is the foremost of all beings,

original: evaṃ sabbesaṃ kusaladhammānaṃ kārāpakaappamādo aggoti daṭṭhabbo. Nanu cesa lokiyova,
analyzed: evam sabbesam kusala dhammānam kārāpaka appamādaḥ aggaḥ ti daṭṭhabbaḥ nanu ca isa lokiyaḥ uva
translated: so heedfulness, which is the doer of all profitable things, is the foremost of all profitable things. But is not heedfulness itself a profitable thing?

original: kusaladhammā pana lokuttarāpi. Ayañca kāmāvacarova, kusaladhammā pana catubhūmakā.
analyzed: kusala dhammā pana lokuttarā api ayam ca kāmāvacarā uva kusala dhammā pana catu bhūmakā
translated: Yes, but it is a mundane profitable thing, whereas the profitable things mentioned here are supramundane. And this heedfulness belongs to the sense sphere, whereas the profitable things belong to the four paths.

original: Kathamesa tesaṃ aggoti? Paṭilābhakaṭṭhena. Appamādena hi te paṭilabbhanti, tasmā
analyzed: katham esa tesam aggaḥ ti paṭilābhaka ṭṭhena appamādena hi te paṭilabbhanti tasmā
translated: How then is it the foremost of them? By way of acquisition. For it is by means of heedfulness that they are acquired.

original: so tesaṃ aggo. Tenetaṃ vuttaṃ sabbe te appamādamūlakātiādi.
analyzed: so tesam aggaḥ tena itam vuttam sabbe te appamāda mūlaka ati ādi
translated: Therefore it is said: “All these things have heedfulness as their root” .

original: 2. Padasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Discourse on the Word

original: 140. Jaṅgalānanti pathavītalavāsīnaṃ. Pāṇānanti sapādakapāṇānaṃ. Padajātānīti padāni.
analyzed: pathavī tala vāsīnam pāṇānanti pada jātāni iti padāni
translated: “Creatures that move on feet” : those that live on the ground and have feet. “Creatures that move on two feet” : humans and birds. “Creatures that move on four feet” : cattle, etc.

original: Samodhānaṃ gacchantīti odhānaṃ upakkhepaṃ gacchanti. Aggamakkhāyatīti seṭṭhaṃ akkhāyati.
analyzed: samodhānam gacchanti iti odhānam upakkhepam gacchanti aggam akkhāyati iti seṭṭham akkhāyati
translated: “They go to the storing”: they go to the storing up, the heaping up. “It is called the best”: it is called the foremost.

original: Yadidaṃ mahantattenāti mahantabhāvena aggamakkhāyati, na guṇavasenāti attho.
analyzed: yat idam mahanta ttena ati mahanta bhāvena aggam akkhāyati na guṇa vasena ati atthaḥ
translated: “Because of its greatness”: it is called the foremost because of its greatness, not because of its excellence, is the meaning.

original: 3-10. Kūṭasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: kūṭa sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Vassakara Sutta

original: 141-148. Vassikanti sumanapupphaṃ. Imaṃ kira suttaṃ sutvā bhātiyamahārājā vīmaṃsitukāmatāya
analyzed: vassikanti sumana puppham imam kira suttam sutvā bhātiya mahā rājā vīmaṃsitu kāma tāya
translated: Vassakara means a jasmine flower. It seems that after hearing this sutta, King Pasenadi of Kosala,

original: ekasmiṃ gabbhe catujātigandhehi paribhaṇḍaṃ kāretvā sugandhāni pupphāni āharāpetvā
analyzed: ekasmin gabbhe catu jāti gandhehi paribhaṇḍam kāretvā su gandhāni pupphāni āharāpetvā
translated: desiring to investigate the matter, had a room plastered with the four kinds of fragrant substances. He had fragrant flowers brought in,

original: ekassa samuggassa majjhe sumanapupphamuṭṭhiṃ ṭhapetvā sesāni tassa samantato muṭṭhimuṭṭhiṃ
analyzed: ekassa samuggassa majjhe sumana puppha muṭṭhim ṭhapetvā sesāni tassa samantataḥ muṭṭhi muṭṭhim
translated: placed a handful of jasmine flowers in the middle of the room, and placed a handful of other flowers all around them.

original: katvā ṭhapetvā dvāraṃ pidhāya bahi nikkhanto. Athassa muhuttaṃ vītināmetvā dvāraṃ
analyzed: katvā ṭhapetvā dvāram pidhāya bahi nikkhantaḥ athassa muhuttam vītināmetvā dvāram
translated: Then he closed the door and went outside. After a while he opened the door

original: vivaritvā pavisantassa sabbapaṭhamaṃ sumanapupphagandho ghānaṃ pahari. So mahātalasmiṃyeva
analyzed: vivaritvā pavisantassa sabba paṭhamam sumana puppha gandho so mahā talasmiṃ yā iva
translated: and entered. The first scent he smelled was that of the jasmine flowers. He was so delighted🔽that he had a jasmine flower garden laid out on the spot.

original: mahācetiyābhimukho nipajjitvā – “vassikaṃ tesaṃ agganti kathentena sukathitaṃ sammāsambuddhenā”ti🔽cetiyaṃ vandi. Kuṭṭarājānoti khuddakarājāno. “Khuddarājāno”tipi pāṭho. Tantāvutānanti
analyzed: mahā cetiya abhimukhaḥ nipajjitvā vassikam tesam aggam ti kathentena su kathitam sammāsambuddhena ati  cetiyam kuṭṭa rājāno ti khuddaka rājāno khudda rājāno tipi
translated: and lying down facing the Great Shrine, he worshipped the Shrine, saying: “Well proclaimed by the Well-Farer is the rainy-season residence, since they make it the rainy-season residence’s end.”🔽The king of the small countries: the reading is also khuddakarājāno . Woven:

original: tante āvutānaṃ, tantaṃ āropetvā vāyitānanti attho. Idañca paccatte sāmivacanaṃ. Yāni🔽kānici tantāvutāni vatthānīti ayañhettha attho. Atha vā tantāvutānaṃ vatthānaṃ yāni
analyzed: tante tantam āropetvā vāyitānam ti atthaḥ idam ca paccatte sāmivacanam yāni  kānici tantāvutāni vatthāni iti ayam ha ittha atthaḥ atha vā tantāvutānam vatthānam yāni
translated: woven on a loom; the meaning is, made by being drawn out on a loom. And this is a possessive genitive. The meaning here is:

original: kānici vatthānīti evaṃ sāvasesapāṭhanayenapettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: kānici vatthāni iti evam sa avasesa pāṭhanayena pa ittha attho daṭṭhabbo sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: whatever kinds of cloth there are that are woven. Or alternatively, the meaning here can be regarded as: whatever kinds of cloth there are of the kinds of cloth that are woven. The rest is clear in all its aspects.

original: Appamādavaggo aṭṭhamo.🔽9. Balakaraṇīyavaggo
analyzed: appamāda vaggaḥ aṭṭhamaḥ  bala karaṇīya vaggo
translated: The eighth chapter is finished.🔽The chapter on exertion

original: 1. Balasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: bala sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Sutta on Exertion

original: 149. Balakaraṇīyavagge balakaraṇīyāti ūrubalabāhubalena kattabbā dhāvanalaṅghanatāpanavahanādayo
analyzed: bala karaṇīya vagge bala karaṇīyā ati ūru bala bāhu balena kattabbāḥ dhāvana laṅghana tāpana vahana ādayaḥ
translated: In the chapter on exertion, exertion is what should be done by the power of the thighs and the power of the arms, such as running, jumping, swimming, carrying loads, etc.

original: kammantā. Sīle patiṭṭhāyāti catupārisuddhisīle ṭhatvā. Aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ magganti sahavipassanaṃ ariyamaggaṃ.
analyzed: kammantā sīle patiṭṭhāya ati catu pārisuddhi sīle ṭhatvā aṭṭhaṅgikam magganti saha vipassanam ariya maggaṃ
translated: and work. Having established virtue: having established the virtue of the fourfold purity. The eight-factored path: the noble path together with insight.

original: 2. Bījasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: bīja sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Bīja Sutta.

original: 150. Bījagāmabhūtagāmāti ettha pañcavidhampi bījaṃ bījagāmo nāma, tadeva paṇṇasampannaṃ nīlabhāvato paṭṭhāya bhūtagāmoti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: bījagāma bhūtagāmā ti ettha pañcavidham pi bījam bījagāmaḥ nāma tat eva paṇṇa sampannam nīla bhāvataḥ paṭṭhāya bhūtagāmaḥ ti veditabbam
translated: As to “seed-village and plant-village”: the five kinds of seed are called the “seed-village”; and that same seed when it has leaves is called the “plant-village” from the time when it is blue-green.

original: 3. Nāgasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: nāga sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Nāga Sutta.

original: 151. Balaṃ gāhentīti balaṃ gaṇhanti, gahitabalā thirasarīrā honti. Kusobbhe otarantītiādīsu
analyzed: balam gāhenti iti balam gaṇhanti gahita balāḥ thira sarīrāḥ honti kusobbhe otaranti itiādīsu
translated: They take strength: they take strength, they have strong bodies. They enter the lotus pools:

original: ayamanupubbikathā – nāginiyo kira utusamaye patiṭṭhitagabbhā cintenti – “sace mayaṃ🔽idha vijāyissāma, evaṃ no dārakā ūmivegañca supaṇṇassa ca pakkhanditvā āgatassa vegaṃ
analyzed: ayam anupubbi kathā nāginiyaḥ kira utu samaye patiṭṭhita gabbhāḥ cintenti sace mayam  idha vijāyissāma evam naḥ dārakāḥ ūmi vegañca supaṇṇassa ca pakkhanditvā āgatassa vegaṃ
translated: Here is the story. The nāga-females, it seems, when their time of heat has arrived, think “If we give birth here,

original: sahituṃ na sakkhissantī”ti tā mahāsamudde nimujjitvā sambhajjamukhadvāraṃ patvā pañca
analyzed: sahitum na sakkhissanti iti tāḥ mahā samudde nimujjitvā sambhajja mukha dvāram patvā pañca
translated: our young will not be able to endure the force of the wind from the clouds and the force of the wind of the garuḍas when they swoop down” . They dive into the great ocean, reach the mouth of the river Sambhājā, and give birth there.

original: mahānadiyo pavisitvā himavantaṃ gacchanti. Tattha supaṇṇehi apakkhandanīyāsu suvaṇṇarajatamaṇiguhāsu
analyzed: mahā nadiyaḥ pavisitvā himavantam gacchanti tattha su paṇṇehi a pakkhandanīyāsu suvaṇṇa rajata maṇi guhāsu
translated: and enter the great rivers, and go to the Himalayas. There, in the golden, silver, and gem caves, which are inaccessible to the Supaṇṇas,

original: vasamānā vijāyitvā nāgapotake gopphakādipamāṇesu udakesu otāretvā udakataraṇaṃ sikkhāpenti.
analyzed: vasamānāḥ vijāyitvā nāga potake gopphaka ādi pamāṇesu udakesu otāretvā udaka taraṇam sikkhāpenti
translated: they live, and give birth to their young. When the young are the size of a gopphaka, they put them in the water and teach them to swim.

original: Atha yadā anukkamena te nāgā gaṅgādīnaṃ nadīnaṃ orimatīrato paratīraṃ, paratīrato🔽orimatīranti taraṇapaṭitaraṇaṃ kātuṃ sakkonti, tadā “idāni no dārakā ūmivegañca garuḷavegañca
analyzed: atha yadā anukkamena te nāgāḥ gaṅgā dīnam nadīnam para tīram para tīrataḥ  taraṇa paṭitaraṇam kātum sakkonti tadā idāni naḥ dārakāḥ ūmi vegam ca garuḷa vegam ca
translated: Then, when the nāgas are able to cross the rivers, such as the Ganges, from the near to the far shore, and from the far to the near shore,

original: sahituṃ sakkhissantī”ti ñatvā attano ānubhāvena mahāmeghaṃ samuṭṭhāpetvā sakalahimavantaṃ🔽ekodakaṃ viya kurumānā devaṃ vassāpetvā suvaṇṇarajatādimayā nāvā māpetvā upari suvaṇṇatārakavicittaṃ
analyzed: sahitum sakkhissanti iti ñatvā attanaḥ ānubhāvena mahā megham samuṭṭhāpetvā sakala himavantam  eka udakam viya kurumānā devam suvaṇṇa rajata ādi mayā nāvā māpetvā upari suvaṇṇa tāraka vicittam
translated: they know, “Now our young will be able to bear the speed of the wind and the speed of the Supaṇṇas,” and by their own power they cause a great cloud to arise, and making the whole Himalayas like one great lake,🔽they cause rain to fall, and have boats made of gold, silver, and so on. Above, they tie a canopy of cloth decorated with golden stars,

original: samosaritagandhapupphadāmaṃ celavitānaṃ bandhitvā surabhicandanagandhapupphādīni
analyzed: samosarita gandha puppha dāmam cela vitānam bandhitvā surabhi candana gandha puppha ādīni
translated: and hang garlands of fragrant sandal-wood flowers and so on.

original: ādāya tāhi nāvāhi pañca mahānadiyo ogāhitvā anukkamena mahāsamuddaṃ pāpuṇanti. Tattha
analyzed: ādāya tāhi nāvāhi pañca mahā nadiyaḥ ogāhitvā anukkamena mahā samuddam pāpuṇanti tattha
translated: and they enter the five great rivers, and in due course they reach the great ocean.

original: ca vasantā dasabyāma-satabyāma-sahassabyāma-satasahassabyāma-pamāṇataṃ āpajjantā
analyzed: ca vasantā dasa byāma sata byāma sahassa byāma sata sahassa byāma pamāṇataḥ āpajjantā
translated: And while they are there, they attain to a size of ten leagues, a hundred leagues, a thousand leagues, a hundred thousand leagues,

original: mahantattaṃ vepullattaṃ āpajjanti nāma.
analyzed: mahantattam vepullattam āpajjanti nāma
translated: and they attain to greatness and abundance.

original: Evameva khoti ettha himavantapabbato viya catupārisuddhisīlaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ, nāgapotakā
analyzed: evam eva kho ti ettha himavanta pabbataḥ viya catu pārisuddhi sīlam daṭṭhabbam nāga potakā
translated: So too, here, the fourfold purification of virtue should be regarded as the Himalaya, the elephant-cubs as the meditators,

original: viya yogāvacarā, kusobbhādayo viya ariyamaggo, mahāsamuddo viya nibbānaṃ. Yathā nāgapotakā
analyzed: viya yogāvacarā kusobbha ādayaḥ viya ariya maggaḥ mahā samuddaḥ viya nibbānam yathā nāga potakā
translated: the lotus-pools, etc., as the noble path, and Nibbāna as the great ocean. Just as the elephant-cubs,

original: himavante patiṭṭhāya kusobbhādīhi mahāsamuddaṃ patvā kāyamahantattaṃ āpajjanti, evaṃ🔽yogino sīlaṃ nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariyamaggena nibbānaṃ patvā arahattamaggeneva
analyzed: himavante patiṭṭhāya kusobbha ādīhi mahā samuddam patvā kāya mahanta ttam āpajjanti evam  yoginaḥ sīlam nissāya sīle patiṭṭhāya ariya maggena nibbānam patvā arahatta maggena iva
translated: after establishing themselves in the Himalaya, reach the great ocean by means of the lotus-pools, etc., and attain to a size in their bodies,

original: āgatesu chasu abhiññādhammesu guṇasarīramahantattaṃ pāpuṇantīti.
analyzed: āgatesu chasu abhiññā dhammesu guṇa sarīra mahantattam pāpuṇanti iti
translated: so too, the meditators, after depending on virtue and establishing themselves in virtue, reach Nibbāna by means of the noble path and attain to greatness in the body of special qualities, namely, the six kinds of direct knowledge and the four discriminations, which they reach by means of the path of arahatship.

original: 5. Kumbhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: kumbha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Exposition of the Sutta on the Pot

original: 153. Kumbhoti udakaghaṭo. No paccāvamatīti na patiāvamati, na anto pavesetīti attho.
analyzed: kumbho ti udaka ghaṭaḥ no paccāvamati iti na pati āvamati na antar paveseti iti attho
translated: A water-pot is a pot for water. It does not overflow: it does not overflow, the meaning is, it does not let in more water.

original: 7. Ākāsasuttavaṇṇanā🔽155. Puratthimāti puratthimadisato āgatavātā. Pacchimadisādīsupi eseva nayo. Cattāropi
analyzed: ākāsa sutta vaṇṇanā  puratthimā ati puratthima disataḥ āgata vātā pacchima disa ādīsu pi esa iva nayo cattāro api
translated: The explanation of the Sky Simile Thread🔽East: the winds that have come from the eastern direction. The same method applies to the southern direction, etc.

original: satipaṭṭhānāti yatheva hi etesaṃ puratthimādibhedānaṃ vātānaṃ sannipāto ākāse ijjhati,🔽evaṃ idhāpi “cattāro satipaṭṭhānā”tiādinā nayena vuttā bodhipakkhiyadhammā sahavipassanassa
analyzed: sati paṭṭhānā iti yathā iva hi etesam puratthima ādi bhedānam vātānam sannipātaḥ ākāse ijjhati  evam idha api cattāro sati paṭṭhāna ati ādinā nayena vuttāḥ bodhi pakkhiya dhammā saha vipassanassa
translated: Four foundations of mindfulness: just as the meeting of these winds, classified as east, etc., is possible in the sky,

original: ariyamaggassa bhāvanāya ijjhanti, tenetaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ariya maggassa bhāvanāya ijjhanti tena itam vuttam
translated: so too the states called “four foundations of mindfulness” and so on, which are described in the way beginning, “Here a bhikkhu dwells contemplating the body as a body” , are possible in the development of the noble path together with insight. That is why this is said.

original: 8-9. Paṭhamameghasuttādivaṇṇanā🔽156-157. Gimhānaṃ pacchime māseti āsāḷhamāse. Ūhatanti dvipadacatuppadānaṃ pādappahārena
analyzed: gimhānam pacchime māse iti āsāḷha māse ūhatanti dvipada catuppadānam pāda ppahārena
translated: The explanation of the First Cloud Simile Thread

original: pathavītale uṭṭhahitvā uddhaṃ gataṃ vaṭṭivaṭṭi hutvā ākāse pakkhantaṃ. Rajojallanti paṃsurajojallaṃ.
analyzed: pathavī tale uṭṭhahitvā uddham gatam vaṭṭi vaṭṭi hutvā ākāse pakkhantam rajojallanti paṃsu rajojallam
translated: In the last month of the rainy season: in the month of Āsāḷhā . It rises up: it rises up from the surface of the earth by the force of the feet of the two-footed and four-footed creatures, and it goes up into the sky in the form of a spiral. Dust-haze: dust-haze consisting of dust.

original: 10. Nāvāsuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Boat Simile Thread

original: 158. Sāmuddikāya nāvāyātiādi heṭṭhā vāṇijakopame vitthāritameva.
analyzed: sāmuddikāya nāvāya ati ādi heṭṭhā vāṇijaka upame vitthāritam eva
translated: The ship from across the sea, etc., are given in detail in the Merchant’s Son as a simile for the spiritual teacher.

original: 11-12. Āgantukasuttādivaṇṇanā🔽159-160. Āgantukāgāranti puññatthikehi nagaramajjhe kataṃ āgantukagharaṃ, yattha
analyzed: āgantuka sutta ādi vaṇṇanā  āgantuka āgāram ti puññatthikehi nagara majjhe katam āgantuka gharam
translated: The description of the “Visitors’ Quarters” sutta, etc.,

original: rājarājamahāmattehipi sakkā hoti nivāsaṃ upagantuṃ. Abhiññā pariññeyyāti yatheva🔽hi tesaṃ puratthimadisādīhi āgatānaṃ khattiyādīnaṃ vāso āgantukāgāre ijjhati, evaṃ🔽imesaṃ abhiññāpariññeyyātiādīnaṃ dhammānaṃ abhiññāparijānanādīhi sahavipassanassa
analyzed: rāja rāja mahāmattehi pi sakkā hoti nivāsam upagantum abhiññā pariññeyyā ati yathā iva  hi tesam puratthima disā ādīhi āgatānam khattiya ādīnam vāsaḥ āgantuka āgāre ijjhati evam  imesam dhammānam abhiññā parijānana ādīhi saha vipassanassa
translated: The “visitors’ quarters” is a building put up in the middle of a town by people who want to make merit, where it is possible for kings and royal ministers to stay overnight too.

original: ariyamaggassa bhāvanāya ijjhanti, tenetaṃ vuttaṃ. Nadīsuttaṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayamevāti.
analyzed: ariya maggassa bhāvanāya ijjhanti tena itam vuttam nadīsuttam heṭṭhā vutta nayam eva ati
translated: “Should be fully known by direct knowledge”: just as it is possible for the nobles, etc., who have come from the eastern direction, etc., to stay in the visitors’ quarters, so too it is possible for one who develops the noble path with insight by means of direct-knowledge, full-understanding, etc., of the states beginning with “those that should be directly known by direct knowledge.” That is why it is said. The River sutta is given in the same way as above.

original: Balakaraṇīyavaggo navamo.🔽10. Esanāvaggo
analyzed: balakaraṇīya vaggaḥ navamaḥ  esanā vaggaḥ
translated: The ninth chapter is concluded.🔽THE CHAPTER ABOUT SEARCHES

original: 1. Esanāsuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Sutta on Searches

original: 161. Esanāvagge kāmesanāti kāmānaṃ esanā gavesanā magganā patthanā. Bhavesanāti bhavānaṃ esanā. Brahmacariyesanāti micchādiṭṭhisaṅkhātassa brahmacariyassa esanā.
analyzed: esanā vagge kāma īsanā ati kāmānam esanā gavesanā magganā patthanā bhava īsanā ati bhavānam esanā brahmacariya īsanā ati micchādiṭṭhi saṅkhātassa brahmacariyassa esanā
translated: In the chapter on seeking: Seeking for sensual desires is the seeking for, searching for, seeking out, of sensual desires. Seeking for being is the seeking for, searching for, seeking out, of kinds of becoming. Seeking for a rite and ritual is the seeking for, searching for, seeking out, of a rite and ritual that is a wrong view.

original: 2-11. Vidhāsuttādivaṇṇanā🔽162-171. Vidhāti mānakoṭṭhāsā mānaṭhapanā vā. Seyyohamasmīti vidhāti ahamasmi seyyoti🔽evaṃ mānakoṭṭhāso mānaṭhapanā vā. Nīghāti dukkhā. Vacanattho panettha yassa uppajjanti,🔽taṃ purisaṃ nīhanantīti nīghā. Sesamettha uttānamevāti.🔽Esanāvaggo dasamo.
analyzed: vidhā sutta ādi vaṇṇanā  vidhāti māna koṭṭhāsā māna ṭhapanā vā seyyā uham asmi iti vidhāti aham asmi seyyā uti  evam māna koṭṭhāsaḥ māna ṭhapanā vā dukkhā vacana atthaḥ pana ittha yassa uppajjanti  tam purisam nīhananti iti nīghā sesam ettha uttānam eva ati  esanā vaggaḥ dasamaḥ
translated: The explanation of the “Rites” chapter is finished.

original: 11. Oghavaggo🔽1-2. Oghasuttādivaṇṇanā🔽172-173. Oghavagge kāmoghoti pañcasu kāmaguṇesu chandarāgo. Bhavoghoti rūpārūpabhavesu🔽chandarāgo. Diṭṭhoghoti dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyo. Avijjoghoti catūsu saccesu aññāṇaṃ. Kāmayogādīsupi eseva nayo.🔽3-4. Upādānasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: ogha vaggaḥ 🔽ogha sutta ādi vaṇṇanā 🔽ogha vagge kāma oghaḥ iti pañcasu kāmaguṇesu chanda rāgaḥ bhava oghaḥ iti rūpa arūpa bhavesu 🔽chanda rāgaḥ diṭṭhogho ti dvāsaṭṭhi diṭṭhiyaḥ avijjogho ti catūsu saccesu aññāṇam kāma yoga ādīsu pi esa eva nayo 🔽upādāna sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: “Rites” : the bases for conceit or the conceivings. “I am better” : the base for conceit or the conceiving is “I am better than”. “I am equal” : the base for conceit or the conceiving is “I am equal”. “I am worse” : the base for conceit or the conceiving is “I am worse”. “I am” : the base for conceit or the conceiving is “I am”. “I shall be” : the base for conceit or the conceiving is “I shall be”. “I shall not be” : the base for conceit or the conceiving is “I shall not be”. “I shall have a self” : the base for conceit or the conceiving is “I shall have a self”. “I shall not have a self” : the base for conceit or the conceiving is “I shall not have a self”. “I shall be with form” : the base for conceit or the conceiving is “I shall be with form”. “I shall be formless” : the base for conceit or the conceiving is “I shall be formless”. “I shall be percipient” : the base for conceit or the conceiving is “I shall be percipient”. “I shall be non-percipient” : the base for conceit or the conceiving is “I shall be non-percipient”. “I shall be neither percipient nor non-percipient” : the base for conceit or the conceiving is “I shall be neither percipient nor non-percipient”. “I shall be” : the base for conceit or the conceiving is “I shall be”. “I shall not be” : the base for conceit or the conceiving is “I shall not be”. “I shall have a self” : the base for conceit or the conceiving is “I shall have a self”. “I shall not have a self” : the base for conceit or the conceiving is “I shall not have a self”. “I shall be with form” : the base for conceit

original: 174-175. Kāmupādānanti kāmaggahaṇaṃ. Diṭṭhupādānādīsupi eseva nayo. Ganthāti ganthanā🔽ghaṭanā. Kāyaganthoti nāmakāyassa gantho ganthanaghaṭanakileso. Idaṃsaccābhinivesoti
analyzed: kāma upādānam ti kāma ggahaṇam diṭṭha upādāna ādīsu pi esā iva nayaḥ ganthā ati ganthanā  ghaṭanā kāya gantho ti nāma kāyassa ganthaḥ ganthana ghaṭana kilesaḥ idaṃsacca abhiniveso ti
translated: “Clinging to sense pleasures” is the grasping of sense desires. The same method applies to the other kinds of clinging. “Bondage” is the binding, the fettering. “Bondage of the body” is the fetter, the defilement, that binds the mental body. “Adherence to rules and observances” is the adherence to the view that “This is the pure way, this is the pure way” .

original: antaggāhikadiṭṭhivasena uppanno “idameva sacca”nti evaṃ abhiniveso.
analyzed: antaggāhika diṭṭhi vasena uppannaḥ idam eva saccanti evam abhiniveso
translated: “Clinging to sense pleasures” is the grasping of sense desires. The same method applies in the case of clinging to views, etc. “Fetters” : the binding, the binding together. “Body-fetter” : the fetter, the binding, the binding together, of the mental body. “Adherence to rules and observances” : the adherence thus, “This alone is the truth,” which arises with the view that grasps an extreme.

original: 5-10. Anusayasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: anusaya sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary on the Susīma Sutta, etc.🔽. Commentary on the Kāmarāgānusaya Sutta, etc.

original: 176-181. Kāmarāgānusayoti thāmagataṭṭhena kāmarāgova anusayo kāmarāgānusayo. Sesesupi🔽eseva nayo. Orambhāgiyānīti heṭṭhākoṭṭhāsiyāni. Saṃyojanānīti bandhanāni. Uddhambhāgiyānīti
analyzed: kāma rāga anusayo ti thāma gata ṭṭhena kāma rāgaḥ uva anusayo kāma rāga anusayo sesesu pi  esa iva nayaḥ orambhāgiyāni iti heṭṭhākoṭṭhāsiyāni saṃyojanāni iti bandhanāni uddhambhāgiyāni iti
translated: . Commentary on the Orambhāgiya Sutta, etc.

original: uparikoṭṭhāsiyāni. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
analyzed: upari koṭṭhāsiyāni sesam sabbattha uttāna attham eva ati
translated: . Commentary on the Uddhambhāgiya Sutta, etc.

original: Oghavaggo ekādasamo.
analyzed: ogha vaggaḥ ekādasamaḥ
translated: The eleventh chapter

original: Maggasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: magga saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Magga Saṃyutta is finished.

original: 2. Bojjhaṅgasaṃyuttaṃ🔽1. Pabbatavaggo
analyzed: bojjhaṅga saṃyuttam  pabbata vaggaḥ
translated: The Connected Discourses with the Factors of Awakening🔽The Chapter with Pabbatavagga

original: 1. Himavantasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Sutta on the Himalayas

original: 182. Bojjhaṅgasaṃyuttassa paṭhame nāgāti imepi mahāsamuddapiṭṭhe ūmiantaravāsinova,
analyzed: bojjhaṅga saṃyuttassa paṭhame nāgā ti ime pi mahā samudda piṭṭhe ūmi antara vāsinaḥ vā
translated: In the first sutta in the Factors of Awakening, “elephants” are those that live in the water between the waves on the bottom of the great ocean.

original: na vimānaṭṭhakanāgā. Tesaṃ himavantaṃ nissāya kāyavaḍḍhanādisabbaṃ heṭṭhā vuttanayeneva
analyzed: na vimāna aṭṭhaka nāgā tesam himavantam nissāya kāya vaḍḍhana ādi sabbam heṭṭhā vutta nayena eva
translated: not the elephants of the mansions. For their growth of body, etc., should be understood in all ways according to the method stated above in the case of the Himalayas.🔽The factors of enlightenment: here, as to the word bodhi , it is enlightenment because one awakens to the truths, or it is enlightenment because one awakens to the Dhamma of the path, or it is enlightenment because one awakens from the sleep of defilements.🔽For this is said: “Enlightenment is the supreme state of loneliness, the supreme state of coolness” .🔽The factors of enlightenment are factors of that enlightenment, thus they are enlightenment factors .

original: veditabbaṃ. Bojjhaṅgeti ettha bodhiyā, bodhissa vā aṅgāti bojjhaṅgā. Kiṃ vuttaṃ hoti?🔽Yā hi ayaṃ dhammasāmaggī, yāya lokiyalokuttaramaggakkhaṇe uppajjamānāya līnuddhaccapatiṭṭhānāyūhana🔽kāmasukhattakilamathānuyogaucchedasassatābhinivesādīnaṃ anekesaṃ upaddavānaṃ paṭipakkhabhūtāya🔽satidhammavicayavīriyapītipassaddhisamādhiupekkhāsaṅkhātāya dhammasāmaggiyā ariyasāvako🔽bujjhatīti katvā bodhīti vuccati. Bujjhatīti kilesasantānaniddāya uṭṭhahati, cattāri
analyzed: veditabbam bojjhaṅgā iti ettha bodhiyā bodhissa vā aṅgā ati bojjhaṅgā kim vuttam hoti  yā hi ayam dhamma sāmaggī yāya lokiya lokuttara magga kkhaṇe uppajjamānāya  kāma sukha tta kilamatha anuyoga auccheda sassata abhinivesa ādīnam anekesam upaddavānam paṭipakkha bhūtāya  sati dhamma vicaya vīriya pīti passaddhi samādhi upekkhā saṅkhātāya dhamma sāmaggiyā ariya sāvako  bujjhati iti katvā bodhi iti vuccati bujjhati iti kilesa santāna niddāya uṭṭhahati cattāri
translated: What is meant?

original: vā ariyasaccāni paṭivijjhati, nibbānameva vā sacchikarotīti vuttaṃ hoti. Yathāha
analyzed: vā ariya saccāni paṭivijjhati nibbānam eva vā sacchikaroti iti vuttam hoti yathā āha
translated: For this is the concordance of states called enlightenment, which arises at the moment of the worldling’s and the noble disciple’s path, and which is the opposite of the many kinds of misfortune beginning with the choice of the triple ruin , the choice of false ways, the choice of perversions, the choice of defilements, the choice of kamma, the choice of suffering, sloth, negligence, the shackle of sense desires, the shackle of becoming, the shackle of ignorance, the shackle of views, the shackle of conceit, the shackle of defilements, the shackle of kamma, the shackle of birth, the shackle of rebirth, the shackle of the sign, the shackle of craving, the shackle of the six bases, the shackle of the six sense faculties, the shackle of craving for the six sense objects, the shackle of the six classes of craving, the shackle of the six classes of contact, the shackle of the six classes of feeling, the shackle of the six classes of craving for visible objects, etc., the shackle of the six classes of craving for forms, etc., the shackle of the six classes of craving for sounds, etc., the shackle of the six classes of craving for smells, etc., the shackle of the six classes of craving for tastes, etc., the shackle of the six classes of craving for touches, etc., the shackle of the six classes of craving for mental objects, etc., the shackle of the six classes of craving for ideas, etc., the shackle of the six classes of craving for ideas cognizable by the eye, etc., the shackle of the six classes of craving for visible data, etc., the shackle of the six classes of craving for ideas cognizable by the ear, etc.,

original: “satta bojjhaṅge bhāvetvā anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho”ti. Tassā dhammasāmaggisaṅkhātāya
analyzed: satta bojjhaṅge bhāvetvā anuttaram sammāsambodhim abhisambuddhaḥ ti tassāḥ dhamma sāmaggi saṅkhātāya
translated: “Having developed the seven factors of enlightenment he awakened to the supreme full enlightenment.”🔽So they are factors of that enlightenment, called the “unification of the system of ideas,”

original: bodhiyā aṅgāti bojjhaṅgā jhānaṅgamaggaṅgādayo viya. Yopesa yathāvuttappakārāya etāya
analyzed: bodhiyā aṅgā ati bojjhaṅgāḥ jhānaṅga maggaṅga ādayaḥ yathā vutta ppakārāya etāya
translated: like the factors of concentration, the factors of the path, and so on.

original: dhammasāmaggiyā bujjhatīti katvā ariyasāvako bodhīti vuccati, tassa bodhissa aṅgātipi
analyzed: dhamma sāmaggiyā bujjhati iti katvā ariya sāvakaḥ bodhī iti vuccati tassa bodhissa
translated: And the noble disciple who awakens to that supreme enlightenment by means of that unification of the system of ideas as described is called “one who is enlightened” .🔽So they are also factors of that enlightenment,🔽like the factors of a chariot, the factors of a path, and so on. That is why the teachers of the commentaries say:

original: bojjhaṅgā senaṅgarathaṅgādayo viya. Tenāhu aṭṭhakathācariyā – “bujjhanakassa puggalassa
analyzed: bojjhaṅgā senaṅga rathaṅga ādayaḥ tena āhu aṭṭhakathā cariyāḥ bujjhanakassa puggalassa
translated: “They are factors of the person who is enlightened,

original: aṅgāti vā bojjhaṅgā”ti.🔽Apica “bojjhaṅgāti kenaṭṭhena bojjhaṅgā? Bodhāya saṃvattantīti bojjhaṅgā, bujjhantīti🔽bojjhaṅgā, anubujjhantīti bojjhaṅgā, paṭibujjhantīti bojjhaṅgā, sambujjhantīti bojjhaṅgā”iccādinā
analyzed: aṅgā ati vā bojjhaṅgā ati  apica bojjhaṅgā ati kenaṭṭhena bojjhaṅgāḥ bodhāya saṃvattanti iti bojjhaṅgāḥ bujjhanti iti  bojjhaṅgāḥ anubujjhanti iti bojjhaṅgāḥ paṭibujjhanti iti bojjhaṅgā sambujjhanti iti bojjhaṅgāḥ icca ādinā
translated: or they are factors of enlightenment.”🔽Besides, the meaning of “factor of enlightenment” can be understood in the way given in the Paṭisambhidā:

original: paṭisambhidānayenāpi bojjhaṅgattho veditabbo.
analyzed: paṭisambhidā nayena api bojjhaṅga tthaḥ veditabbo
translated: “Enlightenment factors in the sense of conducing to enlightenment, enlightenment factors in the sense of enlightening, enlightenment factors in the sense of following enlightenment, enlightenment factors in the sense of being enlightened, enlightenment factors in the sense of being fully enlightened” ,🔽and so on.

original: Satisambojjhaṅgantiādīsu pana pasattho sundaro ca bojjhaṅgoti sambojjhaṅgo. Satiyeva
analyzed: sati sambojjhaṅga nti ādīsu pana pasatthaḥ sundaro ca bojjhaṅgo ti sambojjhaṅgo satiyā iva
translated: But in the expressions “mindfulness enlightenment factor” and so on, the word “enlightenment” is used in the sense of “good” and “beautiful” , so “enlightenment factor” is a “factor of good and beautiful enlightenment.”

original: sambojjhaṅgoti satisambojjhaṅgo, taṃ satisambojjhaṅganti evaṃ sabbattha attho veditabbo.
analyzed: sambojjhaṅgo ti sati sambojjhaṅgo tam sati sambojjhaṅgam ti evam sabbattha atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: The meaning of the expression “the enlightenment factor of mindfulness” should be understood in each case in the way already stated.

original: Bhāvetīti vaḍḍheti, attano cittasantāne punappunaṃ janeti, abhinibbattetīti attho.🔽Vivekanissitantiādīni kosalasaṃyutte “sammādiṭṭhiṃ bhāveti vivekanissita”nti ettha
analyzed: bhāveti iti vaḍḍheti attanaḥ citta santāne punappunam janeti abhinibbatteti iti attho  viveka nissita nti ādīni kosalasaṃyutte sammādiṭṭhim bhāveti viveka nissitam ti ettha
translated: He develops: he causes to grow. He generates again and again in his cognizance, he brings about, is the meaning.

original: vuttanayeneva veditabbāni.
analyzed: vutta nayena iva veditabbāni
translated: Relying on seclusion, etc., should be understood in the way stated in the Skill in the Knowledge and Vision of What Is and Is Not the Path .

original: Ayaṃ pana viseso – tattha tadaṅgavivekanissitaṃ, samucchedavivekanissitaṃ, nissaraṇavivekanissitanti,
analyzed: ayam pana visesaḥ tattha tad aṅga viveka nissitam samuccheda viveka nissitam nissaraṇa viveka nissitam
translated: But there is this difference. There it was only the triad of seclusion, etc., that was stated,

original: vivekattayameva vuttaṃ, bojjhaṅgabhāvanaṃ patvā pana pañcavidhavivekanissitampi eke
analyzed: viveka ttayam eva vuttam bojjhaṅga bhāvanam patvā pana pañcavidha viveka nissitam pi eke
translated: but some commentators explain that there are five kinds of reliance on seclusion,

original: vaṇṇayanti. Te hi na kevalaṃ balavavipassanāmaggaphalakkhaṇesu eva bojjhaṅge uddharanti
analyzed: vaṇṇayanti te hi na kevalam balava vipassanā magga phala khaṇesu eva bojjhaṅge uddharanti
translated: for they do not extract the enlightenment factors only from the paths of strong direct-knowledge, fruit, and path,

original: vipassanāpādaka-kasiṇajjhāna-ānāpānāsubha-brahmavihārajjhānesupi uddharanti, na ca
analyzed: vipassanā pādaka kasiṇa jhāna ānāpāna asubha brahmavihāra jhānesu pi uddharanti na ca
translated: but also from the kasiṇa jhāna, the mindfulness of breathing, the divine abidings, and the formless jhānas that lead to insight.

original: paṭisiddhā aṭṭhakathācariyehi. Tasmā tesaṃ matena etesaṃ jhānānaṃ pavattikkhaṇe kiccato🔽eva vikkhambhanavivekanissitaṃ. Yathā ca vipassanākkhaṇe “ajjhāsayato nissaraṇavivekanissita”nti
analyzed: paṭisiddhāḥ aṭṭhakathā cariyehi tasmā tesam matena etesam jhānānam pavatti kkhaṇe kiccato  eva vikkhambhana viveka nissitam yathā ca vipassanā kkhaṇe ajjhāsayataḥ nissaraṇa viveka nissitan ti
translated: It is prohibited by the teachers of the commentary. Therefore, according to their opinion, at the moment of the occurrence of these jhanas, the jhanas are based on the seclusion consisting in the abandoning of the hindrances,🔽just as insight is said to be based on the seclusion consisting in the surmounting of perceptions of materiality, etc., at the moment of its occurrence.🔽And just as insight is said to be based on the seclusion consisting in the surmounting of perceptions of materiality, etc., at the moment of its occurrence, so too the jhanas are said to be based on the seclusion consisting in the surmounting of the hindrances.🔽And just as insight is said to be based on the seclusion consisting in the surmounting of perceptions of materiality, etc., at the moment of its occurrence, so too the jhanas are said to be based on the seclusion consisting in the surmounting of the hindrances.

original: vuttaṃ, evaṃ paṭipassaddhivivekanissitampi bhāvetīti vattuṃ vaṭṭati. Sesamettha heṭṭhā vuttanayameva.🔽2. Kāyasuttavaṇṇanā🔽183. Dutiye āhāraṭṭhitikoti paccayaṭṭhitiko. Āhāraṃ paṭiccāti paccayaṃ paṭicca. Subhanimittanti🔽subhampi subhanimittaṃ, subhassa ārammaṇampi subhanimittaṃ. Ayonisomanasikāroti anupāyamanasikāro
analyzed: vuttam evam paṭipassaddhi viveka nissitam api bhāveti iti vattum vaṭṭati sesam ettha heṭṭhā vutta nayam eva  kāya sutta vaṇṇanā  dutiye āhāra ṭṭhitiko ti paccaya ṭṭhitiko āhāram paṭicca ati paccayam paṭicca subha nimittam  subham pi subha nimittam subhassa ārammaṇam pi subha nimittam a yoniso manasikāro ti an upāya manasikāro
translated: The rest is as already stated.

original: uppathamanasikāro anicce “nicca”nti vā, dukkhe “sukha”nti, anattani “attā”ti vā,
analyzed: uppatha manasikāraḥ anicce niccanti vā dukkhe sukhanti anattani attā ati vā
translated: The second is “based on the presence of nutriment” because it is based on the presence of conditions. “With nutriment as condition”: with a condition consisting of nutriment. The sign of the beautiful: the sign of the beautiful is also beautiful, and the object of the beautiful is also a sign of the beautiful. “Improper attention”: attention that is not a means, attention that is a wrong means, attention that is a wrong method. “Perceiving what is impermanent as permanent”: perceiving what is impermanent as permanent, or perceiving what is painful as pleasant, or perceiving what is not the self as the self,

original: asubhe “subha”nti vā, manasikāro. Taṃ tasmiṃ subhārammaṇe bahulaṃ pavattayato kāmacchando
analyzed: asubhe vā manasikāraḥ tam tasmin subha ārammaṇe bahulam pavattayataḥ kāmacchandaḥ
translated: or perceiving what is foul as beautiful. “He frequently gives attention to that”: he frequently gives attention to that perception of what is impermanent as permanent, etc., in that object consisting of the beautiful.

original: uppajjati. Tena vuttaṃ “atthi, bhikkhave, subhanimitta”ntiādi. Evaṃ sabbanīvaraṇesu yojanā veditabbā.
analyzed: uppajjati tena vuttam atthi bhikkhave subha nimittam tiādi evam sabba nīvaraṇesu yojanā veditabbā
translated: So it is said: “Bhikkhus, there are objects of sensual desire in the world that are desirable, lovely, delightful, pleasant, sensually enticing, tantalizing. “

original: Paṭighanimittantiādīsu pana paṭighopi paṭighanimittaṃ paṭighārammaṇampi. Aratīti
analyzed: paṭigha nimittam ti ādīsu pana paṭighaḥ api paṭigha nimittam paṭigha ārammaṇam pi arati iti
translated: In the case of the phrase “the sign of resistance,” etc., resistance is also a sign of resistance, and it is also a resistance as object. Displeasure is

original: ukkaṇṭhitā. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ – “tattha katamā arati? Pantesu vā senāsanesu aññataraññataresu🔽vā adhikusalesu dhammesu arati aratitā anabhirati anabhiramanā ukkaṇṭhitā paritassitā,
analyzed: ukkaṇṭhitā yam sandhāya vuttam tattha katamā arati vā senāsanesu aññatara aññataresu  vā adhikusalesu dhammesu arati arati tā an abhirati an abhiramanā ukkaṇṭhi tā paritassi tā
translated: discontent. It is said of this: “Herein, what is displeasure? Displeasure, discontent, unpleasure, unenjoyment, dissatisfaction, disaffection,

original: ayaṃ vuccati aratī”ti.
analyzed: ayam vuccati arati iti
translated: with regard to the kinds of resting place that are rough, or with regard to the kinds of resting place that are luxurious, or with regard to the kinds of resting place that are neither rough nor luxurious, is called displeasure” .

original: Tandīti atisītādipaccayā uppannaṃ āgantukakāyālasiyaṃ. Yasmiṃ uppanne “atisītaṃ atiuṇhaṃ🔽aticchātosmi atidhātosmi atidūramaggaṃ gatosmī”ti vadati, yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “tattha
analyzed: tandī iti ati sīta ādi paccayā uppannam āgantuka kāya alasiyam yasmin uppanne ati sītam ati uṇham  aticchātaḥ asmi atidhātaḥ asmi ati dūra maggam gataḥ asmi iti vadati yam sandhāya vuttam tattha
translated: Dullness is sluggishness of the body that has arisen owing to such causes as cold, etc., by which a man speaks as follows: “I am cold, I am hot,🔽I am hungry, I am thirsty, I am tired out, I am too busy,” and so on. It is said of this: “Herein, what is dullness? That which is dullness, dulling,

original: katamā tandi, yā tandī tandiyanā tandimanakatā ālasyaṃ ālasyāyanā ālasyāyitattaṃ,🔽ayaṃ vuccati tandī”ti.
analyzed: katamā tandi yā tandī ālasyam ālasyāyanā 🔽ayam vuccati
translated: sluggishness, sluggishness of mind, mental torpor, torpor, torpidness,

original: Vijambhitāti kilesavasena kāyavinamanā. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ – “tattha katamā vijambhitā?
analyzed: vijambhitā ati kilesa vasena kāya vinamanā yam sandhāya vuttam tattha katamā vijambhitā
translated: ‘Yawning’ is bodily distortion through defilements. In such passages as: ‘What is yawning?

original: Yā kāyassa jambhanā vijambhanā ānamanā vinamanā sannamanā paṇamanā byādhiyakaṃ, ayaṃ
analyzed: yā kāyassa jambhanā vijambhanā ānamanā vinamanā sannamanā paṇamanā
translated: It is the distortion, yawning, bending, bowing, stooping, and contortion of the body.

original: vuccati vijambhitā”ti.
analyzed: vuccati vijambhitā ati
translated: This is called yawning.’

original: Bhattasammadoti bhattapariḷāho. Yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ – “tattha katamo bhattasammado?
analyzed: bhatta sammado ti bhatta pariḷāhaḥ yam sandhāya vuttam tattha katamaḥ bhatta sammado
translated: ‘Distension of the stomach’ is distension of the stomach with wind. In such passages as: ‘What is distension of the stomach?🔽It is distension, distension with wind, distension of the stomach, a state of internal inflation, after eating.

original: Yā bhuttāvissa bhattamucchā bhattakilamatho bhattapariḷāho kāyaduṭṭhullaṃ, ayaṃ vuccati bhattasammado”ti.
analyzed: yā bhutta avissa bhatta mucchā bhatta kilamathaḥ bhatta pariḷāho kāya duṭṭhullam ayam vuccati bhatta sammadaḥ ti
translated: This is called distension of the stomach.’

original: Cetaso ca līnattanti cittassa līyanākāro, yaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ – “tattha katamaṃ cetaso
analyzed: cetaso ca cittassa līyana ākāraḥ yam sandhāya vuttam tattha katamam cetaso
translated: ‘Depression of mind’ is a state of depression of the mind. In such passages as: ‘What is depression of mind?

original: līnattaṃ? Yā cittassa akalyatā akammaññatā olīyanā sallīyanā līnaṃ līyanā līyitattaṃ
analyzed: līnattam yā cittassa a kalya tā akammañña tā olīyanā sat līyanā līnam līyanā līyitattam
translated: It is unfitness, unserviceability, sluggishness, mental sluggishness, depression,

original: thinaṃ thiyanā thiyitattaṃ cittassa, idaṃ vuccati cetaso līnatta”nti.
analyzed: thinam thiyanā thiyitattam cittassa idam vuccati cetasaḥ līnattanti
translated: sluggishness of consciousness, a state of sluggishness of mind. This is called depression of mind.’

original: Cetaso avūpasamoti yathā nāma vītaccikopi aṅgāro neva tāva sannisīdati patāpaṃ karotiyeva,
analyzed: yathā nāma aṅgāraḥ na iva san nisīdati
translated: Non-tranquillity of cognizance: just as a smokeless charcoal-burner’s fire does not subside but burns on,

original: yathā ca pattapacanaṭṭhāne neva tāva sannisīdati patāpaṃ karotiyeva, evaṃ cittassa
analyzed: yathā ca patta pacana ṭṭhāne na iva tāva sannisīdati patāpam evam cittassa
translated: and just as the fire in a pot for boiling leaves does not subside but burns on, so too, this is the non-subsiding of cognizance,

original: avūpasantākāro, atthato panetaṃ uddhaccakukkuccameva hoti.
analyzed: a vūpasanta ākāraḥ atthataḥ pana etat uddhacca kukkuccam eva hoti
translated: which in the ultimate sense is agitation and worry.

original: Vicikicchaṭṭhānīyā dhammāti vicikicchāya ārammaṇadhammā. Ayonisomanasikāro sabbattha
analyzed: vicikiccha ṭṭhānīyāḥ dhammā ti vicikicchāyaḥ ārammaṇa dhammāḥ ayoniso manasikāro sabbattha
translated: Ideas provocative of doubt: ideas that are a footing for doubt. Unreasoned attention: the method stated in the case of greed.

original: vuttanayova. Evamettha kāmacchando vicikicchāti ime dve dhammā ārammaṇena kathitā,
analyzed: evam ettha kāmacchandaḥ vicikicchā ati ime dve dhammā ārammaṇena kathitā
translated: So here the two ideas of lust and doubt are stated by way of object,

original: byāpādo ārammaṇena ca upanissayena ca, sesā sahajātena ca upanissayena cāti.
analyzed: byāpādaḥ ārammaṇena ca upanissayena ca sesā sahajātena ca upanissayena ca ati
translated: ill will by way of object and by way of decisive-support, and the rest by way of conascence and by way of decisive-support.

original: Satisambojjhaṅgaṭṭhānīyā dhammāti satiyā ārammaṇadhammā sattatiṃsa bodhipakkhiyā
analyzed: sati sambojjhaṅga ṭṭhānīyāḥ dhammā ti satiyāḥ ārammaṇa dhammāḥ sattatiṃsa bodhi pakkhiyāḥ
translated: Ideas provocative of the mindfulness factor of complete awakening: ideas that are an object of mindfulness. The thirty-seven ideas leading to enlightenment

original: ca nava lokuttaradhammā ca. Tattha yonisomanasikārabahulīkāroti tattha upāyamanasikārassa punappunaṃ karaṇaṃ.
analyzed: ca nava lokuttara dhammā ca tattha yoniso manasikāra bahulīkāraḥ ti tattha upāya manasikārassa punappunam karaṇam
translated: and the nine supramundane ideas. Herein, frequenting much reasoned attention: frequenting much attention that is a means.

original: Kusalākusalā dhammātiādīsu kusalāti kosallasambhūtā anavajjasukhavipākā. Akusalāti
analyzed: kusala akusalāḥ dhammā ti ādīsu kusalāḥ ati kosalla sambhūtāḥ anavajja sukha vipākāḥ akusalāḥ ati
translated: As regards the profitable, unprofitable, etc., profitable means arisen from skill, blameless, ripening in happiness. Unprofitable means

original: akosallasambhūtā sāvajjadukkhavipākā. Sāvajjāti akusalā. Anavajjāti kusalā. Hīnapaṇītakaṇhasukkesupi
analyzed: akosalla sambhūtā sāvajja dukkha vipākā sāvajjā ati akusalā anavajjā ati kusalā hīna paṇīta kaṇha sukkesu pi
translated: As regards the profitable, unprofitable, etc., profitable is what is produced by skill, is blameless, and has pleasant experience as its fruit. Unprofitable is what is produced by unskill, is blameable, and has painful experience as its fruit. Blameless is what is profitable. Blameable is what is unprofitable. As regards inferior, superior, dark, and bright, etc.,

original: eseva nayo. Sappaṭibhāgāti kaṇhasukkāyeva. Kaṇhā hi kaṇhavipākadānato, sukkā ca sukkavipākadānato
analyzed: esā iva nayo sa paṭibhāgā ti kaṇha sukkāya iva kaṇhā hi kaṇha vipāka dānato sukkā ca sukka vipāka dānato
translated: the same method applies. Having an equal footing means simply dark and bright. For the dark has an equal footing in giving a dark fruition, and the bright has an equal footing in giving a bright fruition.
