original: sappaṭibhāgā nāma, sadisavipākakoṭṭhāsāti attho. Paṭipakkhabhūtassa vā bhāgassa atthitāya
analyzed: sappaṭibhāgā nāma sadisa vipāka koṭṭhāsā ti attho paṭipakkha bhūtassa vā bhāgassa atthitāya
translated: The meaning is that they are a class having a like fruition. Or alternatively, they have an equal footing because they have a part that is an opposite.

original: sappaṭibhāgā. Kaṇhānañhi sukkā paṭipakkhabhāgā, sukkānañca kaṇhā paṭipakkhabhāgāti🔽evampi sappaṭibhāgā. Sappaṭibāhitaṭṭhena vā sappaṭibhāgā. Akusalañhi kusalaṃ paṭibāhitvā
analyzed: sa paṭibhāgā kaṇhānam hi sukkā paṭipakkha bhāgā sukkānam ca kaṇhā paṭipakkha bhāgā ti  evam pi sa paṭibhāgā sa paṭibāhita ṭṭhena vā sa paṭibhāgā akusalam hi kusalam paṭibāhitvā
translated: For the bright is a part that is an opposite of the dark, and the dark is a part that is an opposite of the bright.

original: attano vipākaṃ deti, kusalañca akusalaṃ paṭibāhitvāti evampi kaṇhasukkā sappaṭibhāgā.
analyzed: attanaḥ vipākam deti kusalam ca akusalam paṭibāhitvā ati evam pi kaṇhasukkā sa paṭibhāgā
translated: So in this way too they have an equal footing. Or alternatively, they have an equal footing in the sense of having an equal footing in opposition. For the unprofitable gives its own fruition after opposing the profitable, and the profitable gives its fruition after opposing the unprofitable. So in this way too the dark and the bright have an equal footing.

original: Ārambhadhātūti paṭhamārambhavīriyaṃ. Nikkamadhātūti kosajjato nikkhantattā tato balavataraṃ.
analyzed: ārambha dhātu uti paṭhama ārambha vīriyam nikkama dhātu uti kosajjataḥ nikkhanta ttā tatas balavataram
translated: The element of instigation: the first kind of energy. The element of launching: the energy that is stronger than the first because it has come out from idleness.

original: Parakkamadhātūti paraṃ paraṃ ṭhānaṃ akkamanatāya tatopi balavataranti tīhipi padehi
analyzed: parakkama dhātu uti param param ṭhānam akkama natāya tatas pi tīhi pi padehi
translated: The element of launching further: the energy that is stronger than the second because it launches further and further.

original: vīriyameva kathitaṃ.🔽Pītisambojjhaṅgaṭṭhānīyāti pītiyā ārammaṇadhammā. Kāyapassaddhīti tiṇṇaṃ khandhānaṃ🔽darathapassaddhi. Cittapassaddhīti viññāṇakkhandhassa darathapassaddhi. Samathanimittanti
analyzed: vīriyam eva kathitam  pīti sambojjhaṅga ṭṭhānīyā ati pītiyāḥ ārammaṇa dhammā kāya passaddhī iti tiṇṇam khandhānam  daratha passaddhi citta passaddhi iti viññāṇa kkhandhassa daratha passaddhi samatha nimittanti
translated: All three terms refer to energy.

original: samathopi samathanimittaṃ, ārammaṇampi. Abyagganimittanti tasseva vevacanaṃ.🔽Upekkhāsambojjhaṅgaṭṭhānīyāti upekkhāya ārammaṇadhammā, atthato pana majjhattākāro🔽upekkhāṭṭhānīyā dhammoti veditabbo. Evamettha satidhammavicayaupekkhāsambojjhaṅgā
analyzed: samathaḥ api samatha nimittam ārammaṇam pi abyagga nimittam ti tassa iva vevacanam  upekkhā sambojjhaṅga ṭhānīyā ti upekkhāya ārammaṇa dhammāḥ atthato pana majjhatta ākāro  upekkhā aṭṭhānīyā dhammo ti veditabbaḥ evam ettha sati dhamma vicaya aupekkhā sambojjhaṅgā
translated: The states that are a footing for the enlightenment factor of rapture: states that are objects of rapture. Tranquillity of body: the stilling of the defilements in the three aggregates. Tranquillity of consciousness: the stilling of the defilements in the consciousness aggregate. Sign of serenity: serenity itself is the sign of serenity, and also the object of serenity. Sign of non-diversion: this is a synonym for the same term.🔽The states that are a footing for the enlightenment factor of equanimity: states that are objects of equanimity. But in fact the state that is a footing for equanimity should be understood as the aspect of equanimity in the object.

original: ārammaṇena kathitā, sesā ārammaṇenapi upanissayenapi.🔽3. Sīlasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ārammaṇena kathitā sesā ārammaṇena api upanissayena api 🔽sīla sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: So here the enlightenment factors of mindfulness, investigation of states, and equanimity are stated by way of object, while the rest are stated by way of object and by way of decisive support.

original: 184. Tatiye sīlasampannāti ettha khīṇāsavassa lokiyalokuttarasīlaṃ kathitaṃ, tena
analyzed: tatiye sīla sampannā ti ettha khīṇāsavassa lokiya lokuttara sīlam kathitam tena
translated: In the third, “Endowed with virtue”: here virtue is said to be mundane and supramundane in the case of one who is an arahat. By that

original: sampannāti attho. Samādhipaññāsupi eseva nayo. Vimutti pana phalavimuttiyeva. Vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ
analyzed: sampannā ti attho samādhi paññāsu pi esā iva nayaḥ vimutti pana phala vimuttiyā iva vimutti ñāṇa dassanam
translated: “endowed” is the meaning. The same method applies to concentration and understanding. But deliverance is only the fruit deliverance. The knowledge and vision of deliverance

original: paccavekkhaṇañāṇaṃ. Evamettha sīlādayo tayo lokiyalokuttarā, vimutti lokuttarāva,
analyzed: paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇam evam ettha sīla ādayaḥ tayaḥ lokiya lokuttarā
translated: is the knowledge of reviewing. Thus here the three, virtue and so on, are mundane and supramundane, but deliverance is only supramundane,

original: vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ lokiyameva.
analyzed: vimutti ñāṇa dassanam lokiyam eva
translated: and the knowledge and vision of deliverance is only mundane.

original: Dassanampāhanti dassanampi ahaṃ. Taṃ panetaṃ dassanaṃ – cakkhudassanaṃ, ñāṇadassananti
analyzed: dassanam pāham ti dassanam pi aham tam pana etam dassanam cakkhu dassanam ñāṇa dassananti
translated: “I declare the seeing as well”: I declare the seeing as well. But this seeing is twofold as seeing with the eye and as seeing with knowledge.

original: duvidhaṃ. Tattha pasannehi cakkhūhi ariyānaṃ dassanaṃ olokanaṃ cakkhudassanaṃ nāma.🔽Ariyehi pana diṭṭhassa lakkhaṇassa dassanaṃ, paṭividdhassa ca paṭivijjhanaṃ jhānena
analyzed: duvidham tattha pasannehi cakkhūhi ariyānam dassanaṃ olokanam cakkhudassanam nāma  ariyehi pana diṭṭhassa lakkhaṇassa dassanam paṭividdhassa ca paṭivijjhanam jhānena
translated: Herein, seeing with the eye is the looking at Noble Ones with eyes purified of visual defilement.

original: vā vipassanāya vā maggaphalehi vā ñāṇadassanaṃ nāma. Imasmiṃ panettha cakkhudassanaṃ
analyzed: vā vipassanāya vā magga phalehi vā ñāṇa dassanam nāma imasmim pana ittha cakkhu dassanam
translated: But seeing with knowledge is the seeing of the characteristic of what is seen by Noble Ones, and the penetrating of what is penetrated by means of jhāna, insight, the path, and fruition. Herein, seeing with the eye is

original: adhippetaṃ. Ariyānañhi pasannehi cakkhūhi olokanampi bahukārameva. Savananti “asuko
analyzed: adhippetam ariyānam hi pasannehi cakkhūhi olokanam pi bahukāram eva savananti asukaḥ
translated: The noble ones are pleased with just the sight of one who has faith.

original: nāma khīṇāsavo asukasmiṃ nāma raṭṭhe vā janapade vā gāme vā nigame vā vihāre vā leṇe🔽vā vasatī”ti kathentānaṃ sotena savanaṃ, etampi bahukārameva. Upasaṅkamananti “dānaṃ
analyzed: nāma khīṇa asavaḥ asukasmin nāma raṭṭhe vā janapade vā gāme vā nigame vā vihāre vā leṇe  vā vasati iti sotena savanam bahukāram eva dānam
translated: Hearing: hearing from those who say, “So-and-so, who is an arahat, lives in such-and-such a village or town or monastery or cave.”

original: vā dassāmi, pañhaṃ vā pucchissāmi, dhammaṃ vā sossāmi, sakkāraṃ vā karissāmī”ti evarūpena🔽cittena ariyānaṃ upasaṅkamanaṃ. Payirupāsananti pañhāpayirupāsanaṃ. Ariyānaṃ guṇe
analyzed: vā dassāmi pañham vā pucchissāmi dhammam vā sossāmi sakkāram vā karissāmi iti evarūpena  cittena ariyānam upasaṅkamanam payirupāsanam ti pañhā payirupāsanam ariyānam guṇe
translated: Approaching: approaching the noble ones with a mind that thinks, “I will give a gift, or I will ask a question, or I will listen to the Dhamma, or I will render service.”

original: sutvā te upasaṅkamitvā nimantetvā dānaṃ datvā “kiṃ, bhante, kusala”ntiādinā nayena🔽pañhapucchananti attho.
analyzed: sutvā te upasaṅkamitvā nimantetvā dānam da tvā kim bhante kusalanti ādinā nayena  pañha pucchanam ti attho
translated: Honouring: honouring with questions. After hearing the noble ones’ qualities, approaching them, inviting them, giving them a gift, and asking questions in the way beginning, “What is wholesome, venerable sir?”

original: Anussatinti rattiṭṭhānadivāṭṭhānesu nisinnassa “idāni ariyā leṇaguhamaṇḍapādīsu jhānavipassanāmaggaphalasukhehi
analyzed: anussatim ti ratti ṭṭhāna divāṭṭhānesu nisinnassa idāni ariyāḥ leṇa guha maṇḍapa ādīsu jhāna vipassanā magga phala sukhehi
translated: Recollection: while sitting in the place for the day or in the place for the night, recollecting, “Now the noble ones are enjoying the bliss of jhāna, insight, the path, and fruition in the caves, huts, and so on.

original: vītināmentī”ti anussaraṇaṃ. Yo vā tesaṃ santike ovādo laddho hoti, taṃ āvajjitvā
analyzed: anussaraṇam yaḥ vā tesam santike ovādaḥ laddhaḥ hoti tam āvajjitvā
translated: and he recollects the place where he heard it. Or else he recollects the instruction he received from them,

original: “imasmiṃ ṭhāne sīlaṃ kathitaṃ, imasmiṃ samādhi, imasmiṃ vipassanā, imasmiṃ maggo,🔽imasmiṃ phala”nti evaṃ anussaraṇaṃ. Anupabbajjanti ariyesu cittaṃ pasādetvā gharā
analyzed: imasmin ṭhāne sīlam kathitam imasmin samādhi imasmin vipassanā imasmin maggo  imasmin phalanti evam anussaraṇam anupabbajjanti ariyesu cittam pasādetvā
translated: and he recollects the place where virtue was expounded, concentration, understanding, deliverance, and the knowledge and vision of deliverance were expounded,🔽and he recollects the place where the fruit of stream-entry was expounded, that of once-return, that of non-return, that of Arahantship.

original: nikkhamma tesaṃ santike pabbajjaṃ. Ariyānañhi santike cittaṃ pasādetvā tesaṃyeva🔽santike pabbajitvā tesaṃyeva ovādānusāsaniṃ paccāsīsamānassa caratopi pabbajjā anupabbajjā🔽nāma. Ariyesu pasādena aññattha pabbajitvā ariyānaṃ santike ovādānusāsaniṃ paccāsīsamānassa
analyzed: nikkhamma tesam santike pabbajjam ariyānam hi santike cittam pasādetvā tesam yeva  santike pabbajitvā tesam yeva ovāda anusāsanim paccāsīsamānassa carataḥ pi pabbajjā anupabbajjā  nāma ariyesu pasādena aññattha pabbajitvā ariyānam santike ovāda anusāsanim paccāsīsamānassa
translated: “Gone forth under the Noble Ones”: after he has had confidence in the Noble Ones, he goes forth into homelessness in their presence.🔽For one who has had confidence in the Noble Ones, gone forth in their presence, and is living in conformity with their advice, his going forth is called “gone forth under the Noble Ones.”

original: carato pabbajjāpi anupabbajjā nāma. Aññesu pana pasādena aññesaṃyeva santike pabbajitvā
analyzed: carataḥ pabbajjā api anupabbajjā nāma aññesu pana pasādena aññesam yeva santike pabbajitvā
translated: But if he has had confidence in the Noble Ones, gone forth elsewhere, and is living in conformity with their advice, his going forth is also called “gone forth under the Noble Ones.”

original: aññesaṃyeva ovādānusāsaniṃ paccāsīsamānassa carato pabbajjā anupabbajjā nāma na hoti.
analyzed: aññesam yeva ovāda anusāsanim paccāsīsamānassa carato pabbajjā anupabbajjā nāma na hoti
translated: But if he has had confidence in others, gone forth in their presence, and is living in conformity with their advice, his going forth is not called “gone forth under the Noble Ones.”

original: Evaṃ pabbajitesu pana mahākassapattherassa tāva anupabbajjaṃ pabbajitā satasahassamattā🔽ahesuṃ, tathā therasseva saddhivihārikassa ca candaguttattherassa, tassāpi saddhivihārikassa🔽sūriyaguttattherassa, tassāpi saddhivihārikassa assaguttattherassa, tassāpi saddhivihārikassa
analyzed: evam pabbajitesu pana mahākassapa therassa tāva anupabbajjam pabbajitā sata sahassa mattā  ahesum tathā therassa iva saddhivihārikassa ca candagutta therassa tassa api saddhivihārikassa  sūriyagutta therassa tassa api saddhivihārikassa assagutta therassa tassa api saddhivihārikassa
translated: When they had thus gone forth, a hundred thousand people went forth on the example of the Elder Mahā Kassapa,🔽and likewise on the example of the Elder Candagutta, who was the Elder Mahā Kassapa’s pupil,🔽and likewise on the example of the Elder Sūriyagutta, who was the Elder Candagutta’s pupil,🔽and likewise on the example of the Elder Assagutta, who was the Elder Sūriyagutta’s pupil,

original: yonakadhammarakkhitattherassa, tassa pana saddhivihāriko asokarañño kaniṭṭhabhātā
analyzed: yonakadhammarakkhita therassa tassa pana saddhivihārikaḥ asokarañño kaniṭṭha bhātā
translated: and likewise on the example of the Elder Yonaka Dhammarakkhita, who was the Elder Assagutta’s pupil. But the Elder Tissa, who was the Elder Yonaka Dhammarakkhita’s pupil,

original: tissatthero nāma ahosi, tassa anupabbajjaṃ pabbajitā aḍḍhateyyakoṭisaṅkhā ahesuṃ.
analyzed: tissattheraḥ nāma ahosi tassa anupabbajjam pabbajitāḥ aḍḍhateyya koṭi saṅkhāḥ ahesuṃ
translated: was King Asoka’s younger brother. A hundred and fifty koṭis went forth on his example.🔽There is no limit to the number of people who went forth on the example of the Elder Mahinda.

original: Mahindattherassa anupabbajitānaṃ gaṇanaparicchedo natthi. Yāvajjadivasā laṅkādīpe
analyzed: mahinda therassa anupabbajitānam gaṇana paricchedaḥ natthi yāvajjadivasā laṅkādīpe
translated: Even to this day in the island of Laṅkā

original: satthari pasādena pabbajantā mahindattherasseva pabbajjaṃ anupabbajanti nāma.
analyzed: satthari pasādena pabbajantāḥ mahinda therassa iva pabbajjam anupabbajanti nāma
translated: those who go forth through faith in the Master go forth on the example of the Elder Mahinda.

original: Taṃ dhammanti taṃ tesaṃ ovādānusāsanīdhammaṃ. Anussaratīti sarati. Anuvitakketīti
analyzed: tam dhamman ti tam tesam ovāda anusāsanī dhammaṃ anussarati iti sarati anuvitakketi iti
translated: “The Dhamma”: the Dhamma of instruction and counsel of those who have gone forth. “Remembers”: recollects. “Thinks over”:

original: vitakkāhataṃ karoti. Āraddho hotīti paripuṇṇo hoti. Pavicinatītiādi sabbaṃ tattha
analyzed: vitakka āhatam karoti āraddhaḥ hoti iti paripuṇṇaḥ hoti pavicinati itiādi sabbam tattha
translated: he makes it a victim of applied thought. It is set going: it is fulfilled. He gives attention to it: he gives attention to it as impermanent, and so on. He comprehends it: he comprehends it by conascence, etc., in the way already described. He sees it as impermanent, etc., in the way already described. He defines it: he defines it as “the fourth jhāna in the fourth meditation subject.” He determines it: he determines it by the determination of the elements, etc., in the way already described. He consolidates it: he consolidates and confirms it by surmounting the jhāna in the way already described under “He enters into it” . He does not waver: he does not waver through uncertainty, indecision, and lack of conviction, thinking, “This jhāna has no visible fruit, it has no profit, it is not worth the trouble of developing.” He does not tremble: he does not tremble through fear, as one might through fear of an abyss, thinking, “This jhāna is difficult to enter and difficult to develop.” He does not quake: he does not quake through fear, as one might through fear of a ghost, thinking, “This jhāna is difficult to enter and difficult to develop.” He does not waver, he does not tremble, he does not quake: he does not waver through uncertainty, he does not tremble through fear, he does not quake through terror.

original: ñāṇacāravaseneva vuttaṃ. Atha vā pavicinatīti tesaṃ tesaṃ dhammānaṃ lakkhaṇaṃ vicinati.🔽Pavicaratīti tattha ñāṇaṃ carāpeti. Parivīmaṃsamāpajjatīti vīmaṃsanaṃ olokanaṃ gavesanaṃ āpajjati.
analyzed: ñāṇa cāra vasena iva vuttam atha vā pavicinati iti tesam tesam dhammānam lakkhaṇam vicinati  pavicarati iti tattha ñāṇam carāpeti parivīmaṃsam āpajjati iti vīmaṃsanam olokanam gavesanam āpajjati
translated: He makes the mental approach. He has entered upon it: it is fulfilled. He investigates: all this is said according to the method of knowledge and the method of conduct. Or alternatively, he investigates: he investigates the characteristics of those states.

original: Satta phalā sattānisaṃsāti ubhayampetaṃ atthato ekaṃ. Diṭṭheva dhamme paṭikacca aññaṃ🔽ārādhetīti arahattaṃ ārādhento imasmiṃyeva attabhāve ārādheti, tañca kho paṭikacca,🔽asampatteyeva maraṇakāleti attho. Atha maraṇakāleti atha maraṇassa āsannakāle.🔽Antarāparinibbāyīti yo āyuvemajjhaṃ anatikkamitvā parinibbāyati, so tividho hoti.
analyzed: satta phalā satta anisaṃsā ati ubhayam petam atthataḥ ekam diṭṭhe iva dhamme paṭikacca aññam  ārādha iti iti arahattam ārādhentaḥ imasmin yeva atta bhāve ārādha iti tat ca kho paṭikacca  a sampatteya iva maraṇa kāle iti atthaḥ atha maraṇa kāle iti atha maraṇassa āsanna kāle  antarāparinibbāyī iti yaḥ āyu vemajjham an atikkamitvā parinibbāyati saḥ tividhaḥ hoti
translated: He examines: he directs knowledge there. He comprehends: he comprehends by comprehending groups. He contemplates: he contemplates by means of contemplation. He has seven fruits, seven advantages: both these are one in meaning, namely, seven kinds of fruit, seven kinds of advantage. He attains to extinction in this very life: he attains extinction in this very life.

original: Kappasahassāyukesu tāva avihesu nibbattitvā eko nibbattadivaseyeva arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti.
analyzed: kappa sahassa āyukesu tāva avihesu nibbattitvā ekaḥ nibbatta divaseya iva arahattam pāpuṇāti
translated: He attains to extinction in this very life: he attains extinction in this very life. He attains to extinction in this very life: he attains extinction in this very life. He attains to extinction in this very life: he attains extinction in this very life. He attains to extinction in this very life: he attains extinction in this very life. He attains to extinction in this very life: he attains

original: No ce nibbattadivase pāpuṇāti, paṭhamassa pana kappasatassa matthake pāpuṇāti. Ayameko🔽antarāparinibbāyī. Aparo evaṃ asakkonto dvinnaṃ kappasatānaṃ matthake pāpuṇāti, ayaṃ
analyzed: no ce nibbatta divase pāpuṇāti paṭhamassa pana kappa satassa matthake pāpuṇāti ayam eko  antarā parinibbāyī aparaḥ evam a sakkontaḥ dvinnam kappa satānam matthake pāpuṇāti ayam
translated: If he does not reach it on the day of his birth, he reaches it at the end of the first century of the world-cycle. This is one kind of🔽non-returner who attains nibbana in the interval. Another, unable to do this, reaches it at the end of the second century of the world-cycle. This is the second kind of🔽non-returner who attains nibbana in the interval.

original: dutiyo. Aparo evampi asakkonto catunnaṃ kappasatānaṃ matthake pāpuṇāti, ayaṃ tatiyo antarāparinibbāyī.
analyzed: dutiyaḥ aparaḥ evam pi a sakkontaḥ catunnam kappa satānam matthake pāpuṇāti ayam tatiyaḥ antarā parinibbāyī
translated: If he does not reach it on the day of his birth, he reaches it at the end of the first century of the world’s duration. This is the first kind of non-returner who attains Nibbāna in the interval. Another, failing to do so, reaches it at the end of the second century of the world’s duration. This is the second kind. Another, failing to do so, reaches it at the end of the fourth century of the world’s duration. This is the third kind of non-returner who attains Nibbāna in the interval.

original: Pañcamaṃ pana kappasataṃ atikkamitvā arahattaṃ patto upahaccaparinibbāyī nāma hoti.🔽Atappādīsupi eseva nayo. Yattha katthaci uppanno pana sasaṅkhārena sappayogena arahattaṃ
analyzed: pañcamam pana kappa satam atikkamitvā arahattam pattaḥ upahaccaparinibbāyī nāma hoti  a tappa ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ yattha katthaci uppannaḥ pana sa saṅkhārena sa payogena arahattam
translated: But one who reaches it after exceeding the fifth century of the world’s duration is called one who attains Nibbāna after rebirth.

original: patto sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyī nāma, asaṅkhārena appayogena patto asaṅkhāraparinibbāyī🔽nāma. Avihādīsupi nibbatto tattha yāvatāyukaṃ ṭhatvā uparūpari nibbattitvā akaniṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: patto sa saṅkhāra parinibbāyī nāma asaṅkhārena appayogena patto asaṅkhāra parinibbāyī  nāma a viha ādīsu pi nibbattaḥ tattha yāvatāyukam ṭhatvā upari upari nibbattitvā akaniṭṭham
translated: The same method applies in the case of the Atappa and the other worlds. But one who attains Arahantship by exertion and by insight is called one who attains Nibbāna through exertion. One who attains it without exertion and by insight is called one who attains Nibbāna without exertion.

original: patto uddhaṃsoto akaniṭṭhagāmī nāma.
analyzed: patto uddhaṃsotaḥ akaniṭṭhagāmī nāma
translated: One who is reborn in the Aviha and the other worlds and who, living out his appointed life span, is reborn in a higher world and eventually reaches the Akaniṭṭha world is called one who goes upstream to the Akaniṭṭha world.

original: Imasmiṃ pana ṭhāne aṭṭhacattārīsa anāgāmino kathetabbā. Avihesu hi tayo antarāparinibbāyī,🔽eko upahaccaparinibbāyī, eko uddhaṃsoto akaniṭṭhagāmīti pañca honti. Te asaṅkhāraparinibbāyino
analyzed: imasmin pana ṭhāne aṭṭhacattārīsa anāgāmino kathetabbāḥ avihesu hi tayo antarā parinibbāyī  ekaḥ upahacca parinibbāyī ekaḥ uddhaṃsotaḥ akaniṭṭhagāmī iti pañca honti te asaṅkhāra parinibbāyinaḥ
translated: But here forty-eight non-returners should be mentioned. For there are five in Aviha: three who attain Nibbāna in the interval,

original: pañca, sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyino pañcāti dasa honti, tathā atappādīsu. Akaniṭṭhesu
analyzed: pañca sa saṅkhāra parinibbāyino pañca ati dasa honti tathā atappa ādīsu akaniṭṭhesu
translated: one who attains Nibbāna upon landing, and one who goes upstream to the Akaniṭṭha heaven. They are five who attain Nibbāna without exertion and five who attain Nibbāna with exertion, thus there are ten. So too in Atappa, and so on.

original: pana uddhaṃsoto natthi, tasmā tattha cattāro sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyī, cattāro asaṅkhāraparinibbāyīti
analyzed: pana uddhaṃsotaḥ natthi tasmā tattha cattāro sa saṅkhāra parinibbāyī cattāro asaṅkhāra parinibbāyī iti
translated: But in Akaniṭṭha there is no one who goes upstream, so there are four who attain Nibbāna with exertion and four who attain Nibbāna without exertion,

original: aṭṭhāti evaṃ aṭṭhacattālīsa honti. Tesaṃ uddhaṃsoto akaniṭṭhagāmī sabbajeṭṭho ceva
analyzed: aṭṭha ati evam aṭṭhacattālīsa honti tesam a kaniṭṭha gāmī sabbajeṭṭho ca iva
translated: thus there are eight. So there are forty-eight. The one who goes upstream to the Akaniṭṭha heaven is the eldest of all

original: hoti sabbakaniṭṭho ca. Kathaṃ? So hi soḷasakappasahassāyukattā āyunā sabbesaṃ jeṭṭho,
analyzed: hoti sabba kaniṭṭhaḥ ca katham so hi soḷasa kappa sahassa āyuka ttā āyunā sabbesam jeṭṭhaḥ
translated: and the youngest of all. How? He is the eldest in life because he has a life of sixteen thousand eons.🔽He is the youngest because he is the last to reach Arahantship. In this sutta he is called

original: sabbapacchā arahattaṃ pāpuṇīti sabbesaṃ kaniṭṭho. Imasmiṃ sutte apubbaṃ acarimaṃ
analyzed: sabbapacchā arahattam pāpuṇi iti sabbesam kaniṭṭhaḥ imasmin sutte apubbam a carimam
translated: “the first” and “the last” .

original: ekacittakkhaṇikā nānālakkhaṇā arahattamaggassa pubbabhāgavipassanā bojjhaṅgā kathitā.
analyzed: eka citta khaṇikā nānā lakkhaṇā arahatta maggassa pubbabhāga vipassanā bojjhaṅgā kathitā
translated: The enlightenment factors in the prior stage of the path of arahatship are called enlightenment factors, though they are of different characteristics, being of a single moment.

original: 4. Vatthasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vattha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Exposition of the Thread

original: 185. Catutthe satisambojjhaṅgo iti ce me hotīti satisambojjhaṅgoti evaṃ ce mayhaṃ
analyzed: catutthe sati sambojjhaṅgo iti ce me hoti iti evam ce mayham
translated: “If I think ‘The mindfulness factor of complete awakening’ ”: if I think “The mindfulness factor of complete awakening” in this way,

original: hoti. Appamāṇoti me hotīti appamāṇoti evaṃ me hoti. Susamāraddhoti suparipuṇṇo. Tiṭṭhatīti
analyzed: hoti appamāṇo ti me hoti iti appamāṇo ti evam me hoti su samāraddho ti su paripuṇṇo tiṭṭhati iti
translated: “It is immeasurable” : it is so for me. “It is well undertaken” : it is well fulfilled. “It persists” :

original: ettha aṭṭhahākārehi satisambojjhaṅgo tiṭṭhati – uppādaṃ anāvajjitattā anuppādaṃ āvajjitattā
analyzed: ettha aṭṭhahākārehi sati sambojjhaṅgaḥ tiṭṭhati uppādam an āvajjita ttā an uppādam āvajjita ttā
translated: herein, the mindfulness factor of complete awakening persists in eight aspects: it persists as the mindfulness factor of complete awakening because of the non-attention to arising, because of the attention to non-arising,

original: satisambojjhaṅgo tiṭṭhati, pavattaṃ, appavattaṃ, nimittaṃ, animittaṃ saṅkhāre anāvajjitattā,🔽visaṅkhāraṃ āvajjitattā satisambojjhaṅgo tiṭṭhatīti. Imehi aṭṭhahākārehi tiṭṭhatīti
analyzed: sati sambojjhaṅgaḥ tiṭṭhati pavattam appavattam nimittam animittam saṅkhāre an āvajjita ttā  visaṅkhāram āvajjita ttā sati sambojjhaṅgo tiṭṭhati iti imehi aṭṭhahākārehi tiṭṭhati iti
translated: because of the non-attention to occurrence, to non-occurrence, to sign, to signless, to formations,🔽because of the attention to non-formation. It persists in these eight aspects.

original: thero jānāti, vuttākāraviparīteheva aṭṭhahākārehi cavantaṃ cavatīti pajānāti. Sesabojjhaṅgesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: theraḥ jānāti vutta ākāra viparītehi iva aṭṭhaha ākārehi cavantam cavati iti pajānāti sesa bojjhaṅgesu pi esa iva nayo
translated: The elder knows that it persists in these eight aspects. He knows that it vanishes by vanishing in the opposite way to the way stated. The same method applies in the case of the other enlightenment factors.

original: Iti imasmiṃ sutte therassa phalabojjhaṅgā kathitā. Yadā hi thero satisambojjhaṅgaṃ🔽sīsaṃ katvā phalasamāpattiṃ samāpajjati, tadā itare cha tadanvayā honti. Yadā dhammavicayādīsu🔽aññataraṃ, tadāpi sesā tadanvayā hontīti evaṃ phalasamāpattiyaṃ attano ciṇṇavasitaṃ
analyzed: iti imasmin sutte therassa phala bojjhaṅgā kathitā yadā hi thero sati sambojjhaṅgam  sīsam katvā phala samāpattim samāpajjati tadā itare cha tad anvayāḥ honti yadā dhammavicaya ādīsu  aññataram tadā api sesā tad anvayāḥ honti iti evam phala samāpattiyam attano
translated: So in this sutta the Elder’s enlightenment factors are stated as fruits. For when the Elder enters upon fruition attainment with the mindfulness enlightenment factor as his “head,” then the other six are in conformity with it. And when it is with the investigation-of-states enlightenment factor, etc., then the others are in conformity with it. So in this way, in the case of fruition attainment, the Elder had already mastered his own self.🔽

original: dassento thero imaṃ suttaṃ kathesīti.
analyzed: dassentaḥ theraḥ imam suttam kathesi iti
translated: So in this Thread the Elder’s factors of enlightenment in the fruition are stated. For when the Elder enters upon fruition attainment with the factor of complete enlightenment that is mindfulness 1 making the head, then the other six are in conformity with that. When it is with the factor of complete enlightenment that is investigation-of-ideas, then the others are in conformity with that. So showing how he himself had mastered the fruition attainment, the Elder preached this Thread.

original: 5. Bhikkhusuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: bhikkhu sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The bhikkhu Thread

original: 186. Pañcame bodhāya saṃvattantīti bujjhanatthāya saṃvattanti. Kiṃ bujjhanatthāya?🔽Maggena asaṅkhataṃ nibbānaṃ, paccavekkhaṇāya katakiccataṃ, maggena vā kilesaniddāto🔽pabujjhanatthāya, phalena pabujjhanabhāvatthāyātipi vuttaṃ hoti. Tenevettha nibbānasacchikiriyā
analyzed: pañcame bodhāya saṃvattanti iti bujjhan atthāya saṃvattanti kim bujjhan atthāya  maggena asaṅkhatam nibbānam paccavekkhaṇāya kata kicca tam maggena vā kilesa niddāto  pabujjhana tthāya phalena pabujjhana bhāva tthāya ati pi vuttam hoti tena iva ittha nibbāna sacchikiriyā
translated: . In the fifth Thread, ‘ they lead to enlightenment ‘ : they lead to the kind of waking up that is the extinction unalloyed with 1 any remainder of clinging. What kind of waking up?

original: kilesapahānapaccavekkhaṇāti sabbaṃ dassitaṃ.
analyzed: kilesa pahāna paccavekkhaṇā ti sabbam dassitam
translated: Waking up to the unformed extinction by the path, or waking up to the fact that the task is done by reviewing, or waking up from the slumber of defilement by the path, or waking up to the fact that there is waking up by the fruition. That is why all is shown here by ‘ realization of extinction ‘ and ‘ reviewing of the abandoning of defilement ‘ .🔽. The Kuṇḍaliya Thread

original: 6-7. Kuṇḍaliyasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: kuṇḍaliya sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: 6-7. Explanatory exposition of the Kuṇḍaliya Sutta, etc.

original: 187-188. Chaṭṭhe ārāmanissayīti ārāmaṃ nissāya vasanabhāvena ārāmanissayī. Parisāvacaroti
analyzed: chaṭṭhe ārāma nissayī iti ārāmam nissāya vasana bhāvena ārāma nissayī parisā avacaroti
translated: 187-188. In the sixth, he is a monastery-dweller: he is a monastery-dweller because of the fact that he lives in dependence on a monastery. He is a frequenter of assemblies:

original: parisāya avacaro. Parisaṃ nāma bālāpi, paṇḍitāpi osaranti, yo pana parappavādaṃ madditvā🔽attano vādaṃ dīpetuṃ sakkoti, ayaṃ parisāvacaro nāma. Ārāmena ārāmanti ārāmeneva
analyzed: parisāya avacaraḥ parisam nāma bālāḥ api paṇḍitāḥ api osaranti yaḥ pana para pavādam madditvā  attanaḥ vādam dīpetum sakkoti ayam parisāvacaraḥ nāma ārāmena ārāmanti ārāmena iva
translated: an assembly is a gathering of both the ignorant and the wise. But one who can refute the doctrines of others and🔽illuminate his own doctrine is called a frequenter of assemblies. He goes from monastery to monastery: he goes from monastery to monastery, not outside. The meaning is:

original: ārāmaṃ anucaṅkamāmi, na bāhirenāti attho. Uyyānena uyyānanti etthāpi eseva nayo.
analyzed: ārāmam anucaṅkamāmi na bāhirena ati attho uyyānena uyyānam ti ettha api esa iva nayo
translated: he goes from garden to garden. Here too the same method applies.

original: Aññena vā ārāmena pavisitvā aññaṃ ārāmaṃ, aññena uyyānena aññaṃ uyyānanti ayamettha
analyzed: aññena vā ārāmena pavisitvā aññam ārāmam aññena uyyānena aññam uyyānanti ayam ettha
translated: Or the meaning is this: he enters by one monastery and leaves by another, by one garden and by another.

original: attho. Itivādappamokkhānisaṃsanti “evaṃ pucchā hoti, evaṃ vissajjanaṃ, evaṃ gahaṇaṃ,
analyzed: atthaḥ itivāda pamokkha anisaṃsanti evam pucchā hoti evam vissajjanam evam gahaṇam
translated: The benefit of the release by means of the way of questions: the way of questions is the method of questioning thus: “The question is asked in this way, the answer is given in this way, the grasping is done in this way,

original: evaṃ nibbeṭhana”nti iminā nayena itivādo hoti itivādappamokkhoti etaṃ ānisaṃsaṃ.
analyzed: evam nibbeṭhanam ti iminā nayena itivādaḥ hoti itivāda pamokkho ti etam ānisaṃsam
translated: the release is effected in this way.” The benefit of this is the release by means of the way of questions.

original: Upārambhānisaṃsanti “ayaṃ pucchāya doso, ayaṃ vissajjane”ti evaṃ vādadosānisaṃsaṃ.
analyzed: upārambha anisaṃsanti ayam pucchāya dosaḥ ayam vissajjana iti evam vāda dosa anisaṃsam
translated: The benefit of the release by means of the refutation of doctrines: the benefit of this is the refutation of the faults of doctrines in this way: “This is the fault of the question, this is the fault of the answer.”

original: Kathaṃ bhāvito ca, kuṇḍaliya, indriyasaṃvaroti satthā “ettakaṃ ṭhānaṃ paribbājakena
analyzed: katham bhāvitaḥ ca kuṇḍaliyaḥ indriya saṃvaro ti satthā ettakam ṭhānam paribbājakena
translated: “How, Kuñdaliya, is the sense-restraint developed?” The Teacher, thinking “The wanderer has asked about this much,

original: pucchitaṃ, idāni pucchituṃ na sakkotī”ti ñatvā “na tāva ayaṃ desanā yathānusandhiṃ
analyzed: pucchitam idāni pucchitum na sakkoti iti ñatvā na tāva ayam desanā yathā anusandhim
translated: but now he is unable to ask any more,” and knowing “This teaching has not yet reached its conclusion,

original: gatā. Idāni naṃ yathānusandhiṃ pāpessāmī”ti sayameva pucchanto imaṃ desanaṃ ārabhi.🔽Tattha manāpaṃ nābhijjhatīti iṭṭhārammaṇaṃ nābhijjhāyati. Nābhihaṃsatīti na sāmisāya🔽tuṭṭhiyā abhihaṃsati. Tassa ṭhito ca kāyo hoti, ṭhitaṃ cittaṃ ajjhattanti tassa nāmakāyo🔽ca cittañca gocarajjhatte ṭhitaṃ hoti. Susaṇṭhitanti kammaṭṭhānavasena suṭṭhu saṇṭhitaṃ.🔽Suvimuttanti kammaṭṭhānavimuttiyā suvimuttaṃ. Amanāpanti aniṭṭhārammaṇaṃ. Na maṅku
analyzed: gatāḥ idāni nam yathā anusandhim pāpessāmi iti sayam eva pucchantaḥ imam desanam ārabhi  tattha manāpam na abhijjhati iti iṭṭha ārammaṇam na abhijjhāyati na abhihaṃsati iti na sa āmisāya  tuṭṭhiyā abhihaṃsati tassa ṭhitaḥ ca kāyaḥ hoti ṭhitam cittam ajjhattanti tassa nāmakāyo  ca cittam ca gocara jjhatte ṭhitam hoti su saṇṭhitam ti kammaṭṭhāna vasena suṭṭhu saṇṭhitam  su vimuttanti kammaṭṭhāna vimuttiyā su vimuttam amanāpanti aniṭṭha ārammaṇam na maṅku
translated: I will now lead him to its conclusion,” himself began this teaching.

original: hotīti tasmiṃ na maṅku hoti. Appatiṭṭhitacittoti kilesavasena aṭṭhitacitto. Adīnamānasoti
analyzed: hoti iti tasmin na maṅku hoti appatiṭṭhita citto ti kilesa vasena aṭṭhita cittaḥ adīna mānasaḥ iti
translated: Herein, he does not covet what is pleasing is he does not covet a desirable object. He does not grieve over what is unpleasing is he does not grieve over an undesirable object with worldly grief. His body is steady and his mind is steady within is his bodily formation and his mind are steady within, in their own place. Well-composed is well-established by means of the meditation subject. Well-liberated is well-liberated by the liberation of the meditation subject. He is not downcast over what is unpleasing is he is not downcast over an undesirable object. He is not one whose mind is unstable is he is not one whose mind is unstable by defilements. He is not one whose mind is mean is he is not one whose mind is mean by defilements.

original: domanassavasena adīnacitto. Abyāpannacetasoti dosavasena apūticitto.
analyzed: domanassa vasena adīna cittaḥ a byāpanna cetasā ti dosa vasena a pūti cittaḥ
translated: and he is not fainthearted through sorrow. He is not impure in mind through hate.

original: Evaṃ bhāvito kho, kuṇḍaliya, indriyasaṃvaro evaṃ bahulīkato tīṇi sucaritāni paripūretīti
analyzed: evam bhāvitaḥ kho kuṇḍaliyaḥ indriya saṃvaraḥ evam bahulīkataḥ tīṇi su caritāni paripūreti iti
translated: When the restraint of the faculties is developed and much practiced in this way, it fulfils the three kinds of good conduct.

original: ettha evaṃ sucaritapūraṇaṃ veditabbaṃ – imesu tāva chasu dvāresu aṭṭhārasa duccaritāni
analyzed: ettha evam su carita pūraṇam veditabbam imesu tāva chasu dvāresu aṭṭhārasa duccaritāni
translated: Herein, the fulfilment of the three kinds of good conduct should be understood in this way. There are eighteen kinds of misconduct in these six doors.

original: honti. Kathaṃ? Cakkhudvāre tāva iṭṭhārammaṇe āpāthagate kāyaṅgavācaṅgāni acopetvā🔽tasmiṃ ārammaṇe lobhaṃ uppādentassa manoduccaritaṃ hoti. Lobhasahagatena cittena🔽“aho vatidaṃ iṭṭhaṃ kantaṃ manāpa”nti bhaṇantassa vacīduccaritaṃ, tadeva hatthena
analyzed: honti katham cakkhu dvāre tāva iṭṭha ārammaṇe āpātha gate kāyaṅga vācaṅgāni a copetvā  tasmin ārammaṇe lobham uppādentassa manaḥ duccaritam hoti lobha sahagatena cittena  aho vatidam iṭṭham kantam manāpanti bhaṇantassa vacī duccaritam tat eva hatthena
translated: How? When a desirable object comes into the focus of the eye, he does not, without investigating, give attention to it with lust by way of resolve,

original: parāmasantassa kāyaduccaritaṃ. Sesadvāresupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: parāmasantassa kāya duccaritam sesa dvāresu pi esa iva nayo
translated: and he does not arouse greed by way of perception or by way of thought. When he speaks the words, “Oh, how desirable, how lovable, how pleasant that object is,” he commits a verbal misdeed with consciousness accompanied by greed. When he touches that object with his hand, he commits a bodily misdeed. The same method of explanation applies in the case of the other doors.

original: Ayaṃ pana viseso – sotadvārasmiñhi saddārammaṇassa vatthubhūtaṃ saṅkhapaṇavāditūriyabhaṇḍaṃ
analyzed: ayam pana visesaḥ sota dvārasmin hi sadda ārammaṇassa vatthu bhūtam saṅkha paṇava ādi tūriya bhaṇḍam
translated: But there is this difference: in the case of the ear door, the object is the sound that is the basis for the object consisting of a sound.

original: anāmāsaṃ āmasantassa, ghānadvāre gandhārammaṇassa vatthubhūtaṃ gandhamālādiṃ, jivhādvāre
analyzed: anāmāsam āmasantassa ghāna dvāre gandha ārammaṇassa vatthu bhūtam gandha mālā ādim jivhā dvāre
translated: When he touches a garland of flowers, etc., which are the material basis for the object of odour at the nose door,🔽when he tastes fish, meat, etc., which are the material basis for the object of taste at the tongue door,

original: rasārammaṇassa vatthubhūtaṃ macchamaṃsādiṃ, kāyadvāre phoṭṭhabbārammaṇassa vatthubhūtaṃ🔽vatthatūlakapāvārādiṃ, manodvāre paññattivasena dhammārammaṇabhūtaṃ sappitelamadhuphāṇitādiṃ🔽āmasantassa kāyaduccaritaṃ veditabbaṃ. Saṅkhepato panettha chasu dvāresu kāyavītikkamo
analyzed: rasa ārammaṇassa vatthu bhūtam maccha maṃsa ādim kāya dvāre phoṭṭhabba ārammaṇassa vatthu bhūtam  vattha tūlaka pāvāra ādim manaḥ dvāre paññatti vasena dhamma ārammaṇa bhūtam sappi tela madhu phāṇita ādim  āmasantassa kāya duccaritam veditabbam saṅkhepataḥ pana ittha chasu dvāresu kāya vītikkamo
translated: when he touches cloth, silk, fine wool, etc., which are the material basis for the object of touch at the body door,🔽and when he touches ghee, oil, honey, molasses, etc., which are the material basis for the object of mental data at the mind door by way of determinations, he should understand that he is doing bodily misconduct.

original: kāyaduccaritaṃ, vacīvītikkamo vacīduccaritaṃ, manovītikkamo manoduccaritanti tīṇeva duccaritāni honti.
analyzed: kāya duccaritam vacī vītikkamaḥ vacī duccaritam manaḥ vītikkamaḥ manaḥ duccaritam tīṇi iva duccaritāni honti
translated: But in brief, here there are only three kinds of misconduct: bodily misconduct in the six doors by bodily transgression, verbal misconduct in the six doors by verbal transgression, and mental misconduct in the six doors by mental transgression.

original: Ayaṃ pana bhikkhu attano bhāvanāpaṭisaṅkhāne ṭhito imāni duccaritāni sucaritaṃ katvā
analyzed: ayam pana bhikkhu attanaḥ bhāvanā paṭisaṅkhāne ṭhitaḥ imāni duccaritāni su caritam katvā
translated: But this bhikkhu, standing by his own development and reflection, converts these kinds of misconduct into good conduct

original: vipariṇāmeti. Kathaṃ? Cakkhudvāre tāva iṭṭhārammaṇe āpāthagate kāyaṅgavācaṅgāni acāletvā
analyzed: vipariṇāma iti katham cakkhu dvāre tāva iṭṭha ārammaṇe āpātha gate kāyaṅga vācaṅgāni a cāletvā
translated: by transforming them. How? When a desirable object comes into focus at the eye door, he does not move his bodily and vocal organs.

original: rūpārammaṇaṃ vipassanaṃ paṭṭhāpayato manosucaritaṃ hoti, vipassanāsahagatena cittena🔽khayadhammaṃ vayadhammanti bhaṇantassa vacīsucaritaṃ, “anāmāsabhaṇḍaṃ eta”nti anāmasantassa
analyzed: rūpa ārammaṇam vipassanam paṭṭhāpayataḥ manaḥ su caritam hoti vipassanā sahagatena cittena  khaya dhammam vaya dhammanti bhaṇantassa vacī su caritam etat ti an āmasantassa
translated: When he establishes insight with materiality as its object, there is bodily good conduct.🔽When he says, “Subject to destruction, subject to fall,” there is verbal good conduct.

original: kāyasucaritaṃ. Sesadvāresupi eseva nayo. Evaṃ imāni vitthārato aṭṭhārasa sucaritāni🔽honti. Saṅkhepato panetthāpi chasu dvāresu kāyasaṃvaro kāyasucaritaṃ, vacīsaṃvaro
analyzed: kāya su caritam sesa dvāresu pi esā iva nayo evam imāni vitthārato aṭṭhārasa su caritāni  honti saṅkhepato pana itthā api chasu dvāresu kāya saṃvaro kāya su caritam vacī saṃvaro
translated: When he does not say, “This is the unformed,” there is bodily good conduct. The same method applies in the case of the other doors. So these are the eighteen kinds of good conduct in detail.

original: vacīsucaritaṃ, manosaṃvaro manosucaritanti tīṇeva sucaritāni honti. Evaṃ indriyasaṃvaro
analyzed: vacī su caritam manaḥ saṃvaraḥ tīṇi iva su caritāni honti evam indriya saṃvaraḥ
translated: But in brief there are only three kinds of good conduct here, namely, bodily good conduct, verbal good conduct, and mental good conduct.

original: tīṇi sucaritāni paripūretīti veditabbo. Ettāvatā sīlānurakkhitaṃ indriyasaṃvarasīlaṃ kathitaṃ.
analyzed: tīṇi su caritāni paripūreti iti veditabbaḥ ettāvatā sīla anurakkhitam indriya saṃvara sīlam kathitam
translated: So it should be understood that he fulfils the three kinds of good conduct by means of restraint of the faculties. So much for the virtue consisting in restraint, which is guarded by the faculties.

original: Kāyaduccaritaṃ pahāyātiādīsu tividhaṃ kāyaduccaritaṃ, catubbidhaṃ vacīduccaritaṃ,
analyzed: kāya duccaritam pahāya ati ādīsu tividham kāya duccaritam catubbidham vacī duccaritam
translated: As regards the passage beginning, “Having abandoned bodily misconduct” , there are three kinds of bodily misconduct, four kinds of verbal misconduct,

original: tividhaṃ manoduccaritaṃ. Tassa paṭipakkhavasena kāyasucaritādīni veditabbāni. Ettāvatā
analyzed: tividham manoduccaritam tassa paṭipakkha vasena kāya su carita ādīni veditabbāni ettāvatā
translated: and three kinds of mental misconduct. The bodily good conduct, etc., should be understood as the opposites of these. So much for

original: kāyasaṃvaravacīsaṃvarehi pātimokkhasīlaṃ, manosaṃvarena tīṇi sīlānīti catupārisuddhisīlaṃ
analyzed: kāya saṃvara vacī saṃvarehi pātimokkha sīlam manaḥ saṃvarena tīṇi sīlāni iti catu pārisuddhi sīlam
translated: The virtue of the Pātimokkha is the restraint of body and speech, and the three kinds of virtue are the restraint of mind.

original: kathitaṃ hoti. Sakale pana imasmiṃ sutte sucaritamūlakā satipaṭṭhānā lokuttaramissakā,🔽sattannaṃ bojjhaṅgānaṃ mūlabhūtā satipaṭṭhānā pubbabhāgā, tepi satipaṭṭhānamūlakā
analyzed: kathitam hoti sakale pana imasmin sutte su carita mūlakā sati paṭṭhānā lokuttara missakā  sattannam bojjhaṅgānam mūla bhūtā satipaṭṭhānā pubbabhāgā te pi satipaṭṭhāna mūlakā
translated: The fourfold purification of virtue is what is taught. But in this entire sutta the foundations of mindfulness rooted in good conduct are mixed with the supramundane;

original: bojjhaṅgā pubbabhāgāva. Vijjāvimuttimūlakā pana lokuttarāva kathitāti veditabbā.
analyzed: bojjhaṅgā pubba bhāgā ava vijjā vimutti mūlakā pana lokuttarā ava kathitā iti veditabbā
translated: the foundations of mindfulness that are the root of the seven factors of enlightenment are the path of preparation; and the factors of enlightenment rooted in the foundations of mindfulness are also the path of preparation. But it should be understood that the supramundane is taught as having the knowledge and freedom as its root.

original: Sattamaṃ uttānameva.
analyzed: sattamam uttānam eva
translated: The seventh simile is self-evident.

original: 8. Upavānasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: upavāna sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary on the Upavana Sutta

original: 189. Aṭṭhame paccattanti attanāva. Yonisomanasikārāti yoniso manasikārena. Ārabbhamānovāti
analyzed: aṭṭhame paccattanti attanāva yoniso manasikārā ati yoniso manasikārena ārabbhamānā uva ati
translated: . In the eighth sutta, “by himself” means by his own self. “Proper reflection” means by proper reflection. “Engaged” means

original: kurumānoyeva. Suvimuttanti kammaṭṭhānavimuttiyā suṭṭhu vimuttaṃ. Aṭṭhiṃkatvāti atthaṃ
analyzed: su vimuttam ti kammaṭṭhāna vimuttiyā suṭṭhu vimuttam aṭṭhiṃkatvā iti atthaṃ
translated: one who is engaged. “Well liberated” means well liberated by the meditation subject. “Having made the meaning clear” means having made the meaning

original: karitvā, atthiko hutvāti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: karitvā atthikaḥ hutvā iti vuttam hoti
translated: clear, having become one who has made the meaning clear.

original: 9. Paṭhamauppannasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paṭhama auppanna sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary on the First Upavana Sutta🔽.

original: 190. Navame nāññatra tathāgatassa pātubhāvāti tathāgatassa pātubhāvaṃ vinā na aññasmiṃ kāle uppajjantīti attho.
analyzed: navame na aññatra tathāgatassa pātubhāvā ti tathāgatassa pātubhāvam vinā na aññasmin kāle uppajjanti iti attho
translated: In the ninth, “not but for the manifestation of a Tathāgata”: the meaning is that they do not arise at any other time but for the manifestation of a Tathāgata.

original: 10. Dutiyauppannasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya auppanna sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the second on what has arisen is finished.

original: 191. Dasame nāññatra sugatavinayāti sugatovādaṃ vinā na uppajjantīti.
analyzed: dasame na aññatra sugata vinayā ati sugata uvādam vinā na uppajjanti iti
translated: In the tenth, “not but for the discipline of the Well-Farer”: the meaning is that they do not arise but for the teaching of the Well-Farer.

original: Pabbatavaggo.
analyzed: pabbata vaggaḥ
translated: The Mountain Section is finished.

original: 2. Gilānavaggo
analyzed: gilāna vaggo
translated: The Sickly Section

original: 1-3. Pāṇasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the first on breathing is finished.

original: 192-194. Dutiyavaggassa paṭhame cattāro iriyāpathe kappentīti yesaṃ cattāro iriyāpathā
analyzed: dutiya vaggassa paṭhame cattāro iriyāpathe kappenti iti yesam cattāro iriyāpathā
translated: In the first of the second section, “they make use of the four postures”: this is said of those who have the four postures.

original: atthi, tesaṃyeva vasenetaṃ vuttaṃ. Sīlaṃ nissāyāti catupārisuddhisīlaṃ nissayaṃ katvā.
analyzed: atthi tesam yeva vasena itam vuttam sīlam nissāya ati catu pārisuddhi sīlam nissayam katvā
translated: “Having relied on virtue”: having relied on the virtue of the fourfold purification.

original: Satta bojjhaṅgeti sahavipassanake maggabojjhaṅge. Dutiyatatiyāni uttānatthāneva.🔽4-10. Paṭhamagilānasuttādivaṇṇanā🔽195-201. Catutthe tathā pahīno cāyasmato mahākassapassa so ābādho ahosīti therassa
analyzed: satta bojjhaṅge ti saha vipassanake magga bojjhaṅge dutiya tatiyāni  paṭhama gilāna sutta ādi vaṇṇanā  catutthe tathā pahīno ca āyasmataḥ mahākassapassa saḥ ābādhaḥ ahosi iti therassa
translated: “The seven factors of enlightenment”: the factors of enlightenment of the path together with insight. The second and third are evident in meaning.🔽The commentary on the first on the sick is finished.

original: kira imaṃ bojjhaṅgabhāvanaṃ sādhukaṃ suṇantassa etadahosi “mayhaṃ pabbajitadivasato
analyzed: kira imam bojjhaṅga bhāvanam sādhukam suṇantassa etat ahosi mayham pabbajita divasataḥ
translated: In the fourth, “so the venerable Maha Kassapa’s affliction subsided”: it seems that when the elder was listening carefully to this development of the factors of enlightenment, he thought: “From the day I went forth🔽I have never had such a pleasant abiding as I have today.”

original: sattame divase saccāni paṭivijjhantassa ime bojjhaṅgā pātubhūtā”ti. Athassa “niyyānikaṃ🔽vata satthusāsana”nti cintayato lohitaṃ pasīdi, upādārūpaṃ visuddhaṃ ahosi, pokkharapatte🔽patitaudakabindu viya sarīrato rogo vinivattitvā gato. Tena vuttaṃ “tathā pahīno🔽cāyasmato mahākassapassa so ābādho ahosī”ti. Pañcamachaṭṭhesupi eseva nayo. Imesaṃ
analyzed: sattame divase saccāni paṭivijjhantassa ime bojjhaṅgā pātubhūtā ati athassa niyyānikam  vata satthu sāsanam ti cintayataḥ lohitam pasīdi upādā rūpam visuddham ahosi pokkharapatte  patita audaka bindu viya sarīrataḥ rogaḥ vinivattitvā gataḥ tena vuttam tathā pahīnaḥ  ca āyasmataḥ mahākassapassa saḥ ābādhaḥ ahosi iti pañcama chaṭṭhesu pi esa iva nayaḥ imesam
translated: and on the seventh day, when he penetrated the Truths, these factors of enlightenment became manifest to him.” Then, as he reflected, “Surely the Teacher’s Dispensation is worth entering,” his blood became clear and his material form was purified, and the disease left his body and went away like a drop of water on a lotus leaf that has fallen to the ground. Hence it is said: “And so the venerable Maha Kassapa recovered from that affliction.” The same method of explanation applies to the fifth and sixth stories.🔽

original: pana tiṇṇampi janānaṃ pabbatapāde pupphitavisarukkhavātasamphassena uppanno mandasītajaro🔽ābādhoti veditabbo. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.🔽Gilānavaggo.
analyzed: pana tiṇṇam pi janānam pabbata pāde pupphita visa rukkha vāta samphassena uppannaḥ manda sīta jaro  ābādhaḥ ti veditabbaḥ sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati  gilāna vaggo
translated: and on the seventh day, when he penetrated the Truths, these factors of enlightenment became manifest to him.” Then, as he reflected, “The Teacher’s Dispensation is indeed a way out,” his blood became clear and his material form was purified. The disease left his body and went away like a drop of water on a lotus leaf that has fallen to the ground. Hence it is said: “So the venerable Maha Kassapa recovered from his affliction.” The same method of explanation applies to the fifth and sixth stories. But the disease of these three men should be understood as a slight cold and fever arising from the contact of the wind with the flowering trees on the mountain side. The rest is as already stated.🔽The Chapter of the Sick

original: 3. Udāyivaggo🔽1-2. Bodhāyasuttādivaṇṇanā🔽202-203. Tatiyavaggassa paṭhame kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, bojjhaṅgāti vuccantīti
analyzed: udāyi vaggo          tatiya vaggassa paṭhame kittāvatā nu kho bhante bojjhaṅgā ati vuccanti iti
translated: . The Chapter of Udāyī🔽. The Exposition of the First Fifty Discourses on the Factors of Enlightenment🔽. “In what way, venerable sir, are they called factors of enlightenment?”

original: bhante, kittakena nu kho bujjhanakaaṅgā nāma vuccantīti pucchati. Bodhāya saṃvattantīti
analyzed: bhante kittakena nu kho bujjhanakaaṅgāḥ nāma vuccanti iti pucchati bodhāya saṃvattanti iti
translated: “In what way, venerable sir, are they called factors of enlightenment?” “They lead to enlightenment”

original: bujjhanatthāya saṃvattanti. Imasmiṃ sutte missakabojjhaṅgā kathitā. Dutiye dhammaparicchedo kathito.🔽3-5. Ṭhāniyasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: bujjhana tthāya saṃvattanti imasmin sutte missaka bojjhaṅgā kathitā dutiye dhamma paricchedaḥ kathito
translated: they lead to enlightenment. In this Thread the enlightenment factors are mixed. In the second the investigation of ideas is stated.

original: 204-206. Tatiye kāmarāgaṭṭhāniyānanti kāmarāgassa kāraṇabhūtānaṃ ārammaṇadhammānaṃ.
analyzed: tatiye kāma rāga ṭṭhāniyānam ti kāma rāgassa kāraṇa bhūtānaṃ ārammaṇa dhammānam
translated: In the third “as a basis for lust for sensual desires” : as a cause for lust for sensual desires, as ideas that are objects.

original: Byāpādaṭṭhāniyādīsupi eseva nayo. Sakalañhi idaṃ suttaṃ ārammaṇeneva kathitaṃ. Paṭhamavaggassa
analyzed: byāpāda ṭṭhāniya ādīsu pi esa eva nayaḥ sakalam hi idam suttam ārammaṇena iva kathitam paṭhama vaggassa
translated: The same method applies in the case of “as a basis for ill will” and so on. For this whole Thread is stated only in terms of objects.

original: dutiyasutte vuttaparicchedopettha labbhateva. Catutthe missakabojjhaṅgā kathitā.
analyzed: dutiya sutte labbha tā iva catutthe missaka bojjhaṅgā kathitā
translated: In the fourth the enlightenment factors are mixed.

original: Pañcame aparihāniye dhammeti aparihānikare sabhāvadhamme.🔽6-7. Taṇhakkhayasuttādivaṇṇanā🔽207-208. Chaṭṭhe etadavocāti “imissaṃ parisati nisinno udāyitthero nāma anusandhikusalo
analyzed: pañcame a parihāniye dhamme iti a parihāni kare sabhāva dhamme  taṇhā khaya sutta ādi vaṇṇanā  chaṭṭhe etat avoca ati imissam parisati nisinnaḥ udāyi theraḥ nāma anusandhi kusalaḥ
translated: In the fifth “ideas that are not subject to loss” : ideas that are not subject to loss, that is, ideas that are the true nature of non-loss.

original: bhikkhu atthi, so maṃ pucchissatīti bhagavatā osāpitadesanaṃ ñatvā desanānusandhiṃ
analyzed: bhikkhu atthi saḥ mama pucchissati iti bhagavatā osāpita desanam ñatvā desanā anusandhim
translated: In the sixth “he said this” : the venerable elder Udaya, who was skilled in the continuity of the Thread, was sitting in this assembly, and the Blessed One had left the teaching unfinished, thinking “He will question me” . The venerable elder Udaya, having understood that the teaching had been left unfinished, asked the Blessed One the question in order to continue the teaching.

original: ghaṭessāmī”ti pucchanto etaṃ avoca. Vipulantiādi sabbaṃ subhāvitattaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ghaṭessāmi iti pucchantaḥ etam avoca vipula ntiādi sabbam su bhāvita ttam sandhāya vuttam
translated: The words “extensive,” etc., are said with reference to the fact that the enlightenment factor of mindfulness is well developed.

original: Subhāvito hi satisambojjhaṅgo vipulo ca mahaggato ca appamāṇo ca abyāpajjo ca nāma
analyzed: su bhāvitaḥ hi sati sambojjhaṅgaḥ vipulaḥ ca mahaggataḥ ca appamāṇaḥ ca abyāpajjaḥ ca nāma
translated: For when the enlightenment factor of mindfulness is well developed, it is called “extensive,” “great,” “immeasurable,” and “unadulterated.”

original: hoti. So hi patthaṭattā vipulo, mahantabhāvaṃ gatattā mahaggato, vaḍḍhipamāṇattā🔽appamāṇo, nīvaraṇānaṃ dūrībhāvena byāpādarahitattā abyāpajjho nāma hoti. Taṇhāya
analyzed: hoti saḥ hi patthaṭa ttā vipulaḥ mahanta bhāvam gata ttā mahaggataḥ vaḍḍhipamāṇa ttā  appamāṇaḥ nīvaraṇānam dūrībhāvena byāpāda rahita ttā abyāpajjhaḥ nāma hoti taṇhāya
translated: It is extensive because it is expanded; great because it has attained greatness; immeasurable because it is measured by expansion; and unadulterated because it is free from the defilements.

original: pahānā kammaṃ pahīyatīti yaṃ taṇhāmūlakaṃ kammaṃ uppajjeyya, taṃ taṇhāpahānena pahīyati.
analyzed: pahānā kammam pahīyati iti yam taṇhā mūlakam kammam uppajjeyya tam taṇhā apahānena pahīyati
translated: “With the abandoning of craving, kamma is abandoned”: whatever kamma would arise through craving is abandoned through the abandoning of craving.

original: Kammassa pahānā dukkhanti yampi kammamūlakaṃ vaṭṭadukkhaṃ uppajjeyya, taṃ kammapahānena
analyzed: kammassa pahānā dukkhanti yam pi kamma mūlakam vaṭṭa dukkham uppajjeyya tam kamma pahānena
translated: “With the abandoning of kamma, suffering is abandoned”: whatever suffering would arise through kamma is abandoned through the abandoning of kamma.

original: pahīyati. Taṇhakkhayādayo taṇhādīnaṃyeva khayā, atthato panetehi nibbānaṃ kathitanti
analyzed: pahīyati taṇhā khaya ādayaḥ taṇhā ādīnam yeva khayāḥ atthataḥ pana etehi nibbānam kathitan ti
translated: The words “with the destruction of craving,” etc., are said with reference to the destruction of craving, etc., themselves. But in meaning they are said with reference to Nibbāna.

original: veditabbaṃ. Sattamaṃ uttānameva.
analyzed: veditabbam sattamam uttānam eva
translated: The seventh simile is self-evident.🔽The section on the factors of enlightenment is finished.

original: 8. Nibbedhabhāgiyasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: nibbedhabhāgiya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The section on the factors of enlightenment is finished.

original: 209. Aṭṭhame nibbedhabhāgiyanti nibbijjhanakoṭṭhāsiyaṃ. Satisambojjhaṅgaṃ bhāvitenāti
analyzed: aṭṭhame nibbedha bhāgiyam ti nibbijjhana koṭṭhāsiyam sati sambojjhaṅgam bhāvitena ati
translated: In the eighth, in the section on penetration, “having developed the enlightenment factor of mindfulness” means

original: satisambojjhaṅgena bhāvitena, satisambojjhaṅgaṃ vā bhāvetvā ṭhitena, evamettha maggabojjhaṅgā
analyzed: sati sambojjhaṅgena bhāvitena sati sambojjhaṅgam vā bhāvetvā ṭhitena evam ettha magga bojjhaṅgā
translated: having developed the enlightenment factor of mindfulness, or having stood by developing the enlightenment factor of mindfulness. Thus here the path enlightenment factors are

original: missakā. Tehi bhāvitaṃ, te vā bhāvetvā ṭhitaṃ cittaṃ nibbattitalokuttarameva. Tampi
analyzed: missakā tehi bhāvitam te vā bhāvetvā ṭhitam cittam nibbattita lokuttaram eva tam pi
translated: mixed. The supramundane consciousness that arises is developed by them or having stood by developing them.

original: pana magganissitaṃ katvā missakameva kathetuṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: pana magga nissitam katvā missakam eva kathetum vaṭṭati
translated: But it is proper to explain it as mixed, taking it as dependent on the path.

original: 9. Ekadhammasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ekadhamma sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the ninth sutta

original: 210. Navame saṃyojanavinibandhāti saṃyojanasaṅkhātā vinibandhā. Ajjhosānāti pariniṭṭhapetvā gahaṇā.
analyzed: navame saṃyojana vinibandhā ati saṃyojana saṅkhātāḥ vinibandhāḥ ajjhosānā ati pariniṭṭhapetvā gahaṇā
translated: In the ninth, “bonds of fetters” means bonds called fetters. “Clinging” means grasping after completing.

original: 10. Udāyisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: udāyi sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the tenth sutta

original: 211. Dasame abahukatoti akatabahumāno. Ukkujjāvakujjanti ettha ukkujjaṃ vuccati udayo,
analyzed: dasame a bahu kato ti a kata bahu māno ukkujja avakujjanti ettha ukkujjam vuccati udayo
translated: In the tenth, “not being respectful” means not having respect. “Rising and falling” : here rising is called arising,

original: avakujjaṃ vayoti udayabbayavasena parivattento sammasantoti dīpeti. Dhammo ca me,
analyzed: avakujjam vayaḥ ti udaya bbaya vasena parivattento sammasanto ti dīpeti dhammo ca me
translated: falling is called fall. He shows that he is contemplating by revolving by way of arising and fall. “The Dhamma and

original: bhante, abhisamitoti vipassanādhammo abhisamāgato. Maggoti vipassanāmaggova. Sace
analyzed: bhante abhisamitaḥ ti vipassanā dhammaḥ abhisamāgataḥ maggo ti vipassanā maggaḥ uva sace
translated: “The Dhamma of insight is called ‘mastered’ because it has been mastered. The ‘path’ is the path of insight.

original: hi thero tasmiṃ samaye sotāpanno, upari tiṇṇaṃ maggānaṃ atthāya, sace anāgāmī, arahattamaggassa
analyzed: hi thero tasmin samaye sotāpannaḥ upari tiṇṇam maggānaṃ atthāya sace anāgāmī arahatta maggassa
translated: For if the elder is at the time a stream-enterer, it is for the purpose of the three higher paths; if he is a non-returner, it is for the purpose of the path of arahatship.

original: atthāya ayaṃ vipassanā veditabbā. Tathā tathā viharantanti tena tenākārena viharantaṃ.🔽Tathattāyāti tathābhāvāya. Khīṇā jātītiādīhi tathattāyāti adhippetaṃ tathābhāvaṃ
analyzed: atthāya ayam vipassanā veditabbā tathā tathā viharantam ti tena tena ākārena viharantam  tathattāya ati tathābhāvāya khīṇā jātī iti ādīhi tathattāya ati adhippetam tathābhāvam
translated: ‘He should understand that insight’ should be understood thus. ‘While he is living thus’: while he is living in such and such a way.🔽‘For the sake of that’: for the sake of that state. He shows the state intended by ‘for the sake of that’ with the words ‘Birth is destroyed’ , etc.

original: dasseti. Paccavekkhaṇatthāya upanīyatīti hi ettha adhippāyo, taṃ dassento evamāha.
analyzed: dasseti paccavekkhaṇa atthāya upanīyati iti hi ettha adhippāyaḥ tam dassentaḥ evam āha
translated: The meaning intended here is ‘for the purpose of reviewing’ . Showing that, he says ‘Birth is destroyed’ , etc.

original: Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: The rest is clear throughout.

original: Udāyivaggo.
analyzed: udāyi vaggo
translated: The chapter of Upāli.

original: 4. Nīvaraṇavaggo
analyzed: nīvaraṇa vaggo
translated: The chapter on the hindrances

original: 3-4. Upakkilesasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Suttas beginning with that on defilement

original: 214-215. Catutthavaggassa tatiye na ca pabhassaranti na ca pabhāvantaṃ. Pabhaṅgu
analyzed: catuttha vaggassa tatiye na ca na ca pabhāvantam pabhaṅgu
translated: In the third of the fourth chapter, not radiant: not shining.🔽Fragmented: of the nature of breaking up.

original: cāti pabhijjanasabhāvaṃ. Ayoti kāḷalohaṃ. Ṭhapetvā idha vuttāni cattāri avasesaṃ
analyzed: pabhijjana sabhāvam ayaḥ ti kāḷa loham ṭhapetvā idha vuttāni cattāri avasesam
translated: Iron: black iron. Except for the four mentioned here,

original: lohaṃ nāma. Sajjhūti rajataṃ. Cittassāti catubhūmakacittassa. Lokiyassa tāva upakkileso🔽hotu, lokuttarassa kathaṃ hotīti? Uppajjituṃ appadānena. Yadaggena hi uppajjituṃ🔽na denti, tadaggeneva te lokiyassāpi lokuttarassāpi upakkilesā nāma honti. Pabhaṅgu
analyzed: loham nāma sajjhūti rajatam cittassa ati catu bhūmaka cittassa lokiyassa tāva upakkileso  hotu lokuttarassa katham hoti iti uppajjitum appadānena yadaggena hi uppajjitum  na denti tad aggena iva te lokiyassa api lokuttarassa api upakkilesāḥ nāma honti pabhaṅgu
translated: “Metal” is silver. “Mind” is the mind of the four planes. It is a defilement of the mundane mind,

original: cāti ārammaṇe cuṇṇavicuṇṇabhāvūpagamanena bhijjanasabhāvaṃ. Anāvaraṇā anīvaraṇāti
analyzed: ca ati ārammaṇe cuṇṇa vicuṇṇa bhāva upagamanena bhijjana sabhāvam anāvaraṇā anīvaraṇā ti
translated: but how is it a defilement of the supramundane mind? By not giving it the opportunity to arise. For when it is not given the opportunity to arise by the path, then by that very fact it is a defilement of the mundane and supramundane minds. It is “fragile” because it is subject to breaking up by the occurrence of its object in a fragmented state.

original: kusaladhamme na āvarantīti anāvaraṇā, na nīvaranti na paṭicchādentīti anīvaraṇā.🔽Cetaso anupakkilesāti catubhūmakacittassa anupakkilesā.
analyzed: kusala dhamme na āvaranti iti anāvaraṇāḥ na nīvaranti na paṭicchādenti iti anīvaraṇā  cetasaḥ anupakkilesā ati catu bhūmaka cittassa anupakkilesā
translated: “Unhampered, unconfined”: it does not hamper or obstruct profitable states.

original: 8. Āvaraṇanīvaraṇasuttavaṇṇanā🔽219. Aṭṭhame paññāya dubbalīkaraṇāti paññāya mandabhāvakarā. Nīvaraṇānañhi abhiṇhuppāde sati antarantarā uppajjamānā paññā dubbalā hoti mandā avisadā.
analyzed: āvaraṇa nīvaraṇa sutta vaṇṇanā 🔽aṭṭhame paññāya dubbalīkaraṇā ati paññāya manda bhāva karā nīvaraṇānam hi abhiṇhuppāde sati antarantarā uppajjamānā paññā dubbalā hoti mandā avisadā
translated: “Not a corruption of the mind”: not a corruption of the mind of the four planes.

original: Pañca nīvaraṇā tasmiṃ samaye na honti. Sattabojjhaṅgā tasmiṃ samaye bhāvanāpāripūriṃ
analyzed: pañca nīvaraṇā tasmin samaye na honti satta bojjhaṅgā tasmin samaye bhāvanā pāripūrim
translated: The five hindrances are not present on that occasion. The seven factors of enlightenment go to fulfilment by development.

original: gacchantīti ariyasāvakassa hi sappāyadhammassavanaṃ suṇantassa pañca nīvaraṇā dūre
analyzed: gacchanti iti ariya sāvakassa hi sappāya dhamma ssavanam suṇantassa pañca nīvaraṇāḥ dūre
translated: For a noble disciple who is listening to the True Idea as it ought to be heard, the five hindrances are far away.

original: honti. So sace tasmiṃyeva ṭhāne visesaṃ nibbattetuṃ sakkoti, evamassa satta bojjhaṅgā🔽bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchanti. No ce sakkoti, tato vuṭṭhāya rattiṭṭhānadivāṭṭhānaṃ gato
analyzed: honti so sace tasmiṃ yeva ṭhāne visesam nibbattetum sakkoti evam assa satta bojjhaṅgāḥ  bhāvanā pāripūrim gacchanti no ce sakkoti tatas vuṭṭhāya ratti ṭṭhāna divāṭṭhānam gato
translated: If he is able to generate distinction in that place, then on that occasion his seven factors of enlightenment go to fulfilment by development.

original: tameva pītiṃ avijahanto pañca nīvaraṇe vikkhambhetvā visesaṃ nibbattessati. Tattha
analyzed: tam eva pītim a vijahantaḥ pañca nīvaraṇe vikkhambhetvā visesam nibbattessati tattha
translated: If he is not able to do so, then after emerging from that he goes to his night quarters and day quarters and generates distinction by suppressing the five hindrances without abandoning the happiness.

original: asakkontopi yāva sattadivasabbhantarā tameva pītiṃ avijahanto nīvaraṇe vikkhambhetvā
analyzed: a sakkontaḥ api yāva satta divasa bbhantarā tam eva pītim a vijahantaḥ nīvaraṇe vikkhambhetvā
translated: Therein, even if he is not able to do so, he generates distinction by suppressing the hindrances without abandoning that happiness within seven days.

original: visesaṃ nibbattessatīti idaṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Dhammassavanavasena sakiṃ pītipāmojjapakkhiyā
analyzed: visesam nibbattessati iti idam sandhāya itam vuttam dhamma ssavana vasena sakim pīti pāmojja pakkhiyā
translated: This is what is meant by the words ‘ The seven factors of enlightenment go to fulfilment by development ‘ .

original: paṭiladdhabojjhaṅgā hi kammārāmatādīni āgamma nassanti, tathārūpaṃ pana utusappāyādiṃ
analyzed: paṭiladdha bojjhaṅgāḥ hi kamma ārāma tā ādīni āgamma nassanti tathārūpam pana utu sappāya ādim
translated: The factors of enlightenment that have been obtained by the happiness and gladness due to hearing the True Idea are lost by coming under the sway of work, etc.,🔽but the right season, etc., are not like that.

original: labhitvā puna uppajjantāpi tasmiṃ samaye bhāvanāpāripūriṃ gacchanti icceva vuccati.
analyzed: labhitvā punar uppajjantā api tasmin samaye bhāvanā pāripūrim gacchanti icca iva vuccati
translated: and when they arise again after being obtained, they reach fulfilment in development at that time.

original: 9. Rukkhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: rukkha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Tree Sutta

original: 220. Navame ajjhāruhāti abhiruhanakā. Kacchakoti aṭṭhikacchako. Kapitthanoti makkaṭathanasadisaphalo vijātapilakkho.
analyzed: navame ajjhāruhā ati abhiruhanakā kacchako ti aṭṭhikacchako kapitthano ti makkaṭa thana sadisa phalo vijāta pilakkho
translated: In the ninth, “those who climb up” are those who climb up. “The tortoise” is a skeleton. “The jackfruit tree” is a tree with fruit like a monkey’s head and with smooth bark.

original: 10. Nīvaraṇasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: nīvaraṇa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Hindrances Sutta

original: 221. Dasame andhakaraṇāti andhabhāvakaraṇā. Acakkhukaraṇāti paññācakkhussa akaraṇā.
analyzed: dasame andha karaṇā ati andha bhāva karaṇā a cakkhu karaṇā ati paññā cakkhussa a karaṇā
translated: In the tenth, “causing darkness” means causing blindness. “Causing blindness” means causing the eye of wisdom to be blind.

original: Paññānirodhikāti paññāya nirodhanā. Vighātapakkhiyāti dukkhapakkhikā. Anibbānasaṃvattanikāti
analyzed: paññā nirodhikā ati paññāya nirodhanā vighāta pakkhiyā ati dukkha pakkhikā anibbāna saṃvattanikā ati
translated: “Stopping understanding” means stopping understanding. “Adverse to welfare” means on the side of suffering. “Not conducive to Nibbāna”

original: nibbānatthāya asaṃvattanikā. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthameva. Sakalepi imasmiṃ vagge
analyzed: nibbāna atthāya asaṃvattanikā sesam sabbattha uttāna attham eva sakale pi imasmin vagge
translated: means not conducive to the meaning of Nibbāna. The rest is all clear in meaning. In this whole chapter

original: missakabojjhaṅgāva kathitāti.🔽Nīvaraṇavaggo.
analyzed: missaka bojjhaṅgā ava kathitā ati  nīvaraṇa vaggo
translated: only the mixed enlightenment factors have been discussed.🔽The Hindrances Chapter

original: 5. Cakkavattivaggo
analyzed: cakkavatti vaggaḥ
translated: The Wheel-Turning Monarch Chapter

original: 1. Vidhāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vidhā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Explanation of the Destruction Sutta

original: 222. Pañcamavaggassa paṭhame tisso vidhāti tayo mānakoṭṭhāsā, mānoyeva vā. Tathā tathā vidahanato hi mānova vidhāti vuccati.
analyzed: pañcama vaggassa paṭhame tissaḥ vidhāti tayaḥ māna koṭṭhāsāḥ māno yā iva vā tathā tathā vidahanato hi māno uva vidhāti vuccati
translated: In the first of the fifth group, three kinds of pride : three kinds of pride-m ountains, or pride itself is so called because it burns up in this way and that.

original: 2. Cakkavattisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: cakkavatti sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: Explanation of the Wheel-turning Monarch Sutta

original: 223. Dutiye rañño, bhikkhave, cakkavattissāti ettha attano sirisampattiyā rājati,
analyzed: dutiye raññaḥ bhikkhave cakkavattissa ati ettha attano siri sampattiyā rājati
translated: In the second sutta, a king, bhikkhus, who is a wheel-turner : here a king is one who shines with his own glory,🔽or he is a king because he delights the world with the four kinds of sharing . He is a king of that kind.

original: catūhi vā saṅgahavatthūhi lokaṃ rañjetīti rājā, tassa rañño. “Pavattatu bhavaṃ cakkaratana”nti
analyzed: catūhi vā saṅgaha vatthūhi lokam rañjeti iti rājā tassa raññaḥ pavattatu bhavam cakka ratanan ti
translated: “May the Wheel-Treasure appear”

original: puññānubhāvena abbhuggatāya vācāya codento cakkaṃ vattetīti cakkavattī, tassa cakkavattissa.
analyzed: puñña anubhāvena abbhuggatāya vācāya codento cakkam vatteti iti cakkavattī tassa cakkavattissa
translated: and he is a wheel-turner because he turns the wheel by urging the wheel with the speech that has arisen by the influence of his merit.

original: Pātubhāvāti pātubhāvena. Sattannanti gaṇanaparicchedo. Ratanānanti paricchinnaatthadassanaṃ.
analyzed: pātubhāvā ti pātubhāvena gaṇana paricchedaḥ ratanānanti paricchinna attha dassanam
translated: The appearance : the appearance itself. Seven : a delimitation of number. Kinds of treasures : a delimitation of the meaning of the word “ treasure “.

original: Vacanattho panettha ratijananaṭṭhena ratanaṃ. Apica –
analyzed: vacana atthaḥ pana ittha rati janana ṭṭhena ratanam apica
translated: But the meaning of the word here is this : a treasure is so called because it generates delight . Besides :

original: “Cittīkataṃ mahagghañca, atulaṃ dullabhadassanaṃ;
analyzed: cittīkatam mahaggham ca atulam dullabha dassanam
translated: “ It is esteemed, it is costly, It is incomparable, hard to see,

original: Anomasattaparibhogaṃ, ratanaṃ tena vuccatī”ti.
analyzed: ratanam tena vuccati iti
translated: It is used by a noble man, So it is called a treasure “ .

original: Cakkaratanassa ca nibbattakālato paṭṭhāya aññaṃ devaṭṭhānaṃ nāma na hoti, sabbeva
analyzed: cakkaratanassa ca nibbatta kālataḥ paṭṭhāya aññam devaṭṭhānam nāma na hoti sabbā iva
translated: And from the time of the wheel-gem’s appearance no other shrine is needed,

original: gandhapupphādīhi tasseva pūjañca abhivādanādīni ca karontīti cittīkataṭṭhena ratanaṃ.🔽Cakkaratanassa ca “ettakaṃ nāma dhanaṃ agghatī”ti aggho natthi, iti mahagghaṭṭhenāpi
analyzed: gandha puppha ādīhi tassa iva pūjam ca abhivādana ādīni ca karonti iti cittīkata ṭṭhena ratanam  cakkaratanassa ca ettakam nāma dhanam agghati iti agghaḥ natthi iti mahaggha ṭṭhena api
translated: all worship the wheel-gem with perfumes, garlands, etc., and pay homage to it, and so it is a treasure as a shrine.🔽And there is no price for the wheel-gem, as there is for such things as jewels, pearls, etc., in terms of which it could be assessed as worth so much or so much, and so it is a treasure as priceless.

original: ratanaṃ. Cakkaratanañca aññehi loke vijjamānaratanehi asadisanti atulaṭṭhena ratanaṃ.
analyzed: ratanam cakka ratanam ca aññehi loke vijjamāna ratanehi asadisanti atula ṭṭhena ratanam
translated: And the wheel-gem is incomparable with any other treasure in the world, and so it is a treasure as incomparable.

original: Yasmā pana yasmiṃ kappe buddhā uppajjanti, tasmiṃyeva cakkavattino, buddhā ca kadāci🔽karahaci uppajjanti, tasmā dullabhadassanaṭṭhena ratanaṃ. Tadetaṃ jātirūpakulaissariyādīhi
analyzed: yasmai pana yasmin kappe buddhāḥ uppajjanti tasmin yeva cakkavattinaḥ buddhāḥ ca kadācid  uppajjanti tasmā dullabha dassana ṭṭhena ratanam tat etam jāti rūpa kula issariya ādīhi
translated: But since Buddhas appear only in a world system in which Buddhas appear, and wheel-turners only in a world system in which wheel-turners appear, and since Buddhas and wheel-turners appear only occasionally,

original: anomassa uḷārasattasseva uppajjati, na aññassāti anomasattaparibhogaṭṭhenāpi ratanaṃ.
analyzed: anomassa uḷāra sattassa iva uppajjati na aññassa ati anoma satta paribhoga ṭṭhena api ratanam
translated: it is a treasure as hard to find. And it appears only to a great man of the sort described in the way beginning, “He is born into a family of the warrior caste” , and not to anyone else, and so it is a treasure as used by a great man.

original: Yathā ca cakkaratanaṃ, evaṃ sesānipīti. Tena vuttaṃ –
analyzed: yathā ca cakka ratanam evam sesāni api iti tena vuttam
translated: And so too with the rest of the treasures.

original: “Cittīkataṃ mahagghañca, atulaṃ dullabhadassanaṃ;
analyzed: cittīkatam mahaggham ca atulam dullabha dassanam
translated: “The gem is said to be ‘marked,’ ‘costly,’ ‘incomparable,’ ‘hard to find,’

original: Anomasattaparibhogaṃ, ratanaṃ tena vuccatī”ti.🔽Pātubhāvo hotīti nibbatti hoti. Tatrāyaṃ yojanā – cakkavattissa pātubhāvā sattannaṃ
analyzed: ratanam tena vuccati iti  pātubhāvaḥ hoti iti nibbatti hoti tatra ayam yojanā
translated: ‘used by the best of men,’ and ‘a gem.’ ”

original: ratanānaṃ pātubhāvoti ayuttaṃ. Uppannañhi cakkaṃ vattetvā so cakkavattī nāma hotīti
analyzed: rata nānam pātubhāvaḥ ti ayuttam uppannam hi cakkam vattetvā saḥ cakkavattī nāma hoti iti
translated: “The appearance of the wheel-turning monarch is the appearance of seven treasures” is not correct. For the wheel-turning monarch is so called because the wheel has appeared after his appearance.

original: nāyuttaṃ. Kasmā? Cakkavattananiyamāpekkhatāya. Yo hi niyamena cakkaṃ vattessati,🔽so paṭisandhito pabhuti “cakkavatti pātubhūto”ti vattabbataṃ āpajjati. Laddhanāmassa🔽ca purisassa mūluppattivacanatopi yuttamevetaṃ. Yo hi esa cakkavattīti laddhanāmo
analyzed: na ayuttam kasmā cakka vattana niyama apekkha tāya yaḥ hi niyamena cakkam vattessati  saḥ paṭisandhitaḥ pabhuti cakkavatti pātubhūtaḥ iti vattabba tam āpajjati laddha nāmassa  ca purisassa mūla uppatti vacanataḥ pi yuttam eva etam yaḥ hi esa cakkavattī iti laddha nāmo
translated: This is not correct. Why? Because it is dependent on the appearance of the wheel-turning monarch.🔽For he who will turn the wheel is called a wheel-turning monarch from the time of his rebirth.🔽And it is correct to say that the appearance of the wheel-turning monarch is the appearance of the seven treasures because the name “wheel-turning monarch” is given to him after the appearance of the wheel.

original: sattaviseso, tassa paṭisandhisaṅkhāto pātubhāvoti ayamettha attho. Tassa hi pātubhāvā
analyzed: satta viseso tassa paṭisandhi saṅkhāto pātubhāvaḥ ti ayam ettha atthaḥ tassa hi pātubhāvā
translated: For the meaning here is this: the appearance of the seven treasures is the appearance of the wheel-turning monarch, who is a special being.

original: ratanāni pātubhavanti. Pātubhūtehi pana tehi saddhiṃ paripakke puññasambhāre so saṃyujjati,
analyzed: ratanāni pātubhavanti pātubhūtehi pana tehi saddhim paripakke puñña sambhāre saḥ saṃyujjati
translated: For the appearance of the seven treasures is the appearance of the wheel-turning monarch, and when the seven treasures have appeared, he is associated with them, with the matured requisites of merit.

original: tadā lokassa tesu pātubhāvacittaṃ uppajjati. Bahulavacanato cāpi yuttamevetaṃ. Yadā🔽hi lokassa tesu pātubhāvasaññā uppajjati, tadā ekameva paṭhamaṃ, pacchā itarāni cha
analyzed: tadā lokassa tesu pātubhāva cittam uppajjati bahula vacanato ca api yuttam eva etam yadā  hi lokassa tesu pātubhāva saññā uppajjati tadā ekam eva paṭhamam pacchā itarāni cha
translated: And it is because of the occurrence of these that the world’s consciousness arises. And it is also appropriate because of the frequency of their occurrence.🔽For when the world’s perception of their occurrence arises, then the first one occurs first, and the other six occur afterwards.

original: pātubhavantīti bahulavacanato cāpi etaṃ yuttaṃ. Pātubhāvassa ca atthabhedatopi yuttamevetaṃ.
analyzed: pātubhavanti iti bahula vacanato ca api etam yuttam pātubhāvassa ca attha bhedato pi yuttam eva etam
translated: And it is appropriate because of the different meanings of the word “occurrence.”

original: Na kevalañhi pātubhūtameva pātubhāvo, pātubhāvayatīti pātubhāvo. Ayaṃ pātubhāvassa
analyzed: na kevalañhi pātubhūtam eva pātubhāvaḥ pātubhāvayati iti pātubhāvaḥ ayam pātubhāvassa
translated: For “occurrence” is not only what occurs, but also that by which there is occurrence. This is the different meaning of the word “occurrence.”

original: atthabhedo. Yasmā yo so puññasambhāro rājānaṃ cakkavattiṃ paṭisandhivasena pātubhāvayati,
analyzed: attha bhedaḥ yasmai yaḥ so puñña sambhāraḥ rājānam cakkavattim paṭisandhi vasena pātubhāvayati
translated: Since this is so, it is appropriate to say “because of the occurrence of the wheel-turning monarch” because this is the accumulation of merit that occurs by way of rebirth-linking for the wheel-turning monarch.

original: tasmā rañño cakkavattissa pātubhāvā. Na kevalañhi cakkavattiyeva, imāni pana satta🔽ratanānipi pātubhavantīti ayamettha attho. Yatheva hi so puññasambhāro rañño janakahetu,
analyzed: tasmā rañño cakkavattissa pātubhāvā na kevalañhi cakkavattiyā iva imāni pana satta  ratanāni pi pātubhavanti iti ayam ettha atthaḥ yathā iva hi so puñña sambhāraḥ raññaḥ janaka hetu
translated: For not only does the wheel-turning monarch occur, but also these seven treasures occur. This is the meaning here.🔽Just as this accumulation of merit is the cause of the birth of the king,

original: evaṃ ratanānampi pariyāyena upanissayahetūti yuttamevetaṃ “rañño, bhikkhave, cakkavattissa
analyzed: evam ratanānam pi pariyāyena upanissaya hetū ti yuttam eva etam raññaḥ bhikkhave cakkavattissa
translated: so it is also the indirect cause of the treasures. It is appropriate to say “because of the occurrence of the wheel-turning monarch”

original: pātubhāvā sattannaṃ ratanānaṃ pātubhāvo hotī”ti.
analyzed: pātubhāvā pātubhāvaḥ hoti iti
translated: the appearance of the seven treasures.

original: Idāni tesaṃ ratanānaṃ sarūpavasena dassanatthaṃ katamesaṃ sattannaṃ cakkaratanassātiādimāha.🔽Tattha cakkaratanassātiādīsu ayaṃ saṅkhepādhippāyo – dvisahassadīpaparivārānaṃ catunnaṃ
analyzed: idāni tesam ratanānam sarūpa vasena dassana attham katamesam sattannam cakka ratanassa ati ādim āha  tattha cakkaratanassa ati ādīsu ayam saṅkhepa adhippāyaḥ dvi sahassa dīpa parivārānam catunnam
translated: Now, in order to show the nature of those treasures, he said, “What are the seven? The wheel treasure ….”🔽Herein, the meaning of the passage beginning with “the wheel treasure” can be summarized as follows:

original: mahādīpānaṃ sirivibhavaṃ gahetvā dātuṃ samatthassa cakkaratanassa pātubhāvo hoti,
analyzed: mahā dīpānam siri vibhavam gahetvā dātum samatthassa cakka ratanassa pātubhāvaḥ hoti
translated: The wheel treasure appears that is able to take the glory and wealth of the four great continents, which have a double-thousand of island continents as their retinue,🔽and give it to the king;

original: tathā purebhattameva sāgarapariyantaṃ pathaviṃ anupariyāyanasamatthassa vehāsaṅgamassa
analyzed: tathā purebhattam eva sāgara pariyantam pathavim anupariyāyana samatthassa vehāsaṅgamassa
translated: so too the elephant treasure, which is able to travel over the earth bounded by the ocean, going and returning in a single day;

original: hatthiratanassa, tādisasseva assaratanassa, caturaṅgasamannāgatepi andhakāre yojanappamāṇaṃ
analyzed: hatthi ratanassa tādisassa iva assa ratanassa catur aṅga samannāgate pi andhakāre yojana ppamāṇam
