original: sīlādīni vināsetuṃ sakkhissati? Esa attano kammena āgantvā attano kammeneva gamissati?🔽Appaṭicchitapaheṇakaṃ viya paṭivātaṃ khittarajomuṭṭhi viya ca etassevesa kodho matthake
analyzed: sīla ādīni vināsetum sakkhissati esa attano kammena āgantvā attano kammena iva gamissati  appaṭicchita paheṇakam viya paṭivātam khitta rajaḥ muṭṭhi viya ca etassa iva īsa kodhaḥ matthake
translated: destroy your virtue, etc., or not? It will come to you by your own action and will go by your own action.🔽This anger will fall on his head like a clod thrown against the wind or like a boomerang that has been thrown. ” In this way anger is abandoned by reviewing the ownership of kamma by oneself and by another.

original: patissatī”ti evaṃ attano ca parassa ca kammassakataṃ paccavekkhatopi, ubhayakammassakataṃ
analyzed: patissati iti evam attanaḥ ca parassa ca kammassakatam paccavekkhato pi ubhaya kammassakatam
translated: By reviewing the ownership of kamma by both,

original: paccavekkhitvā paṭisaṅkhāne ṭhitassāpi, assaguttattherasadise mettābhāvanārate kalyāṇamitte
analyzed: paccavekkhitvā paṭisaṅkhāne ṭhitassa api assagutta thera sadise mettā bhāvanā rate kalyāṇa mitte
translated: By attending on a good friend who is devoted to the development of loving-kindness, like the Elder Assagutta,

original: sevantassāpi byāpādo pahīyati, ṭhānanisajjādīsu mettānissitasappāyakathāyapi pahīyati.🔽Tena vuttaṃ “cha dhammā byāpādassa pahānāya saṃvattantī”ti. Imehi pana chahi dhammehi
analyzed: sevantassa api byāpādaḥ pahīyati ṭhāna nisajja ādīsu mettā nissita sappāya kathāya api pahīyati  tena vuttam cha dhammā byāpādassa pahānāya saṃvattanti iti imehi pana chahi dhammehi
translated: Anger is abandoned. It is abandoned too by talk about what is suitable, which is concerned with loving-kindness, in the course of the proper occasion for talk, etc.🔽Hence it is said: “Six things lead to the abandoning of anger” .

original: pahīnassa byāpādassa anāgāmimaggena āyatiṃ anuppādo hoti.
analyzed: pahīnassa byāpādassa anāgāmi maggena āyatim anuppādaḥ hoti
translated: But when anger has been abandoned by these six things, it does not arise again even in future states of existence through the path of non-returning.

original: Atthi bhikkhave aratītiādi vuttatthameva. Api ca cha dhammā thinamiddhassa pahānāya
analyzed: atthi bhikkhave arati itiādi vutta ttham eva api ca cha dhammā thinamiddhassa pahānāya
translated: Besides, six things lead to the abandoning of stiffness and torpor:

original: saṃvattanti – atibhojane nimittaggāho, iriyāpathasamparivattanatā, ālokasaññāmanasikāro,🔽abbhokāsavāso, kalyāṇamittatā, sappāyakathāti.
analyzed: saṃvattanti ati bhojane nimitta ggāhaḥ iriyāpatha samparivattana tā āloka saññā manasikāro  abbhokāsa vāso kalyāṇa mitta tā sappāya kathā ti
translated: taking up the sign of in-breaths and out-breaths, changing the posture, giving attention to perception of light, living in the open, having a good friend, and suitable talk.

original: Āharahatthakaṃ, bhuttavamitakaṃ, tatravaṭṭakaṃ, alaṃsāṭakaṃ, kākamāsakabhojanaṃ bhuñjitvā
analyzed: āharahatthakam bhuttavamitakam tatravaṭṭakam alaṃsāṭakam kākamāsaka bhojanam bhuñjitvā
translated: After eating as much as will suffice, after eating to satisfy, after eating to fill oneself up, after eating to gorge oneself, after eating like a grain-gatherer,

original: rattiṭṭhānadivāṭṭhāne nisinnassa hi samaṇadhammaṃ karoto thinamiddhaṃ mahāhatthī🔽viya ottharantaṃ āgacchati, catupañcaālopaokāsaṃ pana ṭhapetvā pānīyaṃ pivitvā yāpanasīlassa
analyzed: ratti ṭṭhāna divāṭṭhāne nisinnassa hi samaṇa dhammam karoto thinam iddham mahā hatthī  viyas ottharantam āgacchati catu pañca āla upaokāsam pana ṭhapetvā pānīyam pivitvā yāpana sīlassa
translated: when he sits down to do the ascetic’s duties in the place where he sleeps at night or in the place where he usually sits, then stiffness and torpor come upon him like a great elephant in rut.🔽But when a bhikkhu is one who lives by what he gets in alms and who is moderate in eating, then that does not happen to him.

original: bhikkhuno taṃ na hotīti evaṃ atibhojane nimittaṃ gaṇhantassapi thinamiddhaṃ pahīyati.
analyzed: bhikkhunaḥ tam na hoti iti evam ati bhojane nimittam gaṇhantassa api thinamiddham pahīyati
translated: So stiffness and torpor are abandoned in one who takes up the sign of over-eating in this way.

original: Yasmiṃ iriyāpathe thinamiddhaṃ okkamati, tato aññaṃ parivattentassāpi, rattiṃ candālokadīpālokaukkāloke
analyzed: yasmin iriyāpathe thinam iddham okkamati tatas aññam parivattentassa api rattim canda āloka dīpa āloka okka āloke
translated: And in one who changes the posture when stiffness and torpor come upon him in the posture he is wearing, and in one who gives attention to light, to the perception of light, to the idea of light, in the evening to the light of the stars and the moon, in the middle of the night to the light of the stars and the moon and to the directions and the sky, and in the morning to the directions, the sky and the sun, and in one who lives in the open, and in one who has a good friend, and in one who has suitable talk.

original: divā sūriyālokaṃ manasikarontassāpi, abbhokāse vasantassāpi, mahākassapattherasadise🔽pahīnathinamiddhe kalyāṇamitte sevantassāpi thinamiddhaṃ pahīyati, ṭhānanisajjādīsu🔽dhutaṅganissitasappāyakathāyapi pahīyati. Tena vuttaṃ “cha dhammā thinamiddhassa
analyzed: divā sūriya ālokam manasikarontassa api abbhokāse vasantassa api mahā kassapa tthera sadise  pahīna thinamiddhe kalyāṇa mitte sevantassa api thinamiddham pahīyati ṭhāna nisajja ādīsu  pahīyati tena vuttam cha dhammā thinamiddhassa
translated: and for one who, while standing, walking, sitting, and lying,🔽gives attention to the sign of serenity, and for one who talks about what is suitable in connection with the ascetic practices, stiffness and torpor are abandoned. That is why it was said above: ‘Six things lead to the abandoning of stiffness and torpor’ .

original: pahānāya saṃvattantī”ti. Imehi pana chahi dhammehi pahīnassa thinamiddhassa arahattamaggena🔽āyatiṃ anuppādo hoti.
analyzed: pahānāya saṃvattanti iti imehi pana chahi dhammehi pahīnassa thinamiddhassa arahatta maggena  āyatim anuppādaḥ hoti
translated: But when stiffness and torpor have been abandoned by these six things, their future non-arising is due to the path of arahatship.

original: Atthi bhikkhave cetaso vūpasamotiādīni vuttatthāneva. Apica cha dhammā uddhaccakukkuccassa
analyzed: atthi bhikkhave cetasaḥ vūpasamaḥ ti ādīni vutta tthānā iva apica cha dhammā uddhacca kukkuccassa
translated: ‘There is the stilling of the mental formations’ , etc., are in the same place as the meaning already given.

original: pahānāya saṃvattanti – bahussutatā, paripucchakatā, vinaye pakataññutā, vuddhasevitatā,
analyzed: pahānāya saṃvattanti bahu ssuta tā paripucchaka tā vinaye pakataññu tā vuddha sevita tā
translated: Moreover, six things lead to the abandoning of agitation and worry: much learning, questioning, skill in the dependent origination, association with good friends,

original: kalyāṇamittatā, sappāyakathāti.
analyzed: kalyāṇa mitta tā sappāya kathā ati
translated: good friendship, and suitable talk.

original: Bāhusaccenapi hi ekaṃ vā dve vā tayo vā cattāro vā pañca vā nikāye pāḷivasena ca
analyzed: hi ekam vā dve vā tayaḥ vā cattāraḥ vā pañca vā nikāye pāḷi vasena ca
translated: For one who is learned in the five Nikāyas as text and in the seven Abhidhamma Piṭakas as text and in the Vinaya as text, and who has asked questions about them and is skilled in the dependent origination, and who associates with good friends,

original: atthavasena ca uggaṇhantassāpi uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahīyati, kappiyākappiyaparipucchābahulassāpi,🔽vinayapaññattiyaṃ ciṇṇavasībhāvatāya pakataññunopi, vuddhe mahallakatthere upasaṅkamantassāpi,
analyzed: attha vasena ca uggaṇhantassa api uddhacca kukkuccam pahīyati kappiya akappiya paripucchā bahulassa api  vinaya paññattiyam ciṇṇavasībhāvatāya pakataññunaḥ api vuddhe mahallakatthere upasaṅkamantassa api
translated: And when he is learning the True Idea for the sake of the benefit of others, then too his agitation and worry are abandoned.🔽And when he is well-versed in the rules of the Discipline and so is discerning, then too his agitation and worry are abandoned.

original: upālittherasadise vinayadhare kalyāṇamitte sevantassāpi, uddhaccakukkuccaṃ pahīyati,🔽ṭhānanisajjādīsu kappiyākappiyanissitasappāyakathāyapi pahīyati. Tena vuttaṃ “cha🔽dhammā uddhaccakukkuccassa pahānāya saṃvattantī”ti. Imehi pana chahi dhammehi pahīne🔽uddhaccakukkucce uddhaccassa arahattamaggena, kukkuccassa anāgāmimaggena āyatiṃ anuppādo hotīti.
analyzed: upālitthera sadise vinaya dhare kalyāṇa mitte sevantassa api uddhacca kukkuccam pahīyati  ṭhāna nisajja ādīsu kappiya akappiya nissita sappāya kathāya api pahīyati tena vuttam cha  dhammā uddhacca kukkuccassa pahānāya saṃvattanti iti imehi pana chahi dhammehi pahīne  uddhacca kukkucce uddhaccassa arahatta maggena kukkuccassa anāgāmi maggena āyatim anuppādaḥ hoti iti
translated: And when he is attending on an elder who is a good friend and a master of the Discipline such as the Elder Upali, then too his agitation and worry are abandoned.🔽And when he is talking about what is allowable and not allowable as a help to him in the matter of the right and wrong occasions for standing, sitting, etc., then too his agitation and worry are abandoned. That is why it was said above ‘ Six dhammas are for abandoning agitation and worry ’ .

original: Kusalākusalā dhammātiādīnipi vuttatthāneva. Apica cha dhammā vicikicchāya pahānāya
analyzed: kusala akusalāḥ dhammā ti ādīni pi vutta tthāna iva apica cha dhammā vicikicchāya pahānāya
translated: But when these six dhammas have abandoned agitation and worry, then agitation is abolished in him by the path of Arahantship and worry is abolished in him by the path of Non-Return.

original: saṃvattanti – bahussutatā, paripucchakatā, vinaye pakataññutā, adhimokkhabahulatā,
analyzed: saṃvattanti bahu ssuta tā paripucchaka tā vinaye pakataññu tā adhimokkha bahula tā
translated: They are: much learning, asking questions, being skilled in the Vinaya, having much resolve,

original: kalyāṇamittatā, sappāyakathāti.
analyzed: kalyāṇa mitta tā sappāya kathā ati
translated: having good friends, and talk that is conducive.

original: Bāhusaccenapi hi ekaṃ vā…pe… pañca vā nikāye pāḷivasena ca atthavasena ca uggaṇhantassāpi
analyzed: hi ekam vāpe pañca vā nikāye pāḷi vasena ca attha vasena ca uggaṇhantassa api
translated: For even one who has learned by heart one or two or five of the five Nikāyas as the letter and the meaning

original: vicikicchā pahīyati, tīṇi ratanāni ārabbha paripucchābahulassāpi, vinaye ciṇṇavasībhāvassāpi,🔽tīsu ratanesu okappaniyasaddhāsaṅkhātaadhimokkhabahulassāpi, saddhādhimutte vakkalittherasadise
analyzed: vicikicchā pahīyati tīṇi ratanāni ārabbha paripucchā bahulassa api vinaye ciṇṇavasībhāvassa api  tīsu ratanesu okappaniya saddhā saṅkhāta adhimokkha bahulassa api saddhā adhimutte vakkali tthera sadise
translated: and who is full of doubt, and even one who is full of questions about the three Treasures, and even one who has mastered the Vinaya,🔽and even one who has much resolve called confidence in the three Treasures, and even one who serves good friends like the Elder Vakkali who was confident in faith,

original: kalyāṇamitte sevantassāpi vicikicchā pahīyati, ṭhānanisajjādīsu tiṇṇaṃ ratanānaṃ🔽guṇanissitasappāyakathāyapi pahīyati. Tena vuttaṃ “cha dhammā vicikicchāya pahānāya
analyzed: kalyāṇa mitte sevantassa api vicikicchā pahīyati ṭhāna nisajja ādīsu tiṇṇam rata nānam  pahīyati tena vuttam cha dhammā vicikicchāya pahānāya
translated: and even one who has talk that is conducive about the special qualities of the three Treasures in such places as a monastery, a lodging, or a seat,🔽doubt is abandoned. That is why it was said above: ‘Six ideas lead to the abandoning of doubt’ .

original: saṃvattantī”ti. Imehi pana chahi dhammehi pahīnāya vicikicchāya sotāpattimaggena
analyzed: saṃvattanti iti imehi pana chahi dhammehi pahīnāya vicikicchāya sotāpatti maggena
translated: But when doubt is abandoned in these six ways, it is abandoned by the path of stream-entry.

original: āyatiṃ anuppādo hoti. Iti bhagavā imasmiṃ sutte desanaṃ tīhi bhavehi nivattetvā arahattena
analyzed: āyatim anuppādaḥ hoti iti bhagavā imasmin sutte desanam tīhi bhavehi nivattetvā arahattena
translated: there is no future arising . Thus the Blessed One, having turned the teaching in this Thread around with three kinds of becoming,

original: kūṭaṃ gaṇhi. Desanāpariyosāne pañcasatā bhikkhū arahattaṃ pāpuṇiṃsu.
analyzed: kūṭam gaṇhi desanā pariyosāne pañcasatāḥ bhikkhū arahattam pāpuṇiṃsu
translated: took the peak with arahatship. At the end of the teaching the five hundred bhikkhus reached Arahantship.

original: 2. Pariyāyasuttavaṇṇanā🔽233. Dutiye sambahulāti vinayapariyāyena tayo janā sambahulāti vuccanti, tato paraṃ
analyzed: pariyāya sutta vaṇṇanā  dutiye sambahulā ati vinaya pariyāyena tayaḥ janā sambahulā ati vuccanti tato param
translated: The Commentary on the Second Thread

original: saṅgho. Suttantapariyāyena tayo tayo eva, tato uddhaṃ sambahulā. Idha suttantapariyāyena🔽sambahulāti veditabbā. Piṇḍāya pavisiṃsūti piṇḍāya paviṭṭhā. Te pana na tāva paviṭṭhā,🔽“pavisissāmā”ti nikkhantattā pana pavisiṃsūti vuttā. Yathā kiṃ? Yathā “gāmaṃ gamissāmī”ti
analyzed: saṅgho suttanta pariyāyena tayo tayo eva tatas sambahulāḥ idha suttanta pariyāyena  sambahulā ati veditabbā piṇḍāya pavisiṃsu iti piṇḍāya paviṭṭhā te pana na tāva paviṭṭhā  pavisissāma iti nikkhanta ttā pana pavisiṃsu iti vuttā yathā kim yathā gāmam gamissāmi iti
translated: In the second Thread “ several “ : according to the Vinaya-tradition three persons are called “ several “ , and more than that is called “ the Community “ . According to the Suttanta-tradition three or three are called “ several “ , and more than that is called “ many “ . Here “ several “ should be understood according to the Suttanta-tradition.🔽They entered the town in search of alms : they entered the town in search of alms. But they did not enter yet,🔽they were called “ entered “ because they had gone forth with the thought “ We shall enter “. How so? Just as a man who has gone forth with the thought “ I shall go to the village “

original: nikkhantapuriso taṃ gāmaṃ apattopi “kahaṃ itthannāmo”ti vutte “gāmaṃ gato”ti vuccati,
analyzed: nikkhanta puriso tam gāmam a pattaḥ api kaham itthannāmaḥ iti vutte gāmam gataḥ ti vuccati
translated: is called “ gone to the village “ even though he has not yet reached the village, when asked “ Where is so-and-so? “

original: evaṃ. Paribbājakānaṃ ārāmoti jetavanassa avidūre aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ārāmo
analyzed: evam paribbājakānam ārāmaḥ ti jetavanassa avidūre añña titthiyānam paribbājakānam ārāmaḥ
translated: “The park of the wanderers” is a park of the wanderers of other sects not far from Jeta’s Grove.

original: atthi, taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Samaṇo āvusoti āvuso tumhākaṃ satthā samaṇo gotamo.
analyzed: atthi tam sandhāya itam vuttam samaṇaḥ āvuso ti āvuso tumhākam satthā samaṇaḥ gotamo
translated: “The recluse” is your teacher, the recluse Gotama.

original: Mayampi kho āvuso sāvakānaṃ evaṃ dhammaṃ desemāti titthiyānaṃ samaye “pañca nīvaraṇā
analyzed: mayam pi kho āvuso sāvakānam evam dhammam desema ati titthiyānam samaye pañca nīvaraṇā
translated: “We too, friend, teach our disciples thus” means that in the doctrine of the sectarians there is no teaching of the disciples to abandon the five hindrances,

original: pahātabbā, satta bojjhaṅgā bhāvetabbā”ti etaṃ natthi. Te pana ārāmaṃ gantvā parisapariyante
analyzed: pahātabbā satta bojjhaṅgā bhāvetabbā ati etam natthi te pana ārāmam gantvā parisapariyante
translated: to develop the seven factors of enlightenment. They go to the park and stand at the edge of the assembly,

original: ṭhatvā aññaṃ olokento viya aññavihitakā viya hutvā bhagavato dhammadesanaṃ suṇanti.
analyzed: ṭhatvā aññam olokentaḥ viya añña vihitakāḥ viya hutvā bhagavataḥ dhamma desanam suṇanti
translated: looking around as if they were lost, and listen to the Blessed One’s teaching.

original: Tato “samaṇo gotamo ‘idaṃ pajahatha idaṃ bhāvethā’ti vadatī”ti sallakkhetvā attano
analyzed: tatas samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ idam pajahatha idam bhāvetha iti vadati iti sallakkhetvā attano
translated: Then, thinking, “The recluse Gotama says, ‘Abandon this, develop that,'” they return to their own park,

original: ārāmaṃ gantvā ārāmamajjhe āsanaṃ paññāpetvā upaṭṭhāyakaupaṭṭhāyikāhi parivutā sīsaṃ
analyzed: ārāmam gantvā ārāma majjhe āsanam paññāpetvā upaṭṭhāyaka aupaṭṭhāyikāhi parivutā sīsam
translated: set up their seats in the middle of the park, and surrounded by their female and male lay followers,

original: ukkhipitvā kāyaṃ unnāmetvā attano sayambhūñāṇena paṭividdhākāraṃ dassentā – “pañca
analyzed: ukkhipitvā kāyam unnāmetvā attanaḥ sayambhū ñāṇena paṭividdha ākāram dassentā pañca
translated: raise their heads and stretch out their bodies, showing that they have penetrated the state of self-awakening by their own knowledge, and say: “The five hindrances

original: nīvaraṇā nāma pahātabbā, satta bojjhaṅgā nāma bhāvetabbā”ti kathenti.🔽Idha no āvusoti ettha idhāti imasmiṃ paññāpane. Ko visesoti kiṃ adhikaṃ? Ko adhippayāsoti
analyzed: nīvaraṇā nāma pahātabbā satta bojjhaṅgā nāma bhāvetabbā ati kathenti  idha no āvuso ti ettha idha ati imasmin paññāpane kaḥ visesaḥ iti kim adhikam kaḥ adhippayāso ti
translated: The hindrances are to be given up, the seven factors of enlightenment are to be developed.”🔽Here, friend: here means in this exposition. What is the distinction? What is the difference? What is the variety? What is the diversity?

original: ko adhikappayogo? Kiṃ nānākaraṇanti kiṃ nānattaṃ? Dhammadesanāya vā dhammadesananti🔽yadidaṃ samaṇassa vā gotamassa dhammadesanāya saddhiṃ amhākaṃ dhammadesanaṃ, amhākaṃ
analyzed: kaḥ adhika ppayogaḥ kim nānākaraṇanti kim nānattam dhamma desanāya vā dhamma desananti  yat idam samaṇassa vā gotamassa dhamma desanāya saddhim amhākam dhamma desanam amhākam
translated: In the sense of the teaching of the Dhamma or of the teaching of the Dhamma.

original: vā dhammadesanāya saddhiṃ samaṇassa gotamassa dhammadesanaṃ ārabbha nānākaraṇaṃ vucceyya,
analyzed: vā dhamma desanāya saddhim samaṇassa gotamassa dhamma desanam ārabbha nānākaraṇam vucceyya
translated: Either in the sense of our teaching of the Dhamma in comparison with the recluse Gotama’s teaching of the Dhamma, or in the sense of the recluse Gotama’s teaching of the Dhamma in comparison with our teaching of the Dhamma,🔽the distinction, the difference, the variety, the diversity is said.

original: taṃ kinnāmāti vadanti. Dutiyapadepi eseva nayo.🔽Neva abhinandiṃsūti “evameva”nti na sampaṭicchiṃsu. Nappaṭikkosiṃsūti “nayidaṃ eva”nti
analyzed: tam kinnāma ati vadanti dutiya pade pi  na iva abhinandiṃsu iti evam evanti na sampaṭicchiṃsu na paṭikkosiṃsu iti na yidam evanti
translated: What is that? they say. The same method applies in the second case.🔽They neither rejoiced in his words nor did they reject them: they did not agree, saying “So it is” ;

original: na paṭisedhiṃsu. Kiṃ pana te pahontā evaṃ akaṃsu, udāhu appahontāti? Pahontā. Na
analyzed: na paṭisedhiṃsu kim pana te pahontā evam udāhu appahontā ati pahontā na
translated: nor did they contradict them, saying “It is not so” . But did they do this because they were unable or because they were able? Because they were able.

original: hi te ettakaṃ kathaṃ kathetuṃ na sakkonti “āvuso tumhākaṃ samaye pañca nīvaraṇā pahātabbā🔽nāma natthi, satta bojjhaṅgā bhāvetabbā nāma natthī”ti. Evaṃ pana tesaṃ ahosi – “atthi
analyzed: hi te ettakam katham kathetum na sakkonti āvuso tumhākam samaye pañca nīvaraṇā pahātabbā  nāma natthi satta bojjhaṅgāḥ bhāvetabbāḥ nāma natthi iti evam pana tesam ahosi atthi
translated: For they were unable to discuss the matter thus: “At your time, friends, the five hindrances are to be abandoned,

original: no etaṃ kathāpābhataṃ, mayaṃ etaṃ satthu ārocessāma, atha no satthā madhuradhammadesanaṃ desessatī”ti.
analyzed: no etam kathāpābhatam mayam etam satthu ārocessāma atha no satthā madhura dhamma desanam desessati iti
translated: but there is no such thing as the seven factors of enlightenment to be developed.” But they thought thus: “This is a matter that has arisen for us. We shall report it to the Teacher. Then he will teach us the Dhamma with its higher and higher levels of meaning, with its more and more sublime levels of meaning.”🔽“Reason”: cause.

original: Pariyāyoti kāraṇaṃ. Na ceva sampāyissantīti sampādetvā kathetuṃ na sakkhissanti.🔽Uttariñca vighātanti asampāyanato uttarimpi dukkhaṃ āpajjissanti. Sampādetvā kathetuṃ
analyzed: pariyāyo ti kāraṇam na ca iva sampāyissanti iti sampādetvā kathetum na sakkhissanti  uttarim ca vighātanti a sampāyanataḥ uttarim pi dukkham āpajjissanti sampādetvā kathetum
translated: “They will not be able to manage it”: they will not be able to discuss it after having managed it.🔽“And they will come to ruin”: because they will not be able to manage it, they will come to further suffering. For when they are unable to discuss it after having managed it,

original: asakkontānañhi dukkhaṃ uppajjati. Yathā taṃ, bhikkhave, avisayasminti ettha tanti
analyzed: a sakkontānam hi dukkham uppajjati yathā tam bhikkhave avisayasmin ti ettha tam ti
translated: suffering arises in them. As to the words “in a domain that is not a domain,”

original: nipātamattaṃ, yathāti kāraṇavacanaṃ, yasmā avisaye pañho pucchitoti attho. Sadevaketi
analyzed: nipāta mattam yathā iti kāraṇa vacanam yasmai avisaye pañho pucchito ti attho sa devaka iti
translated: the word “as” is a causal conjunction; the meaning is: “because a question is asked in a domain that is not a domain.”

original: saha devehi sadevake. Samārakādīsupi eseva nayo. Evaṃ tīṇi ṭhānāni loke pakkhipitvā
analyzed: saha devehi sa devake sa māraka ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ evam tīṇi ṭhānāni loke pakkhipitvā
translated: “Together with the gods”: together with the gods, in the company of the gods. The same method applies to the words “together with Mara” and so on. Having thus included three domains in the world,

original: dve pajāyāti, pañcahipi sattalokameva pariyādiyitvā etasmiṃ sadevakādibhede loke🔽devaṃ vā manussaṃ vā na samanupassāmīti dīpeti. Ito vā pana sutvāti ito vā pana mama
analyzed: dve satta lokam eva etasmin sa devaka ādi bhede loke  devam vā manussam vā na samanupassāmi iti dīpeti itas vā pana sutvā ati itas vā pana mama
translated: Two kinds of people: he shows that he does not see any god or human being in this world consisting of the divine world, etc., after having encompassed the entire world of beings with the five aggregates.

original: sāsanato sutvā. Ito sutvā hi tathāgato tathāgatasāvakopi ārādheyya, paritoseyya,
analyzed: sāsanataḥ sutvā itas sutvā hi tathāgataḥ tathāgata sāvakaḥ api ārādheyya paritoseyya
translated: Or having heard from me: he shows that whether one hears from him or from a disciple of the Tathāgata, one will attain the goal, will be satisfied,

original: aññathā ārādhanā nāma natthīti dasseti.
analyzed: aññathā ārādhanā nāma na atthi iti dasseti
translated: for there is no other way of attaining the goal.🔽Now, showing his own satisfaction with the answer to their questions, he said: “And what, bhikkhus, is the satisfaction of mind?🔽Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu does not lust after the objects of sensual pleasure. He does not lust after sensual pleasures internally or externally.

original: Idāni attano tesaṃ pañhānaṃ veyyākaraṇena cittārādhanaṃ dassento katamo ca bhikkhave🔽pariyāyotiādimāha. Tattha ajjhattaṃ kāmacchandoti attano pañcakkhandhe ārabbha uppannachandarāgo.🔽Bahiddhā kāmacchandoti paresaṃ pañcakkhandhe ārabbha uppannachandarāgo. Uddesaṃ gacchatīti

original: byāpādoti paresaṃ tesu uppannapaṭigho. Ajjhattaṃ dhammesu vicikicchāti attano khandhesu🔽vimati. Bahiddhā dhammesu vicikicchāti bahiddhā aṭṭhasu ṭhānesu mahāvicikicchā. Ajjhattaṃ🔽dhammesu satīti ajjhattike saṅkhāre paṭiggaṇhantassa uppannā sati. Bahiddhā dhammesu
analyzed: byāpādaḥ ti paresam tesu uppanna paṭighaḥ ajjhattam dhammesu vicikicchāti attanaḥ khandhesu  bahiddhā dhammesu vicikicchā ati bahiddhā aṭṭhasu ṭhānesu mahāvicikicchā ajjhattam  dhammesu sati iti ajjhattike saṅkhāre paṭiggaṇhantassa uppannā sati bahiddhā dhammesu
translated: Ill will is hostility towards them when they arise. Doubt about internal ideas is uncertainty about one’s own aggregates. Doubt about external ideas is the great uncertainty about the eight external bases. Mindfulness of internal ideas is the mindfulness that arises in one who accepts internal determinations. Mindfulness of external ideas is the mindfulness that arises in one who does not accept external determinations.

original: satīti bahiddhā saṅkhāre pariggaṇhantassa uppannā sati. Dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgepi eseva nayo.🔽Kāyikanti caṅkamaṃ adhiṭṭhahantassa uppannavīriyaṃ. Cetasikanti – “na tāvāhaṃ imaṃ🔽pallaṅkaṃ bhindissāmi, yāva me anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuccissatī”ti evaṃ kāyapayogaṃ
analyzed: sati iti bahiddhā saṅkhāre pariggaṇhantassa uppannā sati dhammavicaya sambojjhaṅge pi esā iva nayo  kāyikanti caṅkamam adhiṭṭhahantassa uppanna vīriyam cetasikanti na tāva aham imaṃ  pallaṅkam bhindissāmi yāva me an upādāya āsavehi cittam vimuccissati iti evam kāya payogam
translated: Ill will is hostility towards them when they arise internally. Doubt about ideas internally is uncertainty about one’s own aggregates. Doubt about ideas externally is the great uncertainty about the eight external bases. Mindfulness of ideas internally is mindfulness that has arisen in one who is taking the internal formations as object. Mindfulness of ideas externally is mindfulness that has arisen in one who is taking the external formations as object. The same method of explanation applies to the Investigation-of-Ideas enlightenment factor.

original: vinā uppannavīriyaṃ. Kāyappassaddhīti tiṇṇaṃ khandhānaṃ darathapassaddhi. Cittappassaddhīti
analyzed: vinā uppanna vīriyam kāya ppassaddhī iti tiṇṇam khandhānam daratha passaddhi citta ppassaddhī iti
translated: Vigour is bodily when it arises in one who has undertaken walking up and down. It is mental when it arises without bodily effort, as in one who is thinking “I shall not break this cross-legged posture until my mind is liberated from the taints by non-clinging” . Tranquillity of body is the stilling of the three taints of agitation. Tranquillity of cognizance is

original: viññāṇakkhandhassa darathapassaddhi. Upekkhāsambojjhaṅge satisambojjhaṅgasadisova vinicchayo.
analyzed: viññāṇa kkhandhassa upekkhā sambojjhaṅge sati sambojjhaṅga sadisaḥ uva vinicchayaḥ
translated: and the stilling of the disturbance in the consciousness aggregate. The exposition of the equanimity enlightenment factor is similar to that of the mindfulness enlightenment factor.

original: Imasmiṃ sutte missakasambojjhaṅgā kathitā. Etesu hi ajjhattadhammesu sati, pavicayo,
analyzed: imasmin sutte missaka sambojjhaṅgā kathitā etesu hi ajjhatta dhammesu sati pavicayo
translated: In this sutta the mixed enlightenment factors are taught. For in these internal states, mindfulness, investigation,

original: upekkhāti ime attano khandhārammaṇattā lokiyāva honti, tathā maggaṃ apattaṃ kāyikavīriyaṃ.
analyzed: upekkhā ti ime attanaḥ khandha ārammaṇa ttāḥ lokiyāḥ va honti tathā maggam apattam kāyika vīriyam
translated: and equanimity are mundane only because they have as their object one’s own aggregates. Likewise bodily energy if it has not reached the path.

original: Avitakkaavicārā pana pītisamādhī kiñcāpi rūpāvacarā honti, rūpāvacare pana bojjhaṅgā
analyzed: avitakka avicārā pana pīti samādhī kiñcā api rūpāvacarāḥ honti rūpāvacare pana bojjhaṅgā
translated: But the happiness and concentration free from thought and examination are of the fine-material sphere, but the enlightenment factors of the fine-material sphere

original: na labbhantīti lokuttarāva honti. Ye ca therā brahmavihāravipassanāpādakajjhānādīsu
analyzed: na labbhanti iti lokuttarāḥ ava honti ye ca therāḥ brahmavihāra vipassanā pādakajjhāna ādīsu
translated: are not found. Therefore they are supramundane. And according to the view of those elders who extract the enlightenment factors from the jhānas that are the basis for the divine abidings and insight,

original: bojjhaṅge uddharanti, tesaṃ matena rūpāvacarāpi arūpāvacarāpi honti. Bojjhaṅgesu
analyzed: bojjhaṅge uddharanti tesam matena rūpāvacarā api arūpāvacarā api honti bojjhaṅgesu
translated: they are of the fine-material sphere and the immaterial sphere. For in the immaterial-sphere enlightenment factors,🔽only happiness is definitely not found, while the rest are mixed.

original: hi arūpāvacare pītiyeva ekantena na labbhati, sesā cha missakāva hontīti. Desanāpariyosāne
analyzed: hi arūpāvacare pītiyā iva ekantena na labbhati sesā cha missakā ava honti iti desanā pariyosāne

analyzed: keci bhikkhū sotāpannā jātā keci sakadāgāmī keci anāgāmī keci arahantoti
translated: some bhikkhus became stream-enterers, some once-returners, some non-returners, and some arahants.

original: 3. Aggisuttavaṇṇanā🔽234. Tatiye satiñca khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sabbatthikaṃ vadāmīti loṇadhūpanaṃ viya sabbakammikāmaccaṃ
analyzed: aggi sutta vaṇṇanā  tatiye satim ca khvā aham bhikkhave sabbatthikam vadāmi iti loṇa dhūpanam viya sabba kammika amaccam
translated: 3. The third sutta

original: viya ca sabbattha icchitabbaṃ vadāmīti attho. Yathā hi loṇadhūpanaṃ sabbabyañjanesupi
analyzed: viya ca sabbattha icchitabbam vadāmi iti atthaḥ yathā hi loṇa dhūpanam sabba byañjanesu pi
translated: In the third sutta , “I say that mindfulness is necessary everywhere” means that it is to be desired everywhere, like salt in seasoning and like a minister of all work in all affairs. For just as salt is useful in all kinds of sauces and curries,

original: nivisati, yathā ca sabbakammiko amacco yodhakammampi karoti mantakammampi paṭihārakammampīti🔽sabbakiccāni sādheti, evaṃ uddhatassa cittassa niggaṇhanaṃ, līnassa paggaṇhananti
analyzed: nivisati yathā ca sabba kammikaḥ amaccaḥ yodha kammam pi karoti manta kammam pi paṭihāra kammam pi iti  sabba kiccāni sādheti evam uddhatassa cittassa niggaṇhanam līnassa paggaṇhananti
translated: and just as a minister of all work does the work of a soldier, the work of a watchman, and the work of a counsellor,

original: sabbametaṃ satiyā ijjhati, na sakkā vinā satiyā etaṃ sampādetuṃ, tasmā evamāha. Imasmiṃ
analyzed: sabbam etam satiyāḥ ijjhati na sakkā vinā satiyāḥ etam sampādetum tasmai evam āha imasmin
translated: and so he accomplishes all kinds of affairs, so too, the subduing of an excited consciousness and the arousing of a slack consciousness are all accomplished by means of mindfulness. It is not possible to accomplish them without mindfulness. That is why he said this.

original: sutte pubbabhāgavipassanā bojjhaṅgāva kathitā.
analyzed: sutte pubba bhāga vipassanā bojjhaṅgā ava kathitā
translated: In this sutta the enlightenment factors are given in the way in which they are developed in the first stage of the path.

original: 4. Mettāsahagatasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: mettā sahagata sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 4. The fourth sutta

original: 235. Catutthe mettāsahagatena cetasātiādi sabbaṃ sabbākārena visuddhimagge vitthāritameva.
analyzed: catutthe mettā sahagatena cetasā ati ādi sabbam sabba ākārena visuddhi magge vitthāritam eva
translated: In the fourth sutta , “With a mind accompanied by loving-kindness” and so on is all given in detail in the Path of Purification .

original: Mayampi kho, āvuso, sāvakānaṃ evaṃ dhammaṃ desemāti idampi te purimanayeneva satthu🔽dhammadesanaṃ sutvā vadanti. Titthiyānañhi samaye pañcanīvaraṇappahānaṃ vā mettādibrahmavihārabhāvanā🔽vā natthi. Kiṃ gatikā hotīti kiṃ nipphatti hoti. Kiṃ paramāti kiṃ uttamā. Kiṃ phalāti🔽kiṃ ānisaṃsā. Kiṃ pariyosānāti kiṃ niṭṭhā. Mettāsahagatanti mettāya sahagataṃ saṃsaṭṭhaṃ🔽sampayuttaṃ. Eseva nayo sabbattha. Vivekanissitādīni vuttatthāneva.
analyzed: mayam pi kho āvuso sāvakānam evam dhammam desema ati idam pi te purima nayena iva satthu  dhamma desanam sutvā vadanti titthiyānam hi samaye pañca nīvaraṇa ppahānam vā mettā ādi brahmavihāra bhāvanā  vā natthi kim gatikā hoti iti kim nipphatti hoti kim paramā ati kim uttamā kim phalā ati  kim ānisaṃsā kim pariyosānā ati kim niṭṭhā mettā sahagataṃ ti mettāya sahagatam saṃsaṭṭham  sampayuttam esa eva nayaḥ sabbattha viveka nissita ādīni vutta tthāna eva
translated: We too, friend, teach the Dhamma to our disciples like this.” They say this, having heard the Master’s teaching of the Dhamma in the way already stated. For at the time of the sectarians there is no abandoning of the five hindrances or development of the divine abidings beginning with loving- kindness. What is its destination? What is its outcome? What is its excellence? What is its fruit? What is its consummation? Associated with loving-kindness: associated with, joined to, combined with, mingled with, related to, loving-kindness. The same method of explanation applies in each case. Seclusion, etc., are in the same place as before.

original: Appaṭikūlanti duvidhaṃ appaṭikūlaṃ – sattaappaṭikūlañca, saṅkhāraappaṭikūlañca. Tasmiṃ🔽appaṭikūle iṭṭhe vatthusminti attho. Paṭikūlasaññīti aniṭṭhasaññī. Kathaṃ panettha🔽evaṃ viharati? Asubhapharaṇaṃ vā aniccanti manasikāraṃ vā karonto. Vuttañhetaṃ paṭisambhidāyaṃ
analyzed: appaṭikūlanti duvidham appaṭikūlam satta appaṭikūlam ca saṅkhāra appaṭikūlam ca tasmin 🔽a paṭikūle iṭṭhe vatthusmin ti attho paṭikūla saññī iti aniṭṭha saññī katham pana ittha 🔽evam viharati asubha pharaṇam vā aniccanti manasikāram vā karontaḥ vuttam ha etam paṭisambhidā ayam
translated: We too teach the Dhamma to our disciples in this way. ” This is what they say after hearing the Master’s teaching of the Dhamma in the way already described. For the sectarians have no teaching about the abandoning of the five hindrances or the development of the divine abidings beginning with loving- kindness. What is its destination? What is its outcome? What is its excellence? What is its danger? What is its escape? Associated with loving-kindness: associated with, bound up with, accompanied by loving-kindness. The same method of explanation applies in each case. Rooted in seclusion, etc., are in the same place as the above. Not-loathed: there are two kinds of not-loathed, namely, not-loathed as a living being and not-loathed as a thing. Herein, not-loathed as a living being is what is meant. In a not-loathed object: in a desirable object. Percipient of loathsomeness: percipient of undesirability. But how does he dwell? Either by means of the pervasion of foulness or by giving attention to it as “impermanent.” For this is said in the Paṭisambhidā:

original: “kathaṃ appaṭikūle paṭikūlasaññī viharati. Iṭṭhasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ asubhāya vā pharati,🔽aniccato vā upasaṃharatī”ti. Paṭikūle pana aniṭṭhe vatthusmiṃ mettāpharaṇaṃ vā dhātumanasikāraṃ🔽vā karonto appaṭikūlasaññī viharati nāma. Yathāha “kathaṃ paṭikūle appaṭikūlasaññī
analyzed: katham a paṭikūle paṭikūla saññī viharati iṭṭhasmim vatthusmim asubhāya vā pharati  aniccataḥ vā upasaṃharati iti paṭikūle pana aniṭṭhe vatthusmim mettā pharaṇam vā dhātu manasikāram  vā karontaḥ appaṭikūla saññī viharati nāma yathā āha katham paṭikūle appaṭikūla saññī
translated: “How does he dwell perceiving the unrepulsive in the repulsive? He pervades an agreeable object with the sign of the unrepulsive,🔽or he brings repulsiveness to mind in what is not unrepulsive. But when he pervades an object that is not agreeable with loving- kindness or he brings the sign of the unrepulsive to mind in what is unrepulsive, then he dwells perceiving the unrepulsive.

original: viharati. Aniṭṭhasmiṃ vatthusmiṃ mettāya vā pharati, dhātuto vā upasaṃharatī”ti.🔽Ubhayamissakapadesupi eseva nayo. Appaṭikūlappaṭikūlesu hi tadeva asubhapharaṇaṃ🔽vā aniccanti manasikāraṃ vā karonto paṭikūlasaññī viharati nāma. Paṭikūlāpaṭikūlesu
analyzed: viharati an iṭṭhasmim vatthusmim mettāya vā pharati dhātutaḥ vā upasaṃharati iti  ubhaya missaka padesu pi esa iva nayaḥ appaṭikūla paṭikūlesu hi tat eva asubha pharaṇam  vā aniccanti manasikāram vā karonto paṭikūla saññī viharati nāma paṭikūla a paṭikūlesu
translated: As it is said: “How does he dwell perceiving the unrepulsive in the repulsive? He pervades an unrepulsive object with loving-kindness, or he brings repulsiveness to mind in what is repulsive” .

original: ca tadeva mettāpharaṇaṃ vā dhātumanasikāraṃ vā karonto appaṭikūlasaññī viharati nāma.
analyzed: ca tat eva mettā pharaṇam vā dhātu manasikāram vā karontaḥ a paṭikūla saññī viharati nāma
translated: The same method applies to the two passages about the mixed. For when he brings the sign of the unrepulsive to mind or he brings repulsiveness to mind in the unrepulsive and in the mixed, then he dwells perceiving the repulsive. But when he pervades the mixed with loving- kindness or he brings the sign of the unrepulsive to mind in the repulsive and in the mixed, then he dwells perceiving the unrepulsive.

original: “Cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā neva sumano hotī”tiādinā nayena vuttaṃ pana chaḷaṅgupekkhaṃ
analyzed: cakkhunā rūpam disvā na iva su manaḥ hoti itiādinā nayena vuttam pana chaḷaṅgu pekkham
translated: The equanimity consisting in neutrality stated in the way beginning, “On seeing a visible object with the eye, he is neither glad nor …” ,

original: pavattayamāno “appaṭikūle ca paṭikūle ca tadubhayaṃ abhinivajjetvā upekkhako tattha
analyzed: pavattayamānaḥ appaṭikūle ca paṭikūle ca tat ubhayam abhinivajjetvā upekkhakaḥ tattha
translated: “Having avoided both the unrepulsive and the repulsive, he should abide in onlooking-equanimity.”

original: viharati sato sampajāno”ti veditabbo.🔽Ettāvatā ca imassa bhikkhuno mettāya tikacatukkajjhānaṃ nibbattetvā tadeva pādakaṃ🔽katvā vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā arahattaṃ pattassa saha vipassanāya maggasambojjhaṅgānaṃ🔽ariyiddhiyā ca dassitattā desanā vinivaṭṭetabbā siyā. Idaṃ pana mettājhānaṃ pādakaṃ
analyzed: viharati sataḥ sampajānoti veditabbo  ettāvatā ca imassa bhikkhuno mettāya tika catukka jjhānam nibbattetvā tat eva pādakam  katvā vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā arahattam pattassa saha vipassanāya magga sambojjhaṅgānaṃ  ariya iddhiyā ca dassita ttā desanā vinivaṭṭetabbā siyā idam pana mettā jhānam pādakam
translated: “He abides in equanimity, mindful and fully aware, having given up pleasure and pain” .🔽At this point the teaching could be brought to an end by showing how this bhikkhu, after producing the third and fourth jhānas in loving- kindness, and then extending it by means of the fourth jhāna as the basis for direct-knowledge, has reached Arahantship by developing insight and has thus shown the noble one’s power of supernormal knowledge.

original: katvā saṅkhāre sammasantopi yo arahattaṃ pāpuṇituṃ na sakkoti, yasmā tassa arahattaparamā
analyzed: katvā saṅkhāre sammasantaḥ api yaḥ arahattam pāpuṇitum na sakkoti yasmā tassa arahatta paramā
translated: But this teaching is begun in order to show the loving kindness that is not supreme in the case of one who is unable to reach Arahantship by developing insight with formations as object after taking that same fourth jhāna on loving kindness as the basis for insight.🔽But that which is supreme must be shown.

original: mettā na hoti. Yaṃparamā pana hoti, taṃ dassetabbaṃ. Tasmā tassa dassanatthaṃ ayaṃ🔽desanā āraddhā. Parato sabbaso vā pana rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamātiādīsupi iminā nayena
analyzed: mettā na hoti yaṃparamā pana hoti tam dassetabbam tasmā tassa dassana attham ayaṃ  desanā āraddhā paratas sabbasas vā pana rūpa saññānam iminā nayena
translated: So this teaching is begun in order to show that.

original: puna desanārambhapayojanaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: puna desanā ārambha payojanam veditabbam
translated: Or alternatively, the purpose of beginning the teaching again in the passage beginning, “When he abides in this way …” can be understood in the same way as the purpose of beginning it in the passage beginning, “When he brings to mind … as liberating … . ”

original: Subhaparamanti subhaniṭṭhaṃ, subhakoṭikaṃ, subhanipphattiṃ. Idhapaññassāti idheva🔽paññā assa, nayimaṃ lokaṃ atikkamatīti idhapañño, tassa idhapaññassa, lokiyapaññassāti
analyzed: subha paramanti subha niṭṭham subha koṭikam subha nipphattim idha paññassa ati idha iva  paññā assa na imam lokam atikkamati iti idha pañño tassa idha paññassa lokiya paññassa ati
translated: Subhaparamanti: subha-niṭṭhaṃ, subha-koṭikaṃ, subha-nipphattiṃ. Idhapaññassāti: idheva paññā assa, nayimaṃ lokaṃ atikkamatīti idhapañño, tassa idhapaññassa, lokiyapaññassāti.

original: attho. Uttarivimuttiṃ appaṭivijjhatoti lokuttaradhammaṃ appaṭivijjhantassa. Yo pana🔽paṭivijjhituṃ sakkoti, tassa arahattaparamāva mettā hotīti attho. Karuṇādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: atthaḥ uttari vimuttim a paṭivijjhato ti lokuttara dhammam a paṭivijjhantassa yaḥ pana  paṭivijjhitum sakkoti tassa mettā hoti iti attho karuṇā ādīsu pi esa eva nayo
translated: “Subha-p,” etc. : it is the end of beauty, the peak of beauty, the consummation of beauty. “Here-wisdom”: his wisdom is here, it does not go beyond this world. He has here-wisdom. The meaning is, he has mundane wisdom. “He does not penetrate to the further freedom”: he does not penetrate to the supramundane state. But the meaning is that one who can penetrate to it has loving-kindness that culminates in arahatship. The same method applies to compassion, and so on.

original: Kasmā panetāsaṃ mettādīnaṃ subhaparamāditā vuttā bhagavatāti? Sabhāgavasena tassa
analyzed: kasmā pana itāsam metta ādīnam subha parama ādi tā vuttā bhagavatā iti sa bhāga vasena tassa
translated: But why are loving-kindness, etc., said to culminate in beauty, and so on, by the Blessed One?🔽Because of their similarity to the respective jhānas.

original: tassa upanissayattā. Mettāvihārissa hi sattā appaṭikūlā honti, athassa appaṭikūlaparicayā
analyzed: tassa upanissaya ttā mettāvihārissa hi sattā a paṭikūlāḥ honti athassa a paṭikūla paricayā
translated: For when a person develops loving-kindness, beings are not repulsive to him, and then, when he has had practice in the non-repulsive,

original: appaṭikūlesu parisuddhavaṇṇesu nīlādīsu cittaṃ upasaṃharato appakasireneva tattha
analyzed: a paṭikūlesu parisuddha vaṇṇesu nīla ādīsu cittam upasaṃharato appa kasirena iva tattha
translated: his mind readily enters into the beautiful kasiṇas such as the blue one, etc.,

original: cittaṃ pakkhandati. Iti mettā subhavimokkhassa upanissayo hoti, na tato paraṃ, tasmā
analyzed: cittam pakkhandati iti mettā subha vimokkhassa upanissayaḥ hoti na tatas param tasmā
translated: So loving-kindness is a condition for the beautiful deliverance, but not for any higher deliverance, and that is why it is said to culminate in beauty.

original: subhaparamāti vuttā.
analyzed: subha paramā ati vuttā
translated: It is called “having beauty as its sovereign”.

original: Karuṇāvihārissa uṇhābhighātādirūpanimittaṃ sattadukkhaṃ samanupassantassa karuṇāya
analyzed: karuṇā vihārissa uṇha abhighāta ādi rūpa nimittam satta dukkham samanupassantassa karuṇāya
translated: When one who abides in compassion sees the sign of materiality in the form of the affliction of heat, etc., and the suffering of the seven kinds of personal existence, compassion

original: pavattisambhavato rūpe ādīnavo parividito hoti, athassa parividitarūpādīnavattā pathavīkasiṇādīsu
analyzed: pavatti sambhavataḥ rūpe ādīnavaḥ parividitaḥ hoti athassa parividita rūpa ādīnava ttā pathavī kasiṇa ādīsu
translated: occurs in him. So the danger in materiality becomes evident to him. Then, because he has evident to him the danger in materiality,

original: aññataraṃ ugghāṭetvā rūpanissaraṇe ākāse cittaṃ upasaṃharato appakasireneva tattha
analyzed: aññataram ugghāṭetvā rūpa nissaraṇe ākāse cittam upasaṃharato appa kasirena iva tattha
translated: after he has penetrated any one of the kasiṇas beginning with the earth kasiṇa, when he directs his mind to the space element as the escape from materiality,

original: cittaṃ pakkhandati. Iti karuṇā ākāsānañcāyatanassa upanissayo hoti, na tato paraṃ,
analyzed: cittam pakkhandati iti karuṇā ākāsānañcāyatanassa upanissayaḥ hoti na tatas param
translated: his mind enters into it without difficulty. So compassion is the proximate cause for the base consisting of boundless space, not for anything higher than that.

original: tasmā ākāsānañcāyatanaparamāti vuttā.🔽Muditāvihārissa pana tena tena pāmojjakāraṇena uppannapāmojjasattānaṃ viññāṇaṃ samanupassantassa🔽muditāya pavattisambhavato viññāṇaggahaṇaparicitaṃ hoti, athassa anukkamādhigataṃ
analyzed: tasmai ākāsa anañca āyatana paramā ati vuttā  muditāvihārissa pana tena tena pāmojja kāraṇena uppanna pāmojja sattānam viññāṇam samanupassantassa  muditāya pavatti sambhavataḥ viññāṇa ggahaṇa paricitam hoti athassa anukkama adhigatam
translated: It is called “having the base consisting of boundless space as its sovereign”.🔽But when one who abides in gladness sees the consciousness of beings who are glad because of this or that cause for gladness,🔽gladness occurs in him. So he becomes familiar with the apprehension of consciousness. Then, after he has penetrated the base consisting of boundless space, which he has reached in due course,

original: ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ atikkamma ākāsanimittagocare viññāṇe cittaṃ upasaṃharato appakasireneva
analyzed: ākāsānañcāyatanam atikkamme ākāsa nimitta gocare viññāṇe cittam upasaṃharato appa kasirena iva
translated: and has directed his mind to the consciousness that has the sign of space as its object, his mind enters into it without difficulty.

original: tattha cittaṃ pakkhandati. Iti muditā viññāṇañcāyatanassa upanissayo hoti, na tato
analyzed: tattha cittam pakkhandati iti muditā viññāṇañcāyatanassa upanissayaḥ hoti na tatas
translated: and his cognizance enters into that and acquires confidence in that. So the measure of the measureless is the base consisting of boundless consciousness.

original: paraṃ, tasmā viññāṇañcāyatanaparamāti vuttā.🔽Upekkhāvihārissa pana “sattā sukhitā vā hontu, dukkhato vā vimuccantu, sampattasukhato
analyzed: param tasmā viññāṇam ca āyatana paramā ti vuttā  upekkhāvihārissa pana sattā sukhitāḥ vā hontu dukkhataḥ vā vimuccantu sampatta sukhataḥ
translated: The measure of the measureless is the base consisting of boundless consciousness.🔽But in one who abides in equanimity, since there is no concern with “May beings be happy” or “May they be free from pain” or “May they keep to their own happiness” ,

original: vā mā vigacchantū”ti ābhogābhāvato sukhadukkhādiparamatthagāhavimukhasambhavato avijjamānaggahaṇadukkhacittaṃ🔽hoti. Athassa paramatthagāhato vimukhabhāvaparicitacittassa paramatthato avijjamānaggahaṇadukkhacittassa
analyzed: vā mā vigacchantu iti ābhoga abhāvataḥ sukha dukkha ādi paramattha gāha vimukha sambhavataḥ a vijjamāna ggahaṇa dukkha cittam  hoti athassa paramattha gāhataḥ vimukha bhāva paricita cittassa paramatthataḥ a vijjamāna ggahaṇa dukkha cittassa
translated: his cognizance is free from the suffering due to the taking up of what does not exist in the ultimate sense.🔽Then, when his cognizance is familiar with the state of being free from the taking up of what does not exist in the ultimate sense,🔽and his cognizance is free from the suffering due to the taking up of what does not exist in the ultimate sense,

original: ca anukkamādhigataṃ viññāṇāñcāyatanaṃ samatikkammasambhavato avijjamāne paramatthabhūtassa🔽viññāṇassa abhāve cittaṃ upasaṃharato appakasireneva tattha cittaṃ pakkhandati. Iti
analyzed: ca anukkama adhigatam viññāṇānaṃ ca āyatanam samatikkamma sambhavataḥ a vijjamāne paramattha bhūtassa  viññāṇassa abhāve cittam upasaṃharato appa kasirena iva tattha cittam pakkhandati iti
translated: and the base consisting of boundless consciousness has been reached in due course,🔽then when he brings his cognizance to bear on the non-existence in the ultimate sense of the consciousness that does not exist in the ultimate sense,

original: upekkhā ākiñcaññāyatanassa upanissayo hoti, na tato paraṃ, tasmā ākiñcaññāyatanaparamāti
analyzed: upekkhā ākiñcaññāyatanassa upanissayaḥ hoti na tatas param tasmai ākiñcaññāyatana paramā ti
translated: his cognizance enters into that and acquires confidence in that with little difficulty. So the measure of the measureless is the base consisting of nothingness.🔽The measure of the measureless is the base consisting of nothingness.

original: vuttā. Desanāpariyosāne pañcasatā bhikkhū arahattaṃ pattāti.
analyzed: vuttāḥ desanā pariyosāne pañcasatāḥ bhikkhū arahattam pattā ti
translated: and they did so. At the conclusion of the teaching, five hundred bhikkhus attained arahatship.

original: 5. Saṅgāravasuttavaṇṇanā🔽236. Pañcame pagevāti paṭhamaññeva. Kāmarāgapariyuṭṭhitenāti kāmarāgagahitena. Kāmarāgaparetenāti
analyzed: saṅgārava sutta vaṇṇanā  pañcame pagā iva ati paṭhamañca iva kāma rāga pariyuṭṭhitena ati kāma rāga gahitena kāma rāga paretena ati
translated: The Commentary on the Sangārava Sutta🔽On the very first day: on the very first day of his going forth. Obscured by lust and consumed by lust: seized by lust.🔽Surrounded by lust: accompanied by lust. Escape: there are three kinds of escape from lust: escape by suppression,

original: kāmarāgānugatena. Nissaraṇanti tividhaṃ kāmarāgassa nissaraṇaṃ vikkhambhananissaraṇaṃ🔽tadaṅganissaraṇaṃ samucchedanissaraṇanti. Tattha asubhe paṭhamajjhānaṃ vikkhambhananissaraṇaṃ
analyzed: kāma rāga anugatena nissaraṇanti tividham kāma rāgassa nissaraṇam vikkhambhana nissaraṇam  tad aṅga nissaraṇam samuccheda nissaraṇam ti tattha asubhe paṭhama jhānam vikkhambhana nissaraṇam
translated: escape by substitution of opposites, and escape by eradication. Herein, the first jhāna is called “escape by suppression” because it suppresses lust.

original: nāma, vipassanā tadaṅganissaraṇaṃ nāma, arahattamaggo samucchedanissaraṇaṃ nāma.
analyzed: nāma vipassanā tad aṅga nissaraṇam nāma arahatta maggo samuccheda nissaraṇam nāma
translated: Insight is called “escape by substitution of opposites” because it substitutes for lust. The path of arahatship is called “escape by eradication” because it eradicates lust.🔽The meaning is that he does not understand any of these three kinds of escape from lust.

original: Taṃ tividhampi nappajānātīti attho. Attatthampītiādīsu arahattasaṅkhāto attano attho
analyzed: tam tividham pi na pajānāti iti atthaḥ attattham pi itiādīsu arahatta saṅkhātaḥ attanaḥ attho
translated: In the phrases “his own good,” etc., his own good is the good of one who has attained arahatship;

original: attattho nāma, paccayadāyakānaṃ attho parattho nāma, sveva duvidhopi ubhayattho nāma.
analyzed: attatthaḥ nāma paccaya dāyakānam attho paratthaḥ nāma su eva duvidhaḥ pi ubhayatthaḥ nāma
translated: the good of others is the good of those who give the requisites; the good of both is the good of both the one who has attained arahatship and those who give the requisites.

original: Iminā nayena sabbavāresu attho veditabbo.
analyzed: iminā nayena sabba vāresu atthaḥ veditabbo
translated: The meaning should be understood in this way in all the parallel passages.

original: Ayaṃ pana viseso – byāpādassa nissaraṇantiādīsu hi dveva nissaraṇāni vikkhambhananissaraṇañca
analyzed: ayam pana visesaḥ byāpādassa nissaraṇa nti ādīsu hi dve eva nissaraṇāni vikkhambhana nissaraṇam ca
translated: But there is this difference. In the case of the words ‘the escape from ill will’ and so on, there are two kinds of escape, namely, escape by suppression and escape by eradication.

original: samucchedanissaraṇañca. Tattha byāpādassa tāva mettāya paṭhamajjhānaṃ vikkhambhananissaraṇaṃ,🔽anāgāmimaggo samucchedanissaraṇaṃ. Thinamiddhassa ālokasaññā vikkhambhananissaraṇaṃ,
analyzed: samuccheda nissaraṇam ca tattha byāpādassa tāva mettāya paṭhama jhānam vikkhambhana nissaraṇam  anāgāmi maggo samuccheda nissaraṇam thinamiddhassa āloka saññā vikkhambhana nissaraṇam
translated: Herein, the first jhāna is the escape by suppression of ill will,🔽and the non-return path is the escape by eradication of it. The perception of light is the escape by suppression of stiffness and torpor,

original: arahattamaggo samucchedanissaraṇaṃ. Uddhaccakukkuccassa yo koci samatho vikkhambhananissaraṇaṃ,
analyzed: arahatta maggo samuccheda nissaraṇam uddhacca kukkuccassa yaḥ koci samathaḥ vikkhambhana nissaraṇam
translated: and the arahant path is the escape by eradication of it. Any kind of serenity is the escape by suppression of agitation and worry,

original: uddhaccassa panettha arahattamaggo, kukkuccassa anāgāmimaggo samucchedanissaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: uddhaccassa pana ittha arahatta maggo kukkuccassa anāgāmi maggo samuccheda nissaraṇam
translated: but here the arahant path is the escape by eradication of agitation and the non-return path that of worry.🔽The defining of ideas is the escape by suppression of uncertainty,

original: Vicikicchāya dhammavavatthānaṃ vikkhambhananissaraṇaṃ, paṭhamamaggo samucchedanissaraṇaṃ.
analyzed: vicikicchāya dhamma vavatthānam vikkhambhana nissaraṇam paṭhama maggaḥ samuccheda nissaraṇam
translated: and the first path is the escape by eradication of it.

original: Yā panettha seyyathāpi brāhmaṇa udapatto saṃsaṭṭho lākhāya vātiādikā upamā vuttā,
analyzed: yā pana ittha sā iyyathā api brāhmaṇaḥ uda pattaḥ saṃsaṭṭhaḥ lākhāya vāti ādikā upamā vuttā
translated: But the simile of the water-bubble, etc., given here in the way beginning, “Just as, brāhmaṇa, a water-bubble …” ,

original: tāsu udapattoti udakabharitā pāti. Saṃsaṭṭhoti vaṇṇabhedakaraṇavasena saṃsaṭṭho.🔽Pakkuthitoti kuthito. Usmudakajātoti usumajāto. Sevālapaṇakapariyonaddhoti tilabījakādibhedena
analyzed: tāsu uda patto ti udaka bharitā pāti saṃsaṭṭho ti vaṇṇa bheda karaṇa vasena saṃsaṭṭhaḥ  pakkuthitaḥ iti kuthitaḥ usmudaka jātaḥ iti usuma jātaḥ sevā lapaṇaka pariyonaddhaḥ tila bījaka ādi bhedena
translated: Among them, “a bowl of water” is a bowl filled with water. “Muddied” is muddied by the making of a difference in colour.

original: sevālena vā nīlamaṇḍūkapiṭṭhivaṇṇena vā udakapiṭṭhiṃ chādetvā nibbattapaṇakena pariyonaddho.🔽Vāteritoti vātena erito kampito. Āviloti appasanno. Luḷitoti asannisinno. Kalalībhūtoti
analyzed: sevālena vā nīla maṇḍūka piṭṭhi vaṇṇena vā udaka piṭṭhim chādetvā nibbatta paṇakena pariyonaddhaḥ  vāta īritaḥ iti vātena eritaḥ kampitaḥ āvilaḥ ti appasannaḥ luḷitaḥ ti a sannisinno kalalībhūtaḥ iti
translated: “Turbid” is churned. “With sediment” is with sediment. “Covered over with water plants and algae” is covered over with water plants and algae born of heat, or covered over with water plants and algae of the kind called “sesame seed” and so on.

original: kaddamībhūto. Andhakāre nikkhittoti koṭṭhantarādibhede anālokaṭṭhāne ṭhapito. Imasmiṃ
analyzed: kaddamībhūtaḥ andhakāre nikkhitto ti koṭṭhantara ādi bhede anāloka ṭhāne ṭhapito imasmin
translated: “Disturbed by wind” is disturbed by wind, shaken. “Unclear” is not clear. “Muddy” is not settled. “Become like a morass” is become like a swamp. “Thrown into darkness” is thrown into a place without light, such as a pit.

original: sutte bhagavā tīhi bhavehi desanaṃ nivattetvā arahattanikūṭena desanaṃ niṭṭhāpesi,
analyzed: sutte bhagavā tīhi bhavehi desanam nivattetvā arahatta nikūṭena desanam niṭṭhāpesi
translated: In this sutta the Blessed One turned the teaching away from the three kinds of becoming and concluded the teaching with the peak of the dispensation,

original: brāhmaṇo pana saraṇamatte patiṭṭhito.🔽6. Abhayasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ pana saraṇa matte patiṭṭhito  abhaya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: but the brahmin was established in the refuge of the Triple Gem.🔽The explanation of the Abhaya Sutta is finished.

original: 237. Chaṭṭhe aññāṇāya adassanāyāti aññāṇatthāya adassanatthāya. Taggha bhagavā nīvaraṇāti
analyzed: chaṭṭhe aññāṇāya a dassanāya ati aññāṇa atthāya a dassana atthāya tat ha bhagavā nīvaraṇā ti
translated: In the sixth sutta, “for the sake of non-knowing, for the sake of non-seeing” means for the sake of ignorance, for the sake of blindness. “Indeed, Blessed One, an obstruction” means

original: ekaṃsena bhagavā nīvaraṇā. Kāyakilamathoti kāyadaratho. Cittakilamathoti cittadaratho.
analyzed: ekaṃsena bhagavā nīvaraṇā kāya kilamathā uti kāya daratho citta kilamathā uti citta daratho
translated: The Blessed One is the hindrance in the sense of obstructing. “Bodily pain” is bodily affliction. “Mental pain” is mental affliction.

original: Sopi me paṭippassaddhoti tassa kira satthu santike sītalaṃ utusappāyaṭṭhānaṃ pavisitvā
analyzed: saḥ api me paṭippassaddhaḥ ti tassa kira satthu santike sītalam utusappāyaṭṭhānam pavisitvā
translated: “That too has subsided in me”: it seems that when he entered a cool place suitable to the season,

original: nisinnassa kāyadaratho paṭipassambhi, tasmiṃ paṭipassaddhe tadanvayeneva cittadarathopi.
analyzed: nisinnassa tasmin paṭipassaddhe tad anvayena iva cittadaratho pi
translated: sitting down, his bodily affliction subsided, and with its subsiding his mental affliction did so too.

original: Apica maggenevassa etaṃ ubhayampi passaddhanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: apica maggena iva assa etam ubhayam pi passaddham ti veditabbam
translated: Besides, it should be understood that both were subsided by the path itself.

original: 7. Ānāpānavaggo
analyzed: āna apāna vaggaḥ
translated: The chapter on breathing

original: 1. Aṭṭhikamahapphalasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Aṭṭhika Sutta, etc.

original: 238. Sattamādīsu aṭṭhikasaññāti aṭṭhikaṃ aṭṭhikanti bhāventassa uppannasaññā. Taṃ
analyzed: sattama ādīsu aṭṭhika saññā ti aṭṭhikam aṭṭhikanti bhāventassa uppanna saññā taṃ
translated: In the case of the perception of a skeleton, etc., the perception that arises in one who develops the perception of a skeleton as a skeleton is the perception of a skeleton.

original: panetaṃ bhāvayato yāva nimittaṃ na uppajjati, tāva chavipi cammampi upaṭṭhāti. Nimitte
analyzed: pana itam bhāvayataḥ yāva nimittam na uppajjati tāva chavi pi cammampi upaṭṭhāti nimitte
translated: But when he develops it, as long as the sign does not arise, the skin and flesh and blood appear.🔽But when the sign arises, the skin, flesh and blood do not appear;

original: pana uppanne chavicammāni neva upaṭṭhahanti, saṅkhavaṇṇo suddhaaṭṭhikasaṅghāṭova
analyzed: pana uppanne chavi cammāni na iva upaṭṭhahanti saṅkha vaṇṇaḥ suddha aṭṭhika saṅghāṭaḥ uva
translated: only a pure mass of bones appears, like a white chalk outline,

original: upaṭṭhāti hatthikkhandhagataṃ dhammikatissarājānaṃ olokentassa sāmaṇerassa viya,
analyzed: upaṭṭhāti hatthi kkhandha gatam dhammika tissa rājānam olokentassa sāmaṇerassa viya
translated: as in the case of the novice attendant who was looking at King Dhammāsoka’s elephant.

original: paṭimagge hasamānaṃ itthiṃ olokentassa cetiyapabbatavāsino tissattherassa viya cāti.
analyzed: paṭimagge hasamānam itthim olokentassa cetiya pabbata vāsino tissa therassa viya
translated: and he who looked at a woman laughing on the opposite side of a street, like the Elder Tissa who lived on Cetiya Mountain.🔽The stories are given in detail in the Path of Purification.

original: Vatthūni visuddhimagge vitthāritāni. Sati vā upādiseseti gahaṇasese upādānasese vijjamānamhi.
analyzed: vatthūni visuddhi magge vitthāritāni sati vā upādi sese iti gahaṇa sese upādāna sese vijjamānamhi
translated: “As long as there is a residue of substrate”: as long as there is a residue of grasping, a residue of assuming.

original: 2-10. Puḷavakasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: puḷavaka sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Meditation Subject of the Nine Charnel-Ground Contemplations

original: 239-247. Puḷavakasaññāti puḷavaṃ puḷavanti bhāventassa uppannasaññā. Vinīlakasaññādīsupi
analyzed: puḷavaka saññā iti puḷavam puḷavanti bhāventassa uppanna saññā vinīlaka saññā ādīsu pi
translated: “The perception of a bloated corpse”: the perception arisen in one who develops the perception of a bloated corpse, a festering corpse, etc.,

original: eseva nayo. Vinicchayakathā panettha saddhiṃ bhāvanānayena visuddhimagge vuttā. Mettādayo
analyzed: esā iva nayaḥ vinicchaya kathā pana ittha saddhim bhāvanā nayena visuddhi magge vuttāḥ mettā ādayaḥ
translated: The explanation of the decision is given in the Path of Purification together with the method of development.

original: tikacatukkajjhānavasena veditabbā, upekkhā catutthajjhānavaseneva.
analyzed: tika catukka jhāna vasena veditabbā upekkhā catuttha jhāna vasena iva
translated: Loving-kindness, etc., should be understood as the three or four jhānas respectively, and equanimity as the fourth jhāna only.

original: 8. Nirodhavaggo
analyzed: nirodha vaggo
translated: The Chapter about Cessation

original: 1-10. Asubhasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Meditation Subject of the Nine Cemetery Contemplations

original: 248-257. Asubhasaññāti asubhe paṭhamajjhānasaññā. Maraṇasaññāti “avassaṃ maritabbaṃ,🔽maraṇapaṭibaddhaṃ me jīvita”nti abhiṇhaṃ paccavekkhantassa uppannasaññā. Āhāre paṭikūlasaññāti
analyzed: asubha saññā ati asubhe paṭhamajjhāna saññā maraṇa saññā ati avassam maritabbam 🔽maraṇa paṭibaddham me jīvitanti abhiṇham paccavekkhantassa uppanna saññā āhāre paṭikūla saññā ati
translated: “The perception of a bloated corpse”: the perception of the first jhāna in a bloated corpse.

original: odanakummāsādimhi ajjhoharaṇīye paṭikūlasaññā. Sabbaloke anabhiratisaññāti sakalalokasmiṃ
analyzed: odana kummāsa ādimhi ajjhoharaṇīye paṭikūla saññā sabba loke anabhirati saññā ati sakala lokasmiṃ
translated: Perception of foulness in what is to be swallowed, such as rice and porridge,

original: anabhiratiṃ uppādentassa uppannasaññā. Pahānasaññāvirāgasaññāti dve pubbabhāgā. Nirodhasaññā
analyzed: anabhiratim uppādentassa uppanna saññā pahāna saññā virāga saññā ati dve pubbabhāgāḥ nirodha saññā
translated: Perception of non-delight in all the world is the perception that arises in one who arouses non-delight in the whole world. Perception of giving up, perception of dispassion, and perception of cessation are the first two of the three kinds of perception associated with the development of understanding. Perception of abandoning is mixed.

original: missakā. Evametāni aṭṭhikasaññādīni vīsati kammaṭṭhānāni niddiṭṭhāni. Tesaṃ navasu
analyzed: missakāḥ evam etāni aṭṭhika saññā ādīni vīsati kammaṭṭhānāni niddiṭṭhāni tesam navasu
translated: So these twenty meditation subjects beginning with the perception of a skeleton have been demonstrated.🔽Nine of them have absorption; eleven are of the nature of access.

original: appanā honti, ekādasa upacārajjhānikā. Sesā panettha vinicchayakathā visuddhimagge
analyzed: appanāḥ honti ekādasa upacāra jhānikā sesā pana ittha vinicchaya kathā visuddhi magge
translated: But the rest of the explanation is given in the Path of Purity .

original: āgatāva. Gaṅgāpeyyālādayo maggasaṃyutte vuttanayeneva veditabbā.🔽Bojjhaṅgasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: āgatā ava gaṅgā peyyāla ādayaḥ magga saṃyutte vutta nayena iva veditabbā  bojjhaṅga saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Simile of the Ganges Raft, etc., should be understood in the way given in the Magga Saṃyutta .🔽The exposition of the Factors of Enlightenment is ended.

original: 3. Satipaṭṭhānasaṃyuttaṃ🔽1. Ambapālivaggo
analyzed: sati paṭṭhāna saṃyuttam  ambapāli vaggo
translated: The Connected Discourses on the Arousing of Mindfulness🔽The Chapter with Ambapālī

original: 1. Ambapālisuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Connected Discourse with Ambapālī

original: 367. Satipaṭṭhānasaṃyuttassa paṭhame ambapālivaneti ambapāliyā nāma rūpūpajīviniyā
analyzed: sati paṭṭhāna saṃyuttassa paṭhame ambapāli vane ti ambapāliyā nāma rūpa upajīviniyā
translated: In the first of the Connected Discourses on the Arousing of Mindfulness, “the chapter with Ambapālī” is the chapter with the nun named Ambapālī.

original: ropite ambavane. Taṃ kira tassā uyyānaṃ ahosi. Sā satthu dhammadesanaṃ sutvā pasannacittā
analyzed: ropite ambavane tam kira tassāḥ uyyānam ahosi sā satthu dhamma desanam sutvā pasanna cittā
translated: It seems that she had a park called Ambapālī. After hearing the Teacher teach the Dhamma, she became filled with confidence

original: tattha vihāraṃ kāretvā tathāgatassa niyyātesi. Taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Ekāyanvāyanti
analyzed: tattha vihāram kāretvā tathāgatassa niyyātesi tam sandhāya itam vuttam
translated: and he had a dwelling built and presented it to the Tathāgata. That is the meaning of the text. ‘The only way’:

original: ekāyano ayaṃ. Tattha ekāyanoti ekamaggo. Maggassa hi –
analyzed: eka ayanaḥ ayam tattha eka ayanaḥ ti eka maggaḥ maggassa hi
translated: ‘ekāyano’ means ‘the only way.’ For the word ‘way’ has many synonyms such as

original: “Maggo pantho patho pajjo, añjasaṃ vaṭumāyanaṃ;
analyzed: maggaḥ panthaḥ pathaḥ pajjaḥ añjasam vaṭuma ayanam
translated: ‘path,’ ‘road,’ ‘course,’ ‘track,’ ‘route,’

original: Nāvā uttarasetū ca, kullo ca bhisi saṅkamo”ti. –
analyzed: nāvā uttarasetū ca kullo ca bhisi saṅkamoti
translated: ‘raft,’ ‘bridge,’ ‘ford,’ ‘bank,’ ‘causeway,’

original: Bahūni nāmāni. Svāyaṃ idha ayananāmena vutto. Tasmā ekāyanvāyaṃ, bhikkhave, maggoti
analyzed: bahūni nāmāni su ayam idha ayana nāmena vuttaḥ tasmai ekāyanvā ayam bhikkhave maggo ti
translated: ‘boat,’ ‘means.’ Here it is called a ‘way’ . That is why it is said: ‘Bhikkhus, this way is the only way’ .

original: ettha ekamaggo. Ayaṃ, bhikkhave, maggo, na dvedhāpathabhūtoti evamattho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: ettha eka maggaḥ ayam bhikkhave maggaḥ na dvedhāpatha bhūtaḥ ti evamatthaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: Herein, ‘the only way’ means ‘the one and only way.’ ‘Bhikkhus, this way is the only way’ means that this way is not a way that leads two ways.

original: Maggoti kenaṭṭhena maggo? Nibbānagamanaṭṭhena, nibbānatthikehi magganīyaṭṭhena ca.🔽Sattānaṃ visuddhiyāti rāgādīhi malehi abhijjhāvisamalobhādīhi ca upakkilesehi saṃkiliṭṭhacittānaṃ
analyzed: maggaḥ iti kena ṭṭhena maggaḥ nibbāna gamana ṭṭhena nibbāna atthikehi magganīya ṭṭhena ca  sattānam visuddhiyā ati rāga ādīhi malehi abhijjhā visama lobha ādīhi ca upakkilesehi saṃkiliṭṭha cittānam
translated: ‘Way’: for what reason is it called a ‘way’? Because it goes to Nibbāna, and because those who seek Nibbāna should be gone by way of it.🔽‘For the purification of beings’: beings whose minds are defiled by the defilements of lust, etc., and by the stains of covetousness, dishonesty, etc.,

original: sattānaṃ visuddhatthāya. Sokaparidevānaṃ samatikkamāyāti sokassa ca paridevassa ca
analyzed: sattānam visuddha tthāya soka paridevānam samatikkamāya ati sokassa ca paridevassa ca
translated: are purified for the sake of purification from those defilements. ‘For the overcoming of sorrow and lamentation’:🔽‘sorrow’ is that arisen from sense desire, and ‘lamentation’ is that arisen from ill will.

original: samatikkamāya, pahānāyāti attho. Dukkhadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāyāti kāyikadukkhassa🔽ca cetasikadomanassassa cāti imesaṃ dvinnaṃ atthaṅgamāya, nirodhāyāti attho. Ñāyassa🔽adhigamāyāti ñāyo vuccati ariyo aṭṭhaṅgiko maggo, tassa adhigamāya pattiyāti vuttaṃ🔽hoti. Ayañhi pubbabhāge lokiyo satipaṭṭhānamaggo bhāvito lokuttaramaggassa adhigamāya
analyzed: samatikkamāya pahānāya ati atthaḥ dukkha domanassānaṃ atthaṅgamāya ati kāyika dukkhassa  ca cetasika domanassassa ca ati imesam dvinnam atthaṅgamāya nirodhāya ati atthaḥ ñāyassa  adhigamāya ati ñāyaḥ vuccati ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggo tassa adhigamāya pattiyā iti vuttam  hoti ayam hi pubbabhāge lokiyaḥ satipaṭṭhāna maggaḥ bhāvitaḥ lokuttara maggassa adhigamāya
translated: for the surmounting of, for the abandoning of. For the stilling of suffering and grief: for the stilling of these two, that is, for the cessation of bodily pain and mental grief. For the realization of knowledge: knowledge is said to be the noble path of eight factors. For the realization of that, for the attainment of it, is what is meant. For this is said: “The supramundane path is realized by means of the mundane path” .🔽🔽

original: saṃvattati. Tenāha “ñāyassa adhigamāyā”ti. Nibbānassa sacchikiriyāyāti taṇhāvānavirahitattā🔽nibbānanti laddhanāmassa amatassa sacchikiriyāya, attapaccakkhāyāti vuttaṃ hoti.🔽Ayañhi maggo bhāvito anupubbena nibbānasacchikiriyaṃ sādheti. Tenāha “nibbānassa sacchikiriyāyā”ti.🔽Evaṃ bhagavatā sattahi padehi ekāyanamaggassa vaṇṇo bhāsito, so kasmāti ce? Bhikkhūnaṃ
analyzed: saṃvattati tena āha ñāyassa adhigamāya ati nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya ati taṇhā vāna virahita ttā 🔽nibbānam ti laddha nāmassa amatassa sacchikiriyāya atta paccakkhāya ati vuttam hoti 🔽ayan hi maggaḥ bhāvitaḥ anupubbena nibbāna sacchikiriyam sādheti tena āha nibbānassa sacchikiriyāya ati 🔽evam bhagavatā sattahi padehi ekāyana maggassa vaṇṇaḥ bhāsito saḥ kasmā iti ce bhikkhūnam
translated: for the surmounting of them, for the abandoning of them, is what is meant. For the fading away of lust, for the fading away of hatred, for the fading away of delusion: for the fading away of these three, is what is meant. For the fading away of lust, etc., is the same as for their abandoning. For the cessation of bodily pain and mental grief: for the cessation of these two, is what is meant. For bodily pain is the painful feeling rooted in bodily intimation, and mental grief is displeasure. For the cessation of these two, is what is meant. For the realization of the fruit of true knowledge and deliverance: the noble path consisting of the seven factors of enlightenment is called “true knowledge” and the fruit of arahantship is called “deliverance.” For the realization of these two, is what is meant. For the noble path is the means for realizing true knowledge, and the fruit of arahantship is the means for realizing deliverance. For the realization of the fruit of true knowledge and deliverance: for the realization of these two, is what is meant. For the noble path is the means for realizing true knowledge, and the fruit of arahantship is the means for realizing deliverance. For the realization of the fruit of true knowledge and deliverance: for the realization of these two, is what is meant. For the noble path is the means for realizing true knowledge, and the fruit of arahantship is the means for realizing deliverance. For the realization of the fruit of true knowledge and deliverance: for the realization of these two, is what is meant. For the noble path is the means for realizing true knowledge, and the fruit of arahantship is the means for realizing deliverance. For the realization of the fruit of true knowledge and deliverance: for the realization of these two, is what is meant. For the noble path is the means for realizing true knowledge, and the fruit of arahantship is the means for realizing deliverance. For the realization of the fruit of true knowledge and deliverance: for the realization of these two, is what is meant. For the noble path is the means for realizing true knowledge, and the fruit of arahantship is the means for realizing deliverance. For the realization of the fruit of true knowledge and deliverance: for the realization of these two, is what is meant. For the noble path is the means for realizing true knowledge, and the fruit of arahantship is the means for realizing deliverance. For the realization of the fruit of true knowledge and deliverance

original: ussāhajananatthaṃ. Vaṇṇabhāsanañhi sutvā te bhikkhū – “ayaṃ kira maggo hadayasantāpabhūtaṃ🔽sokaṃ, vācāvippalāpabhūtaṃ paridevaṃ, kāyikaasātabhūtaṃ dukkhaṃ, cetasikaasātabhūtaṃ
analyzed: ussāha janana attham vaṇṇa bhāsanam hi sutvā te bhikkhū ayam kira maggaḥ hadaya santāpa bhūtam  sokam vācā vippalāpa bhūtam paridevam kāyika asāta bhūtam dukkham cetasika asāta bhūtam
translated: for the purpose of arousing zeal. For when they hear the praise of the path, the bhikkhus will think: “This path, it seems, removes the four dangers which are the cause of sorrow, namely,

original: domanassanti cattāro upaddave harati. Visuddhiṃ, ñāyaṃ, nibbānanti tayo visese āvahatī”ti
analyzed: domanassanti cattāraḥ upaddave harati visuddhim ñāyam nibbānanti tayaḥ visese āvahati iti
translated: sorrow itself, lamentation, pain, and despair, and it brings about the three special qualities, namely, purification, the right path, and Nibbāna.”

original: ussāhajātā imaṃ desanaṃ uggahetabbaṃ pariyāpuṇitabbaṃ, dhāretabbaṃ, imañca maggaṃ🔽bhāvetabbaṃ maññissanti. Iti tesaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ ussāhajananatthaṃ vaṇṇaṃ abhāsi kambalavāṇijādayo
analyzed: ussāha jātāḥ imam desanam uggahetabbam pariyāpuṇitabbam dhāretabbam imam ca maggaṃ  bhāvetabbam maññissanti iti tesam bhikkhūnam ussāha janana attham vaṇṇam abhāsi kambala vāṇija ādayo
translated: Thus they will consider that this teaching should be learned, mastered, borne in mind, and this path should be

original: kambalādīnaṃ vaṇṇaṃ viya.🔽Yadidanti nipāto, ye imeti ayamassa attho. Cattāroti gaṇanaparicchedo. Tena “na tato
analyzed: kambala ādīnam vaṇṇam viya  yat idam iti nipātaḥ ye ime iti ayam assa attho cattāro ti gaṇana paricchedaḥ tena na tatas
translated: developed. Thus it is for the purpose of arousing zeal in those bhikkhus that the Exalted One praises the path, just as the merchants praise the wool, etc.

original: heṭṭhā, na uddha”nti satipaṭṭhānaparicchedaṃ dīpeti. Satipaṭṭhānāti tayo satipaṭṭhānā
analyzed: heṭṭhā naḥ uddhanti sati paṭṭhāna paricchedam dīpeti sati paṭṭhānā ati tayo sati paṭṭhānā
translated: Yad-idam is a particle; ye ime is its meaning. Cattaro is a numerical determination. By that he shows the determination of the establishments of mindfulness, “not less than that, not more than that.” Satipatthana means the three establishments of mindfulness.

original: satigocaropi, tidhā paṭipannesu sāvakesu satthuno paṭighānunayavītivattatāpi, satipi.
analyzed: sati gocaraḥ api tidhā paṭipannesu sāvakesu satthuno sati pi
translated: And the object of mindfulness is the avoidance of resentment and gratification towards disciples who are practising the three ways.

original: “Catunnaṃ, bhikkhave, satipaṭṭhānānaṃ samudayañca atthaṅgamañca desessāmi taṃ suṇātha.
analyzed: catunnam bhikkhave satipaṭṭhānānam samudayañca atthaṅgamañca desessāmi tam suṇātha
translated: “Bhikkhus, I will teach you the origin and the passing away of the four foundations of mindfulness. Listen and attend closely to what I shall say.”

original: Ko ca, bhikkhave, kāyassa samudayo? Āharasamudayā kāyasamudayo”tiādīsu hi satigocaro🔽satipaṭṭhānanti vutto. Tathā “kāyo upaṭṭhānaṃ, no sati, sati upaṭṭhānañceva sati
analyzed: kaḥ ca bhikkhave kāyassa samudayaḥ āhara samudayā kāya samudayaḥ iti ādīsu hi sati gocaraḥ  sati paṭṭhānam ti vuttaḥ tathā kāyaḥ upaṭṭhānam no sati sati upaṭṭhānam ca iva sati
translated: “And what, bhikkhus, is the origin of the body? It is the origin of nutriment that is the origin of the body” .🔽Herein, the object of mindfulness is called a “foundation of mindfulness” .🔽And so too in the passage: “The body is a thing to be meditated upon, but not the perception of the body as a limited being; the perception of unloveliness is a thing to be meditated upon, but not the body” ,

original: cā”tiādīsupi. Tassa attho – patiṭṭhāti asminti paṭṭhānaṃ. Kā patiṭṭhāti? Sati. Satiyā
analyzed: ca ati ādīsu pi tassa atthaḥ patiṭṭhāti asmin ti paṭṭhānam kā patiṭṭhāti satī satiyā
translated: the meaning is this: It is a foundation because it is established in this . What is established? Mindfulness.🔽The foundation of mindfulness is that which is the foundation for mindfulness.

original: paṭṭhānaṃ satipaṭṭhānaṃ. Padhānaṃ ṭhānanti vā paṭṭhānaṃ. Satiyā paṭṭhānaṃ satipaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: paṭṭhānam sati paṭṭhānam padhānam ṭhānanti vā paṭṭhānam satiyā paṭṭhānam sati paṭṭhānam
translated: Or alternatively, it is a foundation because it is a standing place. The foundation of mindfulness is that which is the standing place for mindfulness,

original: hatthiṭṭhānaassaṭṭhānādīni viya.
analyzed: hatthi ṭṭhāna assa ṭṭhāna ādīni viya
translated: like the elephant’s standing place, the horse’s standing place, and so on.

original: “Tayo satipaṭṭhānā, yadariyo sevati, yadariyo sevamāno satthā gaṇamanusāsitumarahatī”ti
analyzed: tayo satipaṭṭhānā yat ariyaḥ sevati yat ariyaḥ sevamāno satthā gaṇam anusāsitum arahati iti
translated: “There are these three foundations of mindfulness that the Noble One cultivates, cultivating which the Noble One is a teacher fit to instruct a group” .

original: ettha tidhā paṭipannesu sāvakesu satthuno paṭighānunayavītivattatā satipaṭṭhānanti
analyzed: ettha tidhā paṭipannesu sāvakesu satthuno paṭigha anunaya vītivatta tā sati paṭṭhānan ti
translated: The Teacher’s transcending of resentment and approval towards disciples who have entered upon the three ways is the foundation of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of mental objects.

original: vuttā. Tassattho – paṭṭhapetabbato paṭṭhānaṃ, pavattayitabbatoti attho. Kena paṭṭhapetabboti?
analyzed: vuttā tassa atthaḥ paṭṭhapetabbataḥ paṭṭhānam pavattayitabbataḥ ti atthaḥ kena paṭṭhapetabbaḥ ti
translated: The Teacher’s transcending of resistance and approval in regard to disciples who have entered upon the three ways is called “establishment of mindfulness” . Its meaning is this: it is establishment because it is to be established, because it is to be brought about, is the meaning. By what is it to be established?

original: Satiyā. Satiyā paṭṭhānaṃ satipaṭṭhānanti.
analyzed: satiyā satiyā paṭṭhānam sati paṭṭhānam ti
translated: By mindfulness. Establishment by mindfulness is establishment of mindfulness .

original: “Cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satta bojjhaṅge paripūrentī”tiādīsu pana🔽satiyeva satipaṭṭhānanti vuttā. Tassattho – patiṭṭhātīti paṭṭhānaṃ, upaṭṭhāti okkanditvā🔽pakkhanditvā pavattatīti attho. Satiyeva paṭṭhānaṃ satipaṭṭhānaṃ. Atha vā saraṇaṭṭhena
analyzed: cattāro satipaṭṭhānā bhāvitā bahulīkatā satta bojjhaṅge paripūrenti itiādīsu pana  satiyā iva sati paṭṭhānanti vuttā tassa atthaḥ patiṭṭhāti iti paṭṭhānam upaṭṭhāti okkanditvā  pakkhanditvā pavattati iti attho satiyā iva paṭṭhānam satipaṭṭhānam atha vā saraṇa aṭṭhena
translated: But in such passages as “The four establishments of mindfulness, developed and repeatedly practiced, fulfil the seven factors of enlightenment” ,

original: sati, upaṭṭhānaṭṭhena paṭṭhānaṃ, iti sati ca sā paṭṭhānañcātipi satipaṭṭhānaṃ. Idamidha adhippetaṃ.
analyzed: sati upaṭṭhāna aṭṭhena paṭṭhānam iti sati ca sā sati paṭṭhānam ca atipi sati paṭṭhānam idam idha adhippetaṃ
translated: mindfulness itself is called “establishment of mindfulness” . Its meaning is this: it establishes , thus it is establishment ; it occurs by jumping down and jumping up, is the meaning. Establishment by mindfulness is establishment of mindfulness . Or alternatively, it is mindfulness because of the meaning of remembering , it is establishment because of the meaning of establishing ; thus it is both mindfulness and establishment, hence it is “mindfulness and establishment” . This is what is intended here.

original: Yadi evaṃ kasmā “satipaṭṭhānā”ti bahuvacanaṃ katanti? Satīnaṃ bahuttā. Ārammaṇabhedena
analyzed: yadi evam kasmā sati paṭṭhānā iti bahuvacanam satīnam bahuttā ārammaṇa bhedena
translated: If that is so, why is the plural form “establishments of mindfulness” used? Because there are many kinds of mindfulness.

original: hi bahukā satiyo. Atha “maggo”ti kasmā ekavacananti? Magganaṭṭhena ekattā. Catassopi
analyzed: hi bahukā satiyaḥ atha maggo ti kasmai ekavacananti maggana ṭṭhena ekattā catasso pi
translated: for there are many kinds of mindfulness. But why is the word “path” used in the singular? Because of unity in the sense of a path.

original: hi etā satiyo magganaṭṭhena ekattaṃ gacchanti. Vutañhetaṃ “maggoti kenaṭṭhena maggo?
analyzed: hi etāḥ satiyaḥ maggana ṭṭhena ekattam gacchanti vutam ha etam maggo iti kenaṭṭhena maggo
