translated: For all these four kinds of mindfulness go together in the sense of a path. It is said: “In what sense is it a path?🔽In the sense of a path to Nibbāna, and in the sense of what should be gone by way of a path by those who seek Nibbāna” .

original: Nibbānamagganaṭṭhena, nibbānatthikehi magganīyaṭṭhena cā”ti. Catassopi cetā aparabhāge🔽kāyādīsu ārammaṇesu kiccaṃ sādhayamānā nibbānaṃ gacchanti, ādito paṭṭhāya ca nibbānatthikehi
analyzed: nibbāna maggana ṭhena nibbāna atthikehi magganīya ṭṭhena ca ati catasso pi cetāḥ aparabhāge  kāya ādīsu ārammaṇesu kiccam sādhayamānāḥ nibbānam gacchanti āditaḥ paṭṭhāya ca nibbāna atthikehi
translated: And all these four kinds of mindfulness go to Nibbāna in the end,

original: maggiyantīti tasmā catassopi eko maggoti vuttā. Evañca sati vacanānusandhinā sānusandhikāva desanā hoti.
analyzed: maggiyanti iti tasmā catassaḥ api ekaḥ maggo ti vuttā evañca sati vacana anusandhinā sa anusandhikā ava desanā hoti
translated: and from the beginning they are gone by as a path by those who seek Nibbāna. That is why all four are called “one path” . And when that is so, the teaching has continuity in the sense of verbal continuity.

original: Katame cattāroti kathetukamyatāpucchā. Kāyeti rūpakāye. Kāyānupassīti kāyaṃ anupassanasīlo,
analyzed: katame cattāro ti kathā itu kamyatā pucchā kāya iti rūpa kāye kāya anupassī iti kāyam anupassana sīlaḥ
translated: “Which four?” is a question expressing a desire to speak. “The body” is the material body. “One who contemplates the body”: one whose habit is to contemplate the body;

original: kāyaṃ vā anupassamāno. Ayañhi bhikkhu imaṃ kāyaṃ aniccānupassanādīnaṃ sattannaṃ anupassanānaṃ
analyzed: kāyam vā anupassamānaḥ ayam hi bhikkhu imam kāyam anicca anupassanā ādīnam sattannam anupassanānam
translated: or he contemplates the body. For this bhikkhu contemplates the body in seven ways, that is, by way of the seven contemplations beginning with that of impermanence.

original: vasena aniccato anupassati, no niccato, dukkhato anupassati, no sukhato, anattato
analyzed: vasena aniccataḥ anupassati no niccataḥ dukkhataḥ anupassati no sukhataḥ anattato
translated: He contemplates as impermanent, not as permanent; as painful, not as pleasant; as not-self, not as self;

original: anupassati, no attato, nibbindati, no nandati, virajjati, no rajjati, nirodheti,🔽no samudeti, paṭinissajjati, no ādiyati. So taṃ aniccato anupassanto niccasaññaṃ
analyzed: anupassati no attataḥ nibbindati no nandati virajjati no rajjati nirodheti  no samudeti paṭinissajjati no ādiyati saḥ tam aniccataḥ anupassantaḥ nicca saññam
translated: he becomes dispassionate, not rapturous; he causes fading away of greed, not greed; he causes cessation, not origination; he relinquishes, not grasps.

original: pajahati, dukkhato anupassanto sukhasaññaṃ pajahati, anattato anupassanto attasaññaṃ🔽pajahati, nibbindanto nandiṃ pajahati, virajjanto rāgaṃ pajahati, nirodhento samudayaṃ
analyzed: pajahati dukkhataḥ anupassantaḥ sukha saññam pajahati anattataḥ anupassantaḥ atta saññam  pajahati nibbindantaḥ nandim pajahati virajjantaḥ rāgam pajahati nirodhentaḥ samudayam
translated: As he contemplates as impermanent, he abandons perception of permanence; as he contemplates as painful, he abandons perception of pleasure; as he contemplates as not-self, he abandons perception of self;

original: pajahati, paṭinissajjanto ādānaṃ pajahatīti veditabbo.
analyzed: pajahati paṭinissajjantaḥ ādānam pajahati iti veditabbo
translated: as he becomes dispassionate, he abandons delight; as he causes fading away of greed, he abandons greed; as he causes cessation, he abandons origination; as he relinquishes, he abandons grasping.

original: Viharatīti irīyati. Ātāpīti tīsu bhavesu kilese ātapatīti ātāpo, vīriyassetaṃ nāmaṃ.
analyzed: viharati iti irīyati ātāpī iti tīsu bhavesu kilese ātapati iti ātāpaḥ vīriyassa etam nāmam
translated: He abides: he conducts himself. He is ardent: the burning up of defilements in the three planes is ardour, which is a name for energy.

original: Ātāpo assa atthīti ātāpī. Sampajānoti sampajaññasaṅkhātena ñāṇena samannāgato. Satimāti
analyzed: ātāpaḥ assa atthi iti ātāpī sampajānoti sampajañña saṅkhātena ñāṇena samannāgataḥ satimā ati
translated: He has that, thus he is ardent. He is clearly comprehending: he possesses knowledge called clear comprehension. He is mindful: he possesses the mindfulness that is established by way of the four foundations.

original: kāyapariggāhikāya satiyā samannāgato. Ayaṃ pana yasmā satiyā ārammaṇaṃ pariggahetvā
analyzed: kāya pariggāhikāya satiyā samannāgataḥ ayam pana yasmai satiyā ārammaṇam pariggahetvā
translated: But this mindfulness, after it has collected the object,

original: paññāya anupassati. Na hi sativirahitassa anupassanā nāma atthi, tenevāha “satiñca🔽khvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sabbatthikaṃ vadāmī”ti. Tasmā ettha “kāye kāyānupassī viharatī”ti
analyzed: paññāya anupassati na hi sati virahitassa anupassanā nāma atthi tena iva āha satiñca  khvā aham bhikkhave sabbatthikam vadāmi iti tasmai ettha kāye kāya anupassī viharati iti
translated: examines it with understanding. For there is no such thing as “examining” in one devoid of mindfulness. That is why it is said: “Mindfulness, I say, is useful everywhere” .🔽So what is meant here by “he dwells contemplating the body in the body” is the development of the foundation of mindfulness of contemplating the body in the body.

original: ettāvatā kāyānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ vuttaṃ hoti. Atha vā yasmā anātāpino antosaṅkhepo🔽antarāyakaro hoti, asampajāno upāyapariggahe anupāyaparivajjane ca sammuyhati, muṭṭhassati
analyzed: ettāvatā kāya anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam vuttam hoti atha vā yasmai anātāpinaḥ antosaṅkhepo  antarāya karaḥ hoti a sampajānaḥ upāya pariggahe an upāya parivajjane ca sammuyhati muṭṭhaḥ sati
translated: Or alternatively, since one who is not ardent is slack in his application,🔽one who is not fully aware is confused about the right and wrong way of doing things,🔽and one whose mindfulness is muddled is incapable of relinquishing the wrong way and adopting the right way,

original: upāyāpariccāge anupāyāpariggahe ca asamattho hoti, tenassa taṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ na sampajjati.🔽Tasmā yesaṃ dhammānaṃ ānubhāvena taṃ sampajjati, tesaṃ dassanatthaṃ “ātāpī sampajāno
analyzed: upāya a pariccāge anupāya a pariggahe ca asamatthaḥ hoti tena assa tat kammaṭṭhānam na sampajjati  tasmai yesam dhammānam ānubhāvena tam sampajjati tesam dassana attham ātāpī sampajānaḥ
translated: his meditation subject does not succeed.

original: satimā”ti idaṃ vuttanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: satimā iti idam vuttan ti veditabbam
translated: So this is said in order to show the qualities whose influence makes the meditation subject succeed.

original: Iti kāyānupassanāsatipaṭṭhānaṃ sampayogaṅgañjassa dassetvā idāni pahānaṅgaṃ dassetuṃ
analyzed: iti kāya anupassanā sati paṭṭhānam dassetvā idāni pahānaṅgam dassetum
translated: So, having shown the factor of association in the contemplation of the body as a foundation of mindfulness, he now said “Having abandoned covetousness and grief regarding the world” in order to show the factor of abandoning.

original: vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassanti vuttaṃ. Tattha vineyyāti tadaṅgavinayena vā vikkhambhanavinayena
analyzed: vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassan ti vuttam tattha vineyya ti tad aṅga vinayena vā vikkhambhana vinayena
translated: Herein, having abandoned means having abandoned by suppression or by substitution of opposites.

original: vā vinayitvā. Loketi tasmiṃyeva kāye. Kāyo hi idha lujjanapalujjanaṭṭhena lokoti
analyzed: vā vinayitvā loka iti tasmin yeva kāye kāyaḥ hi idha
translated: Regarding the world means in that same body. For the world is intended here in the sense of that which is worn away and wasted .

original: adhippeto. Yasmā panassa na kāyamatteyeva abhijjhādomanassaṃ pahīyati, vedanādīsupi
analyzed: adhippetaḥ yasmā panassa na abhijjhā domanassam pahīyati vedanā ādīsu pi
translated: But since covetousness and grief are not abandoned only in the body but also in feeling, etc.,

original: pahīyati eva. Tasmā “pañcapi upādānakkhandhā loko”ti vibhaṅge vuttaṃ. Lokasaṅkhātattā
analyzed: pahīyati eva tasmā upādānakkhandhāḥ vibhaṅge vuttam loka saṅkhāta ttā
translated: it is said in the Vibhaṅga: “The world is the five aggregates as objects of clinging” .🔽Or this is said by way of the method of determining the meaning of the word loka .

original: vā tesaṃ dhammānaṃ atthuddhāranayenetaṃ vuttaṃ. Yaṃ panāha “tattha katamo loko, sveva
analyzed: vā tesam dhammānam attha uddhāra nayena itam vuttam yam pana āha tattha katamaḥ loko su eva
translated: But when it is said: “Herein, what is the world? This body is called the world” ,

original: kāyo loko”ti, ayamevettha attho. Tasmiṃ loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ vineyyāti evaṃ sambandho daṭṭhabbo.
analyzed: kāyaḥ loko ti ayam eva ittha attho tasmin loke abhijjhā domanassam vineyya ti evam sambandhaḥ daṭṭhabbo
translated: the meaning is the same. The construction should be seen thus: “Having abandoned covetousness and grief regarding that world, in that world.”

original: Vedanāsūti ettha tisso vedanā, tā ca lokiyā eva, cittampi lokiyaṃ, tathā dhammā.
analyzed: vedanāsu iti ettha tissaḥ vedanā tā ca lokiyāḥ eva cittam pi lokiyam tathā dhammā
translated: Herein, the three kinds of feeling are the feeling triad. And the cognizance and mental factors are mundane only.

original: Yathā pana vedanā anupassitabbā, tathā anupassanto esa vedanānupassīti veditabbo.
analyzed: yathā pana vedanā anupassitabbā tathā anupassantaḥ esa vedanā anupassī iti veditabbo
translated: But when he is contemplating in such a way, he is called “one who contemplates feelings” in the way appropriate to the contemplation of feeling.🔽The same method of explanation applies to the cognizance triad and the mental-formation triad.

original: Esa nayo cittadhammesu. Kathañca vedanā anupassitabbāti? Sukhā tāva vedanā dukkhato,
analyzed: esa nayaḥ citta dhammesu kathañca vedanā anupassitabbā ti sukhā tāva vedanā dukkhato
translated: How should he contemplate feelings? Firstly, pleasant feeling should be contemplated as pain,

original: dukkhā sallato, adukkhamasukhā aniccato. Yathāha –
analyzed: dukkhā sallataḥ adukkham asukhā aniccataḥ yathā āha
translated: painful feeling as a dart, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling as inconstant. As it is said:🔽“He who sees pain in pleasant feeling,

original: “Yo sukhaṃ dukkhato adda, dukkhamaddakkhi sallato;
analyzed: yaḥ sukham dukkhataḥ adda dukkham addakkhi sallataḥ
translated: And sees a dart in painful feeling,

original: Adukkhamasukhaṃ santaṃ, addakkhi naṃ aniccato;
analyzed: adukkham asukham santam addakkhi nam aniccataḥ
translated: And sees what is impermanent in that called neither-painful-nor-pleasant,

original: Sa ve sammaddaso bhikkhu, upasanto carissatī”ti.🔽Sabbā eva cetā dukkhātipi anupassitabbā. Vuttañhetaṃ “yaṃkiñci vedayitaṃ, sabbaṃ🔽taṃ dukkhasminti vadāmī”ti. Sukhadukkhatopi ca anupassitabbā, yathāha – “sukhā kho,
analyzed: sa ve sammaddasaḥ bhikkhu upasantaḥ carissati iti  sabbāḥ eva cetāḥ anupassitabbāḥ vuttam ha etam yaṃ kiñci vedayitam sabbam  tam dukkhasmin ti vadāmi iti sukha dukkhataḥ api ca anupassitabbā yathā āha sukhā kho
translated: That bhikkhu sees rightly: he will fare in bliss” .🔽And all should be contemplated as pain too, for this is said: “Whatever is felt is suffering” .🔽And they should be contemplated as pleasure and pain too, according to what is said: “Pleasant feeling, friend Visākha, is to be directly known as pain;

original: āvuso visākha, vedanā ṭhitisukhā vipariṇāmadukkhā”ti sabbaṃ vitthāretabbaṃ. Apica
analyzed: āvuso visākha vedanā ṭhiti sukhā vipariṇāma dukkhā ati sabbam vitthāretabbam apica
translated: painful feeling … Neither-painful-nor-pleasant feeling … all is to be directly known as pain” .🔽And they should be contemplated as impermanent, painful, not-self, arisen from what is impermanent, arisen from what is made, subject to destruction, subject to fall, subject to fading away, subject to cessation, subject to change, and so on.

original: aniccādisattaanupassanāvasenapi anupassitabbā.🔽Cittadhammesupi cittaṃ tāva ārammaṇādhipatisahajātabhūmikammavipākakiriyādinānattabhedānaṃ
analyzed: anicca ādi satta anupassanā vasena api anupassitabbā  citta dhammesu pi cittam tāva
translated: and also by way of the seven contemplations beginning with that of impermanence.🔽As regards cognizance and mental data, cognizance should be contemplated as impermanent, etc.,🔽by way of the various kinds of difference consisting in object-predominance, conascence, plane, kamma-result, function, and so on,

original: aniccādianupassanānaṃ sarāgādīnañca bhedānaṃ vasena anupassitabbaṃ. Dhammā salakkhaṇasāmaññalakkhaṇānaṃ
analyzed: anicca ādi anupassanānam sa rāga ādīnam ca bhedānam vasena anupassitabbam dhammāḥ sa lakkhaṇa sāmañña lakkhaṇānam
translated: and by way of the various kinds of difference consisting in lust, etc., and mental-data should be contemplated by way of the various kinds of difference consisting in specific- characteristic, general-characteristic,

original: suññatadhammassa aniccādisattaanupassanānaṃ “santaṃ vā ajjhattaṃ kāmacchanda”ntiādīnañca
analyzed: suññata dhammassa anicca ādi satta anupassanānam santam vā ajjhattam kāmacchanda nti ādīnam ca
translated: voidness, impermanence, etc., and the seven contemplations beginning with that of “When there is lust in him he knows ‘There is lust in me’ ” .

original: pabhedānaṃ vasena anupassitabbā. Sesaṃ vuttanayameva. Ayamettha saṅkhepo, vitthāro
analyzed: pabhedānam vasena anupassitabbā sesam vutta nayam eva ayam ettha saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ
translated: The rest is as already stated. This is the brief account. The detailed account,

original: pana dīghamajjhimaṭṭhakathāsu satipaṭṭhānavaṇṇanāyaṃ vuttanayeneva veditabbo.
analyzed: pana dīgha majjhima ṭṭhakathāsu sati paṭṭhāna vaṇṇanā ayam vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ
translated: however, should be understood as in the Commentaries on the Long, Middle, and Short Texts and in the Description of the Arousing of Mindfulness in the Paṭisambhidā.

original: 2. Satisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sati sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The second Sutta

original: 368. Dutiye satoti kāyādianupassanāsatiyā samannāgato. Sampajānoti catusampajaññapaññāya
analyzed: dutiye sato ti kāya ādi anupassanā satiyā samannāgato sampajānoti catu sampajañña paññāya
translated: In the second sutta, mindful is possessed of mindfulness consisting in contemplation of the body, and so on. Clearly comprehending is possessed of the understanding consisting in the four kinds of exact knowledge .

original: samannāgato. Abhikkante paṭikkanteti ettha abhikkantaṃ vuccati gamanaṃ, paṭikkantaṃ
analyzed: samannāgataḥ abhikkante paṭikkante iti ettha abhikkantam vuccati gamanam paṭikkantam
translated: In going forward and returning: here going forward is called going, and returning is called coming back.

original: nivattanaṃ, tadubhayampi catūsu iriyāpathesu labbhati. Gamane tāva purato kāyaṃ abhiharanto
analyzed: nivattanam tat ubhayam pi catūsu iriyāpathesu labbhati gamane tāva puratas kāyam abhiharanto
translated: and returning. Both these are possible in the four postures. In going forwards, in other words, in going in the direction in which the body is facing,🔽he goes forwards, and in going backwards, in other words, in the opposite direction, he goes backwards. In standing, in other words, while standing still,🔽he goes forwards by bending the body forwards, and he goes backwards by bending it backwards. In sitting, in other words, while sitting,

original: abhikkamati nāma, paṭinivattanto paṭikkamati nāma. Ṭhānepi ṭhitakova kāyaṃ purato🔽onamanto abhikkamati nāma, pacchato apanāmento paṭikkamati nāma. Nisajjāyapi nisinnakova🔽āsanassa purimaaṅgābhimukho saṃsaranto abhikkamati nāma, pacchimaaṅgappadesaṃ paccāsaṃsaranto🔽paṭikkamati nāma. Nipajjanepi eseva nayo.
analyzed: abhikkamati nāma paṭinivattanto paṭikkamati nāma ṭhāne pi ṭhitakaḥ uva kāyam puratas  onamantaḥ abhikkamati nāma pacchatas apanāmentaḥ paṭikkamati nāma  āsanassa purima aṅga abhimukho saṃsarantaḥ abhikkamati nāma pacchima aṅga ppadesam paccā a saṃsarantaḥ  paṭikkamati nāma nipajjane pi esā iva nayaḥ
translated: he goes forwards by moving the body forwards in the direction of the front part of the seat, and he goes backwards by moving it backwards in the direction of the back part of the seat. The same method applies in lying down.

original: Sampajānakārī hotīti sampajaññena sabbakiccakārī, sampajaññasseva vā kārī. So hi abhikkantādīsu sampajaññaṃ karoteva, na katthaci sampajaññavirahito hoti.
analyzed: sampajāna kārī hoti iti sampajaññena sabba kicca kārī sampajaññassa iva vā kārī so hi abhikkanta ādīsu sampajaññam karotā iva na katthaci sampajañña virahitaḥ hoti
translated: He is one who acts with clear comprehension: he is one who does all his actions with clear comprehension, or he is one who acts with the clear comprehension itself. For he is one who acts with clear comprehension in going forwards, etc., and he is never without clear comprehension in any posture.

original: Tattha sātthakasampajaññaṃ, sappāyasampajaññaṃ, gocarasampajaññaṃ, asammohasampajaññanti
analyzed: tattha sātthaka sampajaññam sa pāya sampajaññam gocara sampajaññam a sammoha sampajaññanti
translated: Herein, the clear comprehension of purpose is the clear comprehension of the purpose of the postures. The clear comprehension of suitability is the clear comprehension of the suitability of the time for the postures. The clear comprehension of ownership is the clear comprehension of the need for skill in the postures. The clear comprehension of condition is the clear comprehension of the suitability of the postures for the removal of discomfort. The clear comprehension of direction is the clear comprehension of the suitability of the postures for the purpose of seeing, etc., in the various directions. The clear comprehension of time is the clear comprehension of the suitability of the postures for the purpose of seeing a teacher at a particular time, etc. The clear comprehension of resort is the clear comprehension of the suitability of the postures for the purpose of resort to the various kinds of requisites. The clear comprehension of bodily position is the clear comprehension of the suitability of the postures for the purpose of adopting the various kinds of bodily positions. The clear comprehension of activity is the clear comprehension of the suitability of the postures for the purpose of the various kinds of activity. The clear comprehension of the purification of means is the clear comprehension of the suitability of the postures for the purpose of the development of the four paths. The clear comprehension of danger is the clear comprehension of the danger in the postures. The clear comprehension of escape is the clear comprehension of the escape from the postures.

original: catubbidhaṃ sampajaññaṃ. Tattha abhikkamanacitte uppanne cittavaseneva agantvā “kiṃ🔽nu me ettha gatena attho atthi, natthī”ti atthānatthaṃ pariggaṇhitvā atthapariggaṇhanaṃ🔽sātthakasampajaññaṃ. Tattha ca atthoti cetiyadassanabodhidassanasaṅghadassanatheradassanaasubhadassanādivasena🔽dhammato vaḍḍhi. Cetiyaṃ disvāpi hi buddhārammaṇaṃ, saṅghadassanena saṅghārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: catubbidham sampajaññam tattha abhikkamana citte uppanne citta vasena iva a gantvā kim  nu me ettha gatena atthaḥ atthi natthi iti attha anattham pariggaṇhitvā attha pariggaṇhanam  sa atthaka sampajaññam tattha ca attho ti cetiya dassana bodhi dassana saṅgha dassana thera dassana asubha dassana ādi vasena  dhammataḥ vaḍḍhi cetiyam disvā api hi buddha ārammaṇam saṅgha dassanena saṅgha ārammaṇam
translated: Understanding is fourfold. Herein, when the mind is about to go forth, instead of going with the mind, he discerns whether there is any purpose in going there or not. The discernment of purpose is understanding of what is profitable. And here the purpose is the increase of merit by way of the Dhamma, through seeing a shrine, seeing the Enlightenment Tree, seeing the Community of Bhikkhus, seeing an elder, seeing a meditation subject, seeing a good person, seeing a superior person, seeing a spiritual guide, seeing a teacher, seeing a preceptor, seeing a co-student, seeing a fellow-student, seeing a clansman, seeing a good man, seeing a Buddha, hearing a Dhamma talk, hearing a recitation, hearing a recital, hearing a True Idea, hearing a True Idea and a True Dhamma, hearing a True Idea, a True Dhamma and a True Guide, hearing a True Guide, hearing a True Dhamma, hearing a True Dhamma and a True Guide, hearing a True Guide and a True Dhamma, hearing a True Idea and a True Guide, hearing a True Idea, a True Dhamma and a True Guide, hearing a True Guide, a True Dhamma and a True Guide, seeing a miracle, seeing a wonder, seeing a miracle and a wonder, seeing a wonder and a miracle, seeing a True Idea and a wonder, seeing a True Idea, a True Dhamma and a wonder, seeing a wonder and a True Dhamma, seeing a wonder and a True Guide, seeing a True Dhamma and a True Guide, seeing a True Guide and a True Dhamma, seeing a True Guide and a True Dhamma and a True Guide, seeing a True Dhamma and a True Guide and a True Dhamma, seeing a True Dhamma and a True Guide and a True Guide, seeing a True Dhamma and a True Guide and a True Dhamma, seeing a True Dhamma and a True Guide and a True Dhamma and a True Guide, seeing a True Dhamma and a True Guide and a True Dhamma and a True Guide, seeing a True Dhamma and a True Guide and a True Dhamma and a True Guide, seeing a True Dhamma and a True Guide and a True Dhamma and a True Guide, seeing a True Dhamma and a True Guide and a True Dhamma and a True Guide, seeing a True Dhamma and a True Guide and a True Dhamma and a True Guide, seeing a True Dhamma and a

original: pītiṃ uppādetvā tadeva khayato sammasanto arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. Mahāvihārasmiñhi dakkhiṇadvāre🔽ṭhatvā mahācetiyaṃ olokentā tiṃsasahassabhikkhū arahattaṃ pāpuṇiṃsu, tathā pacchimadvāre🔽uttaradvāre pācīnadvāre ca, tathā pañhamaṇḍapaṭṭhāne abhayavāpipāḷiyaṃ, thūpārāmadvāre🔽nagarassa dakkhiṇadvāre anurādhavāpipāḷiyaṃ.
analyzed: pītim uppādetvā tat eva khayataḥ sammasantaḥ arahattam pāpuṇāti mahāvihārasmin hi dakkhiṇa dvāre 🔽ṭhatvā mahācetiyam olokentā tiṃsa sahassa bhikkhū arahattam pāpuṇiṃsu tathā pacchima dvāre 🔽uttara dvāre pācīna dvāre ca tathā pañha maṇḍa paṭṭhāne abhaya vāpi pāḷiyam thūpa ārāma dvāre 🔽nagarassa dakkhiṇa dvāre anurādha vāpipāḷiyam
translated: Understanding is fourfold. Herein, when the mind has arisen to go out, instead of going out with the mind, he discerns what is profitable and unprofitable, etc., thus: “What is the purpose of my going out? Is there any purpose or not?” The discernment of what is profitable is profitable understanding. And here what is profitable? It is increase by way of the True Idea. For when he has seen the shrine he arouses happiness with the Enlightened One as object, and when he has seen the Community he arouses happiness with the Community as object, and when he has seen the elder bhikkhus he arouses happiness with the elder bhikkhus as object, and when he has seen the young bhikkhus he arouses happiness with the young bhikkhus as object, and when he has seen the novices he arouses happiness with the novices as object, and when he has seen the female devotees he arouses happiness with the female devotees as object, and when he has seen the male devotees he arouses happiness with the male devotees as object, and when he has seen the laymen he arouses happiness with the laymen as object, and when he has seen the laywomen he arouses happiness with the laywomen as object. And when he has seen the shrine he comprehends it as liable to destruction, and when he has seen the Community he comprehends it as liable to destruction, and when he has seen the elder bhikkhus he comprehends them as liable to destruction, and when he has seen the young bhikkhus he comprehends them as liable to destruction, and when he has seen the novices he comprehends them as liable to destruction, and when he has seen the female devotees he comprehends them as liable to destruction, and when he has seen the male devotees he comprehends them as liable to destruction, and when he has seen the laymen he comprehends them as liable to destruction, and when he has seen the laywomen he comprehends them as liable to destruction. And when he has seen the shrine he comprehends it as liable to destruction, and when he has seen the Community he comprehends it as liable to destruction, and when he has seen the elder bhikkhus he comprehends them as liable to destruction, and when he has seen the young bhikkhus he comprehends them as liable to destruction, and when he has seen the novices he comprehends them as liable to destruction, and when he has seen

original: Mahāariyavaṃsabhāṇakatthero panāha “kiṃ tumhe vadatha, mahācetiyassa samantā kucchivedikāya🔽heṭṭhimabhāgato paṭṭhāya paññāyanaṭṭhāne yattha yattha dve pādā sakkā honti samaṃ
analyzed: mahāariyavaṃsabhāṇaka theraḥ pana āha kim tumhe vadatha mahā cetiyassa samantā kucchi vedikāya  heṭṭhima bhāgataḥ paṭṭhāya paññāyana ṭṭhāne yattha yattha dve pādā sakkā honti samam
translated: The Elder who recited the Great Lineage of Noble Ones said: “What do you say? From the time of the laying out of the site for the lower terrace all round the Great Shrine,

original: patiṭṭhāpetuṃ, tattha tattha ekapaduddhāre tiṃsatiṃsa bhikkhusahassāni arahattaṃ🔽pāpuṇiṃsūti sakkā vatu”nti. Aparo pana mahāthero āha – “mahācetiyatale ākiṇṇavālikāya
analyzed: patiṭṭhāpetum tattha tattha eka paduddhāre tiṃsatiṃsa bhikkhu sahassāni arahattam  pāpuṇiṃsu iti sakkāḥ vatunti aparaḥ pana mahā theraḥ āha mahā cetiya tale ākiṇṇa vālikāya
translated: wherever it was possible to set down two feet evenly, there, with each step, thirty thousand bhikkhus reached Arahantship.”🔽Another elder said: “There were more bhikkhus who reached Arahantship on the sand-covered floor of the Great Shrine.”

original: bahutarā bhikkhū arahattaṃ pattā”ti. There disvā tesaṃ ovāde patiṭṭhāya asubhaṃ disvā
analyzed: bahutarāḥ bhikkhū arahattam pattā ti there disvā tesam ovāde patiṭṭhāya asubham disvā
translated: Seeing them, they established themselves in the advice, and after seeing foulness,

original: tattha paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ uppādetvā tadeva khayato sammasanto arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. Tasmā🔽etesaṃ dassanaṃ sātthaṃ. Keci pana – “āmisatopi vaḍḍhi atthoyeva, taṃ nissāya brahmacariyānuggahāya
analyzed: tattha paṭhamam jhānam uppādetvā tat eva khayataḥ sammasantaḥ arahattam pāpuṇāti tasmā  etesam dassanam sa attham keci pana āmisataḥ pi vaḍḍhi atthaḥ yā iva tam nissāya brahmacariya anuggahāya
translated: they aroused the first jhana there and by comprehending it as liable to destruction they reached Arahantship. So

original: paṭipannattā”ti vadanti.
analyzed: vadanti
translated: their seeing was fruitful. But some say that the increase in material things is also fruitful because it helps the life of purity by providing a basis for it.

original: Tasmiṃ pana gamane sappāyāsappāyaṃ pariggaṇhitvā sappāyapariggaṇhanaṃ sappāyasampajaññaṃ.
analyzed: tasmim pana gamane sappāya asappāyam pariggaṇhitvā sappāya pariggaṇhanam sappāya sampajaññam
translated: The discerning of what is suitable and unsuitable in that respect is suitable-unsuitable knowledge.🔽What is that? Visiting a shrine is suitable. But if a great festival is being held at a shrine and

original: Seyyathidaṃ? Cetiyadassanaṃ tāva sātthaṃ. Sace pana cetiyassa mahāpūjāya dasadvādasayojanantare
analyzed: sā iyyathā idam cetiya dassanam tāva sa attham sace pana cetiyassa mahā pūjāya dasa dvādasa yojana antare
translated: crowds gather from a distance of twelve or fifteen leagues,

original: parisā sannipatanti, attano vibhavānurūpā itthiyopi purisāpi alaṅkatapaṭiyattā cittakammarūpakāni
analyzed: parisā sannipatanti attanaḥ vibhava anurūpāḥ itthiyaḥ api purisāḥ api alaṅkata paṭiyattā citta kamma rūpakāni
translated: men and women, adorned and decorated, go about in the same way as the actors in a theatre.

original: viya sañcaranti. Tatra cassa iṭṭhe ārammaṇe lobho, aniṭṭhe paṭigho, asamapekkhane
analyzed: viya sañcaranti tatra ca ssa iṭṭhe ārammaṇe lobhaḥ aniṭṭhe paṭighaḥ a samapekkhane
translated: There greed arises over a desirable object, resentment over an undesirable object, and delusion in the form of indifference to the occurrence of neither.

original: moho uppajjati, kāyasaṃsagge kāyasaṃsaggāpattiṃ āpajjati, jīvitabrahmacariyānaṃ vā
analyzed: mohaḥ uppajjati kāya saṃsagge kāya saṃsagga āpattim āpajjati jīvita brahmacariyānam vā
translated: One may commit an offence of sexual misconduct through bodily contact. And there may be an obstacle to life or to celibacy.

original: antarāyo ca hoti. Evaṃ taṃ ṭhānaṃ asappāyaṃ hoti, vuttappakāraantarāyābhāve sappāyaṃ.
analyzed: antarāyo ca hoti evam tat ṭhānam asappāyam hoti vutta ppakāra antarāya abhāve sappāyam
translated: So that place is unsuitable. It is suitable if there is no such obstacle as described.

original: Saṅghadassanampi sātthaṃ. Sace pana antogāme mahāmaṇḍapaṃ kāretvā sabbarattiṃ dhammassavanaṃ
analyzed: saṅgha dassanam pi sa attham sace pana antogāme mahā maṇḍapam kāretvā sabbarattim dhammassavanam
translated: Visiting the Order is suitable.

original: kārentesu manussesu vuttappakāreneva janasannipāto ceva antarāyo ca hoti, evaṃ taṃ
analyzed: kārentesu manussesu vutta ppakārena iva jana sannipātaḥ ca iva antarāyaḥ ca hoti evam tam
translated: If people are working, there is an obstruction of the kind already described, namely, a crowd of people and so on.

original: ṭhānaṃ asappāyaṃ, antarāyābhāve sappāyaṃ. Mahāparivārānaṃ therānaṃ dassanepi eseva nayo.🔽Asubhadassanampi sātthaṃ. Tadatthadīpanatthañca idaṃ vatthu – eko kira daharabhikkhu🔽sāmaṇeraṃ gahetvā dantakaṭṭhatthāya gato. Sāmaṇero maggā okkamitvā purato gacchanto
analyzed: ṭhānam asappāyam antarāya abhāve sappāyam mahāparivārānam therānam dassane pi esa iva nayo  asubha dassanam pi sa attham tad attha dīpana attham ca idam vatthu ekaḥ kira dahara bhikkhu  sāmaṇeram gahetvā dantakaṭṭhatthāya gataḥ sāmaṇeraḥ maggā okkamitvā puratas gacchantaḥ
translated: If there are people who are working, then there is a crowd of people and an obstruction of the kind already described. So that place is unsuitable if there is an obstruction. It is suitable if there is no obstruction. The same method applies to the sight of elder bhikkhus with a large retinue.

original: asubhaṃ disvā paṭhamajjhānaṃ nibbattetvā tadeva pādakaṃ katvā saṅkhāre sammasanto
analyzed: asubham disvā paṭhamajjhānam nibbattetvā tat eva pādakam katvā saṅkhāre sammasantaḥ
translated: The sight of a corpse is beneficial. And this is the story that illustrates the point. A young bhikkhu, it seems, went with a novice pupil to get tooth wood. The novice went in front on the path and saw a corpse. He entered upon the first jhāna. Then, making that the basis, he comprehended formations,

original: tīṇi phalāni sacchikatvā uparimaggatthāya kammaṭṭhānaṃ pariggahetvā aṭṭhāsi. Daharo🔽taṃ apassanto “sāmaṇerā”ti pakkosi. So – “mayā pabbajitadivasato paṭṭhāya bhikkhunā
analyzed: tīṇi phalāni sacchikatvā upari magga tthāya kammaṭṭhānam pariggahetvā aṭṭhāsi daharaḥ  tam a passanto sāmaṇera ati pakkosi saḥ mayā pabbajita divasataḥ paṭṭhāya bhikkhunā
translated: realized the three states of final knowledge, and stood there having taken up the meditation subject for the higher paths. The young bhikkhu🔽called out, “Novice!” When he did not come, he went on to where he was and asked, “Why don’t you come when I call?”

original: saddhiṃ dve kathā nāma na kathitapubbā, aññasmimpi divase uparivisesaṃ nibbattessāmī”ti
analyzed: saddhim dve kathā nāma na kathita pubbā aññasmim pi divase upari visesam nibbattessāmi iti
translated: “I have not spoken to a bhikkhu since the day I went forth,” he said. “I will attain further distinction on another day.”

original: cintetvā “kiṃ, bhante,”ti paṭivacanaṃ adāsi. “Ehī”ti vutte ekavacaneneva āgantvā🔽– “bhante, iminā tāva maggena gantvā mayā ṭhitokāse muhuttaṃ puratthābhimukhā hutvā
analyzed: cintetvā kim bhante iti paṭivacanam adāsi ehi iti vutte eka vacanena iva āgantvā  bhante iminā tāva maggena gantvā mayā ṭhita ukāse muhuttam purattha abhimukhā hutvā
translated: and after thinking it over he gave his consent. When the Elder said, “Come,” he came with a single word.

original: olokethā”ti āha. So tathā katvā tena pattavisesameva pāpuṇi. Evaṃ ekaṃ asubhaṃ dvinnaṃ🔽janānaṃ atthāya jātaṃ. Evaṃ sātthampi panetaṃ purisassa mātugāmāsubhaṃ asappāyaṃ,
analyzed: āha saḥ tathā katvā tena patta visesam eva pāpuṇi evam ekam asubham dvinnam  janānam atthāya jātam evam sa attham pi pana itam purisassa mātu gāma asubham a sappāyam
translated: The Elder said, “Go by this path, friend, and look out in the place where I stand for a moment facing east.” He did so and found only a bowl. So one object of foulness arose for the benefit of two people.

original: mātugāmassa ca purisāsubhaṃ, sabhāgameva sappāyanti evaṃ sappāyapariggaṇhanaṃ sappāyasampajaññaṃ.
analyzed: mātugāmassa ca purisa asubham sa bhāgam eva sappāyanti evam sappāya pariggaṇhanam sappāya sampajaññam
translated: So this foulness in a man is not suitable for a woman, and that in a woman is not suitable for a man. Only that which is similar is suitable. This is how the discerning of what is suitable should be understood.

original: Evaṃ pariggahitasātthasappāyassa pana aṭṭhatiṃsakammaṭṭhānesu attano cittarucikaṃ
analyzed: evam pariggahita sāttha sappāyassa pana aṭṭhatiṃsa kammaṭṭhānesu attano citta rucikam
translated: When he has discerned what is suitable in this way, he should choose as his meditation subject one among the forty objects that suits his temperament,

original: kammaṭṭhānasaṅkhātaṃ gocaraṃ uggahetvā bhikkhācāragocare taṃ gahetvāva gamanaṃ gocarasampajaññaṃ nāma.
analyzed: kammaṭṭhāna saṅkhātam gocaram uggahetvā bhikkhācāra gocare tam gahetvā ava gamanam gocarasampajaññam nāma
translated: and he should learn it by heart. The going to the place of the teacher to learn the meditation subject is called “discernment of the resort.”

original: Tassāvibhāvatthaṃ idaṃ catukkaṃ veditabbaṃ – idhekacco bhikkhu harati na paccāharati,
analyzed: tassa avibhāva attham idam catukkam veditabbam idha ekaccaḥ bhikkhu harati na paccāharati
translated: The following fourfold method should be understood for the purpose of explaining that: Herein, one bhikkhu takes but does not return;

original: ekacco paccāharati na harati, ekacco pana neva harati na paccāharati, ekacco harati ca paccāharati ca.
analyzed: ekacco paccāharati na harati ekacco pana na iva harati na paccāharati ekacco harati ca paccāharati ca
translated: one returns but does not take; one neither takes nor returns; one both takes and returns.

original: Tattha yo bhikkhu divasaṃ caṅkamena nisajjāya ca āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi cittaṃ parisodhetvā
analyzed: tattha yaḥ bhikkhu divasam caṅkamena nisajjāya ca āvaraṇīyehi dhammehi cittam parisodhetvā
translated: Herein, a bhikkhu who during the day purifies his mind from obstructive states by walking and sitting practice and by the appropriate means of practice,

original: tathā rattiyā paṭhamaṃ yāmaṃ majjhimayāme seyyaṃ kappetvā, pacchimayāmepi nisajjācaṅkamehi
analyzed: tathā rattiyā paṭhamam yāmam majjhima yāme seyyam kappetvā pacchima yāme pi
translated: and who in the first watch of the night does likewise and then lies down in the middle watch to rest a while, and who in the last watch gets up and passes the time in walking and sitting practice and by the appropriate means of practice,

original: vītināmetvā, pageva cetiyaṅgaṇabodhiyaṅgaṇavattaṃ katvā bodhirukkhe udakaṃ āsiñcitvā
analyzed: vītināmetvā pagā iva cetiyaṅgaṇa bodhiyaṅgaṇa vattam katvā bodhi rukkhe udakam āsiñcitvā
translated: and who, after doing the duties connected with the shrine terrace and the Enlightenment Tree, watering them and so on, and after doing the duties connected with the Bodhi Tree, watering it and so on,

original: pānīyaṃ paribhojanīyaṃ paccupaṭṭhapetvā ācariyupajjhāyavattādīni samādāya vattati.
analyzed: pānīyam paribhojanīyam paccupaṭṭhapetvā ācariya upajjhāya vatta ādīni samādāya vattati
translated: and after doing the duties connected with the teacher, the guide, and the preceptor, and so on,

original: So sarīraparikammaṃ katvā senāsanaṃ pavisitvā dve tayo pallaṅke usumaṃ gāhāpento
analyzed: so sarīra parikammam katvā senāsanam pavisitvā dve tayo pallaṅke usumam gāhāpento
translated: after doing the duties of the body, enters the dwelling and has two or three sitting-supports brought and warms his back,

original: kammaṭṭhānamanuyuñjitvā bhikkhācāravelāya uṭṭhahitvā kammaṭṭhānasīseneva pattacīvaramādāya
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam anuyuñjitvā bhikkhā cāra velāya uṭṭhahitvā kammaṭṭhāna sīsena iva patta cīvaram ādāya
translated: and he should rise at the time of the alms round after devoting himself to his meditation subject. Taking his bowl and robe, which are to be kept in readiness,

original: senāsanato nikkhamitvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikarontova cetiyaṅgaṇaṃ gantvā sace buddhānussatikammaṭṭhānaṃ🔽hoti, taṃ avissajjetvāva cetiyaṅgaṇaṃ pavisati. Aññaṃ ce kammaṭṭhānaṃ hoti, sopānapādamūle
analyzed: senāsanataḥ nikkhamitvā kammaṭṭhānam manasikarontaḥ iva cetiya ṅgaṇam gantvā sace buddha anussati kammaṭṭhānam  hoti tam a vissajjetvā ava cetiya ṅgaṇam pavisati aññam ce kammaṭṭhānam hoti sopāna pāda mūle
translated: he should leave his lodging with his meditation subject as his chief concern. If he has the meditation subject of the recollection of the Buddha,🔽he should enter the shrine terrace without putting aside that meditation subject. But if he has some other meditation subject, he should put that aside and, standing at the foot of the steps of the shrine terrace,

original: ṭhatvā hatthena gahitabhaṇḍaṃ viya taṃ ṭhapetvā buddhārammaṇaṃ pītiṃ gahetvā cetiyaṅgaṇaṃ
analyzed: ṭhatvā hatthena gahita bhaṇḍam viya tam ṭhapetvā buddha ārammaṇam pītim gahetvā cetiya ṅgaṇam
translated: he should take up the meditation subject of the recollection of the Buddha, which is like goods placed on deposit with him.

original: āruyha mahantaṃ cetiyaṃ ce, tikkhattuṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā catūsu ṭhānesu vanditabbaṃ,
analyzed: āruyha mahantam cetiyam ce tikkhattum padakkhiṇam katvā catūsu ṭhānesu vanditabbam
translated: He should then ascend the shrine terrace and, if it is a large one, he should circumambulate it three times and worship at the four places for worship.

original: khuddakaṃ ce, tatheva padakkhiṇaṃ katvā aṭṭhasu ṭhānesu vanditabbaṃ. Cetiyaṃ vanditvā
analyzed: khuddakam ce tathā iva padakkhiṇam katvā aṭṭhasu ṭhānesu vanditabbam cetiyam vanditvā
translated: If it is a small one, he should circumambulate it once and worship at the eight places for worship.

original: bodhiyaṅgaṇaṃ pattenāpi buddhassa bhagavato sammukhā viya nipaccakāraṃ dassetvā bodhi
analyzed: bodhi yaṅgaṇam pattena api buddhassa bhagavato sammukhā viya nipacca kāram dassetvā
translated: After worshipping the shrine, he should go to the Bodhi Tree terrace and show respect there as if to the Blessed One face to face.

original: vanditabbā. So evaṃ cetiyañca bodhiñca vanditvā paṭisāmitaṭṭhānaṃ gantvā paṭisāmitabhaṇḍakaṃ🔽hatthena gaṇhanto viya nikkhittakammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā gāmasamīpe kammaṭṭhānasīseneva
analyzed: vanditabbā sā evam cetiyam ca bodhim ca vanditvā paṭisāmita ṭṭhānam gantvā paṭisāmita bhaṇḍakam  hatthena gaṇhantaḥ viya nikkhitta kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā gāma samīpe kammaṭṭhāna sīsena iva
translated: and the Bodhi Tree. Then he goes to the place where the requisites have been laid by and🔽takes the requisites as though he were taking the meditation subject. He puts on his sarong evenly all round, covering the navel and the knees.

original: cīvaraṃ pārupitvā gāmaṃ piṇḍāya pavisati.
analyzed: cīvaram pārupitvā gāmam piṇḍāya pavisati
translated: He puts on the upper robe evenly on both shoulders. After washing his bowl, he takes it with its handle towards his body and🔽enters the village for alms with mindfulness established and with his mind well guarded.

original: Atha naṃ manussā disvā “ayyo no āgato”ti paccuggantvā pattaṃ gahetvā āsanasālāya🔽vā gehe vā nisīdāpetvā yāguṃ datvā yāva bhattaṃ na niṭṭhāti, tāva pāde dhovitvā makkhetvā🔽purato nisīditvā pañhaṃ vā pucchanti, dhammaṃ vā sotukāmā honti. Sacepi na kathāpenti,
analyzed: atha nam manussāḥ disvā ayyaḥ naḥ āgataḥ iti paccuggantvā pattam gahetvā āsana sālāya  vā gehe vā nisīdāpetvā yāgum datvā yāva bhattam na niṭṭhāti tāva pāde dhovitvā makkhetvā  puratas nisīditvā pañham vā pucchanti dhammam vā sotu kāmāḥ honti sace pi na kathāpenti
translated: When people see him, they come out to meet him, saying, “Our lord has come. ” They take his bowl and lead him to the sitting hall or to the house.🔽After giving him rice gruel, they wash his feet while he is still standing, anoint his feet, and make him sit down in front of them. They ask him questions or want to listen to the Dhamma.

original: janasaṅgahaṇatthaṃ dhammakathā nāma kātabbāyevāti aṭṭhakathācariyā vadanti. Dhammakathā
analyzed: jana saṅgahaṇa attham dhammakathā nāma kātabbāya eva ati aṭṭhakathā cariyāḥ vadanti dhammakathā
translated: If he does not tell them a story, the teachers of the commentaries say that he should tell them a Dhamma story in order to win them over.

original: hi kammaṭṭhānavinimuttā nāma natthi, tasmā kammaṭṭhānasīseneva dhammaṃ kathetvā kammaṭṭhānasīseneva
analyzed: hi kammaṭṭhāna vinimuttā nāma natthi tasmai kammaṭṭhāna sīsena iva dhammam kathetvā kammaṭṭhāna sīsena iva
translated: For there is no Dhamma talk that is outside the meditation subject. So he should tell them a Dhamma story and then give a meditation subject to each one according to his disposition.

original: āhāraṃ paribhuñjitvā anumodanaṃ katvā nivattiyamānehipi manussehi anugatova gāmato
analyzed: āhāram paribhuñjitvā anumodanam katvā manussehi anugataḥ uva gāmataḥ
translated: After he had eaten his meal and had given thanks, he was about to leave, but the people followed him.

original: nikkhamitvā tattha te nivattetvā maggaṃ paṭipajjati.
analyzed: nikkhamitvā tattha te nivattetvā maggam paṭipajjati
translated: He left the village, turned back, and went back to the road.

original: Atha naṃ puretaraṃ nikkhamitvā bahigāme katabhattakiccā sāmaṇeradaharabhikkhū disvā🔽paccuggantvā pattacīvaramassa gaṇhanti. Porāṇakabhikkhū kira na “amhākaṃ upajjhāyo
analyzed: atha nam puretaram nikkhamitvā bahigāme kata bhatta kiccā sāmaṇera dahara bhikkhū disvā  paccuggantvā patta cīvaram assa gaṇhanti porāṇaka bhikkhū kira na amhākam upajjhāyo
translated: Then young bhikkhus and novices who had gone out earlier and had finished their meal saw him.🔽They went out to meet him and took his bowl and robe. The senior bhikkhus did not do the duties for him, thinking, “Our preceptor and teacher are coming.”

original: ācariyo”ti mukhaṃ oloketvā vattaṃ karonti, sampattaparicchedeneva karonti. Te taṃ🔽pucchanti – “bhante, ete manussā tumhākaṃ kiṃ honti, mātipakkhato sambandhā pitipakkhato”ti?
analyzed: ācariyo ti mukham oloketvā vattam karonti sampatta paricchedena iva karonti te tam  pucchanti bhante ete manussā tumhākam kim honti māti pakkhato sambandhā piti pakkhato ti
translated: They did the duties only when they were approached. The young bhikkhus asked him,🔽“Venerable sir, what are these people to you? Are they your relatives on your mother’s side or on your father’s?”

original: Kiṃ disvā pucchathāti? Tumhesu etesaṃ pemaṃ bahumānanti. “Āvuso, yaṃ mātāpitūhipi
analyzed: kim disvā pucchatha ati tumhesu etesam āvuso yam
translated: “Why do you ask?” “Because of your affection and respect for them.”

original: dukkarataraṃ, taṃ ete amhākaṃ karonti, pattacīvarampi no etesaṃ santakameva, etesaṃ
analyzed: dukkarataram tam ete amhākam karonti pattacīvaram pi no etesam santakam eva etesam
translated: “Friends, they do for us what is more difficult to do than for our mothers and fathers. Our bowl and robe are theirs.

original: ānubhāvena neva bhaye bhayaṃ, na chātake chātakaṃ jānāma, edisā nāma amhākaṃ upakārino
analyzed: ānubhāvena nā iva bhaye bhayam na chātake chātakam jānāma edisāḥ nāma amhākam upakārinaḥ
translated: He goes on telling their virtues, saying, “We do not know whether it is through their power or not, but we have no fear of danger, and the chātaka bird knows no want.”

original: natthī”ti tesaṃ guṇe kathayanto gacchati. Ayaṃ vuccati harati na paccāharatīti.
analyzed: na atthi iti tesam guṇe kathayantaḥ gacchati ayam vuccati harati na paccāharati iti
translated: This is called “he takes but does not return.”

original: Yassa pana pageva vuttappakāraṃ vattapaṭipattiṃ karontassa kammajatejo pajjalati,🔽anupādiṇṇakaṃ muñcitvā upādiṇṇakaṃ gaṇhāti, sarīrato sedā muccanti, kammaṭṭhānavīthiṃ🔽nārohati, so pageva pattacīvaramādāya vegasāva cetiyaṃ vanditvā gorūpānaṃ nikkhamanavelāyameva
analyzed: yassa pana pagā iva vutta ppakāram vatta paṭipattim karontassa kamma ja tejaḥ pajjalati  an upādiṇṇakam muñcitvā upādiṇṇakam gaṇhāti sarīrataḥ sedāḥ muccanti kammaṭṭhāna vīthim  na ārohati saḥ pagā iva patta cīvaram ādāya cetiyam vanditvā go rūpānam nikkhamana velāyam eva
translated: But when one who is already practising the aforementioned duties finds that the fire of his action blazes up,🔽and he takes the unperceived instead of the perceived, sweat breaks out on his body, and he cannot enter the meditation subject,🔽then he should go to the shrine, worship, and depart quickly, taking his bowl and robe. He should enter the village for almsfood at the time of the cows’ coming home.

original: gāmaṃ yāgubhikkhāya pavisitvā yāguṃ labhitvā āsanasālaṃ gantvā pivati. Athassa dvittikkhattuṃ🔽ajjhoharaṇamatteneva kammajatejo upādiṇṇakaṃ muñcitvā anupādiṇṇakaṃ gaṇhāti, ghaṭasatena
analyzed: gāmam yāgu bhikkhāya pavisitvā yāgum labhitvā āsana sālam gantvā pivati athassa dvittikkhattum  ajjhoharaṇa mattena iva kamma ja tejaḥ upādiṇṇakam muñcitvā an upādiṇṇakam gaṇhāti ghaṭa satena
translated: After getting rice gruel, he should go to the refectory and drink it. Then,🔽as soon as he has drunk it twice or thrice, the fire of his action takes the unperceived instead of the perceived, and he becomes as cool as if he had bathed in sandalwood water.

original: nhāto viya tejodhātupariḷāhanibbānaṃ patvā kammaṭṭhānasīsena yāguṃ paribhuñjitvā
analyzed: nhātaḥ viya tejodhātu pariḷāha nibbānam patvā kammaṭṭhāna sīsena yāgum paribhuñjitvā
translated: He should then eat his food with the head of the meditation subject.

original: pattañca mukhañca dhovitvā antarābhatte kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikatvā avasesaṭṭhāne piṇḍāya
analyzed: pattam ca mukham ca dhovitvā antarābhatte kammaṭṭhānam manasikatvā avasesa ṭṭhāne piṇḍāya
translated: After washing his bowl and his mouth, he should give attention to the meditation subject during the day.🔽He should go for alms in the remaining part of the day.

original: caritvā kammaṭṭhānasīsena āhāraṃ paribhuñjitvā tato paṭṭhāya poṅkhānupoṅkhaṃ upaṭṭhahamānaṃ
analyzed: caritvā kammaṭṭhāna sīsena āhāram paribhuñjitvā tatas paṭṭhāya poṅkha anupoṅkham upaṭṭhahamānam
translated: He should eat his food with the meditation subject foremost in his mind. After that he should go to the place where he is to sleep and sit up cross-legged.

original: kammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvāva āgacchati. Ayaṃ vuccati paccāharati na haratīti. Edisā ca
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam gahetvā ava āgacchati ayam vuccati paccāharati na harati iti edisā ca
translated: He should not lie down until he has attained at least access. This is called “not carrying the meditation subject away” .

original: bhikkhū yāguṃ pivitvā vipassanaṃ ārabhitvā buddhasāsane arahattaṃ pattā nāma gaṇanapathaṃ🔽vītivattā. Sīhaḷadīpeyeva tesu tesu gāmesu āsanasālāyaṃ na taṃ āsanamatthi, yattha
analyzed: bhikkhū yāgum pivitvā vipassanam ārabhitvā buddha sāsane arahattam pattāḥ nāma gaṇanapatham  tesu tesu gāmesu āsana sālāyam na tat āsanam atthi yattha
translated: And the bhikkhus who have begun insight after drinking the rice-gruel have gone beyond counting in the Enlightened One’s Dispensation as those who have attained the supreme state.

original: yāguṃ pivitvā arahattaṃ pattā bhikkhū natthīti.
analyzed: yāgum pivitvā arahattam pattā bhikkhū na atthi iti
translated: In the Island of the Rose-apple Tree there is not even a sitting-mat in the rest-house in any village where there is a rest-house that there is no bhikkhu who has attained the supreme state after drinking rice-gruel.

original: Yo pana pamādavihārī hoti nikkhittadhuro, sabbavattāni bhinditvā pañcavidhacetovinibandhabaddhacitto
analyzed: yaḥ pana pamāda vihārī hoti nikkhitta dhuraḥ sabbavattāni bhinditvā pañcavidha cetaḥ vinibandha baddha cittaḥ
translated: But he who is negligent, who has abandoned the burden, who has broken the rules of training, whose mind is bound by the fivefold bondage of the mind,

original: viharanto “kammaṭṭhānaṃ nāma atthī”tipi saññaṃ akatvā gāmaṃ piṇḍāya pavisitvā ananulomikena
analyzed: viharantaḥ kammaṭṭhānam nāma atthi itipi saññam a katvā gāmam piṇḍāya pavisitvā ananulomikena
translated: and who goes into the village for alms without even the idea “There is a meditation subject” and who does not conform to the rules of conduct—

original: gihisaṃsaggena saṃsaṭṭho caritvā ca bhuñjitvā ca tuccho nikkhamati. Ayaṃ vuccati
analyzed: gihi saṃsaggena saṃsaṭṭhaḥ caritvā ca bhuñjitvā ca tucchaḥ nikkhamati ayam vuccati
translated: and he goes away empty-handed after associating with and eating the food of householders. This is called

original: neva harati na paccāharatīti.
analyzed: na iva harati na paccāharati iti
translated: neither taking nor returning.

original: Yo panāyaṃ harati ca paccāharati cāti vutto, so gatapaccāgatikavattavasena veditabbo.
analyzed: yaḥ pana ayam harati ca paccāharati ca ati vuttaḥ saḥ gatapaccāgatika vatta vasena veditabbaḥ
translated: But as to the one who is said to take and return, he should be understood in the way stated in the “refrain” in the case of the “one who goes back and forth”:

original: Attakāmā hi kulaputtā sāsane pabbajitvā dasapi vīsampi tiṃsampi cattālīsampi paññāsampi🔽satampi ekato vasantā katikavattaṃ katvā viharanti “āvuso, tumhe na iṇaṭṭā, na bhayaṭṭā,
analyzed: atta kāmā hi kula puttā sāsane pabbajitvā dasa pi vīsam pi tiṃsam pi cattālīsam pi paññāsam pi  satam pi ekatas vasantā katikavattam katvā viharanti āvuso tumhe na iṇaṭṭā na bhayaṭṭā
translated: For young men of good family who have gone forth in the Dispensation are not like those who go forth among the Ājīvakas.🔽For those who go forth among the Ājīvakas do so because they are in debt, or because they are frightened of their creditors, or because they are evading the king, or because they are afraid, or because they want to better their lot.🔽But those who go forth here do so because they are dispassionate, seeking dispassion for themselves.🔽So when they go forth, they should live by the observance of the proper conduct, thinking: ‘Friends, you have not gone forth in order to argue,

original: na jīvikāpakatā pabbajitā, dukkhā muccitukāmā panettha pabbajitā, tasmā gamane uppannakilesaṃ
analyzed: na jīvikā pakatā pabbajitā dukkhā muccitu kāmā pana ittha pabbajitā tasmā gamane uppanna kilesam
translated: but you have gone forth in order to seek the peace of heart that is to be reached by each one for himself. So suppress any lust that arises,

original: gamaneyeva niggaṇhatha, ṭhāne, nisajjāya, sayane uppannakilesaṃ sayaneyeva niggaṇhathā”ti.
analyzed: gamaneya iva niggaṇhatha ṭhāne nisajjāya sayane uppanna kilesam sayaneya iva niggaṇhatha ati
translated: suppressing it by means of the reflection on dispassion.

original: Te evaṃ katikavattaṃ katvā bhikkhācāraṃ gacchantā aḍḍhausabhausabhaaḍḍhagāvutagāvutantaresu
analyzed: te evam katikavattam katvā bhikkhācāram gacchantā aḍḍhausabha ausabha aḍḍhagāvutagāvuta antaresu
translated: When you go on an alms round, you should go in twos and threes,

original: pāsāṇā honti, tāya saññāya kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikarontāva gacchanti. Sace kassaci gamane🔽kileso uppajjati, tattheva naṃ niggaṇhāti. Tathā asakkonto tiṭṭhati. Athassa pacchato
analyzed: pāsāṇāḥ honti tāya saññāya kammaṭṭhānam manasikarontā ava gacchanti sace kassaci gamane  kilesaḥ uppajjati tattha eva nam niggaṇhāti tathā a sakkontaḥ tiṭṭhati atha assa pacchatas
translated: He goes on contemplating the meditation subject all the time. If any defilement arises in anyone while he is going,

original: āgacchantopi tiṭṭhati, so “ayaṃ bhikkhu tuyhaṃ uppannavitakkaṃ jānāti, ananucchavikaṃ
analyzed: āgacchantaḥ api tiṭṭhati saḥ ayam bhikkhu tuyham uppanna vitakkam jānāti ananucchavikam
translated: he suppresses it there and then. If he is unable to do so, he stops. Then the one who is following behind also stops, thinking, “This bhikkhu knows the thought that has arisen in me. It is not proper for me to go on.”

original: te eta”nti attānaṃ paṭicodetvā vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā tattheva ariyabhūmiṃ okkamati,🔽tathā asakkonto nisīdatīti so eva nayo. Ariyabhūmiṃ okkamituṃ asakkontopi, taṃ kilesaṃ
analyzed: te etanti attānam paṭicodetvā vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā tattha iva ariya bhūmim okkamati  tathā a sakkontaḥ nisīdati iti saḥ eva nayaḥ ariya bhūmim okkamitum a sakkontaḥ api tam kilesam
translated: He reproves himself, develops insight, and enters upon the supramundane states right there.🔽If he is unable to do so, he sits down. The same method applies here.

original: vikkhambhetvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikarontova gacchati, na kammaṭṭhānavippayuttena cittena🔽pādaṃ uddharati. Uddharati ce, paṭinivattitvā purimapadesaṃyeva eti ālindakavāsī
analyzed: vikkhambhetvā kammaṭṭhānam manasikarontaḥ eva gacchati na kammaṭṭhāna vippayuttena cittena  pādam uddharati uddharati ce eti ālindaka vāsī
translated: If he is unable to enter upon the supramundane states, he goes on suppressing that defilement and contemplating the meditation subject. He does not lift up his foot or put it down with mind unconcentrated.

original: mahāphussadevatthero viya.
analyzed: mahāphussadeva ttheraḥ
translated: If he does so, he turns back and goes to the place he has left behind. He is like the Elder Mahā Phussadeva of Āḷavaka.

original: So kira ekūnavīsati vassāni gatapaccāgatikavattaṃ pūrento eva vihāsi. Manussāpi sudaṃ
analyzed: saḥ kira ekūnavīsati vassāni gatapaccāgatika vattam pūrentaḥ eva vihāsi manussā api sudam
translated: It is said that he spent nineteen years in the practice of going back and forth. People who were

original: antarāmagge kasantā ca vapantā ca maddantā ca kammāni ca karontā theraṃ tathā gacchantaṃ
analyzed: antara āmagge kasantā ca vapantā ca maddantā ca kammāni ca karontā theram tathā gacchantam
translated: ploughing, sowing, and doing other work on the road saw him going back and forth in this way.

original: disvā – “ayaṃ thero punappunaṃ nivattitvā gacchati, kiṃ nu kho maggamūḷho, udāhu
analyzed: disvā ayam thero punappunam nivattitvā gacchati kim nu kho magga mūḷhaḥ udāhu
translated: They said, “This elder goes back and forth again and again. Is he confused about the road, or

original: kiñci pamuṭṭho”ti samullapanti. So taṃ anādiyitvā kammaṭṭhānayuttacitteneva samaṇadhammaṃ🔽karonto vīsativassabbhantare arahattaṃ pāpuṇi. Arahattappattadivase cassa caṅkamanakoṭiyaṃ
analyzed: kiñci pamuṭṭhaḥ iti samullapanti saḥ tam an ādiyitvā kammaṭṭhāna yutta cittena iva samaṇa dhammaṃ  karontaḥ vīsati vassa abbhantare arahattam pāpuṇi arahatta patta divase ca ssa caṅkamana koṭiyam
translated: is he confused about something else?” But he paid no attention to them. With his mind intent on the meditation subject, he went on doing his ascetic practice.

original: adhivatthā devatā aṅgulīhi dīpaṃ ujjāletvā aṭṭhāsi. Cattāropi mahārājāno sakko ca
analyzed: adhivatthā devatā aṅgulīhi dīpam ujjāletvā aṭṭhāsi cattāro api mahā rājāno sakko ca
translated: In the twentieth year he reached Arahantship. On the day he reached Arahantship, a deity who lived at the end of the walk he used for his exercise lit a torch with her fingernail to show him the walk. The four Great Kings, Sakka Ruler of Gods,

original: devānamindo brahmā ca sahampati upaṭṭhānaṃ āgamaṃsu. Tañca obhāsaṃ disvā vanavāsīmahātissatthero
analyzed: devānamindaḥ brahmā ca sahampati upaṭṭhānam āgamaṃsu tat ca obhāsam disvā vana vāsī mahā tissa theraḥ
translated: and Brahma Sahampati all came to wait on him. The Elder Maha Tissa, who lived in the forest, saw the light and said,

original: taṃ dutiyadivase pucchi – “rattibhāge āyasmato santike obhāso ahosi, kiṃ so obhāso”ti?
analyzed: tam dutiya divase pucchi ratti bhāge āyasmato santike obhāsaḥ ahosi kim saḥ obhāsaḥ iti
translated: He asked him about it on the following day, saying, “There was a radiance in the presence of the venerable one during the night. What was that radiance? ”

original: Thero vikkhepaṃ karonto “obhāso nāma dīpobhāsopi hoti, maṇiobhāsopī”ti evamādimāha.
analyzed: theraḥ vikkhepam karontaḥ obhāsaḥ nāma dīpa ubhāsaḥ api hoti maṇi obhāsaḥ api iti evamādim āha
translated: The elder made an evasion, saying, “The radiance is the radiance of a lamp, the radiance of a gem, and so on. ”

original: Tato “paṭicchādetha tumhe”ti nibaddho āmāti paṭijānitvā ārocesi.
analyzed: tatas paṭicchādetha tumhā iti nibaddhaḥ paṭijānitvā ārocesi
translated: Then, being pressed, he admitted it, saying, “Conceal it you should. ”

original: Kāḷavallimaṇḍapavāsīmahānāgatthero viya ca. Sopi kira gatapaccāgatikavattaṃ pūrento
analyzed: ca saḥ api kira gata paccāgatika vattam pūrento
translated: And like the Elder Mahānāga who lived in the Kāḷavellī Monastery. He, it seems, was fulfilling the duties of going on and returning.

original: paṭhamaṃ tāva “bhagavato mahāpadhānaṃ pūjessāmī”ti satta vassāni ṭhānacaṅkamameva
analyzed: paṭhamam tāva bhagavataḥ mahāpadhānam pūjessāmi iti satta vassāni ṭhāna caṅkamam eva
translated: First he resolved to spend seven years standing and walking in order to worship the Blessed One’s Great Retirement .

original: adhiṭṭhāsi. Puna soḷasa vassāni gatapaccāgatikavattaṃ pūretvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇi. So
analyzed: adhiṭṭhāsi puna soḷasa vassāni gatapaccāgatika vattam pūretvā arahattam pāpuṇi so
translated: Then he fulfilled the duties of going on and returning for sixteen years and reached Arahantship.

original: kammaṭṭhānayutteneva cittena pādaṃ uddharanto vippayuttena uddhaṭe paṭinivattanto
analyzed: kammaṭṭhāna yuttena iva cittena pādam uddharantaḥ vippayuttena uddhaṭe paṭinivattantaḥ
translated: He raised his foot with a consciousness associated with a meditation subject, and he turned back with an unassociated consciousness.

original: gāmasamīpaṃ gantvā “gāvī nu pabbajito nū”ti āsaṅkanīyapadese ṭhatvā cīvaraṃ pārupitvā
analyzed: gāma samīpam gantvā gāvī nu pabbajitaḥ nu iti āsaṅkanīya padese ṭhatvā cīvaram pārupitvā
translated: When he had gone near to a village, he stood in a place where it could be doubted whether he was an ox or a bhikkhu, and he put on his outer robe.

original: kacchakarakato udakena pattaṃ dhovitvā udakagaṇḍūsaṃ karoti. Kiṃ kāraṇā? “Mā me bhikkhaṃ
analyzed: kaccha karakataḥ udakena pattam dhovitvā udaka gaṇḍūsam karoti kim kāraṇā mā me bhikkham
translated: He washes his bowl with water from the water dipper and makes a water strainer. Why is that? “So that my almsfood

original: dātuṃ vā vandituṃ vā āgate manusse ‘dīghāyukā hothā’ti vacanamattenāpi kammaṭṭhānavikkhepo
analyzed: dātum vā vanditum vā āgate manusse dīgha āyukāḥ hotha ati vacana mattena api kammaṭṭhāna vikkhepaḥ
translated: He washes his bowl with water from his water-strainer and then makes a water-strainer with the water. Why? So that he will not be distracted from his meditation subject by the people who come to give him almsfood or to pay him homage, by saying “May you live long” and so on.

original: ahosī”ti “ajja, bhante, katimī”ti divasaṃ vā bhikkhugaṇanaṃ vā pañhaṃ vā pucchito
analyzed: ahosi iti ajja bhante katimī iti divasam vā bhikkhu gaṇanam vā pañham vā pucchito
translated: If anyone asks him, “What is today’s date, venerable sir?,” or “What is the number of the day, venerable sir?,” or “What is the question, venerable sir?,”

original: pana udakaṃ gilitvā āroceti. Sace divasādipucchakā na honti, nikkhamanavelāyaṃ gāmadvāre niṭṭhubhitvā yāti.🔽Kalambatitthavihāre vassūpagatā paññāsa bhikkhū viya ca. Te kira āsāḷhipuṇṇamiyaṃ
analyzed: pana udakam gilitvā āroceti sace divasa ādi pucchakāḥ na honti nikkhamana velāyam gāma dvāre niṭṭhubhitvā yāti  kalamba tittha vihāre vassūpagatā paññāsa bhikkhū ca te kira āsāḷhipuṇṇamiyam
translated: he swallows the water and then answers. If no one asks him, he goes out through the village gate at the time for starting work and departs trumpeting.

original: katikavattaṃ akaṃsu – “arahattaṃ apatvā aññamaññaṃ nālapissāmā”ti. Gāmañca piṇḍāya
analyzed: katikavattam akaṃsu arahattam a patvā aññam aññam na ālapissāma ati gāmam ca piṇḍāya
translated: And also like the fifty bhikkhus who went to the Kalambaka monastery for the rains. They made a rule, it seems, on the day of the observance of the beginning of the rains, that they would not speak to one another until they had attained Nibbāna.🔽And when they entered the village for alms they made a water-strainer with water.

original: pavisantā udakagaṇḍūsaṃ katvā pavisiṃsu. Divasādīsu pucchitesu vuttanayeneva paṭipajjiṃsu.
analyzed: pavisantāḥ udaka gaṇḍūsam katvā pavisiṃsu divasa ādīsu pucchitesu vutta nayena iva paṭipajjiṃsu
translated: And when asked about the day and so on, they conducted themselves in the way already described.

original: Tattha manussā niṭṭhubhanaṃ disvā jāniṃsu – “ajjeko āgato, ajja dve”ti. Evañca cintesuṃ
analyzed: tattha manussāḥ niṭṭhubhanam disvā jāniṃsu ajja ekaḥ āgataḥ ajja dve iti evam ca cintesuṃ
translated: The people, seeing the spittings, knew that one had come on one day and two on another. They thought:

original: – “kiṃ nu kho ete amheheva saddhiṃ na sallapanti, udāhu aññamaññampi. Yadi aññamaññaṃ🔽na sallapanti, addhā vivādajātā bhavissanti. Etha ne aññamaññaṃ khamāpessāmā”ti sabbe
analyzed: kim nu kho ete amhehi iva saddhim na sallapanti udāhu aññam aññam pi yadi aññam aññam  na sallapanti addhā vivāda jātāḥ bhavissanti etha ne aññamaññam khamāpessāma ati sabbe
translated: “Why do they not talk with us? Or do they not talk with one another? If they do not talk with one another,

original: vihāraṃ gantvā paññāsāya bhikkhūsu dvepi bhikkhū ekokāse nāddasaṃsu. Tato yo tesu🔽cakkhumā puriso, so āha – “na bho kalahakārakānaṃ okāso īdiso hoti, susammaṭṭhaṃ
analyzed: vihāram gantvā paññāsāya bhikkhūsu dve api bhikkhū ekokāse na addasaṃsu tatas yaḥ tesu  cakkhumā puriso saḥ āha na bho kalahakārakānam okāsaḥ īdisaḥ hoti su sammaṭṭham
translated: they must have fallen out. Come, let us make them reconcile their differences.” So they all went to the monastery. They did not see two bhikkhus in the same place among the fifty bhikkhus. Then the man among them who was the most intelligent said:

original: cetiyaṅgaṇaṃ bodhiyaṅgaṇaṃ, sunikkhittā sammajjaniyo, supaṭṭhitaṃ pānīyaṃ paribhojanīya”nti.
analyzed: cetiya aṅgaṇam bodhiya aṅgaṇam su nikkhittā sammajjaniyaḥ su paṭṭhitam pānīyam paribhojanīyanti
translated: “It is not the case, friends, that there is no place for those who fall out. The shrine terrace is well swept, the Bodhi Tree terrace is well swept, the brooms are well placed, the drinking water and the washing water are well placed.”

original: Te tatova nivattā. Tepi bhikkhū antotemāseyeva arahattaṃ patvā mahāpavāraṇāyaṃ visuddhipavāraṇaṃ pavāresuṃ.
analyzed: te tatas va nivattā te api bhikkhū antotemāseya iva arahattam patvā mahāpavāraṇāyam visuddhi pavāraṇam pavāresuṃ
translated: So they turned back there and then. And those bhikkhus reached Arahantship within the inner courtyard and on the Great Invitation Day they invited with a pure purification.

original: Evaṃ kāḷavallimaṇḍapavāsī mahānāgatthero viya, kalambatitthavihāre vassūpagatā bhikkhū🔽viya ca kammaṭṭhānayutteneva cittena pādaṃ uddharanto gāmasamīpaṃ gantvā udakagaṇḍūsaṃ
analyzed: evam kāḷavalli maṇḍapa vāsī mahānāga ttheraḥ kalamba tittha vihāre vassu upagatāḥ bhikkhū  viya ca kammaṭṭhāna yuttena iva cittena pādam uddharantaḥ gāma samīpam gantvā udaka gaṇḍūsam
translated: As did the Elder Mahanaga who lived in the Black Rock Cave, and as did the bhikkhus who entered upon the rains residence in the Kalambaka Monastery.

original: katvā vīthiyo sallakkhetvā yattha surāsoṇḍadhuttādayo kalahakārakā caṇḍahatthiassādayo
analyzed: katvā vīthiyaḥ sallakkhetvā yattha surā soṇḍa dhutta ādayo kalahakārakā caṇḍahatthiassa ādayo
translated: When he has gone to the village, he should take a mouthful of water in his mouth and look up the street to see whether there are any quarrels, thieves, wild beasts, or the like, and also to see whether there are any mad bulls, horses, etc., that might cause injury.🔽He should not go along the street too hurriedly as though he were in a race.

original: vā natthi, taṃ vīthiṃ paṭipajjati. Tattha ca piṇḍāya caramāno na turitaturito viya🔽javena gacchati. Na hi javena piṇḍapātikadhutaṅgaṃ nāma kiñci atthi. Visamabhūmibhāgapattaṃ🔽pana udakasakaṭaṃ viya niccalo hutvā gacchati. Anugharaṃ paviṭṭho ca dātukāmaṃ vā
analyzed: vā na atthi tam vīthim paṭipajjati tattha ca piṇḍāya caramānaḥ na turita turitaḥ viya  javena gacchati na hi javena piṇḍapātikadhutaṅgam nāma kiñci atthi visama bhūmi bhāga pattam  pana udaka sakaṭam viya niccalaḥ hutvā gacchati ca dātu kāmam vā
translated: For there is no such virtue of a alms-food eater as speed.🔽He should go as steadily as a water-drawing wheel.🔽When he has entered a street, he should not look at the giver if she is a woman, or at the attendant if he is a man, in case he should be contaminated by lust.🔽He should look down at the tip of his nose or a span’s distance in front of his feet.

original: adātukāmaṃ vā sallakkhetuṃ tadanurūpaṃ kālaṃ āgamento bhikkhaṃ gahetvā antogāme vā
analyzed: a dātu kāmam vā sallakkhetum tad anurūpam kālam āgamentaḥ bhikkham gahetvā antogāme vā
translated: He should not go too far into the village or the town for alms.

original: bahigāme vā vihārameva vā āgantvā yathāphāsuke patirūpe okāse nisīditvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: bahigāme vā vihāram eva vā āgantvā yathāphāsuke pati rūpe okāse nisīditvā kammaṭṭhānam
translated: He should go for alms in the place where he gets alms.

original: manasikaronto āhāre paṭikūlasaññaṃ upaṭṭhapetvā akkhabbhañjanavaṇalepanaputtamaṃsūpamāvasena
analyzed: manasikarontaḥ āhāre paṭikūla saññam upaṭṭhapetvā akkhabbhañjana vaṇa lepana putta maṃsūpamā vasena
translated: As he does so, he establishes the perception of the foulness of food by means of the simile of the sack for carrying dung, the simile of the ointment for ulcers, and the simile of the child’s flesh.

original: paccavekkhanto aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ āhāraṃ āhāreti, neva davāya na madāya na maṇḍanāya🔽na vibhūsanāya…pe… bhuttāvī ca udakakiccaṃ katvā muhuttaṃ bhattakilamathaṃ paṭipassambhetvā
analyzed: paccavekkhantaḥ aṭṭhaṅga samannāgatam āhāram āhāreti na iva davāya na madāya na maṇḍanāya  na vibhūsanāyape bhuttāvī ca udaka kiccam katvā muhuttam bhatta kilamatham paṭipassambhetvā
translated: When he reflects, he takes food endowed with eight factors. He does not do so for amusement, for intoxication, for the sake of physical beauty and attractiveness,🔽but only for the endurance and continuance of this body, for ending discomfort, and for assisting the holy life, considering: “Thus I shall terminate old feelings without arousing new feelings and I shall be healthy and blameless and shall live in comfort.”🔽After the meal, when he has rinsed his bowl and hands, he should spend the remainder of the day and the first watch of the night thus,

original: yathā purebhattaṃ, evaṃ pacchābhattaṃ purimayāmaṃ pacchimayāmañca kammaṭṭhānameva
analyzed: yathā purebhattam evam pacchābhattam purima yāmam pacchima yāmam ca kammaṭṭhānam eva
translated: and in the last watch he should lie down in the lion’s posture, on the right side, placing one foot on the other, mindful and clearly comprehending, after noting in his mind the time for rising.

original: manasikaroti. Ayaṃ vuccati harati ca paccāharati cāti.
analyzed: manasikaroti ayam vuccati harati ca paccāharati ca ati
translated: This is called “one who both takes and brings back.”

original: Imaṃ pana haraṇapaccāharaṇasaṅkhātaṃ gatapaccāgatikavattaṃ pūrento yadi upanissayasampanno
analyzed: imam pana haraṇa paccāharaṇa saṅkhātam gatapaccāgatika vattam pūrentaḥ yadi upanissaya sampannaḥ
translated: One who is fulfilling this virtue called “taking and bringing back,” which is also called “the virtue of going and coming,” if he has the requisite supporting conditions,🔽attains Arahantship in the first stage of life. If not, then in the middle stage of life;

original: hoti, paṭhamavaye eva arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. No ce paṭhamavaye pāpuṇāti, atha majjhimavaye🔽pāpuṇāti. No ce majjhimavaye pāpuṇāti, atha pacchimavaye pāpuṇāti, no ce pacchimavaye
analyzed: hoti paṭhama vaye eva arahattam pāpuṇāti no ce paṭhama vaye pāpuṇāti atha majjhima vaye 🔽pāpuṇāti no ce majjhima vaye pāpuṇāti atha pacchima vaye pāpuṇāti no ce pacchima vaye
translated: if not, then in the last stage of life.

original: pāpuṇāti, atha maraṇasamaye. No ce maraṇasamaye pāpuṇāti, atha devaputto hutvā. No
analyzed: pāpuṇāti atha maraṇa samaye no ce maraṇa samaye pāpuṇāti atha devaputto hutvā no
translated: if not, then at the time of death. If not at the time of death, then as a god.

original: ce devaputto hutvā pāpuṇāti, anuppanne buddhe nibbatto paccekabodhiṃ sacchikaroti.
analyzed: ce deva puttaḥ hutvā pāpuṇāti anuppanne buddhe nibbattaḥ paccekabodhim sacchikaroti
translated: If not as a god, then when a Buddha has not arisen he is reborn and realises the Paccekabodhi.

original: No ce paccekabodhiṃ sacchikaroti, atha buddhānaṃ sammukhībhāve khippābhiñño vā hoti,
analyzed: no ce paccekabodhim sacchikaroti atha buddhānam sammukhībhāve khippa abhiññaḥ vā hoti
translated: If not the Paccekabodhi, then when the Buddhas are present he is one of quick understanding,🔽like the Elder Bāhiyo Dārucīriya, or one of great wisdom,

original: seyyathāpi thero bāhiyo dārucīriyo mahāpañño vā, seyyathāpi thero sāriputto, mahiddhiko
analyzed: seyyathāpi theraḥ bāhiyaḥ dārucīriyaḥ mahā paññaḥ vā seyyathāpi theraḥ sāriputtaḥ mahiddhiko
translated: like the Elder Sāriputta, or one of great psychic power,🔽like the Elder Mahāmoggallāna, or one who teaches the ascetic practices,

original: vā, seyyathāpi thero mahāmoggallāno, dhutavādo vā, seyyathāpi thero mahākassapo,
analyzed: vā seyyathāpi theraḥ mahāmoggallānaḥ dhutavādaḥ vā seyyathāpi theraḥ mahākassapo
translated: like the Elder Mahākassapa, or one with the divine eye,

original: dibbacakkhuko vā, seyyathāpi thero anuruddho, vinayadharo vā, seyyathāpi thero upāli,
analyzed: dibba cakkhukaḥ vā seyyathāpi theraḥ anuruddhaḥ vinaya dharaḥ vā seyyathāpi theraḥ upāli
translated: like the Elder Anuruddha, or one who is an expert in the Vinaya,🔽like the Elder Upāli, or one who is a preacher of the Dhamma,

original: dhammakathiko vā, seyyathāpi thero puṇṇo mantāṇiputto, āraññiko vā, seyyathāpi thero
analyzed: dhamma kathikaḥ vā seyyathāpi thero puṇṇaḥ mantāṇi putto āraññikaḥ vā seyyathāpi thero
translated: like the Elder Puṇṇa Mantāṇiputta, or one who lives in the forest,🔽like the Elder Revata, or one who is learned,

original: revato, bahussuto vā, seyyathāpi thero ānando, sikkhākāmo vā, seyyathāpi thero rāhulo
analyzed: revataḥ bahussutaḥ vā seyyathā api theraḥ ānando sikkhākāmaḥ vā seyyathā api theraḥ rāhulo
translated: like the Elder Ānanda, or one who is eager for training, like the Elder Rāhula.

original: buddhaputtoti. Iti imasmiṃ catukke yvāyaṃ harati paccāharati ca, tassa gocarasampajaññaṃ sikhāpattaṃ hoti.
analyzed: buddha putto ti iti imasmim catukke yvā ayam harati paccāharati ca tassa gocara sampajaññam sikhāpattam hoti
translated: So in this tetrad, the one who goes and comes back has the kind of clear comprehension of resort that is like the crest-jewel.🔽But the non-confusion about going forwards and backwards, etc., is clear comprehension of non-delusion. That should be understood as follows.

original: Abhikkamādīsu pana asammuyhanaṃ asammohasampajaññaṃ. Taṃ evaṃ veditabbaṃ – idha bhikkhu
analyzed: abhikkama ādīsu pana a sammuyhanam a sammoha sampajaññam tam evam veditabbam idha bhikkhu
translated: Here a bhikkhu,

original: abhikkamanto vā paṭikkamanto vā yathā andhaputhujjanā abhikkamādīsu – “attā abhikkamati,
analyzed: abhikkamantaḥ vā paṭikkamantaḥ vā yathā andha puthujjanāḥ abhikkama ādīsu attā abhikkamati
translated: when going forwards or backwards, does not go as do the blind, ordinary people, who go about confused, thinking, “The self goes forward,

original: attanā abhikkamo nibbattito”ti vā “ahaṃ abhikkamāmi, mayā abhikkamo nibbattito”ti🔽vā sammuyhanti, tathā asammuyhanto abhikkamāmīti citte uppajjamāne teneva cittena🔽saddhiṃ cittasamuṭṭhānā vāyodhātu viññattiṃ janayamānā uppajjati, iti cittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphāravasena
analyzed: attanā abhikkamaḥ nibbattito ti vā aham abhikkamāmi mayā abhikkamaḥ nibbattito ti  vā sammuyhanti tathā a sammuyhantaḥ abhikkamāmi iti citte uppajjamāne tena iva cittena  saddhim citta samuṭṭhānā vāyodhātu viññattim janayamānā uppajjati iti citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphāra vasena
translated: the self goes backwards,” or “The self is the goer,” or “The self is the one who makes the going,” or “The self is the one who sets the going in motion.”🔽When the thought “I am going forwards” arises in him,🔽then with that thought there arises the air element that is originated by that thought and that generates the intimation.

original: ayaṃ kāyasammato aṭṭhisaṅghāṭo abhikkamati. Tassevaṃ abhikkamato ekekapāduddharaṇe
analyzed: ayam kāya sammataḥ aṭṭhi saṅghāṭaḥ abhikkamati tassa ivam abhikkamataḥ ekeka pāda uddharaṇe
translated: So it is by the distension of the air element that is a function of mind that this frame of bones, which is reckoned as the body, goes forwards.🔽When he goes forwards in this way,

original: pathavīdhātu āpodhātūti dve dhātuyo omattā honti mandā, itarā dve adhimattā honti🔽balavatiyo, tathā atiharaṇavītiharaṇesu, vossajjane tejodhātu vāyodhātūti dve dhātuyo
analyzed: pathavī dhātu āpaḥ dhātu uti dve dhātuyaḥ omattāḥ honti mandāḥ itarāḥ dve adhimattāḥ honti  tathā atiharaṇa vītiharaṇesu vossajjane tejaḥ dhātu vāyaḥ dhātu iti dve
translated: The two elements, the earth element and the water element, are deficient, weak, while the other two are excessive, strong.🔽So too in the case of carrying away and carrying out. In the case of letting go, the two elements, the fire element and the air element,

original: omattā honti mandā, itarā dve adhimattā honti balavatiyo, tathā sannikkhepanasannirumbhanesu.
analyzed: omattāḥ honti mandāḥ itarāḥ dve adhimattāḥ honti balavatiyaḥ tathā sannikkhepana sannirumbhanesu
translated: are deficient, weak, while the other two are excessive, strong. So too in the case of putting down and pressing down.

original: Tattha uddharaṇe pavattā rūpārūpadhammā atiharaṇaṃ na pāpuṇanti, tathā atiharaṇe
analyzed: tattha uddharaṇe pavattāḥ rūpa arūpa dhammāḥ atiharaṇam na pāpuṇanti tathā atiharaṇe
translated: Herein, the material and immaterial states occurring in lifting do not reach carrying away, and so too

original: pavattā vītiharaṇaṃ, vītiharaṇe pavattā vossajjanaṃ, vossajjane pavattā sannikkhepanaṃ,🔽sannikkhepane pavattā sannirumbhanaṃ na pāpuṇanti, tattha tattheva pabbapabbaṃ sandhisandhi
analyzed: pavattā vītiharaṇam vītiharaṇe pavattā vossajjanam vossajjane pavattā sannikkhepanam  sannikkhepane pavattā sannirumbhanam na pāpuṇanti tattha tattha iva pabba pabbam sandhi sandhi
translated: those occurring in carrying away do not reach carrying out, and those occurring in carrying out do not reach letting go, and those occurring in letting go do not reach putting down,

original: odhiodhi hutvā tattakapāle pakkhittatilāni viya taṭataṭāyantā bhijjanti. Tattha ko
analyzed: odhi odhi hutvā tatta kapāle pakkhitta tilāni viya taṭataṭāyantāḥ bhijjanti tattha ko
translated: and those occurring in putting down do not reach pressing down. They break up there and then, like sesame seeds pressed in a sesame-seed press, like “hill against hill.”

original: eko abhikkamati, kassa vā ekassa abhikkamanaṃ? Paramatthato hi dhātūnaṃyeva gamanaṃ,
analyzed: ekaḥ abhikkamati kassa vai ekassa abhikkamanam paramatthataḥ hi dhātūnam yeva gamanam
translated: Herein, who is it that goes forward? Or whose is the going forward? For it is only elements that go.

original: dhātūnaṃ ṭhānaṃ, dhātūnaṃ nisajjā, dhātūnaṃ sayanaṃ. Tasmiṃ tasmiñhi koṭṭhāse saddhiṃ rūpena –
analyzed: dhātūnam ṭhānam dhātūnam nisajjā dhātūnam sayanam tasmin tasmin hi koṭṭhāse saddhim rūpena
translated: the postures of the elements, the sitting, lying, and so on, of the elements.

original: “Aññaṃ uppajjate cittaṃ, aññaṃ cittaṃ nirujjhati;
analyzed: aññam uppajjate cittam aññam cittam nirujjhati
translated: “One consciousness arises, another ceases,

original: Avīcimanusambandho, nadīsotova vattatī”ti. –
analyzed: avīci manu sambandhaḥ nadī sotaḥ uva vattati iti
translated: In uninterrupted continuity, like the flow of a river.”

original: Evaṃ abhikkamādīsu asammuyhanaṃ asammohasampajaññaṃ nāmāti.
analyzed: evam abhikkama ādīsu a sammuyhanam a sammoha sampajaññam nāma ati
translated: So non-confusion about going forward and so on is called “clear comprehension of non-delusion.”

original: Niṭṭhito “abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hotī”tipadassa attho.
analyzed: niṭṭhitaḥ abhikkante paṭikkante sampajāna kārī hoti iti padassa attho
translated: The meaning of the clause “He is one who acts with clear comprehension in looking ahead and behind” has now been explained.

original: Ālokite vilokiteti ettha pana ālokitaṃ nāma purato pekkhanaṃ, vilokitaṃ nāma anudisāpekkhanaṃ.🔽Aññānipi heṭṭhā upari pacchato anupekkhanavasena olokitaullokitāpalokitāni nāma honti.
analyzed: ālokite vilokita iti ettha pana ālokitam nāma puratas pekkhanam vilokitam nāma anudisā apekkhanam  aññāni api heṭṭhā upari pacchatas an upekkhana vasena olokita aullokita apalokitāni nāma honti
translated: As regards the clause “in looking straight on and in looking away,” looking straight on is looking in front, and looking away is looking to the left and right.

original: Tāni idha na gahitāni, sāruppavasena pana imāneva dve gahitāni. Iminā vā mukhena
analyzed: tāni idha na gahitāni sāruppa vasena pana imāneva dve gahitāni iminā vā mukhena
translated: There are also looking up, looking down, and looking sideways, but these are not mentioned here. However, these two are included by the words “looking straight on” and “looking away”

original: sabbānipi tāni gahitānevāti.
analyzed: sabbāni api tāni gahitāni eva ati
translated: because they are included under the appropriate headings.

original: Tattha “ālokessāmī”ti citte uppanne cittavaseneva anoloketvā atthapariggaṇhanaṃ sātthakasampajaññaṃ. Taṃ āyasmantaṃ nandaṃ kāyasakkhiṃ katvā veditabbaṃ. Vuttañhetaṃ bhagavatā –
analyzed: tattha ālokessāmi iti citte uppanne citta vasena iva anoloketvā attha pariggaṇhanam sātthaka sampajaññam tam āyasmantam nandam kāya sakkhim katvā veditabbam vuttam ha etam bhagavatā
translated: Herein, the discerning of meaning by the mere arising of the thought “I shall look” without looking is the “understanding of what has and has not been done” . This should be understood as the venerable Nanda’s “witness within himself.” For this is said by the Blessed One:

original: “Sace, bhikkhave, nandassa puratthimā disā āloketabbā hoti, sabbaṃ cetasā samannāharitvā🔽nando puratthimaṃ disaṃ āloketi ‘evaṃ me puratthimaṃ disaṃ ālokayato nābhijjhādomanassā
