analyzed: sace bhikkhave nandassa puratthimā disā āloketabbā hoti sabbam cetasā samannāharitvā  nando puratthimam disam āloketi evam me puratthimam disam ālokayataḥ na abhijjhā domanassā
translated: “If, bhikkhus, the eastern direction were to be ablaze, I should tell Nanda to look at it;🔽and when he was looking, I should ask him: ‘How is it, Nanda, is there lust, hate, or delusion there?’

original: pāpakā akusalā dhammā anvāsavissantī’ti. Itiha tattha sampajāno hoti. Sace, bhikkhave,
analyzed: pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ dhammāḥ anvāsavissanti iti iti ha tattha sampajānaḥ hoti sace bhikkhave
translated: and he would say: ‘No, venerable sir.’

original: nandassa pacchimā disā, uttarā disā, dakkhiṇā disā, uddhaṃ, adho, anudisā āloketabbā
analyzed: nandassa pacchimā disā uttarā disā dakkhiṇā disā uddham adhas anudisā āloketabbā
translated: And if the western, northern, southern, downward, upward, or the intermediate directions were to be ablaze, I should tell Nanda to look at it;

original: hoti, sabbaṃ cetasā samannāharitvā nando anudisaṃ āloketi ‘evaṃ me anudisaṃ ālokayato’…pe… sampajāno hotī”ti.
analyzed: hoti sabbam cetasā samannāharitvā nandaḥ anudisam āloketi evam me anudisam ālokayatā upe sampajānaḥ hoti iti
translated: and when he was looking, I should ask him: ‘How is it, Nanda, is there lust, hate, or delusion there?’ and he would say: ‘No, venerable sir.’

original: Apica idhāpi pubbe vuttacetiyadassanādivaseneva sātthakatā ca sappāyatā ca veditabbā.
analyzed: apica idha api pubbe vutta cetiya dassana ādi vasena iva sātthaka tā ca sappāya tā ca veditabbā
translated: Furthermore, the meaningfulness and the suitability should be understood here too in the way already described in the description of the profitable consciousnesses of the sense sphere.🔽But the mere fact of not abandoning the meditation subject is the mindfulness concerned with the body.

original: Kammaṭṭhānassa pana avijahanameva gocarasampajaññaṃ, tasmā khandhadhātuāyatanakammaṭṭhānikehi
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānassa pana a vijahanam eva gocara sampajaññam tasmā khandha dhātu āyatana kammaṭṭhānikehi
translated: So those who have the meditation subjects of the aggregates, elements, sense bases, etc.,

original: attano kamaṭṭhānavaseneva kasiṇādikammaṭṭhānikehi vā pana kammaṭṭhānasīseneva ālokanavilokanaṃ kātabbaṃ.
analyzed: attano kamaṭṭhāna vasena iva kasiṇa ādi kammaṭṭhānikehi vā pana kammaṭṭhāna sīsena iva ālokana vilokanam kātabbam
translated: should look straight on and look away by means of their meditation subjects. But those who have kasiṇas, etc., as their meditation subjects should look straight on and look away by means of the meditation subject.

original: “Abbhantare attā nāma āloketā vā viloketā vā natthi, ‘ālokessāmī’ti pana citte uppajjamāne
analyzed: abbhantare attā nāma āloketā vā viloketā vā natthi ālokessāmi iti pana citte uppajjamāne
translated: “There is no self or soul on the inside that looks straight on or looks away. But when the thought occurs, ‘I shall look straight on,’

original: teneva cittena saddhiṃ cittasamuṭṭhānā vāyodhātu viññattiṃ janayamānā uppajjati.
analyzed: tena iva cittena saddhim citta samuṭṭhānā vāyodhātu viññattim janayamānā uppajjati
translated: then the mind-born air element that arises together with that thought generates intimation.

original: Iti cittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphāravasena heṭṭhimaṃ akkhidalaṃ adho sīdati, uparimaṃ
analyzed: iti citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphāra vasena heṭṭhimam akkhi dalam adhas sīdati uparimam
translated: So the lower eyelid sinks down and the upper eyelid rises up by the impact of the current of air that arises with the movement of the mind.

original: uddhaṃ laṅgheti, koci yantakena vivaranto nāma natthi, tato cakkhuviññāṇaṃ dassanakiccaṃ
analyzed: uddham laṅgheti koci yantakena vivarantaḥ nāma na atthi tatas cakkhu viññāṇam dassana kiccam
translated: There is no one who opens the eye by means of a contrivance. Then eye-consciousness performs the function of seeing.

original: sādhentaṃ uppajjatī”ti evaṃ pajānanaṃ panettha asammohasampajaññaṃ nāma.
analyzed: sādhentam uppajjati iti evam pajānanam pana ittha asammoha sampajaññam nāma
translated: This is called clear comprehension of non-delusion.🔽Furthermore, clear comprehension of non-delusion should be understood here as the full understanding of the root, as the adventitious nature, and as the timely state.

original: Apica mūlapariññāāgantukatāvakālikabhāvavasenapettha asammohasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ. Mūlapariññāvasena tāva –🔽“Bhavaṅgāvajjanañceva, dassanaṃ sampaṭicchanaṃ;
analyzed: apica mūla pariññā āgantuka tāvakālika bhāva vasena pa ittha asammoha sampajaññam veditabbam mūla pariññā vasena tāva  dassanam sampaṭicchanam
translated: As the full understanding of the root, it is as follows:🔽The life-continuum, the adverting, Seeing, receiving, and then,

original: Santīraṇaṃ voṭṭhabbanaṃ, javanaṃ bhavati sattamaṃ”.
analyzed: santīraṇam voṭṭhabbanam javanam bhavati sattamam
translated: Investigating, determining, and impulsion, which is the seventh.

original: Tattha bhavaṅgaṃ upapattibhavassa aṅgakiccaṃ sādhayamānaṃ pavattati, taṃ āvaṭṭetvā
analyzed: tattha bhavaṅgam upapatti bhavassa aṅga kiccam sādhayamānam pavattati tam āvaṭṭetvā
translated: Herein, the life-continuum occurs accomplishing the function of a link in the continuity of becoming. It is followed by

original: kiriyamanodhātu āvajjanakiccaṃ sādhayamānā, tannirodhā cakkhuviññāṇaṃ dassanakiccaṃ
analyzed: kiriya manaḥ dhātu āvajjana kiccam sādhayamānā tad nirodhā cakkhu viññāṇam dassana kiccam
translated: the functional mind element, which accomplishes the function of adverting. With its cessation, eye-consciousness arises accomplishing the function of seeing.

original: sādhayamānaṃ, tannirodhā vipākamanodhātu sampaṭicchanakiccaṃ sādhayamānā, tannirodhā
analyzed: sādhayamānam tad nirodhā vipāka manaḥ dhātu sampaṭicchana kiccam sādhayamānā tad nirodhā
translated: With its cessation, resultant mind element accomplishes the function of receiving. With its cessation,

original: vipākamanoviññāṇadhātu santīraṇakiccaṃ sādhayamānā, tannirodhā kiriyamanoviññāṇadhātu
analyzed: vipāka manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu santīraṇa kiccam sādhayamānā tad nirodhā kiriya manaḥ viññāṇa dhātu
translated: resultant mind-consciousness element accomplishes the function of investigating. With its cessation, the functional mind-consciousness element accomplishes the function of determining.

original: voṭṭhabbanakiccaṃ sādhayamānā, tannirodhā sattakkhattuṃ javanaṃ javati. Tattha paṭhamajavanepi
analyzed: voṭṭhabbana kiccam sādhayamānā tad nirodhā satta kkhattum javanam javati tattha paṭhama javane pi
translated: Herein, in the first impulsion

original: “ayaṃ itthī, ayaṃ puriso”ti rajjanadussanamuyhanavasena ālokitavilokitaṃ na hoti,
analyzed: ayam itthī ayam purisaḥ ti rajjana dussana muyhana vasena ālokita vilokitam na hoti
translated: there is no looking and so on with lust, hate, or delusion, thinking “This is a woman,” “This is a man.”

original: dutiyajavanepi…pe… sattamajavanepi. Etesu pana yuddhamaṇḍale yodhesu viya heṭṭhupariyavasena
analyzed: sattama javane pi etesu pana yuddha maṇḍale yodhesu viya heṭṭhu pariya vasena
translated: In the second impulsion … In the seventh impulsion …

original: bhijjitvā patitesu “ayaṃ itthī, ayaṃ puriso”ti rajjanādivasena ālokitavilokitaṃ hoti.
analyzed: bhijjitvā patitesu ayam itthī ayam puriso ti rajjana ādi vasena ālokita vilokitam hoti
translated: But when they have broken up and fallen like warriors in a battle, then looking and so on with lust, etc., occurs, thinking “This is a woman,” “This is a man.”

original: Evaṃ tāvettha mūlapariññāvasena asammohasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Cakkhudvāre pana rūpe āpāthamāgate bhavaṅgacalanato uddhaṃ sakakiccanipphādanavasena
analyzed: evam tāva ittha mūla pariññā vasena asammoha sampajaññam veditabbam  cakkhu dvāre pana rūpe āpātham āgate bhavaṅga calanato uddham saka kicca nipphādana vasena
translated: This, in the first place, is how non-delusion should be understood here as knowledge of the way to abandon.🔽But when a visible datum has come into the eye’s focus, after the wavering of the life-continuum,

original: āvajjanādīsu uppajjitvā niruddhesu avasāne javanaṃ uppajjati, taṃ pubbe uppannānaṃ
analyzed: āvajjana ādīsu uppajjitvā niruddhesu avasāne javanam uppajjati tam pubbe uppannānam
translated: impulsion arises at the end of the occurrence of the kinds of consciousness beginning with adverting, which have arisen and ceased accomplishing their own particular functions.🔽That impulsion is like a visitor in the eye door, the life-continuum’s abode,

original: āvajjanādīnaṃ gehabhūte cakkhudvāre āgantukapuriso viya hoti. Tassa yathā paragehe
analyzed: āvajjana ādīnam geha bhūte cakkhu dvāre āgantuka purisaḥ viya hoti tassa yathā para gehe
translated: which is like a house.

original: kiñci yācituṃ paviṭṭhassa āgantukapurisassa gehasāmikesu tuṇhīmāsinesu āṇākaraṇaṃ🔽na yuttaṃ, evaṃ āvajjanādīnaṃ gehabhūte cakkhudvāre āvajjanādīsupi arajjantesu adussantesu
analyzed: kiñci yācitum paviṭṭhassa āgantuka purisassa geha sāmikesu tuṇhī māsinesu āṇākaraṇam  na yuttam evam āvajjana ādīnam geha bhūte cakkhu dvāre āvajjana ādīsu pi a rajjantesu a dussantesu
translated: It is not proper for the householder to give orders to a guest who has come to ask for something while the householders remain silent.🔽So too, it is not proper for the act of looking, etc., to be greedy, hate-ridden, and deluded, when the eye, which is the physical basis for the act of looking, etc., is not greedy, hate-ridden, and deluded.

original: amuyhantesu ca rajjanadussanamuyhanaṃ ayuttanti evaṃ āgantukabhāvavasena asammohasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: a muyhantesu ca rajjana dussana muyhanam ayuttan ti evam āgantuka bhāva vasena asammoha sampajaññam veditabbam
translated: Thus non-delusion in regard to the state of being a guest should be understood.

original: Yāni panetāni cakkhudvāre voṭṭhabbanapariyosānāni cittāni uppajjanti, tāni saddhiṃ
analyzed: yāni pana etāni cakkhu dvāre voṭṭhabbana pariyosānāni cittāni uppajjanti tāni saddhim
translated: The mind that arises in the eye door together with its associated states breaks up there itself,

original: sampayuttadhammehi tattha tattheva bhijjanti, aññamaññaṃ na passanti, ittarāni tāvakālikāni🔽honti. Tattha yathā ekasmiṃ ghare sabbesu mānusakesu matesu avasesassa ekassa taṅkhaṇaṃyeva
analyzed: sampayutta dhammehi tattha tattha iva bhijjanti aññam aññam na passanti ittarāni tāvakālikāni  honti tattha yathā ekasmin ghare sabbesu mānusakesu matesu avasesassa ekassa
translated: and the other minds do not see it. They are momentary, temporary.🔽Just as in a house where all the human beings have died, it is not proper for a ghost that is about to die at that very moment to enjoy dancing, singing, etc.,

original: maraṇadhammassa na yuttā naccagītādīsu abhirati nāma, evameva ekadvāre sasampayuttesu
analyzed: maraṇa dhammassa na yuttā nacca gīta ādīsu abhirati nāma evam eva eka dvāre sa sampayuttesu
translated: so too, in the case of the eye door, it is not proper for the mind that is associated with its associated states

original: āvajjanādīsu tattha tattheva matesu avasesassa taṅkhaṇaṃyeva maraṇadhammassa javanassāpi
analyzed: āvajjana ādīsu tattha tattha iva matesu avasesassa maraṇa dhammassa javanassa api
translated: and the rest of the impulsions that occur in the same moment as the death consciousness, which is called “death” .

original: rajjanadussanamuyhanavasena abhirati nāma na yuttāti evaṃ tāvakālikabhāvavasena asammohasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Apica khandhāyatanadhātupaccayapaccavekkhaṇavasenapetaṃ veditabbaṃ. Ettha hi cakkhu
analyzed: rajjana dussana muyhana vasena abhirati nāma na yuttā ati evam tāvakālika bhāva vasena asammoha sampajaññam veditabbam  apica khandha āyatana dhātu paccaya paccavekkhaṇa vasena apetam veditabbam ettha hi cakkhu
translated: But there is no delight in the impulsion that occurs in the same moment as the death consciousness, since it is the cause of the cutting off of the continuity of aggregates. So this is how non-delusion should be understood as knowledge of the right and wrong occasion.

original: ceva rūpā ca rūpakkhandho, dassanaṃ viññāṇakkhandho, taṃsampayuttā vedanā vedanākkhandho,🔽saññā saññākkhandho, phassādikā saṅkhārā saṅkhārakkhandho, evametesaṃ pañcannaṃ khandhānaṃ
analyzed: ca iva rūpā ca rūpa kkhandho dassanam viññāṇa kkhandho tad sampayuttā vedanā vedanā kkhandho  saññā saññā kkhandho phassa ādikā saṅkhārā saṅkhāra kkhandho evam etesam pañcannam khandhānam
translated: Besides, it should be understood as the reviewing of the aggregates, bases, and elements, and of conditions. For here the eye and the visible data are the form aggregate, seeing is the consciousness aggregate, feeling is the feeling aggregate,🔽perception is the perception aggregate, and the associated formations are the formations aggregate.

original: samavāye ālokanavilokanaṃ paññāyati. Tattha ko eko āloketi, ko viloketi? Tathā cakkhu
analyzed: samavāye ālokana vilokanam paññāyati tattha kaḥ ekaḥ āloketi kaḥ viloketi tathā cakkhu
translated: So when there is a combination of these five aggregates, looking straight on and looking away are evident. Here, who is it that looks straight on? Who looks away? Likewise, the eye is the eye base, visible data are the form base, seeing is the mind base,

original: cakkhāyatanaṃ, rūpaṃ rūpāyatanaṃ, dassanaṃ manāyatanaṃ, vedanādayo sampayuttadhammā
analyzed: cakkha āyatanam rūpam rūpa āyatanam dassanam manā āyatanam vedanā ādayo sampayutta dhammā
translated: and feeling, etc., are the mental-data base.

original: dhammāyatanaṃ, evametesaṃ catunnaṃ āyatanānaṃ samavāye ālokanavilokanaṃ paññāyati.🔽Tattha ko eko āloketi, ko viloketi? Tathā cakkhu cakkhudhātu, rūpaṃ rūpadhātu, dassanaṃ
analyzed: dhammāyatanam evam etesam catunnam āyatanānam samavāye ālokana vilokanam paññāyati  tattha kaḥ ekaḥ āloketi kaḥ viloketi tathā cakkhu cakkhu dhātu rūpam rūpa dhātu dassanam
translated: So it is by the concurrence of these four bases that looking straight on and looking away are manifested.

original: cakkhuviññāṇadhātu, taṃsampayuttā vedanādayo dhammā dhammadhātu, evametesaṃ catunnaṃ🔽dhātūnaṃ samavāye ālokanavilokanaṃ paññāyati. Tattha ko eko āloketi, ko viloketi?
analyzed: cakkhu viññāṇa dhātu tad sampayuttāḥ vedanā ādayaḥ dhammāḥ dhamma dhātu evam etesam catunnam  dhātūnam samavāye ālokana vilokanam paññāyati tattha kaḥ ekaḥ āloketi kaḥ viloketi
translated: Herein, who is it that looks straight on and who that looks away? The eye is the eye element, the visible data are the form element, seeing is the eye-consciousness element, and the associated feeling, etc., are the mental-data element. So it is by the concurrence of these four elements that looking straight on and looking away are manifested. Herein, who is it that looks straight on and who that looks away?

original: Tathā cakkhu nissayapaccayo, rūpaṃ ārammaṇapaccayo, āvajjanaṃ anantarasamanantarūpanissayanatthivigatapaccayo,🔽āloko upanissayapaccayo, vedanādayo sahajātapaccayo. Evametesaṃ paccayānaṃ samavāye
analyzed: tathā cakkhu nissaya paccayaḥ rūpam ārammaṇa paccayaḥ āvajjanam anantara samananta rūpa nissaya natthi vigata paccayaḥ  ālokaḥ upanissaya paccayaḥ vedanā ādayo sahajāta paccayaḥ evam etesam paccayānam samavāye
translated: The eye is the support condition, the visible data are the object condition, adverting is the proximity, contiguity, decisive-support, absence, disappearance conditions,🔽light is the decisive-support condition, feeling, etc., are the conascence condition. So it is by the concurrence of these conditions that looking straight on and looking away are manifested. Herein, who is it that looks straight on and who that looks away?

original: ālokanavilokanaṃ paññāyati. Tattha ko eko āloketi, ko viloketīti evamettha khandhāyatanadhātupaccayapaccavekkhaṇavasenapi🔽asammohasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: ālokana vilokanam paññāyati tattha kaḥ ekaḥ āloketi kaḥ viloketi iti evam ettha khandha āyatana dhātu paccaya paccavekkhaṇa vasena pi 🔽a sammoha sampajaññam veditabbam
translated: So here too the kinds of clear comprehension should be understood as four, that is to say, as clear comprehension of the physical frame, of the four elements, of the six bases, and of conditions.

original: Samiñjite pasāriteti pabbānaṃ samiñjanapasāraṇe. Tattha cittavaseneva samiñjanapasāraṇaṃ
analyzed: samiñjite pasāritā iti pabbānam samiñjana pasāraṇe tattha citta vasena iva samiñjana pasāraṇam
translated: In the flexing and extending of the knees: in the flexing and extending of the thighs. Herein, the flexing and extending are due to the mind.

original: akatvā hatthapādānaṃ samiñjanapasāraṇapaccayā atthānatthaṃ pariggaṇhitvā atthapariggaṇhanaṃ
analyzed: a katvā hattha pādānam samiñjana pasāraṇa paccayā attha anattham pariggaṇhitvā attha pariggaṇhanam
translated: In flexing and extending: in the flexing and extending of the limbs. Herein, the discerning of the useful is the discerning of the useful as a condition for the flexing and extending of the limbs, not for the flexing and extending by mere movement of the mind.

original: sātthakasampajaññaṃ. Tattha hatthapāde aticiraṃ samiñjitvā vā pasāretvā vā ṭhitassa🔽khaṇe khaṇe vedanā uppajjanti, cittaṃ ekaggaṃ na labhati, kammaṭṭhānaṃ paripatati,
analyzed: sātthaka sampajaññam tattha hattha pāde aticiram samiñjitvā vā pasāretvā vā ṭhitassa  khaṇe khaṇe vedanāḥ uppajjanti cittam ekaggam na labhati kammaṭṭhānam paripatati
translated: For when one stands with the limbs too flexed or too extended,🔽pain arises every moment and the mind does not become concentrated, the meditation subject does not come to growth, increase and fulfilment,

original: visesaṃ nādhigacchati. Kāle samiñjantassa kāle pasārentassa pana tā vedanā nuppajjanti,
analyzed: visesam na adhigacchati kāle samiñjantassa kāle pasārentassa pana tāḥ vedanāḥ nuppajjanti
translated: but when one stands with the limbs neither too flexed nor too extended, no such pain arises,

original: cittaṃ ekaggaṃ hoti, kammaṭṭhānaṃ phātiṃ gacchati, visesamadhigacchatīti evaṃ atthānatthapariggaṇhanaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: cittam ekaggam hoti kammaṭṭhānam phātim gacchati visesam adhigacchati iti evam attha anattha pariggaṇhanam veditabbam
translated: the mind becomes concentrated, the meditation subject comes to growth, increase and fulfilment. So this is how the discerning of the useful should be understood.

original: Atthe pana satipi sappāyāsappāyaṃ pariggaṇhitvā sappāyapariggaṇhanaṃ sappāyasampajaññaṃ.
analyzed: atthe pana sati pi sappāya a sappāyam pariggaṇhitvā sappāya pariggaṇhanam sappāya sampajaññam
translated: But when there is the useful, the discerning of what is suitable and unsuitable as a condition for that should be understood as the knowledge of what is suitable.

original: Tatrāyaṃ nayo – mahācetiyaṅgaṇe kira daharabhikkhū sajjhāyaṃ gaṇhanti. Tesaṃ piṭṭhipasse🔽daharabhikkhuniyo dhammaṃ suṇanti. Tattheko daharo hatthaṃ pasārento kāyasaṃsaggaṃ
analyzed: tatra ayam nayaḥ mahā cetiyaṅgaṇe kira dahara bhikkhū sajjhāyam gaṇhanti tesam piṭṭhi passe  dahara bhikkhuniyaḥ dhammam suṇanti tattha ekaḥ daharaḥ hattham pasārentaḥ kāya saṃsaggaṃ
translated: Here is the way in which it should be understood: It seems that young bhikkhus were reciting in the courtyard of the Great Relic Shrine.🔽Young bhikkhunīs were listening to the Dhamma behind them.🔽One young bhikkhu, while stretching his arm, made bodily contact with a bhikkhunī.

original: patvā teneva kāraṇena gihī jāto. Aparo bhikkhu pādaṃ pasārento aggimhi pasāresi,
analyzed: patvā tena iva kāraṇena gihī jātaḥ aparaḥ bhikkhu pādam pasārentaḥ aggimhi pasāresi
translated: He became a layman on account of that. Another bhikkhu stretched his foot in the fire.🔽His foot was burnt to the bone. Another stretched it in an ant-hill.

original: aṭṭhiṃ āhacca pādo jhāyi. Aparo vammike pasāresi, so āsīvisena daṭṭho. Aparo cīvarakuṭidaṇḍake
analyzed: aṭṭhim āhacca pādaḥ jhāyi aparaḥ vammike pasāresi saḥ āsīvisena daṭṭho aparo cīvara kuṭi daṇḍake
translated: He was bitten by a poisonous snake. Another stretched it on a bamboo pole for a robe-rack.

original: pasāresi, taṃ maṇisappo ḍaṃsi. Tasmā evarūpe asappāye apasāretvā sappāye pasāretabbaṃ.
analyzed: pasāresi tam maṇi sappaḥ tasmai evarūpe a sappāye a pasāretvā sappāye pasāretabbam
translated: A gem-snake bit him. So he should not stretch it in such unsuitable places but only in suitable places.

original: Idamettha sappāyasampajaññaṃ.
analyzed: idam ettha sappāya sampajaññam
translated: This is the clear comprehension of suitability here.

original: Gocarasampajaññaṃ pana mahātheravatthunā dīpetabbaṃ – mahāthero kira divāṭṭhāne nisinno
analyzed: gocara sampajaññam pana mahā thera vatthunā dīpetabbam mahā theraḥ kira divāṭṭhāne nisinnaḥ
translated: But the clear comprehension of resort should be illustrated by the story of the Elder Maha Tissa. The elder was sitting in the day-time lodging.

original: antevāsikehi saddhiṃ kathayamāno sahasā hatthaṃ samiñjitvā puna yathāṭhāne ṭhapetvā
analyzed: antevāsikehi saddhim kathayamānaḥ sahasā hattham samiñjitvā puna yathāṭhāne ṭhapetvā
translated: While he was talking with his pupils he suddenly contracted his hand and then put it back in its place.

original: saṇikaṃ samiñjesi. Taṃ antevāsikā pucchiṃsu – “kasmā, bhante, sahasā hatthaṃ samiñjitvā🔽puna yathāṭhāne ṭhapetvā saṇikaṃ samiñjitthā”ti. Yato paṭṭhāyāhaṃ, āvuso, kammaṭṭhānaṃ🔽manasikātuṃ āraddho, na me kammaṭṭhānaṃ muñcitvā hattho samiñjitapubbo, idāni pana🔽tumhehi saddhiṃ kathayamānena kammaṭṭhānaṃ muñcitvā samiñjito, tasmā puna yathāṭhāne
analyzed: saṇikam samiñjesi tam antevāsikā pucchiṃsu kasmai bhante sahasā hattham samiñjitvā  puna yathāṭhāne ṭhapetvā saṇikam samiñjittha ati yatas paṭṭhāya aham āvuso kammaṭṭhānam  manasikātum āraddhaḥ na me kammaṭṭhānam muñcitvā hatthaḥ samiñjita pubbaḥ idāni pana  tumhehi saddhim kathayamānena kammaṭṭhānam muñcitvā tasmai puna yathāṭhāne
translated: and slowly drew it in. His pupils asked him, “Why did you suddenly draw in your hand,🔽and then put it back as it was and slowly draw it in again?” “Since I began to🔽attend to the meditation subject, friends, I have never drawn in my hand without first releasing the meditation subject. But now, while I was talking with you, I🔽released the meditation subject and drew in my hand. Therefore I put it back as🔽it was and slowly drew it in again.”🔽

original: ṭhapetvā samiñjesinti. Sādhu, bhante, bhikkhunā nāma evarūpena bhavitabbanti. Evametthāpi🔽kammaṭṭhānāvijahanameva gocarasampajaññanti veditabbaṃ.🔽Abbhantare attā nāma koci samiñjanto vā pasārento vā natthi, vuttappakāracittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphārena
analyzed: ṭhapetvā samiñjesinti sādhu bhante bhikkhunā nāma evarūpena bhavitabbanti evam ettha api  kammaṭṭhāna avijahanam eva gocara sampajaññam ti veditabbam  abbhantare attā nāma koci samiñjantaḥ vā pasārentaḥ vā natthi vutta ppakāra citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphārena
translated: He drew it in slowly. His pupils asked him, “Why, venerable sir, did you draw in your hand quickly and then draw it in slowly after putting it back in its former place?” “Friends, since I began to give attention to the meditation subject, I have not drawn in my hand without first giving up my meditation subject. But now, while talking with you, I gave up my meditation subject and drew it in. That is why I put it back in its former place and drew it in again. ” “It is good, venerable sir, that a bhikkhu should be like this. ” So here too it should be understood that the meditation subject is not to be given up even in such a case.

original: pana suttākaḍḍhanavasena dāruyantassa hatthapādalaḷanaṃ viya samiñjanapasāraṇaṃ hotīti
analyzed: pana sutta ākaḍḍhana vasena dāruyantassa hattha pāda laḷanam viya samiñjana pasāraṇam hoti iti
translated: There is no such thing as a self or soul that draws in or extends the hand. But owing to the diffusion of the air element in the way already described, the drawing in and extending of the hand occurs like the drawing in and extending of the arm of a machine.

original: parijānanaṃ panettha asammohasampajaññanti veditabbaṃ.🔽Saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇeti ettha saṅghāṭicīvarānaṃ nivāsanapārupanavasena, pattassa
analyzed: parijānanam pana ittha asammoha sampajaññan ti veditabbam  saṅghāṭi patta cīvara dhāraṇā iti ettha saṅghāṭi cīvarānam nivāsana pārupana vasena pattassa
translated: And the understanding of these should be understood as clear comprehension of non-delusion.🔽As to the wearing of the triple robe and bowl-bag: the use of the triple robe is by way of wearing the upper robe and the waist-band, and the use of the bowl-bag is by way of taking the bowl.

original: bhikkhāpaṭiggahaṇādivasena paribhogo dhāraṇaṃ nāma. Tattha saṅghāṭicīvaradhāraṇe🔽tāva nivāsetvā pārupitvā ca piṇḍāya carato āmisalābho, “sītassa paṭighātāyā”tiādinā
analyzed: bhikkhā paṭiggahaṇa ādi vasena paribhogaḥ dhāraṇam nāma tattha saṅghāṭi cīvara dhāraṇe  tāva nivāsetvā ca piṇḍāya carataḥ āmisa lābho sītassa paṭighātāya ati ādinā
translated: Herein, the wearing of the triple robe is called “use” in the sense of using it by wearing it.🔽And the meaning stated by the Blessed One thus, “For the warding off of cold, for the warding off of heat,” and so on, is the meaning in this case.

original: nayena bhagavatā vuttappakāroyeva ca attho attho nāma. Tassa vasena sātthakasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Uṇhapakatikassa pana dubbalassa ca cīvaraṃ sukhumaṃ sappāyaṃ, sītālukassa ghanaṃ🔽dupaṭṭaṃ. Viparītaṃ asappāyaṃ. Yassa kassaci jiṇṇaṃ asappāyameva. Aggaḷādidānena
analyzed: nayena bhagavatā vutta ppakārā yā iva ca atthaḥ atthaḥ nāma tassa vasena sa atthaka sampajaññam veditabbam  uṇha pakatikassa pana dubbalassa ca cīvaram sukhumam sappāyam sītālukassa ghanam  dupaṭṭam viparītam asappāyam yassa kassaci jiṇṇam asappāyam eva aggaḷa ādi dānena
translated: Clear comprehension of meaning should be understood as the understanding of this meaning.🔽But a thin robe is suitable for one of hot temperament and one who is strong,🔽and a thick robe is suitable for one of cold temperament and one who is weak. The opposite is unsuitable. Any that is torn is unsuitable. And if it is given with a button-loop for the neck or with a button-loop at the side, it is an impediment.

original: hissa taṃ palibodhakaraṃ hoti. Tathā paṭṭuṇṇadukūlādibhedaṃ lobhanīyacīvaraṃ. Tādisañhi
analyzed: hissa tam palibodha karam hoti tathā paṭṭuṇṇa dukūla ādi bhedam lobhanīya cīvaram tādisam hi
translated: So too, a robe that is eye-catching, such as one of fine material of the kind called “woven by ghosts,”

original: araññe ekakassa nivāsantarāyakaraṃ, jīvitantarāyakarañcāpi hoti. Nippariyāyena pana🔽yaṃ nimittakammādimicchājīvavasena uppannaṃ, yañcassa sevamānassa akusalā dhammā
analyzed: araññe ekakassa nivāsa antarāya karam jīvita antarāya karam ca api hoti nippariyāyena pana  yam nimitta kamma ādim icchājīva vasena uppannam yam ca assa sevamānassa akusalāḥ dhammāḥ
translated: But in the ultimate sense,

original: abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, taṃ asappāyaṃ. Viparītaṃ sappāyaṃ, tassa
analyzed: abhivaḍḍhanti kusalāḥ dhammāḥ parihāyanti tam a sappāyam viparītam sa ppāyam tassa
translated: what is unbeneficial is that which arises by means of the wrong means of livelihood consisting in hinting, etc., and by means of wrong knowledge and wrong deliverance, and which causes unwholesome states to increase and wholesome states to diminish when given attention. The opposite of that is beneficial.

original: vasenettha sappāyasampajaññaṃ, kammaṭṭhānāvijahanavaseneva ca gocarasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: vasena ittha sappāya sampajaññam kammaṭṭhāna avijahana vasena iva ca gocara sampajaññam veditabbam
translated: Herein, the knowledge of what is beneficial should be understood as the knowledge of what is beneficial in the sense of that, and the knowledge of resorts as the knowledge of resorts in the sense of that.🔽There is no self at all inside that puts on a robe.

original: Abbhantare attā nāma koci cīvaraṃ pārupanto natthi, vuttappakāracittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphāreneva🔽pana cīvarapārupanaṃ hoti. Tattha cīvarampi acetanaṃ, kāyopi acetano. Cīvaraṃ na
analyzed: abbhantare attā nāma koci cīvaram pārupantaḥ natthi vutta ppakāra citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphārena iva  pana cīvara pārupanam hoti tattha cīvaram pi acetanam kāyaḥ api acetanaḥ cīvaram na
translated: But it is only by the diffusion of the air element that there is the putting on of a robe.

original: jānāti “mayā kāyo pārupito”ti. Kāyopi na jānāti “ahaṃ cīvarena pārupito”ti. Dhātuyova
analyzed: jānāti mayā kāyaḥ pārupitaḥ iti kāyaḥ api na jānāti aham cīvarena pārupitaḥ iti
translated: Herein, the robe is without thought, the body is without thought, the robe does not know “A robe is worn by me,” the body does not know “I am clothed in a robe.”

original: dhātusamūhaṃ paṭicchādenti paṭapilotikāya potthakarūpapaṭicchādane viya. Tasmā neva
analyzed: dhātu samūham paṭicchādenti paṭa pilotikāya potthaka rūpa paṭicchādane tasmā na iva
translated: It is only the elements that cover the collection of elements, as a piece of cloth covers a piece of wood.

original: sundaraṃ cīvaraṃ labhitvā somanassaṃ kātabbaṃ, na asundaraṃ labhitvā domanassaṃ.
analyzed: sundaram cīvaram labhitvā somanassam kātabbam na a sundaram labhitvā domanassam
translated: When he gets a fine robe, he should be glad, not displeased if he gets an inferior one.

original: Nāgavammikacetiyarukkhādīsu hi keci mālāgandhadhūmavatthādīhi sakkāraṃ karonti, keci🔽gūthamuttakaddamadaṇḍasatthapahārādīhi asakkāraṃ. Na tehi nāgavammikarukkhādayo somanassaṃ
analyzed: nāga vammika cetiya rukkha ādīsu hi keci mālā gandha dhūma vattha ādīhi sakkāram karonti keci  gūtha muttaka ddama daṇḍa sattha pahāra ādīhi asakkāram na tehi nāga vammika rukkha ādayo somanassam
translated: For some people honor the ant-hill, the tree, the shrine, etc., with garlands, scents, incense, etc.,🔽while others do not honor them in this way. But the ant-hill, the tree, etc., are not glad at being honored,

original: vā karonti domanassaṃ vā. Evamevaṃ neva sundaraṃ cīvaraṃ labhitvā somanassaṃ kātabbaṃ,
analyzed: vā karonti domanassam vai evam evam na iva sundaram cīvaram labhitvā somanassam kātabbam
translated: nor displeased at not being honored. So too, he should not be glad at getting a fine robe,

original: na asundaraṃ labhitvā domanassanti evaṃ pavattapaṭisaṅkhānavasenettha asammohasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Pattadhāraṇepi pattaṃ sahasāva aggahetvā – “imaṃ gahetvā piṇḍāya caramāno bhikkhaṃ
analyzed: na asundaram labhitvā domanassanti evam pavatta paṭisaṅkhāna vasena ittha asammoha sampajaññam veditabbam  patta dhāraṇe pi pattam sahasāva aggahetvā imam gahetvā piṇḍāya caramānaḥ bhikkham
translated: nor displeased at getting an inferior one. This is how he should understand the right reflection in this case.

original: labhissāmī”ti evaṃ pattaggahaṇapaccayā paṭilabhitabbaatthavasena sātthakasampajaññaṃ
analyzed: labhissāmi iti evam patta ggahaṇa paccayā paṭilabhitabba attha vasena sa atthaka sampajaññam
translated: When he takes the bowl in his hand, he should not do so suddenly, thinking, “I shall go to the village or town for alms with this” and thus make the bowl an object of attachment. He should understand it as useful only for the purpose of receiving alms.

original: veditabbaṃ. Kisadubbalasarīrassa pana garupatto asappāyo. Yassa kassaci catupañcagaṇṭhikāhato🔽dubbisodhanīyo asappāyova. Duddhotapatto hi na vaṭṭati, taṃ dhovantasseva cassa palibodho
analyzed: veditabbam kisa dubbala sarīrassa pana garu pattaḥ asappāyaḥ yassa kassaci catu pañca gaṇṭhikā hataḥ  dubbisodhanīyaḥ asappāyaḥ iva duddhota pattaḥ hi na vaṭṭati tam dhovantassa iva ca assa palibodhaḥ
translated: One that has four or five seams is difficult to wash clean, so it is unsuitable.🔽For one that has not been well washed is not allowable. And while he is washing it, he is hindered from his meditation subject.

original: hoti. Maṇivaṇṇapatto pana lobhanīyo cīvare vuttanayeneva asappāyo. Nimittakammādivasena
analyzed: hoti maṇi vaṇṇa patto pana lobhanīyaḥ cīvare vutta nayena iva asappāyaḥ nimitta kamma ādi vasena
translated: But a cloth of the color of gems is tempting, so it is unsuitable in the way already stated under robe-material.

original: laddho, pana yañcassa sevamānassa akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti, kusalā dhammā parihāyanti,
analyzed: laddhaḥ pana yat cassa sevamānassa akusalāḥ dhammāḥ abhivaḍḍhanti kusalāḥ dhammāḥ parihāyanti
translated: But if he gets one by way of a present, and by using it evil states increase in him and good states diminish,

original: ayaṃ ekantaasappāyova. Viparīto sappāyo. Tassa vasenettha sappāyasampajaññaṃ, kammaṭṭhānāvijahanavaseneva
analyzed: ayam ekanta asappāyaḥ iva viparīto sappāyo tassa vasena ittha sappāya sampajaññam kammaṭṭhāna avijahana vasena iva
translated: it is quite unsuitable. The opposite kind is suitable. And here the knowledge of what is suitable is to be understood as the knowledge of what is suitable in a resort by not abandoning the meditation subject,

original: ca gocarasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Abbhantare attā nāma koci pattaṃ gaṇhanto natthi, vuttappakāracittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphāreneva
analyzed: ca gocara sampajaññam veditabbam  abbhantare attā nāma koci pattam gaṇhantaḥ natthi vutta ppakāra citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphārena iva
translated: and the knowledge of what is suitable in provisions by not abandoning the right measure in eating.🔽There is no such thing as a self inside that takes the bowl.

original: pattaggahaṇaṃ nāma hoti. Tattha pattopi acetano, hatthāpi acetanā. Patto na jānāti
analyzed: patta gahaṇam nāma hoti tattha pattaḥ api acetanaḥ hatthā api acetanā pattaḥ na jānāti
translated: It is only by the diffusion of the wind element that there comes to be what is called “taking the bowl.” Herein, the bowl is without consciousness, the hand is without consciousness, the mind is without consciousness.

original: “ahaṃ hatthehi gahito”ti. Hatthāpi na jānanti “patto amhehi gahito”ti. Dhātuyova
analyzed: aham hatthehi gahito ti hatthā api na jānanti pattaḥ amhehi gahito ti dhātuyā uva
translated: “I have been seized by hands.” And the hands do not know, “A man has been seized by us.”

original: dhātusamūhaṃ gaṇhanti, saṇḍāsena aggivaṇṇapattaggahaṇe viyāti evaṃ pavattapaṭisaṅkhānavasenettha
analyzed: dhātu samūham gaṇhanti saṇḍāsena aggi vaṇṇa patta ggahaṇe viyā ti evam pavatta paṭisaṅkhāna vasena ittha
translated: It is only the elements that seize a collection of elements, just as a fire seizes a piece of wood.

original: asammohasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Apica yathā chinnahatthapāde vaṇamukhehi paggharitapubbalohitakimikule nīlamakkhikasamparikiṇṇe
analyzed: a sammoha sampajaññam veditabbam  apica yathā chinna hattha pāde vaṇa mukhehi paggharita pubba lohita kimi kule nīla makkhika samparikiṇṇe
translated: So the knowledge of non-delusion should be understood here as the reflection that occurs in this way.

original: anāthasālāya anāthamanusse disvā dayālukā purisā tesaṃ vaṇapaṭṭacoḷakāni ceva kapālādīhi
analyzed: anātha sālāya anātha manusse disvā dayālukā purisā tesam vaṇa paṭṭa coḷakāni ca iva kapāla ādīhi
translated: Moreover, when compassionate people see a helpless man in a public hospital ward with his limbs cut off, lying in his own excrement and urine, covered with maggots, and repulsive,🔽they bring him cloth bandages and medicines in vessels and so on.

original: bhesajjāni ca upanāmenti. Tattha coḷakānipi kesañci saṇhāni, kesañci thūlāni pāpuṇanti,
analyzed: bhesajjāni ca upanāmenti tattha coḷakāni pi kesañci saṇhāni kesañci thūlāni pāpuṇanti
translated: Then the bandages reach some with softness and some with roughness,

original: bhesajjakapālānipi kesañci susaṇṭhānāni, kesañci dussaṇṭhānāni pāpuṇanti, na te tattha🔽sumanā vā dummanā vā honti. Vaṇapaṭicchādanamatteneva hi coḷakena bhesajjapaṭiggahamatteneva
analyzed: bhesajja kapālāni pi kesañci su saṇṭhānāni kesañci dussaṇṭhānāni pāpuṇanti na te tattha 🔽su manāḥ vā dummanāḥ vā honti vaṇa paṭicchādana mattena iva hi coḷakena bhesajja paṭiggaha mattena iva
translated: and the vessels with the medicines reach some with good shapes and some with bad shapes, but they do not become pleased or displeased about that.🔽For the bandages are only for covering the wounds, and the medicines are only for taking.

original: ca kapālakena tesaṃ attho. Evameva yo bhikkhu vaṇacoḷakaṃ viya cīvaraṃ, bhesajjakapālakaṃ
analyzed: ca kapālakena tesam atthaḥ evam eva yaḥ bhikkhu vaṇa coḷakam viya cīvaram bhesajja kapālakam
translated: and the bowl is like the medicine-pot. So too, if a bhikkhu considers the robe as a wound-dressing, the bowl as a medicine-pot,

original: viya ca pattaṃ, kapāle bhesajjamiva ca patte laddhabhikkhaṃ sallakkheti. Ayaṃ saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe🔽asammohasampajaññena uttamasampajānakārīti veditabbo.
analyzed: viya ca pattam kapāle bhesajjam iva ca patte laddha bhikkham sallakkheti ayam saṅghāṭi patta cīvara dhāraṇe  asammoha sampajaññena uttama sampajāna kārī iti veditabbo
translated: and the alms food as medicine, he is one who carries out the highest form of clear comprehension in wearing the triple robe, carrying the bowl, and receiving alms food.

original: Asitādīsu asiteti piṇḍapātabhojane. Pīteti yāguādipāne. Khāyiteti piṭṭhakhajjakādikhādane.
analyzed: asita ādīsu asita iti piṇḍapāta bhojane pīta iti yāgu ādi pāne khāyita iti piṭṭhakhajjaka ādi khādane
translated: As to eating, etc., eating is eating staple foods such as a meal. Drinking is drinking beverages such as gruel. Chewing is chewing non-staple foods such as sugar-cane.

original: Sāyiteti madhuphāṇitādisāyane. Tattha “neva davāyā”tiādinā nayena vutto aṭṭhavidhopi
analyzed: sāyita iti madhu phāṇita ādi sāyane tattha na iva davāya ati ādinā nayena vutto aṭṭhavidhaḥ api
translated: Sucking is sucking sweet drinks such as honey and molasses. Herein, the eight kinds of meaning stated in the way beginning, “Not for fun, etc.,”

original: attho attho nāma, tassa vasena sātthakasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Lūkhapaṇītatittamadhurādīsu pana yena bhojanena yassa aphāsu hoti, taṃ tassa asappāyaṃ.
analyzed: atthaḥ atthaḥ nāma tassa vasena sa atthaka sampajaññam veditabbam  lūkha paṇīta titta madhura ādīsu pana yena bhojanena yassa hoti tam tassa asappāyam
translated: is what is called “meaning.” Comprehension of what is meaningful should be understood as the meaning of that.🔽But as regards coarseness, etc., the food that is unsuitable for one who finds it uncomfortable is unallowable for him.

original: Yaṃ pana nimittakammādivasena paṭiladdhaṃ, yañcassa bhuñjato akusalā dhammā abhivaḍḍhanti,
analyzed: yam pana nimitta kamma ādi vasena paṭiladdham yat ca assa bhuñjato akusalāḥ dhammāḥ abhivaḍḍhanti
translated: But that which is obtained by means of signs, etc., and which causes unwholesome states to increase in him when he eats it,

original: kusalā dhammā parihāyanti, taṃ ekantaasappāyameva. Viparītaṃ sappāyaṃ. Tassa vasenettha
analyzed: kusalāḥ dhammā parihāyanti tam ekanta a sappāyam eva viparītam sappāyam tassa vasena ittha
translated: and unwholesome states increase, then that is entirely unbeneficial. The opposite is beneficial.

original: sappāyasampajaññaṃ, kammaṭṭhānāvijahanavaseneva ca gocarasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: sa ppāya sampajaññam kammaṭṭhāna avijahana vasena iva ca gocara sampajaññam veditabbam
translated: Herein, the knowledge of what is beneficial should be understood as the knowledge of what is beneficial in the sense of the abandoning of the meditation subject.

original: Abbhantare attā nāma koci bhuñjako natthi, vuttappakāracittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphāreneva🔽pattapaṭiggahaṇaṃ nāma hoti, cittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphāreneva hatthassa patte otāraṇaṃ
analyzed: abbhantare attā nāma koci bhuñjakaḥ natthi vutta ppakāra citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphārena iva  patta paṭiggahaṇam nāma hoti citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphārena iva hatthassa patte otāraṇam
translated: There is no such thing as a self or soul inside that eats,🔽but it is by the diffusion of the air element that the act of receiving the mouthful is done;

original: nāma hoti, cittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphāreneva ālopakaraṇaṃ ālopuddharaṇaṃ mukhavivaraṇañca
analyzed: nāma hoti citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphārena iva āla upakaraṇam āla upuddharaṇam mukha vivaraṇam ca
translated: it is by the diffusion of the air element that the placing of the mouthful in the stomach is done;

original: hoti. Na koci kuñcikāya na yantakena hanukaṭṭhīni vivarati, cittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphāreneva
analyzed: hoti na koci kuñcikāya na yantakena hanu kaṭṭhīni citta kiriya vāyaḥ dhātu vipphārena iva
translated: it is by the diffusion of the air element that the opening of the mouth is done and the taking of the morsel and the swallowing. No one opens his jaw-bones with a key or with a pulley;

original: ālopassa mukhe ṭhapanaṃ uparidantānaṃ musalakiccasādhanaṃ heṭṭhādantānaṃ udukkhalakiccasādhanaṃ
analyzed: ālopassa mukhe ṭhapanam upari dantānam musala kicca sādhanam heṭṭhā dantānam udukkhala kicca sādhanam
translated: it is by the diffusion of the air element that the placing of the morsel in the mouth is done and the crushing by the upper row of teeth and the grinding by the lower row of teeth like pestles in a mortar

original: jivhāya hatthakiccasādhanañca hoti. Iti naṃ tattha aggajivhāya tanukakheḷo, mūlajivhāya
analyzed: jivhāya hattha kicca sādhanam ca hoti iti nam tattha agga jivhāya tanuka kheḷaḥ mūla jivhāya
translated: and the tongue performs the function of a hand. So the thin saliva is at the tip of the tongue,🔽and the thick saliva at the root of the tongue.

original: bahalakheḷo makkheti. Taṃ heṭṭhādantaudukkhale jivhāhatthaparivattitaṃ kheḷaudakatemitaṃ🔽uparidantamusalasañcuṇṇitaṃ koci kaṭacchunā vā dabbiyā vā anto pavesento nāma natthi,
analyzed: bahala kheḷaḥ makkheti tam heṭṭhā danta odukkhale jivhā hattha parivattitam kheḷa audaka temitam  upari danta musala sañcuṇṇitam koci kaṭacchunā vā dabbiyā vā antar pavesento nāma natthi
translated: The saliva is churned up by the tongue and hand in the lower jaw, and it is churned again🔽by the upper jaw, which is like a pestle. No one puts it in with a ladle or a spoon.

original: vāyodhātuyāva pavisati. Paviṭṭhaṃ paviṭṭhaṃ koci palālasantharaṃ katvā dhārento nāma🔽natthi, vāyodhātuvaseneva tiṭṭhati. Ṭhitaṃ ṭhitaṃ koci uddhanaṃ katvā aggiṃ jāletvā
analyzed: pavisati paviṭṭham paviṭṭham koci palāla santharam katvā dhārentaḥ nāma  natthi vāyo dhātu vasena iva tiṭṭhati ṭhitam ṭhitam koci uddhanam katvā aggim jāletvā
translated: It enters by means of the air element. No one spreads a bed of straw and puts it there,🔽for it remains by means of the air element. No one builds a furnace and lights a fire

original: pacanto nāma natthi, tejodhātuyāva paccati. Pakkaṃ pakkaṃ koci daṇḍakena vā yaṭṭhiyā
analyzed: pacantaḥ nāma natthi tejodhātuyā ava paccati pakkam pakkam koci daṇḍakena vā
translated: to cook it, for it cooks by means of the fire element. No one carries it out with a pole or a basket,

original: vā bahi nīharako nāma natthi, vāyodhātuyeva nīharati. Iti vāyodhātu atiharati ca
analyzed: vā bahi nīharakaḥ nāma natthi vāyodhātuyā iva nīharati iti vāyodhātu atiharati ca
translated: for the air element itself carries it out. So the air element carries it away,

original: vītiharati ca dhāreti ca parivatteti ca sañcuṇṇeti ca visoseti ca nīharati ca; pathavīdhātu
analyzed: vītiharati ca dhāreti ca parivatteti ca sañcuṇṇā iti ca visoseti ca nīharati ca pathavī dhātu
translated: carries it out, holds it, turns it over, grinds it, sorts it, and carries it out. The earth element

original: dhāreti ca parivatteti ca sañcuṇṇeti ca visoseti ca; āpodhātu sineheti ca allattañca
analyzed: dhārā iti ca parivattā iti ca sañcuṇṇā iti ca visosā iti ca āpodhātu sinehā iti ca allattam ca
translated: He keeps it, turns it over, grinds it up, mixes it, and the water element moistens it,

original: anupāleti; tejodhātu antopaviṭṭhaṃ paripāceti; ākāsadhātu añjaso hoti; viññāṇadhātu
analyzed: anupāleti tejaḥ dhātu anta upaviṭṭham paripāca iti ākāsa dhātu añjasas hoti viññāṇa dhātu
translated: and the fire element ripens it, and the air element moves it about, and the space element is its location, and the consciousness element is the mere condition for the occurrence of the elements.

original: tattha tattha sammāpayogamanvāya ābhujatīti evaṃ pavattapaṭisaṅkhānavasenettha asammohasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Apica gamanato, pariyesanato, paribhogato, āsayato, nidhānato, aparipakkato, paripakkato,🔽phalato, nissandato, sammakkhanatoti evaṃ dasavidhaṃ paṭikūlabhāvaṃ paccavekkhaṇatopettha
analyzed: tattha tattha sammā apayogam anvāya ābhujati iti evam pavatta paṭisaṅkhāna vasena ittha asammoha sampajaññam veditabbam  apica gamanato pariyesanato paribhogato āsayataḥ nidhānataḥ a paripakkato paripakkato  phalataḥ nissandataḥ sammakkhanataḥ ti evam dasavidham paṭikūla bhāvam paccavekkhaṇato upa ittha
translated: So he should advert to the elements in this way. The clear comprehension of non-delusion should be understood here in the way stated in the Description of the Mindfulness of Breathing .🔽Furthermore, the clear comprehension of non-delusion should be understood here in the way stated in the Description of the Contemplation of the Nine Cemetery Thoughts .

original: asammohasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ. Vitthārakathā panettha visuddhimagge āhārapaṭikūlasaññāniddesato gahetabbā.
analyzed: asammoha sampajaññam veditabbam vitthāra kathā pana ittha visuddhi magge āhāra paṭikūla saññā niddesato gahetabbā
translated: The detailed explanation should be understood according to the Description of the Contemplation of the Repulsiveness of Food .

original: Uccārapassāvakammeti uccārassa ca passāvassa ca karaṇe. Tattha pattakāle uccārapassāvaṃ
analyzed: uccāra passāva kamma iti uccārassa ca passāvassa ca karaṇe tattha patta kāle uccāra passāvam
translated: In the act of defecation and urination: at the time when it is proper to defecate and urinate.

original: akarontassa sakalasarīrato sedā muccanti, akkhīni bhamanti, cittaṃ na ekaggaṃ hoti,
analyzed: a karontassa sakala sarīrataḥ sedāḥ muccanti akkhīni bhamanti cittam na ekaggam hoti
translated: If he does not, sweat breaks out all over his body, his eyes roll, his mind becomes unbalanced,

original: aññe ca rogā uppajjanti. Karontassa pana sabbaṃ taṃ na hotīti ayamettha attho. Tassa
analyzed: aññe ca rogā uppajjanti karontassa pana sabbam tam na hoti iti ayam ettha attho tassa
translated: and other diseases arise. But if he does, none of this happens. This is the meaning here.

original: vasena sātthakasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ. Aṭṭhāne uccārapassāvaṃ karontassa pana āpatti🔽hoti, ayaso vaḍḍhati, jīvitantarāyopi hoti. Patirūpe ṭhāne karontassa sabbaṃ taṃ
analyzed: vasena sātthaka sampajaññam veditabbam aṭṭhāne uccāra passāvam karontassa pana āpatti  hoti ayasaḥ vaḍḍhati jīvita antarāyaḥ api hoti patirūpe ṭhāne karontassa sabbam tam
translated: Understanding of what is beneficial should be understood as the understanding of what is beneficial in this context. But if he defecates or urinates in an unsuitable place, he commits an offense.

original: na hotīti idamettha sappāyaṃ. Tassa vasena sappāyasampajaññaṃ, kammaṭṭhānāvijahanavasena🔽ca gocarasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Abbhantare attā nāma koci uccārapassāvakammaṃ karonto natthi, cittakiriyavāyodhātuvipphāreneva
analyzed: na hoti iti idam ettha sappāyam tassa vasena sappāya sampajaññam kammaṭṭhāna avijahana vasena  ca gocara sampajaññam veditabbam  abbhantare attā nāma koci uccāra passāva kammam karontaḥ natthi citta kiriya vāyodhātu vipphārena iva
translated: His disrepute increases, and there is even danger to life. But if he does it in a suitable place, none of this happens. This is the suitable in this context. Understanding of what is suitable should be understood as the understanding of what is suitable in this context, and understanding of the surrounding area should be understood as the understanding of the surrounding area in this context.

original: pana uccārapassāvakammaṃ hoti. Yathā pana pakke gaṇḍe gaṇḍabhedena pubbalohitaṃ akāmatāya
analyzed: pana uccāra passāva kammam hoti yathā pana pakke gaṇḍe gaṇḍa bhedena pubba lohitam a kāma tāya
translated: There is no self inside that defecates or urinates. It is just that the action of defecating or urinating comes about through the distension of the bowel and the bladder, and through the agency of the air element in the process of mental activity.🔽But when a boil has ripened, the pus and blood come out unwillingly.

original: nikkhamati, yathā ca atibharitā udakabhājanā udakaṃ akāmatāya nikkhamati, evaṃ pakkāsayamuttavatthīsu
analyzed: nikkhamati yathā ca ati bharitā udaka bhājanā udakam akāmatāya nikkhamati evam pakkāsaya mutta vatthīsu
translated: And just as water overflows from a vessel that is too full, so too, the receptacle of digested food and the receptacle of digested fluid,

original: sannicitā uccārapassāvā vāyuvegasamuppīḷitā akāmatāyapi nikkhamanti. So panāyaṃ evaṃ
analyzed: sannicitāḥ uccāra passāvāḥ vāyu vega samuppīḍitāḥ nikkhamanti saḥ pana ayam evam
translated: when they are full, force out the feces and urine, which then come out unwillingly, being pressed by the force of the winds.

original: nikkhamanto uccārapassāvo neva tassa bhikkhuno attano hoti na parassa, kevalaṃ sarīranissandova
analyzed: nikkhamantaḥ uccāra passāvaḥ na eva tassa bhikkhuno attanaḥ hoti na parassa kevalam sarīra nissandaḥ uva
translated: But this feces and urine, when they come out in this way, do not belong to anyone, either to the bhikkhu himself or to another; they are just a secretion of the body.

original: hoti. Yathā kiṃ? Yathā udakatumbato purāṇaudakaṃ chaḍḍentassa neva taṃ attano hoti🔽na paresaṃ, kevalaṃ paṭijagganamattameva hoti. Evaṃ pavattapaṭisaṅkhānavasenettha
analyzed: hoti yathā kim yathā udaka tumbataḥ purāṇa odakam chaḍḍentassa na iva tam hoti  na paresam kevalam paṭijaggana mattam eva hoti evam pavatta paṭisaṅkhāna vasena ittha
translated: How so? Just as when someone throws away old water from a water pot, the water does not belong to himself or to another; he just gets rid of it.

original: asammohasampajaññaṃ veditabbaṃ.🔽Gatādīsu gateti gamane. Ṭhiteti ṭhāne. Nisinneti nisajjāya. Sutteti sayane. Jāgarite
analyzed: a sammoha sampajaññam veditabbam  gata ādīsu gatā iti gamane ṭhitā iti ṭhāne nisinnā iti nisajjāya suttā iti sayane jāgarite
translated: So too, here the clear comprehension of non-delusion should be understood to be the state of mind that occurs in the mode of such reflection.🔽As to gone, etc., “gone” is in the past,🔽“standing” is in the present, “sitting” is in the present, “lying down” is in the present, “speaking” is in the present, “not speaking” is in the present, “waking” is in the present.

original: ti jāgaraṇe. Bhāsiteti kathane. Tuṇhībhāveti akathane. Ettha ca yo ciraṃ gantvā vā
analyzed: ti jāgaraṇe bhāsita iti kathane tuṇhībhāva iti a kathane ettha ca yaḥ ciram gantvā vā
translated: And here, when someone has gone a long way, or

original: caṅkamitvā vā aparabhāge ṭhito iti paṭisañcikkhati “caṅkamanakāle pavattā rūpārūpadhammā
analyzed: caṅkamitvā vā apara bhāge ṭhitaḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati caṅkamana kāle pavattāḥ rūpa arūpa dhammā
translated: or, if he is standing, he reflects thus: “The material and immaterial phenomena that occurred in me while I was walking,

original: ettheva niruddhā”ti, ayaṃ gate sampajānakārī nāma.🔽Yo sajjhāyaṃ vā karonto pañhaṃ vā vissajjento kammaṭṭhānaṃ vā manasikaronto ciraṃ
analyzed: etthā iva niruddhā ati ayam gate sampajānakārī nāma  yaḥ sajjhāyam vā karontaḥ pañham vā vissajjentaḥ kammaṭṭhānam vā manasikarontaḥ ciram
translated: Or else, after walking, he reflects thus when he has sat down: “The material and immaterial phenomena that occurred in me while I was walking have been stopped.” This bhikkhu is called one who is clearly aware of the postures.

original: ṭhatvā aparabhāge nisinno iti paṭisañcikkhati “ṭhitakāle pavattā rūpārūpadhammā ettheva🔽niruddhā”ti, ayaṃ ṭhite sampajānakārī nāma.🔽Yo sajjhāyādikaraṇavaseneva ciraṃ nisīditvā aparabhāge nipanno iti paṭisañcikkhati – “nisinnakāle pavattā rūpārūpadhammā ettheva niruddhā”ti, ayaṃ nisinne sampajānakārī nāma.🔽Yo pana nipannakova sajjhāyaṃ karonto kammaṭṭhānaṃ vā manasikaronto niddaṃ okkamitvā
analyzed: ṭhatvā apara bhāge nisinnaḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati ṭhita kāle pavattāḥ rūpa arūpa dhammāḥ ettha eva  ayam ṭhite sampajānakārī nāma  yaḥ sajjhāya ādi karaṇa vasena iva ciram nisīditvā apara bhāge nipannaḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati nisinna kāle pavattāḥ rūpa arūpa dhammāḥ ettha iva niruddhā ati ayam nisinne sampajānakārī nāma  yaḥ pana nipannakaḥ iva sajjhāyam karontaḥ kammaṭṭhānam vā manasikarontaḥ niddam okkamitvā
translated: Or else, after standing, he reflects thus when he has sat down: “The material and immaterial phenomena that occurred in me while I was standing have been stopped.” This bhikkhu is called one who is clearly aware of the postures.🔽Or else, after sitting, he reflects thus when he has lain down: “The material and immaterial phenomena that occurred in me while I was sitting have been stopped.” This bhikkhu is called one who is clearly aware of the postures.

original: aparabhāge uṭṭhāya iti paṭisañcikkhati – “sayanakāle pavattā rūpārūpadhammā ettheva
analyzed: aparabhāge uṭṭhāya iti paṭisañcikkhati sayana kāle pavattāḥ rūpa arūpa dhammāḥ ettha eva
translated: Or else, after reciting the Dhamma or after answering a question or after giving a discourse on the Dhamma, he reflects thus when he has lain down: “The material and immaterial phenomena that occurred in me while I was doing all this have been stopped.” This bhikkhu is called one who is clearly aware of the postures.

original: niruddhā”ti, ayaṃ sutte ca jāgarite ca sampajānakārī nāma. Kiriyamayacittānañhi appavattaṃ
analyzed: niruddhā ati ayam sutte ca jāgarite ca sampajāna kārī nāma kiriya maya cittānam hi appavattam
translated: “The past is ceased” is one who is fully aware both when he is awake and when he is working.

original: suttaṃ nāma, pavattaṃ jāgaritaṃ nāmāti.
analyzed: suttam nāma pavattam jāgaritam nāma ati
translated: “When I am asleep, they are ceased,” he is called one who is clearly aware of both sleep and wakefulness. For the non-occurrence of the functional consciousnesses is called sleep, and their occurrence is called wakefulness.

original: Yo pana bhāsamāno – “ayaṃ saddo nāma oṭṭhe ca paṭicca dante ca jivhañca tāluñca paṭicca
analyzed: yaḥ pana bhāsamānaḥ ayam saddaḥ nāma oṭṭhe ca paṭicca dante ca jivhañca tāluñca paṭicca
translated: But when one who is speaking is mindful and clearly aware that “This sound arises in dependence on the throat, lips, palate, teeth, and tongue,

original: cittassa ca tadanurūpaṃ payogaṃ paṭicca jāyatī”ti sato sampajāno bhāsati, ciraṃ vā
analyzed: cittassa ca tad anurūpam payogam paṭicca jāyati iti sataḥ sampajānaḥ bhāsati ciram vā
translated: and in dependence on the appropriate effort of consciousness,” and when he speaks for a long time,

original: pana kālaṃ sajjhāyaṃ katvā dhammaṃ vā kathetvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ vā parivattetvā pañhaṃ🔽vā vissajjetvā aparabhāge tuṇhībhūto iti paṭisañcikkhati “bhāsitakāle uppannā rūpārūpadhammā
analyzed: pana kālam sajjhāyam katvā dhammam vā kathetvā kammaṭṭhānam vā parivattetvā pañham  vā vissajjetvā apara bhāge tuṇhībhūtaḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati bhāsita kāle uppannāḥ rūpa arūpa dhammāḥ
translated: or when one who has recited a text for a long time, or has preached the Dhamma, or has gone over his meditation subject, or has answered a question,

original: ettheva niruddhā”ti ayaṃ bhāsite sampajānakārī nāma.
analyzed: etthā iva ayam bhāsite sampajānakārī nāma
translated: and afterwards, when he is silent, he reflects thus: “The material and immaterial phenomena that arose while I was speaking have ceased right there,” he is called one who is clearly aware of speech.

original: Yo tuṇhībhūto ciraṃ dhammaṃ vā kammaṭṭhānaṃ vā manasikatvā aparabhāge iti paṭisañcikkhati
analyzed: yaḥ tuṇhībhūtaḥ ciram dhammam vā kammaṭṭhānam vā manasikatvā aparabhāge iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: But when one who is silent reflects thus after giving attention for a long time to the Dhamma or to a meditation subject,

original: – “tuṇhībhūtakāle pavattā rūpārūpadhammā ettheva niruddhā”ti. Upādārūpapavattiyā
analyzed: tuṇhībhūta kāle pavattāḥ rūpa arūpa dhammāḥ ettha iva niruddhā ati upādā rūpa pavattiyā
translated: “The material and immaterial states occurring at the time of silence are only ceased here.”

original: sati bhāsati nāma, asati tuṇhī bhavati nāmāti, ayaṃ tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī nāmāti.
analyzed: sati bhāsati nāma asati tuṇhī bhavati nāma ati ayam tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī nāma ati
translated: When there is the occurrence of derivative materiality, he speaks; when there is not, he is silent. This is how he is “fully aware of the act of his silence.”

original: Evamettha asammohasampajaññaṃ tassa vasena sampajānakāritā veditabbā. Imasmiṃ sutte
analyzed: evam ettha asammoha sampajaññam tassa vasena sampajāna kāri tā veditabbā imasmim sutte
translated: Thus the clear comprehension of non-delusion should be understood here, and the act of clear comprehension by means of that. In this sutta

original: satipaṭṭhānamissakasampajaññaṃ pubbabhāgaṃ kathitaṃ.
analyzed: sati paṭṭhāna missaka sampajaññam pubbabhāgam kathitam
translated: the clear comprehension of the establishment of mindfulness is stated in the preliminary stage.

original: 3. Bhikkhusuttavaṇṇanā🔽369. Tatiye evameva panidhekacceti so kira bhikkhu kammaṭṭhānaṃ kathāpetvā ito cito
analyzed: bhikkhu sutta vaṇṇanā  tatiye evam eva panidhā ikacce iti so kira bhikkhu kammaṭṭhānam kathāpetvā itas citas
translated: The commentary on the Bhikkhu Sutta

original: ca āhiṇḍati, kāyavivekaṃ nānuyuñjati. Tena naṃ bhagavā niggaṇhanto evamāha. Tasmāti
analyzed: ca āhiṇḍati kāya vivekam na anuyuñjati tena nam bhagavā evam āha tasmā iti
translated: In the third sutta, “So too, bhikkhus, some bhikkhu here” : it seems that this bhikkhu, after having had the meditation subject expounded to him, wandered about here and there and did not apply himself to the seclusion of the body. The Blessed One, in order to restrain him, said thus. “Therefore”

original: yasmā saṃkhittena desanaṃ yācasi, tasmā. Diṭṭhīti kammassakatādiṭṭhi.
analyzed: yasmā saṃkhittena desanam yācasi tasmā diṭṭhī iti kammassaka tā diṭṭhi
translated: means: since you have asked for the teaching in brief, therefore. “View” means the view of the ownership of kamma, etc.

original: 4. Sālasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sāla sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Sāla Sutta

original: 370. Catutthe dhammavinayoti dhammoti vā vinayoti vā ubhayametaṃ satthusāsanasseva
analyzed: catutthe dhamma vinayo ti dhammo ti vā vinayo ti vā ubhayam etam satthu sāsanassa iva
translated: In the fourth sutta, “Dhamma and Discipline” : both “Dhamma” and “Discipline” are the

original: nāmaṃ. Samādapetabbāti gaṇhāpetabbā. Ekodibhūtāti khaṇikasamādhinā ekaggabhūtā. Samāhitā
analyzed: nāmam samādapetabbā ati gaṇhāpetabbā ekodibhūtā ati khaṇika samādhinā ekagga bhūtā samāhitā
translated: Name. Should be gladdened: should be made to take up. Single-minded: become one-pointed through momentary concentration.

original: ekaggacittāti upacārappanāvasena sammā ṭhapitacittā ca ekaggacittā ca. Imasmiṃ sutte
analyzed: ekagga cittā ti upacāra ppanā vasena sammā ṭhapita cittā ca ekagga cittā ca imasmin sutte
translated: Concentrated: their minds well steadied through access and absorption concentration. Single-minded: their minds one-pointed. In this sutta

original: navakabhikkhūhi ceva khīṇāsavehi ca bhāvitasatipaṭṭhānā pubbabhāgā, sattahi sekhehi bhāvitā missakā.
analyzed: navaka bhikkhūhi ca iva khīṇāsavehi ca bhāvita sati paṭṭhānā pubbabhāgā sattahi sekhehi bhāvitā missakā
translated: the newly ordained bhikkhus and those with cankers destroyed have developed the foundations of mindfulness in the preliminary part of the path, while the seven in training have developed them in the mixed part.

original: 6. Sakuṇagghisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sakuṇagghi sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary on the Sakuṇagghi Sutta

original: 372. Chaṭṭhe sakuṇagghīti sakuṇaṃ hanatīti sakuṇagghi, senassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Sahasā
analyzed: chaṭṭhe sakuṇagghi iti sakuṇam hanati iti sakuṇagghi senassa itam adhivacanam sahasā
translated: In the sixth sutta, the word sakuṇagghi is a compound of sakuṇa and agghi. The word agghi is a synonym for sena .

original: ajjhapattāti lobhasāhasena pattā. Alakkhikāti nissirikā. Appapuññāti parittapuññā.🔽Sacejja mayanti sace ajja mayaṃ. Naṅgalakaṭṭhakaraṇanti naṅgalena kasikaraṇaṃ, adhunā
analyzed: ajjhapattā ati lobha sāhasena pattā alakkhikā ati nissirikā appa puññā ati paritta puññā  saced ijja mayanti sace ajja mayam naṅgala kaṭṭha karaṇanti naṅgalena kasi karaṇam adhunā
translated: They have fallen into misfortune: they have fallen into misfortune through the misfortune of greed. They are not thrifty: they are not economical. They have little merit: they have small merit.

original: kaṭṭhaṃ khettaṭṭhānanti attho. Leḍḍuṭṭhānanti leḍḍūnaṃ ṭhānaṃ. Saṃvadamānāti sammā
analyzed: kaṭṭham khetta ṭṭhānanti atthaḥ leḍḍu ṭṭhānanti leḍḍūnam ṭhānam saṃvadamānā ati sammā
translated: If today: if today we. Ploughing with the plough: ploughing with the plough. Now the meaning is: the place for the field. A place for clods: a place for clods. They are quarrelling: they are arguing.

original: vadamānā, attano balassa suṭṭhu vaṇṇaṃ vadamānāti attho. Mahantaṃ leḍḍuṃ abhiruhitvāti
analyzed: vadamānā attanaḥ balassa suṭṭhu vaṇṇam vadamānā ati atthaḥ mahantam leḍḍum abhiruhitvā ati
translated: She was speaking of herself, of her own strength. She climbed up a great rock:

original: uddhanasaṇṭhānena ṭhitesu tīsu leḍḍūsu “ito sene āgacchante ito nikkhamissāmi, ito
analyzed: uddhana saṇṭhānena ṭhitesu tīsu leḍḍūsu itas sene āgacchante itas nikkhamissāmi itas
translated: she stood on three rocks placed one above the other, thinking: “When the army comes from this side, I will go from this side;

original: āgacchante ito”ti sallakkhetvā tesu ekaṃ leḍḍuṃ abhiruhitvā aṭṭhāsi avadamāno. Sannayhāti
analyzed: āgacchante itoti sallakkhetvā tesu ekam leḍḍum abhiruhitvā aṭṭhāsi a vadamāno sannayhā iti
translated: when it comes from this side, I will go from this side.” She stood on one of the rocks, not speaking. She fixed her bow:

original: khurappaṃ sannayhamāno viya sannayhitvā suṭṭhu ṭhapetvā. Bahuāgato kho myāyanti “mayhaṃ
analyzed: khurappam sannayhamānaḥ viya sannayhitvā suṭṭhu ṭhapetvā bahu āgataḥ kho myāyanti mayham
translated: she fixed it as if she were fixing an arrow, she placed it well. “He has come a long way”:

original: atthāya ayaṃ bahutaṃ ṭhānaṃ āgato, appaṃ avasiṭṭhaṃ, idāni maṃ gaṇhissatī”ti ñatvā
analyzed: atthāya ayam bahutam ṭhānam āgataḥ appam avasiṭṭham idāni mam gaṇhissati iti ñatvā
translated: she thought: “He has come a long way for my sake; little is left for him; now he will seize me.”

original: dāruguḷo viya vinivattitvā tasseva leḍḍussa antare paccupādi, paṭipanno paviṭṭhoti
analyzed: dāru guḷaḥ viya vinivattitvā tassa iva leḍḍussa antare paccupādi paṭipanno paviṭṭho ti
translated: She turned back like a frightened doe and entered the space between the rocks. She entered, she went in:🔽this is the meaning. She struck her breast:

original: attho. Uraṃ paccatāḷesīti “ekappahāreneva lāpassa sīsaṃ chinditvā gahessāmī”ti pakkhandattā
analyzed: attho uram paccatāḷesi iti eka ppahārena iva lāpassa sīsam chinditvā gahessāmi iti pakkhandattā
translated: she rushed forward thinking: “With one blow I will cut off his head and seize him.”

original: vegaṃ sandhāretuṃ asakkonto tasmiṃ leḍḍusmiṃ uraṃ patāḷesi. Tāvadevassa hadayamaṃsaṃ
analyzed: vegam sandhāretum a sakkontaḥ tasmin leḍḍusmin uram patāḷesi tāvadevassa hadaya maṃsam
translated: Unable to restrain her speed, she struck her breast on the rock. Immediately her heart flesh

original: phāliyittha. Atha lāpo “diṭṭhā vata sattuno piṭṭhī”ti haṭṭhatuṭṭho tassa hadaye aparāparaṃ caṅkami.
analyzed: atha lāpaḥ diṭṭhā vata sattuno piṭṭhī iti haṭṭha tuṭṭho tassa hadaye apara aparam caṅkami
translated: and it split open. Then the crow, delighted, thinking, “At last I have seen the back of the beast,” walked back and forth over its heart.

original: 7. Makkaṭasuttavaṇṇanā🔽373. Sattame duggāti duggamā. Cārīti sañcāro. Lepaṃ oḍḍentīti vaṭarukkhakhīrādīhi🔽yojetvā lepaṃ karonti, taṃ makkaṭānaṃ dhuvagamanaṭṭhānanti sallakkhetvā rukkhasākhādīsu🔽ṭhapenti. Pañcoḍḍitoti pañcasu ṭhānesu kājadaṇḍakaṃ pavesetvā gahetabbā kājasikkā
analyzed: makkaṭa sutta vaṇṇanā  sattame duggā ati duggamā cārī iti sañcāraḥ lepam oḍḍenti iti vaṭa rukkha khīra ādīhi  yojetvā lepam karonti tam makkaṭānam dhuva gamana ṭhānam ti sallakkhetvā rukkha sākhā ādīsu  ṭhapenti pañca uḍḍitā ti pañcasu ṭhānesu kāja daṇḍakam pavesetvā gahetabbā kāja sikkā
translated: The Commentary on the Seventieth Sutta

original: viya oḍḍito. Thunaṃ setīti thunanto sayati.
analyzed: viyaḥ oḍḍitaḥ thunam seti iti thunantaḥ sayati
translated: In the seventh sutta, “difficult to traverse” is duggā; “to move” is cārī. “They plaster it” means they mix the sap of the vaṭa tree with other things and plaster it. “They set a trap” means they set it up in the branches of trees, etc., thinking that it is a place where monkeys will come to bathe. “Five-pronged” means that it is set up in such a way that it can be grasped by inserting the hand in five places, like a toy called a “monkey trap.” “He lies in wait” means he lies in wait for the prey.

original: 8. Sūdasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sūda sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Eighty-first Sutta

original: 374. Aṭṭhame sūdoti bhattakārako. Nānaccayehīti nānācayehi, nānāvidhehīti attho.🔽Ayameva vā pāṭho. Ambilaggehīti ambilakoṭṭhāsehi. Eseva nayo sabbattha. Abhiharatīti
analyzed: aṭṭhame sūdaḥ ti bhatta kārakaḥ nānaccayehi iti nānā cayehi nānāvidhehi iti attho  ayam eva vā pāṭhaḥ ambi laggehi iti ambila koṭṭhāsehi esa iva nayaḥ sabbattha abhiharati iti
translated: In the eighth sutta, “cook” is sūda. “With various condiments” means with various kinds of condiments.🔽Or the reading may be nāññaca yehi, in which case the meaning is “with other kinds of condiments.”

original: gahaṇatthāya hatthaṃ pasāreti. Bahuṃ gaṇhātīti ekaggahaṇena bahuṃ gaṇhantopi punappunaṃ
analyzed: gahaṇa atthāya hattham pasāreti bahum gaṇhāti iti eka ggahaṇena bahum gaṇhantaḥ api punappunam
translated: “With various pickles” means with various kinds of sour substances. The same method applies in all cases. “He serves” means he extends his hand to take . “He takes a lot” means that even if he takes a lot in one grasp, he takes it again and again.

original: gaṇhantopi bahuṃ gaṇhateva. Abhihārānanti sataṃ vā sahassaṃ vā ukkhipitvā abhihaṭānaṃ🔽dāyānaṃ. Upakkilesāti pañca nīvaraṇā. Nimittaṃ na uggaṇhātīti “imaṃ me kammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: gaṇhantaḥ api bahum gaṇhatā iva satam vā sahassam vā ukkhipitvā  dāyānam upakkilesā ati pañca nīvaraṇāḥ nimittam na uggaṇhāti iti imam me kammaṭṭhānam
translated: and when he does, he takes a lot. “Gifts that are brought” : gifts that are brought and offered, a hundred or a thousand.

original: anulomaṃ vā gotrabhuṃ vā āhacca ṭhita”nti na jānāti, attano cittassa nimittaṃ gaṇhituṃ
analyzed: anulomam vā gotrabhum vā na jānāti attano cittassa nimittam gaṇhitum
translated: “Defilements” : the five hindrances. “Does not grasp the sign” : he does not know, “This meditation subject of mine is adjacent to conformity or to change-of-lineage,” and he is unable to grasp the sign of his own cognizance.

original: na sakkoti. Imasmiṃ sutte pubbabhāgavipassanā satipaṭṭhānāva kathitā.
analyzed: na sakkoti imasmin sutte pubba bhāga vipassanā sati paṭṭhānā ava kathitā
translated: In this sutta only the insight of the initial stage is taught, namely the four foundations of mindfulness.

original: 9. Gilānasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: gilāna sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the ninth sutta

original: 375. Navame beḷuvagāmaketi vesāliyā samīpe evaṃnāmako pādagāmo atthi, tasmiṃ. Yathāmittantiādīsu
analyzed: navame beḷuvagāmaka iti vesāliyā samīpe evaṃnāmako pādagāmo atthi tasmin yathāmittanti ādīsu
translated: In the village of Beluva: there was a village of that name near Vesali. As to “friends” and so on,

original: mittāti mittāva. Sandiṭṭhāti tattha tattha saṅgamma diṭṭhamattā nātidaḷhamittā. Sambhattāti
analyzed: mittā ati sandiṭṭhā ati tattha tattha saṅgamma diṭṭha mattā na ati daḷha mittā sambhattā ati
translated: friends are just friends. Acquaintances are not very close friends, just seen here and there.🔽Associates are good friends, affectionate, close friends.

original: suṭṭhu bhattā sinehavanto daḷhamittā. Yesaṃ yattha yattha evarūpā bhikkhū atthi,
analyzed: suṭṭhu bhattā sinehavantaḥ daḷha mittāḥ yesam yattha yattha evarūpāḥ bhikkhū atthi
translated: Wherever there are such bhikkhus,

original: te tattha tattha vassaṃ upethāti attho. Kasmā evamāha? Tesaṃ phāsuvihāratthāya. Tesaṃ🔽kira beḷuvagāmake senāsanaṃ nappahoti, bhikkhāpi mandā. Samantā vesāliyā pana bahūni
analyzed: te tattha tattha vassam upetha ati kasmai evam āha tesam phāsu vihāra atthāya tesam  kira beḷuva gāmake senāsanam na ppahoti bhikkhā api mandā samantā vesāliyā pana bahūni
translated: the meaning is, they should spend the rains there. Why does he say this? For the sake of their comfort. It seems that there was not enough accommodation in the Banyan Grove, and almsfood was scarce. But all round Vesālī there were many🔽

original: senāsanāni, bhikkhāpi sulabhā. Tasmā evamāha.🔽Atha kasmā “yathāsukhaṃ gacchathā”ti na vissajjesi? Tesaṃ anukampāya. Evaṃ kirassa🔽ahosi – “ahaṃ dasamāsamattaṃ ṭhatvā parinibbāyissāmi. Sace ime dūraṃ gacchissanti,🔽maṃ parinibbānakāle daṭṭhuṃ na sakkhissanti. Atha nesaṃ ‘satthā parinibbāyanto amhākaṃ
analyzed: senāsanāni bhikkhā api sulabhā tasmai evam āha  atha kasmai yathāsukham gacchatha ati na vissajjesi tesam anukampāya evam kirassa  ahosi aham dasa māsa mattam ṭhatvā parinibbāyissāmi sace ime dūram gacchissanti  mam parinibbāna kāle daṭṭhum na sakkhissanti atha nesam satthā parinibbāyantaḥ amhākam
translated: The meaning is that they should spend the rains there. Why did he say this? For the sake of their comfort. It seems that there was not enough accommodation in the Banyan Grove, and almsfood was scarce. But there were many monasteries around Vesālī, and almsfood was easy to obtain. That is why he said this.

original: satimattampi na adāsi. Sace jāneyyāma, na evaṃ dūre vaseyyāmā’ti vippaṭisāro bhaveyya.🔽Vesāliyā samantā pana vassaṃ vasantā māsassa aṭṭha vāre āgantvā dhammaṃ suṇissanti,
analyzed: na adāsi sace jāneyyāma na evam dūre vaseyyāma ati vippaṭisāraḥ bhaveyya  vesāliyā samantā pana vassam vasantā māsassa aṭṭha vāre āgantvā dhammaṃ suṇissanti
translated: Why did he not dismiss them, saying, “Go where you like”? Out of compassion for them. He thought, “I shall attain final Nibbāna after staying for ten months. If they go far away, they will not be able to see me when I attain final Nibbāna. They might feel remorse, thinking, ‘The Teacher attained final Nibbāna without giving us even a hint. If we had known, we would not have lived so far away.’

original: sugatovādaṃ labhissantī”ti na vissajjesi.
analyzed: sugata uvādam labhissanti iti na vissajjesi
translated: But if they spend the rains all around Vesālī, they will be able to come eight times a month to hear the Dhamma and receive the Sugata’s advice.” That is why he did not dismiss them.

original: Kharoti pharuso. Ābādhoti visabhāgarogo. Bāḷhāti balavatiyo. Māraṇantikāti maraṇantaṃ
analyzed: pharusaḥ visa bhāga rogaḥ balavatiyaḥ māraṇantikā ati
translated: Rough: harsh. Sickness: an illness of an unusual kind. Violent: strong. Life-threatening: ending in death.

original: maraṇasantikaṃ pāpanasamatthā. Sato sampajāno adhivāsesīti satiṃ sūpaṭṭhitaṃ katvā🔽ñāṇena paricchinditvā adhivāsesi. Avihaññamānoti vedanānuvattanavasena aparāparaṃ
analyzed: maraṇa santikam pāpana samatthā sataḥ sampajānaḥ adhivāsesi iti satim su upaṭṭhitam katvā  ñāṇena paricchinditvā adhivāsesi a vihaññamānaḥ ti vedanā anuvattana vasena apara aparam
translated: “Rough” : harsh. “Illness” : a disease that is unlike the usual. “Violent” : strong. “Fatal” : ending in death, able to bring about death. “Mindfully, with full awareness, he endured it” : he endured it with mindfulness well-established,

original: parivattanaṃ akaronto apīḷiyamāno adukkhiyamāno ca adhivāsesi. Anāmantetvāti ajānāpetvā.
analyzed: parivattanam a karontaḥ a pīḷiyamānaḥ a dukkhiyamānaḥ ca adhivāsesi an āmantetvā ati a jānāpetvā
translated: discriminating it with knowledge. “Without being troubled” : without being afflicted, without being pained, he endured it without turning his mind to the matter of his death. “Without taking counsel” : without informing.

original: Anapaloketvāti ajānāpetvāva ovādānusāsaniṃ adatvāti vuttaṃ hoti. Vīriyenāti pubbabhāgavīriyena🔽ceva phalasamāpattivīriyena ca. Paṭipaṇāmetvāti vikkhambhetvā. Jīvitasaṅkhāranti🔽ettha jīvitampi jīvitasaṅkhāro. Yena jīvitaṃ saṅkharīyati chijjamānaṃ ghaṭetvā ṭhapīyati,
analyzed: an apaloketvā ti ovāda anusāsanim a datvā iti vuttam hoti vīriyena ati pubbabhāga vīriyena  ca iva phala samāpatti vīriyena ca paṭipaṇāmetvā ati vikkhambhetvā jīvita saṅkhāranti  ettha jīvitam pi jīvita saṅkhāraḥ yena jīvitam saṅkharīyati chijjamānam ghaṭetvā ṭhapīyati
translated: “Without looking around” : without informing. “Without giving advice” : without giving advice and instruction. “By his energy” : by the energy of the prior stage🔽and by the energy of the fruition attainment. “Having directed it” : having suppressed it. “The life formation” : here the life faculty is also a life formation. By means of it life is formed, for when it is ceasing it is arrested and kept going.

original: so phalasamāpattidhammopi jīvitasaṅkhāro. So idha adhippeto. Adhiṭṭhāyāti adhiṭṭhahitvā
analyzed: so phala samāpatti dhammaḥ api jīvita saṅkhāro saḥ idha adhippetaḥ adhiṭṭhāyāti adhiṭṭhahitvā
translated: The Dhamma of fruition attainment is also a life formation. That is what is meant here. “Having resolved” : having resolved.

original: pavattetvā jīvitaṭhapanasamatthaṃ phalasamāpattiṃ samāpajjeyyanti ayamettha saṅkhepattho.
analyzed: pavattetvā jīvita ṭhapana samattham phala samāpattim samāpajjeyyanti ayam ettha saṅkhepa tthaḥ
translated: and then he would attain the fruition attainment that is able to suspend the life faculty. This is the meaning in brief.

original: Kiṃ pana bhagavā ito pubbe phalasamāpattiṃ na samāpajjatīti? Samāpajjati. Sā pana
analyzed: kim pana bhagavā itas pubbe phala samāpattim na samāpajjati iti samāpajjati sā pana
translated: But did the Blessed One not attain fruition attainment before this? He did. But that was

original: khaṇikasamāpatti. Khaṇikasamāpatti ca antosamāpattiyaṃyeva vedanaṃ vikkhambheti,
analyzed: khaṇika samāpatti khaṇika samāpatti ca anto samāpattiyam yeva vedanam vikkhambheti
translated: a momentary attainment. And momentary attainment suppresses only the feeling in the attainment itself,

original: samāpattito vuṭṭhitamattassa kaṭṭhapātena vā kaṭhalapātena vā chinnasevālo viya udakaṃ,🔽puna sarīraṃ vedanā ajjhottharati. Yā pana rūpasattakaṃ arūpasattakañca niggumbaṃ
analyzed: samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhita mattassa kaṭṭhapātena vā kaṭhala pātena vā chinna sevālo viya udakaṃ  puna sarīram vedanāḥ ajjhottharati yā pana rūpa sattakam a rūpa sattakam ca niggumbam
translated: just as the water that has been split by the stroke of the axe does not flow beyond the place struck.

original: nijjaṭaṃ katvā mahāvipassanāvasena samāpannā samāpatti, sā suṭṭhu vikkhambheti. Yathā
analyzed: nijjaṭam katvā mahāvipassanā vasena samāpannā samāpatti sā suṭṭhu vikkhambheti yathā
translated: But the attainment that he entered by means of the great insight, after he had encompassed the seven kinds of material dhammas and the seven kinds of immaterial dhammas,

original: nāma purisena pokkharaṇiṃ ogāhetvā hatthehi ca pādehi ca suṭṭhu apabyuḷhasevālo cirena
analyzed: nāma purisena pokkharaṇim ogāhetvā hatthehi ca pādehi ca suṭṭhu apabyuḷha sevālo cirena
translated: suppressed them well. Just as the water that has been well bailed out by a scoop does not quickly fill the place bailed out,🔽so too, the feeling that arises in him after he has emerged is slow to arise. So on that day

original: udakaṃ ottharati, evameva tato vuṭṭhitassa cirena vedanā uppajjati. Iti bhagavā taṃdivasaṃ
analyzed: udakam ottharati evam eva tatas vuṭṭhitassa cirena vedanā uppajjati iti bhagavā taṃ divasam
translated: the Blessed One

original: mahābodhipallaṅke abhinavaṃ vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapento viya rūpasattakaṃ arūpasattakañca
analyzed: mahā bodhi pallaṅke abhinavam vipassanam paṭṭhapentaḥ viya rūpa sattakam arūpa sattakañca
translated: As if he were starting a new insight on the great enlightenment seat, he discerned the seven kinds of material dhammas and the seven kinds of immaterial dhammas,

original: niggumbaṃ nijjaṭaṃ katvā cuddasahākārehi sannetvā mahāvipassanāya vedanaṃ vikkhambhetvā
analyzed: niggumbam nijjaṭam katvā cuddasa hākārehi sannetvā mahāvipassanāya vedanam vikkhambhetvā
translated: and after he had done so, he discerned feeling by means of the fourteen ways of discerning it, and he suppressed it by means of the great insight.

original: “dasamāse mā uppajjitthā”ti samāpattiṃ samāpajji, samāpattivikkhambhitā vedanā dasa
analyzed: dasa māse mā uppajjittha ati samāpattim samāpajji samāpatti vikkhambhitāḥ vedanāḥ dasa
translated: And he resolved that it should not arise for ten months, and he attained jhāna by suppressing it. The feeling suppressed by the jhāna

original: māse na uppajjiyeva.
analyzed: māse na uppajjiyeva
translated: did not arise for ten months.

original: Gilānā vuṭṭhitoti gilāno hutvā puna vuṭṭhito. Madhurakajāto viyāti sañjātagarubhāvo
analyzed: gilānā vuṭṭhitā ti gilānaḥ hutvā puna vuṭṭhitaḥ madhuraka jātaḥ viyāti sañjāta garu bhāvaḥ
translated: “Having recovered from his illness”: having been ill, he recovered. “As if he had a fresh wound”: he had become sensitive,

original: sañjātathaddhabhāvo sūle uttāsitapuriso viya. Na pakkhāyantīti na pakāsanti, nānākārato
analyzed: sañjāta thaddha bhāvaḥ sūle uttāsita purisaḥ viya na pakkhāyanti iti na pakāsanti nānā ākārato
translated: as a man is sensitive when a dart is being extracted. “Did not shine forth”: did not appear, did not become evident in its various aspects.

original: na upaṭṭhahanti. Dhammāpi maṃ nappaṭibhantīti satipaṭṭhānadhammā mayhaṃ pākaṭā na
analyzed: na upaṭṭhahanti dhammā api mam na ppaṭibhanti iti sati paṭṭhāna dhammāḥ mayham pākaṭāḥ na
translated: “Nor did ideas present themselves to me”: he shows that the ideas of the foundations of mindfulness were not evident to him.

original: hontīti dīpeti. Tantidhammā pana therassa suppaguṇā. Na udāharatīti pacchimaovādaṃ
analyzed: honti iti dīpeti tanti dhammā pana therassa su paguṇā na udāharati iti
translated: But those ideas are very helpful to the Elder. “Nor did I utter speech”: he does not give his last exhortation.

original: na deti, taṃ sandhāya vadati.
analyzed: na deti tam sandhāya vadati
translated: He speaks with reference to that.

original: Anantaraṃ abāhiranti dhammavasena vā puggalavasena vā ubhayaṃ akatvā. “Ettakaṃ dhammaṃ🔽parassa na desessāmī”ti hi cintento dhammaṃ abbhantaraṃ karoti nāma, “ettakaṃ parassa🔽desessāmī”ti cintento bāhiraṃ karoti nāma. “Imassa puggalassa desessāmī”ti cintento🔽pana puggalaṃ abbhantaraṃ karoti nāma, “imassa na desessāmī”ti cintento puggalaṃ
