analyzed: anantaram dhamma vasena vā puggala vasena vā ubhayam a katvā ettakam dhammam  parassa na desessāmi iti hi cintentaḥ dhammam abbhantaram karoti nāma ettakam parassa  desessāmi iti cintentaḥ bāhiram karoti nāma imassa puggalassa desessāmi iti cintentaḥ  pana puggalam abbhantaram karoti nāma imassa na desessāmi iti cintento puggalaṃ
translated: Or else, without making either the Dhamma or the person internal or external, he thinks, “I will not teach the Dhamma to anyone else up to this point,” and then he makes the Dhamma internal. He thinks, “I will teach the Dhamma to others up to this point,” and then he makes the Dhamma external. He thinks, “I will teach this person,” and then he makes the person internal. He thinks, “I will not teach this person,” and then he makes the person external.

original: bāhiraṃ karoti nāma. Evaṃ akatvā desitoti attho. Ācariyamuṭṭhīti yathā bāhirakānaṃ🔽ācariyamuṭṭhi nāma hoti, daharakāle kassaci akathetvā pacchimakāle maraṇamañce nipannā🔽piyamanāpassa antevāsikassa kathenti, evaṃ tathāgatassa “idaṃ mahallakakāle pacchimaṭhāne🔽kathessāmī”ti muṭṭhiṃ katvā pariharitvā ṭhapitaṃ kiñci natthīti dasseti.
analyzed: bāhiram karoti nāma evam a katvā desito ti attho ācariya muṭṭhī iti yathā 🔽ācariyamuṭṭhi nāma hoti dahara kāle kassaci a kathetvā pacchima kāle maraṇa mañce nipannā 🔽piyamanāpassa antevāsikassa kathenti evam tathāgatassa idam mahallaka kāle pacchima ṭhāne 🔽kathessāmi iti muṭṭhim katvā pariharitvā ṭhapitam kiñci na atthi iti dasseti
translated: “Not kept back, not kept outside”: without keeping back either the Dhamma or the person. For when he thinks, “I will not teach the Dhamma to such and such people,” he keeps the Dhamma back; when he thinks, “I will teach it to such and such people,” he keeps it outside. When he thinks, “I will teach it to this person,” he keeps the person back; when he thinks, “I will not teach it to this person,” he keeps the person outside. The meaning is that he teaches without keeping back in this way. “No fistful held back by the Teacher”: just as the sectarians have a “fistful held back by the Teacher,” which they do not tell anyone while they are young but lie on their deathbeds and tell it to a beloved pupil, so the Tathāgata has no such thing kept back, held in reserve, thinking, “I will teach this in my old age, in my last days.”

original: Ahaṃ bhikkhusaṅghanti ahameva bhikkhusaṅghaṃ pariharissāmīti vā, mamuddesikoti ahaṃ🔽uddisitabbaṭṭhena uddeso assāti mamuddesiko, mameva uddissitvā maṃ paccāsīsamāno🔽bhikkhusaṅgho hotu mama accayena mā vā ahosi, yaṃ vā taṃ vā hotūti iti vā pana yassa🔽assāti attho. Na evaṃ hotīti bodhipallaṅkeyeva issāmaccherānaṃ vigatattā evaṃ na
analyzed: aham bhikkhu saṅgham ti aham eva bhikkhu saṅgham pariharissāmi iti vā mamuddesikaḥ ti aham  uddisitabba ṭṭhena uddesaḥ assa ati mamuddesikaḥ mama eva uddissitvā mam paccāsīsamāno  bhikkhu saṅghaḥ hotu mama accayena mā vā ahosi yam vā tam vā hotu uti iti vā pana yassa  assa ati atthaḥ na evam hoti iti vigata ttā evam na
translated: “I will look after the Order of bhikkhus” or “I am the one to be dedicated to” means I am the one to be dedicated to in the sense of being dedicated to. Having dedicated to me, having made me the recipient, let the Order of bhikkhus be after my passing, or let it not be, or whatever it may be. This is the meaning of “or whatever it may be”. It is not so means it is not so because of the absence of envy and avarice on the part of the Bodhisatta even at the foot of the Bodhi Tree.

original: hoti. Sa kinti so kiṃ. Āsītikoti asītisaṃvacchariko, idaṃ pacchimavayaṃ anuppattabhāvadīpanatthaṃ🔽vuttaṃ. Veṭhamissakenāti bāhabandhacakkabandhādinā paṭisaṅkharaṇena veṭhamissakena.🔽Maññeti jarasakaṭaṃ viya veṭhamissakena maññe yāpeti, arahattaphalaveṭhanena catuiriyāpathakappanaṃ🔽tathāgatassa hotīti dasseti.
analyzed: hoti sa kinti so kim asīti saṃvaccharikaḥ idam pacchima vayam anuppatta bhāva dīpana ttham 🔽vuttam veṭha missakena ati bāha bandha cakka bandha ādinā paṭisaṅkharaṇena veṭha missakena 🔽maññe ti jarasa kaṭam viya veṭha missakena maññe yāpeti arahatta phala veṭhanena catu iriyāpatha kappanam 🔽tathāgatassa hoti iti dasseti
translated: I will be the Community of bhikkhus: I alone will look after the Community of bhikkhus. Or: I am the one to be dedicated to, thus I am the one to be dedicated to. Having dedicated to me, having made me the recipient, let the Community of bhikkhus be after my passing, or let it not be, or whatever it may be. The meaning is: I am not like that. It is not so: it is not so because of the absence of envy and avarice in the seat of awakening. What is that? What is that? Eighty years: eighty years of age. This is said in order to show the state of the last age. With a yoke-yoke: with a yoke-yoke that is a re-arrangement by means of arm-bands, leg-bands, and so on. I think: I think that he goes along with a yoke-yoke, as if with an old cart, the Tathāgata’s going along with the four postures of the body is with the yoke-yoke of arahatship.

original: Idāni tamatthaṃ pakāsento yasmiṃ ānanda samayetiādimāha. Tattha sabbanimittānanti
analyzed: idāni tam attham pakāsentaḥ yasmin ānanda samaya iti ādim āha tattha sabba nimittānam ti
translated: Now, in order to make that clear, he said: “In whatever way, Ananda, etc.” Herein, of all signs means

original: rūpanimittādīnaṃ. Ekaccānaṃ vedanānanti lokiyānaṃ vedanānaṃ. Tasmātihānandāti yasmā
analyzed: rūpa nimitta ādīnam lokiyānam
translated: of the sign of visible form, and so on. Of some feelings means of mundane feelings.

original: iminā phalasamāpattivihārena phāsu hoti, tasmā tumhepi tadatthāya evaṃ viharathāti🔽dasseti. Attadīpāti mahāsamuddagatā dīpaṃ viya attānaṃ dīpaṃ patiṭṭhaṃ katvā viharatha.🔽Attasaraṇāti attagatikāva hotha, mā aññagatikā. Dhammadīpadhammasaraṇapadesupi eseva
analyzed: iminā phala samāpatti vihārena phāsu hoti tasmā tumhe pi tad atthāya evam viharatha ati  dassa iti atta dīpā ati mahā samudda gatāḥ dīpam viya attānam dīpam patiṭṭham katvā viharatha  atta saraṇā ati atta gatikā ava hotha mā añña gatikā dhamma dīpa dhamma saraṇa padesu pi esā iva
translated: Therefore, Ananda, means since it is comfortable by means of this abiding in the attainment of fruition, therefore you should abide thus for that purpose.

original: nayo. Ettha ca dhammoti navavidho lokuttaradhammo veditabbo. Tamataggeti tamaagge,
analyzed: nayaḥ ettha ca dhammo ti navavidhaḥ lokuttara dhammo veditabbaḥ tama tagge ti tama agge
translated: Make yourselves your island means make yourselves your refuge, not others. The same method of explanation applies in the case of the words: “Make the Dhamma your island” and “Make the Dhamma your refuge.” Herein, the Dhamma should be understood as the nine supramundane states.

original: majjhe ta-kāro padasandhivasena vutto. Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – ime aggatamāti tamataggāti.
analyzed: majjhe takāraḥ pada sandhi vasena vuttaḥ idam vuttam hoti ime agga tamā ati tama taggā ati
translated: The end of suffering means the end of suffering, the middle of the word being abbreviated in the way mentioned above. This is what is said: “These are at the end of suffering, thus they are the end of suffering.”🔽Having thus cut off the whole stream of suffering, these bhikkhus of mine, Ananda, are

original: Evaṃ sabbaṃ tamasotaṃ chinditvā ativiya agge uttamabhāve ete, ānanda, mama bhikkhū
analyzed: evam sabbam tamasā utam chinditvā ativiya agge uttama bhāve ete ānanda mama bhikkhū
translated: at the head, at the foremost place, in the supreme state.

original: bhavissanti, tesaṃ agge bhavissanti. Ye keci sikkhākāmā, sabbesaṃ tesaṃ catusatipaṭṭhānagocarāva
analyzed: bhavissanti tesam agge bhavissanti ye keci sikkhā kāmā sabbesam tesam catusati paṭṭhāna gocarā ava
translated: They will be foremost among them. And those who wish for training will all have the bhikkhus who range in the four foundations of mindfulness as their foremost.

original: bhikkhū agge bhavissantīti arahattanikūṭena desanaṃ gaṇhīti.
analyzed: bhikkhū agge bhavissanti iti arahatta nikūṭena desanam gaṇhi iti
translated: He took the teaching as far as arahatship.

original: 10. Bhikkhunupassayasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: bhikkhun upassaya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Discussion of the Ten Insights

original: 376. Dasame tenupasaṅkamīti tasmiṃ upassaye kammaṭṭhānakammikā bhikkhuniyo atthi,🔽tāsaṃ ussukkāpetvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ kathessāmīti upasaṅkami. Uḷāraṃ pubbenāparaṃ visesanti
analyzed: dasame tena upasaṅkamīti tasmin upassaye kammaṭṭhāna kammikāḥ bhikkhuniyaḥ atthi  tāsam ussukkāpetvā kammaṭṭhānam kathessāmi iti upasaṅkami uḷāram pubbena aparam
translated: In the tenth, he went to her: there were bhikkhunis who were doing meditation subjects in that dwelling place,🔽and he went to them, thinking, “I shall teach them a meditation subject after stirring up their zeal.” Uḷāraṃ pubbenāparaṃ visesaṃ: a higher distinction than the previous one.

original: pubbavisesato aparaṃ uḷāravisesaṃ. Tattha mahābhūtapariggaho pubbaviseso, upādārūpapariggaho
analyzed: pubba visesataḥ aparam uḷāra visesam tattha mahābhūta pariggahaḥ pubba visesaḥ upādā rūpa pariggaho
translated: Herein, the analysis of the primary elements is the previous distinction, the analysis of the derived materiality is the

original: aparaviseso nāma. Tathā sakalarūpapariggaho pubbaviseso, arūpapariggaho aparaviseso
analyzed: apara visesaḥ nāma tathā sakala rūpa pariggahaḥ pubba visesaḥ arūpa pariggahaḥ apara visesaḥ
translated: higher distinction. So too, the analysis of all materiality is the previous distinction, the analysis of the immaterial is the🔽higher distinction. The analysis of materiality and the immaterial is the previous distinction, the analysis of conditions is the

original: nāma. Rūpārūpapariggaho pubbaviseso, paccayapariggaho aparaviseso nāma sappaccayanāmarūpadassanaṃ
analyzed: nāma rūpa arūpa pariggahaḥ pubba visesaḥ paccaya pariggahaḥ apara visesaḥ nāma sappaccaya nāma rūpa dassanam
translated: higher distinction. The seeing of mentality-materiality with its conditions is the previous distinction, the analysis of the🔽dependent origination is the higher distinction.

original: pubbaviseso, tilakkhaṇāropanaṃ aparaviseso nāma. Evaṃ pubbenāparaṃ uḷāravisesaṃ jānātīti attho.
analyzed: pubba visesaḥ ti lakkhaṇa āropanam apara visesaḥ nāma evam pubbena aparam uḷāra visesam jānāti iti attho
translated: The prior distinction is the prior distinction of the object, and the subsequent distinction is the subsequent distinction of the object. The meaning is that he knows the prior and subsequent distinctions of the object.

original: Kāyārammaṇoti yaṃ kāyaṃ anupassati, tameva ārammaṇaṃ katvā uppajjati kilesapariḷāho.
analyzed: kāya ārammaṇaḥ ti yam kāyam anupassati tam eva ārammaṇam katvā uppajjati kilesa pariḷāho
translated: “The defilement of the body as object”: the defilement of lust arises in him by making the body that he is contemplating the object.

original: Bahiddhā vā cittaṃ vikkhipatīti bahiddhā vā puthuttārammaṇe cittuppādo vikkhipati.
analyzed: bahiddhā vā cittam vikkhipati iti bahiddhā vā puthuttā ārammaṇe cittuppādaḥ vikkhipati
translated: “Or his mind becomes distracted externally”: or the arising of consciousness externally, on a different object, is distraction.

original: Kismiñcideva pasādanīye nimitte cittaṃ paṇidahitabbanti evaṃ kilesapariḷāhe ca līnatte
analyzed: kismiñcid eva pasādanīye nimitte cittam paṇidahitabbanti evam kilesa pariḷāhe ca līnatte
translated: “He should direct his mind to some inspiring sign”: when the defilement of lust and the slackness of depression arise in this way,

original: ca bahiddhāvikkhepe ca uppanne kilesānurañjitena na vattitabbaṃ, kismiñcideva pasādanīye
analyzed: ca bahiddhā vikkhepe ca uppanne kilesa anurañjitena na vattitabbam kismiñcid eva pasādanīye
translated: he should not consent to their occurrence by relishing them. He should establish his meditation subject in some inspiring place,

original: pasādāvahe buddhādīsu aññatarasmiṃ ṭhāne kammaṭṭhānacittaṃ ṭhapetabbaṃ. Cittaṃ samādhiyatīti🔽ārammaṇe sammā ādhiyati suṭṭhu ṭhapitaṃ ṭhapiyati. Paṭisaṃharāmīti pasādanīyaṭṭhānato
analyzed: pasāda āvahe buddha ādīsu aññatarasmim ṭhāne kammaṭṭhāna cittam ṭhapetabbam cittam samādhiyati iti  ārammaṇe sammā ādhiyati suṭṭhu ṭhapitam ṭhapiyati paṭisaṃharāmi iti pasādanīya ṭṭhānato
translated: in the Buddha, Dhamma, or Sangha, or in some other inspiring object. “His mind becomes concentrated”:🔽it is properly concentrated, well established, on the object. “I will breathe in … will breathe out tranquilizing the activity of the mind formation”:

original: paṭisaṃharāmi, mūlakammaṭṭhānābhimukhaṃyeva naṃ karomīti attho. So paṭisaṃharati
analyzed: paṭisaṃharāmi mūlakammaṭṭhāna abhimukham yeva nam karomi iti attho so paṭisaṃharati
translated: the meaning is that he will breathe in and breathe out making the mind formation tranquil, calming the grossness of the mind. “I will breathe in … will breathe out focusing on dispassion”:

original: cevāti mūlakammaṭṭhānābhimukhañca peseti. Na ca vitakketi na ca vicāretīti kilesavitakkaṃ
analyzed: ca iva ati mūla kammaṭṭhāna abhimukhaṃ ca peseti na ca vitakketi na ca vicāreti iti kilesa vitakkam
translated: and he directs his mind to the sign of the beauty of the meditation subject. He neither thinks nor examines: he does not think or examine the defilements.🔽He is neither ponderer nor inquirer: he is not a ponderer or inquirer into the defilements.🔽He has left pondering and inquiry behind: he has left pondering and inquiry into the defilements behind.

original: na vitakketi, kilesavicāraṃ na vicāreti. Avitakkomhi avicāroti kilesavitakkavicārehi🔽avitakkāvicāro. Ajjhattaṃ satimā sukhamasmīti gocarajjhatte pavattāya satiyā “satimāhamasmi
analyzed: na vitakketi kilesa vicāram na vicāreti a vitakkomhi a vicāro ti kilesa vitakka vicārehi  a vitakka a vicāraḥ ajjhattam satimā sukham asmi iti gocara jjhatte pavattāya satiyā satimā aham asmi
translated: He has removed doubt: he has removed doubt about the meditation subject.🔽He has surmounter the plane of the ordinary man: he has surmounted the plane of the worldling.🔽He possesses the knowledge of the attainment of the fruit of stream-entry: he possesses the knowledge of the attainment of the fruit of stream-entry.🔽He understands: he understands the four noble truths.🔽He has realized the fruit of stream-entry: he has realized the fruit of stream-entry.

original: sukhito cā”ti pajānāti.🔽Evaṃ kho, ānanda, paṇidhāya bhāvanā hotīti evaṃ, ānanda, ṭhapetvā bhāvanā hoti. Imassa
analyzed: sukhitaḥ ca ati pajānāti  evam kho ānanda paṇidhāya bhāvanā hoti iti evam ānanda ṭhapetvā bhāvanā hoti imassa
translated: Translation: ceti passaddhiṃ vā upekkhaṃ vā āvajjati | na vitakketi na vicāreti kilesavitakkaṃ vā kilesavicāraṃ vā na vitakketi na vicāreti | avitakkomhi avicāroti kilesavitakkavicārehi avitakkāvicāro | ajjhattaṃ satima sukhamīti ajjhattaṃ pavattāya satiyā “satiyā me ajjhattaṃ pītisukhamāpannaṃ”ti pajānāti |

original: hi bhikkhuno yathā nāma purisassa mahantaṃ ucchubhāraṃ ukkhipitvā yantasālaṃ nentassa🔽kilantakilantakāle bhūmiyaṃ ṭhapetvā ucchukhaṇḍaṃ khāditvā puna ukkhipitvā gamanaṃ
analyzed: hi bhikkhuno yathā nāma purisassa mahantam ucchu bhāram ukkhipitvā yanta sālam nentassa  kilanta kilanta kāle bhūmiyam ṭhapetvā ucchu khaṇḍam khāditvā punar ukkhipitvā gamanaṃ
translated: evaṃ kho ānanda paṇidhāya bhāvanāti evaṃ ānanda ṭhapetvā bhāvanā hoti | imassa hi bhikkhuno yathā nāma purisassa mahantaṃ ucchubhāraṃ ukkhipitvā yantasālaṃ nentassa kilantaṃ kilantaṃ kālaṃ bhūmiyaṃ ṭhapetvā ucchukhaṇḍaṃ khāditvā puna ukkhipitvā gantassa evaṃ hoti |

original: hoti; evameva arahattaṃ pāpuṇituṃ uggahitakammaṭṭhānassa kāyapariḷāhādīsu uppannesu
analyzed: hoti evam eva arahattam pāpuṇitum uggahita kammaṭṭhānassa kāya pariḷāha ādīsu uppannesu
translated: evameva arahattaṃ pāpuṇituṃ uggahitakammaṭṭhānassa kāyapariḷāhādīsu uppannesu

original: taṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ ṭhapetvā buddhaguṇādianussaraṇena cittaṃ pasādetvā kammaniyaṃ katvā
analyzed: tam kammaṭṭhānam ṭhapetvā buddha guṇa ādi anussaraṇena cittam pasādetvā kammaniyam katvā
translated: He should set aside that meditation subject, and he should then purify his mind by bringing to mind the special qualities of the Buddha, etc., and make it wieldy.

original: bhāvanā pavattā, tasmā “paṇidhāya bhāvanā hotī”ti vuttaṃ. Tassa pana purisassa ucchubhāraṃ
analyzed: bhāvanā pavattā tasmā paṇidhāya bhāvanā hoti iti vuttam tassa pana purisassa ucchu bhāram
translated: Then he should resume his meditation subject and continue its development. So it is said, “Development is with prompting.”

original: yantasālaṃ netvā pīḷetvā rasapānaṃ viya imassa bhikkhuno kammaṭṭhānaṃ matthakaṃ pāpetvā
analyzed: yantasālam netvā pīḍetvā rasa pānam viya imassa bhikkhuno kammaṭṭhānam matthakam pāpetvā
translated: Just as the man took the sugarcane stalk and after having it pressed for its juice and drunk the juice, he could afterwards enjoy the pleasure of the stalk as he liked,

original: arahattaṃ pattassa phalasamāpattisukhānubhavanaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: arahattam pattassa phala samāpatti sukha anubhavanam veditabbam
translated: so too, this bhikkhu should bring his meditation subject to the culmination of the fourth jhāna, and then he can enjoy the pleasure of the fruition attainment of arahatship.

original: Bahiddhāti mūlakammaṭṭhānaṃ pahāya bahi aññasmiṃ ārammaṇe. Appaṇidhāyāti aṭṭhapetvā.🔽Atha pacchā pure asaṃkhittaṃ vimuttaṃ appaṇihitanti pajānātīti ettha kammaṭṭhānavasena
analyzed: bahiddhā ti mūlakammaṭṭhānam pahāya bahi aññasmin ārammaṇe a paṇidhāya ati aṭṭhapetvā  atha pacchā pure asaṃkhittam vimuttam appaṇihitanti pajānāti iti ettha kammaṭṭhāna vasena
translated: “In what is external” means in some other object than the meditation subject. “Without prompting” means without determining.

original: vā sarīravasena vā desanāvasena vā attho veditabbo.
analyzed: vā sarīra vasena vā desanā vasena vā attho veditabbo
translated: “Afterwards he understands what was formerly undefined as liberated” : here the meaning should be understood as the meditation subject, or as the body, or as the teaching.

original: Tattha kammaṭṭhāne tāva kammaṭṭhānassa abhiniveso pure nāma, arahattaṃ pacchā nāma.
analyzed: tattha kammaṭṭhāne tāva kammaṭṭhānassa abhiniveso pure nāma arahattam pacchā nāma
translated: Herein, firstly as the meditation subject: the determination of the meditation subject is called “formerly”; arahatship is called “afterwards.”

original: Tattha yo bhikkhu mūlakammaṭṭhānaṃ gahetvā kilesapariḷāhassa vā līnattassa vā bahiddhāvikkhepassa
analyzed: tattha yaḥ bhikkhu mūlakammaṭṭhānam gahetvā kilesa pariḷāhassa vā līnattassa vā bahiddhā vikkhepassa
translated: Herein, a bhikkhu who has taken up a meditation subject and who, without giving opportunity for the arising of defilements, lassitude, or distraction externally,

original: vā uppajjituṃ okāsaṃ adento sudantagoṇe yojetvā sārento viya caturassacchidde sutacchitaṃ🔽caturassaghaṭikaṃ pakkhipanto viya vipassanaṃ paṭṭhapetvā atiṭṭhanto alagganto arahattaṃ🔽pāpuṇāti, so puresaṅkhātassa kammaṭṭhānābhinivesassa pacchāsaṅkhātassa arahattassa
analyzed: vā uppajjitum okāsam su danta goṇe yojetvā sārentaḥ viya  catu assa ghaṭikam pakkhipantaḥ viya vipassanam paṭṭhapetvā a tiṭṭhantaḥ a laggantaḥ arahattam  pāpuṇāti so pure saṅkhātassa kammaṭṭhāna abhinivesassa pacchā saṅkhātassa arahattassa
translated: sets about insight by establishing it, as it were, by yoking and driving the well-broken ox of virtue, as it were, putting in the well-fitted plough of concentration in the well-ploughed field of virtue,

original: ca vasena pacchā pure asaṃkhittaṃ vimuttaṃ appaṇihitanti pajānāti nāma.
analyzed: ca vasena pacchā pure asaṃkhittam vimuttam appaṇihitam ti pajānāti nāma
translated: and who reaches Arahantship by insight, is called one who “has resolved upon what is in front” and who “has attained Nibbāna” by “not holding” and “not applying” in the sense of the Arahantship that comes after the resolution upon the meditation subject that comes before.

original: Sarīre pana pādaṅgulīnaṃ aggapabbāni pure nāma, sīsakaṭāhaṃ pacchā nāma. Tattha yo
analyzed: sarīre pana pāda aṅgulīnam agga pabbāni pure nāma sīsa kaṭāham pacchā nāma tattha yaḥ
translated: In the body, the tips of the toes are called “in front,” and the skull-top is called “behind.” Herein,

original: bhikkhu pādaṅgulīnaṃ aggapabbaaṭṭhikesu abhinivisitvā byābhaṅgiyā yavakalāpaṃ mocento🔽viya vaṇṇasaṇṭhānadisokāsaparicchedavasena aṭṭhīni pariggaṇhanto antarā kilesapariḷāhādīnaṃ
analyzed: bhikkhu pāda aṅgulīnam agga pabba aṭṭhikesu abhinivisitvā byābhaṅgiyāḥ yava kalāpam mocentaḥ 🔽viya vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna disā ukāsa pariccheda vasena aṭṭhīni pariggaṇhantaḥ antarā kilesa pariḷāha ādīnam
translated: a bhikkhu who resolves upon the bones of the toes and, as it were, shoots an arrow with a feathered shaft,🔽observing the bones by colour, shape, direction, location, and delimitation, and who reaches Arahantship by insight, is called one who “has resolved upon what is in front” and who “has attained Nibbāna” by “not holding” and “not applying” in the sense of the Arahantship that comes after the resolution upon the meditation subject that comes before.

original: uppattiṃ vāretvā yāva sīsakaṭāhā bhāvanaṃ pāpeti, so puresaṅkhātānaṃ aggapādaṅgulipabbānaṃ
analyzed: uppattim vāretvā yāva sīsa kaṭāhāḥ bhāvanam pāpeti saḥ puresaṅkhātānam agga pāda aṅguli pabbānam
translated: and he develops it until the tips of the hair and the top of the head are the first to appear.🔽

original: pacchāsaṅkhātassa sīsakaṭāhassa ca vasena pacchā pure asaṃkhittaṃ vimuttaṃ appaṇihitanti pajānāti nāma.
analyzed: pacchā saṅkhātassa sīsa kaṭāhassa ca vasena pacchā pure asaṃkhittam vimuttam appaṇihitam ti pajānāti nāma
translated: and he directs his development until the top of the head, then he is said to know “liberated by non-clinging” as “un-condensed in the past and un-condensed in the future.”

original: Desanāyapi dvattiṃsākāradesanāya kesā pure nāma, matthaluṅgaṃ pacchā nāma. Tattha
analyzed: dvattiṃsa ākāra desanāya kesā pure nāma matthaluṅgam pacchā nāma tattha
translated: And in the case of the thirty-two-fold aspect teaching, the head hairs are called “in the past” and the brain is called “in the future.”

original: yo bhikkhu kesesu abhinivisitvā vaṇṇasaṇṭhānadisokāsavasena kesādayo pariggaṇhanto
analyzed: yaḥ bhikkhu kesesu abhinivisitvā vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna disokāsa vasena kesa ādayaḥ pariggaṇhantaḥ
translated: Herein, a bhikkhu who, after discerning head hairs, etc., by colour, shape, direction, location, and delimitation,

original: antarā kilesapariḷāhādīnaṃ uppattiṃ vāretvā yāva matthaluṅgā bhāvanaṃ pāpeti. So🔽puresaṅkhātānaṃ kesānaṃ pacchāsaṅkhātassa matthaluṅgassa ca vasena pacchā pure asaṃkhittaṃ
analyzed: antarā kilesa pariḷāha ādīnam uppattim vāretvā yāva matthaluṅgā bhāvanam pāpā iti saḥ  pure saṅkhātānam kesānam pacchā saṅkhātassa matthaluṅgassa ca vasena pacchā pure a saṃkhittam
translated: directs his development until the brain, preventing the arising of any desire to see or know what is beyond that,

original: vimuttaṃ appaṇihitanti pajānāti nāma.
analyzed: vimuttam appaṇihitanti pajānāti nāma
translated: is said to know “liberated by non-clinging” as “un-condensed in the past and un-condensed in the future.”

original: Evaṃ kho, ānanda, appaṇidhāya bhāvanā hotīti evaṃ, ānanda, aṭṭhapetvā bhāvanā hoti.
analyzed: evam kho ānanda a paṇidhāya bhāvanā hoti iti evam ānanda aṭṭhapetvā bhāvanā hoti
translated: “So, Ānanda, there is development of concentration that is not clung to” is said of this.

original: Imassa hi bhikkhuno yathā nāma purisassa guḷabhāraṃ labhitvā attano gāmaṃ atiharantassa
analyzed: imassa hi bhikkhunaḥ yathā nāma purisassa guḷa bhāram labhitvā attanaḥ gāmam atiharantassa
translated: For this bhikkhu is like a man who has received a load of sugar and is carrying it to his village.🔽But on the way he stops and eats the sugar lumps, etc., that are on the top.

original: antarā aṭṭhapetvāva uccaṅge pakkhittāni guḷakhaṇḍādīni khādanīyāni khādantassa attano
analyzed: antarā aṭṭhapetvā ava uccaṅge pakkhittāni guḷa khaṇḍa ādīni khādanīyāni khādantassa attano
translated: So he reaches his village still eating the sugar.

original: gāmeyeva otaraṇaṃ hoti, evameva arahattaṃ pāpuṇituṃ āraddhabhāvanassa kāyapariḷāhādīnaṃ
analyzed: hoti evam eva arahattam pāpuṇitum āraddha bhāvanassa kāya pariḷāha ādīnam
translated: So too, when this bhikkhu has begun his development in order to reach Arahantship, he prevents the arising of bodily affliction, etc., and he carries on developing his meditation subject.

original: uppattiṃ vāretvā kammaṭṭhānabhāvanā pavattā, tasmā “appaṇidhāya bhāvanā”ti vuttā.
analyzed: uppattim vāretvā kammaṭṭhāna bhāvanā pavattā tasmā a paṇidhāya bhāvanā iti vuttā
translated: That is why it is called “development without relishing.”

original: Tassa pana purisassa taṃ guḷabhāraṃ attano gāmaṃ netvā ñātīhi saddhiṃ paribhogo viya
analyzed: tassa pana purisassa tam guḷa bhāram attanaḥ gāmam netvā ñātīhi saddhim paribhogaḥ viya
translated: But when the man has taken his load of sugar to his village, he enjoys it with his kinsmen.

original: imassa bhikkhuno kammaṭṭhānaṃ matthakaṃ pāpetvā arahattaṃ pattassa phalasamāpattisukhānubhavanaṃ
analyzed: imassa bhikkhuno kammaṭṭhānam matthakam pāpetvā arahattam pattassa phala samāpatti sukha anubhavanaṃ
translated: So too, when this bhikkhu has brought his meditation subject to its culmination and reached Arahantship, he enjoys the bliss of fruition attainment.

original: veditabbaṃ. Imasmiṃ sutte pubbabhāgavipassanā kathitā. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.🔽Ambapālivaggo paṭhamo.🔽2. Nālandavaggo🔽2. Nālandasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: veditabbam imasmim sutte pubba bhāga vipassanā kathitā sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati 🔽ambapāli vaggo paṭhamo 🔽na alanda vaggo 🔽nālanda sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: This should be understood. In this sutta the insight of the earlier stage is taught. The rest is clear.

original: 378. Dutiyavaggassa dutiye nālandāyanti nālandāti evaṃnāmake nagare, taṃ nagaraṃ🔽gocaragāmaṃ katvā. Pāvārikambavaneti dussapāvārikaseṭṭhino ambavane. Taṃ kira tassa🔽uyyānaṃ ahosi. So bhagavato dhammadesanaṃ sutvā bhagavati pasanno tasmiṃ uyyāne kuṭileṇamaṇḍapādipaṭimaṇḍitaṃ
analyzed: dutiya vaggassa dutiye nālandāyanti nālandāti evaṃnāmake nagare tam nagaram  gocara gāmam katvā pāvārika ambavana iti dussa pāvārika seṭṭhinaḥ ambavane tam kira tassa  uyyānam ahosi saḥ bhagavataḥ dhamma desanam sutvā bhagavati pasannaḥ tasmin uyyāne kuṭileṇa maṇḍapa ādi paṭimaṇḍitam
translated: In the second vagga, in the second sutta, “in Nāḷandā” means in the town called Nāḷandā. That town was made the alms-resort of the Blessed One. “In the mango grove of Cunda the Smith” means in the mango grove of the smith Cunda. That was his pleasure grove, it seems. After hearing the Dhamma taught by the Blessed One, he became a lay follower and had a hut, a pavilion, and so on built in that grove.

original: bhagavato vihāraṃ katvā niyyātesi. So vihāro jīvakambavanaṃ viya pāvārikambavanantveva🔽saṅkhaṃ gato. Tasmiṃ pāvārikambavane viharatīti attho.🔽Evaṃpasannoti evaṃ uppannasaddho, evaṃ saddahāmīti attho. Bhiyyobhiññataroti bhiyyataro🔽abhiññāto bhiyyatarābhiyyo vā, uttaritarañāṇoti attho. Sambodhiyanti sabbaññutaññāṇe
analyzed: bhagavataḥ vihāram katvā so vihāraḥ jīva kamba vanam viya  saṅkham gataḥ tasmin pāvārikamba vane viharati iti attho  evaṃpasannaḥ ti evam uppanna saddhaḥ evam saddahāmi iti atthaḥ bhiyyobhiññataraḥ iti bhiyyataraḥ  abhiññātaḥ bhiyyatara abhiyyaḥ vā uttaritara ñāṇo ti attho sambodhiyanti sabbaññu taññāṇe
translated: In the second vagga, in the second sutta: In Nāḷandā means in the town called Nāḷandā. That town was made the village for collecting alms. In the mango grove of Cunda the Smith means in the mango grove of the smith Cunda. That was his garden, it seems. He, having heard the Dhamma taught by the Blessed One, was pleased with the Blessed One, and having had a dwelling built for the Blessed One, decorated with a pavilion, a hall, etc., he gave it to the Blessed One. That dwelling became known as the mango grove of Cunda the Smith just as the Jīvaka Mango Grove became known as the Jīvaka Mango Grove. The meaning is: he dwelt in that mango grove of Cunda the Smith.

original: arahattamaggañāṇe vā arahattamaggeneva hi buddhaguṇā nippadesā gahitā honti, dvepi
analyzed: arahatta magga ñāṇe vā arahatta maggena iva hi buddha guṇāḥ nippadesāḥ gahitāḥ honti dve pi
translated: Thus have I heard means thus has faith arisen in me; the meaning is: thus I have faith. More distinguished in direct-knowledge means more distinguished in direct-knowledge, more distinguished in higher knowledge, or more distinguished in higher direct-knowledge; the meaning is: more distinguished in knowledge. In the supreme perfect enlightenment means in the knowledge of omniscience or in the knowledge of the path of arahatship. For the qualities of a Buddha are included only by the path of arahatship and by the knowledge of omniscience.

original: aggasāvakā arahattamaggeneva sāvakapāramīñāṇaṃ paṭilabhanti, paccekabuddhā paccekabodhiñāṇaṃ,
analyzed: aggasāvakāḥ arahatta maggena iva sāvaka pāramī ñāṇam paṭilabhanti paccekabuddhāḥ pacceka bodhi ñāṇam
translated: The chief disciples obtain the knowledge of the perfection of discipleship by the path of arahatship. The paccekabuddhas obtain the knowledge of the paccekabodhi.

original: buddhā sabbaññutaññāṇañceva sakale ca buddhaguṇe. Sabbampi nesaṃ arahattamaggeneva
analyzed: buddhā sabbaññuta ññāṇañca iva sakale ca buddha guṇe sabbam pi na īsam arahatta maggena iva
translated: The Buddhas obtain the knowledge of omniscience and all the qualities of a Buddha. All of this is obtained by the path of arahatship.

original: ijjhati. Tasmā arahattamaggañāṇaṃ sambodhi nāma hoti. Tena uttaritaro ca bhagavatā
analyzed: tasmai arahatta magga ñāṇam sambodhi nāma hoti tena uttaritaraḥ ca bhagavatā
translated: Therefore the knowledge of the path of arahatship is called “enlightenment.” There is none higher than the Exalted One.

original: natthi. Tenāha “bhagavatā bhiyyobhiññataro, yadidaṃ sambodhiya”nti.
analyzed: na atthi tena āha bhagavatā bhiyyobhiññataraḥ yat idam sambodhiyanti
translated: Therefore it is said: “There is none more enlightened than the Exalted One, that is to say, by way of enlightenment.”

original: Uḷārāti seṭṭhā. Ayañhi uḷārasaddo “uḷārāni khādanīyāni khādantī”tiādīsu madhure āgacchati.
analyzed: uḷārā ti seṭṭhā ayam hi uḷāra saddaḥ uḷārāni khādanīyāni khādanti itiādīsu madhure āgacchati
translated: Excellent: best. For this word “excellent” occurs in such passages as “eating excellent food” in the sense of sweet.

original: “Uḷārāya khalu bhavaṃ vacchāyano samaṇaṃ gotamaṃ pasaṃsāya pasaṃsatī”tiādīsu seṭṭhe.
analyzed: uḷārāya khalu bhavam vacchāyanaḥ samaṇam gotamam pasaṃsāya pasaṃsati itiādīsu seṭṭhe
translated: In such passages as “The venerable Vacchayana praises the recluse Gotama with high praise indeed” it occurs in the sense of best.

original: “Appamāṇo uḷāro obhāso”tiādīsu vipule. Svāyamidha seṭṭhe āgato. Tena vuttaṃ “uḷārāti
analyzed: appamāṇaḥ uḷāraḥ obhāsaḥ ti ādīsu vipule seṭṭhe āgato tena vuttam uḷārā ati
translated: In such passages as “The light was immeasurable, excellent, and sublime” it occurs in the sense of vast. Here it has the sense of best. Therefore it is said: “Excellent: best.”

original: seṭṭhā”ti. Āsabhīti usabhassa vācāsadisī acalā asampavedhī. Ekaṃso gahitoti anussavena
analyzed: seṭṭhā ati āsabhī iti usabhassa vācā asadisī acalā a sampavedhī ekaṃsaḥ gahitaḥ iti anussavena
translated: Like the voice of the bull: unshaken and unperturbed like the voice of the bull. Taken in one sense: taken by way of tradition.

original: vā ācariyaparamparāya vā itikirāya vā piṭakasampadānena vā ākāraparivitakkena vā
analyzed: vā ācariya paramparāya vā itikirāya vā piṭaka sampadānena vā ākāra parivitakkena vā
translated: or by a succession of teachers, or by hearsay, or by the approval of a text as such, or by reflection on the appearances of things,

original: diṭṭhinijjhānakkhantiyā vā takkahetu vā nayahetu vā akathetvā paccakkhato ñāṇena
analyzed: diṭṭhi nijjhāna kkhantiyā vā takka hetu vā naya hetu vā a kathetvā paccakkhataḥ ñāṇena
translated: or by a preference for particular views, or by the authority of a speculative reasoner, or by the authority of a tradition, but by his own insight into the Truth,

original: paṭivijjhitvā viya ekaṃso gahito, sanniṭṭhānakathāva kathitāti attho. Sīhanādoti
analyzed: paṭivijjhitvā viya ekaṃsaḥ gahito sanniṭṭhāna kathā ava kathitā ti attho sīha nādaḥ ti
translated: and as if he had penetrated it, he has taken up one side only, and has spoken with the certainty of one who knows.🔽The Lion’s Roar:

original: seṭṭhanādo, vane unnādayantena sīhena viya uttamanādo naditoti attho.🔽Kiṃ nu te sāriputtāti imaṃ desanaṃ kasmā ārabhi? Anuyogadāpanatthaṃ. Ekacco hi sīhanādaṃ
analyzed: seṭṭha nādaḥ vane unnādayantena sīhena viya uttama nādaḥ nadito ti attho  kim nu te sāriputta ati imam desanam kasmai ārabhi anuyoga dāpana attham ekaccaḥ hi sīha nādam
translated: the best roar. The meaning is that he has roared a roar that is the best, as a lion roars in the forest.

original: naditvā attano sīhanāde anuyogaṃ dātuṃ na sakkoti, nighaṃsanaṃ na khamati, silese
analyzed: naditvā sīha nāde anuyogam dātum na sakkoti nighaṃsanam na khamati silese
translated: Why did he begin this teaching? In order to test him. For some, after they have roared the Lion’s Roar, are unable to stand the test of it, and cannot bear the challenge. They are like a monkey that has fallen into a pit of thorns.

original: patitamakkaṭo viya hoti. Yathā dhamamānaṃ aparisuddhaṃ lohaṃ jhāyitvā aṅgāro hoti,
analyzed: patita makkaṭaḥ viya hoti yathā dhamamānam a parisuddham loham jhāyitvā aṅgāraḥ hoti
translated: Just as impure iron, when heated in the fire, becomes charcoal,

original: evaṃ jhāmaṅgāro viya hoti. Eko sīhanāde anuyogaṃ dāpiyamāno dātuṃ sakkoti, nighaṃsanaṃ
analyzed: evam jhāmaṅgāraḥ viya hoti ekaḥ sīhanāde anuyogam dāpiyamānaḥ dātum sakkoti nighaṃsanam
translated: so he becomes like a piece of charcoal that is burnt out. But another, when challenged, is able to stand the test.

original: khamati, dhamamānaṃ niddosajātarūpaṃ viya adhikataraṃ sobhati, tādiso thero. Tena
analyzed: khamati dhamamānam niddosa jātarūpam viya adhikataram sobhati tādisaḥ theraḥ tena
translated: He is one who is agreeable, who, like gold from the Jambu River, is more resplendent when polished, such is the elder.

original: naṃ bhagavā “anuyogakkhamo aya”nti ñatvā sīhanāde anuyogadāpanatthaṃ imaṃ desanaṃ ārabhi.🔽Tattha sabbe teti sabbe te tayā. Evaṃsīlāti maggasīlena phalasīlena lokiyalokuttarasīlena
analyzed: nam bhagavā anuyoga khamaḥ ayanti ñatvā sīhanāde anuyoga dāpana attham imam desanam ārabhi  tattha sabbe te iti sabbe te tayā evaṃsīlā ati magga sīlena phala sīlena lokiya lokuttara sīlena
translated: He was like a piece of iron that is heated and glows all over, and when the flame is removed it shines even more brightly than before. The Blessed One knew that the Elder was capable of being urged on, and so he began this teaching in order to urge him on with a lion’s roar.🔽Herein, all those who are such in virtue, etc., means: all those who are such in virtue, such in states, such in wisdom, such in deliverance, such in knowledge and vision of deliverance, as you are.

original: evaṃsīlā. Evaṃdhammāti ettha samādhipakkhā dhammā adhippetā, maggasamādhinā phalasamādhinā
analyzed: evaṃsīlāḥ evaṃdhammāḥ ti ettha samādhi pakkhāḥ dhammāḥ adhippetāḥ magga samādhinā phala samādhinā
translated: Such in virtue means: such in virtue of the path, such in virtue of the fruition, such in virtue of the mundane and supramundane.

original: lokiyalokuttarena samādhinā evaṃsamādhīti attho. Evaṃpaññāti maggapaññādivaseneva
analyzed: lokiya lokuttarena samādhinā evaṃsamādhī iti atthaḥ evaṃpaññā ti magga paññā ādi vasena iva
translated: Such in states means: the states that are factors of concentration are intended here. The meaning is: such in concentration of the path, such in concentration of the fruition, such in concentration of the mundane and supramundane.🔽Such in wisdom means: such in wisdom of the path, etc.

original: evaṃpaññā. Evaṃvihārinoti ettha pana heṭṭhā samādhipakkhānaṃ dhammānaṃ gahitattā
analyzed: evaṃpaññāḥ evaṃvihārino ti ettha pana heṭṭhā samādhi pakkhānam dhammānam gahita ttā
translated: Such in deliverance means: here, since the states that are factors of concentration have already been included,

original: vihāro gahitopi puna kasmā gahitameva gaṇhatīti ce. Therena idaṃ gahitameva. Idañhi
analyzed: vihāraḥ gahitaḥ api punar kasmai gahitam eva gaṇhati iti ce therena idam gahitam eva idam hi
translated: why does he include deliverance again? The Elder included it, thinking: “This is included by me.”🔽For this was said in order to illustrate the attainment of cessation.

original: nirodhasamāpattidīpanatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Tasmā evaṃ nirodhasamāpattivihārino te bhagavanto
analyzed: nirodha samāpatti dīpana attham vuttam tasmai evam nirodha samāpatti vihārinaḥ te bhagavanto
translated: Therefore, those Blessed Ones are such in the deliverance of the attainment of cessation.

original: ahesunti evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo.🔽Evaṃvimuttāti ettha vikkhambhanavimutti, tadaṅgavimutti, samucchedavimutti, paṭipassaddhivimutti,🔽nissaraṇavimuttīti pañcavidhā vimutti. Tattha aṭṭha samāpattiyo sayaṃ vikkhambhitehi
analyzed: ahesun ti evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo  evam vimuttā ti ettha vikkhambhana vimutti tad aṅga vimutti samuccheda vimutti paṭipassaddhi vimutti  nissaraṇa vimutti iti pañcavidhā vimutti tattha aṭṭha samāpattiyo sayam vikkhambhitehi
translated: This is how the meaning should be regarded here.🔽As to “freed thus”: there are five kinds of freedom, that is to say, freedom by suppression, freedom by substitution of opposites, freedom by cutting off, freedom by tranquillization, and freedom by renunciation.

original: nīvaraṇādīhi vimuttattā vikkhambhanavimuttīti saṅkhaṃ gacchanti. Aniccānupassanādikā
analyzed: nīvaraṇa ādīhi vimutta ttā vikkhambhana vimutti iti saṅkham gacchanti anicca anupassanā ādikā
translated: Herein, the eight attainments are called “freedom by suppression” because they are freed by the supressions of the hindrances, etc., respectively.

original: satta anupassanā sayaṃ tassa tassa paccanīkavasena pariccattāhi niccasaññādīhi vimuttattā🔽tadaṅgavimuttīti saṅkhaṃ gacchanti. Cattāro ariyamaggā sayaṃ samucchinnehi kilesehi🔽vimuttattā samucchedavimuttīti saṅkhaṃ gacchanti. Cattāri sāmaññaphalāni maggānubhāvena
analyzed: satta anupassanā sayam tassa tassa paccanīka vasena pariccattāhi nicca saññā ādīhi vimutta ttā  tad aṅga vimutti iti saṅkham gacchanti cattāraḥ ariya maggā sayam samucchinnehi kilesehi  vimutta ttā samuccheda vimutti iti saṅkham gacchanti cattāri sāmañña phalāni magga anubhāvena
translated: The seven contemplations beginning with that of impermanence are called “freedom by substitution of opposites” because they are freed by the opposite of the opposite of the perception of permanence, and so on.🔽The four noble paths are called “freedom by cutting off” because they are freed by the cutting off of defilements.🔽The four fruits of the life of purity are called “freedom by tranquillization” because they are freed by the tranquillization of defilements by the influence of the paths.

original: kilesānaṃ paṭipassaddhante uppannattā paṭipassaddhivimuttīti saṅkhaṃ gacchanti. Nibbānaṃ
analyzed: kilesānam paṭipassaddha nte uppanna ttā paṭipassaddhi vimutti iti saṅkham gacchanti nibbānam
translated: Nibbāna is called “freedom by renunciation” because it is freed by the renunciation of all suffering.

original: sabbakilesehi nissaṭattā apagatattā dūre ṭhitattā nissaraṇavimuttīti saṅkhaṃ gataṃ.
analyzed: sabba kilesehi nissaṭa ttā apagata ttā dūre ṭhita ttā nissaraṇa vimutti iti saṅkham gatam
translated: and because of being freed from all defilements, because of being devoid of them, because of being far removed from them, it is called the emancipation of renunciation.

original: Iti imāsaṃ pañcannaṃ vimuttīnaṃ vasena evaṃ vimuttāti ettha attho daṭṭhabbo.🔽Kiṃ pana te sāriputta ye te bhavissantīti atītā tāva niruddhā apaṇṇattikabhāvaṃ gatā
analyzed: iti imāsam pañcannam vimuttīnam vasena evam vimuttā iti ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo  kim pana te sāriputta ye te bhavissanti iti atītā tāva niruddhā apaṇṇattika bhāvam gatā
translated: So the meaning here in the phrase “thus emancipated” should be seen in terms of these five kinds of emancipation.🔽But how will you know, Sāriputta, those who will be in the future? For those who have already arisen have ceased, have passed away, have disappeared, have changed; they have become otherwise, like a lamp’s going out.

original: dīpasikhā viya nibbutā, evaṃ niruddhe apaṇṇattikabhāvaṃ gate tvaṃ kathaṃ jānissasi,
analyzed: dīpasikhāḥ viya nibbutāḥ evam niruddhe apaṇṇattika bhāvam gate tvam katham jānissasi
translated: How will you know those who have ceased, who have passed away, who have disappeared, who have changed; who have become otherwise, like a lamp’s going out?

original: anāgatabuddhānaṃ pana guṇā kiṃ tayā attano cittena paricchinditvā viditāti pucchanto evamāha.
analyzed: anāgata buddhānam pana guṇā kim tayā cittena paricchinditvā viditā ati pucchantaḥ evam āha
translated: But how will you know the qualities of future Buddhas by discerning them with your own mind?

original: Kiṃ pana tyāhaṃ sāriputta etarahīti anāgatāpi buddhā ajātā anibbattā anuppannā, te
analyzed: kim pana tyā aham sāriputta etarahi iti anāgatāḥ api buddhāḥ a jātāḥ a nibbattāḥ an uppannā te
translated: But how will you know, Sāriputta, those who are at present? For future Buddhas have not yet arisen, have not yet been born, have not yet appeared;

original: kathaṃ jānissasi. Tesañhi jānanaṃ apade ākāse padadassanaṃ viya hoti. Idāni mayā
analyzed: katham jānissasi tesam hi jānanam apade ākāse pada dassanam viya hoti idāni mayā
translated: how will you know them? For to know them would be like seeing footsteps on the ground in the sky.

original: saddhiṃ ekavihāre vasasi, ekato bhikkhāya carasi, dhammadesanākāle dakkhiṇapasse
analyzed: saddhim eka vihāre vasasi ekatas bhikkhāya carasi dhamma desanā kāle dakkhiṇa passe
translated: Now you live in the same monastery as I do, you go on alms round in the same place as I do, at the time of teaching the Dhamma you sit on the same seat as I do,

original: nisīdasi, kiṃ pana mayhaṃ guṇā attano cetasā paricchinditvā viditā tayāti anuyuñjanto
analyzed: nisīdasi kim pana mayham guṇāḥ cetasā paricchinditvā viditā tayā ati anuyuñjantaḥ
translated: “You sit in the Teacher’s place, but do you know my special qualities by your own mind?”

original: evamāha. Thero pana pucchitapucchite “no hetaṃ bhante”ti paṭikkhipati.
analyzed: evam āha theraḥ pana pucchita pucchite no ha etam bhante iti paṭikkhipati
translated: The Elder replied, “No, venerable sir.”

original: Therassa ca viditampi atthi, aviditampi. Kiṃ so attano viditaṭṭhāne paṭikkhepaṃ karoti,🔽aviditaṭṭhāneti? Viditaṭṭhāne na karoti, aviditaṭṭhāneyeva karoti. Thero kira anuyoge
analyzed: therassa ca viditam pi atthi aviditam pi kim so attanaḥ vidita ṭṭhāne paṭikkhepam karoti  avidita ṭṭhānā iti vidita ṭṭhāne na karoti karoti thero anuyoge
translated: The Elder knew some things and did not know other things. Did he deny what he knew and affirm what he did not know?

original: āraddhe evaṃ aññāsi “nāyaṃ anuyogo sāvakapāramīñāṇe, sabbaññutaññāṇe pana ayaṃ anuyogo”ti
analyzed: āraddhe evam na ayam anuyogo sāvaka pāramī ñāṇe sabbaññuta ññāṇe pana ayam anuyogo ti
translated: He did not deny what he knew nor affirm what he did not know. The Elder understood thus: “This is not an inquiry into the knowledge of the perfection of the disciple; this is an inquiry into the knowledge of omniscience.”

original: attano sāvakapāramīñāṇe paṭikkhepaṃ akatvāva aviditaṭṭhāne sabbaññutaññāṇe paṭikkhepaṃ🔽karoti. Tena idampi dīpeti – bhagavā mayhaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṃ buddhānaṃ sīlasamādhipaññāvimuttikāraṇajānanasamatthaṃ
analyzed: attanaḥ sāvaka pāramī ñāṇe paṭikkhepam a katvā ava avidita ṭṭhāne sabbaññuta ññāṇe paṭikkhepam  karoti tena idam api dīpeti bhagavā mayham atīta anāgata paccuppannānam buddhānam sīla samādhi paññā vimutti kāraṇa jānana samattham
translated: Therefore, without denying what he knew, namely, the knowledge of the perfection of the disciple, he denied what he did not know, namely, the knowledge of omniscience.

original: sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ natthīti.
analyzed: sabbaññuta ññāṇam na atthi iti
translated: Thus he showed that the Exalted One did not have the knowledge of omniscience, which is able to know the virtue, concentration, wisdom, emancipation, and the knowledge and vision of emancipation of the Buddhas of the past, future, and present.

original: Etthāti etesu atītādibhedesu buddhesu. Atha kiñcarahīti atha kasmā evaṃ ñāṇe asati🔽tayā evaṃ kathitanti vadati. Dhammanvayoti dhammassa paccakkhato ñāṇassa anuyogaṃ
analyzed: ettha iti etesu atīta ādi bhedesu buddhesu atha kiñcarahi iti atha kasmai evam ñāṇe asati  tayā evam kathitanti vadati dhamma anvayaḥ ti dhammassa paccakkhataḥ ñāṇassa anuyogam
translated: ‘But how do you know?’ means ‘but how is it that you say thus when you do not have such knowledge?’🔽‘The inference of the Dhamma’ is the inferential knowledge that arises following the pursuit of the knowledge of the Dhamma by direct perception.

original: anugantvā uppannaṃ anumānañāṇaṃ nayaggāho vidito, sāvakapāramīñāṇe ṭhatvāva iminā
analyzed: anugantvā uppannam anumāna ñāṇam naya ggāhaḥ viditaḥ sāvaka pāramī ñāṇe iminā
translated: Having stood in the knowledge of the perfection of the disciple, he says, ‘I know the Blessed One in this way.’

original: ākārena jānāmi bhagavāti vadati. Therassa hi nayaggāho appamāṇo apariyanto. Yathā
analyzed: ākārena jānāmi bhagavā iti vadati therassa hi naya ggāhaḥ appamāṇaḥ a pariyantaḥ yathā
translated: For the Elder’s inference is immeasurable and unlimited.

original: ca sabbaññutaññāṇassa pamāṇaṃ vā pariyanto vā natthi, evaṃ dhammasenāpatino nayaggāhassa.
analyzed: ca sabbaññu ta ññāṇassa pamāṇam vā pariyantaḥ vā natthi evam dhamma senāpatinaḥ naya ggāhassa
translated: And just as there is no measure or limit to omniscient knowledge, so also there is none to the Elder’s inference.

original: Tena so – “iminā evaṃvidho iminā evaṃvidho, iminā anuttaro iminā anuttaro satthā”ti
analyzed: tena saḥ iminā evaṃvidhaḥ iminā evaṃvidhaḥ iminā anuttaraḥ iminā anuttaraḥ satthā ati
translated: Therefore he knows, ‘By this one is of such a kind, by this one is of such a kind, by this one is unsurpassed, by this one is the unsurpassed Teacher.’

original: jānāti. Therassa hi nayaggāho sabbaññutaññāṇagatiko eva.
analyzed: jānāti therassa hi naya ggāhaḥ sabbaññu taññāṇa gatikaḥ eva
translated: For the Elder’s inference is in conformity with omniscient knowledge.

original: Idāni taṃ nayaggāhaṃ pākaṭaṃ kātuṃ upamaṃ dassento seyyathāpi bhantetiādimāha. Tattha
analyzed: idāni tam naya ggāham pākaṭam kātum upamam dassentaḥ seyyathā api bhante ti ādim āha tattha
translated: Now, in order to make that inference clear, he gives a simile, beginning with the words ‘It is just as if, venerable sir.’ Herein,

original: yasmā majjhimadese nagarassa uddhāpapākārādīni thirāni vā hontu dubbalāni vā, sabbaso
analyzed: yasmai majjhima dese nagarassa uddhā papākāra ādīni thirāni vā hontu dubbalāni vā sabbaso
translated: In the Middle Country, whether the city’s ramparts and so on are strong or weak,

original: vā pana mā hontu, corānaṃ āsaṅkā na hoti. Tasmā taṃ aggahetvā paccantimaṃ nagaranti
analyzed: vā pana mā hontu corānam āsaṅkā na hoti tasmā tam aggahetvā paccantimam
translated: or whether they are absent altogether, there is no fear of thieves. Therefore, leaving out the Middle Country, he said “a frontier city.”

original: āha. Daḷhuddhāpanti thiramūlapākāraṃ. Daḷhapākāratoraṇanti thirapākārañceva thirapiṭṭhasaṅghāṭañca.
analyzed: āha thira mūla pākāram daḷha pākāra toraṇanti thira pākāram ca iva thira piṭṭha saṅghāṭam ca
translated: “With strong ramparts” means with strong foundations and ramparts. “With strong gates” means with strong ramparts and a strong rear wall.

original: Ekadvāranti kasmā āha? Bahudvāre hi nagare bahūhi paṇḍitadovārikehi bhavitabbaṃ,🔽ekadvāreva eko vaṭṭati. Therassa ca paññāya sadiso añño natthi, tasmā attano paṇḍitabhāvassa
analyzed: eka dvāram ti kasmai āha bahu dvāre hi nagare bahūhi paṇḍita dovārikehi bhavitabbam  eka dvārā iva ekaḥ vaṭṭati therassa ca paññāya sadisaḥ aññaḥ na atthi tasmai attano paṇḍita bhāvassa
translated: Why did he say “with one gate”? For in a city with many gates there must be many gatekeepers,

original: opammatthaṃ ekaṃyeva dovārikaṃ dassetuṃ “ekadvāra”nti āha.🔽Paṇḍitoti paṇḍiccena samannāgato. Byattoti veyyattiyena samannāgato visadañāṇo. Medhāvīti
analyzed: opamma attham ekam yeva dovārikam dassetum eka dvāram ti āha  paṇḍito ti paṇḍiccena samannāgataḥ byatto ti veyyattiyena samannāgataḥ visada ñāṇaḥ medhāvī iti
translated: but with one gate only one is sufficient. And since there is no one equal to the Elder in wisdom, he said “with one gate” in order to show that he alone is the gatekeeper, as it were, for the purpose of illustrating his own wisdom.

original: ṭhānuppattikapaññāsaṅkhātāya medhāya samannāgato. Anupariyāyapathanti anupariyāyanāmakaṃ
analyzed: ṭhānuppattika paññā saṅkhātāya medhāya samannāgataḥ anupariyāya pathanti anupariyāya nāmakam
translated: “Wise” means endowed with wisdom. “Able” means endowed with ability, with clear knowledge. “Intelligent” means endowed with the intelligence called “insight.” “With one path of access” means with one path of access called “guarding.”

original: pākāramaggaṃ. Pākārasandhinti dvinnaṃ iṭṭhakānaṃ apagataṭṭhānaṃ. Pākāravivaranti
analyzed: pākāra maggam pākāra sandhinti dvinnam iṭṭhakānam apagata ṭṭhānam pākāra vivaranti
translated: the path of the rampart. The junction of the rampart: the place where two bricks are not separated. The gap in the rampart:

original: pākārassa chinnaṭṭhānaṃ. Cetaso upakkileseti pañcanīvaraṇā cittaṃ upakkilissanti
analyzed: pākārassa chinna ṭṭhānam cetasaḥ upakkileseti pañca nīvaraṇā cittam upakkilissanti
translated: the place where the rampart is broken. The defilements of the mind: the five hindrances defile the mind,

original: kiliṭṭhaṃ karonti upatāpenti viheṭhenti, tasmā “cetaso upakkilesā”ti vuccanti. Paññāya
analyzed: kiliṭṭham karonti upatāpenti viheṭhenti tasmā cetasaḥ upakkilesā ti vuccanti paññāya
translated: they make it dirty, they torment it, they harm it, therefore they are called “the defilements of the mind.”

original: dubbalīkaraṇeti nīvaraṇā uppajjamānā anuppannāya paññāya uppajjituṃ na denti, tasmā
analyzed: dubbalīkaraṇa iti nīvaraṇāḥ uppajjamānāḥ anuppannāya paññāya uppajjitum na denti tasmai
translated: The weakening of wisdom: the hindrances, when they arise, do not allow wisdom that has not yet arisen to arise, therefore

original: “paññāya dubbalīkaraṇā”ti vuccanti. Supatiṭṭhitacittāti catūsu satipaṭṭhānesu suṭṭhu
analyzed: paññāya dubbalīkaraṇā ti vuccanti su patiṭṭhita cittā ati catūsu sati paṭṭhānesu suṭṭhu
translated: they are called “the weakening of wisdom.” The well-established mind: having become well established in the four foundations of mindfulness.

original: ṭhapitacittā hutvā. Satta bojjhaṅge yathābhūtanti satta bojjhaṅge yathāsabhāvena
analyzed: ṭhapita cittāḥ hutvā satta bojjhaṅge satta bojjhaṅge yathā sabhāvena
translated: The seven factors of enlightenment as they really are: having developed the seven factors of enlightenment according to their true nature.

original: bhāvetvā. Anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhinti arahattaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ paṭivijjhiṃsūti dasseti.
analyzed: bhāvetvā anuttaram sammāsambodhin ti arahattam sabbaññu ta ññāṇam paṭivijjhiṃsu iti dasseti
translated: The supreme full enlightenment: he shows that they penetrated the state of arahantship and the knowledge of omniscience.

original: Apicettha satipaṭṭhānāti vipassanā, bojjhaṅgā maggo, anuttarasammāsambodhi arahattaṃ.
analyzed: apica ittha sati paṭṭhānā ati vipassanā bojjhaṅgā maggaḥ anuttara sammāsambodhi arahattam
translated: And here the foundations of mindfulness are insight, the factors of enlightenment are the path, and the supreme full enlightenment is arahantship.

original: Satipaṭṭhānāti vā vipassanā, bojjhaṅgāmissakā, sammāsambodhi arahattameva. Dīghabhāṇakamahāsīvatthero
analyzed: sati paṭṭhānā ati vā vipassanā bojjhaṅgā amissakā sammāsambodhi arahattam eva dīghabhāṇaka mahāsīva thero
translated: Or else the foundations of mindfulness are insight, the enlightenment factors are the path, and the supreme enlightenment is Arahantship.

original: panāha “satipaṭṭhāne vipassanaṃ gahetvā bojjhaṅge maggo ca sabbaññutaññāṇañcāti gahite
analyzed: pana āha sati paṭṭhāne vipassanam gahetvā bojjhaṅge maggo ca sabbaññuta ññāṇam ca ati gahite
translated: The Elder Mahā-Sīva, a reciter of the Digha Nikāya, said: “If the foundations of mindfulness were taken as insight, and the enlightenment factors and the path were taken as the knowledge of omniscience,🔽then the question would be a good one. But it is not so taken.”

original: sundaro pañho bhaveyya, na panevaṃ gahita”nti. Iti thero sabbabuddhānaṃ nīvaraṇappahāne
analyzed: sundaraḥ pañhaḥ bhaveyya na pana ivam gahitan ti iti thero sabba buddhānam nīvaraṇa ppahāne
translated: So the Elder shows that in the abandoning of the hindrances by all Buddhas,

original: satipaṭṭhānabhāvanāya sambodhiyañca majjhe bhinnasuvaṇṇarajatānaṃ viya nānattābhāvaṃ dasseti.
analyzed: sati paṭṭhāna bhāvanāya sambodhiyan ca majjhe bhinna suvaṇṇa rajatānam viya nānatta abhāvam dasseti
translated: in the development of the foundations of mindfulness, and in the supreme enlightenment, there is no difference, like that between gold and silver, as there is between the different kinds of trees.

original: Idha ṭhatvā upamā saṃsandetabbā – āyasmā hi sāriputto paccantanagaraṃ dassesi, pākāraṃ🔽dassesi, anupariyāyapathaṃ dassesi, dvāraṃ dassesi, paṇḍitadovārikaṃ dassesi, nagaraṃ
analyzed: idha upamā saṃsandetabbā  āyasmā hi sāriputto paccanta nagaram dassesi pākāram  dassesi anupariyāya patham dassesi dvāram dassesi paṇḍita dovārikam dassesi nagaram
translated: Here the simile may be completed: the venerable Sāriputta showed the city,🔽showed the rampart,🔽showed the encircling road, showed the gate, showed the gatekeeper,

original: pavisanakanikkhamanake oḷārike pāṇe dassesi, dovārikassa tesaṃ pāṇānaṃ pākaṭabhāvaṃ
analyzed: pavisanaka nikkhamanake oḷārike pāṇe dassesi dovārikassa tesam pāṇānam pākaṭa bhāvam
translated: showed the great crowd of people entering and leaving the city, and showed the gatekeeper’s clear view of the people entering and leaving the city.

original: dassesi. Tattha kiṃ kena sadisanti ce? Nagaraṃ viya hi nibbānaṃ, pākāro viya sīlaṃ,
analyzed: dassesi tattha kim kena sadisanti ce nagaram viya hi nibbānam pākāraḥ viya sīlam
translated: What is it like? Nibbāna is like a city, virtue is like a rampart,

original: anupariyāyapatho viya hirī, dvāraṃ viya ariyamaggo, paṇḍitadovāriko viya dhammasenāpati,
analyzed: anupariyāya pathaḥ viya hirī dvāram viya ariya maggo paṇḍita dovārikaḥ viya dhamma senāpati
translated: conscience is like a moat, the noble path is like a gate, the general of the Dhamma is like a gatekeeper,

original: nagaraṃ pavisanakanikkhamanakā oḷārikapāṇā viya atītānāgatapaccuppannā buddhā, dovārikassa
analyzed: nagaram pavisanaka nikkhamanakāḥ oḷārika pāṇāḥ viya atīta anāgata paccuppannāḥ buddhāḥ dovārikassa
translated: and the Buddhas of the past, future, and present are like the people who enter and leave the city.🔽Just as the gatekeeper is aware of those people,

original: tesaṃ pāṇānaṃ pākaṭabhāvo viya āyasmato sāriputtassa atītānāgatapaccuppannānaṃ buddhānaṃ
analyzed: tesam pāṇānam pākaṭa bhāvaḥ viya āyasmataḥ sāriputtassa atīta anāgata paccuppannānam buddhānam
translated: so the Venerable Sāriputta is aware of the Buddhas of the past, future, and present

original: sīlasamathādīhi pākaṭabhāvo. Ettāvatā therena bhagavato – “evamahaṃ sāvakapāramīñāṇe
analyzed: sīla samatha ādīhi pākaṭa bhāvaḥ ettāvatā therena bhagavataḥ evam aham sāvaka pāramī ñāṇe
translated: through their virtue, concentration, etc. Up to this point the Elder has said: “Thus, standing in the knowledge of the perfection of discipleship,

original: ṭhatvā dhammanvayena nayaggāhena jānāmī”ti attano sīhanādassa anuyogo dinno hoti.
analyzed: ṭhatvā dhamma nvayena naya ggāhena jānāmi iti attanaḥ sīhanādassa anuyogaḥ dinnaḥ hoti
translated: I know by inference through the Dhamma the Buddhas of the past, future, and present.” He has thus given his own lion’s roar.

original: Tasmāti yasmā “na kho metaṃ, bhante, atītānāgatapaccuppannesu arahantesu sammāsambuddhesu
analyzed: tasmā iti yasmā na kho mā etam bhante atīta anāgata paccuppannesu arahantesu sammāsambuddhesu
translated: “Therefore” : since “I do not know, venerable sir, whether the Blessed One is superior or the venerable Sāriputta is superior” ,

original: cetopariyañāṇaṃ atthi, apica dhammanvayo vidito”ti vadati, tasmā. Abhikkhaṇaṃ bhāseyyāsīti🔽punappunaṃ bhāseyyāsi, “pubbaṇhe me kathita”nti mā majjhanhikādīsu na kathayittha,
analyzed: cetas pariya ñāṇam atthi apica dhamma anvayaḥ vidito ti vadati tasmai abhikkhaṇam bhāseyyāsi iti  punappunam bhāseyyāsi pubbaṇhe me kathitanti mā majjhanhika ādīsu na kathayittha
translated: Therefore,🔽Speak again and again:🔽“I was told in the morning,” do not fail to tell it in the middle of the day and so on.

original: “ajja vā me kathita”nti mā paradivasādīsu na kathayitthāti attho. Sā pahīyissatīti🔽“sāriputtasadisopi nāma ñāṇajavanasampanno sāvako buddhānaṃ cittācāraṃ jānituṃ na
analyzed: ajja vā me kathitanti mā para divasa ādīsu na kathayittha ati attho sā pahīyissati iti  sāriputta sadisaḥ api nāma ñāṇa javana sampannaḥ sāvakaḥ buddhānam citta ācāram jānitum na
translated: “I was told today,” do not fail to tell it on the following day and so on.🔽That doubt will be abandoned.

original: sakkoti, evaṃ appameyyā tathāgatā”ti cintentānaṃ yā tathāgate kaṅkhā vā vimati vā, sā pahīyissatīti.
analyzed: sakkoti evam appameyyā tathāgatā ati cintentānam yā tathāgate kaṅkhā vā vimati vā sā pahīyissati iti
translated: “Even a disciple of the Buddhas who is endowed with knowledge and swiftness like Sariputta cannot know the thought- activity of the Buddhas. In this way the Tathagatas are immeasurable.” The doubt or uncertainty that arises in those who think in this way will be abandoned.🔽. Commentary

original: 3. Cundasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: cunda sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: Cundasutta:

original: 379. Tatiye magadhesūti evaṃnāmake janapade. Nālakagāmaketi rājagahassa avidūre attano
analyzed: tatiye magadhesu iti evaṃnāmake janapade nālakagāmaka iti rājagahassa avidūre
translated: In the third sutta, the Buddha says that he was staying in Magadha, in the village of Nala, in the house of Cunda the smith.

original: kulasantake evaṃnāmake gāme. Cundo samaṇuddesoti ayaṃ thero dhammasenāpatissa kaniṭṭhabhātiko,
analyzed: kulasantake evaṃnāmake gāme cundaḥ samaṇuddeso ti ayam theraḥ dhammasenāpatissa kaniṭṭha bhātiko
translated: Cunda was the younger brother of the Venerable Dhammapala, the chief disciple of the Buddha in wisdom.

original: taṃ bhikkhū anupasampannakāle “cundo samaṇuddeso”ti samudācaritvā therakālepi tatheva
analyzed: tam bhikkhū an upasampanna kāle cundaḥ samaṇuddeso ti samudācaritvā thera kāle pi tathā iva
translated: The monks, having treated him as a novice monk when he was not fully admitted, continued to treat him as a novice monk when he was an elder.

original: samudācariṃsu. Tena vuttaṃ “cundo samaṇuddeso”ti. Upaṭṭhāko hotīti mukhodakadantakaṭṭhadānena
analyzed: samudācariṃsu tena vuttam cundo samaṇa uddeso ti upaṭṭhākaḥ hoti iti mukha udaka danta kaṭṭha dānena
translated: The monks, when he was not yet fully admitted, addressed him as “the novice Cunda”; and when he was an elder, they still addressed him as “the novice Cunda.” Hence “the novice Cunda.”

original: ceva pariveṇasammajjana-piṭṭhiparikammakaraṇa-pattacīvaraggahaṇena ca upaṭṭhānakaro
analyzed: ca iva pariveṇa sammajjana piṭṭhi parikamma karaṇa patta cīvara ggahaṇena ca upaṭṭhāna karo
translated: Attended on him: he attended on him by giving him water for washing and a toothstick, by sweeping out the cell, by massaging his back when bathing, and by taking his bowl and robe.

original: hoti. Parinibbāyīti anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbuto. Katarasmiṃ kāleti?
analyzed: hoti parinibbāyī iti anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbutaḥ katarasmin kāle iti
translated: Had attained final Nibbāna: had attained final Nibbāna in the Nibbāna-element without residue of clinging left.🔽In which year?

original: Bhagavato parinibbānasaṃvacchare.🔽Tatrāyaṃ anupubbikathā – bhagavā kira vutthavasso veḷuvagāmakā nikkhamitvā “sāvatthiṃ
analyzed: bhagavataḥ parinibbāna saṃvacchare  tatra ayam anupubbi kathā bhagavā kira vuttha vassaḥ veḷuva gāmakā nikkhamitvā sāvatthim
translated: In the year of the Blessed One’s final Nibbāna.🔽Here is the connected story. The Blessed One, it seems, after spending the Rains, left the village of Veḷuva and, intending to go to Sāvatthī, turned back by the same route by which he had come.

original: gamissāmī”ti āgatamaggeneva paṭinivattanto anupubbena sāvatthiṃ patvā jetavanaṃ pāvisi.
analyzed: gamissāmi iti āgata maggena iva paṭinivattantaḥ anupubbena sāvatthim patvā jetavanam pāvisi
translated: In due course he reached Sāvatthī and entered Jeta’s Wood.

original: Dhammasenāpati bhagavato vattaṃ dassetvā divāṭṭhānaṃ gato, so tattha antevāsikesu
analyzed: dhammasenāpati bhagavataḥ vattam dassetvā divāṭṭhānam gataḥ so tattha antevāsikesu
translated: The general of the Dhamma, after showing the Blessed One hospitality, went to his own lodging for his midday rest.

original: vattaṃ dassetvā paṭikkantesu divāṭṭhānaṃ sammajjitvā cammakhaṇḍaṃ paññāpetvā pāde
analyzed: vattam dassetvā paṭikkantesu divāṭṭhānam sammajjitvā camma khaṇḍam paññāpetvā pāde
translated: After they had shown him the proper respect and departed, he swept the day-quarters, spread out a piece of leather,

original: pakkhāletvā pallaṅkaṃ ābhujitvā phalasamāpattiṃ pāvisi. Athassa yathā paricchedena
analyzed: pakkhāletvā pallaṅkam ābhujitvā phala samāpattim pāvisi athassa yathā paricchedena
translated: washed his feet, sat down cross-legged, and entered into the attainment of fruit. Then, as far as the limits of his knowledge,

original: tato vuṭṭhitassa ayaṃ parivitakko udapādi “buddhā nu kho paṭhamaṃ parinibbāyanti,
analyzed: tatas vuṭṭhitassa ayam parivitakkaḥ udapādi buddhāḥ nu kho paṭhamam parinibbāyanti
translated: he emerged from that attainment and this thought arose: “Do the Buddhas attain final Nibbāna first,

original: udāhu aggasāvakāti, tato “aggasāvakā paṭhama”nti ñatvā attano āyusaṅkhāraṃ olokesi.
analyzed: udāhu aggasāvakā iti tatas aggasāvakā paṭhamanti ñatvā attanaḥ āyu saṅkhāram olokesi
translated: or do the chief disciples?” Then, knowing that the chief disciples attain final Nibbāna first, he considered his own life-constituent.

original: So “sattāhameva me āyusaṅkhārā pavattissantī”ti ñatvā “kattha parinibbāyissāmī”ti cintesi.
analyzed: saḥ sattāham eva me āyu saṅkhārāḥ pavattissanti iti ñatvā kattha parinibbāyissāmi iti cintesi
translated: He knew that his life-constituent would last for seven days. Then he thought: “Where shall I attain final Nibbāna?”

original: Tato “rāhulo tāvatiṃsesu parinibbuto, aññāsikoṇḍaññatthero chaddantadahe, ahaṃ kattha
analyzed: tatas rāhulaḥ tāvatiṃsesu parinibbutaḥ aññāsikoṇḍañña thero chaddanta dahe aham kattha
translated: Then he thought again and again: “Rāhula attained final Nibbāna in the Tāvatiṃsa heaven, the elder Aññāsikoṇḍañña in the Chaddanta forest, and I shall attain final Nibbāna where?”

original: parinibbāyissāmī”ti punappunaṃ cintento mātaraṃ ārabbha satiṃ uppādesi – “mayhaṃ
analyzed: parinibbāyissāmi iti punappunam cintentaḥ mātaram ārabbha satim uppādesi mayham
translated: Thinking thus, he aroused mindfulness in regard to his mother: “My mother,

original: mātā sattannaṃ arahantānaṃ mātā hutvāpi buddhadhammasaṅghesu appasannā, atthi nu
analyzed: mātā sattannam arahantānam mātā hutvā api buddha dhamma saṅghesu appasannā atthi nu
translated: though she was the mother of seven arahants, was not confident in the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha. Is there

original: kho tassā upanissayo, natthi nu kho”ti. Sotāpattimaggassa upanissayaṃ disvā “kassa🔽desanāya abhisamayo bhavissatī”ti olokento “mameva dhammadesanāya bhavissati, na🔽aññassa. Sace kho panāhaṃ appossukko bhaveyyaṃ, bhavissanti me vattāro – “sāriputtatthero🔽avasesajanānampi avassayo hoti. Tathā hissa samacittasuttantadesanādivase koṭisatasahassadevatā🔽arahattaṃ pattā, tayo magge paṭividdhadevatānaṃ gaṇanā natthi, aññesu ca ṭhānesu🔽anekā abhisamayā dissanti, there ca cittaṃ pasādetvā sagge nibbattāneva asīti kulasahassāni,
analyzed: kho tassāḥ upanissayaḥ natthi nu kho ti sotāpatti maggassa upanissayam disvā kassa  desanāya abhisamayaḥ bhavissati iti olokentaḥ mama eva dhamma desanāya bhavissati na  aññassa sace kho pana aham appa ussukkaḥ bhaveyyam bhavissanti me vattāraḥ sāriputta thero  avasesa janānam pi avassayaḥ hoti tathā hissa sama citta suttanta desanā divase koṭi sata sahassa devatā  arahattam pattā tayaḥ magge paṭividdha devatānam gaṇanā natthi aññesu ca ṭhānesu  aneke abhisamayāḥ dissanti there ca cittam pasādetvā sagge asīti kula sahassāni
translated: “Is there no support for it?” Seeing the support for the stream-entry path, he looked to see “By whose teaching will there be penetration?” He saw, “By my teaching, not by anyone else’s. But if I were to be lazy, there would be those who would say, ‘The Elder Sāriputta🔽was a support for the rest of the people. For on the day he gave the teaching of the Discourse on Equanimity, a hundred thousand koṭis of deities attained arahatship, and the number of deities who penetrated the three paths was incalculable. And in other places too🔽many penetrations are seen. And eighty thousand families, having developed confidence in the Elder and been reborn in the heavenly world,🔽

original: so dāni sakamātumicchādassanamattampi harituṃ nāsakkhī”ti. Tasmā mātaraṃ micchādassanā🔽mocetvā jātovarakeyeva parinibbāyissāmī”ti sanniṭṭhānaṃ katvā “ajjeva bhagavantaṃ
analyzed: saḥ dāni saka mātu micchādassana mattam pi haritum na asakkhi iti tasmā mātaram micchādassanā 🔽mocetvā jātovarakeyā iva parinibbāyissāmi iti sanniṭṭhānam katvā ajja eva bhagavantam
translated: “Is there no one who can be his support?” Seeing that there was no one who could be his support, he thought, “By whose teaching will he attain the path?” Seeing that it would be by his own teaching, he thought, “If I do not make an effort, people will say that the Elder Sāriputta was the support of the rest of the people. For on the day that he preached the Sāma Citta Sutta, a hundred thousand koṭis of deities attained arahatship, and the number of deities who had attained the three paths was incalculable. In other places also many attained the paths. Eighty thousand families were established in the refuges and precepts by the Elder, who inspired them with confidence. He was unable to deliver his own mother from wrong views, and he was unable to see her even when he wished to. Therefore I will deliver my mother from wrong views and attain Nibbāna in the place where I was born.” Having thus resolved, he said to the Exalted One, “To-day, Lord, I will deliver my mother from wrong views and attain Nibbāna in the place where I was born.”

original: anujānāpetvā nikkhamissāmī”ti cundattheraṃ āmantesi – “āvuso, cunda, amhākaṃ pañcasatāya🔽bhikkhuparisāya saññaṃ dehi. ‘Gaṇhathāvuso pattacīvarāni, dhammasenāpati nālakagāmaṃ
analyzed: anujānāpetvā nikkhamissāmi iti cunda theram āmantesi āvuso cunda amhākam pañca satāya  bhikkhu parisāya saññam dehi gaṇhatha āvuso patta cīvarāni dhammasenāpati nālakagāmam
translated: “I will go forth after having had permission.” He addressed the Elder Cunda: “Friend Cunda, give notice to our five hundred bhikkhu

original: gantukāmo”’ti. Thero tathā akāsi.
analyzed: gantu kāmaḥ iti theraḥ tathā akāsi
translated: community: ‘Friends, take your bowls and robes. The General of the Dhamma wishes to go to Nāḷakagāma.’” The Elder did as he was asked.

original: Bhikkhū senāsanaṃ saṃsāmetvā pattacīvaramādāya therassa santikaṃ agamaṃsu. Thero
analyzed: bhikkhū senāsanam saṃsāmetvā patta cīvaram ādāya therassa santikam agamaṃsu thero
translated: The bhikkhus put their resting places in order, took their bowls and robes, and went to the Elder. The Elder

original: senāsanaṃ saṃsāmetvā divāṭṭhānaṃ sammajjitvā divāṭṭhānadvāre ṭhatvā divāṭṭhānaṃ oloketvā
analyzed: senāsanam saṃsāmetvā divāṭṭhānam sammajjitvā divāṭṭhāna dvāre ṭhatvā divāṭṭhānam oloketvā
translated: put his resting place in order, swept the yard of the rest house, stood at the door of the rest house, looked at the rest house,

original: “idaṃ dāni pacchimadassanaṃ, puna āgamanaṃ natthī”ti pañcasatabhikkhūhi parivuto
analyzed: idam dāni pacchima dassanam puna āgamanam natthi iti pañca sata bhikkhūhi parivutaḥ
translated: and thought, “This is the last time I shall see this rest house.” Surrounded by the five hundred bhikkhus, he

original: bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca “anujānātu me bhante bhagavā,
analyzed: bhagavantam upasaṅkamitvā vanditvā bhagavantam etat avoca anujānātu me bhante bhagavā
translated: went to the Exalted One, saluted him, and said, “Lord, let the Exalted One permit me.

original: anujānātu sugato. Parinibbānakālo me, ossaṭṭho me āyusaṅkhāro”ti. Buddhā pana yasmā
analyzed: anujānātu sugataḥ parinibbāna kālaḥ me ossaṭṭhaḥ me āyu saṅkhāraḥ iti buddhāḥ pana yasmā
translated: Let the Well-Farer permit me. The time has come for my complete extinction. My life-span is at an end.” But the Buddhas,🔽because they are compassionate by nature,

original: “parinibbāhī”ti vutte maraṇavaṇṇaṃ saṃvaṇṇentīti, “mā parinibbāhī”ti vutte vaṭṭassa
analyzed: parinibbāhi iti vutte maraṇa vaṇṇam saṃvaṇṇenti iti mā parinibbāhi iti vutte vaṭṭassa
translated: “If we say ‘Enter Nibbana,’ they will say that we are praising death.🔽If we say ‘Do not enter Nibbana,’ they will say that we are praising the round of rebirths.

original: guṇaṃ kathentīti micchādiṭṭhikā dosaṃ āropessanti, tasmā tadubhayampi na vadanti.
analyzed: guṇam kathenti iti micchādiṭṭhikāḥ dosam āropessanti tasmā tat ubhayam pi na vadanti
translated: Therefore we will say neither.”

original: Tena naṃ bhagavā – “kattha parinibbāyissasi sāriputtā”ti vatvā – “atthi, bhante,
analyzed: tena nam bhagavā kattha parinibbāyissasi sāriputta ati vatvā  atthi bhante
translated: The Buddha said to him, “Where will you enter Nibbana, Sariputta?”

original: magadhesu nālakagāme jātovarako, tatthāhaṃ parinibbāyissāmī”ti vutte – “yassa dāni🔽tvaṃ, sāriputta, kālaṃ maññasi, idāni pana te jeṭṭhakaniṭṭhabhātikānaṃ tādisassa
analyzed: magadhesu nālakagāme jāta uvarakaḥ tattha aham parinibbāyissāmi iti vutte yassa dāni  tvam sāriputta kālam maññasi idāni pana te jeṭṭha kaniṭṭha bhātikānam tādisassa
translated: “There is a village of the Magadhans called Nalaka. I will enter Nibbana there.”🔽“Now is the time for you to do as you think fit. But it will be difficult for you to see such bhikkhus as your brother and the other elders.

original: bhikkhuno dassanaṃ dullabhaṃ bhavissati, desehi nesaṃ dhamma”nti āha.
analyzed: bhikkhuno dassanam dullabham bhavissati desehi na īsam dhammanti āha
translated: Teach them the Dhamma.”

original: Thero – “satthā mayhaṃ iddhivikubbanapubbaṅgamaṃ dhammadesanaṃ paccāsīsatī”ti ñatvā
analyzed: theraḥ satthā mayham iddhi vikubbana pubbaṅgamam dhamma desanam paccāsīsati iti ñatvā
translated: The elder thought, “The Teacher wants me to teach the Dhamma by first performing a miracle.”

original: bhagavantaṃ vanditvā tālappamāṇaṃ ākāsaṃ abbhuggantvā oruyha dasabalassa pāde vandi,
analyzed: bhagavantam vanditvā tāla ppamāṇam ākāsam abbhut gantvā oruyha dasabalassa pāde vandi
translated: He paid homage to the Buddha, rose into the air to the height of a tala tree, saluted the Master with folded hands, and said,

original: puna dvitālappamāṇaṃ abbhuggantvā oruyha dasabalassa pāde vandi, etenupāyena sattatālappamāṇaṃ🔽abbhuggantvā anekāni pāṭihāriyasatāni dassento dhammakathaṃ ārabhi. Dissamānenapi
analyzed: puna dvi tāla ppamāṇam abbhut gantvā oruyha dasabalassa pāde vandi etena upāyena satta tāla ppamāṇam  abbhuggantvā anekāni pāṭihāriya satāni dassentaḥ dhamma katham ārabhi dissamānena api
translated: Then he rose to the height of two palm trees, descended, and saluted the feet of the Ten Powered One. In this manner he rose to the height of seven palm trees,

original: kāyena katheti, adissamānenapi. Uparimena vā heṭṭhimena vā upaḍḍhakāyena katheti
analyzed: kāyena kathā iti a dissamānena api uparimena vā heṭṭhimena vā upaḍḍha kāyena kathā iti
translated: and displaying many hundreds of miracles, he began to preach the Law. He preached the Law with a visible body, and he preached the Law with an invisible body. He preached the Law with the upper part of his body, and he preached the Law with the lower part of his body.

original: adissamānenapi dissamānenapi, kālena candavaṇṇaṃ dasseti, kālena sūriyavaṇṇaṃ, kālena
analyzed: a dissamānena api dissamānena api kālena canda vaṇṇam dasseti kālena sūriya vaṇṇam kālena
translated: He preached the Law with an invisible body, and he preached the Law with a visible body. Sometimes he displayed the color of the moon, sometimes the color of the sun,

original: pabbatavaṇṇaṃ, kālena samuddavaṇṇaṃ, kālena cakkavattirājā hoti, kālena vessavaṇamahārājā,
analyzed: pabbata vaṇṇam kālena samudda vaṇṇam kālena cakkavatti rājā hoti kālena vessavaṇa mahārājā
translated: sometimes the color of a mountain, sometimes the color of the ocean, sometimes he became a universal king, sometimes he became the great king Vessavaṇa,

original: kālena sakko devarājā, kālena mahābrahmāti evaṃ anekāni pāṭihāriyasatāni dassento
analyzed: kālena sakkaḥ devarājā kālena mahābrahmā ati evam anekāni pāṭihāriya satāni dassento
translated: sometimes he became Sakka king of the gods, sometimes he became Great Brahmā. Thus displaying many hundreds of miracles,

original: dhammakathaṃ kathesi. Sakalanagaraṃ sannipati. Thero oruyha dasabalassa pāde vanditvā
analyzed: dhamma katham kathesi sakala nagaram sannipati theraḥ oruyha dasabalassa pāde vanditvā
translated: he preached the Law. The entire city assembled. The Elder descended, saluted the feet of the Ten Powered One,

original: aṭṭhāsi. Atha naṃ satthā āha – “ko nāmo ayaṃ sāriputta dhammapariyāyo”ti. Sīhavikīḷito
analyzed: aṭṭhāsi atha nam satthā āha kaḥ nāma ayam sāriputta dhamma pariyāyaḥ ti sīha vikīḷito
translated: and stood respectfully on one side. Then the Teacher said to him, “What is the name of this discourse on the Law, Sāriputta?” The Elder replied, “It is called ‘The Play of the Lion.’ ”

original: nāma, bhanteti. Taggha, sāriputta, sīhavikīḷito taggha, sāriputta, sīhavikīḷitoti.
analyzed: nāma bhante iti taggha sāriputta sīha vikīḷito taggha sāriputta sīha vikīḷito ti
translated: “Yes, venerable sir.” “Sāriputta, you have played the lion’s roar like a lion.

original: Thero alattakavaṇṇe hatthe pasāretvā satthu suvaṇṇakacchapasadise pāde gopphakesu
analyzed: theraḥ alattaka vaṇṇe hatthe pasāretvā satthu suvaṇṇa kacchapa sadise pāde gopphakesu
translated: The Elder extended his hand, which was like a lotus in colour, and took hold of the Teacher’s feet, which were like the tortoise shell of a golden tortoise,

original: gahetvā – “bhante, imesaṃ pādānaṃ vandanatthāya kappasatasahassādhikaṃ asaṅkhyeyyaṃ🔽pāramiyo pūritā, so me manoratho matthakaṃ patto, ito dāni paṭṭhāya paṭisandhivasena
analyzed: gahetvā bhante imesam pādānam vandana tthāya kappa sata sahassa adhikam asaṅkhyeyyam  pāramiyaḥ pūritā saḥ me manorathaḥ matthakam patto itas dāni paṭṭhāya paṭisandhi vasena
translated: and said: “Venerable sir, for the purpose of worshipping these feet, I have fulfilled the perfections for four incalculables and a hundred thousand great aeons,

original: na puna ekaṭṭhāne sannipāto samāgamo atthi, chinno esa vissāso, anekehi buddhasatasahassehi
analyzed: na puna eka ṭṭhāne sannipātaḥ samāgamaḥ atthi chinnaḥ esa vissāsaḥ anekehi buddha sata sahassehi
translated: and my desire has been fulfilled. From now on there will be no more meeting together in one place by rebirth. This friendship is broken.

original: paviṭṭhaṃ ajaraṃ amaraṃ khemaṃ sukhaṃ sītalaṃ abhayaṃ nibbānapuraṃ pavisissāmi, sace
analyzed: paviṭṭham ajaram amaram khemam sukham sītalam abhayam nibbāna puram pavisissāmi sace
translated: I shall enter the city of Nibbāna, which is free from old age, death, fear, and sorrow, and which is cool and happy, and which has been entered by many hundreds of thousands of Buddhas.

original: me kiñci kāyikaṃ vā vācasikaṃ vā na rocetha, khamatha taṃ bhagavā, gamanakālo mayha”nti.
analyzed: me kiñci kāyikam vā vācasikam vā na rocetha khamatha tam bhagavā gamana kālaḥ
translated: If I have done anything that has displeased you, whether in deed, word, or thought, forgive me, venerable sir. It is time for me to go.”

original: Khamāmi te, sāriputta, na kho pana te kiñci kāyikaṃ vā vācasikaṃ vā mayhaṃ aruccanakaṃ
analyzed: khamāmi te sāriputta na kho pana te kiñci kāyikam vā vācasikam vā mayham a ruccanakam
translated: “I forgive you, Sāriputta. There is nothing in deed, word, or thought that has displeased me.

original: atthi, yassa dāni tvaṃ, sāriputta, kālaṃ maññasīti.
analyzed: atthi yassa dāni tvam sāriputta kālam maññasi iti
translated: “There is, Sāriputta, now is the time, Sāriputta, to do as you think fit.”

original: Iti bhagavatā anuññātasamanantaraṃ satthu pāde vanditvā uṭṭhitamatte āyasmante sāriputte🔽sinerucakkavāḷahimavantaparibhaṇḍapabbate dhārayamānāpi – “ajja imaṃ guṇarāsiṃ dhāretuṃ
analyzed: iti bhagavatā anuññāta samanantaram satthu pāde vanditvā uṭṭhita matte āyasmante sāriputte  sineru cakka vāḷa himavanta paribhaṇḍa pabbate dhārayamānā api ajja imam guṇa rāsim dhāretum
translated: And immediately after the Exalted One had given him permission, the venerable Sāriputta saluted the Exalted One by touching his head to the Exalted One’s feet. As soon as he had risen up from saluting the Exalted One,

original: na sakkomī”ti vadantī viya ekappahāreneva viravamānā mahāpathavī yāva udakapariyantā
analyzed: na sakkomi iti vadantī viya eka pahārena iva viravamānā mahā pathavī yāva udaka pariyantā
translated: the great earth, which extends to the ocean’s shore and is surrounded by the circle of mountains, quaked, trembled, and shook violently, as if it were a bowl of water that has been struck.

original: akampi, ākāse devadundubhiyo phaliṃsu, mahāmegho uṭṭhahitvā pokkharavassaṃ vassi.🔽Satthā – “dhammasenāpatiṃ paṭipādessāmī”ti dhammāsanā vuṭṭhāya gandhakuṭiabhimukho
analyzed: akampi ākāse deva dundubhiyaḥ phaliṃsu mahā meghaḥ uṭṭhahitvā pokkharavassam vassi  satthā dhamma senāpatim paṭipādessāmi iti dhamma āsanā vuṭṭhāya gandhakuṭi abhimukhaḥ
translated: And the great earth quaked in six ways, as if it were a ship tossed about by the wind on the great ocean.🔽The Exalted One thought: “I will send the general of the Dhamma.” And rising from his seat, he went to the Perfumed Chamber and stood there on the crystal slab.

original: gantvā maṇiphalake aṭṭhāsi. Thero tikkhattuṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā catūsu ṭhānesu vanditvā
analyzed: gantvā maṇiphalake aṭṭhāsi theraḥ tikkhattum padakkhiṇam katvā catūsu ṭhānesu vanditvā
translated: The venerable Sāriputta circumambulated the Exalted One three times, saluted the four directions, and
