original: – “bhagavā ito kappasatasahassādhikassa asaṅkhyeyyassa upari anomadassīsammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: bhagavā itas kappa sata sahassa adhikassa asaṅkhyeyyassa upari anomadassī sammāsambuddhassa
translated: said: “The Exalted One is the unsurpassed trainer of persons to be tamed, the teacher of gods and men.

original: pādamūle nipajjitvā tumhākaṃ dassanaṃ patthesiṃ, sā me patthanā samiddhā, diṭṭhā
analyzed: pāda mūle nipajjitvā tumhākam dassanam patthesim sā me patthanā samiddhā diṭṭhā
translated: and lay at your feet, and I longed to see you. That longing of mine has been fulfilled,

original: tumhe, taṃ paṭhamadassanaṃ, idaṃ pacchimadassanaṃ. Puna tumhākaṃ dassanaṃ natthī”ti
analyzed: tumhe tam paṭhama dassanam idam pacchima dassanam puna tumhākam dassanam natthi iti
translated: I have seen you. That was the first time I saw you, this is the last time I shall see you. There will be no more seeing you.”

original: vatvā dasanakhasamodhānasamujjalaṃ añjaliṃ paggayha yāva dassanavisayā abhimukhova
analyzed: vatvā dasa nakha samodhāna samujjalam añjalim paggayha yāva dassana visayāḥ abhimukhaḥ uva
translated: After saying this, he raised his joined hands in reverential salutation, which were radiant with the light of the ten perfections, and he turned back from the place where he could see the Exalted One,

original: paṭikkamitvā vanditvā pakkāmi. Puna mahāpathavī dhāretuṃ asakkontī udakapariyantaṃ katvā akampi.
analyzed: paṭikkamitvā vanditvā pakkāmi puna mahā pathavī dhāretum a sakkontī udaka pariyantam katvā akampi
translated: and after paying homage to him, he departed. Then the great earth, unable to bear the weight of the Exalted One, quaked up to the edge of the water.

original: Bhagavā parivāretvā ṭhite bhikkhū āha – “anugacchatha, bhikkhave, tumhākaṃ jeṭṭhabhātika”nti.
analyzed: bhagavā parivāretvā ṭhite bhikkhū āha anugacchatha bhikkhave tumhākam jeṭṭha bhātikam ti
translated: The Exalted One said to the monks who were standing about him, “Follow your elder brother, monks.”

original: Tasmiṃ khaṇe catassopi parisā sammāsambuddhaṃ ekakaṃyeva jetavane ohāya niravasesā
analyzed: tasmin khaṇe catassaḥ api parisā sammāsambuddham ekakam yā iva jetavane ohāya niravasesā
translated: At that moment all four assemblies, leaving the Fully Enlightened One alone in Jeta’s Wood,

original: nikkhamiṃsu. Sāvatthinagaravāsinopi – “sāriputtatthero kira sammāsambuddhaṃ āpucchitvā
analyzed: nikkhamiṃsu sāvatthi nagara vāsinaḥ pi sāriputta theraḥ kira sammāsambuddham āpucchitvā
translated: went out without exception. The inhabitants of the city of Sāvatthi also said, “The Elder Sāriputta, it seems, has taken leave of the Fully Enlightened One🔽and has gone forth from home into homelessness.”

original: parinibbāyitukāmo nikkhanto, passissāma na”nti nagaradvārāni nirokāsāni karontā nikkhamitvā🔽gandhamālādihatthā kese vikiritvā – “idāni mayaṃ kahaṃ mahāpañño nisinno, kahaṃ dhammasenāpati
analyzed: parinibbāyitu kāmo nikkhanto passissāma nanti nagara dvārāni nirokāsāni karontā nikkhamitvā  gandha mālā ādi hatthāḥ kese vikiritvā idāni mayam kaham mahā paññaḥ nisinno kaham dhamma senāpati
translated: “We will see him as he goes forth to attain Nibbāna.”🔽They went out, blocking the city gates, and with their hands full of perfumes and garlands, their hair disheveled,🔽they asked, “Where is the Elder seated? Where is the General of the Dhamma?

original: nisinno”ti pucchantā – “kassa santikaṃ gamissāma, kassa hatthe satthāraṃ ṭhapetvā
analyzed: nisinnaḥ iti pucchantā kassa santikam gamissāma kassa hatthe satthāram ṭhapetvā
translated: To whose presence shall we go? In whose hands shall we place the Teacher?🔽The Elder has gone forth.”

original: thero pakkanto”tiādinā nayena paridevantā rodantā theraṃ anubandhiṃsu.
analyzed: theraḥ pakkantaḥ iti ādinā nayena paridevantā rodantā theram anubandhiṃsu
translated: In this way they lamented and wept, following the Elder.

original: Thero mahāpaññāya ṭhitattā – “sabbesaṃ anatikkamanīyo esa maggo”ti mahājanaṃ ovaditvā
analyzed: theraḥ mahā paññāya ṭhita ttā sabbesam an atikkamanīyaḥ esa maggaḥ iti mahājanam ovaditvā
translated: The Elder, because of his great wisdom, instructed the great multitude, saying, “This is a path that none can transgress.”

original: – “tumhepi, āvuso, tiṭṭhatha, mā dasabale pamādaṃ āpajjitthā”ti bhikkhusaṅghampi
analyzed: tumhe pi āvuso tiṭṭhatha mā dasabale pamādam āpajjittha ati bhikkhu saṅgham pi
translated: He turned back the Community of Bhikkhus, saying, “You also, friends, stand here and do not be negligent with regard to the One of Ten Powers.”

original: nivattetvā attano parisāyeva saddhiṃ pakkāmi. Yepi manussā – “pubbe ayyo paccāgamanacārikaṃ
analyzed: nivattetvā attanaḥ parisāya iva saddhim pakkāmi ye pi manussā pubbe ayyo paccāgamana cārikaṃ
translated: He went forth with his own following. Those people who thought, “Formerly the Elder went forth on a tour of inspection,

original: carati, idaṃ idāni gamanaṃ na puna paccāgamanāyā”ti paridevantā anubandhiṃsuyeva.
analyzed: carati idam idāni gamanam na puna paccāgamanāya ati paridevantā
translated: but this time he goes forth not to return again,” lamented and followed him.

original: Tepi – “appamattā, āvuso, hotha, evaṃbhāvino nāma saṅkhārā”ti nivattesi.
analyzed: te pi appamattāḥ āvuso hotha evaṃbhāvinaḥ nāma saṅkhārā ti nivattesi
translated: “Be careful, friends. Such are the nature of formations.”🔽Then the venerable Sāriputta, spending the rainy season in one place and the next in another,

original: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto sabbattha ekarattivāsena antarāmagge sattāhaṃ manussānaṃ
analyzed: atha kho āyasmā sāriputto sabbattha eka ratti vāsena antarāmagge sattāham manussānaṃ
translated: and spending seven days in the company of people,

original: saṅgahaṃ karonto sāyaṃ nālakagāmaṃ patvā gāmadvāre nigrodharukkhamūle aṭṭhāsi. Atha
analyzed: saṅgaham karontaḥ sāyam nālakagāmam patvā gāma dvāre nigrodha rukkha mūle aṭṭhāsi atha
translated: reached the village of Nāḷakapāna in the evening. He stood at the foot of a banyan tree at the village gate.

original: uparevato nāma therassa bhāgineyyo bahigāmaṃ gacchanto theraṃ disvā upasaṅkamitvā
analyzed: uparevataḥ nāma therassa bhāgineyyaḥ bahigāmam gacchantaḥ theram disvā upasaṅkamitvā
translated: Then a young man named Uparevata, who was going out of the village, saw the elder, approached him,

original: vanditvā aṭṭhāsi. Thero taṃ āha – “atthi gehe te ayyikā”ti. Āma bhanteti. Gaccha🔽amhākaṃ idhāgatabhāvaṃ ārocehi. “Kasmā āgato”ti ca vutte – “ajja kira ekadivasaṃ
analyzed: vanditvā aṭṭhāsi theraḥ tam āha atthi gehe te ayyikā ati āma bhante iti gaccha  amhākam idhāgata bhāvam ārocehi kasmai āgataḥ iti ca vutte ajja kira eka divasam
translated: and stood in attendance on him. The elder said to him, “Is there a lady in your house, friend?”

original: antogāme vasissati, jātovarakaṃ paṭijaggatha, pañcannañca kira bhikkhusatānaṃ vasanaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: antogāme vasissati jāta uvarakam paṭijaggatha pañcannam ca kira bhikkhu satānam vasana ṭhānam
translated: “Yes, venerable sir.” “Go and tell her that we have come.” “Why have you come?” “Today, it seems, he will stay in the village for one day. Prepare a lying-in room and find a place for five hundred bhikkhus to stay.”

original: jānāthā”ti. So gantvā – “ayyike mayhaṃ mātulo āgato”ti āha. Idāni kuhinti? Gāmadvāreti.
analyzed: jānātha ati saḥ gantvā ayyike mayham mātulaḥ āgataḥ iti āha idāni kuhinti gāmadvārā iti
translated: He went and said, “Lady, my uncle has come.” “Where is he now?” “At the village gate.”

original: Ekakova, aññopi koci atthīti? Atthi pañcasatā bhikkhūti. Kiṃkāraṇā āgatoti? So taṃ🔽pavattiṃ ārocesi. Brāhmaṇī – “kiṃ nu kho ettakānaṃ vasanaṭṭhānaṃ paṭijaggāpeti, daharakāle🔽pabbajitvā mahallakakāle gihī hotukāmo”ti cintentī jātovarakaṃ paṭijaggāpetvā pañcasatānaṃ
analyzed: ekakaḥ iva aññaḥ pi koci atthi iti atthi pañca satā bhikkhū iti kiṃkāraṇā āgataḥ ti so tam  pavattim ārocesi brāhmaṇī kim nu kho ettakānam vasana ṭṭhānam paṭijaggāpeti dahara kāle  pabbajitvā mahallaka kāle gihī hotu kāmaḥ iti cintentī jāta uvarakam paṭijaggāpetvā pañca satānam
translated: “Is there anyone else?” “There are five hundred bhikkhus.” “What is the reason for his coming?” He told her the story. The brāhmaṇī thought, “What is the use of looking after a dwelling for so many? In his youth he went forth, but in his old age he wants to be a householder.” She had the newly-born child looked after, and then she went to the monastery.

original: vasanaṭṭhānaṃ kāretvā daṇḍadīpikā jāletvā therassa pāhesi.🔽Thero bhikkhūhi saddhiṃ pāsādaṃ āruyha jātovarakaṃ pavisitvā nisīdi, nisīditvā “tumhākaṃ🔽vasanaṭṭhānaṃ gacchathā”ti bhikkhū uyyojesi. Tesu gatamattesuyeva therassa kharo🔽ābādho uppajji, lohitapakkhandikā māraṇantikā vedanā vattanti. Ekaṃ bhājanaṃ pavisati,
analyzed: vasanaṭṭhānam kāretvā daṇḍadīpikā jāletvā therassa pāhesi  theraḥ bhikkhūhi saddhim pāsādam āruyha jātovarakam pavisitvā nisīdi nisīditvā tumhākam  vasanaṭṭhānam gacchatha ati bhikkhū uyyojesi tesu gata mattesu yeva therassa kharo  ābādhaḥ uppajji lohita pakkhandikā māraṇantikā vedanā vattanti ekam bhājanam pavisati
translated: “Is there anyone else?” “There are five hundred bhikkhus.” “Why did he come?” She told him what had happened. The brāhmaṇī thought, “What is he going to do with so many dwellings? When he was young he went forth, and now that he is old he wants to become a householder.” She had a new dwelling built for herself and had five hundred dwellings built for the five hundred bhikkhus. She had a torch lit and sent it to the elder.

original: ekaṃ nikkhamati. Brāhmaṇī – “mama puttassa pavatti mayhaṃ na ruccatī”ti attano vasanagabbhadvāraṃ nissāya aṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: ekam nikkhamati brāhmaṇī mama puttassa pavatti mayham na ruccati iti attanaḥ vasana gabbha dvāram nissāya aṭṭhāsi
translated: The elder went up to the stilt house with the bhikkhus. He entered the new dwelling and sat down. After sitting down, he dismissed the bhikkhus, saying, “Go to your dwellings.” As soon as they had left, the elder experienced a severe affliction, a life-threatening illness. One bowl entered and another left. The brāhmaṇī thought, “What my son is doing does not please me.” She stood near the door of her own dwelling.

original: Cattāro mahārājāno “dhammasenāpati kuhiṃ viharatī”ti olokentā nālakagāme jātovarake
analyzed: cattāro mahā rājānaḥ dhamma senāpati kuhim viharati iti olokentā nālaka gāme jāta uvarake
translated: The Four Great Kings, looking about to see where the General of the Dhamma was staying, saw him lying on his deathbed in the Jātarūpa shrine in the village of Nāḷandā.

original: parinibbānamañce nipanno, pacchimadassanaṃ gamissāmā”ti āgamma vanditvā aṭṭhaṃsu.
analyzed: parinibbāna mañce nipanno pacchima dassanam gamissāma ati āgamma vanditvā aṭṭhaṃsu
translated: They came and paid homage to him, thinking, “We will see him for the last time.”

original: Ke tumheti? Mahārājāno bhanteti. Kasmā āgatatthāti? Gilānupaṭṭhākā bhavissāmāti.
analyzed: ke tumhe iti mahā rājānaḥ bhante ti kasmai āgatattha ati gilāna upaṭṭhākāḥ bhavissāma ati
translated: “Who are you?” “Venerable sir, we are the Four Great Kings.” “Why have you come?” “To attend upon the sick.”

original: “Hotu, atthi gilānupaṭṭhāko, gacchatha tumhe”ti uyyojesi. Tesaṃ gatāvasāne teneva
analyzed: hotu atthi gilāna upaṭṭhākaḥ gacchatha tumhe iti uyyojesi tesam gata avasāne tena iva
translated: “Very well, there is already an attendant upon the sick. You may go.” When they had left,

original: nayena sakko devānamindo. Tasmiṃ gate mahābrahmā ca āgamiṃsu. Tepi tatheva thero uyyojesi.
analyzed: nayena sakkaḥ devānamindo tasmin gate mahābrahmā ca āgamiṃsu te pi tathā iva theraḥ uyyojesi
translated: Sakka, King of the Gods, came in the same way. When he had gone, Great Brahmā came. The Elder sent them away in the same way.

original: Brāhmaṇī devatānaṃ āgamanañca gamanañca disvā “ke nu kho ete mama puttaṃ vanditvā🔽gacchantī”ti therassa gabbhadvāraṃ gantvā “tāta, cunda, kā pavattī”ti pucchi. So
analyzed: brāhmaṇī devatānam āgamanam ca gamanam ca disvā ke nu kho ete mama puttam vanditvā  gacchanti iti therassa gabbha dvāram gantvā tāta cunda kā pavatti iti pucchi so
translated: The brāhmaṇī saw the gods coming and going and asked, “Who are these that pay homage to my son and then go away?”🔽The Elder went to the door of the inner room and asked, “Dear Cunda, what is happening?”

original: taṃ pavattiṃ ācikkhitvā “mahāupāsikā, bhante, āgatā”ti āha. Thero “kasmā avelāya
analyzed: tam pavattim ācikkhitvā mahā upāsikā bhante āgatā iti āha thero kasmai avelāya
translated: He told her what was happening and said, “Venerable lady, the gods have come.” The Elder said, “Venerable lady, why do you not go?”🔽“Venerable sir, I am a woman. It is not proper for me to go to the place where the gods have assembled.”🔽“Very well, then, I will take you there.”

original: āgatā”ti pucchi. Sā “tuyhaṃ, tāta, dassanatthāyā”ti vatvā “tāta, paṭhamaṃ ke āgatā”ti
analyzed: āgatā iti pucchi sā tuyham tāta dassana tthāya ati vatvā tāta paṭhamam ke āgatā ati
translated: “Have they come?” She said, “Dear, they have come to see you.” She asked, “Dear, who came first?”

original: pucchi. Cattāro mahārājāno upāsiketi. Tāta, tvaṃ catūhi mahārājehi mahantataroti?
analyzed: pucchi cattāraḥ mahā rājānaḥ upāsikā iti tāta tvam catūhi mahā rājehi mahantataraḥ iti
translated: “The Four Great Kings.” “Dear, are you greater than the Four Great Kings?”

original: Ārāmikasadisā ete upāsike, amhākaṃ satthu paṭisandhiggahaṇato paṭṭhāya khaggahatthā
analyzed: ārāmika sadisāḥ ete upāsike amhākam satthu paṭisandhi ggahaṇato paṭṭhāya khagga hatthā
translated: “These lay followers are like the monastery attendants. From the time of my Master’s conception, they have protected him with swords in their hands.”

original: hutvā ārakkhaṃ akaṃsūti. Tesaṃ tāta gatāvasāne ko āgatoti? Sakko devānamindoti. Devarājatopi
analyzed: hutvā ārakkham akaṃsu iti tesam tāta gata avasāne kaḥ āgataḥ iti sakkaḥ devānamindo iti devarājataḥ pi
translated: “Who came after them?” “Sakka, Lord of the Gods.” “Dear, are you greater than the Lord of the Gods?”

original: tvaṃ tāta mahantataroti? Bhaṇḍaggāhakasāmaṇerasadiso esa upāsike, amhākaṃ satthu
analyzed: tvam tāta bhaṇḍaggāhaka sāmaṇera sadisaḥ esaḥ upāsike amhākam satthu
translated: “This lay follower is like the novice monk who carried the goods. When my Master

original: tāvatiṃsato otaraṇakāle pattacīvaraṃ gahetvā otiṇṇoti. Tassa tāta gatāvasāne jotayamāno🔽viya ko āgatoti? Upāsike, tuyhaṃ bhagavā ca satthā ca mahābrahmā nāma esoti. Mayhaṃ
analyzed: tāvatiṃsataḥ otaraṇa kāle patta cīvaram gahetvā otiṇṇoti tassa tāta gata avasāne jotayamāno  viya kaḥ āgataḥ iti upāsike tuyham bhagavā ca satthā ca mahābrahmā nāma eso ti mayham
translated: came down from the Tāvatiṃsa heaven, he came down carrying his bowl and robe.”🔽“Who came after him?” “The lay follower Jotipāla.” “Dear, is your Master the Buddha, and is the Great Brahma your Master?”🔽“Dear, are you greater than the Buddha and the Great Brahma?” “Yes, lay follower, they are indeed

original: bhagavato mahābrahmatopi tvaṃ, tāta, mahantataroti? Āma upāsike, ete nāma kira amhākaṃ
analyzed: tvam tāta tvam tāta ete nāma kira amhākam
translated: my Master.”

original: satthu jātadivase cattāro mahābrahmāno mahāpurisaṃ suvaṇṇajālena paṭiggaṇhiṃsūti.🔽Atha brāhmaṇiyā – “puttassa tāva me ayaṃ ānubhāvo, kīdiso vata mayhaṃ puttassa bhagavato
analyzed: satthu jāta divase cattāro mahābrahmānaḥ mahāpurisam suvaṇṇa jālena paṭiggaṇhiṃsu iti  atha brāhmaṇiyā puttassa tāva me ayaṃ ānubhāvaḥ kīdisaḥ vata mayham puttassa bhagavato
translated: On the day of the Master’s birth, four Great Brahmās received the Great Man with a golden net.

original: satthu ānubhāvo bhavissatī”ti cintayantiyā sahasā pañcavaṇṇā pīti uppajjitvā sakalasarīraṃ
analyzed: satthu ānubhāvaḥ bhavissati iti cintayantiyā sahasā pañca vaṇṇā pīti uppajjitvā sakala sarīram
translated: Then, as the brāhmaṇī was thinking: “This is the power of my son. What will the power of my son, the Exalted One, be like?” a rapture of five colours arose suddenly and pervaded her entire body.

original: phari. Thero – “uppannaṃ me mātu pītisomanassaṃ, ayaṃ dāni kālo dhammadesanāyā”ti🔽cintetvā “kiṃ cintesi mahāupāsike”ti āha. Sā “puttassa tāva me ayaṃ guṇo, satthu
analyzed: theraḥ uppannam me mātu pīti somanassam ayam dāni kālaḥ dhamma desanāya ati  cintetvā kim cintesi mahā upāsikā iti āha sā puttassa tāva me ayam guṇaḥ satthu
translated: The Elder thought: “My mother has experienced rapture and joy. Now is the time to teach her the Dhamma.”

original: panassa kīdiso bhavissatīti idaṃ, tāta, cintemī”ti āha. Mahāupāsike, mayhaṃ satthujātakkhaṇe
analyzed: panassa kīdisaḥ bhavissati iti idam tāta cintemi iti āha mahā upāsike mayham satthu jāta kkhaṇe
translated: He asked: “What were you thinking about, great lay devotee?” She replied: “I was thinking: ‘This is the power of my son. What will the power of my son, the Exalted One, be like?’” The Elder said: “Great lay devotee, at the time of my Teacher’s birth,

original: mahābhinikkhamane sambodhiyaṃ dhammacakkappavattane ca dasasahassilokadhātu kampittha.
analyzed: mahā abhinikkhamane sambodhiyam dhamma cakka ppavattane ca dasa sahassi lokadhātu kampittha
translated: at the time of his Great Renunciation, at the time of his enlightenment, and at the time of his setting in motion the Wheel of the Dhamma, the ten-thousandfold world system shook.

original: Sīlena samādhinā paññāya vimuttiyā vimuttiñāṇadassanena samo nāma natthi, itipi so
analyzed: sīlena samādhinā paññāya vimuttiyā vimutti ñāṇa dassanena samaḥ nāma natthi iti pi so
translated: There is no one equal to him in virtue, concentration, wisdom, emancipation, or the knowledge and vision of emancipation. Thus he is called the Exalted One.

original: bhagavāti vitthāretvā buddhaguṇapaṭisaṃyuttaṃ dhammadesanaṃ kathesi.🔽Brāhmaṇī piyaputtassa dhammadesanāpariyosāne sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhāya puttaṃ āha
analyzed: bhagavā iti vitthāretvā buddha guṇa paṭisaṃyuttam dhamma desanam kathesi  brāhmaṇī piya puttassa dhamma desanā pariyosāne sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhāya puttam āha
translated: and he preached the Dhamma to her, beginning with the special qualities of the Buddha.

original: – “tāta upatissa, kasmā evamakāsi, evarūpaṃ nāma amataṃ mayhaṃ ettakaṃ kālaṃ na adāsī”ti.
analyzed: tāta upatissa kasmai evam akāsi evarūpam nāma amatam mayham ettakam kālam na adāsi iti
translated: At the conclusion of the discourse the Brahman woman attained the Fruit of Conversion. She said to her son, “Dear Upatissa, why did you do this? Why did you not give me this ambrosial doctrine before this?”

original: Thero – “dinnaṃ dāni me mātu rūpasāriyā brāhmaṇiyā posāvanikamūlaṃ, ettakena vaṭṭissatī”ti
analyzed: theraḥ dinnam dāni me mātu rūpasāriyā brāhmaṇiyā posāvanika mūlam ettakena vaṭṭissati iti
translated: The Elder thought to himself, “I have now repaid the Brahman woman Rūpasārī my mother, for the support she gave me. This will suffice.”

original: cintetvā – “gaccha mahāupasike”ti brāhmaṇiṃ uyyojetvā – “cunda kā velā”ti āha. Balavapaccūsakālo,🔽bhanteti. Bhikkhusaṅghaṃ sannipātehīti. Sannipatito bhante bhikkhusaṅghoti. “Maṃ
analyzed: cintetvā gaccha mahāupasikā iti brāhmaṇim cunda kā velā iti āha balava paccūsa kālaḥ  bhante iti bhikkhu saṅgham sannipātehi iti sannipatitaḥ bhante bhikkhu saṅghaḥ ti mama
translated: So he dismissed the Brahman woman, saying to her, “Go, Mahāupāsikā.” Then he said to Cunda, “What time is it, Cunda?”🔽“It is the time of the strong dawn, Reverend Sir.”

original: ukkhipitvā nisīdāpehi cundā”ti ukkhipitvā nisīdāpesi.
analyzed: ukkhipitvā nisīda apehi cunda ati ukkhipitvā nisīda apesi
translated: “Summon the company of the monks.” “Reverend Sir, the company of the monks is already assembled.” “Cunda, remove me and seat me on the couch.” So saying, he had Cunda remove him and seat him on the couch.

original: Thero bhikkhū āmantesi – “āvuso catucattālīsaṃ vo vassāni mayā saddhiṃ vicarantānaṃ
analyzed: theraḥ bhikkhū āmantesi āvuso catucattālīsam vaḥ vassāni mayā saddhim vicarantānam
translated: Then the Elder addressed the monks, “Brethren, for forty-four years you have wandered about with me.

original: yaṃ me kāyikaṃ vā vācasikaṃ vā na rocetha, taṃ khamatha āvuso”ti. Ettakaṃ, bhante,
analyzed: yam me kāyikam vā vācasikam vā na rocetha tam khamatha āvuso ti ettakam bhante
translated: “If there is anything in deed, word, or thought that you disapprove of, forgive me, friends.” “Venerable sir,

original: amhākaṃ chāyā viya tumhe amuñcitvā vicarantānaṃ aruccanakaṃ nāma natthi, tumhe pana
analyzed: amhākam chāyā viya tumhe a muñcitvā vicarantānam aruccanakam nāma natthi tumhe pana
translated: we have never gone anywhere without taking you with us, as if you were our shadow. There is nothing that we disapprove of.

original: amhākaṃ khamathāti. Atha thero mahācīvaraṃ saṅkaḍḍhitvā mukhaṃ pidhāya dakkhiṇena
analyzed: amhākam khamatha ati atha theraḥ mahā cīvaram saṅkaḍḍhitvā mukham pidhāya dakkhiṇena
translated: But you should forgive us.” Then the Elder, having gathered up his great robe, covered his face with it, and lay down on his right side.

original: passena nipanno satthā viya nava anupubbasamāpattiyo anulomapaṭilomato samāpajjitvā
analyzed: passena nipannaḥ satthā viya nava anupubba samāpattiyaḥ anuloma paṭilomataḥ samāpajjitvā
translated: The Teacher, as it were, entered the nine successive abidings in the order of advancement and in the reverse order,

original: puna paṭhamajjhānaṃ ādiṃ katvā yāva catutthajjhānā samāpajji. Tato vuṭṭhāya anantaraṃyeva
analyzed: puna paṭhama jhānam ādim katvā yāva catuttha jhānā samāpajji tatas vuṭṭhāya anantaram yeva
translated: and again, beginning with the first jhāna, he entered the four jhānas in succession, and emerging from the fourth jhāna,

original: mahāpathaviṃ unnādento anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyi.
analyzed: mahā pathavim unnādentaḥ anupādisesāya nibbānadhātuyā parinibbāyi
translated: he attained Nibbāna, which is without remainder of the substratum of being, and he made the great earth resound with a great shout.

original: Upāsikā – “kiṃ nu kho me putto, na kiñci kathetī”ti uṭṭhāya piṭṭhipāde parimajjantī
analyzed: upāsikā kim nu kho me putto na kiñci katheti iti uṭṭhāya piṭṭhi pāde parimajjantī
translated: The lay disciple, thinking, “Why does my son say nothing?” rose up and stroked his back.

original: parinibbutabhāvaṃ ñatvā mahāsaddaṃ kurumānā pādesu nipatitvā – “tāta mayaṃ ito pubbe
analyzed: parinibbuta bhāvam ñatvā mahā saddam kurumānā pādesu nipatitvā tāta mayam itas pubbe
translated: When she discovered that he was dead, she fell down at his feet and, making a great lamentation, cried out, “Dear son, before this time,

original: tava guṇaṃ na jānimhā, idāni pana taṃ ādiṃ katvā anekasate anekasahasse anekasatasahasse🔽bhikkhū imasmiṃ nivesane nisīdāpetvā bhojetuṃ na labhimhā, cīvarehi acchādetuṃ na
analyzed: tava guṇam na jānimha idāni pana tam ādim katvā aneka sate aneka sahasse aneka sata sahasse  bhikkhū imasmin nivesane nisīdāpetvā bhojetum na labhimhā cīvarehi acchādetum na
translated: We did not know your virtue, but now that we have begun, we will not be able to get many hundreds, many thousands, many hundreds of thousands of monks to sit down in this house and feed them, to clothe them with robes,🔽to give them almsfood, to give them lodgings, and to give them medicinal requisites.

original: labhimhā, vihārasataṃ vihārasahassaṃ kāretuṃ na labhimhā”ti yāva aruṇuggamanā paridevi.🔽Aruṇe uggatamatteyeva suvaṇṇakāre pakkosāpetvā suvaṇṇagabbhaṃ vivarāpetvā suvaṇṇaghaṭiyo
analyzed: labhimha vihāra satam vihāra sahassam kāretum na labhimha ati yāva aruṇuggamanā  aruṇe uggata matteya iva suvaṇṇa kāre pakkosāpetvā suvaṇṇa gabbham vivarāpetvā suvaṇṇa ghaṭiyaḥ
translated: “We did not know your virtues, but now that we have begun, we shall not be able to get more than a hundred, or a thousand, or a hundred thousand monks to sit in this house and eat. We shall not be able to clothe them with robes. We shall not be able to build a hundred monasteries or a thousand monasteries.” And they lamented until dawn.

original: mahātulāya tulāpetvā – “pañca kūṭāgārasatāni pañca agghikasatāni karothā”ti dāpeti.
analyzed: mahā tulāya pañca kūṭāgāra satāni pañca agghika satāni karotha ati dāpa iti
translated: As soon as dawn broke, they summoned the goldsmiths, opened the gold chest, weighed the gold in a great balance, and had five hundred peaked houses and five hundred furnaces built.

original: Sakkopi devarājā vissakammadevaputtaṃ āmantetvā – “tāta dhammasenāpati parinibbuto,🔽pañca kūṭāgārasatāni pañca agghikasatāni ca māpehī”ti āha. Iti upāsikāya kāritāni
analyzed: sakkaḥ api devarājā vissakammadeva puttam āmantetvā tāta dhammasenāpati parinibbutaḥ  pañca kūṭāgāra satāni pañca agghika satāni ca mā apehi iti āha iti upāsikāya kāritāni
translated: Sakka, King of the Gods, summoned Vissakamma, saying, “Dear, the General of the Dhamma has attained Nibbāna.

original: ca vissakammena nimmitāni ca sabbānipi dvesahassāni ahesuṃ. Tato nagaramajjhe sāramayaṃ
analyzed: ca vissa kammena nimmitāni ca sabbāni pi dve sahassāni ahesum tatas nagara majjhe sāra mayam
translated: Build five hundred peaked houses and five hundred furnaces.” Thus there were two thousand houses, five hundred built by the lay devotee and five hundred by Vissakamma. Then, in the middle of the city, they built a peaked house of heartwood

original: mahāmaṇḍapaṃ kāretvā maṇḍapamajjhe mahākūṭāgāraṃ ṭhapetvā sesāni parivārasaṅkhepena
analyzed: mahā maṇḍapam kāretvā maṇḍapa majjhe mahā kūṭāgāram ṭhapetvā sesāni parivāra saṅkhepena
translated: and having had a great pavilion erected, and having placed a great many-storied building in the middle of the pavilion, and having placed the rest of the requisites in the form of a surrounding wall,

original: ṭhapetvā sādhukīḷikaṃ ārabhiṃsu. Devānaṃ antare manussā, manussānaṃ antare devā ahesuṃ.
analyzed: ṭhapetvā sādhukīḷikam ārabhiṃsu devānam antare manussāḥ manussānam antare devāḥ ahesuṃ
translated: they began to play well. Among the gods there were men, among men there were gods.

original: Revatī nāma ekā therassa upaṭṭhāyikā – “ahaṃ therassa pūjaṃ karissāmī”ti suvaṇṇapupphānaṃ🔽tayo kumbhe kāresi. “Therassa pūjaṃ karissāmī”ti sakko devarājā aḍḍhateyyakoṭināṭakehi
analyzed: revatī nāma ekā therassa upaṭṭhāyikā aham therassa pūjam karissāmi iti suvaṇṇa pupphānam  tayo kumbhe kāresi therassa pūjam karissāmi iti sakkaḥ devarājā aḍḍhateyya koṭi nāṭakehi
translated: A female lay disciple named Revati, thinking: “I will make an offering to the Elder,” had three jars of gold flowers

original: parivārito otari. “Sakko otaratī”ti mahājano pacchāmukho paṭikkami. Tattha sāpi upāsikā
analyzed: parivāritaḥ otari sakkaḥ otarati iti mahā janaḥ pacchāmukho paṭikkami tattha sā api upāsikā
translated: made. “I will make an offering to the Elder,” Sakka, King of the Gods, descended surrounded by a retinue of a hundred and fifty koṭis. “Sakka is descending,” the great crowd turned their faces away. There the female lay disciple

original: paṭikkamamānā garubhārattā ekamantaṃ apasakkituṃ asakkontī manussānaṃ antare pati.
analyzed: paṭikkamamānā garu bhārattā ekamantam apasakkitum a sakkontī manussānam antare pati
translated: turning away, because of her great weight, was unable to move aside, and fell among the people.

original: Manussā apassantā taṃ madditvā agamiṃsu. Sā tattheva kālaṃ katvā tāvatiṃsabhavane
analyzed: manussāḥ a passantā tam madditvā agamiṃsu sā tattha iva kālam katvā tāvatiṃsa bhavane
translated: The people, not seeing her, trampled her to death and went on. She died right there and was reborn in the Tāvatiṃsa heaven

original: kanakavimāne nibbatti. Nibbattakkhaṇeyevassā ratanakkhandho viya tigāvutappamāṇo
analyzed: kanaka vimāne nibbatti ratana kkhandhaḥ viya
translated: in a golden palace. At the moment of her rebirth, a heap of jewels, three gavutas in size,

original: attabhāvo ahosi saṭṭhisakaṭapūrappamāṇaalaṅkārapaṭimaṇḍitā accharāsahassaparivāritā.
analyzed: atta bhāvaḥ ahosi saṭṭhi sakaṭa pūra ppamāṇa alaṅkāra paṭimaṇḍitā accharā sahassa parivāritā
translated: and she became a celestial nymph, surrounded by a thousand other celestial nymphs, and adorned with ornaments worth a hundred thousand pieces of money.

original: Athassā dibbaṃ sabbakāyikādāsaṃ purato ṭhapayiṃsu. Sā attano sirisampattiṃ disvā
analyzed: dibbam sabbakāyikā dāsam puratas ṭhapayiṃsu sā attanaḥ siri sampattim disvā
translated: Then they placed before her a celestial mirror, and she, beholding her own beauty,

original: – “uḷārā ayaṃ sampatti, kiṃ nu kho me kammaṃ kata”nti cintayamānā addasa – “mayā
analyzed: uḷārā ayam sampatti kim nu kho me kammam katanti cintayamānā addasa mayā
translated: thought: “This is a great glory. What deed did I do?” And she saw that

original: sāriputtattherassa parinibbutaṭṭhāne tīhi suvaṇṇapupphakumbhehi pūjā katā, mahājano🔽maṃ madditvā gato, sāhaṃ tattha kālaṃ katvā idhūpapannā, theraṃ nissāya laddhaṃ idāni
analyzed: sāriputta therassa parinibbuta ṭṭhāne tīhi suvaṇṇa puppha kumbhehi pūjā katā mahājano  mam madditvā gataḥ sā aham tattha kālam katvā idhu upapannā theram nissāya laddham idāni
translated: she had made an offering with three golden flowers at the place where the Elder Sāriputta had attained Nibbāna, and that a great crowd had🔽trodden her down and passed on. She thought: “I died there and was reborn here. Now I will tell men of the fruit of merit I have received

original: puññavipākaṃ manussānaṃ kathessāmī”ti saha vimāneneva otari.🔽Mahājano dūratova disvā – “kiṃ nu kho dve sūriyā uṭṭhitā”ti? Olokento – “vimāne āgacchante
analyzed: puñña vipākam manussānam kathessāmi iti saha vimānena iva otari  mahā janaḥ dūratas iva disvā kim nu kho dve sūriyā uṭṭhitā ati olokentaḥ vimāne āgacchante
translated: through the Elder.” And with her celestial mansion she descended to earth.

original: kūṭāgārasaṇṭhānaṃ paññāyati, nāyaṃ sūriyo, vimānametaṃ eka”nti āha. Tampi vimānaṃ
analyzed: kūṭāgāra saṇṭhānam paññāyati na ayam sūriyaḥ vimānam etam ekam ti āha tam pi vimānam
translated: The people, beholding her from afar, said: “What is this? Are two suns risen?” And looking, they said: “It appears like a peaked house coming through the air. This is not the sun. It is a celestial mansion.”

original: tāvadeva āgantvā therassa dārucitakamatthake vehāsaṃ aṭṭhāsi. Devadhītā vimānaṃ ākāseyeva
analyzed: tāvat eva āgantvā therassa dārucitaka matthake vehāsam aṭṭhāsi deva dhītā vimānam
translated: and stood in the air at the top of the Elder’s funeral pyre. The deva maiden, having left the divine palace in the sky,

original: ṭhapetvā pathaviṃ otari. Mahājano – “kā tvaṃ, ayye”ti? Pucchi. “Na maṃ tumhe jānātha,
analyzed: ṭhapetvā pathavim otari mahājano kā tvam ayyā iti pucchi na mama tumhe jānātha
translated: came down to earth. The people asked her, “Who are you, lady?” She replied, “You do not know me.

original: revatī nāmāhaṃ, tīhi suvaṇṇapupphakumbhehi theraṃ pūjaṃ katvā manussehi madditā kālaṃ
analyzed: revatī nāma aham tīhi suvaṇṇa puppha kumbhehi theram pūjam katvā manussehi madditā kālam
translated: I am Revati. Having worshipped the Elder with three golden flower-baskets, I was crushed by the people and died.

original: katvā tāvatiṃsabhavane nibbattā, passatha me sirisampattiṃ, tumhepi dāni dānāni detha,
analyzed: katvā tāvatiṃsa bhavane nibbattā passatha me siri sampattim tumhe pi dāni dānāni detha
translated: I was reborn in the realm of the Thirty-three. See my glory. Now you also should give gifts,

original: puññāni karothā”ti kusalakiriyāya vaṇṇaṃ kathetvā therassa citakaṃ padakkhiṇaṃ katvā
analyzed: puññāni karotha ati kusala kiriyāya vaṇṇam kathetvā therassa citakam padakkhiṇam katvā
translated: and do meritorious deeds.” Having thus praised meritorious deeds, she circumambulated the Elder’s funeral pyre,

original: vanditvā attano devaṭṭhānaṃyeva gatā.🔽Mahājanopi sattāhaṃ sādhukīḷikaṃ kīḷitvā sabbagandhehi citakaṃ akāsi, citakā ekūnaratanasatikā
analyzed: vanditvā devaṭṭhānaṃyā iva gatā  mahā janaḥ api sattāham sādhu kīḷikam kīḷitvā sabba gandhehi citakam akāsi citakā ekūna ratana satikā
translated: worshipped it, and went to her own divine abode.🔽The people, having played at games of skill for seven days, made the funeral pyre fragrant with all perfumes. The funeral pyre was one hundred and ninety cubits high.🔽The Elder’s body was placed on the funeral pyre and covered with bundles of aloe wood. The people, having lit the funeral pyre,

original: ahosi. Therassa sarīraṃ citakaṃ āropetvā usīrakalāpakehi ālimpesuṃ. Āḷāhane sabbarattiṃ
analyzed: ahosi therassa sarīram citakam āropetvā usīra kalāpakehi ālimpesuṃ āḷāhane sabbarattim
translated: worshipped it all night long.

original: dhammassavanaṃ pavatti. Anuruddhatthero sabbagandhodakena therassa citakaṃ nibbāpesi.
analyzed: dhammassavanam pavatti anuruddha thero sabba gandha udakena therassa citakam nibbāpesi
translated: and the hearing of the Dhamma took place. Elder Anuruddha extinguished the funeral pyre with perfumed water.

original: Cundatthero dhātuyo parissāvane pakkhipitvā – “na dāni mayā idheva sakkā ṭhātuṃ,🔽mayhaṃ jeṭṭhabhātikassa dhammasenāpatisāriputtattherassa parinibbutabhāvaṃ sammāsambuddhassa
analyzed: cunda ttheraḥ dhātuyaḥ parissāvane pakkhipitvā na dāni mayā idha iva sakkā ṭhātum  mayham jeṭṭha bhātikassa dhammasenāpati sāriputta therassa parinibbuta bhāvam sammāsambuddhassa
translated: Elder Cunda put the relics in a basket and thought, “I cannot stay here any longer.

original: ārocessāmī”ti dhātuparissāvanaṃ therassa ca pattacīvaraṃ gahetvā sāvatthiṃ agamāsi.
analyzed: ārocessāmi iti dhātu parissāvanam therassa ca patta cīvaram gahetvā sāvatthim agamāsi
translated: I will inform the Fully Enlightened One of the passing away of my elder brother, the Elder Sāriputta, the General of the Dhamma.” So he took the basket containing the relics and the elder’s bowl and robe and set out for Sāvatthī.

original: Ekaṭṭhānepi ca dve rattiyo avasitvā sabbattha ekarattivāseneva sāvatthiṃ pāpuṇi.
analyzed: eka ṭṭhāne pi ca dve rattiyaḥ avasitvā sabbattha eka ratti vāsena iva sāvatthim pāpuṇi
translated: And he reached Sāvatthī in two days by traveling one day and a half on the first day and a half-day on the second.

original: Tamatthaṃ dassetuṃ atha kho cundo samaṇuddesotiādi vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tam attham dassetum atha kho cundaḥ samaṇuddeso tiādi vuttaṃ
translated: To show that, it is said: “Then Cunda the novice attendant” .

original: Tattha yenāyasmā ānandoti yena attano upajjhāyo dhammabhaṇḍāgāriko āyasmā ānando,
analyzed: tattha yena ayasmai ānandaḥ ti yena attanaḥ upajjhāyaḥ dhammabhaṇḍāgārikaḥ āyasmai ānandaḥ
translated: Herein, by the words “he approached the venerable Ānanda” he approached his own preceptor, the venerable Ānanda, the treasurer of the Dhamma.

original: tenupasaṅkami. Kasmā panesa ujukaṃ satthu santikaṃ agantvā therassa santikaṃ agamāsīti?
analyzed: tena upasaṅkami kasmā pana esa ujukam satthu santikam a gantvā therassa santikam agamāsi iti
translated: But why did he not go straight to the Teacher but go to the elder?

original: Satthari ca there ca gāravena. Jetavanamahāvihāre pokkharaṇiyaṃ kirassa nhatvā paccuttaritvā
analyzed: satthari ca there ca gāravena jetavana mahāvihāre pokkharaṇiyam kirassa nhatvā paccuttaritvā
translated: after bathing in the lotus-tank in the Great Monastery, he came out and

original: sunivatthasupārutassa etadahosi – “buddhā nāma mahāpāsāṇacchattaṃ viya garuno, phaṇakatasappa🔽sīhabyagghamattavaravāraṇādayo viya ca durāsadā, na sakkā mayā ujukameva satthu santikaṃ
analyzed: sunivattha supārutassa etat ahosi buddhāḥ nāma mahā pāsāṇa chattam viya  sīha byaggha matta vara vāraṇa ādayaḥ viya ca durāsadāḥ na sakkāḥ mayā ujukam eva satthu santikam
translated: put on his robe. Then he thought, “The Buddhas are very dignified, like a great stone umbrella, and they are hard to approach, like a cobra,

original: gantvā kathetuṃ, kassa nu kho santikaṃ gantabba”nti. Tato cintesi – “upajjhāyo me🔽dhammabhaṇḍāgāriko jeṭṭhabhātikattherassa uttamasahāyo, tassa santikaṃ gantvā taṃ
analyzed: gantvā kathetum kassa nu kho santikam gantabbanti tatas cintesi upajjhāyaḥ me  dhammabhaṇḍāgārikaḥ jeṭṭhabhātika therassa uttama sahāyaḥ tassa santikam gantvā tam
translated: a lion, a tiger, an elephant, or a bull. I cannot go straight to the Teacher and speak to him. To whom shall I go?” Then he thought, “My preceptor🔽is the treasurer of the Dhamma, and he is the intimate friend of the Elder Jeṭṭhabhāradvāja. I will go to him and take him with me and speak to the

original: ādāya satthārā saddhiṃ kathessāmī”ti satthari ceva there ca gāravena upasaṅkami.🔽Idamassa pattacīvaranti “ayamassa paribhogapatto, idaṃ dhātuparissāvana”nti evaṃ
analyzed: ādāya satthārā saddhim kathessāmi iti satthari ca iva there ca gāravena upasaṅkami  idam assa patta cīvaran ti ayam assa paribhoga patto idam dhātu parissāvanan ti evam
translated: Teacher through him.” So out of respect for the Teacher and the Elder, he went to the Elder.

original: ekekaṃ ācikkhi. Pāḷiyaṃ pana “idamassa pattacīvara”nti ettakameva vuttaṃ. Kathāpābhatanti
analyzed: ekekam ācikkhi pāḷiyam pana idam assa patta cīvaranti ettakam eva vuttam kathāpābhatanti
translated: “This is his bowl and robe,” he said, and he pointed out each article, saying, “This is his bowl; this is his bathing-cloth.” But in the text it is said simply, “This is his bowl and robe.” “The talk that was current” means

original: kathāmūlaṃ. Mūlañhi pābhatanti vuccati. Yathāha –
analyzed: kathā mūlam mūlam hi pābhatanti vuccati yathā āha
translated: The root of talk. For the root is called the “origin” . As it is said:

original: “Appakenapi medhāvī, pābhatena vicakkhaṇo;
analyzed: appakena api medhāvī pābhatena vicakkhaṇaḥ
translated: “Even with a little, the wise man,🔽The man of vision, makes his origin;🔽He makes himself arise, like fire

original: Samuṭṭhāpeti attānaṃ, aṇuṃ aggiṃva sandhama”nti. ;
analyzed: samuṭṭhāpeti attānam aṇum aggim iva sandhamanti
translated: From two sticks rubbed together” .

original: Bhagavantaṃ dassanāyāti bhagavantaṃ dassanatthāya. Kiṃ paniminā bhagavā na diṭṭhapubboti?🔽No na diṭṭhapubbo. Ayañhi āyasmā divā nava vāre, rattiṃ nava vāreti ekāhaṃ aṭṭhārasa
analyzed: bhagavantam dassanāya ati bhagavantam dassana atthāya kim paniminā bhagavā na diṭṭha pubbaḥ ti  no na diṭṭha pubbaḥ ayan hi āyasmai divā nava vāre rattim nava vāre iti ekāham aṭṭhārasa
translated: To see the Lord: for the purpose of seeing the Lord. But has he not seen the Lord before?

original: vāre upaṭṭhānameva gacchati. Divasassa pana satavāraṃ vā sahassavāraṃ vā gantukāmo
analyzed: vāre upaṭṭhānam eva gacchati divasassa pana sata vāram vā sahassa vāram vā gantu kāmo
translated: No, he has not. For this venerable one goes to attend on the Lord eighteen times a day, nine times in the day and nine times at night. And although he would like to go a hundred or a thousand times a day,

original: samānopi na akāraṇā gacchati, ekaṃ pañhadvāraṃ gahetvāva gacchati. So taṃdivasaṃ🔽tena kathāpābhatena gantukāmo evamāha. Idamassa pattacīvaranti theropi – “idaṃ tassa
analyzed: samānaḥ api na akāraṇā gacchati ekam pañha dvāram gahetvā ava gacchati saḥ taṃ divasam  tena kathā pābhatena gantu kāmaḥ evam āha idam assa patta cīvaram ti theraḥ api idam tassa
translated: he does not go without reason. He goes only to take some question to ask. And on this occasion he wanted to go because of the talk he had heard.

original: pattacīvaraṃ, idañca dhātuparissāvana”nti pāṭiyekkaṃyeva dassetvā ācikkhi.
analyzed: patta cīvaram idam ca dhātu parissāvananti pāṭiyekkaṃ yeva dassetvā ācikkhi
translated: This is his bowl and robe: the elder pointed out each separately, saying, “This is his bowl, this his double-robe and water-strainer.”

original: Satthā hatthaṃ pasāretvā dhātuparissāvanaṃ gahetvā hatthatale ṭhapetvā bhikkhū āmantesi
analyzed: satthā hattham pasāretvā dhātu parissāvanam gahetvā hattha tale ṭhapetvā bhikkhū āmantesi
translated: The Teacher, stretching out his hand, took the water for sprinkling the relics, and placing it in his hand, addressed the monks,

original: – “yo so, bhikkhave, bhikkhu purimadivase anekāni pāṭihāriyasatāni katvā parinibbānaṃ
analyzed: yaḥ saḥ bhikkhave bhikkhu purima divase anekāni pāṭihāriya satāni katvā parinibbānam
translated: “Monks, the monk who yesterday performed many hundreds of miracles, and who asked permission to pass into Nibbāna,

original: anujānāpesi, tassa idāni imā saṅkhavaṇṇasannibhā dhātuyova paññāyanti, kappasatasahassādhikaṃ
analyzed: tassa idāni imā saṅkha vaṇṇa sannibhāḥ dhātuyaḥ eva paññāyanti kappa sata sahassa adhikam
translated: his relics, which are like conch-shells in color, are now seen. He has fulfilled the Perfections for more than a hundred thousand incalculable ages.

original: asaṅkhyeyyaṃ pūritapāramī esa, bhikkhave, bhikkhu, mayā pavattitaṃ dhammacakkaṃ anupavattako
analyzed: asaṅkhyeyyam pūrita pāramī esa bhikkhave bhikkhu mayā pavattitam dhammacakkam anupavattakaḥ
translated: This monk has followed the Wheel of the Law which I have set rolling.

original: esa bhikkhu, paṭiladdhadutiyaāsano esa bhikkhu, pūritasāvakasannipāto esa bhikkhu,
analyzed: esa bhikkhu paṭiladdha dutiya āsanaḥ esa bhikkhu pūrita sāvaka sannipātaḥ esa bhikkhu
translated: This monk has obtained a second seat. This monk has filled the assembly of disciples.

original: ṭhapetvā maṃ dasasu cakkavāḷasahassesu paññāya asadiso esa bhikkhu, mahāpañño esa
analyzed: ṭhapetvā mama dasasu cakkavāḷa sahassesu paññāya asadisaḥ esa bhikkhu mahā pañño esa
translated: Excepting me, there is no one in the ten thousand world systems who is his equal in wisdom. This monk is possessed of great wisdom.

original: bhikkhu, puthupañño hāsapañño javanapañño tikkhapañño nibbedhikapañño esa bhikkhu,
analyzed: bhikkhu puthu paññaḥ hāsa paññaḥ javana paññaḥ tikkha paññaḥ nibbedhika paññaḥ esa bhikkhu
translated: He is possessed of wide wisdom, of joyous wisdom, of swift wisdom, of keen wisdom, of penetrating wisdom.

original: appiccho esa bhikkhu, santuṭṭho pavivitto asaṃsaṭṭho āraddhavīriyo codako pāpagarahī
analyzed: appicchaḥ esa bhikkhu santuṭṭhaḥ pavivittaḥ asaṃsaṭṭhaḥ āraddha vīriyo codako pāpa garahī
translated: He is content, he is satisfied, he is secluded, he is not a companion of the multitude, he is energetic, he is a reprover of sin, he is a reprover of evil.

original: esa bhikkhu, pañca jātisatāni paṭiladdhamahāsampattiyo pahāya pabbajito esa bhikkhu,
analyzed: esa bhikkhu pañca jāti satāni paṭiladdha mahā sampattiyaḥ pahāya pabbajitaḥ esa bhikkhu
translated: He has gone forth after giving up the great gains he had for five hundred lives.

original: mama sāsane pathavīsamakhantiko esa bhikkhu, chinnavisāṇausabhasadiso esa bhikkhu,
analyzed: mama sāsane pathavī sama khantikaḥ esa bhikkhu chinna visāṇa osabha sadisaḥ esa bhikkhu
translated: He is as patient as the earth. He is like a bull whose horns have been cut off.🔽He has a humble mind like the son of a caṇḍāla.

original: caṇḍālaputtasadisanīcacitto esa bhikkhu. Passatha, bhikkhave, mahāpaññassa dhātuyo,
analyzed: caṇḍāla putta sadisa nīca cittaḥ esa bhikkhu passatha bhikkhave mahā paññassa dhātuyaḥ
translated: Do you see, monks, the elements of the one with great wisdom?

original: passatha, bhikkhave, puthupaññassa hāsapaññassa javanapaññassa tikkhapaññassa nibbedhikapaññassa
analyzed: passatha bhikkhave puthu paññassa hāsa paññassa javana paññassa tikkha paññassa nibbedhika paññassa
translated: Do you see the elements of the one with wide wisdom, the one with smiling wisdom, the one with swift wisdom, the one with sharp wisdom, the one with deep wisdom,

original: appicchassa santuṭṭhassa pavivittassa asaṃsaṭṭhassa āraddhavīriyassa, codakassa,
analyzed: appicchassa santuṭṭhassa pavivittassa asaṃsaṭṭhassa āraddha vīriyassa codakassa
translated: the one with few desires, the one who is content, the one who is secluded, the one who is not socializing, the one who has aroused energy, the one who is an admonisher,

original: passatha, bhikkhave, pāpagarahissa dhātuyoti.🔽“Yo pabbajī jātisatāni pañca,
analyzed: passatha bhikkhave pāpa garahissa dhātuyaḥ ti  yaḥ pabbajī jāti satāni pañca
translated: the one who is a critic?🔽“He who went forth after giving up the delightful sensual pleasures

original: Pahāya kāmāni manoramāni;
analyzed: pahāya kāmāni manoramāni
translated: For five hundred lives,

original: Taṃ vītarāgaṃ susamāhitindriyaṃ,
analyzed: tam vīta rāgam su samāhita indriyam
translated: The one with no passion, with well-concentrated faculties,

original: Parinibbutaṃ vandatha sāriputtaṃ.
analyzed: parinibbutam vandatha sāriputtam
translated: Extinguished—pay homage to Sāriputta.

original: “Khantibalo pathavisamo na kuppati,
analyzed: khanti balaḥ pathavi samaḥ na kuppati
translated: “The one with patience as his strength, like the earth, who does not get angry,

original: Na cāpi cittassa vasena vattati;
analyzed: na ca api cittassa vasena vattati
translated: And does not go along with the mind,

original: Anukampako kāruṇiko ca nibbuto,
analyzed: anukampakaḥ kāruṇikaḥ ca nibbutaḥ
translated: The one with compassion, the one with mercy, who is extinguished,

original: Parinibbutaṃ vandatha sāriputtaṃ.
analyzed: parinibbutam vandatha sāriputtam
translated: Do homage to Sāriputta who has attained Nibbāna.

original: “Caṇḍālaputto yathā nagaraṃ paviṭṭho,
analyzed: caṇḍāla puttaḥ yathā nagaram paviṭṭhaḥ
translated: Just as a candāla boy, entering a city,

original: Nīcamano carati kaḷopihattho;
analyzed: nīca manaḥ carati
translated: Walks about with head lowered, hands on knees,

original: Tathā ayaṃ viharati sāriputto,
analyzed: tathā ayam viharati sāriputto
translated: So does this one walk about, Sāriputta.

original: Parinibbutaṃ vandatha sāriputtaṃ.
analyzed: parinibbutam vandatha sāriputtam
translated: Do homage to Sāriputta who has attained Nibbāna.

original: “Usabho yathā chinnavisāṇako,
analyzed: usabhaḥ yathā chinna visāṇakaḥ
translated: Just as a bull with broken horns

original: Aheṭhayanto carati purantare vane;
analyzed: carati purantare vane
translated: Walks about unmolested in the forest,

original: Tathā ayaṃ viharati sāriputto,
analyzed: tathā ayam viharati sāriputto
translated: So does this one walk about, Sāriputta.

original: Parinibbutaṃ vandatha sāriputta”nti.
analyzed: parinibbutam vandatha sāriputtanti
translated: Do homage to Sāriputta who has attained Nibbāna.”

original: Iti bhagavā pañcahi gāthāsatehi therassa vaṇṇaṃ kathesi. Yathā yathā bhagavā therassa
analyzed: iti bhagavā pañcahi gāthā satehi therassa vaṇṇam kathesi yathā yathā bhagavā therassa
translated: Thus the Blessed One spoke these five hundred stanzas in praise of the elder. As the Blessed One praised the elder

original: vaṇṇaṃ kathesi, tathā tathā ānandatthero sandhāretuṃ na sakkoti, biḷāramukhe pakkhantakukkuṭo
analyzed: vaṇṇam kathesi tathā tathā ānanda thero sandhāretum na sakkoti biḷāra mukhe pakkhanta kukkuṭo
translated: in this way, the elder Ānanda was unable to contain himself, and he trembled

original: viya pavedhati. Tenāha apica me, bhante, madhurakajāto viya kāyoti sabbaṃ vitthāretabbaṃ.
analyzed: viya pavedhati tena āha apica me bhante madhuraka jātaḥ viya kāyaḥ iti sabbam vitthāretabbam
translated: like a water drop on a lotus leaf when a breeze touches it. Therefore he said: “And, venerable sir, my body seems as if it were drugged. ” All this should be related in detail.

original: Tattha madhurakajātotiādīnaṃ attho vuttoyeva. Idha pana dhammāti uddesaparipucchādhammā
analyzed: tattha madhuraka jātaḥ ti ādīnam atthaḥ vuttaḥ yeva idha pana dhammā ti uddesa paripucchā dhammā
translated: Herein, the meaning of “as if drugged” and so on has already been given . But here “Dhamma” is the Dhamma of instruction and interrogation,

original: adhippetā. Tassa hi uddesaparipucchādhamme agahite vā gahetuṃ, gahite vā sajjhāyaṃ🔽kātuṃ cittaṃ na pavattati. Atha satthā pañcapasādavicitrāni akkhīni ummīletvā theraṃ🔽olokento “assāsessāmi na”nti assāsento kiṃ nu kho te, ānanda, sāriputtotiādimāha.🔽Tattha sīlakkhandhanti lokiyalokuttarasīlaṃ. Samādhipaññāsupi eseva nayo. Vimutti🔽pana lokuttarāva. Vimuttiñāṇadassanaṃ paccavekkhaṇañāṇaṃ, taṃ lokiyameva. Ovādakoti
analyzed: adhippetā tassa hi uddesa paripucchā dhamme a gahite vā gahetum gahite vā sajjhāyam  kātum cittam na pavattati atha satthā pañca pasāda vicitrāni akkhīni ummīletvā theram  olokentaḥ assāsessāmi nanti assāsentaḥ kim nu kho te ānanda sāriputta iti ādim āha  tattha sīla kkhandhanti lokiya lokuttara sīlam samādhi paññāsu pi esā iva nayaḥ vimutti  pana vimutti ñāṇa dassanam paccavekkhaṇa ñāṇam tam lokiyam eva
translated: The Elder Ānanda was the one who was intended. For when the Dhamma is being recited, his mind does not incline to the acquisition of what has not been acquired or to the reviewing of what has been acquired. Then the Teacher, opening his eyes variegated with the five colors, looked at the Elder Ānanda and, thinking, “I will encourage him,” said: “What do you think, Ānanda? ”🔽Herein, virtue is both mundane and supramundane. So too concentration and understanding. But deliverance is only supramundane. Knowledge and vision of deliverance is reviewing knowledge, which is mundane. “Counselor” is one who advises. “Instructor” is one who teaches. “Mentor” is one who reminds. “Adviser” is one who gives advice.

original: ovādadāyako. Otiṇṇoti otiṇṇesu vatthūsu nānappakārena otaraṇasīlo. Viññāpakoti dhammakathākāle🔽atthañca kāraṇañca viññāpetā. Sandassakoti khandhadhātuāyatanavasena tesaṃ tesaṃ🔽dhammānaṃ dassetā. Samādapakoti “idañcidañca gaṇhathā”ti evaṃ gaṇhāpako. Samuttejakoti
analyzed: ovāda dāyakaḥ otiṇṇaḥ ti otiṇṇesu vatthūsu nānappakārena otaraṇa sīlo viññāpako ti dhammakathā kāle 🔽attham ca kāraṇam ca viññāpetā sandassakā ti khandha dhātu āyatana vasena tesam tesam 🔽dhammānam dassetā samādapako ti idam ca idam ca gaṇhatha ati evam gaṇhāpako samuttejako ti
translated: The Elder Ānanda was not yet fully mature in the three trainings. He was not yet fully mature in the higher virtue, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom. He was not yet fully mature in the three aggregates . He was not yet fully mature in the aggregates of virtue, concentration, and wisdom. He was not yet fully mature in the three kinds of knowledge . He was not yet fully mature in the knowledge of the scriptures, in the knowledge of mental development, and in the knowledge of perspicuity. He was not yet fully mature in the three kinds of confidence . He was not yet fully mature in confidence in the Enlightened One, in confidence in the True Idea, and in confidence in the Community. He was not yet fully mature in the three kinds of faith . He was not yet fully mature in faith in the Enlightened One, in faith in the True Idea, and in faith in the Community. He was not yet fully mature in the three kinds of knowledge of the scriptures . He was not yet fully mature in the knowledge of the scriptures in the five Nikayas, in the knowledge of the scriptures in the seven Abhidhamma Piṭakas, and in the knowledge of the scriptures in the eight Paramattha Piṭakas. He was not yet fully mature in the three kinds of knowledge of mental development . He was not yet fully mature in the knowledge of mental development in the forty meditation subjects, in the knowledge of mental development in the thirty-two modes of mindfulness of breathing, and in the knowledge of mental development in the thirty-two kinds of bodily reflection. He was not yet fully mature in the three kinds of perspicuity . He was not yet fully mature in perspicuity in the scriptures, in perspicuity in mental development, and in perspicuity in perspicuity. He was not yet fully mature in the three kinds of learning . He was not yet fully mature in learning in the scriptures, in learning in mental development, and in learning in perspicuity. He was not yet fully mature in the three kinds of knowledge of the scriptures . He was not yet fully mature in the knowledge of the scriptures in the five Nikayas, in the knowledge of the scriptures in the seven Abhidhamma Piṭakas, and in the knowledge of the scriptures in the eight Paramattha Piṭakas. He was not yet fully mature in the three kinds of knowledge of mental development . He was not yet fully mature in the knowledge of mental development in the forty meditation subjects, in the knowledge

original: abbhussāhako. Sampahaṃsakoti paṭiladdhaguṇehi modāpako jotāpako.🔽Akilāsu dhammadesanāyāti dhammadesanaṃ ārabhitvā “sīsaṃ vā me rujjati, hadayaṃ vā🔽kucchi vā piṭṭhi vā”ti evaṃ osakkanākāravirahito nikkilāsu visārado ekassāpi dvinnampi
analyzed: abbhussāhako sampahaṃsako ti paṭiladdha guṇehi modāpakaḥ jotāpakaḥ  a kilāsu dhamma desanāya ati dhamma desanam ārabhitvā sīsam vā me rujjati hadayam vā  vā piṭṭhi vā ati evam osakkana ākāra virahitaḥ nikkilāsu visāra daḥ ekassa api dvinnam pi
translated: He is a stimulator. He is a gladdener: he is one who gladdens and delights by means of the special qualities he has acquired.🔽He is indefatigable in teaching the Dhamma: he is indefatigable, fearless, and confident in teaching the Dhamma, without showing any such signs as a stiff neck, a headache, a pain in the heart, or a pain in the stomach.

original: sīhavegeneva pakkhandati. Anuggāhako sabrahmacārīnanti padassa attho khandhakavagge
analyzed: sīha vegena iva pakkhandati anuggāhakaḥ padassa attho khandhaka vagge
translated: He teaches the Dhamma to others in detail as he has heard it and learned it. He is a supporter of the community: the meaning of this phrase has been given in the Khandhakas.

original: vitthāritova. Dhammojaṃ dhammabhoganti ubhayenapi dhammaparibhogova kathito. Dhammānuggahanti
analyzed: vitthāritaḥ iva dhamma ojam dhamma bhogam ti ubhayena api dhamma paribhogaḥ uva kathitaḥ dhamma anuggaham ti
translated: He is one who partakes of the Dhamma: by both phrases he is said to partake of the Dhamma. He is a promoter of the Dhamma:

original: dhammena anuggahaṇaṃ.
analyzed: dhammena anuggahaṇam
translated: he is one who promotes the Dhamma.

original: Satthā “ativiya ayaṃ bhikkhu kilamatī”ti puna taṃ assāsento nanu taṃ, ānanda, mayātiādimāha.
analyzed: satthā ativiya ayam bhikkhu kilamati iti puna tam assāsentaḥ nanu tam ānanda mayā iti ādim āha
translated: The Teacher, thinking “This bhikkhu is over-fatigued,” again encouraged him, saying “Now, Ananda, have I not told you already:

original: Tattha piyehi manāpehīti mātāpitābhātābhaginīādikehi jātiyā nānābhāvo, maraṇena vinābhāvo,
analyzed: tattha piyehi manāpehi iti mātā pitā bhātā bhaginī ādikehi jātiyā nānābhāvaḥ maraṇena vinābhāvaḥ
translated: Herein, dear to those dear: there is difference in kind through birth, such as mother, father, brother, sister, etc., and difference through death, such as wife, child, slaves, servants, and so on.

original: bhavena aññathābhāvo. Taṃ kutettha, ānanda, labbhāti tanti tasmā. Yasmā sabbehi piyehi
analyzed: bhavena aññathābhāvo tam kuta ittha ānanda tanti tasmai yasmai sabbehi piyehi
translated: and the separation from what is dear is a different state. Where is that to be found, Ānanda? ” Thus. Because of the separation from all that is dear and agreeable,

original: manāpehi nānābhāvo, tasmā dasa pāramiyo pūretvāpi sambodhiṃ patvāpi dhammacakkaṃ
analyzed: tasmā dasa pāramiyaḥ pūretvā api sambodhim patvā api dhammacakkam
translated: therefore, after fulfilling the ten perfections, after attaining full enlightenment, after setting in motion the Wheel of the Dhamma,

original: pavattetvāpi yamakapāṭihāriyaṃ dassetvāpi devorohanaṃ katvāpi yaṃ taṃ jātaṃ bhūtaṃ
analyzed: pavattetvā api yamaka pāṭihāriyam dassetvā api deva ārohanam katvā api yam tam jātam bhūtam
translated: after displaying the Twin Miracle, after descending from the Tāvatiṃsa gods, after performing all the duties of a Buddha,

original: saṅkhataṃ palokadhammaṃ, taṃ tathāgatassāpi sarīraṃ mā palujjīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjati,
analyzed: saṅkhatam paloka dhammam tam tathāgatassa api sarīram mā palujji iti na itam ṭhānam vijjati
translated: that which is born, become, compounded, subject to dissolution, that the Tathāgata’s body should not dissolve—that is not possible.

original: rodantenapi kandantenapi na sakkā taṃ kāraṇaṃ laddhunti. So palujjeyyāti so bhijjeyya.🔽Evameva khoti ettha yojanasatubbedho mahājamburukkho viya bhikkhusaṅgho tassa dakkhiṇadisaṃ
analyzed: rodantena api kandantena api na sakkā tam kāraṇam laddhun ti saḥ palujjeyya ati saḥ bhijjeyya  evam eva kho ti ettha yojana satu bedhaḥ mahā jambu rukkhaḥ viya bhikkhu saṅgho tassa dakkhiṇa disam
translated: Even if you weep and wail, you will not be able to get that reason. It will dissolve.

original: gato paññāsayojaniko mahākhandho viya dhammasenāpati. Tasmiṃ mahākhandhe bhinne tato
analyzed: gataḥ paññāsayojanikaḥ mahā khandhaḥ viya dhammasenāpati tasmin mahā khandhe bhinne tatas
translated: Just so, in the same way, the Community of monks is like a great rose-apple tree a hundred yojanas high, and the General of the Dhamma is like a great branch of it, fifty yojanas long,

original: paṭṭhāya anupubbena vaḍḍhitvā pupphaphalādīhi taṃ ṭhānaṃ pūretuṃ samatthassa aññassa
analyzed: paṭṭhāya anupubbena vaḍḍhitvā puppha phala ādīhi tam ṭhānam pūretum samatthassa aññassa
translated: on the southern side. When that great branch is broken, then after that, gradually increasing, another one is able to fill that place with flowers, fruits, etc.

original: khandhassa abhāvo viya there parinibbute soḷasannaṃ paññānaṃ matthakaṃ pattassa aññassa
analyzed: khandhassa abhāvaḥ viya there parinibbute soḷasannam paññānam matthakam pattassa aññassa
translated: Just as there is no more of the aggregate of the aggregates when the Elder has attained Nibbāna, so too there is no more of the bhikkhu who has reached the summit of the sixteen kinds of knowledge and is capable of sitting in the seat of offering like Sāriputta.

original: dakkhiṇāsane nisīdanasamatthassa sāriputtasadisassa bhikkhuno abhāvo. Tāya paribhinnāya🔽so rukkho viya bhikkhusaṅgho khandhotveva jātoti veditabbo. Tasmāti yasmā sabbaṃ
analyzed: dakkhiṇāsane nisīdana samatthassa sāriputta sadisassa bhikkhuno abhāvaḥ tāya paribhinnāya  so rukkhaḥ viya bhikkhu saṅghaḥ khandhaḥ tvā iva jātaḥ iti veditabbaḥ tasmā iti yasmā sabbam
translated: When that is broken up,🔽the Community of bhikkhus is like the tree and should be understood as the aggregate of the aggregates.

original: saṅkhataṃ palokadhammaṃ, taṃ mā palujjīti na sakkā laddhuṃ, tasmā.
analyzed: saṅkhatam paloka dhammam tam mā palujji iti na sakkā laddhum tasmai
translated: Therefore: since all that is formed is subject to destruction, it cannot be made not to be destroyed.

original: 4-5. Ukkacelasuttādivaṇṇanā🔽380-381. Catutthe aciraparinibbutesu sāriputtamoggallānesūti naciraparinibbutesu
analyzed: catutthe acira parinibbutesu sāriputta moggallānesu iti nacira parinibbutesu
translated: The explanation of the Ukkacelā Sutta, etc.,🔽In the fourth , in the case of the two chief disciples who had recently attained Nibbāna: not long after they had attained Nibbāna,

original: dvīsu aggasāvakesu. Tesañhi dhammasenāpati kattikamāsapuṇṇamāya parinibbuto, mahāmoggallāno
analyzed: dvīsu aggasāvakesu tesam hi dhammasenāpati kattika māsa puṇṇamāya parinibbutaḥ mahā moggallānaḥ
translated: for the General of the Dhamma had attained Nibbāna on the full-moon day of the Kattika month, and Mahā Moggallāna

original: tato aḍḍhamāsaṃ atikkamma amāvasuposathe. Satthā dvīsu aggasāvakesu parinibbutesu
analyzed: tatas aḍḍha māsam atikkamma amāvasu posathe satthā dvīsu aggasāvakesu parinibbutesu
translated: had done so a fortnight later on the Uposatha day of the waning fortnight. When the two chief disciples had attained Nibbāna,

original: mahābhikkhusaṅghaparivāro mahāmaṇḍale cārikaṃ caramāno anupubbena ukkacelanagaraṃ
analyzed: mahā bhikkhu saṅgha parivāraḥ mahā maṇḍale cārikam caramānaḥ anupubbena ukkacela nagaram
translated: the Master, surrounded by a great community of bhikkhus, was wandering on walking tour among the Magadhans and eventually reached the town of Ukkacelā.

original: patvā tattha piṇḍāya caritvā gaṅgāpiṭṭhe rajatapaṭṭavaṇṇavālikāpuline vihāsi. Tena
analyzed: patvā tattha piṇḍāya caritvā gaṅgā piṭṭhe rajata paṭṭa vaṇṇa vālikā puline vihāsi tena
translated: and after wandering for alms there, he stayed on the bank of the Ganges on a sandy isle the color of silver-leaf.

original: vuttaṃ “aciraparinibbutesu sāriputtamoggallānesū”ti. Ye mahantatarā khandhā te palujjeyyunti🔽idhāpi yojanasatubbedho mahājamburukkho viya bhikkhusaṅgho, tassa dakkhiṇato ca uttarato
analyzed: vuttam acira parinibbutesu sāriputta moggallānesu iti ye mahantatarā khandhā te palujjeyyun ti  idha api yojana satu bedhaḥ mahā jambu rukkhaḥ viya bhikkhu saṅgho tassa dakkhiṇatas ca uttaratas
translated: Therefore it was said: “Soon after the final Nibbana of Sariputta and Moggallana.”🔽The two chief disciples are like the two great branches of a great rose-apple tree, each fifty leagues long, that extend to the south and north of the tree.

original: ca gatā paṇṇāsayojanikā dve mahākhandhā viya dve aggasāvakāti. Sesaṃ purimanayeneva
analyzed: ca gatā paṇṇāsi yojanikā dve mahā khandhā viya dve agga sāvakā ati sesam purima nayena iva
translated: The rest should be construed in the same way as before.

original: yojetabbaṃ. Pañcame diṭṭhīti kammassakadiṭṭhi.
analyzed: yojetabbam pañcame diṭṭhi iti kammassaka diṭṭhi
translated: In the fifth sutta, “views” means the view that one is the owner of one’s kamma.

original: 6. Uttiyasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: uttiya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Sutta on Uttiya

original: 382. Chaṭṭhe maccudheyyassa pāranti tebhūmakavaṭṭassa pārabhūtaṃ, nibbānaṃ.
analyzed: chaṭṭhe maccudheyyassa tebhūmakavaṭṭassa pāra bhūtam nibbānam
translated: In the sixth sutta, “the destruction of the domain of Death” means Nibbana, which is the destruction of the round of rebirths in the three planes.

original: 8. Brahmasuttavaṇṇanā🔽384. Aṭṭhame kāye vā bhikkhūti tasmiṃ kāle bhikkhuyeva natthi, evaṃ santepi yo satipaṭṭhāne
analyzed: brahma sutta vaṇṇanā  aṭṭhame kāye vā bhikkhu iti tasmin kāle bhikkhuyā iva natthi evam sante pi yaḥ satipaṭṭhāne
translated: The Sutta on Brahma🔽In the eighth sutta, “a bhikkhu” means one who develops the foundations of mindfulness.🔽Even though there were no bhikkhus at that time, he is called a bhikkhu because he is a splitter of the defilements.

original: bhāveti, so kilesabhindanena bhikkhuyevāti dassento evamāha. Ekāyananti ekamaggaṃ.
analyzed: bhāveti so kilesa bhindanena bhikkhuyā iva ati dassentaḥ evam āha ekāyanam ti eka maggam
translated: “The one way” is the one path.

original: Jātikkhayantadassīti jātiyā khayoti ca antoti ca nibbānaṃ, taṃ passatīti attho. Maggaṃ🔽pajānātīti ekāyanasaṅkhātaṃ ekamaggabhūtaṃ maggaṃ pajānāti. Ekāyanamaggo vuccati
analyzed: jāti khaya anta dassī iti jātiyā khayaḥ ati ca antaḥ ti ca nibbānam tam passati iti atthaḥ maggam  pajānāti iti ekāyana saṅkhātam eka magga bhūtam maggam pajānāti ekāyana maggaḥ vuccati
translated: He sees the end of birth: the end of birth is extinction, and he sees that.🔽He understands the path: he understands the path that is called the “one-way-path” because it is the one path.

original: pubbabhāgasatipaṭṭhānamaggo, taṃ pajānātīti attho.
analyzed: pubbabhāga sati paṭṭhāna maggo tam pajānāti iti attho
translated: The path of the earlier-mentioned foundations of mindfulness is called the “one-way-path.” He understands that, is the meaning.

original: 9. Sedakasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sedaka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Explanation of the Ninth Meditation Subject

original: 385. Navame sumbhesūti evaṃnāmake janapade. Medakathālikāti evaṃ itthiliṅgavasena
analyzed: navame evaṃnāmake janapade evam itthi liṅga vasena
translated: In the country called Sumbha: in the country called Sumbha. Medakathālikā: the name of a woman.

original: laddhanāmaṃ. Mamaṃ rakkha, ahaṃ taṃ rakkhissāmīti ettha ayaṃ tassa laddhi – ācariyo🔽ukkhittavaṃsaṃ suggahitaṃ agaṇhanto, antevāsikena pakkhantapakkhantadisaṃ agacchanto,🔽sabbakālañca vaṃsaggaṃ anullokento antevāsikaṃ na rakkhati nāma, evaṃ arakkhito antevāsiko
analyzed: laddha nāmam mamam rakkha aham tam rakkhissāmi iti ettha ayam tassa laddhi ācariyo  ukkhitta vaṃsam su gahitam a gaṇhantaḥ antevāsikena pakkhanta pakkhanta disam a gacchantaḥ  sabbakālam ca vaṃsaggam an ullokentaḥ antevāsikam na rakkhati nāma evam a rakkhitaḥ antevāsikaḥ
translated: Protect me, I will protect you: here is the agreement: the teacher🔽does not hold the well-planted pole, and the pupil, going in the direction he has been sent,🔽and looking at the top of the pole all the time, does not protect the pupil. The pupil,

original: patitvā cuṇṇavicuṇṇaṃ hoti. Vaṃsaṃ pana suggahitaṃ gaṇhanto, tena pakkhantapakkhantadisaṃ
analyzed: patitvā cuṇṇa vicuṇṇam hoti vaṃsam pana suggahitam gaṇhanto tena pakkhanta pakkhanta disam
translated: not being protected in this way, falls down and is smashed to pieces. But if the pupil holds the pole well planted, and the teacher, going in the direction the pupil has been sent,

original: gacchanto, sabbakālañca vaṃsaggaṃ ullokento taṃ rakkhati nāma. Antevāsikopi ito cito🔽ca pakkhanditvā migo viya kīḷanto ācariyaṃ na rakkhati nāma. Evañhi sati tikhiṇavaṃsakoṭi
analyzed: gacchantaḥ sabbakālam ca vaṃsaggam ullokentaḥ tam rakkhati nāma antevāsikaḥ api itas citas  ca pakkhanditvā migaḥ viya kīḷantaḥ ācariyam na rakkhati nāma evam hi sati
translated: and he protects the teacher by looking at the top of the bamboo pole all the time as he goes. The pupil does not protect the teacher if he jumps about here and there

original: ācariyassa galavāṭake vā nalāṭe vā ṭhapitā ṭhitaṭṭhānaṃ bhinditvā gaccheyya. Ācārasampannatāya🔽pana yato vaṃso namati, tato anāmento taṃ ākaḍḍhento viya ekatobhāgiyaṃ katvā vātūpathambhaṃ
analyzed: ācariyassa galavāṭake vā nalāṭe vā ṭhapitā ṭhita ṭṭhānam bhinditvā gaccheyya ācāra sampanna tāya  pana yatas vaṃsaḥ namati tatas tam ākaḍḍhentaḥ viyaḥ ekatobhāgiyam katvā
translated: like a deer and plays the clown. For if he did so, the sharp end of the bamboo pole might slip from its place in the teacher’s throat or chest and go in some other direction. But when he is possessed of good conduct,

original: gāhāpetvā satiṃ sūpaṭṭhitaṃ katvā niccalova nisīdanto ācariyaṃ rakkhati nāmāti.
analyzed: gāhāpetvā satim su upaṭṭhitam katvā niccalaḥ va nisīdantaḥ ācariyam rakkhati nāma ati
translated: he does not let the bamboo pole bend to one side or the other as he walks, but he holds it upright like a flagstaff set up as an offering to a deity, and he sits down without moving as soon as he has established mindfulness well. That is how he protects the teacher.

original: Tvaṃ ācariya attānaṃ rakkha, ahaṃ attānaṃ rakkhissāmīti ettha ayamadhippāyo – ācariyo
analyzed: tvam ācariya attānam rakkha aham attānam rakkhissāmi iti ettha ayam adhippāyaḥ ācariyaḥ
translated: The meaning of the words “You protect yourself, teacher, I shall protect myself” is this: the teacher

original: vaṃsaṃ suggahitaṃ gaṇhanto, antevāsikena pakkhantapakkhantadisaṃgacchanto, sabbakālañca
analyzed: vaṃsam suggahitam gaṇhantaḥ antevāsikena pakkhanta pakkhanta disaṃgacchantaḥ sabbakālam ca
translated: holds the bamboo pole well gripped, and the pupil, who is jumping about here and there,

original: vaṃsaggaṃ ullokento, attānameva rakkhati, na antevāsikaṃ. Antevāsikopi kāyampi ekatobhāgiyaṃ🔽katvā vātūpathambhaṃ gāhāpetvā satiṃ sūpaṭṭhitaṃ katvā niccalova nisīdamāno attānaṃyeva
analyzed: vaṃsaggam ullokentaḥ attānam eva rakkhati na antevāsikam antevāsikaḥ api kāyam pi ekatobhāgiyam  katvā vātūpathambham gāhāpetvā satim su upaṭṭhitam katvā niccalaḥ uva nisīdamānaḥ attā anaṃyā iva
translated: He protects himself, not his pupil. And the pupil, too, by making himself a single unit with his body,

original: rakkhati nāma, na ācariyaṃ.
analyzed: rakkhati nāma naḥ ācariyam
translated: by taking a firm stance, by establishing mindfulness well, by sitting down unagitated, protects himself, not his teacher.

original: So tattha ñāyoti yaṃ medakathālikā āha. So tattha ñāyo, so upāyo, taṃ kāraṇanti attho.
analyzed: so tattha ñāyo ti yam medakathālikā āha saḥ tattha ñāyo saḥ upāyo tam kāraṇanti attho
translated: “That is the way there”: the way spoken of by Medakathālikā is the way, the means, the cause.

original: Satipaṭṭhānaṃ sevitabbanti catubbidhaṃ satipaṭṭhānaṃ sevitabbaṃ. Āsevanāyāti kammaṭṭhānāsevanāya.
analyzed: sati paṭṭhānam sevitabbanti catubbidham sati paṭṭhānam sevitabbam āsevanāya ati kammaṭṭhāna āsevanāya
translated: “The foundations of mindfulness should be developed”: the four foundations of mindfulness should be developed. “By development”: by the development of the meditation subject.

original: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, attānaṃ rakkhanto paraṃ rakkhatīti yo bhikkhu kammārāmatādīni
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave attānam rakkhantaḥ param rakkhati iti yaḥ bhikkhu kamma ārāma tā ādīni
translated: “Thus, bhikkhus, by protecting oneself”: a bhikkhu who abandons delight in work, etc.,

original: pahāya rattiṭṭhānadivāṭṭhānesu mūlakammaṭṭhānaṃ āsevanto bhāvento arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti,
analyzed: pahāya ratti ṭṭhāna divāṭṭhānesu mūlakammaṭṭhānam āsevantaḥ bhāventaḥ arahattam pāpuṇāti
translated: and who attains arahatship by developing and cultivating the basic meditation subject in the night quarters and the day quarters,

original: atha naṃ paro disvā – “bhaddako vatāyaṃ, bhikkhu, sammāpaṭipanno”ti tasmiṃ cittaṃ
analyzed: atha nam paraḥ disvā bhaddakaḥ vata ayam bhikkhu sammāpaṭipannaḥ ti tasmim cittam
translated: then another bhikkhu, seeing him, thinks: “This bhikkhu is truly well behaved.” He arouses a sense of

original: pasādetvā saggaparāyaṇo hoti. Ayaṃ attānaṃ rakkhanto paraṃ rakkhati nāma.🔽Khantiyāti adhivāsanakhantiyā. Avihiṃsāyāti sapubbabhāgāya karuṇāya. Mettacittatāyāti
analyzed: pasādetvā sagga parāyaṇaḥ hoti ayam attānam rakkhantaḥ param rakkhati nāma  khantiyā ati adhivāsana khantiyā avihiṃsāya ati sa pubbabhāgāya karuṇāya metta citta tāya ati
translated: and he is reborn in heaven. This is called “one who protects himself protects another.”

original: sapubbabhāgāya mettāya. Anudayatāyāti anuvaḍḍhiyā, sapubbabhāgāya muditāyāti attho.
analyzed: sa pubbabhāgāya mettāya anudayatāya ati anuvaḍḍhiyā sa pubbabhāgāya muditāya ati attho
translated: “Patience” is the patience of acquiescence. “Non-violence” is compassion with its prior stage. “A mind of loving-kindness” is loving-kindness with its prior stage. “Sympathy” is sympathy with its prior stage, that is, appreciative joy.

original: Paraṃ rakkhanto attānaṃ rakkhatīti ettha yo bhikkhu rattiṭṭhānadivāṭṭhānaṃ gato tīsu
analyzed: param rakkhantaḥ attānam rakkhati iti ettha yaḥ bhikkhu ratti ṭṭhāna divāṭṭhānam gataḥ tīsu
translated: “One who protects another protects himself”: here a bhikkhu who has gone to a place for the day’s abiding or to a place for the night’s abiding,

original: brahmavihāresu tikacatukkajjhānāni nibbattetvā jhānaṃ pādakaṃ katvā saṅkhāre sammasanto
analyzed: brahmavihāresu tika catukka jjhānāni nibbattetvā jhānam pādakam katvā saṅkhāre sammasantaḥ
translated: after producing the triple and quadruple jhanas in the three divine abidings, makes jhana the basis for insight,

original: vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti. Ayaṃ paraṃ rakkhanto attānaṃ rakkhati nāmāti veditabbo.
analyzed: vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā arahattam pāpuṇāti ayam param rakkhantaḥ attānam rakkhati nāma ati veditabbaḥ
translated: and after developing insight he attains arahatship. This is called “one who protects another protects himself.”

original: 10. Janapadakalyāṇīsuttavaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary

original: 386. Dasame janapadakalyāṇīti janapadamhi kalyāṇī uttamā chasarīradosarahitā pañcakalyāṇasamannāgatā.
analyzed: dasame janapada kalyāṇī iti janapadamhi kalyāṇī uttamā cha sarīra dosa rahitā pañca kalyāṇa samannāgatā
translated: Janapadakalyani: the most beautiful woman in the country, the best, free from the faults of voice and body, endowed with the five qualities of beauty.

original: Sā hi yasmā nātidīghā nātirassā, nātikisā nātithūlā, nātikāḷā nāccodātā, atikkantā,🔽mānusavaṇṇaṃ appattā dibbavaṇṇaṃ, tasmā chasarīradosarahitā. Chavikalyāṇaṃ, maṃsakalyāṇaṃ,
analyzed: sā hi yasmā na ati dīghā na ati rassā na ati kisā na ati thūlā na ati kāḷā na accodātā atikkantā  mānusa vaṇṇam appattā dibba vaṇṇam tasmā cha sarīra dosa rahitā chavi kalyāṇam maṃsa kalyāṇam
translated: For it is not too long, not too short, not too thin, not too stout, not too dark, not too fair, but🔽passes beyond the human colour and approaches the divine colour.🔽It is endowed with the five kinds of beauty, namely, beauty of skin, beauty of flesh,🔽beauty of bone, beauty of veins, and beauty of age. It is devoid of the three faults of skin, namely, roughness, coarseness, and impurity.🔽It is devoid of the three faults of flesh, namely, looseness, flabbiness, and unevenness.

original: nhārukalyāṇaṃ, aṭṭhikalyāṇaṃ, vayakalyāṇanti imehi pana kalyāṇehi samannāgatattā🔽pañcakalyāṇehi samannāgatā nāma. Tassā hi āgantukobhāsakiccaṃ natthi, attano sarīrobhāseneva
analyzed: nhāru kalyāṇam aṭṭhi kalyāṇam vaya kalyāṇanti imehi pana kalyāṇehi samannāgata ttā  pañca kalyāṇehi samannāgatā nāma tassāḥ hi āgantuka ubhāsa kiccam natthi attanaḥ sarīra ubhāsena iva
translated: It is devoid of the three faults of veins, namely, crookedness, roughness, and unevenness.🔽It is devoid of the three faults of bones, namely, crookedness, roughness, and unevenness.🔽It is devoid of the three faults of age, namely, paleness, trembling, and weakness.

original: dvādasahatthaṭṭhāne ālokaṃ karoti, piyaṅgusāmā vā hoti, suvaṇṇasāmā vā, ayamassā
analyzed: dvādasa hattha ṭṭhāne ālokam karoti piyaṅgu sāmā vā hoti suvaṇṇa sāmā vā
translated: It is devoid of the three faults of skin, namely, roughness, coarseness, and impurity.

original: chavikalyāṇatā. Cattāro panassā hatthapādā mukhapariyosānañca lākhārasaparikammakataṃ🔽viya rattapavāḷarattakambalasadisaṃ hoti, ayamassā maṃsakalyāṇatā. Vīsati pana nakhapattāni
analyzed: chavi kalyāṇa tā cattāro panassāḥ hattha pādāḥ mukha pariyosānañca lākhā rasa parikammakatam  ratta pavāḷa ratta kambala sadisam hoti maṃsa kalyāṇa tā vīsati pana nakha pattāni
translated: It is devoid of the three faults of flesh, namely, looseness, flabbiness, and unevenness.🔽It is devoid of the three faults of veins, namely, crookedness, roughness, and unevenness.🔽It is devoid of the three faults of bones, namely, crookedness, roughness, and unevenness.

original: maṃsato amuttaṭṭhāne lākhārasapūritāni viya, muttaṭṭhāne khīradhārāsadisāni, honti
analyzed: maṃsataḥ a mutta ṭṭhāne lākhā rasa pūritāni viya mutta ṭṭhāne khīra dhārā sadisāni honti
translated: It is devoid of the three faults of age, namely, paleness, trembling, and weakness.

original: ayamassā nhārukalyāṇakatā. Dvattiṃsa dantā suphusitā sudhotavajirapanti viya khāyanti,
analyzed: dvattiṃsa dantā su phusitā viya khāyanti
translated: This is her good teeth. Her thirty-two teeth are set evenly and look as if they were made of pure dhava-gold.

original: ayamassā aṭṭhikalyāṇatā. Vīsativassasatikāpi pana samānā soḷasavassuddesikā viya
analyzed: ayam assā aṭṭhi kalyāṇa tā vīsati vassa satikā api pana samānā soḷasa vassuddesikā viya
translated: This is her good bones. And though she is over twenty years old, she looks as if she were sixteen.

original: hoti nippalitā, ayamassā vayakalyāṇatā.🔽Paramapāsāvinīti ettha pasavanaṃ pasāvo, pavattīti attho. Pasāvo eva pāsāvo. Paramo🔽pāsāvo paramapāsāvo, so assā atthīti paramapāsāvinī. Nacce ca gīte ca uttamapavatti
analyzed: hoti nippalitā  parama pāsāvinī iti ettha pasavanam pasāvaḥ pavatti iti attho pasāvaḥ eva pāsāvaḥ paramaḥ  pāsāvo parama pāsāvo saḥ assā atthi iti parama pāsāvinī nacce ca gīte ca uttama pavatti
translated: This is her good age.🔽She has the utmost charm: here the charm is the charm of her movement, the meaning being that her movement is charming. The charm of her movement is her utmost charm. She has that utmost charm. She is the utmost in dancing and singing:

original: seṭṭhakiriyā, uttamameva naccaṃ naccati, gītaṃ vā gāyatīti vuttaṃ hoti. Sesaṃ sabbattha
analyzed: seṭṭha kiriyā uttamam eva naccam naccati gītam vā gāyati iti vuttam hoti sesam sabbattha
translated: she is the utmost in dancing and singing, the best in dancing and singing, is what is meant. The rest is all clear.

original: uttānatthameva. Imesu pana dvīsu suttesu pubbabhāgavipassanāva kathitāti.
analyzed: uttāna attham eva imesu pana dvīsu suttesu pubbabhāga vipassanā ava kathitā ti
translated: But in these two sutta-passages only insight reached in the earlier stage is spoken of.

original: Nālandavaggo dutiyo.🔽3. Sīlaṭṭhitivaggo
analyzed: nālanda vaggaḥ dutiyaḥ  sīla ṭṭhiti vaggo
translated: The second sub-chapter on Nāḷandā is finished.🔽1. The sub-chapter on the support of virtue

original: 1-2. Sīlasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Sīlakkhandhavagga is finished.

original: 387-388. Tatiyavaggassa paṭhame sīlānīti catupārisuddhisīlāni. Dutiye ummaṅgoti pañhamaggo pañhagavesanaṃ.
analyzed: tatiya vaggassa paṭhame sīlāni iti catu pārisuddhi sīlāni dutiye ummaṅgo ti pañha maggo pañha gavesanam
translated: In the first of the third group, “virtues” are the virtues of the fourfold purity. In the second, “the path of questions” is the path of questioning, the seeking of questions.

original: 3-5. Parihānasuttādivaṇṇanā🔽389-391. Tatiye parihānaṃ hotīti puggalavasena parihānaṃ hoti. Yo hi buddhesu dharantesupi🔽cattāro satipaṭṭhāne na bhāveti, tassa saddhammo antarahito nāma hoti devadattādīnaṃ
analyzed: tatiye parihānam hoti iti puggala vasena parihānam hoti yaḥ hi buddhesu  cattāro sati paṭṭhāne na bhāveti tassa saddhammo antarahitaḥ nāma hoti devadatta ādīnam
translated: The Exposition of the Parihānasutta, etc.

original: viya. Iti imasmiṃ sutte tassa puggalasseva dhammantaradhānaṃ kathitaṃ. Catutthapañcamesu sabbaṃ uttānameva.
analyzed: viya iti imasmim sutte tassa puggalassa iva dhamma antara dhānam kathitam catuttha pañcamesu sabbam uttānam eva
translated: In the third, “there is a falling away” means that there is a falling away of persons. For when one does not develop the four foundations of mindfulness, the true Dhamma disappears for him, as it did for Devadatta and others. So in this sutta the disappearance of the Dhamma for that kind of person is spoken of. In the fourth and fifth all is clear.

original: 6. Padesasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: padesa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Exposition of the Padesasutta

original: 392. Chaṭṭhe padesaṃ bhāvitattāti padesato bhāvitattā. Cattāro hi magge tīṇi ca phalāni nibbattentena satipaṭṭhānā padesaṃ bhāvitā nāma honti.
analyzed: chaṭṭhe padesam bhāvita ttā ati padesataḥ bhāvita ttā cattāraḥ hi magge tīṇi ca phalāni nibbattentena sati paṭṭhānā padesam bhāvitāḥ nāma honti
translated: In the sixth, “because they are developed in part” means that they are developed in part because they are developed in part. For when one generates the four paths and the three fruits, the foundations of mindfulness are called “developed in part.”

original: 7. Samattasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: samatta sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Exposition of the Samattasutta

original: 393. Sattame samattaṃ bhāvitattāti samattā bhāvitattā. Arahattaphalaṃ uppādentena hi satipaṭṭhānā samattaṃ bhāvitā nāma honti.
analyzed: sattame samattam bhāvita ttā ati samattāḥ bhāvita ttāḥ arahatta phalam uppādentena hi sati paṭṭhānā samattam bhāvitāḥ nāma honti
translated: In the seventh, “he has developed them to consummation”: they are called “developed to consummation” because he has developed them to consummation. For when he arouses the fruit of arahantship, the foundations of mindfulness are called “developed to consummation.”
