refined are those of

original: sotāpattimaggeyeva indriyehi mudutarāni dhammānusārimaggindriyāni. Tehipi mudutarāni
analyzed: indriyehi mudutarāni dhamma anusāri magga indriyāni tehi pi mudutarāni
translated: The faculties of the Dhamma-follower path are more sluggish than those of the stream-enterer path. The faculties of the faith-follower path are more sluggish than those.

original: saddhānusārimaggindriyāni. Chaṭṭhasattamāni vuttanayāneva. Imesu pana tīsupi suttesu
analyzed: saddhā anusāri magga indriyāni chaṭṭha sattamāni vutta nayānā iva imesu pana tīsu pi suttesu
translated: The sixth and seventh are as already stated. But in these three suttantas

original: pubbabhāgavipassanindriyāneva kathitāni.
analyzed: kathitāni
translated: the faculties of insight in the preliminary stage are spoken of.

original: 8. Paṭipannasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paṭipanna sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary on the “Path-attainer” Thread

original: 488. Aṭṭhame tato mudutarehīti maggaphalavasena nissakkaṃ veditabbaṃ. Taṃ pāḷiyaṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhame tatas mudutarehi iti magga phala vasena nissakkam veditabbam tam pāḷiyam
translated: . In the eighth, “more sluggish than those” should be understood as referring to the path and fruition attainments. That is stated in the text.

original: vuttameva. Bāhiroti imehi aṭṭhahi puggalehi bahibhūto. Puthujjanapakkhe ṭhitoti puthujjanakoṭṭhāse
analyzed: vuttam eva bāhiraḥ ti imehi aṭṭhahi puggalehi bahibhūto puthujjana pakkhe ṭhito ti puthujjana koṭṭhāse
translated: “Outside” : excluded from these eight persons. “Standing in the faction of the worldling” : standing in the worldling’s position.

original: ṭhito. Imasmiṃ sutte lokuttarāneva indriyāni kathitāni.
analyzed: imasmin sutte indriyāni kathitāni
translated: In this sutta only supramundane faculties are spoken of.

original: 9-10. Sampannasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: sampanna sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary on the “Endowed” Thread, etc.

original: 489-490. Navame indriyasampannoti paripuṇṇindriyo. Dasamaṃ uttānameva. Imasmiṃ suttadvaye missakāni indriyāni kathitānīti.
analyzed: navame indriya sampannaḥ ti paripuṇṇa indriyaḥ dasamam uttānam eva imasmim sutta dvaye missakāni indriyāni kathitāni iti
translated: . In the ninth, “endowed with faculties” : having complete faculties. The tenth is self-evident. In these two suttantas mixed faculties are spoken of.

original: Mudutaravaggo dutiyo.
analyzed: mudutara vaggo dutiyaḥ
translated: The second sub-chapter on “more sluggish” is finished.

original: 3. Chaḷindriyavaggo
analyzed: chaṣ indriya vaggaḥ
translated: . The sub-chapter on the six faculties

original: 2. Jīvitindriyasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary on the “Life Faculty” Thread🔽.

original: 492. Tatiyavaggassa dutiye itthindriyantiādīsu itthibhāve indaṭṭhaṃ karotīti itthindriyaṃ.
analyzed: tatiya vaggassa dutiye itthi indriya nti ādīsu itthi bhāve indaṭṭham karoti iti itthi indriyam
translated: In the second of the third group, in the case of the words the femininity faculty, etc., it makes the determination in the femininity state, thus it is the femininity faculty.

original: Purisabhāve indaṭṭhaṃ karotīti purisindriyaṃ. Jīvite indaṭṭhaṃ karotīti jīvitindriyaṃ.
analyzed: purisa bhāve indaṭṭham karoti iti purisa indriyam jīvite indaṭṭham karoti iti jīvitindriyam
translated: It makes the determination in the masculinity state, thus it is the masculinity faculty. It makes the determination in the life faculty state, thus it is the life faculty.

original: Atthuppattikaṃ kiretaṃ suttaṃ. Saṅghamajjhasmiñhi “kati nu kho vaṭṭindriyānī”ti kathā
analyzed: attha uppattikam kiretam suttam saṅgha majjhasmin hi kati nu kho vaṭṭi indriyāni iti kathā
translated: This sutta is apparently a question-begging one, for the discussion arose in the midst of the Sangha as to how many faculties there are in the round of rebirths.🔽Then the Blessed One, showing the faculties in the round of rebirths, said, “Bhikkhus, there are these three faculties.”

original: udapādi, atha bhagavā vaṭṭindriyāni dassento tīṇimāni bhikkhavetiādimāha.🔽3. Aññindriyasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: udapādi atha bhagavā vaṭṭi indriyāni dassentaḥ tīṇi imāni bhikkhave ti ādim āha  aññindriya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Faculties

original: 493. Tatiye anaññātaññassāmītindriyanti “anamatagge saṃsāre ajānitapubbaṃ dhammaṃ🔽jānissāmī”ti paṭipannassa sotāpattimaggakkhaṇe uppannaṃ indriyaṃ. Aññindriyanti tesaṃyeva
analyzed: tatiye an aññā a tañña ssāmi iti indriyanti an amatagge saṃsāre a jānita pubbam dhammaṃ  jānissāmi iti paṭipannassa sotāpatti magga kkhaṇe uppannam indriyam aññindriyanti tesam yeva
translated: In the third, the faculty of final knowledge of what is as yet unknown is the faculty that arises in one who has entered upon the way for the realization of the Dhamma that has not been known before in the beginningless round of rebirths.🔽The faculty of final knowledge is the faculty that arises in the six instances beginning with the fruit of stream-entry in one who has known those dhammas.

original: ñātadhammānaṃ ājānanākārena sotāpattiphalādīsu chasu ṭhānesu uppannaṃ indriyaṃ. Aññātāvindriyanti
analyzed: ñāta dhammānam ājānana ākārena sotāpatti phala ādīsu chasu ṭhānesu uppannam indriyam aññātāvindriyam ti
translated: The faculty of final knowledge of what is as yet unknown is the faculty that arises in one who has entered upon the way for the realization of the Dhamma that has not been known before in the beginningless round of rebirths.

original: aññātāvīsu arahattaphaladhammesu uppannaṃ indriyaṃ. Tattha tattha tena tenākārena
analyzed: aññātāvīsu arahatta phala dhammesu uppannam indriyam tattha tattha tena tena ākārena
translated: The faculty arisen in the states of the path of arahatship is the faculty of one who has known.

original: uppannassa ñāṇassevetaṃ adhivacanaṃ. Idampi suttaṃ atthuppattikameva. Saṅghamajjhasmiñhi🔽“kati nu kho lokuttarindriyānī”ti kathā udapādi, atha bhagavā tāni dassento tīṇimāni,
analyzed: uppannassa ñāṇassa iva etam adhivacanam idam pi suttam attha uppattikam eva saṅgha majjhasmin hi  kati nu kho lokuttara indriyāni iti kathā udapādi atha bhagavā tāni dassento tīṇi imāni
translated: This is a term for the knowledge arisen in this or that way in this or that state. This sutta too is concerned with the arising of meaning.

original: bhikkhave, indriyānītiādimāha.
analyzed: bhikkhave indriyāni iti ādim āha
translated: For the discussion arose in the midst of the Order: “How many supramundane faculties are there?” Then the Exalted One, showing them, said: “Bhikkhus, there are these three faculties.”

original: 4. Ekabījīsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ekabījī sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary to the Single-Seed Discourse

original: 494. Catutthe tato mudutarehīti vipassanato nissakkaṃ veditabbaṃ. Samattāni hi pañcindriyāni🔽arahattamaggassa vipassanindriyāni nāma honti, tato mudutarāni antarāparinibbāyissa🔽vipassanindriyāni, tato mudutarāni upahaccaparinibbāyissa, tato mudutarāni asaṅkhāraparinibbāyissa,
analyzed: catutthe tatas mudutarehi iti vipassanataḥ nissakkam veditabbam samattāni hi pañca indriyāni  arahatta maggassa vipassanindriyāni nāma honti tatas mudutarāni antarā parinibbāyissa  vipassanī indriyāni tatas mudutarāni upahacca parinibbāyissa tatas mudutarāni asaṅkhāra parinibbāyissa
translated: In the fourth, “more tender than that” should be understood as “more tender than insight.” For the five faculties that are complete🔽are called the faculties of insight of the path of arahatship. More tender than that are the faculties of insight of one who attains extinction in the interval;🔽more tender than that are the faculties of insight of one who attains extinction upon landing; more tender than that are the faculties of insight of one who attains extinction without prompting;

original: tato mudutarāni sasaṅkhāraparinibbāyissa, tato mudutarāni uddhaṃsotaakaniṭṭhagāmissa
analyzed: tatas mudutarāni sa saṅkhāra parinibbāyissa tatas mudutarāni
translated: more tender than that are the faculties of insight of one who attains extinction with prompting; more tender than that are the faculties of insight of one who goes upstream to the end of the peak of existence.

original: vipassanindriyāni nāma. Idhāpi purimanayeneva arahattamagge ṭhatvā pañca nissakkāni nīharitabbāni.
analyzed: vipassanindriyāni nāma idha api purima nayena iva arahatta magge ṭhatvā pañca nissakkāni nīharitabbāni
translated: The faculties of insight are called the faculties of the path of arahatship. Here too, as in the case of the path of non-return, five factors should be eliminated.

original: Yathā pana purimanaye sakadāgāmimagge ṭhatvā tīṇi nissakkāni, evamidha pañca nīharitabbāni.🔽Sakadāgāmimaggassa hi vipassanindriyehi mudutarāni sotāpattimaggassa vipassanindriyāni,
analyzed: yathā pana purima naye sakadāgāmi magge ṭhatvā tīṇi nissakkāni evam idha pañca nīharitabbāni  sakadāgāmi maggassa hi vipassan indriyehi mudutarāni sotāpatti maggassa vipassan indriyāni
translated: But just as in the case of the path of non-return three factors are eliminated, so here five should be eliminated.🔽For the faculties of insight of the path of stream-entry are more sluggish than those of the path of non-return.🔽And the faculties of insight of the path of the once-returner are more sluggish than those of the path of stream-entry.

original: sotāpattimaggassa ca tehi vipassanindriyehi mudutarāni ekabījiādīnaṃ maggassa vipassanindriyāni.
analyzed: sotāpatti maggassa ca tehi vipassanī indriyehi mudutarāni ekabīji ādīnam maggassa vipassanī indriyāni
translated: And the faculties of insight of the path of the non-returner are more sluggish than those of the path of the once-returner.🔽And the faculties of insight of the path of the arahat are more sluggish than those of the path of the non-returner.🔽And the faculties of insight of the paths of the single-opener, etc., are more sluggish than those of the path of the arahat.

original: Ettha ca ekabījītiādīsu yo sotāpanno hutvā ekameva attabhāvaṃ janetvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti,🔽ayaṃ ekabījī nāma. Yathāha “katamo ca puggalo ekabījī, idhekacco puggalo tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ
analyzed: ettha ca ekabījī iti ādīsu yaḥ so utāpannaḥ hutvā ekam eva atta bhāvam janetvā arahattam pāpuṇāti  ayam ekabījī nāma yathā āha katamo ca puggalo ekabījī idha ekacco puggalo tiṇṇam saṃyojanānam
translated: Herein, the single-opener is one who, having become a stream-enterer, produces only one more existence and then attains arahatship.🔽As it is said: “What kind of person is a single-opener? Here someone, with the destruction of three fetters, is a stream-enterer, no longer subject to perdition, bound for enlightenment.

original: parikkhayā sotāpanno hoti avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo, so ekaññeva mānusakaṃ
analyzed: parikkhayā sotāpannaḥ hoti avinipāta dhammo niyataḥ sambodhi parāyaṇaḥ so ekaññā iva mānusakam
translated: He is reborn among human beings once

original: bhavaṃ sandhāvitvā saṃsaritvā dukkhassantaṃ karoti. Ayaṃ vuccati puggalo ekabījī”ti.
analyzed: bhavam sandhāvitvā saṃsaritvā dukkhassantam karoti ayam vuccati puggalaḥ eka bījī ti
translated: who makes an end of suffering after wandering and transmigrating in two or three existences. This is called a single-seeded person.”

original: Yo pana dve tayo bhave saṃsaritvā dukkhassantaṃ karoti, ayaṃ kolaṃkolo nāma. Yathāha🔽“katamo ca puggalo kolaṃkolo. Idhekacco puggalo tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā sotāpanno🔽hoti avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo, so dve vā tīṇi vā kulāni sandhāvitvā🔽saṃsaritvā dukkhassantaṃ karoti. Ayaṃ vuccati puggalo kolaṃkolo”ti. Tattha kulānīti
analyzed: yaḥ pana dve tayaḥ bhave saṃsaritvā dukkhassantam karoti ayam kolaṃkolaḥ nāma yathā āha  katamo ca puggalo kolaṃkolaḥ idha ekacco puggalo tiṇṇam saṃyojanānam parikkhayā sotāpanno  hoti a vinipāta dhammaḥ niyataḥ sambodhi parāyaṇaḥ saḥ dve vā tīṇi vā kulāni sandhāvitvā  saṃsaritvā dukkhassantam karoti ayam vuccati puggalo kolaṃkolo ti tattha kulāni iti
translated: But one who makes an end of suffering after wandering and transmigrating in two or three existences is called a “clusterer,” according as it is said:

original: bhavā veditabbā. “Dve vā tīṇi vā”ti idaṃ desanāmattameva, yāva chaṭṭhabhavā saṃsaranto🔽pana kolaṃkolova hoti.
analyzed: bhavāḥ veditabbāḥ dve vā tīṇi vā ati idam desanā mattam eva yāva chaṭṭha bhavā saṃsaranto  pana kolaṃkolaḥ uva hoti
translated: “What kind of person is a clusterer? Here someone with the destruction of three fetters is a stream-enterer, no longer bound to the nether world, fixed in destiny, heading for enlightenment. He wanders and transmigrates among gods and humans two or three times and then makes an end of suffering. This is called a clusterer.” Herein, “two or three times” is a mere expression for “two or three existences.” But a clusterer wanders and transmigrates as far as the sixth existence.

original: Yassa sattakkhattuṃ paramā upapatti, aṭṭhamaṃ bhavaṃ nādiyati, ayaṃ sattakkhattuparamo
analyzed: yassa satta kkhattum paramā upapatti aṭṭhamam bhavam na ādiyati ayam satta kkhattu paramaḥ
translated: One whose rebirth is limited to seven times at most, who does not take an eighth existence, is called one “with rebirth limited to seven times” .

original: nāma. Yathāha “katamo ca puggalo sattakkhattuparamo. Idhekacco puggalo tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ🔽parikkhayā sotāpanno hoti avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo, so sattakkhattuṃ🔽deve ca manusse ca sandhāvitvā saṃsaritvā dukkhassantaṃ karoti, ayaṃ vuccati puggalo
analyzed: nāma yathā āha katamaḥ ca puggalo satta kkhattu paramaḥ idha ekacco puggalo tiṇṇam saṃyojanānam  parikkhayā sotāpannaḥ hoti a vinipāta dhammaḥ niyataḥ sambodhi parāyaṇaḥ so sattakkhattum  deve ca manusse ca sandhāvitvā saṃsaritvā dukkhassantam karoti ayam vuccati puggalo
translated: As it is said: “And what is a person of seven rebirths at most? Here someone, with the exhaustion of three fetters is a stream-enterer, no longer subject to falling (into the lower realms), and has a fixed destiny ending in Final Awakening;🔽having passed away seven times among gods and humans, he makes an end of suffering. This is called a person of seven rebirths at most.🔽🔽

original: sattakkhattuparamo”ti.🔽Bhagavatā gahitanāmavaseneva cetāni tesaṃ nāmāni. “Ettakañhi ṭhānaṃ gato ekabījī
analyzed: satta kkhattu paramaḥ ti  bhagavatā gahita nāma vasena iva ca itāni tesam nāmāni ettakam hi ṭhānam gataḥ ekabījī
translated: and so on. As it is said: “What kind of person is a one-seeder? Here someone, with the exhaustion of three fetters, is a stream-enterer, no longer subject to rebirth in lower worlds, fixed in destiny, heading for enlightenment. Having transmigrated seven times among gods and humans, he makes an end of suffering. This kind of person is called a one-seeder” .

original: nāma hoti, ettakaṃ kolaṃkolo, ettakaṃ sattakkhattuparamo”ti bhagavatā etesaṃ nāmaṃ
analyzed: nāma hoti ettakam kolaṃkolaḥ ettakam satta kkhattu paramaḥ ti bhagavatā etesam nāmam
translated: These names are given to them by the Blessed One according to the name of the state they have reached. “He has gone this far” , the Blessed One has said, “he is a one-seeder; he has gone this far, he is a clan-to-clanner; he has gone this far, he is a seven-seeder” .

original: gahitaṃ. Niyamato pana “ayaṃ ekabījī, ayaṃ kolaṃkolo, ayaṃ sattakkhattuparamo”ti natthi.
analyzed: gahitam niyamataḥ pana ayam eka bījī ayam kolaṃkolaḥ ayam satta khattu paramaḥ ti natthi
translated: But there is no fixed rule that “this one is a one-seeder, this one is a clan-to-clanner, this one is a seven-seeder.”

original: Ko pana nesaṃ etaṃ pabhedaṃ niyametīti? Keci pana therā “pubbahetu niyametī”ti vadanti,
analyzed: kaḥ pana nesam etam pabhedam niyameti iti keci pana therā pubba hetu niyameti iti vadanti
translated: But who determines their classification? Some elders say that the prior cause determines it.

original: keci “paṭhamamaggo”, keci “uparima tayo maggā”, keci “tiṇṇaṃ maggānaṃ vipassanā”ti.🔽Tattha “pubbahetu niyametī”ti vāde paṭhamamaggassa upanissayo kato nāma hoti, upari
analyzed: paṭhama maggo tayaḥ maggā keci tiṇṇam maggānam vipassanā ati  tattha pubba hetu niyameti iti vāde paṭhama maggassa upanissayaḥ kataḥ nāma hoti upari
translated: Some say it is the first path, some the three higher paths, some the insight of the three paths.

original: tayo maggā anupanissayā uppannāti vacanaṃ āpajjati. “Paṭhamamaggo niyametī”ti vāde🔽upari tiṇṇaṃ maggānaṃ niratthakatā āpajjati. “Upari tayo maggā niyamentī”ti vāde🔽paṭhamamagge anuppanneva upari tayo maggā uppannāti āpajjati. “Tiṇṇaṃ maggānaṃ vipassanā
analyzed: tayo maggāḥ anupanissayāḥ uppannā ati vacanam āpajjati paṭhama maggaḥ niyameti iti vāde  upari tiṇṇam maggānam niratthaka tā āpajjati upari tayo maggāḥ niyamenti iti vāde  paṭhama magge anuppannā iva upari tayo maggāḥ uppannā ati āpajjati tiṇṇam maggānam vipassanā
translated: Herein, in the case of the view that the first path determines, it follows that the first path is made the decisive-support, and the three higher paths arise without a decisive-support.🔽In the case of the view that the first path determines, it follows that the three higher paths are useless.🔽In the case of the view that the three higher paths determine, it follows that the three higher paths arise even before the first path.

original: niyametī”ti vādo pana yujjati. Sace hi upari tiṇṇaṃ maggānaṃ vipassanā balavatī hoti,🔽ekabījī nāma hoti, tato mandatarāya kolaṃkolo, tato mandatarāya sattakkhattuparamoti.
analyzed: niyameti iti vādaḥ pana yujjati sace hi upari tiṇṇam maggānam vipassanā balavatī hoti  ekabījī nāma hoti tatas mandatarāya kolaṃkolo tatas mandatarāya satta kkhattu paramaḥ ti
translated: But the view that the insight of the three paths determines is correct. For if the insight of the three higher paths is strong,🔽he is called a single-seed , and if it is weaker than that, a clan-to-clan , and if it is weaker still, a seven-at-most .

original: Ekacco hi sotāpanno vaṭṭajjhāsayo hoti vaṭṭābhirato punappunaṃ vaṭṭasmiṃyeva vicarati
analyzed: ekaccaḥ hi sotāpannaḥ vaṭṭa ajjhāsayaḥ hoti vaṭṭa abhirato punappunam vaṭṭasmiṃyeva vicarati
translated: For some who have entered the stream are addicted to the round and delight in the round. They go round and round in the round again and again.

original: sandissati. Anāthapiṇḍiko seṭṭhi, visākhā upāsikā, cūḷarathamahārathā devaputtā,
analyzed: sandissati anāthapiṇḍiko seṭṭhi visākhā upāsikā cūḷaratha mahārathā devaputtā
translated: and it is he who is meant here. The merchant Anathapindika, the laywoman Visakha, the two young gods Cula- and Maha-Ratha,

original: anekavaṇṇo devaputto, sakko devarājā, nāgadatto devaputtoti ime hi ettakā janā vaṭṭajjhāsayā
analyzed: anekavaṇṇaḥ deva putto sakkaḥ deva rājā nāgadatto deva putto ti ime hi ettakāḥ janāḥ vaṭṭa jhāsayā
translated: the young god Anekavanna, Sakka Ruler of Gods, and the young god Nagasena: these people, though they have had the thought of the round for a long time,

original: vaṭṭābhiratā ādito paṭṭhāya cha devaloke sodhetvā akaniṭṭhe ṭhatvā parinibbāyissanti,
analyzed: vaṭṭa abhiratāḥ āditas paṭṭhāya cha deva loke sodhetvā akaniṭṭhe ṭhatvā parinibbāyissanti
translated: though they delight in the round, will purify the six divine worlds beginning with the first, and then they will attain extinction in the Akanittha heaven.

original: ime idha na gahitā. Na kevalañcime, yopi manussesuyeva sattakkhattuṃ saṃsaritvā arahattaṃ🔽pāpuṇāti, yopi devaloke nibbatto devesuyeva sattakkhattuṃ aparāparaṃ saṃsaritvā arahattaṃ
analyzed: ime idha na gahitāḥ na kevalañca ime yaḥ api manussesu yā iva satta kkhattum saṃsaritvā arahattam  pāpuṇāti yaḥ api deva loke nibbattaḥ devesu yā iva satta kkhattum apara aparam saṃsaritvā arahattam
translated: But they are not included here. And not only they, but also those who attain Arahantship after passing through seven more existences among men,

original: pāpuṇāti, imepi idha na gahitā. Kālena deve, kālena manusse saṃsaritvā pana arahattaṃ🔽pāpuṇantova idha gahito. Tasmā sattakkhattuparamoti idaṃ idhaṭṭhakavokiṇṇasukkhavipassakassa
analyzed: pāpuṇāti ime pi idha na gahitā kālena deve kālena manusse saṃsaritvā pana arahattam  pāpuṇanto va idha gahito tasmā satta kkhattu paramaḥ ti idam idhaṭṭhaka vokiṇṇa sukkha vipassakassa
translated: and those who attain Arahantship after passing through seven more existences among the gods, are not included here. But those who attain Arahantship after passing through existences among gods and men both are included here.

original: nāmaṃ kathitanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: nāmam kathitan ti veditabbam
translated: Therefore it should be understood that the words “at most seven times” are said of the type of person who is included here, who is a once-returner with a single interval, a once-returner with a double interval, or a once-returner with a triple interval.

original: Dhammānusārī saddhānusārīti ettha pana imasmiṃ sāsane lokuttaradhammaṃ nibbattentassa
analyzed: dhamma anusārī saddhā anusārī iti ettha pana imasmim sāsane lokuttara dhammam nibbattentassa
translated: In this Dispensation there are two kinds of persons who generate the supramundane Dhamma:

original: dve dhurāni, dve sīsāni, dve abhinivesā – saddhādhuraṃ, paññādhuraṃ, saddhāsīsaṃ,🔽paññāsīsaṃ, saddhābhiniveso, paññābhinivesoti. Tattha yo bhikkhu “sace saddhāya sakkā
analyzed: dve dhurāni dve sīsāni dve abhinivesā saddhādhuram paññādhuram saddhāsīsam  pañcāsīsam saddhā abhiniveso paññā abhiniveso ti tattha yaḥ bhikkhu sace saddhāya sakkā
translated: two kinds of persons who are headed by faith and two kinds who are headed by understanding, two kinds who have faith as their chief and two kinds who have understanding as their chief, two kinds who are resolved upon faith and two kinds who are resolved upon understanding.

original: nibbattetuṃ, nibbattessāmi lokuttaramagga”nti saddhaṃ dhuraṃ katvā sotāpattimaggaṃ🔽nibbatteti, so maggakkhaṇe saddhānusārī nāma hoti. Phalakkhaṇe pana saddhāvimutto
analyzed: nibbattetum nibbattessāmi lokuttara maggam ti saddham dhuram katvā sotāpatti maggam  nibbattā iti so magga kkhaṇe saddhā anusārī nāma hoti phala kkhaṇe pana saddhā vimutto
translated: Herein, when a bhikkhu thinks “If it is possible to generate the supramundane path by means of faith, I shall generate it,” and he generates the stream-entry path by making faith the chief factor,

original: nāma hutvā ekabījī kolaṃkolo sattakkhattuparamoti tividho hoti. Tattha ekeko dukkhāpaṭipadādivasena
analyzed: nāma hutvā eka bījī kolaṃkolo satta kkhattu paramaḥ ti tividhaḥ hoti tattha ekekaḥ dukkha apaṭipada ādi vasena
translated: he is called a faith-follower at the moment of the path. But at the moment of fruition he is called one “liberated by faith” and he is of three kinds as a single-opener, a clan-to-clanner, and a seven-at-most.🔽Herein, each of these is of four kinds as of swift direct-knowledge, etc.,

original: catubbidhabhāvaṃ āpajjatīti saddhādhurena dvādasa janā honti.
analyzed: catubbidha bhāvam āpajjati iti saddhā dhurena dvādasa janāḥ honti
translated: so there are twelve kinds in all who are headed by faith.

original: Yo pana “sace paññāya sakkā nibbattetuṃ, nibbattessāmi lokuttaramagga”nti paññaṃ
analyzed: yaḥ pana sace paññāya sakkā nibbattetum nibbattessāmi lokuttara maggan ti paññam
translated: But when a bhikkhu thinks “If it is possible to generate the supramundane path by means of understanding, I shall generate it,” and he generates the stream-entry path by making understanding the chief factor,

original: dhuraṃ katvā sotāpattimaggaṃ nibbatteti, so maggakkhaṇe dhammānusārī nāma hoti. Phalakkhaṇe🔽pana paññāvimutto nāma hutvā ekabījiādibhedena dvādasabhedova hoti. Evaṃ dve maggaṭṭhā
analyzed: dhuram katvā sotāpatti maggam nibbatteti so magga kkhaṇe dhamma anusārī nāma hoti phala kkhaṇe  pana paññāvimuttaḥ nāma hutvā eka bīji ādi bhedena dvādasa bhedaḥ u hoti evam dve maggaṭṭhā
translated: and he generates the path of stream-entry, making that the object, he is called a “Dhamma-follower” at the moment of the path.🔽But at the moment of fruition he is called “liberated by understanding” and he is one of the twelve kinds of stream-enterer distinguished according to the number of his remaining births, and so on.

original: phalakkhaṇe catuvīsati sotāpannā hontīti.
analyzed: phalakkhaṇe catuvīsati sotāpannāḥ honti iti
translated: So there are two kinds of persons in the state of the path and twenty-four kinds in the state of fruition.

original: Tipiṭakatissatthero kira “tīṇi piṭakāni sodhessāmī”ti paratīraṃ gato. Taṃ eko kuṭumbiko
analyzed: tipiṭaka tissa theraḥ kira tīṇi piṭakāni sodhessāmi iti para tīram gataḥ tam ekaḥ kuṭumbikaḥ
translated: The Elder Tipiṭaka Cūḷa-Abhaya, it seems, went to the other shore, thinking, “I shall purify the three Piṭakas.” A certain householder

original: catūhi paccayehi upaṭṭhāsi, thero āgamanakāle “gacchāmi upāsakā”ti āha. “Kahaṃ bhante”ti?🔽“Amhākaṃ ācariyupajjhāyānaṃ santika”nti. “Na sakkā, bhante, mayā gantuṃ, bhaddantaṃ
analyzed: catūhi paccayehi upaṭṭhāsi theraḥ āgamana kāle gacchāmi upāsaka iti āha kaham bhante iti  amhākam ācariya upajjhāyānam santikam ti na sakkā bhante mayā gantum bhaddantam
translated: attended on him with the four requisites. When the elder was about to leave, he said, “I am going, lay follower.” “Where to, venerable sir?”

original: pana nissāya mayā sāsanassa guṇo ñāto, tumhākaṃ parammukhā kīdisaṃ bhikkhuṃ upasaṅkamāmī”ti?
analyzed: pana nissāya mayā sāsanassa guṇo ñāto tumhākam parammukhā kīdisam bhikkhum upasaṅkamāmi iti
translated: “To my teachers and preceptors.” “I cannot go, venerable sir, but because of your kindness, venerable sir, I have come to know the good qualities of the Dispensation. What kind of bhikkhu should I visit?”

original: Atha naṃ thero āha – “yo bhikkhu catuvīsati sotāpanne dvādasa sakadāgāmī aṭṭhacattālīsa
analyzed: atha nam theraḥ āha yo bhikkhu catuvīsati sotāpanne dvādasa sakadāgāmī aṭṭha cattālīsa
translated: Then the elder said, “A bhikkhu who has twenty-four stream-enterers, twelve once-returners, and forty-eight non-returners

original: anāgāmī dvādasa arahante dassetvā dhammakathaṃ kathetuṃ sakkoti, evarūpaṃ bhikkhuṃ
analyzed: anāgāmī dvādasa arahante dassetvā dhamma katham kathetum sakkoti evarūpam bhikkhum
translated: The non-returner can teach Dhamma after showing twelve arahants. A bhikkhu of this kind

original: upaṭṭhātuṃ vaṭṭatī”ti. Imasmiṃ sutte vipassanā kathitāti.
analyzed: upaṭṭhātum vaṭṭati iti imasmin sutte vipassanā kathitā ti
translated: is fit to attend on the sick.” Insight is taught in this sutta.

original: 5-10. Suddhakasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: suddhaka sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary on the Suddhaka Sutta, etc.

original: 495-500. Pañcame cakkhu ca taṃ cakkhudvāre nibbattānaṃ dhammānaṃ ādhipateyyasaṅkhātena
analyzed: pañcame cakkhu ca tam cakkhu dvāre nibbattānam dhammānam ādhipateyya saṅkhātena
translated: . In the fifth sutta, “eye” is the eye faculty because it is a ruler in the sense of being dominant over the states that arise in the eye door.

original: indaṭṭhena indriyañcāti cakkhundriyaṃ. Sotindriyādīsupi eseva nayo. Sesaṃ sabbattha🔽uttānameva. Imasmiṃ vagge paṭhamasuttañceva chaṭṭhādīni ca pañcāti cha suttāni catusaccavasena kathitānīti.🔽Chaḷindriyavaggo tatiyo.
analyzed: inda aṭṭhena indriyam ca ati cakkhundriyam sotindriya ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ sesam sabbattha  uttānam eva imasmin vagge paṭhama suttam ca iva chaṭṭha ādīni ca pañca ati cha suttāni catu sacca vasena kathitāni iti  chaḷ indriya vaggo tatiyaḥ
translated: The same method applies to the ear faculty, etc. The rest is clear throughout.

original: 4. Sukhindriyavaggo🔽1-5. Suddhikasuttādivaṇṇanā🔽501-505. Catutthavaggassa paṭhame sukhañca taṃ sahajātānaṃ ādhipateyyasaṅkhātena
analyzed: sukha indriya vaggo 🔽suddhika sutta ādi vaṇṇanā 🔽catuttha vaggassa paṭhame sukham ca tam sahajātānam ādhipateyya saṅkhātena
translated: In this vagga, the first sutta and the last five suttas, beginning with the sixth, are the six suttas taught by way of the four truths.

original: indaṭṭhena indriyañcāti sukhindriyaṃ. Dukkhindriyādīsupi eseva nayo. Ettha ca sukhindriyadukkhindriyadomanassindriyāni🔽kāmāvacarāneva, somanassindriyaṃ ṭhapetvā arūpāvacaraṃ sesaṃ tebhūmakaṃ, upekkhindriyaṃ
analyzed: inda aṭṭhena indriyam ca ati sukha indriyam dukkha indriya ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ ettha ca sukha indriya dukkha indriya domanassa indriyāni  kāmāvacarān eva somanassindriyam ṭhapetvā arūpāvacaram sesam tebhūmakam upekkhindriyam
translated: and in the sense of ruling, it is a faculty. So too with the pain faculty, etc.🔽Herein, the pleasure faculty, pain faculty, and grief faculty🔽are only in the sense sphere. The joy faculty is in the fine-material sphere, except in the fourth jhāna, and it is in the sense sphere. The rest are in three planes. The equanimity faculty🔽is in all three.🔽

original: catubhūmakaṃ. Dutiyādīni cattāri catusaccavaseneva kathitāni.
analyzed: catu bhūmakam dutiya ādīni cattāri catu sacca vasena iva kathitāni
translated: and in the sense of ruling, it is a faculty. So it is the pleasure faculty. The same method applies in the case of the pain faculty, and so on. Herein, the pleasure faculty, the pain faculty, and the joy faculty are only in the sense sphere. The equanimity faculty is in four planes. The remaining three are in three planes, excluding the immaterial sphere. The second and the following three are stated according to the four truths.

original: 6. Paṭhamavibhaṅgasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: . The first division

original: 506. Chaṭṭhe kāyikanti kāyapasādavatthukaṃ. Sukhanti ayamassa sarūpaniddeso. Sātanti
analyzed: chaṭṭhe kāyikanti kāya pasāda vatthukam sukhanti ayam assa sarūpa niddeso sātam ti
translated: In the sixth, bodily: based on bodily comfort. Pleasure: this is its specific nature. Bliss:

original: tasseva vevacanaṃ, madhuranti vuttaṃ hoti. Kāyasamphassajanti kāyasamphassato jātaṃ.
analyzed: tassa iva vevacanam madhuranti vuttam hoti kāya samphassa janti kāya samphassataḥ jātam
translated: this is a synonym for it; it is said to be sweet. Born of bodily contact: arisen from bodily contact.

original: Sukhaṃ sātanti vuttanayameva. Vedayitanti ayamassa sabbavedanāsādhāraṇo aññadhammavisiṭṭho
analyzed: sukham sātam ti vutta nayam eva vedayitanti ayam assa sabba vedanā sādhāraṇaḥ añña dhamma visiṭṭho
translated: Pleasure and bliss are stated in the same way as above. Is felt: this is its specific nature common to all feelings, distinguished from other dhammas.

original: sabhāvaniddeso. Iminā nayena sesesupi attho veditabbo. Kāyikaṃ vā cetasikaṃ vāti
analyzed: sabhāva niddesaḥ iminā nayena sesesu pi attho veditabbo kāyikam vā cetasikam vā ti
translated: The meaning of the rest should be understood in the same way. Bodily or mental:

original: ettha pana cakkhādayo cattāro pasādakāye vatthuṃ katvā uppattivasena kāyikanti vuttaṃ.
analyzed: ettha pana cakkha ādayo cattāro pasāda kāye vatthum katvā uppatti vasena kāyikanti vuttam
translated: But here the four beginning with the eye are called bodily because they arise with the physical basis of the sensitive matter.

original: Kāyapasādavatthukaṃ pana adukkhamasukhaṃ nāma natthi.
analyzed: kāya pasāda vatthukam pana adukkham asukham nāma natthi
translated: But there is no bodily equanimity that is neither-unpleasant-nor-pleasant.

original: 9. Kaṭṭhopamasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: kaṭṭhopama sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the “Simile of the Log” .

original: 509. Navame dvinnaṃ kaṭṭhānanti dvinnaṃ araṇīnaṃ. Saṅghaṭṭanasamodhānāti saṅghaṭṭanena🔽ceva samodhānena ca. Usmāti usumākāro. Tejoti aggidhūmo. Ettha ca adharāraṇī viya🔽vatthārammaṇaṃ, uttarāraṇī viya phasso, saṅghaṭṭo viya phassasaṅghaṭṭanaṃ, aggi viya
analyzed: navame dvinnam kaṭṭhānam ati dvinnam araṇīnam saṅghaṭṭana samodhānā ati saṅghaṭṭanena  samodhānena ca usmā ati usuma ākāro ettha ca adharāraṇī  vattha ārammaṇam uttarāraṇī viya phassaḥ saṅghaṭṭaḥ viya phassa saṅghaṭṭanam aggi viya
translated: In the ninth , “of two sticks”: of two fire-sticks. “By rubbing together”: by rubbing together.🔽“Heat”: the state of heat. “Flame”: the flame. “Smoke”: the smoke. And here the physical basis and the object should be regarded as the lower fire-stick, contact as the upper fire-stick, contact’s impingement as the rubbing together, and feeling as the heat, flame, and smoke.

original: vedanā daṭṭhabbā. Vatthārammaṇaṃ vā uttarāraṇī viya, phasso adharāraṇī viya daṭṭhabbo.🔽10. Uppaṭipāṭikasuttavaṇṇanā🔽510. Dasamaṃ yathādhammarasena paṭipāṭiyā vuttampi imasmiṃ indriyavibhaṅge sesasuttāni
analyzed: vedanā daṭṭhabbā vattha ārammaṇam vā uttarāraṇī viya phassaḥ adharāraṇī viya daṭṭhabbo  uppaṭipāṭika sutta vaṇṇanā  dasamam yathā dhamma rasena paṭipāṭiyā vuttam pi imasmin indriya vibhaṅge sesa suttāni
translated: Or the physical basis and the object should be regarded as the upper fire-stick and contact as the lower fire-stick.🔽The explanation of the “Reversal” .

original: viya adesitattā uppaṭipāṭikasuttaṃ nāmāti veditabbaṃ. Tattha nimittantiādīni sabbāni
analyzed: viya a desita ttā uppaṭipāṭikasuttam nāma ati veditabbam tattha nimitta nti ādīni sabbāni
translated: In the tenth , although the remaining suttas are given in the order of the elements, they should be understood as called “Reversal” because they are not taught in the exposition of the faculties as they are in the other suttas. Herein, “sign” is the object.

original: paccayavevacanāneva. Dukkhindriyañca pajānātīti dukkhasaccavaseneva pajānāti. Dukkhindriyasamudayanti
analyzed: paccaya vevacanāni eva dukkha indriyam ca pajānāti iti dukkha sacca vasena iva pajānāti dukkha indriya samudayanti
translated: and they are synonyms for conditions. He understands the pain faculty: he understands it only as the truth of suffering. The origin of the pain faculty:

original: kaṇṭakena vā viddhassa maṅkulena vā daṭṭhassa paccattharaṇe vā valiyā phuṭṭhassa
analyzed: kaṇṭakena vā viddhassa maṅkulena vā daṭṭhassa paccattharaṇe vā valiyā phuṭṭhassa
translated: when someone is pierced by a thorn or bitten by a snake or struck by a clod or a stick,

original: dukkhasahagataṃ kāyaviññāṇaṃ uppajjati, taṃ etassa samudayoti pajānāti.
analyzed: dukkha sahagatam kāya viññāṇam uppajjati tam etassa samudayaḥ iti pajānāti
translated: painful bodily consciousness arises in him. He understands that that is its origin.

original: Parato domanassindriyasamudayantiādīsupi tesaṃ tesaṃ kāraṇavaseneva samudayo veditabbo.
analyzed: paratas tesam tesam kāraṇa vasena iva samudayaḥ veditabbo
translated: As regards the origin of the grief faculty, etc., their origin should be understood in each instance as the reason for their arising.

original: Pattacīvarādīnaṃ vā hi saṅkhārānaṃ saddhivihārikādīnaṃ vā sattānaṃ vināsena domanassindriyaṃ🔽uppajjatīti tesaṃ vināsaṃ tassa samudayoti pajānāti. Subhojanaṃ bhuñjitvā varasayane🔽nipannassa hatthapādasambāhanatālavaṇṭavātādisamphassena sukhindriyaṃ uppajjati,
analyzed: patta cīvara ādīnam vā hi saṅkhārānam saddhivihārika ādīnam vā sattānam vināsena domanassindriyam  uppajjati iti tesam vināsam tassa samudayaḥ ti pajānāti su bhojanam bhuñjitvā vara sayane  nipannassa hattha pāda sambāhana tāla vaṇṭa vāta ādi samphassena sukha indriyam uppajjati
translated: For the grief faculty arises with the destruction of requisites such as bowl and robe, or of pupils and monasteries, etc.,🔽and he understands that their destruction is the origin of that grief. The pleasure faculty arises in one who has eaten good food and gone to bed on a comfortable couch when he experiences the contact of the fanning of the breeze from a palm leaf, etc.,

original: taṃ phassaṃ tassa samudayoti pajānāti. Vuttappakārānaṃ pana sattasaṅkhārānaṃ manāpānaṃ
analyzed: tam phassam tassa samudayaḥ ti pajānāti vutta ppakārānam pana satta saṅkhārānam manāpānam
translated: and he understands that that contact is the origin of that pleasure. But the joy faculty arises in one who has obtained agreeable requisites and agreeable pupils and monasteries, etc.,🔽and

original: paṭilābhavasena somanassindriyaṃ uppajjati, taṃ paṭilābhaṃ tassa samudayoti pajānāti.🔽Majjhattākārena pana upekkhindriyaṃ uppajjati, taṃ sattasaṅkhāresu majjhattākāraṃ
analyzed: paṭilābha vasena somanassindriyam uppajjati tam paṭilābham tassa samudayo ti pajānāti  majjhatta ākārena pana upekkhindriyam uppajjati tam satta saṅkhāresu majjhatta ākāram
translated: The equanimity faculty arises through the neutral state. He understands that neutral state in the six sense- bases

original: tassa samudayoti pajānāti.
analyzed: tassa samudayaḥ ti pajānāti
translated: to be the origin of that equanimity.

original: Kattha cuppannaṃ dukkhindriyaṃ aparisesaṃ nirujjhati, idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vivicceva🔽kāmehītiādīsu pana ayaṃ ekatova vinicchayakathā – dukkhindriyañhi paṭhamajjhānassa
analyzed: kattha cuppannam dukkha indriyam aparisesam nirujjhati idha bhikkhave bhikkhu vivicca iva  kāmehi itiādīsu pana ayam ekatas va vinicchaya kathā dukkha indriyam hi paṭhama jhānassa
translated: “And where does the arisen pain faculty cease without remainder? Here, bhikkhus, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the first jhana, which is … accompanied by applied and sustained thought.

original: upacārakkhaṇeyeva nirujjhati pahīnaṃ hoti, domanassādīni dutiyajjhānādīnaṃ. Evaṃ🔽santepi tesaṃ atisayanirodhattā ayaṃ jhānesuyeva nirodho vutto. Atisayanirodho hi
analyzed: upacāra kkhaṇe iya iva nirujjhati pahīnam hoti domanassa ādīni dutiya jhāna ādīnam evam  sante pi tesam atisaya nirodha ttā ayam jhānesu yeva nirodhaḥ vuttaḥ atisaya nirodhaḥ hi
translated: As regards the passages beginning, “Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states” , the exposition should be understood as follows: for the pain faculty ceases without remainder in the first jhana, which abandons five factors and possesses five factors. The grief faculty ceases without remainder in the second jhana, which abandons applied and sustained thought. The pleasure faculty ceases without remainder in the third jhana, which abandons happiness. The bodily pain faculty ceases without remainder in the fourth jhana, which abandons bliss. The bodily pleasure faculty ceases without remainder in the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception, which abandons the third jhana. The mental grief faculty ceases without remainder in the attainment of cessation, which abandons the base consisting of nothingness. The mental joy faculty ceases without remainder in the attainment of the ariyan path, which abandons the defilements.🔽The mental equanimity faculty ceases without remainder in the fruit of arahantship, which abandons the defilements.

original: tesaṃ paṭhamajjhānādīsu, na nirodhoyeva, nirodhoyeva pana upacārakkhaṇe, nātisayanirodho.
analyzed: tesam paṭhama jhāna ādīsu na nirodho yeva nirodho yeva pana upacāra kkhaṇe na atisaya nirodho
translated: The equanimity faculty in the first jhana is the equanimity of neutralization of the hindrances. The equanimity faculty in the second jhana is the equanimity of balance of the factors. The equanimity faculty in the third jhana is the equanimity of neutrality towards the pleasure. The equanimity faculty in the fourth jhana is the equanimity of neutrality towards the equanimity. The equanimity faculty in the base consisting of boundless consciousness is the equanimity of neutrality towards bliss. The equanimity faculty in the base consisting of nothingness is the equanimity of neutrality towards equanimity. The equanimity faculty in the base consisting of neither perception nor non-perception is the equanimity of neutrality towards equanimity. The equanimity faculty in the attainment of cessation is the equanimity of neutrality towards equanimity. The equanimity faculty in the fruit of arahantship is the equanimity of neutrality towards equanimity.

original: Tathā hi nānāvajjane paṭhamajjhānupacāre niruddhassāpi dukkhindriyassa ḍaṃsamakasādisamphassena🔽vā visamāsanupatāpena vā siyā uppatti, na tveva antoappanāyaṃ. Upacāre vā niruddhampetaṃ
analyzed: tathā hi nānā vajjane paṭhama jhāna upacāre niruddhassa api dukkha indriyassa ḍaṃsama kasā ādi samphassena  vā vā upacāre vā
translated: For when the painful bodily feeling that has ceased in the first-jhāna access, which has various kinds of object, arises again through contact with gadflies, flies, etc., or through an uneven seat, it does not arise in the first jhāna, which has a single kind of object.

original: na suṭṭhu niruddhaṃ hoti paṭipakkhena avihatattā. Antoappanāyaṃ pana pītipharaṇena
analyzed: na suṭṭhu niruddham hoti paṭipakkhena a vihata ttā antoappanāyam pana pīti pharaṇena
translated: Or again, although it has ceased in the first-jhāna access, it has not ceased well because it has not been suppressed by its opposite, namely, the first jhāna. But in the first jhāna it has ceased in virtue of the pervading bliss,

original: sabbo kāyo sukhokkanto hoti, sukhokkantakāyassa ca suṭṭhu niruddhaṃ hoti dukkhindriyaṃ🔽paṭipakkhena vihatattā. Nānāvajjaneyeva ca dutiyajjhānupacāre pahīnassa domanassindriyassa
analyzed: sabbo kāyaḥ sukha ukkantaḥ hoti sukha ukkanta kāyassa ca suṭṭhu niruddham hoti dukkha indriyam  paṭipakkhena vihata ttā ca dutiya jhāna upacāre pahīnassa domanassindriyassa
translated: and with the pervading bliss the painful bodily feeling has ceased well because it has been suppressed by its opposite.

original: yasmā etaṃ vitakkavicārapaccayepi kāyakilamathe cittupaghāte ca sati uppajjati, vitakkavicārābhāve
analyzed: yasmai etam vitakka vicāra paccaye pi kāya kilamathe citta upaghāte ca sati uppajjati vitakka vicāra abhāve
translated: And in the second-jhāna access, which has various kinds of object, the grief that has ceased has not ceased well because it arises again when there is bodily weariness and mental vexation due to the conditions of applied thought and sustained thought.

original: neva uppajjati. Yattha pana uppajjati, tattha vitakkavicārabhāve, appahīnā eva ca
analyzed: na iva uppajjati yattha pana uppajjati tattha vitakka vicāra bhāve appahīnāḥ eva ca
translated: But when there is no applied thought and sustained thought, it does not arise.🔽And where it arises, it does so only when there is applied thought and sustained thought, and it has not been well suppressed there because it has not been abandoned by the means of its suppression, namely, the second jhāna.

original: dutiyajjhānupacāre vitakkavicārāti tatthassa siyā uppatti. Na tveva dutiyajjhāne
analyzed: dutiya jhāna upacāre vitakka vicārā ti tattha siyā uppatti na tu eva dutiya jhāne
translated: But not in the second jhāna.

original: pahīnapaccayattā. Tathā tatiyajjhānupacāre pahīnassāpi sukhindriyassa pītisamuṭṭhānapaṇītarūpaphuṭṭhakāyassa
analyzed: pahīna paccaya ttā tathā tatiya jhāna upacāre pahīnassa api sukha indriyassa pīti samuṭṭhāna paṇīta rūpa phuṭṭha kāyassa
translated: Similarly, in the third-jhāna access, though the pleasure faculty has been abandoned, it might arise there in one whose body is affected by the gross physical matter originated by that happiness.

original: siyā uppatti, na tveva tatiyajjhāne. Tatiyajjhāne hi sukhassa paccayabhūtā pīti sabbaso🔽niruddhā. Tathā catutthajjhānupacāre pahīnassāpi somanassindriyassa āsannattā appanāppattāya
analyzed: siyā uppatti na tu eva tatiya jhāne tatiya jhāne hi sukhassa paccaya bhūtā pi iti sabbaso  niruddhā tathā catuttha jjhāna upacāre pahīnassa api somanassindriyassa āsanna ttā appanā appattāya
translated: But not in the third jhāna. For in the third jhāna happiness has ceased completely with its condition, applied thought, absent.🔽Similarly, in the fourth-jhāna access, though the joy faculty has been abandoned, it might arise there because it is near and because the equanimity that has reached absorption is not yet purified.

original: upekkhāya abhāvena sammā anatikkantattā ca siyā uppatti, na tveva catutthajjhāne.🔽Tasmā “ettha cuppannaṃ dukkhindriyaṃ aparisesaṃ nirujjhatī”ti tattha tattha aparisesaggahaṇaṃ kataṃ.
analyzed: upekkhāya abhāvena sammā an atikkanta ttā ca siyā uppatti na tu eva catuttha jhāne  tasmai ettha cuppannam dukkha indriyam aparisesam nirujjhati iti tattha tattha aparisesa ggahaṇam katam
translated: But not in the fourth jhāna.🔽That is why the words “Any pain faculty that has arisen … Any grief faculty that has arisen … Any applied thought that has arisen … Any sustained thought that has arisen … Any happiness faculty that has arisen … Any grief faculty that has arisen … Any equanimity faculty that has arisen ceases completely” are said in each case with the words “without remainder.”

original: Yaṃ panettha tadatthāya cittaṃ upasaṃharatīti vuttaṃ, tattha alābhī samāno uppādanatthāya
analyzed: yam pana ittha tad atthāya cittam upasaṃharati iti vuttam tattha alābhī samānaḥ uppādana tthāya
translated: But it was said above, “He directs his mind to the field of that profitable kamma” .

original: cittaṃ upasaṃharati, lābhī samāno samāpajjanatthāyāti evamattho veditabbo. Imesu
analyzed: cittam upasaṃharati lābhī samānaḥ samāpajjana tthāya ati evamatthaḥ veditabbaḥ imesu
translated: He directs his mind to it. When he has attained it, it is for the purpose of attaining it. This is the meaning to be understood.

original: dvīsupi suttesu sammasanavārova kathitoti.
analyzed: dvīsu pi suttesu sammasana vāraḥ eva kathito ti
translated: In these two suttas, only the serenity of serenity and insight is stated.

original: Sukhindriyavaggo catuttho.
analyzed: sukhindriya vaggo catutthaḥ
translated: The fourth chapter on the pleasure faculty is finished.

original: 5. Jarāvaggo
analyzed: jarā vaggo
translated: The chapter on old age

original: 1. Jarādhammasuttavaṇṇanā🔽511. Pañcamavaggassa paṭhame pacchātapeti pāsādacchāyāya puratthimadisaṃ paṭicchannattā
analyzed: jarā dhamma sutta vaṇṇanā  pañcama vaggassa paṭhame pacchā ātapeti pāsāda chāyāya puratthima disam
translated: The explanation of the sutta on the nature of being subject to old age🔽In the first sutta of the fifth chapter, the sun heats his back: because the eastern direction is covered by the shadow of the palace,

original: pāsādassa pacchimadisābhāge ātapo hoti, tasmiṃ ṭhāne paññattavarabuddhāsane nisinnoti
analyzed: pāsādassa pacchima disā bhāge ātapaḥ hoti tasmin ṭhāne paññatta vara buddhāsane nisinno ti
translated: the sun is in the western direction of the palace. The meaning is that he was sitting on the excellent Buddha seat prepared in that place.

original: attho. Piṭṭhiṃ otāpayamānoti yasmā sammāsambuddhassapi upādinnakasarīre uṇhakāle🔽uṇhaṃ hoti, sītakāle sītaṃ, ayañca himapātasītasamayo. Tasmā mahācīvaraṃ otāretvā
analyzed: attho piṭṭhim otāpayamānaḥ ti yasmā sammāsambuddhassa api upādinnaka sarīre uṇha kāle  uṇham hoti sīta kāle sītam tasmai mahā cīvaram
translated: He warmed his back: because even in the body of a Fully Enlightened One, heat

original: sūriyarasmīhi piṭṭhiṃ otāpayamāno nisīdi.
analyzed: piṭṭhim otāpayamānaḥ nisīdi
translated: is hot in hot weather and cold in cold weather, and this is a time of cold with snowfall, he sat down warming his back with the sun’s rays after spreading out his large outer cloak.

original: Kiṃ pana buddharasmiyo madditvā sūriyarasmi anto pavisituṃ sakkotīti? Na sakkoti.
analyzed: kim pana buddha rasmiyaḥ madditvā sūriya rasmi antar pavisitum sakkoti iti na sakkoti
translated: But can the sun’s rays be absorbed and enter inside? They cannot.

original: Evaṃ sante kiṃ tāpetīti? Rasmitejaṃ. Yatheva hi ṭhitamajjhanhike parimaṇḍalāya chāyāya🔽rukkhamūle nisinnassa kiñcāpi sūriyarasmiyo sarīraṃ na phusanti, sabbadisāsu pana🔽tejo pharati, aggijālāhi parikkhitto viya hoti, evaṃ sūriyarasmīsu buddharasmiyo
analyzed: evam sante kim yathā iva hi ṭhitam ajjhanhike parimaṇḍalāya chāyāya  rukkha mūle nisinnassa kiñcā api sūriya rasmiyaḥ sarīram na phusanti sabba disāsu pana  tejaḥ pharati aggi jālāhi parikkhittaḥ viya hoti evam sūriya rasmīsu buddha rasmiyaḥ
translated: If it is so, what does it scorch? It scorches the heat of the sun’s rays.🔽Just as when one sits at the foot of a tree in the middle of the day, although the sun’s rays do not touch one’s body,🔽the heat of the sun spreads in all directions, and one feels as if one is surrounded by flames, in the same way, in the sun’s rays, the Buddha’s rays🔽

original: madditvā anto pavisituṃ asakkuṇantīsupi satthā tejaṃ tāpento nisinnoti veditabbo.
analyzed: madditvā antar pavisitum a sakkuṇantīsu pi satthā tejam tāpentaḥ nisinnaḥ ti veditabbo
translated: “If it is so, what does he burn?” The heat of the sun’s rays. Just as when one sits at the foot of a tree in the middle of the day, the sun’s rays do not touch one’s body, but the heat of the sun’s rays spreads in all directions, and one feels as if one is surrounded by flames, in the same way, even though the Buddha’s rays cannot penetrate the sun’s rays, the Teacher sits burning the heat.

original: Anomajjantoti piṭṭhiparikammakaraṇavasena anumajjanto. Acchariyaṃ bhanteti thero🔽bhagavato piṭṭhito mahācīvaraṃ otāretvā nisinnassa dvinnaṃ aṃsakūṭānaṃ antare suvaṇṇāvaṭṭaṃ
analyzed: anomajjanto ti piṭṭhi parikamma karaṇa vasena anumajjantaḥ acchariyam bhante ti thero  bhagavataḥ piṭṭhitaḥ mahā cīvaram otāretvā nisinnassa dvinnam aṃsakūṭānam antare suvaṇṇa avaṭṭam
translated: “Anomajjanto” means “anointing.” The Elder,

original: viya kesaggappamāṇaṃ valiyāvaṭṭaṃ disvā – “evarūpepi nāma sarīre jarā paññāyatī”ti
analyzed: viya kesagga ppamāṇam valiyā avaṭṭam disvā evarūpe api nāma sarīre jarā paññāyati iti
translated: having taken off the great robe from behind the Blessed One and sat down, saw a wrinkle the size of a hair-tip between the two shoulders of the Blessed One, like a golden bracelet, and thinking, “Wrinkles are seen even in such a body,”

original: sañjātasaṃvego jaraṃ garahanto evamāha. Garahanacchariyaṃ nāma kiretaṃ.
analyzed: sañjāta saṃvegaḥ jaram evam āha gara hanat śariyam nāma kiretam
translated: became deeply moved and, reproaching old age, said, “It is a wonder, venerable sir!” This, it is said, is a wonder of reproach.

original: Na cevaṃ dāni, bhante, bhagavato tāva parisuddhoti yathā pakatiyā chavivaṇṇo parisuddho,
analyzed: na ca ivam dāni bhante bhagavato tāva parisuddhaḥ ti yathā pakatiyā chavi vaṇṇo parisuddhaḥ
translated: “And now, Lord, your skin is not so clear and bright as it was before.”

original: na evametarahīti dīpento evamāha. Tathāgatassa hi daharakāle saṅkusatasamabbhāhataṃ🔽usabhacammaṃ viya vihatavaliko kāyo hoti, tasmiṃ ṭhapito hattho bhassateva, na santiṭṭhati,🔽telapuñchanākārappatto viya hoti. Mahallakakāle pana sirājālā milāyanti, sandhipabbāni
analyzed: na evam etarahi iti dīpentaḥ evam āha tathāgatassa hi dahara kāle  usabha cammam viya vihata valikaḥ kāyaḥ hoti tasmin ṭhapitaḥ hatthaḥ bhassatā iva na santiṭṭhati  tela puñchana ākāra ppattaḥ viya hoti mahallaka kāle pana sirā jālāḥ milāyanti sandhi pabbāni
translated: For the body of a Tathāgata, when he is young, is like a piece of hide that has been stretched over a frame of pegs and beaten with a club,🔽and when it is placed on the ground, the hand sinks in and leaves an indentation. It is like a bowl of oil.🔽But in the case of an old man, the net-like veins disappear, the joints of the bones become loose,

original: sithilāni honti, maṃsaṃ aṭṭhito muccitvā sithilabhāvaṃ āpajjitvā tattha tattha olambati.🔽Buddhānaṃ pana evarūpaṃ na hoti. Aññesaṃ apākaṭaṃ, santikāvacarattā ānandattherasseva
analyzed: sithilāni honti maṃsam aṭṭhitas muccitvā sithila bhāvam āpajjitvā tattha tattha olambati  buddhānam pana evarūpam na hoti aññesam apākaṭam santika avacara ttā ānanda therassa iva
translated: the flesh and skin become slack and hang down in folds here and there.🔽But this is not so in the case of a Buddha. It is not so obvious in the case of others,

original: pākaṭaṃ hoti, tasmā evamāha.
analyzed: pākaṭam ha iti tasmai evam āha
translated: but it is obvious in the case of the Elder Ānanda, because he is always near the Teacher.

original: Sithilāni ca gattānīti aññesaṃ mukhe aṃsakūṭantarehi tesu tesu ṭhānesu valiyo santiṭṭhanti,
analyzed: sithilāni ca gattāni iti aññesam mukhe aṃsakūṭa antarehi tesu tesu ṭhānesu valiyaḥ santiṭṭhanti
translated: “And your limbs are slack and wrinkled.” In the case of others, wrinkles appear in the mouth, between the shoulders, and in other places.

original: satthu panetaṃ natthi, thero ca dvinnaṃ aṃsakūṭānaṃ antare valiyāvaṭṭakaṃ disvā evamāha.
analyzed: satthu pana etat natthi thero ca dvinnam aṃsakūṭānam antare valiyā vaṭṭakam disvā evam āha
translated: But the Teacher had none of these. The Elder, however, saw a circular fold in the flesh between his shoulders, and therefore he said, “All the signs of a Great Man are complete.”

original: Sabbāni valiyajātānīti idampi attano pākaṭavasena evamāha – satthu pana aññesaṃ viya🔽valiyo nāma natthi. Purato pabbhāro ca kāyoti satthā brahmujugatto, devanagare samussitasuvaṇṇatoraṇaṃ🔽viyassa kāyo ujukameva uggato. Mahallakakāle pana kāyo purato vaṅko hoti, svāyaṃ
analyzed: sabbāni valiya jātāni iti idam pi attanaḥ pākaṭa vasena evam āha satthu pana aññesam viya  valiyaḥ nāma natthi puratas pabbhāro ca kāyo ti satthā brahmujugattaḥ devanagare samussita suvaṇṇa toraṇaṃ  viyassa kāyo ujukam eva uggataḥ mahallaka kāle pana kāyo puratas vaṅkaḥ hoti
translated: “All the signs of decrepitude” – the Elder said this because they were manifest in himself. But the Teacher had none of these.🔽His body was straight as the brahma-world, like a pillar of solid gold.

original: aññesaṃ apākaṭo, santikāvacarattā pana therasseva pākaṭo, tasmā evamāha. Dissati🔽ca indriyānaṃ aññathattanti indriyāni nāma na cakkhuviññeyyāni. Yato pana pakatiyā
analyzed: aññesam apākaṭaḥ santika avacarattā pana therassa iva pākaṭaḥ tasmai evam āha dissati  ca indriyānam aññathattanti indriyāni nāma na cakkhu viññeyyāni yatas pana pakatiyā
translated: But in his old age his body was bent forward. This was not manifest in others, but it was manifest in the Elder, because he was in close attendance upon the Teacher. Therefore he said, “The signs of decrepitude are manifest.”

original: parisuddho chavivaṇṇo, idāni na tathā parisuddho, aṃsakūṭantare vali paññāyati, brahmujukāyo
analyzed: parisuddhaḥ chavi vaṇṇo idāni na tathā parisuddhaḥ aṃsakūṭa antare paññāyati brahmuju kāyo
translated: “The change in the faculties” – the faculties are not visible to the eye. But because his complexion was naturally clear and pure, and now was not so, because a circular fold was visible between his shoulders, and because his body, which had been straight as the brahma-world, was now bent forward,

original: purato vaṅko, imināva kāraṇena cakkhādīnañca indriyānaṃ aññathattena bhavitabbanti
analyzed: puratas vaṅkaḥ iminā ava kāraṇena cakkha ādīnam ca indriyānam aññathattena bhavitabbanti
translated: the Elder concluded that the change in the faculties of the eye and the other senses must be due to the same cause.

original: nayaggāhato evamāha. Dhī taṃ jammi jare atthūti lāmake jare dhī taṃ tuyhaṃ hotu,
analyzed: evam āha dhī tam jammi jare lāmake jare dhī tam tuyham hotu
translated: “May it be yours, dear brother, in old age,” means: “May it be yours, dear brother, in old age, in your dotage.”

original: dhikkāro taṃ phusatu. Bimbanti attabhāvo.
analyzed: dhikkāraḥ tam phusatu bimbanti atta bhāvaḥ
translated: “Bimba” means: the body.

original: 2. Uṇṇābhabrāhmaṇasuttavaṇṇanā🔽512. Dutiye gocaravisayanti gocarabhūtaṃ visayaṃ. Aññamaññassāti cakkhu sotassa,
analyzed: uṇṇābha brāhmaṇa sutta vaṇṇanā  dutiye gocara visayanti gocara bhūtam visayam aññam aññassa ati cakkhu sotassa
translated: . The Explanation of the Discourse with the Brahmana Unnata🔽. “The domain of the range” means: the domain which is the range.🔽“One another’s” means: the eye is not the range of the ear,

original: sotaṃ vā cakkhussāti evaṃ ekaṃ ekassa gocaravisayaṃ na paccanubhoti. Sace hi nīlādibhedaṃ
analyzed: sotam vā cakkhussa ati evam ekam ekassa gocara visayam na paccanubhoti sace hi nīla ādi bhedam
translated: or the ear is not the range of the eye. If, having combined the object of form,

original: rūpārammaṇaṃ samodhānetvā sotindriyassa upaneyya – “iṅgha tvaṃ tāva naṃ vavatthapehi
analyzed: rūpa ārammaṇam samodhānetvā sotindriyassa upaneyya iṅgha tvam tāva nam
translated: which is divided into blue, etc., and having brought it into the range of the ear faculty, one were to say: “Now, you define it,🔽and make it clear, ‘What is this object?’”

original: vibhāvehi ‘kinnāmetaṃ ārammaṇa”’nti. Cakkhuviññāṇaṃ vināpi mukhena attano dhammatāya
analyzed: vibhāvehi kinnāma etam ārammaṇanti cakkhu viññāṇam vinā api mukhena attanaḥ dhamma tāya
translated: The eye consciousness would say without the mouth, by its own nature,

original: evaṃ vadeyya – “are, andhabāla, vassasatampi vassasahassampi vassasatasahassampi
analyzed: evam vadeyya are andha bāla vassa satam pi vassa sahassam pi vassa sata sahassam pi
translated: “Hey, you blind fool, even if you were to run around for a hundred years, a thousand years, a hundred thousand years,🔽apart from me, where will you get the knowledge of this? Bring it, and I will define it for you.”

original: paridhāvamāno aññatra mayā kuhiṃ etassa jānanakaṃ labhissasi, taṃ āhara, cakkhupasāde
analyzed: paridhāvamānaḥ aññatra mayā kuhim etassa jānanakam labhissasi tam āhara cakkhu upasāde
translated: “The eye faculty is the range of the eye consciousness,

original: upanehi, ahametaṃ ārammaṇaṃ jānissāmi – yadi vā nīlaṃ, yadi vā pītakaṃ. Na hi eso🔽aññassa visayo, mayhameveso visayo”ti. Sesadvāresupi eseva nayo. Evametāni aññamaññassa
analyzed: upanehi aham etam ārammaṇam jānissāmi yadi vā nīlam yadi vā pītakam na hi eso  aññassa visayo mayham eva iso visayo ti sesa dvāresu pi esa iva nayo evam etāni aññamaññassa
translated: “Bring it, I shall know whether it is blue or yellow.

original: gocaravisayaṃ na paccanubhonti nāma.
analyzed: gocara visayam na paccanubhonti nāma
translated: This is not another’s province, it is my province.” The same method applies in the case of the other doors. Thus they do not experience each other’s domain.

original: Kiṃ paṭisaraṇanti etesaṃ kiṃ paṭisaraṇaṃ, kiṃ etāni paṭisarantīti pucchati. Mano
analyzed: kim etesam kim paṭisaraṇam kim etāni paṭisaranti iti pucchati mano
translated: What is their resort? He asks: “What is their resort? What do they resort to?”

original: paṭisaraṇanti javanamano paṭisaraṇaṃ. Manova nesanti manodvārikajavanamanova etesaṃ🔽gocaravisayaṃ rajjanādivasena anubhoti. Cakkhuviññāṇañhi rūpadassanamattameva, ettha
analyzed: paṭisaraṇanti javana mano paṭisaraṇam manodvārika javana manovaḥ etesam  gocara visayam rajjana ādi vasena anubhoti cakkhu viññāṇam hi rūpa dassana mattam eva ettha
translated: The mind is their resort. The impulsion mind is their resort. The mind-door impulsion minds experience their domain, the objects, by way of lust, etc.

original: rajjanaṃ vā dussanaṃ vā muyhanaṃ vā natthi. Ekasmiṃ pana dvāre javanaṃ rajjati vā
analyzed: rajjanam vā dussanam vā muyhanam vā natthi ekasmim pana dvāre javanam rajjati vā
translated: For eye-consciousness merely sees visible forms; there is no lust, hate, or delusion in regard to them. But at the mind-door impulsion mind lusts after, hates, or deludes itself in regard to the object.

original: dussati vā muyhati vā. Sotaviññāṇādīsupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: dussati vā muyhati vā sota viññāṇa ādīsu pi esa iva nayo
translated: The same method applies in the case of ear-consciousness, etc.

original: Tatrāyaṃ upamā – pañca kira dubbalabhojakā rājānaṃ sevitvā kicchena kasirena ekasmiṃ
analyzed: tatra ayam upamā pañca kira dubbala bhojakāḥ rājānam sevitvā kicchena kasirena ekasmin
translated: Here is a simile: Five weaklings, it is said, served a king. With great difficulty and hardship they earned their wages.

original: pañcakulike gāme parittakaṃ āyaṃ labhiṃsu. Tesaṃ tattha macchabhāgo maṃsabhāgo, addukahāpaṇo🔽vā yottakahāpaṇo vā māsakahāpaṇo vā aṭṭhakahāpaṇo vā soḷasakahāpaṇo vā catusaṭṭhikahāpaṇo🔽vā daṇḍoti ettakamattameva pāpuṇāti, satavatthukaṃ pañcasatavatthukaṃ sahassavatthukaṃ🔽mahābaliṃ rājāva gaṇhāti.
analyzed: pañcakulike gāme parittakam āyam labhiṃsu tesam tattha maccha bhāgaḥ maṃsa bhāgaḥ addu kahāpaṇo  vā yotta kahāpaṇaḥ vā māsa kahāpaṇaḥ vā aṭṭha kahāpaṇaḥ vā soḷasa kahāpaṇaḥ vā catusaṭṭhi kahāpaṇaḥ  vā daṇḍoti ettakam attam eva pāpuṇāti sata vatthukam pañca sata vatthukam sahassa vatthukam  mahā balim rājā ava gaṇhāti
translated: and they received a small income in a village of five families. There they got a share of fish, a share of meat, a half-penny, a penny, a quarter-penny, an eight-penny piece, a sixteen-penny piece, a thirty-two-penny piece,🔽a staff—only so much as that. The king took a hundred-penny piece, a five-hundred-penny piece, a thousand-penny piece,🔽a great offering.

original: Tattha pañcakulikagāmā viya pañcapasādā daṭṭhabbā, pañca dubbalabhojakā viya pañcaviññāṇāni;🔽rājā viya javanaṃ, dubbalabhojakānaṃ parittakaāyapāpuṇanaṃ viya cakkhuviññāṇādīnaṃ🔽rūpadassanādimattaṃ, rajjanādi pana etesu natthi. Rañño mahābaliggahaṇaṃ viya tesu🔽dvāresu javanassa rajjanādīni veditabbāni. Evamettha manoti kusalākusalajavanaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: tattha pañca kulika gāmā viya pañca pasādā daṭṭhabbā pañca dubbala bhojakā viya pañca viññāṇāni 🔽rājā viya javanam dubbala bhojakānam parittaka āya pāpuṇanam viya cakkhu viññāṇa ādīnam 🔽rūpa dassana ādimattam rajjana ādi pana etesu natthi raññaḥ mahā bali ggahaṇam viya tesu 🔽dvāresu javanassa rajjana ādīni veditabbāni evam ettha manaḥ ti kusala akusala javanam vuttam
translated: They got a small income from the five-family village. There they got only a share of fish, a share of meat, a half-penny, a penny, a quarter-penny, an eighth-penny, a sixteenth-penny, a thirty-second-penny, a sixty-fourth-penny, a hundredth-penny, a thousandth-penny, a ten-thousandth-penny, a hundred-thousandth-penny, a millionth-penny, a ten-millionth-penny, a hundred-millionth-penny, a thousand-millionth-penny, a ten-thousand-millionth-penny, a hundred-thousand-millionth-penny, a hundred-thousand-billionth-penny, a hundred-thousand-trillionth-penny, a hundred-thousand-quadrillionth-penny, a hundred-thousand-quintillionth-penny, a hundred-thousand-sextillionth-penny, a hundred-thousand-septillionth-penny, a hundred-thousand-octillionth-penny, a hundred-thousand-nonillionth-penny, a hundred-thousand-decadillionth-penny, a hundred-thousand-undecillionth-penny, a hundred-thousand-duodecillionth-penny, a hundred-thousand-tredecillionth-penny, a hundred-thousand-tetradecil-lionth-penny, a hundred-thousand-pentadecillionth-penny, a hundred-thousand-hexadecillionth-penny, a hundred-thousand-heptadecillionth-penny, a hundred-thousand-octadecil-lionth-penny, a hundred-thousand-enneadecillionth-penny, a hundred-thousand-vigintillionth-penny, a hundred-thousand-centillionth-penny, a hundred-thousand-googolth-penny, a hundred-thousand-googolplexth-penny, a hundred-thousand-googolplexplexth-penny, a hundred-thousand-googolplexplexplexth-penny, a hundred-thousand-googolplexplexplexplexth-penny, a hundred-thousand-googolplexplexplexplexplexth-penny, a hundred-thousand-googolplexplexplexplexplexplexth-penny, a hundred-thousand-googolplexplexplexplexplexplexplexth-penny, a hundred-thousand-googolplexplexplex

original: Sati paṭisaraṇanti maggasati paṭisaraṇaṃ. Javanamano hi maggasatiṃ paṭisarati. Vimuttīti🔽phalavimutti. Paṭisaraṇanti phalavimuttiyā nibbānaṃ paṭisaraṇaṃ. Tañhi sā paṭisarati.🔽Nāsakkhi pañhassa pariyantaṃ gahetunti pañhassa paricchedaṃ pamāṇaṃ gahetuṃ nāsakkhi,🔽appaṭisaraṇaṃ dhammaṃ “sappaṭisaraṇa”nti pucchi. Nibbānaṃ nāmetaṃ appaṭisaraṇaṃ,🔽na kiñci paṭisarati. Nibbānogadhanti nibbānabbhantaraṃ nibbānaṃ anupaviṭṭhaṃ. Brahmacariyanti🔽maggabrahmacariyaṃ. Nibbānaparāyaṇanti nibbānaṃ paraṃ ayanamassa parā gati, na tato
analyzed: sati paṭisaraṇan ti magga sati paṭisaraṇam javana manaḥ hi magga satim paṭisarati vimutti iti  phala vimutti paṭisaraṇanti phala vimuttiyāḥ nibbānam paṭisaraṇam tat hi sā paṭisarati  na asakkhi pañhassa pariyantam gahetunti pañhassa paricchedam pamāṇam gahetum na asakkhi  a paṭisaraṇam dhammam sa paṭisaraṇam ti pucchi nibbānam nāma etam a paṭisaraṇam  na kiñci paṭisarati nibbāna ogadhanti nibbāna abbhantaram nibbānam an upaviṭṭham brahmacariyanti  magga brahmacariyam nibbāna parāyaṇam ti nibbānam param ayanam assa parā gati na tatas
translated: “The Realised One’s mindfulness is his refuge” means the mindfulness of the path is his refuge. The swift mind is mindful of the path. “Liberation” means🔽the liberation of the fruit. “The Realised One’s liberation is his refuge” means the liberation of the fruit is his refuge. That is what he is mindful of.🔽“He was not able to grasp the limit of his speech” means he was not able to grasp the measure or extent of his speech,🔽he asked about a teaching without a refuge, thinking it had a refuge. But this is not a teaching without a refuge,🔽it is not mindful of anything. “The supreme austerity is entered into” means it is entered into within Nibbāna, it is established in Nibbāna. “The supreme life of celibacy” means🔽the celibate life of the path. “The supreme going” means Nibbāna is his supreme going, his supreme destination, there is no going beyond that.

original: paraṃ gacchatīti attho. Nibbānaṃ pariyosānaṃ avasānaṃ assāti nibbānapariyosānaṃ.🔽Mūlajātā patiṭṭhitāti maggena āgatasaddhā vuccati. Imamhi ce, bhikkhave, samayeti

original: kiṃ sandhāyāha? Jhānaanāgāmitaṃ. Tasmiñhi samaye brāhmaṇassa paṭhamamaggena pañca
analyzed: kim sandhāya āha jhāna anāgāmi tam tasmin hi samaye brāhmaṇassa paṭhama maggena pañca
translated: What did he say? He said: “The non-returner’s jhana.” For at that time the brahmin had reached the first path and fruit.

original: akusalacittāni pahīnāni, paṭhamajjhānena pañca nīvaraṇānīti jhānaanāgāmiṭṭhāne ṭhito.🔽So aparihīnajjhāno kālaṃ katvā tattheva parinibbāyeyya. Sace panassa puttadāraṃ anusāsantassa
analyzed: akusala cittāni pahīnāni paṭhama jhānena pañca nīvaraṇāni iti jhāna anāgāmi ṭhāne ṭhitaḥ  saḥ a parihīna jjhānaḥ kālam katvā tattha iva parinibbāyeyya sace panassa putta dāram anusāsantassa
translated: What did he have in mind? The non-returner by way of jhana. For at that time the brahmin had abandoned the five unprofitable thoughts by means of the first path and the five hindrances by means of the first jhana, so he was established in the state of non-returner by way of jhana.

original: kammante vicārentassa jhānaṃ nassati, naṭṭhe jhāne gati anibaddhā hoti, anaṭṭhe pana
analyzed: kammante vicārentassa jhānam nassati naṭṭhe jhāne gati anibaddhā hoti an aṭṭhe pana
translated: If he were to die without losing his jhana, he would attain final Nibbana there in the brahma world. But if his jhana were to be lost while he was instructing his sons and relatives and attending to his property, then his destiny would be uncertain,

original: nibaddhāti imaṃ jhānaanāgāmitaṃ sandhāya evamāha.
analyzed: nibaddhā iti imam jhāna anāgāmi tam sandhāya evam āha
translated: whereas if it were not lost it would be certain. So he said this having in mind the non-returner by way of jhana.

original: 3. Sāketasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sāketa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The Sāketa Sutta is finished.

original: 513. Tatiye añjanavaneti añjanavaṇṇapupphānaṃ rukkhānaṃ ropitavane. Yaṃ, bhikkhave,🔽saddhindriyaṃ, taṃ saddhābalanti tañhi adhimokkhalakkhaṇe indaṭṭhena saddhindriyaṃ,
analyzed: tatiye añjana vana iti añjana vaṇṇa pupphānam rukkhānam ropita vane yam bhikkhave  saddhā indriyam tam saddhā balanti tat hi adhimokkha lakkhaṇe inda ṭṭhena saddhā indriyam
translated: . In the third, in the Añjana Grove: in a grove planted with trees of the colour of collyrium. “Bhikkhus, whatever is the faculty of faith, that is the strength of faith” : this is the faculty of faith in the sense of confidence in the three jewels, in the sense of resolution about the four noble truths.🔽It is the strength of faith in the sense of unshakability by non-faith. As regards the others, the faculty of energy is the exertion of energy in the sense of the act of exerting.🔽It is the strength of energy in the sense of unshakability by idleness. The faculty of mindfulness is the act of establishing in the sense of establishing the object in the mind’s presence.🔽It is the strength of mindfulness in the sense of unshakability by forgetfulness. The faculty of concentration is the act of concentrating in the sense of concentrating the mind on the object.🔽It is the strength of concentration in the sense of unshakability by agitation. The faculty of understanding is the act of understanding in the sense of the act of penetrating the truths.

original: assaddhiye akampanena saddhābalaṃ. Itaresaṃ paggahaupaṭṭhānaavikkhepapajānanalakkhaṇesu
analyzed: a saddhiye a kampanena saddhā balam itaresam paggaha upaṭṭhāna avikkhepa pajānana lakkhaṇesu
translated: It is the strength of understanding in the sense of unshakability by ignorance.

original: indaṭṭhena indriyabhāvo, kosajjamuṭṭhasaccavikkhepāvijjāsu akampanena balabhāvo veditabbo.
analyzed: inda aṭṭhena indriya bhāvaḥ kosajja muṭṭha sacca vikkhepa avijjāsu akampanena bala bhāvaḥ veditabbo
translated: The state of faculties should be understood as the state of predominance of faith, etc., in the sense of ruling, and the state of powers should be understood as the state of predominance of faith, etc., in the sense of unshakability by their opposites.

original: Evameva khoti tassā nadiyā ekasotaṃ viya saddhāvīriyasatisamādhipaññāvasena etesaṃ🔽ninnānākaraṇaṃ veditabbaṃ, dve sotāni viya indaṭṭhaakampanaṭṭhehi indriyabalavasena
analyzed: evam eva kho ti tassāḥ nadiyāḥ eka sotam viya saddhā vīriya sati samādhi paññā vasena etesam  ninnānākaraṇam veditabbam dve sotāni viya inda ṭṭha akampana ṭṭhehi indriya bala vasena
translated: So too, the distinction of these should be understood as being due to faith, energy, mindfulness, concentration, and understanding, as in the case of the river’s single stream.

original: nānākaraṇaṃ veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: nānākaraṇam veditabbam
translated: The distinction should be understood as being due to the faculties and the powers, which are respectively described as the state of predominance in the sense of ruling and the state of predominance in the sense of unshakability.

original: 4. Pubbakoṭṭhakasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pubba koṭṭhaka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The Discourse at the Fore-shore.

original: 514. Catutthe amatogadhanti amatabbhantaraṃ. Amataparāyaṇanti amatanibbattikaṃ. Amatapariyosānanti amataniṭṭhaṃ. Sādhu sādhūti therassa byākaraṇaṃ pasaṃsanto sādhukāraṃ deti.
analyzed: catutthe amatogadhanti amatabbhantaram amata parāyaṇam amata nibbattikam amata pariyosānam amata niṭṭham sādhu sādhu iti therassa byākaraṇam pasaṃsanto sādhukāram deti
translated: In the fourth , “having the deathless as its heartwood” means having the deathless as its core; “having the deathless as its climax” means having the deathless as its culmination; “having the deathless as its final end” means having the deathless as its conclusion. He gives his approval with the exclamation “Good! Good!” to the elder’s explanation.

original: 5. Paṭhamapubbārāmasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paṭhama pubbārāma sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The Discourse at the Eastern Gate.

original: 515. Pañcame tadanvayāti taṃ anugacchamānā, anuvattamānāti attho. Pubbakoṭṭhakaṃ ādiṃ katvā paṭipāṭiyā chasu suttesu phalindriyāneva kathitāni.
analyzed: pañcame tad anvayā ti tam anugacchamānā anuvattamānā iti attho pubba koṭṭhakam ādim katvā paṭipāṭiyā chasu suttesu kathitāni
translated: In the fifth , “in conformity with that” means following that, conforming to that; the meaning is, “in accordance with that.” In the first six discourses beginning with the Discourse at the Fore-shore, only the fruits are mentioned.

original: 10. Āpaṇasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: āpaṇa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The Discourse at the Market Town.

original: 520. Dasame ime kho te dhammāti upari saha vipassanāya tayo maggā. Ye me pubbe sutāva
analyzed: dasame ime kho te dhammā ati upari saha vipassanāya tayo maggā ye me pubbe sutāva
translated: 1. In the tenth, ‘These are the ideas’ is the three paths above with insight.

original: ahesunti ye dhammā mayā pubbe “arahattaphalindriyaṃ nāma atthī”ti kathentānaṃyeva
analyzed: ahesunti ye dhammā mayā pubbe arahatta phalindriyam nāma atthi iti kathentānam yeva
translated: In the tenth, “These are those ideas” is the three paths above with insight. “Which I heard about” : the ideas which I heard about previously from those who spoke of the name “the faculty of the fruition of Arahantship”

original: sutā ahesuṃ. Kāyena ca phusitvāti nāmakāyena ca phusitvā paṭilabhitvā. Paññāya ca
analyzed: sutāḥ ahesum kāyena ca phusitvā ati nāmakāyena ca phusitvā paṭilabhitvā paññāya ca
translated: “and touched with my body” : having touched with my body and acquired them,

original: ativijjha passāmīti paccavekkhaṇapaññāya ca ativijjhitvā passāmi. Yā hissa, bhante,
analyzed: ativijjha passāmi iti paccavekkhaṇa paññāya ca ativijjhitvā passāmi yā hissa bhante
translated: “I see with wisdom” : I see having pierced them with the wisdom of reviewing. For what is this?

original: saddhāti ayaṃ katarasaddhā? Catūhi indriyehi sampayuttā saddhā heṭṭhā kathitāva,
analyzed: saddhā ati ayam katara saddhā catūhi indriyehi sampayuttā saddhā heṭṭhā kathitā ava
translated: “Faith, venerable sir” : what faith is this? The faith associated with the four faculties is already mentioned below.

original: ayaṃ pana paccavekkhaṇasaddhā. Sampayuttasaddhā hi missakā, paccavekkhaṇasaddhā lokiyāva.
analyzed: ayam pana paccavekkhaṇa saddhā sampayutta saddhā hi missakā paccavekkhaṇa saddhā lokiyā ava
translated: But this is the faith of reviewing. For the faith associated with the four faculties is mixed, while the faith of reviewing is mundane only.

original: Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: The rest is all plain.

original: Jarāvaggo pañcamo.🔽6. Sūkarakhatavaggo
analyzed: jarā vaggaḥ pañcamaḥ  sūkara khata vaggo
translated: The fifth chapter on ageing is finished.🔽The chapter on the boar’s cave

original: 1. Sālasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sāla sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Sāḷha Sutta

original: 521. Chaṭṭhavaggassa paṭhame sūrenāti sūrabhāvena. Bodhāyāti bujjhanatthāya.
analyzed: chaṭṭha vaggassa paṭhame sūrena ati sūra bhāvena bodhāya ati bujjhana tthāya
translated: In the first of the sixth chapter, “heroes” : by virtue of their being fragrant. “For the sake of enlightenment” : for the sake of awakening.

original: 2. Mallikasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: mallika sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Mallikā Sutta

original: 522. Dutiye mallesūti evaṃnāmake janapade. Imasmiṃ sutte cattāri indriyāni missakāni, ariyañāṇaṃ lokuttaraṃ. Tampi pana catukkindriyanissitaṃ katvā missakanti bhājetuṃ vaṭṭati.
analyzed: dutiye mallesu iti evaṃnāmake janapade imasmin sutte cattāri indriyāni missakāni ariya ñāṇam lokuttaram tam pi pana catukkindriya nissitam katvā missakanti bhājetum vaṭṭati
translated: In the second, in the country called Malla . In this sutta the four faculties are mixed, and the noble knowledge is supramundane. But that can be divided up as mixed by taking it as based on the four kinds of faculty.

original: 3. Sekhasuttavaṇṇanā🔽523. Tatiye na heva kho kāyena phusitvā viharatīti na nāmakāyena phusitvā paṭilabhitvā🔽viharati, phusituṃ paṭilabhituṃ na sakkoti. Paññāya ca ativijjha passatīti paccavekkhaṇapaññāya🔽pana “upari arahattaphalindriyaṃ nāma atthī”ti pajānāti. Asekhabhūmiyaṃ phusitvā
analyzed: sekha sutta vaṇṇanā  tatiye na ha iva kho kāyena phusitvā viharati iti na nāmakāyena phusitvā paṭilabhitvā  viharati phusitum paṭilabhitum na sakkoti paññāya ca ativijjha passati iti paccavekkhaṇa paññāya  pana upari arahatta phala indriyam nāma atthi iti pajānāti asekhabhūmiyam phusitvā
translated: . The explanation of the third sutta🔽In the third , he does not dwell having contacted with the body and having continuously experienced it with the mind,

original: viharatīti paṭilabhitvā viharati. Paññāyāti paccavekkhaṇapaññāya “arahattaphalindriyaṃ🔽nāma atthī”ti pajānāti. Na kuhiñci kismiñcīti dvepi aññamaññavevacanāneva, kismiñci
analyzed: viharati iti paṭilabhitvā viharati paññāya ati paccavekkhaṇa paññāya arahatta phala indriyam 🔽nāma atthi iti pajānāti na kuhiñci kismiñci iti dve pi kismiñci

original: bhave na uppajjissantīti attho. Imasmiṃ sutte pañcindriyāni lokuttarāni, cha lokikāni
analyzed: bhave na uppajjissanti iti attho imasmin sutte pañca indriyāni lokuttarāni cha lokikāni
translated: the meaning is, they will not arise in becoming. In this Thread the five faculties are supramundane, and the six are mundane.

original: vaṭṭanissitāneva kathitāni.
analyzed: kathitāni
translated: They are only spoken of as connected with the round .

original: 4-5. Padasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: Commentary on the Verses on the Terms🔽In the fourth , whatever terms are conducive to enlightenment are whatever terms of Dhamma, whatever sections of Dhamma, are conducive to awakening. The fifth is self-evident.🔽Commentary on the Thread on the Foundation

original: 524-525. Catutthe yāni kānici padāni bodhāya saṃvattantīti yāni kānici dhammapadāni, ye keci dhammakoṭṭhāsā, bujjhanatthāya saṃvattanti. Pañcamaṃ uttānameva.
analyzed: catutthe yāni kānici padāni bodhāya saṃvattanti iti yāni kānici dhamma padāni ye keci dhamma koṭṭhāsāḥ bujjhana tthāya saṃvattanti pañcamam uttānam eva
translated: In the sixth , he guards his cognizance against the defilements and the ideas defiled : he guards his cognizance against the arising of defilements in regard to ideas in the three planes.🔽He is said to guard his cognizance against the defilements and the ideas defiled.🔽The seventh is self-evident.

original: 6-7. Patiṭṭhitasuttādivaṇṇanā🔽526-527. Chaṭṭhe cittaṃ rakkhati āsavesu ca sāsavesu ca dhammesūti tebhūmakadhamme
analyzed: patiṭṭhita sutta ādi vaṇṇanā  chaṭṭhe cittam rakkhati āsavesu ca sa āsavesu ca dhammesu uti tebhūmaka dhamme
translated: Commentary on the Thread about the Boar’s Cave🔽In the eighth , in the boar’s cave : in the boar’s cave-dwelling. At the time of the Buddha Kassapa, it seems, that cave-dwelling, which was then underground, was formed when the earth was extended during an intervening period between two Buddhas. analyzed: ārabbha āsava uppattim vārentaḥ āsavesu ca sa āsavesu ca dhammesu cittam rakkhati nāma

original: Sattamaṃ uttānameva.🔽8. Sūkarakhatasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sattamam uttānam eva  sūkarakhata sutta vaṇṇanā

original: 528. Aṭṭhame sūkarakhatāyanti sūkarakhataleṇe. Kassapabuddhakāle kira taṃ leṇaṃ ekasmiṃ
analyzed: aṭṭhame sūkarakhatāyanti sūkara khata leṇe kassapa buddha kāle kira tam leṇam ekasmin
translated: aṭṭhame sūkarakhatāti sūkarakhataleṇe | kassapabuddhānusāsane kira taṃ leṇaṃ ekaṃ

original: buddhantare pathaviyā vaḍḍhamānāya antobhūmigataṃ jātaṃ. Athekadivasaṃ eko sūkaro
analyzed: buddha antare pathaviyā vaḍḍhamānāya antar bhūmi gatam jātam atha eka divasam ekaḥ sūkaraḥ
translated: buddhantare pathaviyā vaḍḍhamānāya antobhūmigataṃ jātaṃ | atha eko divā sūkarabhūto

original: tassa chadanapariyantasamīpe paṃsuṃ khaṇi. Deve vuṭṭhe paṃsu dhotā, chadanapariyanto
analyzed: tassa chadana pariyanta samīpe paṃsum deve vuṭṭhe paṃsu dhotā chadana pariyanto
translated: He dug the earth near the edge of the roof-cover. When the rain had passed, the earth that had been washed away

original: pākaṭo ahosi. Eko vanacarako disvā “pubbe sīlavantehi paribhuttaṭṭhānena bhavitabbaṃ,
analyzed: pākaṭaḥ ahosi ekaḥ vana carakaḥ disvā pubbe sīlavantehi paribhutta ṭṭhānena bhavitabbam
translated: had exposed the edge of the roof-cover. A forest-dweller saw it, and thinking: ‘This must be a place used by those who are virtuous,
