original: paṭijaggissāmi na”nti samantato paṃsuṃ apanetvā leṇaṃ sodhetvā kuṭiparikkhepaṃ katvā
analyzed: paṭijaggissāmi nanti samantataḥ paṃsum apanetvā leṇam sodhetvā kuṭi parikkhepam katvā
translated: I will look after it,’ he removed the earth all round, cleaned out the cave, made a boundary for the hut,

original: dvāravātapānaṃ yojetvā supariniṭṭhitasudhākammacittakammaṃ rajatapaṭṭasadisāya vālikāya
analyzed: dvāra vāta pānam yojetvā su pariniṭṭhita sudhā kamma cittakammam rajata paṭṭa sadisāya vālikāya
translated: put in a door and a window, and after making the plastering and the painting of the walls very fine,

original: santharitaṃ pariveṇaṃ katvā mañcapīṭhaṃ paññāpetvā bhagavato vasanatthāya adāsi,🔽leṇaṃ gambhīraṃ ahosi otaritvā āruhitabbaṃ. Taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Paramanipaccakāranti🔽bhāvanapuṃsakaṃ, paramanipaccakārī hutvā pavattamāno pavattatīti vuttaṃ hoti. Anuttaraṃ
analyzed: santharitam pariveṇam katvā mañca pīṭham paññāpetvā bhagavataḥ vasana tthāya adāsi  leṇam gambhīram ahosi otaritvā āruhitabbam tam sandhāya itam vuttam parama nipaccakāranti  bhāva napuṃsakam hutvā pavattamānaḥ pavattati iti vuttam hoti anuttaram
translated: he made a surrounding space and spread sand like a silver sheet, and after arranging a bed and a chair, he gave it to the Blessed One to live in.🔽The cave was deep, and one had to go down into it and climb up again. It was said with reference to that. The highest🔽hospitality: it occurs as one who is practising the highest hospitality. The unsurpassed

original: yogakkhemanti arahattaṃ. Sappatissoti sajeṭṭhako. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
analyzed: yogakkhemanti arahattam sappatissaḥ ti sajeṭṭhako sesam sabbattha uttāna attham eva ati
translated: security from bondage: arahatship. The most excellent: the most senior. The rest is clear in all its aspects.

original: Sūkarakhatavaggo chaṭṭho.
analyzed: sūkarakhata vaggaḥ chaṭṭhaḥ
translated: The Sixth Chapter on the Hog’s Thigh is finished.

original: 7. Bodhipakkhiyavaggo
analyzed: bodhi pakkhiya vaggaḥ
translated: The Chapter on the Factors of Enlightenment

original: 531-650. Sattamavagge satta phalāni pubbabhāgāni, tesaṃ heṭṭhā dve phalāni ādiṃ katvā missakāni. Sesamettha ito parañca sabbaṃ uttānamevāti.
analyzed: sattama vagge satta phalāni pubba bhāgāni tesam heṭṭhā dve phalāni ādim katvā missakāni sesam ettha itas param ca sabbam uttānam eva ati
translated: . In the seventh chapter there are seven fruits and seven kinds of prior-to-insight practice. The first two fruits are given first and then mixed up. The rest here and what follows are all plain.

original: Indriyasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: indriya saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Description of the Connected Discourses on the Faculties is finished.

original: 5. Sammappadhānasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Connected Discourses on the Right End of the Path

original: 651-704. Sammappadhānasaṃyutte sakalepi pubbabhāgavipassanāva kathitāti.
analyzed: sammappadhāna saṃyutte sakale pi pubba bhāga vipassanā ava kathitā ti
translated: . In the Connected Discourses on the Right End of the Path, the entire prior-to-insight practice is explained.

original: Sammappadhānasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sammappadhāna saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Description of the Connected Discourses on the Right End of the Path is finished.

original: 6. Balasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: bala saṃyutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Connected Discourses on the Powers

original: 705-812. Balasaṃyutte balāni missakāneva kathitāni. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: bala saṃyutte balāni kathitāni sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: . In the Connected Discourses on the Powers, only the mixed powers are explained. The rest is all plain.

original: Balasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: bala saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The Description of the Connected Discourses on the Powers is finished.

original: 7. Iddhipādasaṃyuttaṃ
analyzed: iddhipāda saṃyuttam
translated: The Connected Discourses on the Bases of Success

original: 1. Cāpālavaggo
analyzed: cāpāla vaggo
translated: . The Chapter on the Arrow

original: 1. Apārasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: apāra sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The Discourse on the Other Shore

original: 813. Iddhipādasaṃyuttassa paṭhame chandaṃ nissāya pavatto samādhi chandasamādhi.
analyzed: iddhipāda saṃyuttassa paṭhame chandam nissāya pavattaḥ samādhi chanda samādhi
translated: . In the first discourse in the Connected Discourses on the Bases of Success, concentration arisen dependent on desire is concentration due to desire.

original: Padhānabhūtā saṅkhārā padhānasaṅkhārā. Samannāgatanti tehi dhammehi upetaṃ. Iddhiyā
analyzed: padhāna bhūtā saṅkhārā padhāna saṅkhārā samannāgatanti tehi dhammehi upetam iddhiyā
translated: Formations that are a basis are formations as a basis. Endowed means provided with those states. Success

original: pādaṃ, iddhibhūtaṃ vā pādanti iddhipādaṃ. Sesesupi eseva nayo. Ayamettha saṅkhepo,🔽vitthāro pana iddhipādavibhaṅge āgatova. Visuddhimagge panassa attho dīpito. Tathā
analyzed: pādam iddhi bhūtam vā iddhipādam sesesu pi eṣa iva nayaḥ ayam ettha saṅkhepo  vitthāraḥ pana iddhipāda vibhaṅge āgataḥ eva visuddhi magge pana assa atthaḥ dīpitaḥ tathā
translated: and the foot is the basis for it, thus it is a road for success. The same method applies in the case of the rest. This is the brief treatment here.🔽The detailed treatment is given in the Description of the Roads to Power. But its meaning is elucidated in the Path of Purification.

original: maggabojjhaṅgasatipaṭṭhānasaṃyuttesu ceva idha ca ekaparicchedova.
analyzed: magga bojjhaṅga sati paṭṭhāna saṃyuttesu ca iva idha ca
translated: And in the same way in the case of the enlightenment factors, the foundations of mindfulness, and the Dependent Origination, the exposition is the same.

original: 5. Iddhipadesasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: iddhi padesa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Discourse on the Bases of Success.

original: 817. Pañcame iddhipadesanti tayo ca magge tīṇi ca phalāni.🔽6. Samattasuttavaṇṇanā🔽818. Chaṭṭhe samattaṃ iddhinti arahattaphalameva. Ādito paṭṭhāya pana navasupi suttesu vivaṭṭapādakā eva iddhipādā kathitā.
analyzed: pañcame ca magge tīṇi ca phalāni  samatta sutta vaṇṇanā  chaṭṭhe samattam iddhinti arahatta phalam eva āditaḥ paṭṭhāya pana navasu pi suttesu vivaṭṭa pādakā eva iddhipādā kathitā
translated: In the fifth, the bases of success are the three paths and the three fruits.🔽The explanation of the Discourse on Completion.

original: 10. Cetiyasuttavaṇṇanā🔽822. Dasame nisīdananti cammakhaṇḍaṃ adhippetaṃ. Udenaṃ cetiyanti udenayakkhassa🔽cetiyaṭṭhāne katavihāro vuccati. Gotamakādīsupi eseva nayo. Bhāvitāti vaḍḍhitā. Bahulīkatāti
analyzed: cetiya sutta vaṇṇanā 🔽dasame nisīdanan ti camma khaṇḍam adhippetam udenam cetiyanti udena yakkhassa 🔽cetiya ṭṭhāne kata vihāraḥ vuccati gotamaka ādīsu pi esā iva nayaḥ bhāvitā ati vaḍḍhitā bahulīkatā ati
translated: In the sixth, the completion of the bases of success is the fruit of arahantship. But in all the nine discourses beginning with the first, the bases of success are stated as the preliminary work.

original: punappunaṃ katā. Yānīkatāti yuttayānaṃ viya katā. Vatthukatāti patiṭṭhānaṭṭhena vatthu
analyzed: punappunam katā yā anīka tā ati yutta yānam viya katā vatthukatā ati patiṭṭhāna ṭṭhena vatthu
translated: They are done again and again. They are made like a well-equipped chariot. They are made like a basis in the sense of being a foundation.

original: viya katā. Anuṭṭhitāti adhiṭṭhitā. Paricitāti samantato citā suvaḍḍhitā. Susamāraddhāti suṭṭhu samāraddhā.
analyzed: viya katā anuṭṭhitā ati adhiṭṭhitā paricitā ati samantataḥ citā su vaḍḍhitā su samāraddhā ati suṭṭhu samāraddhā
translated: They are undertaken. They are developed all round. They are well undertaken.

original: Iti aniyamena kathetvā puna niyametvā dassento tathāgatassa khotiādimāha. Ettha ca
analyzed: iti aniyamena kathetvā puna niyametvā dassentaḥ tathāgatassa kho ti ādim āha ettha ca
translated: Having thus spoken without distinction, he now said “The Tathagata, bhikkhus” in order to show them with distinction.🔽Herein, the life-span is the life-period. He could remain making the life-period complete for that time,

original: kappanti āyukappaṃ, tasmiṃ tasmiṃ kāle yaṃ manussānaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ, taṃ paripuṇṇaṃ🔽karonto tiṭṭheyya. Kappāvasesaṃ vāti “appaṃ vā bhiyyo”ti vuttavassasatato atirekaṃ🔽vā. Mahāsīvatthero panāha “buddhānaṃ aṭṭhāne gajjitaṃ nāma natthi. Yatheva hi veḷuvagāmake🔽uppannaṃ māraṇantikavedanaṃ dasa māse vikkhambhesi, evaṃ punappunaṃ taṃ samāpattiṃ
analyzed: kappanti āyu kappam tasmin tasmin kāle yam manussānam āyu ppamāṇam tam paripuṇṇam  karontaḥ tiṭṭheyya kappa avasesam vā āti appam vā bhiyyas ti vutta vassa satataḥ atirekam  vā mahāsīva theraḥ pana āha buddhānam aṭṭhāne gajjitam nāma natthi yathā iva hi veḷuva gāmake  uppannam māraṇa antika vedanam dasa māse vikkhambhesi evam punappunam tam samāpattim
translated: for the remainder of the life-period. For more than a hundred years, which is the remainder of the life-period,

original: samāpajjitvā dasa dasa māsepi vikkhambhento imaṃ bhaddakappameva tiṭṭheyyā”ti.
analyzed: samāpajjitvā dasa dasa māse pi vikkhambhentaḥ imam bhaddakappam eva tiṭṭheyya ati
translated: is what is meant. But the Elder Maha-Siva said: “There is no such thing as the Buddhas’ thundering without reason. Just as he suppressed the pain that arose in the Veḷugumba Shrine for ten months, so he could remain for this fortunate aeon, suppressing it again and again by entering upon that attainment for ten months at a time.”

original: Kasmā pana na ṭhitoti? Upādiṇṇakasarīraṃ nāma khaṇḍiccādīhi abhibhuyyati, buddhā
analyzed: kasmā pana na upādiṇṇaka sarīram nāma khaṇḍicca ādīhi buddhā
translated: Why does he not remain? A body that is still subject to clinging is overcome by the breaking up of the components, etc.

original: nāma khaṇḍiccādibhāvaṃ apatvāva pañcame āyukoṭṭhāse bahujanassa piyamanāpakāleyeva
analyzed: nāma khaṇḍicca ādi bhāvam pañcame āyu koṭṭhāse bahu janassa
translated: The Buddhas, however, do not allow their bodies to be broken up, etc., but attain final Nibbāna in the fifth stage of the jhānas, at a time when they are dear to and beloved by the multitude.

original: parinibbāyanti. Buddhānubuddhesu ca mahāsāvakesu parinibbutesu ekakena khāṇukena🔽viya ṭhātabbaṃ hoti, daharasāmaṇeraparivāritena vā, tato – “aho buddhānaṃ parisā”ti
analyzed: parinibbāyanti buddhānubuddhesu ca mahāsāvakesu parinibbutesu ekakena khāṇukena  viya ṭhātabbam hoti dahara sāmaṇera parivāritena vā tatas aho buddhānam parisā ati
translated: And when the Buddhas and their chief disciples have attained final Nibbāna, it would be as if they had been left behind as a log.🔽Or it would be as if they were surrounded by young novices, and then it would be as if they were despised, “Oh, the Buddha’s disciples!” That is why he does not remain.

original: hīḷetabbataṃ āpajjeyya, tasmā na ṭhitoti. Evaṃ vuttepi so pana na ruccati, “āyukappo”ti
analyzed: āpajjeyya tasmā na ṭhitaḥ ti evam vutte pi saḥ pana na ruccati āyu kappo ti
translated: But even though this is said, it is still not acceptable. The statement “the span of life”

original: idameva aṭṭhakathāyaṃ niyamitaṃ.🔽Yathā taṃ mārena pariyuṭṭhitacittoti ettha tanti nipātamattaṃ. Yathā mārena pariyuṭṭhitacitto
analyzed: idam eva aṭṭhakathā ayam niyamitam  yathā tam mārena pariyuṭṭhita cittaḥ iti ettha nipāta mattam yathā mārena pariyuṭṭhita cittaḥ
translated: is the only one that is restricted in the commentary.🔽As though his mind was possessed by Māra: the word as though is merely an expression.

original: ajjhotthaṭacitto aññopi koci puthujjano paṭivijjhituṃ na sakkuṇeyya, evameva nāsakkhi
analyzed: ajjhotthaṭa cittaḥ aññaḥ api koci puthujjanaḥ paṭivijjhitum na sakkuṇeyya evam eva na asakkhi
translated: Just as any other worldling whose mind is possessed by Māra, whose mind is overwhelmed, would be unable to penetrate, so he too was unable to penetrate.

original: paṭivijjhitunti attho. Māro hi yassa sabbena sabbaṃ dvādasa vipallāsā appahīnā, tassa
analyzed: paṭivijjhitunti atthaḥ māraḥ hi yassa sabbena sabbam dvādasa vipallāsāḥ a pahīnā tassa
translated: The meaning is: he penetrated. For Māra’s control of the mind of one in whom the twelve inversions are not completely abandoned is

original: cittaṃ pariyuṭṭhāti. Therassa ca cattāro vipallāsā appahīnā, tenassa māro cittaṃ🔽pariyuṭṭhāsi. So pana cittapariyuṭṭhānaṃ karonto kiṃ karotīti? Bheravaṃ rūpārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: cittam pariyuṭṭhāti therassa ca cattāro vipallāsāḥ appahīnā tena assa māro cittam  pariyuṭṭhāsi saḥ pana citta pariyuṭṭhānam karontaḥ kim karoti iti bheravam rūpa ārammaṇam
translated: like the control of the mind of a child by its mother. But the Elder had not abandoned four inversions, and so Māra had control of his mind.

original: vā dasseti, saddārammaṇaṃ vā sāveti, tato sattā taṃ disvā vā sutvā vā satiṃ vissajjetvā
analyzed: vā dasseti sadda ārammaṇam vā sāveti tatas sattā tam disvā vā sutvā vā satim vissajjetvā
translated: But what does he do in controlling the mind? He shows a frightening object as a visible form, or he makes a frightening sound. Then, on seeing or hearing it, people lose their mindfulness,

original: vivaṭamukhā honti, tesaṃ mukhena hatthaṃ pavesetvā hadayaṃ maddati, te visaññī hutvā🔽tiṭṭhanti. Therassa panesa mukhe hatthaṃ pavesetuṃ kiṃ sakkhissati? Bheravārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: vivaṭa mukhāḥ honti tesam mukhena hattham pavesetvā hadayam maddati te visaññī hutvā  tiṭṭhanti therassa pana esa mukhe hattham pavesetum kim sakkhissati bherava ārammaṇam
translated: and their mouths gape open. He puts his hand in their mouths and pulls out their hearts. They stand there senseless.🔽But how could he put his hand in the Elder’s mouth? He showed a frightening object. On seeing it, the Elder did not penetrate the appearance as a sign.

original: pana dasseti, taṃ disvā thero nimittobhāsaṃ na paṭivijjhi. Jānantoyeva bhagavā kimatthaṃ
analyzed: pana dassa iti tam disvā theraḥ nimitta ubhāsam na paṭivijjhi jānantaḥ yā iva bhagavā kimattham
translated: The Blessed One knew perfectly well why he addressed him a third time.

original: yāvatatiyakaṃ āmantesīti. Parato “tiṭṭhatu, bhante, bhagavā”ti yācite “tuyhevetaṃ
analyzed: yāvatatiyakam āmantesi iti paratas tiṭṭhatu bhante bhagavā ati yācite
translated: When the Elder said, “Let the Blessed One be seated, venerable sir,” the Blessed One said, “What is this, Moggallāna?

original: dukkaṭaṃ, tuyhevetaṃ aparaddha”nti dosāropanena sokatanukaraṇatthaṃ.
analyzed: dukkaṭam dosa āropanena soka tanu karaṇa ttham
translated: and “It is your own fault,” in order to make him feel remorse by accusing him of anger.

original: Māro pāpimāti ettha satte anatthe niyojento māretīti māro. Pāpimāti tasseva vevacanaṃ.
analyzed: māraḥ pāpimā iti ettha satte anatthe niyojentaḥ māreti iti māraḥ pāpimā iti tassa iva vevacanam
translated: The Wicked Mara: here, in that he employs beings in what is unprofitable, he kills them, thus he is Mara. Wicked is a synonym for him.

original: So hi pāpadhammasamannāgatattā “pāpimā”ti vuccati. Kaṇho, antako, namuci, pamattabandhūtipi
analyzed: so hi pāpa dhamma samannāgata ttā pāpimā iti vuccati kaṇhaḥ antakaḥ namuci
translated: For he is called “wicked” because he is possessed of wicked states. Black, Destroyer, Unrestrained, and Kinsman of the heedless are also🔽his names. But the Blessed One, after attaining enlightenment,

original: tasseva nāmāni. Bhāsitā kho panesāti ayañhi bhagavato sambodhipattiyā aṭṭhame sattāhe
analyzed: tassa iva nāmāni bhāsitā kho pana isā ati ayan hi bhagavato sambodhi pattiyā aṭṭhame sattāhe
translated: on the eighth day after his enlightenment,

original: bodhimaṇḍaṃyeva āgantvā – “bhagavā yadatthaṃ tumhehi pāramiyo pūritā, so vo attho
analyzed: āgantvā bhagavā yadattham tumhehi pāramiyaḥ pūritā saḥ vaḥ attho
translated: came to the Bodhi Tree and said: “The purpose for which you fulfilled the perfections has been attained by you,

original: anuppatto, paṭividdhaṃ sabbaññutaññāṇaṃ, kiṃ vo lokavicaraṇenā”ti vatvā yathā ajja,
analyzed: an uppatto paṭividdham sabbaññu ta ññāṇam kim vaḥ loka vicaraṇena ati vatvā yathā ajja
translated: the knowledge of omniscience has been penetrated by you, what have you to do with wandering for alms in the world?” and he spoke as he does today,

original: evameva – “parinibbātu dāni, bhante, bhagavā, parinibbātu, sugato,”ti yāci. Bhagavā
analyzed: evam eva parinibbātu dāni bhante bhagavā parinibbātu sugataḥ iti yāci bhagavā
translated: saying: “Let the Blessed One now attain final Nibbana, let the Sublime One attain final Nibbana,” and the Blessed One

original: cassa “na tāvāha”ntiādīni vatvā paṭikkhipi. Taṃ sandhāya “bhāsitā kho panesā, bhante,”tiādimāha.
analyzed: cassa na tau aham iti ādīni vatvā paṭikkhipi tam sandhāya bhāsitā kho pana isā bhante ti ādim āha
translated: refused him, saying: “Not yet, friend,” and so on. Referring to that, he said: “But, venerable sir, this has been said by the Blessed One: ‘Not yet, Ananda, have I allowed the full admission of women to the Order.’“

original: Tattha viyattāti maggavasena byattā. Tatheva vinītā. Tathā visāradā. Bahussutāti
analyzed: tattha viyattā ati magga vasena byattā tathā iva vinītā tathā visāradā bahu sutā
translated: Herein, well-trained is by way of path well-trained. Just so well-disciplined. Just so confident. Learned

original: tepiṭakavasena bahu sutametesanti bahussutā. Tadeva dhammaṃ dhārentīti dhammadharā.
analyzed: te piṭaka vasena bahu tat eva dhammam dhārenti iti dhammadharā
translated: Herein, they are “well trained” by way of the path. They are “well disciplined” in the same way. They are “confident” in the same way. “Learned” means they have learned much by way of the three Piṭakas. They are “learned” because they have learned much. They “bear in mind” that same Dhamma.

original: Atha vā pariyattibahussutā ceva paṭivedhabahussutā ca, pariyattipaṭivedhadhammānaṃyeva🔽dhāraṇato dhammadharāti evamettha attho daṭṭhabbo. Dhammānudhammappaṭipannāti ariyadhammassa🔽anudhammabhūtaṃ vipassanādhammaṃ paṭipannā. Sāmīcippaṭipannāti anucchavikapaṭipadaṃ
analyzed: atha vā pariyatti bahussutā ca iva paṭivedha bahussutā ca pariyatti paṭivedha dhammānaṃ eva  dhāraṇataḥ dhamma dharā ti evam ettha atthaḥ daṭṭhabbo dhamma anudhamma paṭipannā ti ariya dhammassa  anudhamma bhūtam vipassanā dhammam paṭipannā sāmīci paṭipannā ati anucchavika paṭipadam
translated: Or else, they are learned in the scriptures and learned in the penetration of the meaning of the scriptures.🔽The meaning should be regarded as follows: they bear in mind the scriptures and the meaning of the scriptures. “They practice in accordance with the Dhamma” means they practice the Dhamma of insight, which is in accordance with the noble Dhamma. “They practice in accordance with the Vinaya” means they practice the proper practice.

original: paṭipannā. Anudhammacārinoti anudhammacaraṇasīlā. Sakaṃ ācariyakanti attano ācariyavādaṃ.
analyzed: paṭipannāḥ anudhamma cārino ti anudhamma caraṇa sīlā sakam ācariyakam ti attanaḥ ācariya vādam
translated: “They are of good character” means they have the virtue of good character. “Their own teacher’s instruction” means their own teacher’s doctrine.

original: Ācikkhissantītiādīni sabbāni aññamaññasseva vevacanāni. Sahadhammenāti sahetukena
analyzed: ācikkhissanti iti ādīni sabbāni aññamaññassa iva vevacanāni sahadhammena ati sa hetukena
translated: “They will proclaim” and so forth are all synonyms for each other. “With the Dhamma” means with a reason.

original: sakāraṇena vacanena. Sappāṭihāriyanti yāva niyyānikaṃ katvā dhammaṃ desessanti.
analyzed: sa kāraṇena vacanena sappāṭihāriyanti yāva niyyānikam katvā dhammam desessanti
translated: “With the discipline” means they will teach the Dhamma up to the point of release.

original: Brahmacariyanti sikkhattayasaṅgahitaṃ sakalaṃ sāsanabrahmacariyaṃ. Iddhanti samiddhaṃ
analyzed: brahmacariyanti sikkhattaya saṅgahitam sakalam sāsana brahmacariyam iddham ti samiddham
translated: “The life of purity” is the whole life of purity of the Dispensation, which is included in the three trainings. “Flourished”

original: jhānassādavasena. Phītanti vuḍḍhipattaṃ sabbapāliphullaṃ viya abhiññāsampattivasena.
analyzed: jhāna ssāda vasena phītanti vuḍḍhi pattam sabba pāli phullam viya abhiññā sampatti vasena
translated: means it was successful, by the success of the jhānas. “Prospered” means it reached growth, like a tree in full flower, by the success of the higher knowledges.

original: Vitthārikanti vitthataṃ tasmiṃ tasmiṃ disābhāge patiṭṭhitavasena. Bāhujaññanti bahūhi
analyzed: vitthārikanti vitthatam tasmin tasmin disā bhāge patiṭṭhita vasena bāhujaññanti bahūhi
translated: “Was widespread” means it was extended, by its establishment in various directions. “Was well proclaimed” means it was well known, well penetrated, by many,

original: ñātaṃ paṭividdhaṃ mahājanābhisamayavasena. Puthubhūtanti sabbākārena puthulabhāvapattaṃ.
analyzed: ñātam paṭividdham mahā jana abhisamaya vasena puthu bhūtanti sabba ākārena puthula bhāva pattam
translated: by the understanding of the multitude. “Was visible” means it had reached the state of being extended in every way.

original: Kathaṃ? Yāva devamanussehi suppakāsitaṃ, yattakā viññujātikā devā ceva manussā ca
analyzed: katham yāva deva manussehi su pakāsitam yattakā viññu jātikā devā ca iva manussā ca
translated: How? It was well proclaimed as far as gods and men. As many as there are beings who are wise, gods and men,

original: atthi, sabbehi suṭṭhu pakāsitanti attho.🔽Appossukkoti nirālayo. Tvañhi pāpima aṭṭhamasattāhato paṭṭhāya “parinibbātu dāni,
analyzed: atthi sabbehi suṭṭhu pakāsitanti attho  appossukko ti nirālayaḥ tvam hi pāpima aṭṭhama satta ahataḥ paṭṭhāya parinibbātu dāni
translated: the meaning is, it was well proclaimed by all of them.🔽“Without clinging” means without support. For you, Evil One, from the eighth day after the Blessed One’s final attainment of Nibbāna you went about crying: “Now let the recluse Gotama attain final Nibbāna,

original: bhante, bhagavā, parinibbātu sugato”ti viravanto āhiṇḍittha, ajja dāni paṭṭhāya vigatussāho
analyzed: bhante bhagavā parinibbātu sugataḥ iti viravantaḥ āhiṇḍittha ajja dāni paṭṭhāya vigatussāhaḥ
translated: let the well-farer attain final Nibbāna” . From today onwards you are without hope.

original: hohi, mā mayhaṃ parinibbānatthaṃ vāyāmaṃ karohīti vadati.
analyzed: hohi mā mayham parinibbāna attham vāyāmam karohi iti vadati
translated: “Be, do not make effort for my final Nibbāna.”

original: Sato sampajāno āyusaṅkhāraṃ ossajīti satiṃ sūpaṭṭhitaṃ katvā ñāṇena paricchinditvā🔽āyusaṅkhāraṃ vissaji pajahi. Tattha na bhagavā hatthena leḍḍuṃ viya āyusaṅkhāraṃ🔽ossaji, temāsamattameva pana phalasamāpattiṃ samāpajjitvā tato paraṃ na samāpajjissāmīti
analyzed: sataḥ sampajānaḥ āyu saṅkhāram ossajīti satim su upaṭṭhitam katvā ñāṇena paricchinditvā  āyu saṅkhāram vissaji pajahi tattha na bhagavā hatthena leḍḍum viya āyu saṅkhāram  ossaji te māsa mattam eva pana phala samāpattim samāpajjitvā tatas param na samāpajjissāmi iti
translated: “Mindfully and with full awareness he relinquished the life-process”: having made mindfulness well-established, having delimited with knowledge,

original: cittaṃ uppādesi. Taṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ “ossajī”ti. Ussajītipi pāṭho. Mahābhūmicāloti
analyzed: cittam uppādesi tam sandhāya vuttam ossajī iti ussajī iti pi pāṭhaḥ mahā bhūmi cālo ti
translated: he relinquished, he abandoned the life-process. Herein, the Blessed One did not relinquish the life-process like a man throwing away a piece of chewed straw. He merely aroused the thought: “I will not attain the fruition attainment for three months.” With reference to that it was said: “He relinquished.” The reading “ussajī” is also correct. A great earthquake:

original: mahanto pathavikampo. Tadā kira dasasahassilokadhātu akampittha. Bhiṃsanakoti bhayajanako.🔽Devadundubhiyo ca phaliṃsūti devabheriyo phaliṃsu, devo sukkhagajjitaṃ gajji, akālavijjulatā
analyzed: mahantaḥ pathavi kampo tadā kira dasa sahassi lokadhātu akampittha bhiṃsanakaḥ uti bhaya janakaḥ  ca deva bheriyaḥ ca devaḥ sukkha gajjitam gajji akāla vijjula tā
translated: a great trembling of the earth. At that time, it is said, the ten-thousandfold world system shook. Frightful: causing fear.🔽And the deva-drums thundered: the deva-drums sounded. The sky rained down the flowers of the coral tree, and the sky rained down showers of the perfume of the tagara flower, it is said.

original: nicchariṃsu, khaṇikavassaṃ vassīti vuttaṃ hoti.
analyzed: nicchariṃsu khaṇika vassam vassī iti vuttam hoti
translated: And the deva-drums thundered: the deva-drums sounded. The sky rained down the flowers of the coral tree, and the sky rained down showers of the perfume of the tagara flower, it is said.

original: Udānaṃ udānesīti kasmā udānesi? Koci nāma vadeyya “bhagavā pacchato pacchato anubandhitvā
analyzed: udānam udānesi iti kasmai udānesi koci nāma vadeyya bhagavā pacchatas pacchatas anubandhitvā
translated: Why did he utter this exalted utterance? Because someone might say that the Blessed One had released his life-continuum by the exertion of following after them,

original: – ‘parinibbāyatha, bhante, parinibbāyatha, bhante’ti upadduto bhayena āyusaṅkhāraṃ
analyzed: parinibbāyatha bhante parinibbāyatha bhanteti upaddutaḥ bhayena āyu saṅkhāram
translated: thinking, ‘Venerable sirs, attain final Nibbāna! Venerable sirs, attain final Nibbāna!’ out of fear and terror.

original: vissajjesī”ti. Tassokāso mā hotūti. Bhītassa hi udānaṃ nāma natthīti pītivegavissaṭṭhaṃ udānesi.
analyzed: vissajjesi iti tassa ukāsaḥ mā hotu uti bhītassa hi udānam nāma natthi iti pīti vega vissaṭṭham udānesi
translated: So he uttered this exalted utterance in order to preclude such a notion, for one who is afraid has no exalted utterance.

original: Tattha sabbesaṃ soṇasiṅgālādīnampi paccakkhabhāvato tulitaṃ paricchinnanti tulaṃ.
analyzed: tattha sabbesam soṇa siṅgāla ādīnam pi paccakkha bhāvato tulitam paricchinnanti tulam
translated: Herein, weighed and discerned by him is weighed ;

original: Kiṃ taṃ? Kāmāvacarakammaṃ. Na tulaṃ, na vā tulaṃ sadisamassa aññaṃ lokiyakammaṃ atthīti🔽atulaṃ. Kiṃ taṃ? Mahaggatakammaṃ. Atha vā kāmāvacaraṃ rūpāvacarañca tulaṃ, arūpāvacaraṃ
analyzed: kim tam kāmāvacara kammam na tulam na vā tulam sadisam assa aññam lokiya kammaṃ atthi iti  atulam kim tat mahaggata kammam atha vā kāmāvacaram rūpāvacaram ca tulam arūpāvacaram
translated: What is that? Sense-desire-world kamma. There is no other kamma in the world that is equal to that, or that is like it,

original: atulaṃ. Appavipākaṃ tulaṃ, bahuvipākaṃ atulaṃ. Sambhavanti sambhavahetubhūtaṃ, piṇḍakārakaṃ
analyzed: atulam ap pavipākam tulam bahu vipākam atulam sambhavanti sambhava hetu bhūtam piṇḍa kārakam
translated: so it is unequalled . What is that? High-fruition kamma. Or alternatively, sense-desire-world and fine-material-world kamma are weighed ; immaterial-world kamma is unequalled . Kamma with little result is weighed ; kamma with much result is unequalled .🔽It is the cause of becoming, the maker of bundles ,

original: rāsikārakanti attho. Bhavasaṅkhāranti punabbhavassa saṅkhāraṃ. Avassajīti vissajjesi.
analyzed: rāsikārakam ti atthaḥ bhava saṅkhāram ti punabbhavassa saṅkhāram avassaji iti vissajjesi
translated: the meaning is, he made an end of the heap. The “formation of being” is the formation of renewed existence. “He cast off”: he relinquished.

original: Munīti buddhamuni. Ajjhattaratoti niyakajjhattarato. Samāhitoti upacārappanāsamādhivasena
analyzed: muni iti buddha muni ajjhattarato ti niyaka ajjhattarato samāhitaḥ ti upacāra ppanā samādhi vasena
translated: The “sage”: the Buddha-sage. “Delighting in his own mind”: delighting in his own mind’s peace. “Concentrated”: concentrated by means of access concentration and absorption concentration.

original: samāhito. Abhindi kavacamivāti kavacaṃ viya abhindi. Attasambhavanti attani jātakilesaṃ.
analyzed: samāhitaḥ abhindi kavacam iva ati kavacam viya abhindi jāta kilesam
translated: “He broke through”: he broke through as if breaking through a coat of mail. “His own being”: the defilements arisen in himself.

original: Idaṃ vuttaṃ hoti – savipākaṭṭhena sambhavaṃ bhavābhisaṅkhaṇaṭṭhena bhavasaṅkhāranti🔽ca laddhanāmaṃ tulātulasaṅkhātaṃ lokiyakammañca ossaji, saṅgāmasīse mahāyodho kavacaṃ
analyzed: idam vuttam hoti sa vipāka ṭṭhena sambhavam bhava abhisaṅkhaṇa ṭṭhena bhava saṅkhāranti  ca laddha nāmam tulā tula saṅkhātam lokiya kammaṃ ca ossaji saṅgāma sīse mahā yodhaḥ kavacaṃ
translated: This is the meaning: he cast off the worldling’s action, which is called “having becoming” in the sense of having ripening, and “the formation of being” in the sense of the formation of renewed existence, which is reckoned as “having no becoming” .

original: viya attasambhavaṃ kilesañca ajjhattarato samāhito hutvā abhindīti.🔽Atha vā tulanti tulento tīrento. Atulañca sambhavanti nibbānañceva bhavañca. Bhavasaṅkhāranti
analyzed: atta sambhavam kilesam ca ajjhattaratas samāhitaḥ hutvā abhindi iti  atha vā tulanti tulentaḥ tīrentaḥ atulam ca sambhavanti nibbānam ca iva bhavam ca bhava saṅkhāranti
translated: Like a great warrior who breaks through a coat of mail at the head of the battle, he broke through his own being, the defilements, while delighting in his own mind’s peace and being concentrated.

original: bhavagāmikammaṃ. Avassaji munīti “pañcakkhandhā aniccā, pañcannaṃ khandhānaṃ nirodho
analyzed: bhava gāmi kammam avassaji muni iti pañca kkhandhāḥ aniccā pañcannam khandhānam nirodhaḥ
translated: Or alternatively, “having become” is “having become one who measures” and “one who crosses over.” “Having no becoming” is Nibbāna and becoming. The “formation of being” is action that leads to becoming. “He cast off”: “The five aggregates are impermanent, the cessation of the five aggregates

original: nibbānaṃ nicca”ntiādinā nayena tulayanto buddhamuni bhave ādīnavaṃ nibbāne cānisaṃsaṃ🔽disvā taṃ khandhānaṃ mūlabhūtaṃ bhavasaṅkhāraṃ “kammakkhayāya saṃvattatī”ti evaṃ
analyzed: nibbānam niccanti ādinā nayena tulayantaḥ buddha muni bhave ādīnavam nibbāne ca anisaṃsam  disvā tam khandhānam mūla bhūtam bhava saṅkhāram kamma khayāya saṃvattati iti evam
translated: The Buddha, the Sage, weighed up the danger in existence and the benefit in Nibbāna in the way beginning, “Nibbāna is permanent” .🔽Seeing that, he abandoned the formation of existence, which is the root of the aggregates, by means of the noble path called “the path that leads to the exhaustion of action” .🔽How? He was inwardly pleased and concentrated;

original: vuttena kammakkhayakarena ariyamaggena avassaji. Kathaṃ? Ajjhattarato samāhito abhindi
analyzed: vuttena kamma khaya karena ariya maggena avassaji katham ajjhattarataḥ samāhitaḥ abhindi
translated: He broke the armour of the origin of being.

original: kavacamivattasambhavaṃ. So hi vipassanāvasena ajjhattarato, samathavasena samāhitoti🔽evaṃ pubbabhāgato paṭṭhāya samathavipassanābalena kavacamiva attabhāvaṃ pariyonandhitvā
analyzed: so hi vipassanā vasena ajjhattaratas samatha vasena samāhitaḥ ti  evam pubba bhāgataḥ paṭṭhāya samatha vipassanā balena kavacam iva atta bhāvam pariyonandhitvā
translated: Inwardly pleased means pleased by means of insight; concentrated means concentrated by means of serenity.

original: ṭhitaṃ, attani sambhavattā attasambhavanti laddhanāmaṃ sabbaṃ kilesajātaṃ abhindi.🔽Kilesābhāvena ca kammaṃ appaṭisandhikattā avassaṭṭhaṃ nāma hotīti evaṃ kilesappahānena
analyzed: ṭhitam sambhavattā attasambhavanti laddha nāmam sabbam kilesa jātam abhindi  kilesa abhāvena ca kammam appaṭisandhika ttā avassaṭṭham nāma hoti iti evam kilesa ppahānena
translated: Thus, beginning with the prior stage, with the strength of serenity and insight he broke the armour, that is, the whole mass of defilements called “origin of being” because it originates in the self, which was put on by him and stood surrounding his person.🔽And because of the absence of defilements, action is called “abandoned” because it does not come to re-existence. Thus he destroyed action by abandoning defilements.

original: kammaṃ jahi. Pahīnakilesassa bhayaṃ nāma natthi. Tasmā abhītova āyusaṅkhāraṃ ossaji.
analyzed: kammam jahi pahīna kilesassa bhayam nāma natthi tasmai abhītaḥ uva āyu saṅkhāram ossaji
translated: And because of the absence of defilements there is no fear for one who has abandoned defilements. Therefore he abandoned the life-continuum fearlessly.

original: Abhītabhāvañāpanatthañca udānaṃ udānesīti veditabbo.
analyzed: a bhīta bhāva ñāpana attham ca udānam udānesi iti veditabbo
translated: and he uttered this exalted utterance in order to make known his state of fearlessness.

original: Cāpālavaggo paṭhamo.
analyzed: cāpāla vaggo paṭhamaḥ
translated: The first sub-chapter on the bow-maker is finished.

original: 2. Pāsādakampanavaggo
analyzed: pāsāda kampana vaggo
translated: The second sub-chapter on the shaking of the palace

original: 1-2. Pubbasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the first sutta, etc.

original: 823-824. Dutiyavaggassa paṭhame na ca atilīnotiādīni parato āvi bhavissanti. Imasmiṃ sutte chaabhiññāpādakā iddhipādā kathitā, tathā dutiye ca.🔽3. Chandasamādhisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya vaggassa paṭhame na ca ati līna uti ādīni paratas bhavissanti imasmin sutte cha abhiññā pādakā iddhipādā kathitā tathā dutiye ca  chanda samādhi sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: In the first of the second sub-chapter, “not too slack” , etc., will be given later on. In this sutta the four bases for spiritual power that are prerequisites for the six kinds of direct knowledge are taught, and in the second also.🔽The third

original: 825. Tatiye chandanti kattukamyatāchandaṃ. Nissāyāti nissayaṃ katvā, adhipatiṃ katvāti
analyzed: tatiye chandanti kattu kamyatā chandam nissāya ati nissayam katvā adhipatim katvā iti
translated: “Desire” is desire to act. “Depending on” : making it a support, making it a predominance.

original: attho. Padhānasaṅkhārāti padhānabhūtā saṅkhārā, catukiccasādhakasammappadhānavīriyassetaṃ
analyzed: padhāna saṅkhārā ati padhāna bhūtā saṅkhārā catu kicca sādhaka sammappadhāna vīriyassa etam
translated: The meaning is: “making it a predominance.” “Readiness for striving” is striving that is a state of readiness. This is a term for energy that accomplishes the fourfold task.

original: adhivacanaṃ. Iti ayañca chandotiādīsu chando chandasamādhinā ceva padhānasaṅkhārehi
analyzed: adhivacanam iti ayam ca chandaḥ ti ādīsu chandaḥ chanda samādhinā ca iva padhāna saṅkhārehi
translated: Thus in the passages beginning “Desire, concentration” , etc., desire is accompanied by concentration and by the readines for striving;

original: ca, chandasamādhi chandena ceva padhānasaṅkhārehi ca, padhānasaṅkhārāpi chandena
analyzed: ca chandena ca iva padhāna saṅkhārehi ca chandena
translated: concentration is accompanied by desire and by the readines for striving; and the readines for striving is accompanied by desire and by concentration.

original: ceva chandasamādhinā ca samannāgatā. Tasmā sabbe te dhamme ekato katvā ayaṃ vuccati,🔽bhikkhave, chandasamādhippadhānasaṅkhārasamannāgato iddhipādoti vuttaṃ. Iddhipādavibhaṅge🔽pana “yo tathābhūtassa vedanākkhandho tiādinā nayena imehi dhammehi samannāgatā sesaarūpino
analyzed: ca iva chanda samādhinā ca samannāgatā tasmā sabbe te dhamme ekatas katvā ayam vuccati  bhikkhave chanda samādhi padhāna saṅkhāra samannāgataḥ iddhipādaḥ ti vuttam iddhipāda vibhaṅge  pana yaḥ tathābhūtassa vedanā khandho ti ādinā nayena imehi dhammehi samannāgatā sesa arūpino
translated: and concentration accompanied by will. Therefore all these states are called,🔽“Monks, this is called the road to power that is concentration due to zeal and includes desire and includes concentration.”🔽But in the Vibhaṅga these states are called “the road to power consisting in concentration due to zeal” and the rest in the way beginning, “The road to power consisting in concentration due to zeal is the states consisting in will, endeavour, energy, perseverance, speech, strength, and heroism in one who has such zeal” .

original: dhammā iddhipādāti vuttā.
analyzed: dhammāḥ iddhipādā ti vuttā
translated: And the remaining immaterial states are called “the road to power consisting in the states consisting in concentration due to zeal” and the rest.

original: Apica imepi tayo dhammā iddhīpi honti iddhipādāpi. Kathaṃ? Chandañhi bhāvayato chando🔽iddhi nāma hoti, samādhippadhānasaṅkhārā chandiddhipādo nāma. Samādhiṃ bhāventassa🔽samādhi iddhi nāma hoti, chandappadhānasaṅkhārā samādhiddhiyā pādo nāma. Padhānasaṅkhāre
analyzed: apica ime pi tayo dhammā honti iddhipādā api katham chandam hi bhāvayato chando  id hi nāma hoti samādhi padhāna saṅkhārā chandiddhipādaḥ nāma samādhim bhāventassa  samādhi nāma hoti chanda padhāna saṅkhārā samādhi dhiyā pādaḥ nāma padhāna saṅkhāre
translated: Moreover, these three states are both roads to power and also bases for success. How? When zeal is being developed, zeal is called a road to power;🔽the preliminary work consisting in will, endeavour, energy, perseverance, speech, strength, and heroism is called a base for success in the road to power consisting in zeal. When concentration is being developed,🔽concentration is called a road to power; the preliminary work consisting in will, endeavour, energy, perseverance, speech, strength, and heroism is called a base for success in the road to power consisting in concentration. When the preliminary work is being developed,

original: bhāventassa padhānasaṅkhārā iddhi nāma hoti, chandasamādhi padhānasaṅkhāriddhiyā
analyzed: bhāventassa padhāna saṅkhārā iddhi nāma hoti chanda samādhi padhāna saṅkhāra iddhiyā
translated: the preliminary work is called a road to power; zeal and concentration are called a base for success in the road to power consisting in the preliminary work.

original: pādo nāma, sampayuttadhammesu hi ekasmiṃ ijjhamāne sesāpi ijjhantiyeva.🔽Apica tesaṃ tesaṃ dhammānaṃ pubbabhāgavasenāpi etesaṃ iddhipādatā veditabbā. Paṭhamajjhānañhi
analyzed: pādaḥ nāma sampayutta dhammesu hi ekasmin ijjhamāne sesā api  apica tesam tesam dhammānam pubbabhāga vasena api etesam iddhipāda tā veditabbā paṭhama jhānam hi
translated: For when one of the states associated with the jhāna succeeds, the others do too.🔽Besides, their footing for success should be understood as the states that precede them. For the first jhāna is success, and the desire, etc., associated with the preliminary work that precedes it are the footing for that success.

original: iddhi nāma, paṭhamajjhānassa pubbabhāgaparikammasampayuttā chandādayo iddhipādo nāma.🔽Etenupāyena yāva nevasaññānāsaññāyatanā, iddhividhaṃ ādiṃ katvā yāva dibbacakkhuabhiññā,
analyzed: iddhi nāma paṭhama jhānassa pubbabhāga parikamma sampayuttā chanda ādayo iddhipādo nāma  etena upāyena yāva nevasaññānāsaññāyatanāḥ iddhi vidham ādim katvā yāva dibba cakkhu abhiññā
translated: Similarly, the various kinds of supernormal power, etc., are success, and the desire, etc., associated with the preliminary work that precedes them are the footing for that success.🔽And so too in the case of the divine eye, the divine ear, the knowledge of penetration of minds, the knowledge of recollecting past lives, the knowledge of faring according to deeds, the knowledge of the destruction of the cankers, and the path of the several kinds of enlightenment.

original: sotāpattimaggaṃ ādiṃ katvā yāva arahattamaggā nayo netabbo. Sesiddhipādesupi eseva nayo.
analyzed: sotāpatti maggam ādim katvā yāva arahatta maggāḥ nayaḥ netabbo esā iva nayo
translated: And the same method of explanation should be followed in the case of the other three kinds of success.

original: Keci pana “anibbatto chando iddhipādo”ti vadanti. Idha tesaṃ vādamaddanatthāya abhidhamme uttaracūḷavāro nāma āgato –
analyzed: keci pana anibbatto chandaḥ iddhipādo ti vadanti idha tesam vāda maddana tthāya abhidhamme uttaracūḷavāraḥ nāma āgataḥ
translated: But some say that desire is not a footing for success. In order to refute them the “further-part-peak” in the Abhidhamma is brought in.

original: “Cattāro iddhipādā – chandiddhipādo, vīriyiddhipādo, cittiddhipādo, vīmaṃsiddhipādo.
analyzed: cattāro iddhipādā chandiddhipādaḥ vīriyiddhipādaḥ cittiddhipādaḥ vīmaṃsiddhipādaḥ
translated: “There are four kinds of success: success through desire, success through energy, success through attention, and success through inquiry” .

original: Tattha katamo chandiddhipādo? Idha, bhikkhu, yasmiṃ samaye lokuttaraṃ jhānaṃ bhāveti
analyzed: tattha katamaḥ chandiddhipādo idha bhikkhu yasmin samaye lokuttaram jhānam bhāveti
translated: Herein, what is the road to power consisting in desire? On whatever occasion a bhikkhu develops the supramundane jhana that leads to the penetration of the way, which has the four noble truths for its object, being detached from sense desires… he then abides in that state.🔽On that occasion there is the road to power consisting in desire,

original: niyyānikaṃ apacayagāmiṃ diṭṭhigatānaṃ pahānāya paṭhamāya bhūmiyā pattiyā vivicceva🔽kāmehi…pe… paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharati dukkhāpaṭipadaṃ dandhābhiññaṃ, yo🔽tasmiṃ samaye chando chandikatā kattukamyatā kusalo dhammacchando, ayaṃ vuccati chandiddhipādo.
analyzed: niyyānikam apacaya gāmim diṭṭhi gatānam pahānāya paṭhamāya bhūmiyā pattiyā vivicca iva  kāmehipe paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati dukkha apaṭipadam dandha abhiññam yaḥ  tasmin samaye chando chandika tā kattu kamya tā kusalaḥ dhamma chando ayam vuccati chandiddhipādo
translated: On that occasion there are states productive of the road to power consisting in desire.🔽These states are numerous, of various forms and types.🔽But the road to power consisting in desire is one thing and the states productive of the road to power consisting in desire are another.🔽The road to power consisting in desire is the desire, the striving, the eagerness, the endeavour, the effort, the perseverance, the steadfastness, the intentness of mind, the mental force, the energy of one who, in order to attain the as-yet-unattained, to reach the as-yet-unreached, to realize the as-yet-unrealized, develops the four roads to power with the four foundations of mindfulness.

original: Avasesā dhammā chandiddhipādasampayuttā”ti.
analyzed: avasesā dhammā chandiddhipāda sampayuttā ti
translated: The remaining states are associated with the road to power consisting in desire.

original: Ime pana lokuttaravaseneva āgatā.🔽Tattha raṭṭhapālatthero chandaṃ dhuraṃ katvā lokuttaradhammaṃ nibbattesi. Soṇatthero
analyzed: ime pana lokuttara vasena iva āgatā  tattha raṭṭhapāla thero chandam dhuram katvā lokuttara dhammam nibbattesi soṇa thero
translated: But these are stated only in the supramundane sense.

original: vīriyaṃ dhuraṃ katvā; sambhutatthero cittaṃ dhuraṃ katvā, āyasmā mogharājā vīmaṃsaṃ
analyzed: vīriyam dhuram katvā sambhuta theraḥ cittam dhuram katvā āyasmā mogha rājā vīmaṃsam
translated: Herein, the Elder Ratthapala produced the supramundane states with desire as the forerunner. The Elder Sonaka did so with energy as the forerunner. The Elder Sambhuti did so with consciousness as the forerunner. The venerable Mogharaja did so with investigation as the forerunner.

original: dhuraṃ katvāti. Tattha yathā catūsu amaccaputtesu ṭhānantaraṃ patthetvā rājānaṃ upanissāya
analyzed: dhuram katvā ti tattha yathā catūsu amacca puttesu ṭhāna antaram patthetvā rājānam upanissāya
translated: Herein, just as when four sons of ministers, each of whom is a hero, a great champion, are given a great king’s most delectable chief consort to look after, and she is looked after by them with the hero as the forerunner, or with the great champion as the forerunner, or with the hero and the great champion as the forerunner, or with the hero and the great champion and the king’s most delectable chief consort as the forerunner,

original: viharantesu eko upaṭṭhāne chandajāto rañño ajjhāsayañca ruciñca ñatvā divā ca ratto
analyzed: viharantesu ekaḥ upaṭṭhāne chanda jātaḥ raññaḥ ajjhāsayañca ruciñca ñatvā divā ca ratto
translated: While they were living there, one of them, being keen on service, found out the king’s wishes and likings and served him day and night.

original: ca upaṭṭhahanto rājānaṃ ārādhetvā ṭhānantaraṃ pāpuṇi. Evaṃ chandadhurena lokuttaradhammanibbattako veditabbo.
analyzed: ca upaṭṭhahantaḥ rājānam ārādhetvā ṭhāna antaram pāpuṇi evam chanda dhurena lokuttara dhamma nibbattakaḥ veditabbo
translated: He pleased the king and obtained a post. So it should be understood that the supramundane state is produced by one who is keen on service.

original: Eko pana – “divase divase upaṭṭhātuṃ na sakkomi, uppanne kicce parakkamena ārādhessāmī”ti
analyzed: ekaḥ pana divase divase upaṭṭhātum na sakkomi uppanne kicce parakkamena ārādhessāmi iti
translated: But another said, “I cannot manage to serve day after day. I shall please him by an effort when some occasion arises.”

original: kupite paccante raññā pahito parakkamena sattumaddanaṃ katvā pāpuṇi. Yathā so, evaṃ
analyzed: kupite paccante raññā pahito parakkamena sattu maddanam katvā pāpuṇi yathā saḥ evam
translated: When the border country was in revolt, he was sent by the king. He pleased the king by his effort in subduing the rebels and obtained a post. As he did,

original: vīriyadhurena lokuttaradhammanibbattako veditabbo. Eko “divase divase upaṭṭhānampi
analyzed: vīriya dhurena lokuttara dhamma nibbattakaḥ veditabbaḥ ekaḥ divase divase upaṭṭhānam pi
translated: so it should be understood that the supramundane state is produced by one who is keen on energy.

original: urena sattisarasampaṭicchanampi bhāroyeva, mantabalena ārādhessāmī”ti khattavijjāya
analyzed: ārādhessāmi iti khatta vijjāya
translated: But another said, “Day-by-day service and service under a whip are both a burden. I shall please him by my counsel.”

original: kataparicayattā mantasaṃvidhānena rājānaṃ ārādhetvā pāpuṇi. Yathā so, evaṃ cittadhurena
analyzed: manta saṃvidhānena rājānam ārādhetvā yathā saḥ evam citta dhurena
translated: Because he was skilled in the treatises on statecraft, he pleased the king by his advice and obtained a post. As he did,

original: lokuttaradhammanibbattako veditabbo.
analyzed: lokuttara dhamma nibbattakaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: so it should be understood that the supramundane state is produced by one who is keen on understanding.

original: Aparo – “kiṃ imehi upaṭṭhānādīhi, rājāno nāma jātisampannassa ṭhānantaraṃ denti,
analyzed: aparaḥ kim imehi upaṭṭhāna ādīhi rājānaḥ nāma jāti sampannassa ṭhāna ntaram denti
translated: Another, thinking, “What is the use of these attentions? Kings give positions to those who are well-born.

original: tādisassa dento mayhaṃ dassatī”ti jātisampattimeva nissāya ṭhānantaraṃ pāpuṇi. Yathā🔽so, evaṃ suparisuddhaṃ vīmaṃsaṃ nissāya vīmaṃsadhurena lokuttaradhammanibbattako
analyzed: tādisassa dentaḥ mayham dassati iti jāti sampattim eva nissāya ṭhāna antaram pāpuṇi yathā  saḥ evam su parisuddham vīmaṃsam nissāya vīmaṃsa dhurena lokuttara dhamma nibbattakaḥ
translated: If he gives to such a one as me, he will give to me,” obtained a position by means of his well-born family. As

original: veditabboti. Imasmiṃ sutte vivaṭṭapādakaiddhi kathitā.🔽4. Moggallānasuttavaṇṇanā🔽826. Catutthe uddhatāti uddhaccapakatikā vipphandamānacittā. Uddhaccena hi ekārammaṇe🔽cittaṃ vipphandati dhajayaṭṭhiyaṃ vātena pahatadhajo viya. Unnaḷāti uggatanaḷā, uṭṭhitatucchamānāti
analyzed: veditabbā iti imasmim sutte kathitā  moggallāna sutta vaṇṇanā  catutthe uddhatā ati uddhacca pakatikā vipphandamāna cittā uddhaccena hi eka ārammaṇe  cittam vipphandati dhaja yaṭṭhiyam vātena pahata dhajaḥ viya unnaḷāti uggata naḷā uṭṭhita tuccha mānā ati
translated: he did, so one who has produced the supramundane state by means of the burden of investigation should be known as one who has well-purified investigation. In this sutta the supernormal power of the preliminary-work-revolution is taught.🔽. Commentary

original: vuttaṃ hoti. Capalāti pattacīvaramaṇḍanādicāpallena yuttā. Mukharāti mukhakharā,
analyzed: vuttam hoti capalā ati patta cīvara maṇḍana ādi cāpallena yuttā mukharā ati mukha kharā
translated: In the fourth sutta, uddhatā means those who are of a nature to be excited, whose minds are restless. For by restlessness the mind is excited about a single object, like a flag beaten by the wind on a flag-staff. Unnaḷā means those who are high-strung, who are puffed up. Capalā means those who are occupied with restlessness in adorning their bowls, robes, etc. Mukharā means those who are garrulous,

original: kharavacanāti vuttaṃ hoti. Vikiṇṇavācāti asaṃyatavacanā divasampi niratthakavacanappalāpino.
analyzed: khara vacanā iti vuttam hoti vikiṇṇa vācā ati asaṃyata vacanāḥ divasam pi niratthaka vacana ppalāpinaḥ
translated: kharavacanā means those who are harsh-spoken. Vikiṇṇavācā means those who are unrestrained in speech, who prattle on all day long with meaningless talk.

original: Muṭṭhassatīti naṭṭhassatino. Asampajānāti paññārahitā. Asamāhitāti upacārappanāsamādhivirahitā.🔽Bhantacittāti ubbhantacittā samādhivirahena laddhokāsena uddhaccena. Pākatindriyāti🔽asaṃvutindriyā. Iddhābhisaṅkhāranti āpokasiṇaṃ samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya pāsādapatiṭṭhitaṃ
analyzed: muṭṭha ssatī iti naṭṭha ssatinaḥ asampajānāti paññā rahitā asamāhitā ati upacāra ppanā samādhi virahitā  bhanta cittā ati ubbhanta cittā samādhi virahena laddha ukāsena uddhaccena pākatindriyā ati  a saṃvut indriyāḥ āpokasiṇam samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya pāsāda patiṭṭhitam
translated: “Unmindful” means devoid of mindfulness. “Unaware” means devoid of understanding. “Unconcentrated” means devoid of access concentration and absorption concentration.🔽“With their minds distracted” means with their minds distracted by agitation, which has obtained an opportunity owing to the absence of concentration. “With faculties uncontrolled” means with uncontrolled faculties.

original: pathavibhāgaṃ “udaka”nti adhiṭṭhāya, udakapiṭṭhe ṭhitapāsādaṃ vehāsaṃ abbhuggantvā🔽aṅguṭṭhakena pahari. Gambhīranemoti gambhīraāvāṭo, gambhīrabhūmibhāgaṃ anupaviṭṭhoti
analyzed: pathavi bhāgam udakam ti adhiṭṭhāya udaka piṭṭhe ṭhita pāsādam vehāsam abbhut gantvā  aṅguṭṭhakena gambhīra nemaḥ iti gambhīra āvāṭaḥ gambhīra bhūmi bhāgam anupaviṭṭhaḥ uti
translated: “By the power of his psychic potency” : having attained the water kasiṇa jhāna, he emerged and resolved that the section of the earth on which the palace stood was water. Then, standing on the water, he rose up into the air above the palace,

original: attho. Sunikhātoti suṭṭhu nikhāto, koṭṭetvā suṭṭhu ṭhapito. Idha abhiññāpādakiddhi kathitā.
analyzed: attho su nikhātoti suṭṭhu nikhāto koṭṭetvā suṭṭhu ṭhapito idha abhiññā pādakiddhi kathitā
translated: and struck it with his thumb. “Deep and wide” means deep and large; the meaning is, it was situated on a deep piece of ground. “Well dug in” means well dug in, well planted by digging it in. Here the psychic potency that is the basis for direct knowledge is mentioned.

original: 5. Uṇṇābhabrāhmaṇasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: uṇṇābha brāhmaṇa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the fifth sutta in the Chapter on the Brahmins is finished.

original: 827. Pañcame chandappahānatthanti taṇhāchandassa pahānatthaṃ. Idhāpi vivaṭṭapādakiddhi kathitā.🔽9. Iddhādidesanāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pañcame chanda ppahāna attham ti taṇhā chandassa pahāna attham idha api kathitā 🔽iddha ādi desanā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: In the fifth , “for the abandoning of desire” : for the abandoning of craving and desire. Here too the psychic potency that is the basis for turning away is mentioned.🔽The commentary on the sutta in the Chapter on the Teaching of Psychic Potency, etc. is finished.

original: 831. Navame yo so bhikkhave maggoti abhiññāpādakaṃ catutthajjhānaṃ adhippetaṃ.
analyzed: navame yaḥ saḥ bhikkhave maggo ti abhiññā pādakam catuttha jjhānam adhippetam
translated: “The path” in the ninth case is the fourth jhāna that surmounts direct-knowledge.

original: 10. Vibhaṅgasuttavaṇṇanā🔽832. Dasame kosajjasahagatoti idha bhikkhu chandaṃ uppādetvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikaronto🔽nisīdati. Athassa citte līnākāro okkamati, so “līnākāro me okkanto”ti ñatvā apāyabhayena🔽cittaṃ tajjetvā puna chandaṃ uppādetvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasi karoti. Athassa puna līnākāro🔽okkamati. So puna apāyabhayena cittaṃ tajjetvā chandaṃ uppādetvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasi
analyzed: vibhaṅga sutta vaṇṇanā  dasame kosajja sahagataḥ ti idha bhikkhu chandam uppādetvā kammaṭṭhānam manasikaronto  nisīdati athassa citte līna ākāraḥ okkamati saḥ līna ākāraḥ me okkantaḥ iti ñatvā apāya bhayena  cittam tajjetvā puna chandam uppādetvā kammaṭṭhānam manasi karoti atha assa puna līna ākāraḥ  okkamati saḥ puna apāya bhayena cittam tajjetvā chandam uppādetvā kammaṭṭhānam manasi
translated: The commentary on the Vibhaṅga Sutta is ended.

original: karotīti evamassa kosajjena vokiṇṇattā chando kosajjasahagato nāma hoti. Kosajjasampayuttoti tasseva vevacanaṃ.
analyzed: karoti iti evam assa kosajjena vokiṇṇattā chandaḥ kosajja sahagataḥ nāma hoti kosajja sampayuttaḥ ti tassa iva vevacanam
translated: In the tenth case, “accompanied by stiffness and torpor”: here a bhikkhu sits down to give attention to a meditation subject after arousing zeal. Then a slackened state of consciousness arises in him. He understands “A slackened state has arisen in me,” and he rouses his mind with the danger of the states of loss. Then he gives attention to the meditation subject again. Then the slackened state arises again. He rouses his mind again with the danger of the states of loss and gives attention to the meditation subject again. So his zeal is called “accompanied by stiffness and torpor” because it is interrupted by stiffness and torpor. “Associated with stiffness and torpor” is a synonym for that same zeal.

original: Uddhaccasahagatoti idha bhikkhu chandaṃ uppādetvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikaronto nisīdati.
analyzed: uddhacca sahagataḥ ti idha bhikkhu chandam uppādetvā kammaṭṭhānam manasikarontaḥ nisīdati
translated: “Accompanied by agitation”: here a bhikkhu sits down to give attention to a meditation subject after arousing zeal.

original: Athassa cittaṃ uddhacce patati. So buddhadhammasaṅghaguṇe āvajjetvā cittaṃ hāsetvā
analyzed: atha assa cittam uddhacce patati saḥ buddha dhamma saṅgha guṇe āvajjetvā cittam hāsetvā
translated: His mind falls a prey to agitation. He should arouse confidence by recollecting the special qualities of the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha, and he should gladden his mind.

original: tosetvā kammaniyaṃ katvā puna chandaṃ uppādetvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasi karoti. Athassa🔽puna cittaṃ uddhacce patati. So puna buddhadhammasaṅghaguṇe āvajjetvā cittaṃ hāsetvā
analyzed: tosetvā kammaniyam katvā puna chandam uppādetvā kammaṭṭhānam manasi karoti athassa  puna cittam uddhacce patati saḥ puna buddha dhamma saṅgha guṇe āvajjetvā cittam hāsetvā
translated: Then he should arouse zeal, and he should give attention to his meditation subject.🔽If his mind again falls a prey to agitation, he should again arouse confidence by recollecting the special qualities of the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Sangha, and he should gladden his mind.

original: tosetvā kammaniyaṃ katvā chandaṃ uppādetvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasi karotīti evamassa
analyzed: tosetvā kammaniyam katvā chandam uppādetvā kammaṭṭhānam manasi karoti iti evam assa
translated: Then he should arouse zeal, and he should give attention to his meditation subject.

original: uddhaccena vokiṇṇattā chando uddhaccasahagato nāma hoti.
analyzed: uddhaccena vokiṇṇattā chandaḥ uddhaccasahagataḥ nāma hoti
translated: So his zeal is accompanied by agitation because it is interrupted by agitation.

original: Thinamiddhasahagatoti idha bhikkhu chandaṃ uppādetvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikaronto nisīdati.
analyzed: thinamiddha sahagataḥ ti idha bhikkhu chandam uppādetvā kammaṭṭhānam manasikarontaḥ nisīdati
translated: Accompanied by stiffness and torpor: here a bhikkhu sits down to give attention to his meditation subject after arousing zeal.

original: Athassa thinamiddhaṃ uppajjati. So “uppannaṃ me thinamiddha”nti ñatvā udakena mukhaṃ
analyzed: athassa thinamiddham uppajjati saḥ uppannam me thinamiddham ti ñatvā udakena mukham
translated: Then stiffness and torpor arise in him. He should know, “Stiffness and torpor have arisen in me.” He should wash his face and eyes with water,

original: puñchitvā, kaṇṇe ākaḍḍhitvā paguṇaṃ dhammaṃ sajjhāyitvā divā gahitaṃ vā ālokasaññaṃ
analyzed: puñchitvā kaṇṇe ākaḍḍhitvā paguṇam dhammam sajjhāyitvā divā gahitam vā āloka saññam
translated: rub his limbs with his hands, look around in all directions, and recollect the vision of the deities.

original: manasikaritvā thinamiddhaṃ vinodetvā puna chandaṃ uppādetvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasi karoti.🔽Athassa puna thinamiddhaṃ uppajjati. So vuttanayeneva puna thinamiddhaṃ vinodetvā
analyzed: manasikaritvā thinam iddham vinodetvā puna chandam uppādetvā kammaṭṭhānam manasi karoti  athassa puna thinamiddham uppajjati so vutta nayena iva puna thinamiddham vinodetvā
translated: and he should then arouse zeal and give attention to the meditation subject.🔽If drowsiness and sleepiness arise again, he should dispel them in the way already described and

original: chandaṃ uppādetvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasi karotīti evamassa thinamiddhena vokiṇṇattā🔽chando thinamiddhasahagato nāma hoti.
analyzed: chandam uppādetvā kammaṭṭhānam manasi karoti iti evam assa thinam iddhena vokiṇṇattā  chandaḥ thinamiddhasahagataḥ nāma hoti
translated: then arouse zeal and give attention to the meditation subject. So his zeal is accompanied by drowsiness and sleepiness because it is interrupted by drowsiness and sleepiness.

original: Anuvikkhittoti idha bhikkhu chandaṃ uppādetvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasikaronto nisīdati.
analyzed: anuvikkhittaḥ ti idha bhikkhu chandam uppādetvā kammaṭṭhānam manasikarontaḥ nisīdati
translated: “Distracted” : here a bhikkhu sits down to give attention to a meditation subject after arousing zeal.

original: Athassa kāmaguṇārammaṇe cittaṃ vikkhipati. So “bahiddhā vikkhittaṃ me citta”nti ñatvā🔽anamatagga devadūta- celopama anāgatabhayasuttādīni āvajjento suttadaṇḍena cittaṃ
analyzed: athassa kāma guṇa ārammaṇe cittam vikkhipati saḥ bahiddhā vikkhittam me cittam ti ñatvā  deva dūta cela upama anāgata bhaya sutta ādīni āvajjentaḥ sutta daṇḍena cittam
translated: Then his mind is distracted by the five cords of sense desire. He notices that his mind is distracted externally,

original: tajjetvā kammaniyaṃ katvā puna chandaṃ uppādetvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasi karoti. Athassa
analyzed: tat jetvā kammaniyam katvā puna chandam uppādetvā kammaṭṭhānam manasi karoti athassa
translated: and he rouses it by reviewing such suttas as those dealing with the beginningless round of rebirths, the divine messengers, the corpse simile, and the future peril. He then makes the mind steady, composed, and unified, and he gives attention to the meditation subject again. If

original: puna cittaṃ vikkhipati. So puna suttadaṇḍena cittaṃ kammaniyaṃ katvā chandaṃ uppādetvā
analyzed: puna cittam vikkhipati saḥ puna sutta daṇḍena cittam kammaniyam katvā chandam uppādetvā
translated: He then directs his mind again. Having made his mind workable with the stick of the Dhamma, he arouses zeal,

original: kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasi karotīti evamassa kāmavitakkavokiṇṇattā chando bahiddhā pañca
analyzed: kammaṭṭhānam manasi karoti iti evam assa kāma vitakka vokiṇṇattā chandaḥ bahiddhā pañca
translated: and he gives attention to the meditation subject. Thus his zeal is scattered externally, dissipated externally, in the five cords of sense desire,

original: kāmaguṇe ārabbha anuvikkhitto anuvisaṭo hoti.
analyzed: kāma guṇe ārabbha anuvikkhittaḥ anuvisaṭaḥ hoti
translated: because it is invaded by sensual resolution.

original: Yathā pure tathā pacchāti kammaṭṭhānavasenapi desanāvasenapi purimapacchimatā veditabbā.
analyzed: yathā pure tathā pacchā ati kammaṭṭhāna vasena api desanā vasena api purima pacchima tā veditabbā
translated: As before, so later: the sequence should be understood in the way already stated under the meditation subject and the teaching.

original: Kathaṃ? Kammaṭṭhāne tāva kammaṭṭhānassa abhiniveso pure nāma, arahattaṃ pacchā nāma.🔽Tattha yo bhikkhu mūlakammaṭṭhāne abhinivisitvā atilīnādīsu catūsu ṭhānesu cittassa
analyzed: katham kammaṭṭhāne tāva kammaṭṭhānassa abhiniveso pure nāma arahattam pacchā nāma  tattha yaḥ bhikkhu mūlakammaṭṭhāne abhinivisitvā atilīna ādīsu catūsu ṭhānesu cittassa
translated: How so? In the case of the meditation subject, the prior stage is called the stage of devotion to the meditation subject, and the later stage is called Arahantship.🔽Herein, a bhikkhu who is devoted to the meditation subject and who prevents his mind from descending into the four states beginning with “too slack”

original: okkamanaṃ paṭisedhetvā, duṭṭhagoṇe yojetvā sārento viya caturassaghaṭikaṃ otārento
analyzed: okkamanam paṭisedhetvā duṭṭha goṇe yojetvā sārentaḥ viya catur assa ghaṭikam otārentaḥ
translated: and who, like a driver of a chariot who holds the reins tight and drives on without wavering,

original: viya catunnaṃ ṭhānānaṃ ekaṭṭhānepi asajjanto saṅkhāre sammasitvā arahattaṃ pāpuṇāti.
analyzed: catunnam ṭhānānam eka ṭṭhāne pi a sajjanto saṅkhāre sammasitvā arahattam pāpuṇāti
translated: without wavering from the four states, reaches Arahantship by comprehending formations.

original: Ayampi yathā pure tathā pacchā viharati nāma. Ayaṃ kammaṭṭhānavasena purimapacchimatā.🔽Desanāvasena pana kesā pure nāma, matthaluṅgaṃ pacchā nāma. Tattha yo bhikkhu kesesu
analyzed: ayam pi yathā pure tathā pacchā viharati nāma ayam kammaṭṭhāna vasena purima pacchima tā  desanā vasena pana kesā pure nāma matthaluṅgam pacchā nāma tattha yaḥ bhikkhu kesesu
translated: This is called “he abides in the later way as in the earlier” in the sense of the meditation subject.

original: abhinivisitvā vaṇṇasaṇṭhānādivasena kesādayo pariggaṇhanto catūsu ṭhānesu asajjanto🔽yāva matthaluṅgā bhāvanaṃ pāpeti, ayampi yathā pure tathā pacchā viharati nāma. Evaṃ
analyzed: abhinivisitvā vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna ādi vasena kesa ādayo pariggaṇhantaḥ catūsu ṭhānesu a sajjantaḥ  yāva matthaluṅgā bhāvanam pāpā iti ayam pi yathā pure tathā pacchā viharati nāma evam
translated: In the sense of teaching, the head hairs are called “earlier” and the brain is called “later.” Herein, a bhikkhu who, after discerning head hairs, etc., in the way described, does not hurry the development of the meditation subject by passing on from head hairs to body hairs, etc., but develops it only in head hairs,🔽without skipping any part, right up to the brain, is called “one who abides in the later way as in the earlier.” This is how the “later” and the “earlier” should be understood here in the sense of teaching.

original: desanāvasena purimapacchimatā veditabbā. Yathā pacchā tathā pureti idaṃ purimasseva vevacanaṃ.
analyzed: desanā vasena purima pacchima tā veditabbā yathā pacchā tathā purā iti idam purimassa iva vevacanam
translated: The phrase “in the earlier way as in the later” is a synonym for the phrase “in the later way as in the earlier.”

original: Yathā adho tathā uddhanti idaṃ sarīravasena veditabbaṃ. Tenevāha “uddhaṃ pādatalā
analyzed: yathā adhas tathā uddhan ti idam sarīra vasena veditabbam tena iva āha uddham pāda talā
translated: The phrase “in the upper way as in the lower” should be understood in the sense of the body. Hence it is said: “In the upper way from the soles of the feet,

original: adho kesamatthakā”ti. Tattha yo bhikkhu pādatalato paṭṭhāya yāva kesamatthakā dvattiṃsākāravasena
analyzed: adho kesamatthakā ti tattha yaḥ bhikkhu pāda talataḥ paṭṭhāya yāva kesamatthakā dvattiṃsa ākāra vasena
translated: in the lower way from the top of the hair of the head” . Herein, a bhikkhu who, after discerning the thirty-two parts in the way described, beginning with the soles of the feet and ending with the top of the head,

original: vā pādaṅguliaggapabbaṭṭhito yāva sīsakaṭāhaṃ, sīsakaṭāhato yāva pādaṅgulīnaṃ aggapabbaṭṭhīni,🔽tāva aṭṭhivasena vā bhāvanaṃ pāpeti catūsu ṭhānesu ekaṭṭhānepi asajjanto. Ayaṃ yathā
analyzed: vā pādaṅguli agga pabbaṭṭhitaḥ yāva sīsa kaṭāham sīsa kaṭāhataḥ yāva pādaṅgulīnam agga pabbaṭṭhīni  vā bhāvanam pāpa iti catūsu ṭhānesu eka ṭṭhāne pi a sajjantaḥ ayam yathā
translated: and from the top of the head to the top of the big toe, and from the top of the big toe to the top of the head,

original: uddhaṃ tathā adho, yathā adho tathā uddhaṃ viharati nāma.
analyzed: uddham tathā adhas yathā adhas tathā uddham viharati nāma
translated: he develops the meditation subject by means of the bones, without miscasting his thought on any particular place among the four. This is how he “lives contemplating the body as a body internally.”🔽How does he live contemplating the body as a body externally?🔽How does he live contemplating the body as a body both internally and externally?

original: Yehi ākārehīti yehi koṭṭhāsehi. Yehi liṅgehīti yehi saṇṭhānehi. Yehi nimittehīti
analyzed: yehi ākārehi iti yehi koṭṭhāsehi yehi liṅgehi iti yehi saṇṭhānehi yehi nimittehi iti
translated: How does he live contemplating origination factors in the body?

original: yehi upaṭṭhānehi. Ālokasaññā suggahitā hotīti yo bhikkhu aṅgaṇe nisīditvā ālokasaññaṃ
analyzed: yehi upaṭṭhānehi āloka saññā su ggahitā hoti iti yaḥ bhikkhu aṅgaṇe nisīditvā āloka saññam
translated: How does he live contemplating dissolution factors in the body?🔽How does he live contemplating origination and dissolution factors in the body?

original: manasi karoti, kālena nimīleti, kālena ummīleti. Athassa yadā nimīlentassāpi ummīletvā🔽olokentassa viya ekasadisameva upaṭṭhāti, tadā ālokasaññā jātā nāma hoti. “Divāsaññā”tipi🔽tasseva nāmaṃ. Sā ca pana rattiṃ uppajjamānā suggahitā nāma hoti. Svādhiṭṭhitātipi
analyzed: manasi karoti kālena nimīleti kālena ummīleti athassa yadā nimīlentassa api ummīletvā 🔽olokentassa viya eka sadisam eva upaṭṭhāti tadā āloka saññā jātā nāma hoti divāsaññā atipi 🔽tassa iva nāmam sā ca pana rattim uppajjamānā suggahitā nāma hoti svādhiṭṭhitā atipi
translated: How does he “contemplate the body as a body”?

original: tasseva vevacanaṃ. Suṭṭhu adhiṭṭhitā suṭṭhu ṭhapitā svādhiṭṭhitā nāma vuccati. Sā
analyzed: tassa iva vevacanam suṭṭhu adhiṭṭhitā suṭṭhu ṭhapitā svādhiṭṭhitā nāma vuccati sā
translated: and that is a synonym for “well-directed.” It is called “well-directed” because it is well-established.

original: atthato suggahitāyeva. Yo vā ālokena thinamiddhaṃ vinodetvā chandaṃ uppādetvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: atthataḥ suggahitāya iva yaḥ vā ālokena thinam iddham vinodetvā chandam uppādetvā kammaṭṭhānam
translated: Or when someone dispels stiffness and torpor by means of light and arouses desire to act, and then gives attention to the meditation subject,🔽then even by day his perception of light is called “well-directed” and “well-established.”

original: manasi karoti, tassa divāpi ālokasaññā suggahitā svādhiṭṭhitā nāma. Ratti vā hotu
analyzed: manasi karoti tassa divā api āloka saññā su gahitā svādhiṭṭhitā nāma ratti vā hotu
translated: Whether it is night or day,

original: divā vā yena ālokena thinamiddhaṃ vinodetvā kammaṭṭhānaṃ manasi karoti, tasmiṃ thinamiddhavinodane
analyzed: divā vā yena ālokena thinam iddham vinodetvā kammaṭṭhānam manasi karoti tasmim thinamiddha vinodane
translated: when he dispels stiffness and torpor by means of light and gives attention to the meditation subject,

original: āloke uppannā saññā suggahitāyeva nāma. Vīriyādīsupi eseva nayo. Imasmiṃ sutte channaṃ
analyzed: āloke uppannā saññā nāma vīriya ādīsu pi esa iva nayaḥ imasmin sutte channam
translated: then the perception that has arisen in that light that dispels stiffness and torpor is called “well-directed.” The same method applies in the case of energy, etc.

original: abhiññānaṃ pādakiddhi kathitā.
analyzed: abhiññānam kathitā
translated: In this sutta the preliminary-work concentration for the six kinds of direct-knowledge is taught.

original: Pāsādakampanavaggo dutiyo.🔽3. Ayoguḷavaggo
analyzed: pāsādakampana vaggaḥ dutiyaḥ  ayaḥ guḷa vaggo
translated: The second chapter called “The Chapter about the Palace” is finished.🔽The Chapter about the Iron Ball

original: 2. Ayoguḷasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ayoguḷa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Iron Ball Sutta

original: 834. Tatiyavaggassa dutiye iminā cātumahābhūtikenāti iminā catumahābhūtamayena evaṃ🔽bhārikena garukena samānenāpi. Omātīti pahoti sakkoti, idaṃ tepiṭake buddhavacane
analyzed: tatiya vaggassa dutiye iminā cātumahābhūtikena ati iminā catu mahābhūta mayena evam 🔽bhārikena garukena samānena api idam tepiṭake buddha vacane
translated: In the second of the third chapter, “With this four-element mass” : with this four-element-derived mass, which is so heavy and so ponderous,🔽“I can” : I am able, in the Buddha’s word in the three Piṭakas,

original: asambhinnapadaṃ. Kāyampi citte samodahatīti kāyaṃ gahetvā citte āropeti, cittasannissitaṃ
analyzed: asambhinna padam kāyam pi citte samodahati iti kāyam gahetvā citte āropeti citta sannissitam
translated: and the words are not mixed up. ‘He directs his mind’: he makes the body dependent on the mind, he makes the mind the dominant factor.

original: karoti, cittagatiyā peseti. Cittaṃ nāma mahaggatacittaṃ, cittagatigamanaṃ lahukaṃ
analyzed: karoti citta gatiyā peseti cittam nāma mahaggata cittam citta gati gamanam lahukam
translated: ‘The mind is light in its movement’: the mind is the exalted consciousness; its movement is light.

original: hoti. Cittampi kāye samodahatīti cittaṃ gahetvā kāye āropeti, kāyasannissitaṃ karoti,
analyzed: hoti cittam pi kāye samodahati iti cittam gahetvā kāye āropeti kāya sannissitam karoti
translated: ‘He directs his mind’: he makes the mind dependent on the body, he makes the body the dominant factor.

original: kāyagatiyā peseti, kāyo nāma karajakāyo, kāyagatigamanaṃ dandhaṃ hoti. Sukhasaññañca🔽lahusaññañcāti abhiññācittasahajātasaññā. Sā hi santasukhasamannāgatattā sukhasaññā
analyzed: kāya gatiyā peseti kāyaḥ nāma karaja kāyaḥ kāya gati gamanam dandham hoti sukha saññam ca  lahu saññam ca ati abhiññā citta sahajāta saññā sā hi santa sukha samannāgata ttā sukha saññā
translated: ‘The body is slow in its movement’: the body is the physical body; its movement is slow.🔽‘Pleasant feeling and light feeling’: the feeling that arises together with the consciousness of the higher faculties is called ‘pleasant feeling’

original: nāma hoti, kilesadandhāyitattassa ca abhāvā lahusaññā nāma.🔽Ayoguḷo divasaṃ santatto lahutaro ceva hotīti so hi dvīhi tīhi janehi ukkhipitvā
analyzed: nāma hoti kilesa dandhāyi tattassa ca abhāvā lahu saññā nāma  ayaḥ guḷaḥ divasam santattaḥ lahutaraḥ ca iva hoti iti saḥ hi dvīhi tīhi janehi ukkhipitvā
translated: because it is associated with the bliss of peace, and it is called ‘light feeling’ because there is no heaviness due to defilements.🔽‘A red-hot iron ball is light and easy to handle’: for it is light and easy to handle when it is red-hot and has been heated by two or three people,

original: kammāruddhane pakkhittopi divasaṃ paccamāno vivarānupaviṭṭhena tejena ceva vāyena
analyzed: pakkhittaḥ api divasam paccamānaḥ vivara an upaviṭṭhena tejena ca iva vāyena
translated: and is put into the smith’s furnace, being heated by the fire that penetrates all round it.

original: ca vāyosahagato ca usmāsahagato ca tejosahagato ca hutvā evaṃ lahuko hoti, yathā
analyzed: ca vāyo sahagataḥ ca usmā sahagataḥ ca tejaḥ sahagataḥ ca hutvā evam lahukaḥ hoti yathā
translated: and it is light in that it is accompanied by air, heat, and fire,

original: naṃ kammāro mahāsaṇḍāsena gahetvā ekato parivatteti ukkhipati bahi nīharati. Evaṃ
analyzed: nam kammāraḥ mahā saṇḍāsena gahetvā ekatas ukkhipati bahi nīharati evam
translated: so that the smith can take it in a pair of tongs, turn it, lift it up, and carry it outside.

original: pana mudu ca hoti kammaniyo ca. Yathā naṃ so khaṇḍaṃ khaṇḍaṃ vicchindati, kūṭena
analyzed: pana mudu ca hoti kammaniyo ca yathā naṃ saḥ khaṇḍam khaṇḍam vicchindati kūṭena
translated: And it is pliable and wieldy in that he can cut it up into pieces,🔽and by striking it with a hammer he can make it into long, square, and other shapes.

original: hananto dīghacaturassādibhedaṃ karoti. Imasmiṃ sutte vikubbaniddhi kathitā.
analyzed: ha na antaḥ dīgha caturassa ādi bhedam karoti imasmin sutte kathitā
translated: In this sutta the supernormal power of transformation is taught.

original: 3-10. Bhikkhusuttādivaṇṇanā🔽835-842. Tatiye vivaṭṭapādakiddhi kathitā, tathā catutthe. Apica dve phalāni ādiṃ
analyzed: bhikkhu sutta ādi vaṇṇanā  tatiye kathitā tathā catutthe api ca dve
translated: The commentary on the Bhikkhu Sutta, etc.🔽In the third sutta the supernormal power of the footing of turning away is taught, and in the fourth too. Moreover, the mixed footing of supernormal power is taught below, beginning with the two fruits,

original: katvā heṭṭhā missakiddhipādā kathitā, sattasu phalesu pubbabhāgā. Sattamādīni cattāri
analyzed: katvā heṭṭhā missaka iddhipādā kathitā sattasu phalesu pubba bhāgā sattama ādīni cattāri
translated: and the prior stages in the seven fruits. The seventh, etc., four

original: heṭṭhā kathitanayāneva.
analyzed: heṭṭhā kathita nayānā iva
translated: are in the same way as the teaching below.

original: 11-12. Moggallānasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The commentary on the Moggallāna Sutta, etc.

original: 843-844. Ekādasamadvādasamesu cha abhiññā kathitā. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
analyzed: ekādasama dvādasamesu cha abhiññā kathitā sesam sabbattha uttāna attham eva ati
translated: In the eleventh and twelfth suttas the six kinds of direct knowledge are taught. The rest is all obvious in meaning.

original: Iddhipādasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: iddhipāda saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The commentary on the Supernormal Power (of Transformation) Samyutta is finished.

original: 8. Anuruddhasaṃyuttaṃ
analyzed: anuruddha saṃyuttam
translated: The Connected Discourses with Anuruddha

original: 1. Rahogatavaggo🔽1-2. Paṭhamarahogatasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: rahas gata vaggo  paṭhama rahogata sutta ādi vaṇṇanā
translated: 1. The Section on Seclusion🔽The First Section on Seclusion

original: 899-900. Anuruddhasaṃyuttassa paṭhame āraddhāti paripuṇṇā. Saṅkhepato panettha chattiṃsāya
analyzed: anuruddha saṃyuttassa paṭhame āraddhā ati paripuṇṇā saṅkhepato pana ittha chattiṃsāya
translated: In the first sutta of the Anuruddha Samyutta, “he had just begun” means he had just finished.

original: ṭhānesu arahattaṃ pāpetvā vipassanā kathitā, dutiye dvādasasu ṭhānesu arahattaṃ pāpetvā vipassanā kathitā.
analyzed: ṭhānesu arahattam pāpetvā vipassanā kathitā dutiye dvādasasu ṭhānesu arahattam pāpetvā vipassanā kathitā
translated: In brief, in thirty-six places in this sutta insight is taught after the attainment of arahatship. In the second sutta, insight is taught after the attainment of arahatship in twelve places.

original: 3. Sutanusuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sutanu sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Sutta on Sutanu🔽In the third sutta, “great direct knowledge” means the state of the six kinds of direct knowledge.

original: 901. Tatiye mahābhiññatanti chaabhiññābhāvaṃ. Hīnaṃ dhammantiādīsu imāya pāḷiyā attho veditabbo –
analyzed: tatiye mahā abhiññatanti cha abhiññā bhāvam hīnam dhammam ti ādīsu imāya pāḷiyā atthaḥ veditabbaḥ
translated: In the passage beginning “inferior states,” the meaning should be understood in accordance with the following passage:

original: “Katame dhammā hīnā? Dvādasa akusalacittuppādā, ime dhammā hīnā. Katame dhammā majjhimā?
analyzed: katame dhammā hīnā dvādasa akusala cittuppādāḥ ime dhammā hīnā katame dhammā majjhimā
translated: “What are the inferior states? The twelve kinds of unprofitable consciousness. These are the inferior states. What are the middling states?

original: Tīsu bhūmīsu kusalaṃ, tīsu bhūmīsu vipāko, tīsu bhūmīsu kiriyābyākataṃ sabbañca rūpaṃ,🔽ime dhammā majjhimā. Katame dhammā paṇītā? Cattāro maggā apariyāpannā, cattāri ca
analyzed: tīsu bhūmīsu kusalam tīsu bhūmīsu vipākaḥ tīsu bhūmīsu kiriyā abyākatam sabbam ca rūpam  ime dhammā majjhimā katame dhammā paṇītā cattāro maggāḥ apariyāpannā cattāri ca
translated: The profitable in the three planes, the result in the three planes, the inoperative indeterminate in the three planes, and all materiality.

original: sāmaññaphalāni nibbānañca, ime dhammā paṇītā”ti.
analyzed: sāmañña phalāni nibbānam ca ime dhammā paṇītā ati
translated: These are the middling states. What are the superior states? The four paths, the four fruitions, and Nibbāna. These are the superior states.”

original: 4-7. Paṭhamakaṇḍakīsuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The First Sutta on Kaṇḍaka and the rest

original: 902-905. Catutthe kaṇḍakīvaneti mahākaramandavane. Chaṭṭhe sahassaṃ lokanti iminā
analyzed: catutthe kaṇḍakī vana iti mahā karamanda vane chaṭṭhe sahassam iminā
translated: In the fourth, in the Kaṇḍaka Wood, in the Great Karamanda Wood. In the sixth, a thousand worlds:

original: therassa satata vihāro dassito. Thero hi pātova mukhaṃ dhovitvā atītānāgate kappasahassaṃ
analyzed: therassa vihāro dassito theraḥ hi mukham dhovitvā atīta anāgate kappa sahassam
translated: by this the Elder’s constant abiding is shown. For the Elder, after washing his face in the morning, recollects a thousand world-systems in the past and future,

original: anussarati. Paccuppanne pana dasacakkavāḷasahassaṃ ekāvajjanassa āpāthamāgacchati.
analyzed: anussarati paccuppanne pana dasa cakkavāḷa sahassam ekāvajjanassa āpātham āgacchati
translated: but in the present a thousand great world-systems come within the range of a single adverting.

original: Sattamaṃ uttānameva.
analyzed: sattamam uttānam eva
translated: The seventh sutta is self-evident.

original: 8. Salaḷāgārasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: salaḷāgāra sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Discussion of the Sutta on the Sala-tree House

original: 906. Aṭṭhame salaḷāgāreti salaḷarukkhamayāya paṇṇasālāya, salaḷarukkhassa vā dvāre ṭhitattā evaṃnāmake agāre. Imasmiṃ sutte vipassanāya saddhiṃ vipassakapuggalo kathito.
analyzed: aṭṭhame salaḷa āgāre iti salaḷa rukkha mayāya paṇṇa sālāya salaḷa rukkhassa vā dvāre ṭhita ttā evaṃnāmake agāre imasmin sutte vipassanāya saddhim vipassaka puggalo kathito
translated: In the eighth, in the Sala-tree House: in a leaf house made of Sala-tree leaves, or in a house called “Sala-tree House” because it stands at the door of a Sala-tree. In this sutta the person who has insight is mentioned together with insight.

original: 9. Ambapālivanasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Discussion of the Sutta on the Mango Grove

original: 907. Navame āsabhiṃ vācanti attano arahattabhāvadīpakaṃ uttamavācaṃ. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.
analyzed: navame āsabhim vācanti attanaḥ arahatta bhāva dīpakam uttama vācam sesam sabbattha uttāna attham eva ati
translated: In the ninth, they utter the supreme utterance that reveals their own state of arahantship. The rest is self-evident in all cases.

original: Rahogatavaggo paṭhamo.
analyzed: rahogata vaggo paṭhamo
translated: The first vagga is finished.

original: 2. Dutiyavaggavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya vagga vaṇṇanā
translated: The Discussion of the Second Vagga

original: 909-922. Dutiyavagge ṭhānañca ṭhānatotiādīhi thero dasabalañāṇaṃ paṭijānāti. Kimpanetaṃ sāvakānaṃ hotīti? Ekadesena hoti, sabbaññubuddhānaṃ panetaṃ nippadesaṃ sabbākāraparipūranti.
analyzed: dutiya vagge ṭhānam ca ṭhānataḥ ti ādīhi theraḥ dasa bala ñāṇam paṭijānāti kim pana etat sāvakānam hoti iti ekadesena hoti sabbaññu buddhānam pana etam nippadesam sabba ākāra paripūranti
