translated: In the second sub-chapter, the Elder declares his knowledge of the ten powers of a Buddha with the words “The place and the non-place he knows as they really are” , etc. But what is this to the disciples? It is only a fraction of it, for the knowledge of the Omniscient Ones is complete in all its aspects.

original: Anuruddhasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽9. Jhānasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: anuruddha saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the Anuruddha Samyutta is completed.

original: 923. Jhānasaṃyuttaṃ uttānatthameva.
analyzed: jhāna saṃyuttam uttāna attham eva
translated: The Jhāna Samyutta is straightforward in meaning.

original: Jhānasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: jhāna saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The exposition of the Jhāna Samyutta is completed.

original: 10. Ānāpānasaṃyuttaṃ🔽1. Ekadhammavaggo
analyzed: āna apāna saṃyuttam  eka dhamma vaggaḥ
translated: The Ānāpānasamyutta🔽The Ekadhamma Vagga

original: 1. Ekadhammasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ekadhamma sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Ekadhamma Sutta

original: 977. Ānāpānasaṃyuttassa paṭhame ekadhammoti eko dhammo. Sesamettha yaṃ vattabbaṃ siyā, taṃ sabbaṃ sabbākārena visuddhimagge ānāpānassatikammaṭṭhānaniddese vuttameva.
analyzed: āna apāna saṃyuttassa paṭhame eka dhammo ti ekaḥ dhammo sesam ettha yat vattabbam siyā tat sabbam sabba ākārena visuddhi magge āna apāna ssati kammaṭṭhāna niddese vuttam eva
translated: In the first sutta in the Ānāpānasamyutta, the “one idea” is the one idea. What else is to be said here has all been said in the Visuddhimagga in the Description of Mindfulness Occupied with the Body .

original: 6. Ariṭṭhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: ariṭṭha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Ariṭṭha Sutta

original: 982. Chaṭṭhe bhāvetha noti bhāvetha nu. Kāmacchandoti pañcakāmaguṇikarāgo. Ajjhattaṃ
analyzed: chaṭṭhe bhāvetha no ti bhāvetha nu kāmacchandaḥ ti pañca kāmaguṇika rāgaḥ ajjhattam
translated: In the sixth , “develop” is the same as “develop or not?” “Sensual desire” is lust for the five strands of sense pleasure.

original: bahiddhā ca dhammesūti ajjhattikabāhiresu dvādasasu āyatanadhammesu. Paṭighasaññā
analyzed: bahiddhā ca dhammesu ti ajjhattika bāhiresu dvādasasu āyatana dhammesu paṭigha saññā
translated: And in external ideas : in the twelve internal and external bases as ideas.

original: suppaṭivinītāti paṭighasampayuttasaññā suṭṭhu paṭivinītā, samucchinnāti attho. Iminā🔽attano anāgāmimaggaṃ katheti. Idāni arahattamaggassa vipassanaṃ dassento so satova
analyzed: suppaṭivinītā ati paṭigha sampayutta saññā suṭṭhu paṭivinītā samucchinnā ti atthaḥ iminā  attanaḥ anāgāmi maggam katheti idāni arahatta maggassa vipassanam dassento so satas va
translated: He has well suppressed perception of resistance : perception associated with resistance is well suppressed, the meaning is, well cut off.🔽By this he shows his own path of non-return.

original: assasissāmītiādimāha.
analyzed: assasissāmi itiādim āha
translated: Now, showing the insight of the path of Arahantship, he said, Mindfully I will breathe in, mindfully I will breathe out.

original: 7. Mahākappinasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Great Cock’s Foot Tree Discourse

original: 983. Sattame iñjitattaṃ vā phanditattaṃ vāti ubhayenapi calanameva kathitaṃ.
analyzed: sattame iñjitattam vā phanditattam vā ati ubhayena api calanam eva kathitam
translated: In the seventh, both by ‘trembling’ and by ‘quivering’ shaking is meant.

original: 8. Padīpopamasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: The Simile of the Lamp Discourse

original: 984. Aṭṭhame neva kāyopi kilamati na cakkhūnīti aññesu hi kammaṭṭhānesu kammaṃ karontassa
analyzed: aṭṭhame na iva kāyaḥ api kilamati na cakkhūni iti aññesu hi kammaṭṭhānesu kammam karontassa
translated: In the eighth, ‘his body does not ache and his eyes do not move’ . In other instances of meditation subjects, when he is doing the work of development,

original: kāyopi kilamati, cakkhūnipi vihaññanti. Dhātukammaṭṭhānasmiñhi kammaṃ karontassa
analyzed: kāyaḥ api kilamati cakkhūni api vihaññanti dhātu kammaṭṭhānasmin hi kammam karontassa
translated: his body aches and his eyes suffer. When he is doing the work of development on the meditation subject of elements,

original: kāyo kilamati, yante pakkhipitvā pīḷanākārappatto viya hoti. Kasiṇakammaṭṭhāne kammaṃ
analyzed: kāyaḥ kilamati yante pakkhipitvā pīḷana ākāra ppatto viya hoti kasiṇa kammaṭṭhāne kammaṃ
translated: his body aches, as if it were being pressed by a machine. When he is doing the work of development on the kasiṇa meditation subject,

original: karontassa cakkhūni phandanti kilamanti, nikkhamitvā patanākārappattāni viya honti.
analyzed: karontassa cakkhūni phandanti kilamanti nikkhamitvā patana ākāra ppattāni viya honti
translated: As he does so, his eyes roll back and his body becomes exhausted, as if it were falling down.

original: Imasmiṃ pana kammaṭṭhāne kammaṃ karontassa neva kāyo kilamati, na akkhīni vihaññanti. Tasmā evamāha.
analyzed: imasmim pana kammaṭṭhāne kammam karontassa na iva kāyaḥ kilamati na akkhīni vihaññanti tasmai evam āha
translated: But in this meditation subject the meditator’s body does not become exhausted and his eyes do not suffer. That is why it is said that “the body does not become exhausted.”🔽Why is it said, “Having completely transcended the sphere of boundless consciousness,” and so on?

original: Sabbaso rūpasaññānantiādi kasmā vuttaṃ, kiṃ ānāpāne kasiṇugghāṭanaṃ labbhatīti? Tipiṭakacūḷābhayatthero
analyzed: sabbaso rūpa saññāna nti ādi kasmai vuttam kim āna apāne kasiṇugghāṭanam labbhati iti tipiṭakacūḷābhaya thero
translated: The Elder Tipiṭaka Cūḷa-Abhaya said:

original: panāha – “yasmā ānāpānanimittaṃ tārakarūpamuttāvalikādisadisaṃ hutvā paññāyati, tasmā
analyzed: pana āha yasmai āna apāna nimittam tāraka rūpam uttāvalikā ādi sadisam hutvā paññāyati tasmai
translated: “Because the sign of in-breaths and out-breaths appears like a star, a flower, a ball of thread, and so on,🔽therefore the transcending of the kasiṇa is allowable here.”

original: tattha kasiṇugghāṭanaṃ labbhatī”ti. Tipiṭakacūḷanāgatthero “na labbhatevā”ti āha.
analyzed: tattha kasiṇugghāṭanam labbhati iti tipiṭakacūḷanāga theraḥ na labbhateva ati āha
translated: The Elder Tipiṭaka Cūḷanāga said: “It is not allowable.”

original: Alabbhante ayaṃ ariyiddhiādiko pabhedo kasmā gahitoti? Ānisaṃsadassanatthaṃ. Ariyaṃ
analyzed: a labbhante ayam ariya iddhi ādiko pabhedo kasmā gahito ti ānisaṃsa dassana ttham ariyam
translated: If it is not allowable, why is this distinction, namely, “one who attains by the noble way,” included?🔽It is included in order to point out the benefits.

original: vā hi iddhiṃ cattāri vā rūpāvacarajjhānāni catasso vā arūpasamāpattiyo nirodhasamāpattiṃ
analyzed: vā hi iddhim cattāri vā rūpāvacara jhānāni catassaḥ vā arūpa samāpattiyaḥ nirodha samāpattim
translated: For the noble supernormal power, the four jhānas of the fine-material sphere, the four immaterial attainments, and the attainment of cessation are the benefits here.

original: vā patthayamānena bhikkhunā ayaṃ ānāpānassatisamādhi sādhukaṃ manasikātabbo. Yathā
analyzed: vā patthayamānena bhikkhunā ayam āna apāna ssati samādhi sādhukam manasikātabbaḥ yathā
translated: and he who aspires to them should give attention to this concentration by mindfulness of breathing.

original: hi nagare laddhe yaṃ catūsu disāsu uṭṭhānakabhaṇḍaṃ, taṃ catūhi dvārehi nagarameva
analyzed: hi nagare laddhe yam catūsu disāsu uṭṭhānaka bhaṇḍam tam catūhi dvārehi nagaram eva
translated: For just as when a town is captured, whatever goods there are in the four directions come into the town,

original: pavisatīti, janapado laddho ca hoti. Nagarasseva heso ānisaṃso. Evaṃ ānāpānassatisamādhibhāvanāya🔽ānisaṃso esa ariyiddhiādiko pabhedo, sabbākārena bhāvite ānāpānassatisamādhismiṃ
analyzed: pavisati iti janapadaḥ laddhaḥ ca hoti nagarassa iva ha isaḥ ānisaṃsaḥ evam āna apāna ssati samādhi bhāvanāya  ānisaṃso esa ariyiddhi ādiko pabhedo sabba ākārena bhāvite āna apāna sati samādhismiṃ
translated: and the countryside is captured too, so the benefits of the town are obtained;🔽so too, when concentration by mindfulness of breathing is developed,🔽all this comes to the meditator. That is why it is said that the benefits are shown by the classification beginning with “noble powers.”

original: sabbametaṃ yogino nipphajjatīti ānisaṃsadassanatthaṃ vuttaṃ. Sukhañceti ettha soti
analyzed: sabbam etam yoginaḥ nipphajjati iti ānisaṃsa dassana tham vuttam sukham ca iti ettha saḥ ti
translated: “If he feels a pleasant feeling” .🔽Why is “he” not stated here?

original: kasmā na vuttaṃ? Yasmā bhikkhūti imasmiṃ vāre nāgataṃ.
analyzed: kasmā na vuttam yasmā bhikkhu iti imasmin vāre na āgatam
translated: Because “bhikkhu” is stated in the section on the first tetrad.

original: 9. Vesālīsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vesālī sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Sutta on Vesālī

original: 985. Navame vesāliyanti evaṃnāmake itthiliṅgavasena pavattavohāre nagare. Tañhi nagaraṃ
analyzed: navame evaṃnāmake itthi liṅga vasena pavatta vohāre nagare tat hi nagaram
translated: In the ninth, in Vesālī: in the town that has the name “Vesālī” in the feminine gender. For that town

original: tikkhattuṃ pākāraparikkhepavaḍḍhanena visālībhūtattā vesālīti vuccati. Idampi ca
analyzed: tikkhattum pākāra parikkhepa vaḍḍhanena visālībhūta ttā vesālī iti vuccati idam pi ca
translated: is called “Vesālī” because it was extended by the addition of ramparts three times. And this🔽is said:

original: nagaraṃ sabbaññutaṃ patteyeva sammāsambuddhe sabbākāravepullataṃ pattanti veditabbaṃ.
analyzed: nagaram sabbaññu tam patteya iva sammāsambuddhe sabba ākāra vepulla tam pattanti veditabbam
translated: and the city reached the fullness of all its aspects only when the all-knowing Enlightened One had reached it.

original: Evaṃ gocaragāmaṃ dassetvā nivāsaṭṭhānamāha mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyanti. Tattha mahāvanaṃ🔽nāma sayaṃjātaṃ aropimaṃ saparicchedaṃ mahantaṃ vanaṃ. Kapilavatthusāmantā pana mahāvanaṃ🔽himavantena saha ekābaddhaṃ aparicchedaṃ hutvā mahāsamuddaṃ āhacca ṭhitaṃ. Idaṃ tādisaṃ🔽na hoti, saparicchedaṃ mahantaṃ vananti mahāvanaṃ. Kūṭāgārasālā pana mahāvanaṃ nissāya
analyzed: evam gocaragāmam dassetvā nivāsa ṭṭhānam āha mahā vane kūṭāgāra sālāyanti tattha mahā vanam  nāma sayaṃjātam aropimam sa paricchedam mahantam vanam kapilavatthu sāmantā pana mahā vanam  himavantena saha eka ābaddham a paricchedam hutvā mahā samuddam āhat ca ṭhitam idam tādisam  na hoti sa paricchedam mahantam vananti mahā vanam kūṭāgāra sālā pana mahā vanam nissāya
translated: Having thus shown the resort village, he said, “In the Great Wood, in the pavilion with the peaked roof,” where the Great Wood🔽is a self-existent, enclosed, extensive wood. But the Great Wood

original: kate ārāme kūṭāgāraṃ antokatvā haṃsavaṭṭakacchannena katā sabbākārasampannā buddhassa🔽bhagavato gandhakuṭīti veditabbā.
analyzed: kate ārāme kūṭāgāram antokatvā haṃsa vaṭṭaka channena katā sabba ākāra sampannā buddhassa  bhagavataḥ gandha kuṭī iti veditabbā
translated: around Kapilavatthu is not like that. It is connected with the Himalayas and extends unbroken to the ocean. This is not like that. It is an extensive wood with an enclosure, thus it is the Great Wood. But the pavilion with the peaked roof was built in the monastery situated in the Great Wood. It was a well-constructed building with a peaked roof, covered with a roof of plaster, and it was the Blessed One’s Perfumed Chamber.

original: Anekapariyāyena asubhakathaṃ kathetīti anekehi kāraṇehi asubhākārasandassanappavattaṃ
analyzed: aneka pariyāyena asubha katham katheti iti anekehi kāraṇehi asubha ākāra sandassana ppavattam
translated: He expounded the theme of foulness in many a figure: he expounded the theme of foulness in many a figure, in many a way, by showing the aspects of foulness.

original: kāyavicchandanīyakathaṃ katheti. Seyyathidaṃ – atthi imasmiṃ kāye kesā lomā nakhā
analyzed: kāya vicchandanīya katham kathā iti sā iyyathā idam atthi imasmin kāye kesāḥ lomāḥ nakhāḥ
translated: He gives a talk on the loathsomeness of nutriment, that is to say, he gives a talk on the loathsomeness of this body in this way: “In this body there are head hairs, body hairs, nails, teeth,

original: dantā…pe… muttanti. Kiṃ vuttaṃ hoti? Bhikkhave, imasmiṃ byāmamatte kaḷevare sabbākārenapi
analyzed: dantāpe muttanti kim vuttam hoti bhikkhave imasmin byāma matte kaḷevare sabba ākārena api
translated: skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidney, heart, liver, midriff, spleen, lungs, bowels, entrails, gorge, dung, and whatever else there is that is in this body and is of a similar kind. ” What is meant? Bhikkhus, when one searches in every way

original: vicinanto na koci kiñci muttaṃ vā maṇiṃ vā veḷuriyaṃ vā agaruṃ vā candanaṃ vā kuṅkumaṃ🔽vā kappuraṃ vā vāsacuṇṇādiṃ vā aṇumattampi sucibhāvaṃ passati, atha kho paramaduggandhaṃ🔽jegucchaassirikadassanaṃ kesalomādinānappakāraṃ asucimeva passati, tasmā na ettha
analyzed: vicinantaḥ na koci kiñci muttam vā maṇim vā veḷuriyam vā agarum vā candanam vā kuṅkumam  vā kappuram vā vāsa cuṇṇa ādim vā aṇumattam pi suci bhāvam passati atha kho parama duggandham  jeguccha assirika dassanam kesa loma ādi nānappakāram asucim eva passati tasmā naḥ ettha
translated: in this body, which is no more than a clod of foulness, one does not see anything at all that is pure, such as a gem, or a pearl, or bdellium, or sandalwood, or saffron,

original: chando vā rāgo vā karaṇīyo. Yepi uttamaṅge sirasi jātā kesā nāma, tepi asubhā ceva🔽asucino ca paṭikūlā ca. So ca nesaṃ asubhāsucipaṭikūlabhāvo vaṇṇatopi saṇṭhānatopi
analyzed: chandaḥ vā rāgaḥ vā karaṇīyaḥ ye api uttamaṅge sirasi jātā kesāḥ nāma te api asubhā ca iva  ca paṭikūlā ca so ca na isam asubha asuci paṭikūla bhāvaḥ vaṇṇataḥ pi saṇṭhānataḥ pi
translated: or camphor, or talcum powder, or anything else of a similar kind, however small. On the contrary, one sees only head hairs, body hairs, nails, teeth,🔽skin, and so on, which are of a similar kind and are extremely malodorous, disgusting, repulsive, and filthy. Therefore,🔽one should not arouse desire or passion for it. And the head hairs, which grow on the head, are foul and filthy and repulsive. And their foulness, filthiness, and repulsiveness should be understood in terms of colour, shape,

original: gandhatopi āsayatopi okāsatopīti pañcahākārehi veditabbo. Evaṃ lomādīnampīti ayamettha
analyzed: gandhataḥ api āsayataḥ api okāsataḥ api iti pañcahā ākārehi veditabbaḥ evam loma ādīnam pi iti ayam ettha
translated: smell, habitat, and location. So too with the body hairs, and so on. This is how he should be skilled in the analysis of the body.

original: saṅkhepo, vitthāro pana visuddhimagge vuttanayeneva veditabbo. Iti bhagavā ekamekasmiṃ
analyzed: saṅkhepaḥ vitthāraḥ pana visuddhi magge vutta nayena iva veditabbaḥ iti bhagavā ekam ekasmin
translated: The brief treatment should be understood as given in the Visuddhimagga.

original: koṭṭhāse pañcapañcappabhedena anekapariyāyena asubhakathaṃ katheti.🔽Asubhāya vaṇṇaṃ bhāsatīti uddhumātakādivasena asubhamātikaṃ nikkhipitvā padabhājanīyena
analyzed: koṭṭhāse pañca pañca ppabhedena aneka pariyāyena asubha katham kathā iti  asubhāya vaṇṇam bhāsati iti uddhu mātaka ādi vasena asubha mātikam nikkhipitvā pada bhājanīyena
translated: So the Blessed One teaches the foulness meditation in many ways, with fivefold and other divisions in each section.🔽He extols the virtues of foulness: having set up the meditation subject consisting of foulness in the various aspects of the bloated, etc., he extols it, analyses it, and reveals its special qualities,

original: taṃ vibhajanto vaṇṇento asubhāya vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati. Asubhabhāvanāya vaṇṇaṃ bhāsatīti🔽yā ayaṃ kesādīsu vā uddhumātakādīsu vā ajjhattabahiddhāvatthūsu asubhākāraṃ gahetvā🔽pavattassa cittassa bhāvanā vaḍḍhanā phātikammaṃ, tassā asubhabhāvanāya ānisaṃsaṃ
analyzed: tam vibhajantaḥ vaṇṇentaḥ asubhāya vaṇṇam bhāsati asubha bhāvanāya vaṇṇam bhāsati iti  yā ayam kesa ādīsu vā uddhumātaka ādīsu vā ajjhatta bahiddhā vatthūsu asubha ākāram gahetvā  pavattassa cittassa bhāvanā vaḍḍhanā phāti kammam tassāḥ asubha bhāvanāyaḥ ānisaṃsam
translated: He extols the virtues of foulness meditation:🔽having taken up the aspect of foulness in the internal and external bases beginning with head hairs, he extols the virtues of the meditation that occurs by means of that, its development, its increase, its abundance,

original: dassento vaṇṇaṃ bhāsati, guṇaṃ parikitteti. Seyyathidaṃ – “asubhabhāvanābhiyutto,
analyzed: dassentaḥ vaṇṇam bhāsati guṇam parikittā iti sā iyyathidam asubha bhāvanā abhiyuttaḥ
translated: showing the benefits of foulness meditation in this way:

original: bhikkhave, bhikkhu kesādīsu vā vatthūsu uddhumātakādīsu vā pañcaṅgavippahīnaṃ pañcaṅgasamannāgataṃ
analyzed: bhikkhave bhikkhu kesa ādīsu vā vatthūsu uddhumātaka ādīsu vā pañcaṅga vippahīnam pañcaṅga samannāgatam
translated: “Bhikkhus, a bhikkhu who develops the meditation subject of foulness, who cultivates it, who makes much of it, leaves these five dangers behind. What five?🔽He abandons lust, he abandons hatred, he abandons delusion, he abandons fear, and he acquires a meditation subject” .

original: tividhakalyāṇaṃ dasalakkhaṇasampannaṃ paṭhamajjhānaṃ paṭilabhati. So taṃ paṭhamajjhānasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: tividha kalyāṇam dasa lakkhaṇa sampannam paṭhamajjhānam paṭilabhati saḥ tam paṭhamajjhāna saṅkhātam
translated: and he attains the first jhāna, which is threefold, possesses eight factors, and is of pure heart and possessed of the rapture and bliss born of seclusion.

original: cittamañjūsaṃ nissāya vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā uttamatthaṃ arahattaṃ pāpuṇātī”ti.
analyzed: citta mañjūsam nissāya vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā uttamattham arahattam pāpuṇāti iti
translated: He develops insight, and by means of insight he reaches Arahantship, the supreme security from bondage, by depending on the mind-deliverance of the first jhāna as a proximate cause.”

original: Icchāmahaṃ, bhikkhave, aḍḍhamāsaṃ paṭisallīyitunti ahaṃ, bhikkhave, ekaṃ aḍḍhamāsaṃ🔽paṭisallīyituṃ nilīyituṃ ekakova hutvā viharituṃ icchāmīti attho. Nāmhi kenaci upasaṅkamitabbo🔽aññatra ekena piṇḍapātanīhārakenāti yo attanā payuttavācaṃ akatvā mamatthāya saddhesu🔽kulesu paṭiyattapiṇḍapātaṃ nīharitvā mayhaṃ upanāmeti, taṃ piṇḍapātanīhārakaṃ ekaṃ
analyzed: icchāmaham bhikkhave aḍḍha māsam paṭisallīyitum ti aham bhikkhave ekam aḍḍha māsam  paṭisallīyitum nilīyitum ekakaḥ iva hutvā viharitum icchāmi iti atthaḥ na amhi kenacid upasaṅkamitabbo  aññatra ekena piṇḍapāta nīhārakena ati yaḥ attanā payutta vācam a katvā mamatthāya saddhesu  kulesu paṭiyatta piṇḍapātam nīharitvā upanāma iti tam piṇḍapāta nīhārakam ekam
translated: “Bhikkhus, I wish to enter upon seclusion for half a month.🔽Let no one approach me except the one who brings me almsfood.”

original: bhikkhuṃ ṭhapetvā nāmhi aññena kenaci bhikkhunā vā gahaṭṭhena vā upasaṅkamitabboti.
analyzed: bhikkhum ṭhapetvā aññena kenacid bhikkhunā vā gahaṭṭhena vā upasaṅkamitabbaḥ ti
translated: “I wish to enter upon seclusion for half a month. Let no one approach me except the one who brings me almsfood.”

original: Kasmā pana evamāhāti? Atīte kira pañcasatā migaluddakā mahatīhi daṇḍavāgurādīhi araññaṃ
analyzed: kasmai pana evam āha ati atīte kira pañca satāḥ miga luddakāḥ mahatīhi daṇḍa vāgurā ādīhi araññam
translated: Why did he say this? It seems that once upon a time five hundred hunters, armed with bows and arrows, spears, swords, and so on, entered a forest,

original: parikkhipitvā haṭṭhatuṭṭhā ekatoyeva yāvajīvaṃ migapakkhighātakammena jīvikaṃ kappetvā
analyzed: parikkhipitvā haṭṭha tuṭṭhā ekatoyā iva yāvajīvam miga pakkhi ghāta kammena jīvikam kappetvā
translated: and having surrounded it, they were delighted and satisfied. They made their living for the rest of their lives by killing deer and birds.

original: niraye uppannā. Te tattha paccitvā pubbe katena kenacideva kusalakammena manussesu
analyzed: niraye uppannā te tattha paccitvā pubbe katena kenacid eva kusala kammena manussesu
translated: After being reborn in Hell, having been cooked there, through some previously made wholesome deed they were reborn among humans,

original: uppannā kalyāṇūpanissayavasena sabbepi bhagavato santike pabbajjañca upasampadañca
analyzed: uppannā kalyāṇa upanissaya vasena sabbe api bhagavato santike pabbajjañca upasampadañca
translated: and through the influence of a good friend they all went forth in the presence of the Fortunate One, and they were ordained,

original: labhiṃsu. Tesaṃ tato mūlākusalakammato avipakkavipākā aparāparacetanā tasmiṃ aḍḍhamāsabbhantare
analyzed: labhiṃsu tesam tatas mūla akusala kammataḥ a vipakka vipākā apara apara cetanā tasmim aḍḍhamāsa abbhantare
translated: and from that root unwholesome deed the result that was not yet exhausted, through another and another intention, in that half-month

original: attūpakkamena ca parūpakkamena ca jīvitūpacchedāya okāsamakāsi. Taṃ bhagavā addasa.
analyzed: attu upakkamena ca paru upakkamena ca jīvitu upacchedāya okāsam akāsi tam bhagavā addasa
translated: they made an opportunity for the cutting off of their life through self-violence and violence from others. The Fortunate One saw that.

original: Kammavipāko ca nāma na sakkā kenaci paṭibāhituṃ. Tesu ca bhikkhūsu puthujjanāpi atthi,
analyzed: kamma vipāko ca nāma na sakkā kenacid paṭibāhitum tesu ca bhikkhūsu puthujjana api atthi
translated: And the result of (unwholesome) deeds cannot be averted by anyone. And among those monks there were ordinary people,

original: sotāpannasakadāgāmianāgāmikhīṇāsavāpi. Tattha khīṇāsavā appaṭisandhikā, itare ariyasāvakā
analyzed: sotāpanna sakadāgāmi anāgāmi khīṇāsavā api tattha khīṇāsavāḥ appaṭisandhikāḥ itare ariyasāvakā
translated: and there were Stream-Enterers, Once-Returners, Non-Returners, and those whose defilements had gone. Therein, those whose defilements had gone were without rebirth, but the Noble Disciples

original: niyatagatikā sugatiparāyaṇā, puthujjanānaṃ gati aniyatā.
analyzed: niyata gatikā su gati parāyaṇā puthujjanānam gati aniyatā
translated: were of fixed destiny, and were bound for a happy destiny, but the ordinary people’s destiny was not fixed.

original: Atha bhagavā cintesi – “ime attabhāve chandarāgena maraṇabhayabhītā na sakkhissanti
analyzed: atha bhagavā cintesi ime atta bhāve chanda rāgena maraṇa bhaya bhītāḥ na sakkhissanti
translated: Then the Blessed One thought: “These people, being afraid of death, are attached to their bodies with lust.

original: gatiṃ visodhetuṃ, handa nesaṃ chandarāgappahānāya asubhakathaṃ kathemi. Taṃ sutvā
analyzed: gatim visodhetum handa na īsam chanda rāga pahānāya asubha katham kathemi tam sutvā
translated: They will not be able to purify their destiny. Let me teach them the meditation subject of foulness in order to make them abandon lust. Having heard that,

original: attabhāve vigatacchandarāgatāya gativisodhanaṃ katvā sagge paṭisandhiṃ gaṇhissanti,
analyzed: atta bhāve vigata chanda rāga tāya gati visodhanam katvā sagge paṭisandhim gaṇhissanti
translated: they will be able to purify their destiny by becoming free from lust for their bodies, and they will take rebirth in heaven.

original: evaṃ tesaṃ mama santike pabbajjā sātthikā bhavissatī”ti. Tato tesaṃ anuggahāya asubhakathaṃ
analyzed: evam tesam mama santike pabbajjā sātthikā bhavissati iti tatas tesam anuggahāya asubha katham
translated: In this way their going forth under me will not be fruitless.” So for their benefit he taught the meditation subject of foulness,

original: kathesi kammaṭṭhānasīsena, no maraṇavaṇṇasaṃvaṇṇanādhippāyena. Kathetvā ca panassa
analyzed: kathesi kammaṭṭhāna sīsena no maraṇa vaṇṇa saṃvaṇṇana adhippāyena kathetvā ca panassa
translated: not with the aim of recommending death, but with the aim of abandoning lust.

original: etadahosi – “sace imaṃ aḍḍhamāsaṃ maṃ bhikkhū passissanti, ‘ajja eko bhikkhu mato,🔽ajja dve…pe… ajja dasā’ti āgantvā ārocessanti, ayañca kammavipāko na sakkā mayā vā
analyzed: etat ahosi sace imam aḍḍha māsam mam bhikkhū passissanti ajja ekaḥ bhikkhu mataḥ  ajja dvepe ajja dasāti āgantvā ārocessanti ayaṃ ca kamma vipāko na sakkā mayā vā
translated: And after he had taught it, he thought: “If the bhikkhus see me for half a month, they will come and tell me: ‘Today one bhikkhu has died,

original: aññena vā paṭibāhituṃ, svāhaṃ taṃ sutvāpi kiṃ karissāmi, kiṃ me anatthakena anayabyasanena
analyzed: aññena vā paṭibāhitum svāham tam sutvā api kim karissāmi kim me anatthakena anaya byasanena
translated: today two … today ten have died.’ And this result of kamma cannot be averted either by me or by anyone else. What shall I do when I hear it? What purpose will be served by this misfortune and calamity?

original: sutena, handāhaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ adassanaṃ upagacchāmī”ti. Tasmā evamāha – “icchāmahaṃ,🔽bhikkhave, aḍḍhamāsaṃ paṭisallīyituṃ, nāmhi kenaci upasaṅkamitabbo aññatra ekena
analyzed: sutena handa aham bhikkhūnam adassanam upagacchāmi iti tasmai evam āha icchāmaham  bhikkhave aḍḍha māsam paṭisallīyitum na amhi kenacid upasaṅkamitabbaḥ aññatra ekena
translated: “Since I have heard this, let me go into seclusion.” He said this in order to do so.

original: piṇḍapātanīhārakenā”ti.
analyzed: piṇḍapāta nīhārakena ati
translated: “Monks, I wish to go into seclusion for half a month. No one should approach me except the one who brings me food.”

original: Apare panāhu – “parūpavādavivajjanatthaṃ evaṃ vatvā paṭisallīno”ti. Pare kira bhagavantaṃ🔽upavadissanti – “ayaṃ ‘sabbaññū ahaṃ saddhammavaracakkavattī’ti paṭijānamāno attanopi
analyzed: apare pana āhu parūpavāda vivajjana attham evam vatvā paṭisallīno ti pare kira bhagavantam  upavadissanti ayam sabbaññū aham saddhamma vara cakkavattī iti paṭijānamāno attanaḥ api
translated: But others say that he went into seclusion in order to clear away false accusations. They say that others would accuse the Buddha,

original: sāvake aññamaññaṃ ghātente nivāretuṃ na sakkoti, kiṃ aññaṃ sakkhissatī”ti? Tatra🔽paṇḍitā vakkhanti – “bhagavā paṭisallānamanuyutto na imaṃ pavattiṃ jānāti, kocissa
analyzed: sāvake aññam aññam ghātente nivāretum na sakkoti kim aññam sakkhissati iti tatra  paṇḍitāḥ vakkhanti bhagavā paṭisallānam anuyuttaḥ na imam pavattim jānāti kocissa
translated: “Though he claims to be omniscient and to be a universal monarch of the true Dhamma, he is unable to stop his disciples from killing each other. What else can he do?”

original: ārocayitāpi natthi, sace jāneyya addhā nivāreyyā”ti. Idaṃ pana icchāmattaṃ, paṭhamamevettha
analyzed: ārocayitā api natthi sace jāneyya addhā nivāreyya ati idam pana icchāmattam paṭhamam eva īttha
translated: The wise, however, will say, “The Buddha is devoted to seclusion. He does not know what is happening. No one has informed him. If he knew, he would certainly stop it.” But this is mere speculation.

original: kāraṇaṃ. Nāssudhāti ettha assudhāti padapūraṇamatte avadhāraṇatthe vā nipāto, neva🔽koci bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamīti attho.🔽Anekehi vaṇṇasaṇṭhānādīhi kāraṇehi vokāro assāti anekākāravokāro. Anekākāravokiṇṇo
analyzed: kāraṇam ettha assudhāti pada pūraṇa matte avadhāraṇa atthe vā nipātaḥ na iva  koci bhagavantam upasaṅkamīti attho  anekehi vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna ādīhi kāraṇehi vokāraḥ assa ati aneka ākāra vokāraḥ aneka ākāra vokiṇṇaḥ
translated: The reason is this. In the phrase nāssu, the word assu is a particle used to fill out the line or to indicate limitation. The meaning is: “No one approached the Blessed One.”🔽The meditation subject is of many aspects, of many modes, in that it is of many aspects and modes through the various colors, shapes, and so on. It is said to be of many aspects and modes mixed with the many aspects,

original: anekākārena sammissoti vuttaṃ hoti. Ko so? Asubhabhāvanānuyogo, taṃ anekākāravokāraṃ.
analyzed: aneka ākārena sammissaḥ ti vuttam hoti kaḥ saḥ asubha bhāvanā anuyogo tam aneka ākāra vokāram
translated: in other words, mixed with the many colors, shapes, and so on. What is it? It is the meditation subject consisting of the foulness aspect.

original: Asubhabhāvanānuyogamanuyuttā viharantīti yuttappayuttā viharanti. Aṭṭīyamānāti tena
analyzed: asubha bhāvanā anuyogam anuyuttāḥ viharanti iti yutta ppayuttāḥ viharanti tena
translated: They dwell devoted to the meditation subject consisting of the foulness aspect: they dwell devoted to the meditation subject consisting of the foulness aspect in the various ways of being devoted.

original: kāyena aṭṭā dukkhitā honti. Harāyamānāti lajjamānā. Jigucchamānāti jigucchaṃ uppādayamānā.
analyzed: kāyena aṭṭāḥ dukkhitāḥ honti harāyamānā ati lajjamānā jigucchamānā ati jiguccham uppādayamānā
translated: They are afraid, they are terrified, they are filled with dread: they are afraid, terrified, filled with dread, because of that body. They are ashamed, they are humiliated, they are disgusted: they are ashamed, humiliated, disgusted, because of that body.

original: Satthahārakaṃ pariyesantīti jīvitaharaṇakasatthaṃ pariyesanti. Na kevalañca te satthaṃ
analyzed: sattha hārakam pariyesanti iti jīvita haraṇaka sattham pariyesanti na kevalam ca te sattham
translated: They seek a knife to kill themselves: they seek a knife to take their own lives. And not only do they seek a knife

original: pariyesitvā attanā vā attānaṃ jīvitā voropenti, migalaṇḍikampi pana samaṇakuttakaṃ
analyzed: pariyesitvā attanā vā attānam jīvitā voropenti migalaṇḍikam pi pana samaṇa kuttakam
translated: but they also kill themselves with a knife, or they ask a monk or a nun or a male or female lay follower to kill them, or they commit suicide by hanging, or they swallow poison or take poison, or they throw themselves down, or they go to a sick person and lie down on top of him, saying, “I shall die together with him,” or they go to a leper and lie down with him, saying, “I shall die together with him,” or they go to a charnel ground, or to a place where four roads meet, or to a place where three roads meet, or to a place where two roads meet, or to a threshing-floor, or to a cemetery, or to a jungle-thicket, or to the foot of a tree, or to an ant-hill, or to a place where the grass is long, or to a place where the grass is short, and there they kill themselves.

original: upasaṅkamitvā, “sādhu no, āvuso, jīvitā voropehī”ti vadanti. Ettha ca ariyā neva
analyzed: upasaṅkamitvā sādhu no āvuso jīvitā voropehi iti vadanti ettha ca ariyāḥ na iva
translated: and they approached the monks and said, “It would be good, venerable sirs, if you would deprive us of life.” And here the Noble Ones

original: pāṇātipātaṃ kariṃsu, na samādapesuṃ, na samanuññā ahesuṃ. Puthujjanā pana sabbamakaṃsu.
analyzed: pāṇātipātam kariṃsu na samādapesum na samanuññāḥ ahesum puthujjanāḥ pana sabbam akaṃsu
translated: neither killed nor instigated others to kill nor did they consent to the killing. But the ordinary people did all three.

original: Paṭisallānā vuṭṭhitoti tesaṃ pañcannaṃ bhikkhusatānaṃ jīvitakkhayappattabhāvaṃ ñatvā🔽tato ekībhāvato vuṭṭhito jānantopi ajānanto viya kathāsamuṭṭhāpanatthaṃ āyasmantaṃ
analyzed: paṭisallānā vuṭṭhitā ti tesam pañcannam bhikkhu satānam jīvita khaya patta bhāvam ñatvā  tatas ekībhāvataḥ vuṭṭhitaḥ jānantaḥ api a jānantaḥ viya kathā samuṭṭhāpana attham āyasmantam
translated: Having come out of seclusion: having come out of seclusion after having known the state of the five hundred monks having had their life-span cut short.

original: ānandaṃ āmantesi. Kiṃ nu kho, ānanda, tanubhūto viya bhikkhusaṅghoti ito, ānanda,
analyzed: ānandam āmantesi kim nu kho ānanda tanu bhūtaḥ viya bhikkhu saṅghaḥ ti itas ānanda
translated: Although he knew, he asked, as if he did not know, in order to begin the discussion. He addressed venerable Ānanda, saying: “Ānanda, why is it that the Community of monks seems to have diminished?” From this, Ānanda,

original: pubbe bahū bhikkhū ekato upaṭṭhānaṃ āgacchanti, uddesaṃ paripucchaṃ gaṇhanti, sajjhāyanti,
analyzed: pubbe bahū bhikkhū ekatas upaṭṭhānam āgacchanti uddesam paripuccham gaṇhanti sajjhāyanti
translated: formerly many monks came together to the service, they recited the recitation, they took the questioning, they recited the scriptures,

original: ekapajjoto viya ārāmo dissati. Idāni pana aḍḍhamāsamattassa accayena tanubhūto viya
analyzed: eka pajjotaḥ viya ārāmaḥ dissati idāni pana aḍḍha māsa mattassa accayena tanu bhūtaḥ viya
translated: the monastery appears as if it were one great light. But now, after only half a month, the Community of monks seems to have diminished,

original: tanuko mando appako viraḷo viya jāto bhikkhusaṅgho. Kiṃ nu kho kāraṇaṃ? Kiṃ disāsu pakkantā bhikkhūti?
analyzed: tanukaḥ mandaḥ appakaḥ viraḷaḥ viya jātaḥ bhikkhu saṅghaḥ kim nu kho kāraṇam kim disāsu pakkantāḥ bhikkhū ti
translated: it seems to have become small, weak, few, scattered. What is the reason? Have the monks gone to the different directions?”

original: Athāyasmā ānando kammavipākena tesaṃ jīvitakkhayappattiṃ asallakkhento asubhakammaṭṭhānānuyogapaccayā🔽pana sallakkhento tathā hi pana, bhante bhagavātiādiṃ vatvā bhikkhūnaṃ arahattappattiyā
analyzed: atha āyasmai ānando kamma vipākena tesam jīvita khaya ppattim a sallakkhentaḥ asubha kammaṭṭhāna anuyoga paccayā  pana sallakkhento tathā hi pana bhante bhagavā iti ādim vatvā bhikkhūnam arahatta ppattiyā
translated: but knowing it to be due to the application of the meditation subject of foulness,

original: aññaṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ yācanto, sādhu, bhante, bhagavātiādimāha. Tassattho – sādhu, bhante,
analyzed: aññam kammaṭṭhānam yācantaḥ sādhu bhante bhagavā iti ādim āha tassa atthaḥ sādhu bhante
translated: said, “It is wonderful, venerable sir, it is marvellous! ” and so on, and asked for another meditation subject.🔽The meaning is: “It would be good, venerable sir,

original: bhagavā aññaṃ kāraṇaṃ ācikkhatu, yena bhikkhusaṅgho arahatte patiṭṭhaheyya. Mahāsamuddaṃ🔽orohaṇatitthāni viya aññānipi dasānussati, dasakasiṇa, catudhātuvavatthāna, brahmavihāra,
analyzed: bhagavā aññam kāraṇam ācikkhatu yena bhikkhu saṅghaḥ arahatte patiṭṭhaheyya mahā samuddaṃ  orohaṇa titthāni viya aññāni api brahmavihāra
translated: if the Blessed One would teach the bhikkhu-sangha the other cause whereby it might be established in Arahantship.🔽Just as there are many landing places on the great ocean,🔽so there are many meditation subjects for entering Nibbāna, such as the ten recollections, the ten kasiṇas, the four elements, the divine abidings,

original: ānāpānassatipabhedāni bahūni nibbānorohaṇakammaṭṭhānāni santi, tesu bhagavā bhikkhū🔽samassāsetvā aññataraṃ kammaṭṭhānaṃ ācikkhatūti adhippāyo.
analyzed: āna apāna ssati pabhedāni bahūni nibbāna ārohaṇa kammaṭṭhānāni santi tesu bhagavā bhikkhū  samassāsetvā aññataram kammaṭṭhānam ācikkhatu iti adhippāyaḥ
translated: and mindfulness of breathing. Let the Blessed One encourage the bhikkhus and teach them another meditation subject. ”

original: Atha bhagavā tathā kātukāmo theraṃ uyyojento tenahānandātiādimāha. Tattha vesāliṃ
analyzed: atha bhagavā tathā kātu kāmo theram uyyojento tenahā ānanda iti ādim āha tattha vesāliṃ
translated: Then, wishing to do so, the Blessed One sent the elder away, saying, “Well then, Ānanda, go and do as you think fit.” Herein, in Vesālī,

original: upanissāyāti vesāliyaṃ upanissāya samantā gāvutepi aḍḍhayojanepi yāvatikā viharanti,
analyzed: upanissāya ati vesāliyam upanissāya samantā gāvute pi aḍḍha yojane pi yāvatikāḥ viharanti
translated: “In dependence on” means in dependence on Vesali, all those who live around Vesali, even as far as a league away.

original: te sabbe sannipātehīti attho. Sabbe upaṭṭhānasālāyaṃ sannipātetvāti attanā gantuṃ🔽yuttaṭṭhānaṃ sayaṃ gantvā aññattha daharabhikkhū pahiṇitvā muhutteneva anavasese
analyzed: te sabbe sannipātehi iti attho sabbe upaṭṭhāna sālāyam sannipātetvā ati attanā gantum  yutta ṭṭhānam sayam gantvā aññattha dahara bhikkhū pahiṇitvā muhuttena iva anavasese
translated: The meaning is: “Gather them all together.” Having gathered them all together in the assembly hall,🔽having gone himself to the places where it was proper for him to go and having sent young bhikkhus to the other places, he had all the bhikkhus assembled in the assembly hall in a very short time.

original: bhikkhū upaṭṭhānasālāyaṃ samūhaṃ katvā. Yassadāni, bhante, bhagavā kālaṃ maññatīti🔽ettha ayamadhippāyo – bhagavā bhikkhusaṅgho sannipatito, esa kālo bhikkhūnaṃ dhammakathaṃ
analyzed: bhikkhū upaṭṭhāna sālāyam samūham katvā yassadāni bhante bhagavā kālam maññati iti  ettha ayam adhippāyaḥ bhagavā bhikkhu saṅghaḥ sannipatitaḥ esa kālaḥ bhikkhūnam dhamma katham
translated: “Now is the time, venerable sir, to do as you think fit.”

original: kātuṃ, anusāsaniṃ dātuṃ, idāni yassa tumhe kālaṃ jānātha, taṃ kātabbanti.
analyzed: kātum anusāsanim dātum idāni yassa tumhe kālam jānātha tam kātabbanti
translated: Here is the meaning: “The bhikkhu Sangha has assembled. This is the time to give a talk on the Dhamma and to give advice to the bhikkhus. Now you may do what you think fit.”

original: Atha kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi, ayampi kho, bhikkhaveti. Āmantetvā ca pana bhikkhūnaṃ
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi ayam pi kho bhikkhave iti āmantetvā ca pana bhikkhūnam
translated: Then the Exalted One addressed the bhikkhus. This is the meaning: having addressed the bhikkhus,

original: arahattappattiyā pubbe ācikkhitaasubhakammaṭṭhānato aññaṃ pariyāyaṃ ācikkhanto ānāpānassatisamādhītiādimāha.
analyzed: arahatta ppattiyā pubbe ācikkhita asubha kammaṭṭhānato aññam pariyāyam ācikkhantaḥ āna apāna ssati samādhi iti ādim āha
translated: he spoke the words “The concentration through mindfulness of breathing,” etc., in order to teach them a method other than the meditation subject of foulness, which he had previously taught them, for the attainment of arahatship.

original: Tattha ānāpānassatisamādhīti ānāpānapariggāhikāya satiyā saddhiṃ sampayutto samādhi,
analyzed: tattha āna apāna sati samādhi iti āna apāna pariggāhikāya satiyā saddhim sampayuttaḥ samādhi
translated: Herein, concentration through mindfulness occupied with breathing means concentration associated with mindfulness that is occupied with breathing.

original: ānāpānassatiyaṃ vā samādhi, ānāpānassatisamādhi. Bhāvitoti uppādito vaḍḍhito vā.
analyzed: ānāpānassatiyam vā samādhi ānāpānassati samādhi bhāvitaḥ ti uppāditaḥ vaḍḍhitaḥ vā
translated: Or it is concentration in the mindfulness occupied with breathing, thus it is concentration through mindfulness occupied with breathing.🔽Developed means given rise to, increased.🔽Well developed means made to arise again and again.

original: Bahulīkatoti punappunaṃ kato. Santo ceva paṇīto cāti santo ceva paṇīto ceva. Ubhayattha
analyzed: bahulīkataḥ iti punappunam kataḥ santaḥ ca iva paṇītaḥ ca ati santaḥ ca iva paṇītaḥ ca iva ubhayattha
translated: Tranquil and sublime means tranquil and also sublime.

original: evasaddena niyamo veditabbo. Kiṃ vuttaṃ hoti? Ayañhi yathā asubhakammaṭṭhānaṃ kevalaṃ🔽paṭivedhavasena santañca paṇītañca, oḷārikārammaṇattā pana paṭikūlārammaṇattā ca
analyzed: eva saddena niyamaḥ veditabbaḥ kim vuttam hoti ayan hi yathā asubha kammaṭṭhānam kevalam  paṭivedha vasena santam ca paṇītam ca oḷārika ārammaṇa ttā pana paṭikūla ārammaṇa ttā ca
translated: The word “only” should be understood as a limitation in both cases. What is meant? For this, unlike the meditation subject of foulness, which is tranquil and sublime only in the sense of penetration,🔽is not tranquil and sublime in the sense of object, because its object is gross, being a thing that is repellent.

original: ārammaṇavasena neva santaṃ na paṇītaṃ, na evaṃ kenaci pariyāyena asanto vā appaṇīto
analyzed: ārammaṇa vasena na iva santam na paṇītam na evam kenacid pariyāyena asantaḥ vā appaṇītaḥ
translated: It is not in any way untranquil and unsublime, like a razor’s edge or like milk. On the contrary, it is tranquil and sublime in the sense of the object’s continuity,

original: vā, apica kho ārammaṇasantatāyapi santo vūpasanto nibbuto, paṭivedhasaṅkhātāya aṅgasantatāyapi,
analyzed: vā apica kho ārammaṇa santatāya api santaḥ vūpasantaḥ nibbutaḥ paṭivedha saṅkhātāya aṅga santatāya api
translated: and it is also tranquil and sublime in the sense of the continuity of the factors of the penetration.

original: ārammaṇapaṇītatāya paṇīto atittikaro, aṅgapaṇītatāyapīti. Tena vuttaṃ “santo ceva paṇīto cā”ti.
analyzed: ārammaṇa paṇīta tāya paṇītaḥ atittikaraḥ aṅga paṇīta tāya api iti tena vuttam santaḥ ca iva paṇītaḥ ca ati
translated: It is sublime in the sense of the object’s excellence, and it is also sublime in the sense of the excellence of the factors. That is why it is said to be “tranquil and sublime.”

original: Asecanako ca sukho ca vihāroti ettha pana nāssa secananti asecanako, anāsittako abbokiṇṇo🔽pāṭiyekko āveṇiko, natthi ettha parikammena vā upacārena vā santatā, ādisamannāhārato🔽pabhuti attano sabhāveneva santo ca paṇīto cāti attho. Keci “asecanako”ti anāsittako🔽ojavanto, sabhāveneva madhuro”ti vadanti. Evamayaṃ asecanako ca appitappitakkhaṇe🔽kāyikacetasikasukhappaṭilābhāya saṃvattanato sukho ca vihāroti veditabbo.🔽Uppannuppanneti avikkhambhite. Pāpaketi lāmake. Akusale dhammeti akosallasambhūte🔽dhamme. Ṭhānaso antaradhāpetīti khaṇeneva antaradhāpeti vikkhambheti. Vūpasametīti
analyzed: asecanako ca sukhaḥ ca vihāro ti ettha pana na assa secananti asecanakaḥ anāsittakaḥ abbokiṇṇo  pāṭiyekkaḥ āveṇikaḥ natthi ettha parikammena vā upacārena vā santatā ādi samannāhārato  pabhuti attano sabhāvena iva santo ca paṇīto ca ati attho keci asecanako ti anāsittako  ojavantaḥ sabhāvena iva madhurā iti vadanti evam ayam asecanako ca appita ppita kkhaṇe  kāyika cetasika sukha paṭilābhāya saṃvattanato sukho ca vihāraḥ ti veditabbo  uppanna uppanneti a vikkhambhite pāpake iti lāmake akusale dhamme iti akosalla sambhūte  dhamme ṭhānasaḥ antaradhāpeti iti khaṇena iva antaradhāpeti vikkhambheti vūpasameti iti
translated: “A state of comfort that is not over-sharply painful”: here, it is not over-sharply painful because it is not painful. It is not mixed with pain.
