original: paṭippassambhetīti vuttaṃ hoti. Gimhānaṃ pacchime māseti āsāḷhamāse. Ūhataṃ rajojallanti🔽aṭṭha māse vātātapasukkhāya gomahiṃsādipādappahārasambhinnāya pathaviyā uddhaṃ hataṃ
analyzed: paṭippassambheti iti vuttam hoti gimhānam pacchime māse iti āsāḷha māse ūhatam rajojallanti  aṭṭha māse vāta ātapa sukkhāya go mahiṃsa ādi pāda pahāra sambhinnāya pathaviyā uddham hatam
translated: “It subsides” means that it is allayed. In the last month of the rainy season: in the month of Āsāḷhā. The dust and the mist that were raised:

original: ūhataṃ ākāse samuṭṭhitaṃ rajañca reṇuñca. Mahā akālameghoti sabbaṃ nabhaṃ ajjhottharitvā🔽uṭṭhito āsāḷhajuṇhapakkhe sakalaṃ aḍḍhamāsaṃ vassanakamegho. So hi asampatte vassakāle
analyzed: ākāse samuṭṭhitam rajañca reṇuñca mahā akāla meghaḥ uti sabbam nabham ajjhottharitvā  uṭṭhitaḥ āsāḷha juṇha pakkhe sakalam aḍḍha māsam vassanaka megho so hi a sampatte vassa kāle
translated: the dust and the mist that were raised up from the earth, which for eight months had been dried by the wind and the sun, and which had been churned up by the trampling of cattle, elephants, horses, and so on. A great cloud out of season: a cloud that arose, covering the entire sky,

original: uppannattā akālameghoti idha adhippeto. Ṭhānaso antarādhāpeti vūpasametīti khaṇeneva🔽adassanaṃ neti pathaviyaṃ sannisīdāpeti. Evameva khoti opammanidassanametaṃ. Tato
analyzed: uppanna ttā akāla meghaḥ ti idha adhippeto ṭhānaso antarādhāpeti vūpasameti iti khaṇena iva  a dassanam na iti pathaviyam sannisīda apeti evam eva kho ti opamma nidassanam etam tatas
translated: and rained for the entire fortnight of the bright fortnight of Āsāḷhi. For it is this kind of cloud that is meant here by the expression “out of season,” since it arises at a time when the rainy season has not yet begun. It subsides right there: it disappears in a moment,

original: paraṃ vuttanayameva.
analyzed: param vutta nayam eva
translated: it sinks into the earth. Just as: this is an illustration. The rest is as above.

original: 10. Kimilasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: kimila sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . The explanation of the Kimila Sutta

original: 986. Dasame kimilāyanti evaṃnāmake nagare. Etadavocāti thero kira cintesi – “ayaṃ
analyzed: dasame kim ilāyanti evaṃnāmake nagare etat avoca ati theraḥ kira cintesi ayam
translated: In the tenth sutta, in the city named Kimilā. He said this: the Elder, it seems, thought: “This king

original: desanā na yathānusandhikā katā, yathānusandhiṃ gamessāmī”ti desanānusandhiṃ ghaṭento
analyzed: desanā na yathā anusandhikā katā yathā anusandhim gamessāmi iti desanā anusandhim ghaṭentaḥ
translated: He will not give the teaching in the way in which the application of the mind should be made. He will make the application of the mind in the way in which the teaching should be given. ” So he spoke thus in order to make the application of the teaching.

original: etaṃ avoca. Kāyaññataranti pathavīādīsu kāyesu aññataraṃ vadāmi vāyokāyaṃ vadāmīti
analyzed: etam avoca kāyaññataram ti pathavī ādīsu kāyesu aññataram vadāmi vāyu kāyam vadāmi iti
translated: “In one of the bodies” : I say in one of the bodies such as the earth, etc., I say in the air-body.

original: attho. Atha vā cakkhāyatanaṃ…pe… kabaḷīkāro āhāroti pañcavīsati rūpakoṭṭhāsā rūpakāyo
analyzed: atthaḥ atha vā cakkha āyatanam pe kabaḷīkāro āhāro ti pañcavīsati rūpa koṭṭhāsāḥ rūpa kāyo
translated: Or else, the twenty-five groups of matter are called the matter-body, beginning with the eye-base and ending with the nutriment of gross or fine food.

original: nāma, tesu ānāpānaṃ phoṭṭhabbāyatane saṅgahitattā kāyaññataraṃ hoti, tasmāpi evamāha.🔽Tasmātihāti yasmā catūsu kāyesu aññataraṃ vāyokāyaṃ, pañcavīsati koṭṭhāse vā rūpakāye
analyzed: nāma tesu āna apānam phoṭṭhabba āyatane saṅgahita ttā kāyaññataram hoti tasmā api evam āha  tasmā atihāti yasmā catūsu kāyesu aññataram vāyokāyam pañcavīsati koṭṭhāse vā rūpa kāye
translated: In these, in-breath and out-breath are included in the body-sensibility. Therefore he said thus.

original: aññataraṃ ānāpānaṃ anupassati, tasmā kāye kāyānupassīti attho. Evaṃ sabbattha attho
analyzed: aññataram āna apānam anupassati tasmā kāye kāya anupassī iti attho evam sabbattha attho
translated: “Therefore” : since in one of the four bodies, the air-body, or in one of the twenty-five groups of matter, in-breath and out-breath are observed, therefore the meaning is: “he is one who observes the body in the body.” In this way, the meaning should be understood in all instances.

original: veditabbo. Vedanāññataranti tīsu vedanāsu aññataraṃ, sukhavedanaṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: veditabbaḥ vedanā aññataram ti tīsu vedanāsu aññataram sukha vedanam sandhāya itam vuttam
translated: “In one of the feelings” : in one of the three feelings. This was said with reference to the pleasant feeling.

original: Sādhukaṃ manasikāranti pītipaṭisaṃveditādivasena uppannaṃ sundaraṃ manasikāraṃ. Kiṃ
analyzed: sādhukam pīti paṭisaṃvedita ādi vasena uppannam sundaram manasikāram kim
translated: “With full awareness” : with a beautiful attention arisen by the experience of happiness, etc.

original: pana manasikāro sukhā vedanā hotīti? Na hoti, desanāsīsaṃ panetaṃ. Yatheva hi “aniccasaññābhāvanānuyogamanuyuttā”ti
analyzed: pana manasikāro sukhā vedanā hoti iti na hoti desanā sīsam pana itam yathā iva hi anicca saññā bhāvanā anuyogam anuyuttā ati
translated: For just as in the passage, “Devoted to the development of the perception of impermanence” ,

original: ettha saññānāmena paññā vuttā, evamidhāpi manasikāranāmena jhānavedanā vuttāti veditabbā.
analyzed: ettha saññā nāmena paññā vuttā evam idha api manasikāra nāmena jhāna vedanā vuttā iti veditabbā
translated: perceiving is said by way of understanding, so here feeling should be understood as said by way of jhāna and feeling.

original: Etasmiñhi catukke paṭhamapade pītisīsena vedanā vuttā, dutiyapade sukhanti sarūpeneva🔽vuttā. Cittasaṅkhārapadadvaye “saññā ca vedanā ca cetasikā ete dhammā cittappaṭibaddhā🔽cittasaṅkhārā”ti vacanato “vitakkavicāre ṭhapetvā sabbepi cittasampayuttakā dhammā
analyzed: etasmin hi catukke paṭhhama pade pīti sīsena vedanā vuttā dutiya pade sukhanti sarūpena iva  vuttā citta saṅkhāra pada dvaye saññā ca vedanā ca cetasikā ete dhammā citta ppaṭibaddhā  citta saṅkhārā ti vacanataḥ vitakka vicāre ṭhapetvā sabbe pi citta sampayuttakāḥ dhammāḥ
translated: For in this tetrad feeling is said by way of the head of happiness in the first clause, and by way of its own individual essence in the second clause.🔽And in the two clauses about mental formations, feeling is said by way of mental formations because it is said, “Perception and feeling are mental states, these states are bound to the mind,

original: cittasaṅkhāre saṅgahitā”ti vacanato cittasaṅkhāranāmena vedanā vuttā. Taṃ sabbaṃ
analyzed: citta saṅkhāre saṅgahitā iti vacanato citta saṅkhāra nāmena vedanā vuttā tat sabbam
translated: they are mental formations” , and because it is said, “Except for applied and sustained thought, all the states associated with consciousness included in the categories of the aggregates, bases, and elements are mental formations” .

original: manasikāranāmena saṅgahetvā idha “sādhukaṃ manasikāra”nti āha.
analyzed: manasikāra nāmena saṅgahetvā idha sādhukam āha
translated: So all that is included by way of attention is said here by “close attention.”

original: Evaṃ santepi yasmā esā vedanā ārammaṇaṃ na hoti, tasmā vedanānupassanā na yujjatīti.
analyzed: evam sante pi yasmai esā vedanā ārammaṇam na hoti tasmai vedanā anupassanā na yujjati iti
translated: But still, since this feeling is not the object, the contemplation of feeling is not appropriate.

original: No na yujjati, mahāsatipaṭṭhānādīsupi hi taṃ taṃ sukhādīnaṃ vatthuṃ ārammaṇaṃ katvā
analyzed: no na yujjati mahāsati paṭṭhāna ādīsu pi hi tam tam sukha ādīnam vatthum ārammaṇam katvā
translated: It is not incorrect, for in the case of the four foundations of mindfulness, etc., too, it is a particular kind of pleasant feeling, etc., that is the object,

original: vedanā vedayati, taṃ pana vedanāpavattiṃ upādāya “ahaṃ vedayāmī”ti vohāramattaṃ hoti,
analyzed: vedanāḥ vedayati tam pana vedanā pavattim upādāya aham vedayāmi iti vohāra mattam hoti
translated: and it is in dependence on the occurrence of the feeling that the mere convention “I am experiencing” arises.

original: taṃ sandhāya “sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno sukhaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī”tiādi vuttaṃ. Apica
analyzed: tam sandhāya sukham vedanam vedayamānaḥ sukham vedanam vedayāmi itiādi vuttam apica
translated: And it is with reference to that that it is said, “Experiencing a pleasant feeling he knows: I experience a pleasant feeling.” Moreover,

original: “pītippaṭisaṃvedī”tiādīnaṃ atthavaṇṇanāyametassa parihāro vuttoyeva. Vuttañhetaṃ visuddhimagge –
analyzed: pīti paṭisaṃvedī iti ādīnam attha vaṇṇanā ayam etassa parihāraḥ vuttaḥ yā iva vuttam ha etam visuddhi magge
translated: the answer to this has already been given in the explanation of the meaning of “conascent with joy,” etc., for this is said in the Path of Purification:

original: “Dvīhākārehi pīti paṭisaṃviditā hoti – ārammaṇato ca asammohato ca. Kathaṃ ārammaṇato
analyzed: dvīhākārehi pi iti paṭisaṃviditā hoti ārammaṇato ca asammohato ca katham ārammaṇato
translated: “Joy is known in two ways: as object and as non-delusion. How is it known as object?

original: pīti paṭisaṃviditā hoti? Sappītike dve jhāne samāpajjati, tassa samāpattikkhaṇe jhānapaṭilābhena
analyzed: pīti paṭisaṃviditā hoti sa pītike dve jhāne samāpajjati tassa samāpatti kkhaṇe jhāna paṭilābhena
translated: One enters upon and dwells in the two jhānas that are accompanied by joy. At the moment of his attaining them

original: ārammaṇato pīti paṭisaṃviditā hoti ārammaṇassa paṭisaṃviditattā. Kathaṃ asammohato
analyzed: ārammaṇato pi iti paṭisaṃviditā hoti ārammaṇassa paṭisaṃvidita ttā katham a sammohato
translated: joy is known to him as object because the object is known. How is it known as non-delusion?

original: pīti paṭisaṃviditā hoti? Sappītike dve jhāne samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya jhānasampayuttapītiṃ🔽khayato vayato sammasati, tassa vipassanākkhaṇe lakkhaṇappaṭivedhena asammohato pīti🔽paṭisaṃviditā hoti. Vuttañhetaṃ paṭisambhidāyaṃ “‘dīghaṃ assāsavasena cittassa ekaggataṃ🔽avikkhepaṃ pajānato sati upaṭṭhitā hoti, tāya satiyā tena ñāṇena sā pīti paṭisaṃviditā🔽hotī’ti. Eteneva nayena avasesapadānipi atthato veditabbānī”ti.
analyzed: pīti paṭisaṃviditā hoti sa pītike dve jhāne samāpajjitvā vuṭṭhāya jhāna sampayutta pītim  khayataḥ vayataḥ sammasati tassa vipassanā kkhaṇe lakkhaṇa paṭivedhena a sammohato pi iti  paṭisaṃviditā hoti vuttam ha etam paṭisambhidā ayam dīgham assāsa vasena cittassa ekagga tam  avikkhepam pajānato sati upaṭṭhitā hoti tāya satiyā tena ñāṇena sā pīti paṭisaṃviditā  hoti iti etena iva nayena avasesa padāni pi atthataḥ veditabbāni iti
translated: How is happiness known? When he has emerged from the two jhānas in which happiness is present, he comprehends with insight the happiness associated with the jhāna as liable to destruction and to fall;

original: Iti yatheva jhānapaṭilābhena ārammaṇato pītisukhacittasaṅkhārā paṭisaṃviditā honti,
analyzed: iti yathā iva jhāna paṭilābhena ārammaṇato pīti sukha citta saṅkhārā paṭisaṃviditāḥ honti
translated: at the time of his insight the happiness is known to him by his non-delusion about its characteristics. For this is said in the Paṭisambhidā: “When he knows unification of mind and non-distraction through long in-breaths, … through long out-breaths, … through short in-breaths, … through short out-breaths, … through in-breaths while acquainted with the whole body of breaths, … through out-breaths while acquainted with the whole body of breaths, … through in-breaths tranquillizing the body formation, … through out-breaths tranquillizing the body formation, … through in-breaths accompanied by happiness, … through out-breaths accompanied by happiness, … through in-breaths accompanied by bliss, … through out-breaths accompanied by bliss, … through in-breaths accompanied by the mental formation, … through out-breaths accompanied by the mental formation, … through in-breaths accompanied by the happiness enlightenment factor, … through out-breaths accompanied by the happiness enlightenment factor, … through in-breaths accompanied by the bliss enlightenment factor, … through out-breaths accompanied by the bliss enlightenment factor, … through in-breaths accompanied by the concentration enlightenment factor, … through out-breaths accompanied by the concentration enlightenment factor, … through in-breaths accompanied by the equanimity enlightenment factor, … through out-breaths accompanied by the equanimity enlightenment factor, … through in-breaths classified as the equanimity enlightenment factor, … through out-breaths classified as the equanimity enlightenment factor, … through in-breaths accompanied by the sign of calm, … through out-breaths accompanied by the sign of calm, … through in-breaths accompanied by the sign of non-diversion, … through out-breaths accompanied by the sign of non-diversion, … through in-breaths accompanied by the sign of voidness, … through out-breaths accompanied by the sign of voidness, then his mindfulness is established . By means of that mindfulness and that knowledge he is one who knows and sees . For him, knowing and seeing thus, that happiness is known, seen, recognized, realized, and contacted with wisdom” .

original: evaṃ imināpi jhānasampayuttena vedanāsaṅkhātamanasikārapaṭilābhena ārammaṇato vedanā🔽paṭisaṃviditā hoti. Tasmā suvuttametaṃ “vedanāsu vedanānupassī bhikkhu tasmiṃ samaye viharatī”ti.
analyzed: evam iminā api jhāna sampayuttena vedanā saṅkhāta manasikāra paṭilābhena ārammaṇataḥ vedanā 🔽paṭisaṃviditā hoti tasmā su vuttam etam vedanāsu vedanā anupassī bhikkhu tasmin samaye viharati iti
translated: So too, on this occasion the bhikkhu has obtained the jhana whose nature is the unification of mind and which is accompanied by equanimity.🔽Thus at that time the bhikkhu is dwelling in that jhana, having entered upon it, developed it, and mastered it.🔽That is why it is said: “On that occasion the bhikkhu abides contemplating mind as mind.”

original: Nāhaṃ, ānanda, muṭṭhassatissa asampajānassāti ettha ayamadhippāyo – yasmā “cittapaṭisaṃvedī🔽assāsissāmī”tiādinā nayena pavatto bhikkhu kiñcāpi assāsapassāsanimittamārammaṇaṃ
analyzed: na aham ānanda muṭṭha satissa asampajānassa ati ettha ayam adhippāyaḥ yasmā citta paṭisaṃvedī  assāsissāmi iti ādinā nayena pavattaḥ bhikkhu kiñcā api assāsa passāsa nimittam ārammaṇam
translated: “I do not say, Ananda, of one who is inattentive and who lacks full awareness” : the intention here is this. The bhikkhu who has entered upon the way stated thus, “I shall breathe in … shall breathe out experiencing the mind” makes the sign of in-breaths and out-breaths the object,

original: karoti, tassa pana cittassa ārammaṇe satiñca sampajaññañca upaṭṭhāpetvā pavattanato
analyzed: karoti tassa pana cittassa ārammaṇe satiñca sampajaññañca upaṭṭhāpetvā pavattanato
translated: Herein, the purport of the passage beginning, “I do not say, Ananda, of one who is forgetful and unmindful” is this. Although a bhikkhu who has entered upon the development of mindfulness of breathing in the way beginning, “On breathing in long, he knows ‘I breathe in long,’ on breathing out long, he knows ‘I breathe out long” , makes the sign of in-breaths and out-breaths the object, still, since his consciousness occurs making that sign’s presence its object by keeping in being mindfulness consisting in knowledge, he is called “one who abides contemplating the mind in the mind” .

original: citte cittānupassīyeva nāmesa hoti. Na hi muṭṭhassatissa asampajānassa ānāpānassatisamādhibhāvanā
analyzed: citte citta anupassīyā iva nāma īsa hoti na hi muṭṭha ssatissa asampajānassa āna apāna ssati samādhi bhāvanā
translated: For there is no development of concentration by mindfulness of breathing for one who is forgetful and unmindful.

original: atthi, tasmā ārammaṇato cittapaṭisaṃviditavasena “citte cittānupassī bhikkhu tasmiṃ samaye viharatī”ti.
analyzed: atthi tasmai ārammaṇato citta paṭisaṃvidita vasena citte citta anupassī bhikkhu tasmin samaye viharati iti
translated: Therefore it is said of him that “on that occasion a bhikkhu abides contemplating the mind in the mind, ardent, fully aware, and mindful, having put away covetousness and grief for the world” .

original: So yaṃ taṃ hoti abhijjhādomanassānaṃ pahānaṃ, taṃ paññāya disvā sādhukaṃ ajjhupekkhitā
analyzed: so yam tam hoti abhijjhā domanassānam pahānam tam paññāya disvā sādhukam ajjhupekkhitā
translated: He sees with understanding and wisely inspects that surmounting of covetousness and grief.

original: hotīti ettha abhijjhā kāmacchandanīvaraṇameva, domanassavasena byāpādanīvaraṇaṃ dassitaṃ.
analyzed: hoti iti ettha abhijjhā kāmacchanda nīvaraṇam eva domanassa vasena byāpāda nīvaraṇam dassitaṃ
translated: Herein, covetousness is the same as the hindrance of lust. Grief is shown as the hindrance of ill will.

original: Idañhi catukkaṃ vipassanāvaseneva vuttaṃ, dhammānupassanā ca nīvaraṇapabbādivasena
analyzed: idam hi catukkam vipassanā vasena iva vuttam dhamma anupassanā ca nīvaraṇa pabba ādi vasena
translated: For this tetrad is stated only in terms of insight, and the contemplation of mental objects is fivefold as the contemplation of the hindrances, of the jhāna factors, and so on.

original: pañcavidhā hoti, tassā nīvaraṇapabbaṃ ādi, tassāpi idaṃ nīvaraṇadvayaṃ ādi. Iti dhammānupassanāya🔽ādiṃ dassetuṃ abhijjhādomanassānanti āha. Pahānanti aniccānupassanāya niccasaññaṃ🔽pajahatīti evaṃ pahānakarañāṇaṃ adhippetaṃ. Taṃ paññāya disvāti taṃ aniccavirāganirodhapaṭinissaggañāṇasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: pañcavidhā hoti tassā nīvaraṇa pabbam ādi tassā api idam nīvaraṇa dvayam ādi iti dhamma anupassanāya  ādim dassetum abhijjhā domanassānam ti āha pahānam ti anicca anupassanāya nicca saññam  pajahati iti evam pahāna kara ñāṇam adhippetam tam paññāya disvā ti tam anicca virāga nirodha paṭinissagga ñāṇa saṅkhātam
translated: And the contemplation of the hindrances is the first of these five. And of that contemplation the first two contemplations are the contemplation of the two hindrances. So it is in order to show the first of the contemplations of mental objects that he said “the abandoning of lust and grief.”🔽“Abandoning”: the knowledge of abandoning is intended here. For by means of the contemplation of impermanence he abandons the perception of permanence,

original: pahānañāṇaṃ aparāya vipassanāpaññāya, tampi aparāyāti evaṃ vipassanāparamparaṃ dasseti.🔽Ajjhupekkhitā hotīti yañcassa pathapaṭipannaṃ ajjhupekkhati, yañca ekato upaṭṭhānaṃ
analyzed: pahāna ñāṇam aparāya vipassanā paññāya tat pi aparāya ati evam vipassanā paramparam dasseti  ajjhupekkhitā hoti iti yat ca assa patha paṭipannam ajjhupekkhati yat ca ekatas upaṭṭhānam
translated: and so on. “Having seen with wisdom”: he shows a succession of insights by saying that the knowledge of abandoning, which is called the knowledge of destruction of the taints, is seen with the insight wisdom of the next stage, and that that is seen with the insight wisdom of the next stage.🔽“Is looked on with equanimity”: he looks on with equanimity in two ways: he looks on with equanimity at what has arisen in the first stage, and he looks on with equanimity at what has arisen in the second stage.

original: ajjhupekkhatīti dvidhā ajjhupekkhati nāma. Tattha sahajātānampiajjhupekkhanā hoti
analyzed: ajjhupekkhati iti dvidhā ajjhupekkhati nāma tattha sahajātānam pi ajjhupekkhanā hoti
translated: Herein, the equanimity of looking on is the equanimity of looking on at what is arisen together with it.

original: ārammaṇassāpi ajjhupekkhanā. Idha ārammaṇa ajjhupekkhanā adhippetā. Tasmātihānandāti🔽yasmā “aniccānupassī assāsissāmī”tiādinā nayena pavatto na kevalaṃ nīvaraṇādidhamme,
analyzed: ārammaṇassa api ajjhupekkhanā idha ārammaṇa ajjhupekkhanā adhippetā tasmā atiha ānanda ati  yasmai anicca anupassī assāsissāmi itiādinā nayena pavattaḥ na kevalam nīvaraṇa ādi dhamme
translated: Therefore, Ānanda, …🔽because it is seen with understanding that the knowledge that abandons the states described as greed and hate, etc.,

original: abhijjhādomanassasīsena pana vuttānaṃ dhammānaṃ pahānakarañāṇampi paññāya disvā ajjhupekkhitā
analyzed: abhijjhā domanassa sīsena pana vuttānam dhammānam pahāna kara ñāṇam pi paññāya disvā ajjhupekkhitā
translated: is looked on with equanimity, not only the states beginning with the hindrances,

original: hoti, tasmā dhammesu dhammānupassī bhikkhu tasmiṃ samaye viharatīti veditabbo.
analyzed: hoti tasmā dhammesu dhamma anupassī bhikkhu tasmin samaye viharati iti veditabbaḥ
translated: therefore it should be understood that on that occasion the bhikkhu abides contemplating mental objects in mental objects by way of the contemplation of impermanence, etc., in the states beginning with the hindrances,🔽and that he abides contemplating mental objects in mental objects by way of the contemplation of abandoning in the states described as greed, etc.,🔽and that he abides contemplating mental objects in mental objects by way of the contemplation of equanimity in the states described as knowledge and seeing.

original: Evameva khoti ettha catumahāpatho viya cha āyatanāni daṭṭhabbāni. Tasmiṃ paṃsupuñjo🔽viya chasu āyatanesu kilesā. Catūhi disāhi āgacchantā sakaṭarathā viya catūsu ārammaṇesu
analyzed: evam eva kho ti ettha catu mahāpathaḥ viya cha āyatanāni daṭṭhabbāni tasmim paṃsu puñjaḥ  viya chasu āyatanesu kilesā catūhi disāhi āgacchantā sakaṭarathā viya catūsu ārammaṇesu
translated: Just as, etc. Here the six bases should be regarded as the crossroads, the defilements in the six bases as the heap of dust,

original: pavattā cattāro satipaṭṭhānā. Ekena sakaṭena vā rathena vā paṃsupuñjassa upahananaṃ
analyzed: pavattā cattāro sati paṭṭhānāḥ ekena sakaṭena vā rathena vā paṃsu puñjassa upahananam
translated: the four foundations of mindfulness occurring with the four objects as the four carts and four chariots coming from the four directions,

original: viya kāyānupassanādīhi pāpakānaṃ akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ upaghāto veditabboti.
analyzed: viya kāya anupassanā ādīhi pāpakānam akusalānam dhammānam upaghātaḥ veditabbaḥ ti
translated: and the injury to the evil unskilled states by means of the contemplation of the body, etc., as the removal of the heap of dust by one cart or chariot.

original: Ekadhammavaggo paṭhamo.
analyzed: ekadhamma vaggaḥ paṭhamaḥ
translated: The first chapter on one idea

original: 2. Dutiyavaggo
analyzed: dutiya vaggo
translated: 2. The Second Chapter

original: 1-2. Icchānaṅgalasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Discourse at Icchānangala, etc.

original: 987-988. Dutiyavaggassa paṭhame evaṃ byākareyyāthāti kasmā attano vihārasamāpattiṃ🔽ācikkhati? Upārambhamocanatthaṃ. Sace hi te “na jānāmā”ti vadeyyuṃ, atha nesaṃ titthiyā🔽“tumhe ‘asukasamāpattiyā nāma no satthā temāsaṃ vihāsī’tipi na jānātha, atha kasmā
analyzed: dutiya vaggassa paṭhame evam byākareyyātha ati kasmai attanaḥ vihāra samāpattim  ācikkhati upārambha mocana attham sace hi te na jānāma ati vadeyyuṃ atha na isam titthiyā  tumhe asuka samāpattiyā nāma no satthā temāsam na jānātha atha kasmā
translated: Why does he describe his own abiding in concentration in the first of the second chapter?

original: naṃ upaṭṭhahantā viharathā”ti upārambhaṃ āropeyyuṃ, tato mocanatthaṃ evamāha.
analyzed: naṃ upaṭṭhahantā viharatha iti upārambham āropeyyuṃ tatas mocana attham evam āha
translated: In order to remove a reproach. For if they had said, “We do not know,” then the sectarians would have reproached them, saying, “You do not even know that your teacher has been abiding in such and such concentration for three months, so why do you attend upon him?” In order to remove such a reproach, he says this.

original: Atha kasmā yathā aññattha “satova assasati, dīghaṃ vā assasanto”ti eva-vākāro vutto.🔽Evaṃ idha na vuttoti? Ekantasantattā. Aññesañhi assāso vā pākaṭo hoti passāso vā,
analyzed: atha kasmā yathā aññattha sataḥ iva assasati dīgham vā assasantaḥ iti evavākāraḥ vutto  evam idha na vuttaḥ ti ekanta santattā aññesam hi assāsaḥ vā pākaṭaḥ hoti passāsaḥ vā
translated: But why is the phrase not given here as elsewhere, “Breathing in long, he knows: ‘I breathe in long,’ ” and so on?🔽Because of complete purity. For the breathing in and the breathing out of others is evident,

original: bhagavato ubhayampetaṃ pākaṭameva niccaṃ upaṭṭhitassatitāyāti ekantasantattā na vutto.
analyzed: bhagavataḥ pākaṭam eva niccam upaṭṭhita ssati tāya ati ekanta santa ttā na vuttaḥ
translated: but the Blessed One’s is always evident because of his constant mindfulness. Therefore it is not given here because of complete purity.

original: Atha “sikkhāmī”ti avatvā kasmā “assasāmī”ti ettakameva vuttanti? Sikkhitabbābhāvā.
analyzed: atha sikkhāmi iti avatvā kasmai assasāmi iti ettakam eva vuttanti sikkhitabba abhāvā
translated: Why is it said only “I shall breathe in … shall breathe out acquainted” and not “I shall train to breathe in … shall train to breathe out acquainted”? Because there is no training.

original: Satta hi sekhā sikkhitabbabhāvā sekhā nāma, khīṇāsavā sikkhitabbābhāvā asekhā nāma,🔽tathāgatā asikkhitabbā asekkhā nāma natthi tesaṃ sikkhitabbakiccanti sikkhitabbābhāvā
analyzed: satta hi sekhā sikkhitabba bhāvā sekhā nāma khīṇa āsavā sikkhitabba abhāvā asekhā nāma  tathāgatāḥ asikkhitabbāḥ asekkhāḥ nāma natthi tesam sikkhitabba kiccanti sikkhitabba abhāvā
translated: For there are seven kinds of trainers called “learners” because they have training still to be done, and there are those whose cankers have been destroyed called “those with training” because they have no more training to be done.🔽But there are no Perfect Ones called “those with no more training to be done” because they have no training still to be done.

original: na vuttaṃ. Dutiyaṃ uttānameva.🔽3-10. Paṭhamaānandasuttādivaṇṇanā
analyzed: na vuttam dutiyam uttānam eva
translated: So it is because there is no training that it is said only “I shall breathe in … shall breathe out acquainted” and not “I shall train to breathe in … shall train to breathe out acquainted.” The second is plain.🔽The first is plain.

original: 989-996. Tatiye pavicinatīti aniccādivasena pavicinati. Itaraṃ padadvayaṃ etasseva
analyzed: tatiye pavicinati iti anicca ādi vasena itaram pada dvayam etassa iva
translated: In the third, he investigates by way of impermanence, etc.; the other two terms are synonyms for that.

original: vevacanaṃ. Nirāmisāti nikkilesā kāyikacetasikadarathapaṭipassaddhiyā kāyopi cittampi🔽passambhati. Samādhiyatīti sammā ṭhapiyati, appanācittaṃ viya hoti. Ajjhupekkhitā
analyzed: vevacanam nirāmisāti nikkilesā kāyaḥ api cittam pi  samādhiyati iti sammā ṭhapiyati appanā cittam viya hoti ajjhupekkhitā
translated: It is free from grief: it is free from the defilements; and because bodily and mental fatigue are allayed, the body and mind

original: hotīti sahajātaajjhupekkhanāya ajjhupekkhitā hoti.
analyzed: hoti iti sahajāta ajjhupekkhanāya ajjhupekkhitā hoti
translated: are calmed. It is concentrated: it is well steadied, like the consciousness of absorption. It is looked on with equanimity: it is looked on with the equanimity that is conascent with it.

original: Evaṃ cuddasavidhena kāyapariggāhakassa bhikkhuno tasmiṃ kāye sati satisambojjhaṅgo,
analyzed: evam cuddasavidhena kāya pariggāhakassa bhikkhuno tasmin kāye sati sati sambojjhaṅgo
translated: So when a bhikkhu is investigating the body in these fourteen ways, the enlightenment factor of mindfulness is already arisen in him.

original: tāya satiyā sampayuttañāṇaṃ dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgo, taṃsampayuttameva kāyikacetasikavīriyaṃ
analyzed: tāya satiyā sampayutta ñāṇam dhammavicaya sambojjhaṅgo tad sampayuttam eva kāyika cetasika vīriyam
translated: The knowledge associated with that mindfulness is the factor of the enlightenment of investigation of phenomena. The bodily and mental energy associated with that is the factor of the enlightenment of energy.

original: vīriyasambojjhaṅgo, pītipassaddhicittekaggatā pītipassaddhisamādhisambojjhaṅgā, imesaṃ
analyzed: vīriya sambojjhaṅgo pīti passaddhi citta ekagga tā pīti passaddhi samādhi sambojjhaṅgāḥ imesam
translated: The joy, tranquillity, unification of mind, and equanimity associated with that are the factors of the enlightenment of joy, tranquillity, concentration, and equanimity respectively.

original: channaṃ bojjhaṅgānaṃ anosakkanaanativattanasaṅkhāto majjhattākāro upekkhāsambojjhaṅgo.🔽Yatheva hi samappavattesu assesu sārathino “ayaṃ olīyatī”ti tudanaṃ vā, “ayaṃ atidhāvatī”ti
analyzed: channam bojjhaṅgānam anosakkana anativattana saṅkhātaḥ majjhatta ākāraḥ upekkhā sambojjhaṅgo  yathā iva hi samappavattesu assesu sārathinaḥ ayam olīyati iti tudanam vai ayam atidhāvati iti
translated: The middle way, which is the avoidance of both the slackness of not exerting oneself in these six factors of enlightenment and the agitation of exerting oneself too much, is called the factor of the enlightenment of equanimity.🔽Just as when horses are being driven, the charioteer does not need to urge them on by saying, “This one is lagging behind,” or “That one is running too fast,”

original: ākaḍḍhanaṃ vā natthi, kevalaṃ evaṃ passamānassa ṭhitākārova hoti, evameva imesaṃ
analyzed: ākaḍḍhanam vā natthi kevalam evam passamānassa ṭhita ākāraḥ u hoti evam eva imesam
translated: but the mere fact that he sees them as they are is the cause of their being kept on the right course, so too,

original: channaṃ bojjhaṅgānaṃ anosakkanaanativattanasaṅkhāto majjhattākāro upekkhāsambojjhaṅgo
analyzed: channam bojjhaṅgānam anosakkana anativattana saṅkhātaḥ majjhatta ākāraḥ upekkhā sambojjhaṅgo
translated: the middle way, which is the avoidance of both the slackness of not exerting oneself in these six factors of enlightenment and the agitation of exerting oneself too much, is called the factor of the enlightenment of equanimity.

original: nāma hoti. Ettāvatā kiṃ kathitaṃ? Ekacittakkhaṇikā nānāsarasalakkhaṇā vipassanābojjhaṅgā nāma kathitā.
analyzed: nāma hoti ettāvatā kim kathitam eka citta khaṇikā nānā sarasa lakkhaṇā vipassanā bojjhaṅgā nāma kathitā
translated: What has been shown so far? The insight that occurs in a single conscious moment and has the characteristic of having various aspects has been shown under the heading of the factors of enlightenment.

original: Vivekanissitantiādīni vuttatthāneva. Ettha pana soḷasakkhattukā ānāpānassati missakā🔽kathitā, ānāpānamūlakā satipaṭṭhānā pubbabhāgā, tesaṃ mūlabhūtā ānāpānassati pubbabhāgā.
analyzed: viveka nissita nti ādīni vutta tthāni eva ettha pana soḷasa khattukā āna apāna sati missakā  kathitā ānāpāna mūlakā sati paṭṭhānā pubbabhāgā tesam mūla bhūtā ānāpāna sati pubbabhāgā
translated: The rest are as already explained. Herein, the sixteen kinds of mindfulness of breathing are called “mixed” .🔽The foundations of mindfulness with breathing as their basis are the prior-to-the-path kind. The mindfulness of breathing that is their basis is the prior-to-the-path kind.

original: Bojjhaṅgamūlakā satipaṭṭhānā pubbabhāgā, tepi bojjhaṅgā pubbabhāgāva. Vijjāvimuttipūrakā
analyzed: bojjhaṅga mūlakā sati paṭṭhānā pubbabhāgā te pi bojjhaṅgā pubbabhāgā va vijjā vimutti pūrakā
translated: The foundations of mindfulness with the enlightenment factors as their basis are the prior-to-the-path kind. The enlightenment factors are the prior-to-the-path kind.

original: pana bojjhaṅgā nibbattitalokuttarā, vijjāvimuttiyo ariyaphalasampayuttā. Vijjā vā🔽catutthamaggasampayuttā, vimutti phalasampayuttāti. Catutthapañcamachaṭṭhānipi imināva
analyzed: pana bojjhaṅgāḥ nibbattita lokuttarāḥ vijjā vimuttiyaḥ ariya phala sampayuttāḥ vijjāḥ vā  catuttha magga sampayuttā vimutti phala sampayuttā ti catuttha pañcama chaṭṭhāni pi iminā ava
translated: But the enlightenment factors that fulfil knowledge and deliverance are the supramundane kind that arises in the path moment. Knowledge and deliverance are associated with the noble fruition.🔽Knowledge is associated with the fourth path. Deliverance is associated with the fruition.

original: samānaparicchedāni. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: samāna paricchedāni sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: The fourth, fifth, and sixth are the same in their treatment as this. The rest is clear in all instances.

original: Ānāpānasaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.🔽11. Sotāpattisaṃyuttaṃ🔽1. Veḷudvāravaggo
analyzed: āna apāna saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā  sotāpatti saṃyuttam  veḷu dvāra vaggo
translated: The Exposition of the Mindfulness of Breathing is ended.🔽The Section on Stream-Entry🔽The Bamboo Gate

original: 1. Cakkavattirājasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: cakkavatti rāja sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Discourse on the Universal Monarch

original: 997. Sotāpattisaṃyuttassa paṭhame kiñcāpīti anuggahagarahaṇesu nipāto. Catunnañhi
analyzed: sotāpatti saṃyuttassa paṭhame kiñca api iti anuggaha garahaṇesu nipātaḥ catunnam hi
translated: In the first of the Stream-Entry Section, “Even though” is a particle in the sense of a reason.

original: mahādīpānaṃ issariyādhipaccaṃ rajjaṃ anuggaṇhanto catunnañca apāyānaṃ appahīnabhāvaṃ🔽garahanto satthā “kiñcāpi, bhikkhave, rājā cakkavattī”tiādimāha. Tattha catunnaṃ
analyzed: mahā dīpānam issariya adhipaccam rajjam anuggaṇhantaḥ catunnam ca apāyānam a pahīna bhāvam  garahantaḥ satthā kiñcā api bhikkhave rājā cakkavattī iti ādim āha tattha catunnam
translated: and he was praising the Blessed One’s own sovereignty and supremacy in the four continents and the eight islands and the fact that he had abandoned the four states of deprivation.

original: dīpānanti dvisahassadīpaparivārānaṃ catunnaṃ mahādīpānaṃ. Issariyādhipaccanti issarabhāvo
analyzed: dīpānam ti dvi sahassa dīpa parivārānam catunnam mahā dīpānam issariya ādhipaccanti issara bhāvaḥ
translated: The four continents are the four great continents surrounded by the two thousand islands.🔽Sovereignty and supremacy: sovereignty is the state of being a sovereign, supremacy is the state of being supreme. Sovereignty and supremacy are in this sovereignty and supremacy.

original: issariyaṃ, adhipatibhāvo ādhipaccaṃ, issariyaṃ ādhipaccaṃ etasmiṃ rajje, na chedanabhedananti
analyzed: issariyam adhipati bhāvaḥ ādhipaccam issariyam ādhipaccam etasmim rajje na chedana bhedananti
translated: Not by cutting and digging: not by cutting down trees and digging the earth.🔽Having made: having caused to be.

original: issariyādhipaccaṃ. Kāretvāti evarūpaṃ rajjaṃ pavattāpetvā. Kiñcāpi, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakoti🔽ettha anuggahapasaṃsāsu nipāto. Piṇḍiyālopena hi yāpanaṃ anuggahanto catunnañca apāyānaṃ
analyzed: issariya adhipaccam kāretvā ati evarūpam rajjam pavattāpetvā kiñca api bhikkhave ariya sāvako ti  ettha anuggaha pasaṃsāsu nipātaḥ piṇḍiyā lopena hi yāpanam catunnam ca apāyānam
translated: Though a noble disciple: here the particle api is a particle of praise.🔽For the Blessed One was praising the fact that the noble disciple’s living on almsfood is a help to the abandoning of the four states of deprivation.

original: pahīnabhāvaṃ pasaṃsanto satthā “kiñcāpi, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako”tiādimāha. Tattha
analyzed: pahīna bhāvam pasaṃsanto satthā kiñcā api bhikkhave ariya sāvakaḥ ti ādim āha tattha
translated: The four states of deprivation are the four states of deprivation beginning with hell.

original: nantakānīti anantakāni. Terasahatthopi hi vatthasāṭako dasacchedanato paṭṭhāya nantakanteva saṅkhaṃ gacchati.🔽Aveccappasādenāti acalappasādena. So panāyaṃ pasādo kiṃ eko, anekoti? Ekova, so maggena
analyzed: nantakāni iti anantakāni terasa hatthaḥ pi hi vattha sāṭakaḥ dasa chedanataḥ paṭṭhāya nanta kantā iva saṅkham gacchati  avecca pasādena ati acala ppasādena so pana ayam pasādo kim ekaḥ anekaḥ iti ekaḥ iva so maggena
translated: “Endless” means “not limited.” For even a cloth twelve cubits long is reckoned as “endless” from the time it is cut into ten pieces.🔽“With confidence that has well penetrated” means with unshakable confidence.

original: āgatappasādo. Yesu pana vatthūsu apubbaṃ acarimaṃ ruhati, tesaṃ vasena “buddhe aveccappasādenā”tiādinā🔽nayena tidhā vutto. Yasmā ca eko, tasmāva ninnānākaraṇo hoti. Ariyasāvakassa hi buddheyeva🔽pasādo ca pemañca gāravañca mahantaṃ, na dhamme vā saṅghe vā, dhammeyeva vā mahantaṃ,
analyzed: āgata ppasādaḥ yesu pana vatthūsu apubbam acarimam ruhati tesam vasena buddhe avecca ppasādena ati ādinā  nayena tidhā vuttaḥ ca eko hoti ariya sāvakassa hi  mahantam na dhamme vā saṅghe vā vā mahantam
translated: But is this confidence one or many? It is one, but it is called threefold according to the objects in which it arises: “With confidence in the Buddha that has well penetrated … with confidence in the Dhamma … with confidence in the Saṅgha that has well penetrated.”

original: na buddhe vā saṅghe vā, saṅgheyeva vā mahantaṃ, na buddhe vā dhamme vāti etaṃ natthi.
analyzed: na buddhe vā saṅghe vā saṅgheya iva vā mahantam na buddhe vā dhamme vā ati etam natthi
translated: And since it is one, it is not differentiated by way of its object. For the noble disciple’s confidence, love, and respect are great only towards the Buddha, not towards the Dhamma or the Saṅgha; or only towards the Dhamma, not towards the Buddha or the Saṅgha; or only towards the Saṅgha, not towards the Buddha or the Dhamma.

original: Itipi so bhagavātiādīni visuddhimagge vitthāritāneva.
analyzed: iti pi saḥ bhagavā ati ādīni visuddhi magge
translated: “Thus he is of great wisdom” and so on are explained in detail in the Visuddhimagga.

original: Ariyakantehīti ariyānaṃ kantehi piyehi manāpehi. Pañca hi sīlāni bhavantaragatāpi
analyzed: ariya kantehi iti ariyānam kantehi piyehi manāpehi pañca hi sīlāni
translated: “Dear to the noble ones”: dear to the noble ones, loved by the noble ones, pleasing to the noble ones. For the five precepts are dear to the noble ones, loved by the noble ones, pleasing to the noble ones.

original: ariyā na kopenti, evaṃ tesaṃ piyāni. Tāni sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ. Akhaṇḍehītiādi sadisavasena
analyzed: ariyāḥ na kopenti evam tesam piyāni tāni sandhāya itam vuttam akhaṇḍehi itiādi sadisa vasena
translated: The words “without holes” and so on are said in terms of similarity.

original: vuttaṃ. Mukhavaṭṭiyañhi chinnekadesā pāti khaṇḍāti vuccati, majjhe bhinnā chiddāti,
analyzed: vuttam mukha vaṭṭiyam hi chinna eka desā pāti khaṇḍā ati vuccati majjhe bhinnā chiddā ti
translated: For a bowl with a broken place is called “holed,” and if it is broken in the middle, “cracked.”

original: ekasmiṃ padese visabhāgavaṇṇā gāvī sabalāti, nānābinducittā kammāsāti, evameva paṭipāṭiyā
analyzed: ekasmin padese visabhāga vaṇṇā gāvī nānā bindu cittā evam eva paṭipāṭiyā
translated: A cow with a different color in one place is called “speckled,” and if it has many different spots, “variegated.”

original: ādimhi vā ante vā bhinnaṃ sīlaṃ khaṇḍaṃ nāma, majjhe bhinnaṃ chiddaṃ, yattha katthaci
analyzed: ādimhi vā ante vā bhinnam sīlam khaṇḍam nāma majjhe bhinnam chiddam yattha katthaci
translated: So too, virtue broken at the beginning or the end is called “holed,” and if it is broken in the middle, “cracked.”

original: dvinnaṃ vā tiṇṇaṃ vā paṭipāṭiyā bhinnattā sabalaṃ, ekantaraṃ bhinnaṃ kammāsaṃ. Tesaṃ🔽dosānaṃ abhāvena akhaṇḍāditā veditabbā. Bhujissehīti bhujissabhāvakarehi. Viññuppasatthehīti
analyzed: dvinnam vā tiṇṇam vā paṭipāṭiyā bhinnattā sa balam ekantaram bhinnam kammāsam tesam  dosānam abhāvena akhaṇḍa ādi tā veditabbā bhujissehi iti bhujissa bhāva karehi viññu ppasatthehi iti
translated: Broken in one place or another, it is “speckled” if the breaks are two or three, and “variegated” if the breaks are more than that.🔽It should be understood that it is “without holes” and so on because it is free from these faults.

original: buddhādīhi viññūhi pasaṃsitehi. Aparāmaṭṭhehīti “idaṃ nāma tayā kataṃ, idaṃ vītikkanta”nti
analyzed: buddha ādīhi viññūhi pasaṃsitehi aparāmaṭṭhehi iti idam nāma tayā katam idam vītikkantanti
translated: “Of good repute” means of repute among the good. “Praised by the wise” means praised by the Buddha and so on. “Not faulted” means that it cannot be faulted by saying: “This was done by you, this was transgressed by you.”

original: evaṃ parāmasituṃ asakkuṇeyyehi. Samādhisaṃvattanikehīti appanāsamādhiṃ upacārasamādhiṃ
analyzed: evam parāmasitum a sakkuṇeyyehi samādhi saṃvattanikehi iti appanā samādhim upacāra samādhim
translated: They are called “incapable of being grasped” because they cannot be grasped in any way.

original: vā saṃvattetuṃ samatthehi.🔽2. Brahmacariyogadhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vā saṃvattetum samatthehi  brahmacariyogadha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: “Conducive to concentration”: they are able to bring about absorption concentration or access concentration.🔽The Sutta on the Foundation of Mindfulness in Regard to the Holy Life

original: 998. Dutiye yesaṃ saddhāti padena buddhe pasādo gahito. Sīlanti padena ariyakantāni
analyzed: dutiye yesam saddhā ati padena buddhe pasādaḥ gahitaḥ padena
translated: In the second sutta, the words “he has confidence in the Buddha” include confidence in the Dhamma.🔽The words “he has virtue dear to the noble ones” include confidence in the Saṅgha.

original: sīlāni gahitāni. Pasādoti padena saṅghe pasādo gahito. Dhammadassananti padena dhamme
analyzed: sīlāni gahitāni pasādaḥ iti padena saṅghe pasādaḥ gahitaḥ dhamma dassanam ti padena dhamme
translated: The words “he has seen with his own eyes” include confidence in the Dhamma.🔽Thus the four factors of stream-entry are stated.

original: pasādo gahitoti evaṃ cattāri sotāpattiyaṅgāni vuttāni. Kālena paccentīti kālena pāpuṇanti.🔽Brahmacariyogadhaṃ sukhanti brahmacariyaṃ ogāhitvā ṭhitaṃ uparimaggattayasampayuttaṃ
analyzed: pasādaḥ gahito ti evam cattāri sotāpattiyaṅgāni vuttāni kālena paccenti iti kālena pāpuṇanti  brahmacariya ogadham brahmacariyam ogāhitvā ṭhitam upari magga ttaya sampayuttam
translated: “They reach in due course”: they reach in due course.🔽“The bliss of the foundation of the holy life”: the bliss associated with the three higher paths.

original: sukhaṃ. Yo panesa gāthāya āgato pasādo, so katarapasādo hotīti. Tipiṭakacūḷābhayatthero
analyzed: sukham yaḥ pana isa gāthāya āgato pasādo so katara pasādaḥ hoti iti tipiṭakacūḷābhaya tthero
translated: But what is the confidence referred to in the verse?

original: tāva “maggapasādo”ti āha, tipiṭakacūḷanāgatthero “āgatamaggassa paccavekkhaṇappasādo”ti.
analyzed: tāva magga pasādaḥ ti āha tipiṭakacūḷanāga ttheraḥ āgata maggassa paccavekkhaṇa ppasādo ti
translated: The Elder Tipiṭaka Cūḷa Abhaya said that it is confidence in the path. The Elder Tipiṭaka Cūḷa Nāga said that it is the confidence of reviewing the path already traversed.

original: Ubhopi therā paṇḍitā bahussutā, ubhinnaṃ subhāsitaṃ. Missakappasādo esoti.
analyzed: ubho api therā paṇḍitā bahu sutā ubhinnam su bhāsitam missaka ppasādaḥ esa iti
translated: Both elders were wise and learned, and both spoke well. The verse of shared appreciation is this:

original: 3. Dīghāvuupāsakasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dīghāvu upāsaka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary on the Dīghāvu Sutta

original: 999. Tatiye tasmāti yasmā catūsu sotāpattiyaṅgesu sandissasi, tasmā. Vijjābhāgiyeti🔽vijjākoṭṭhāsike. Sabbasaṅkhāresūti sabbesu tebhūmakasaṅkhāresu. Evamassa upari tiṇṇaṃ
analyzed: tatiye tasmā iti yasmā catūsu sotāpattiyaṅgesu sandissasi tasmā vijjābhāgiyā iti  vijjākoṭṭhāsike sabba saṅkhāresu iti sabbesu tebhūmaka saṅkhāresu evam assa upari tiṇṇam
translated: . In the third sutta, tasmā = “therefore,” because you are seen to possess the four factors of stream-entry. Vijjābhāgiye = “in the category of knowledge.”

original: maggānaṃ vipassanā kathitā. Vighātanti dukkhaṃ.
analyzed: maggānam vipassanā kathitā vighātanti dukkham
translated: In the category of knowledge. Sabbasaṅkhāresu = “in all formations.” In all formations of the three planes. Thus the insight of the three higher paths is stated. Vighātanti dukkhaṃ = “destruction is suffering.”

original: 4-5. Paṭhamasāriputtasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary on the First Sāriputta Sutta

original: 1000-1001. Catuttha uttānameva. Pañcame sotāpattiyaṅganti sotāpattiyā pubbabhāgapaṭilābhaṅgaṃ.
analyzed: catutthe uttānam eva pañcame sotāpattiyā aṅgam ti sotāpattiyā pubbabhāga paṭilābha aṅgam
translated: . In the fourth sutta, uttānaṃ = “obvious.” In the fifth sutta, sotāpattiyaṅgaṃ = “factor of stream-entry.”

original: Buddhe aveccappasādādayo pana paṭiladdhaguṇā sotāpannassa aṅgā nāma, tepi pana sotāpattiyaṅganti
analyzed: buddhe avecca ppasāda ādayaḥ pana paṭiladdha guṇā sotāpannassa aṅgā nāma te pi pana
translated: But the qualities already acquired, such as the conviction about the Buddha, etc., are called factors of the stream-enterer. They too are called factors of stream-entry.

original: āgatā. Tatrāyaṃ dvinnampi vacanattho – sappurise sevanto bhajanto payirupāsanto dhammaṃ
analyzed: āgatā tatra ayam dvinnam pi vacana attho sappurise sevantaḥ bhajantaḥ payirupāsantaḥ dhammaṃ
translated: Here is the meaning of the two terms: One who associates with, serves, and attends upon good people, and who listens to the Dhamma of the noble ones,

original: suṇanto yoniso manasikaronto dhammānudhammaṃ pubbabhāgapaṭipadaṃ paṭipajjanto sotāpattiṃ
analyzed: suṇantaḥ yonisas manasikarontaḥ dhamma anudhammam pubbabhāga paṭipadam paṭipajjantaḥ sotāpattim
translated: He hears the Dhamma, he gives attention well, he enters upon the way in conformity with the Dhamma, he attains the stream,

original: paṭilabhatīti sappurisasaṃsevādayo sotāpattiatthāya aṅganti sotāpattiyaṅgaṃ nāma,🔽itare paṭhamamaggasaṅkhātāya sotāpattiyā aṅgantipi sotāpattiyaṅgaṃ, paṭividdhasotāpattimaggassa
analyzed: paṭilabhati iti sappurisa saṃsevā ādayo sotāpatti atthāya aṅganti sotāpattiyaṅgam nāma  itare paṭhama magga saṅkhātāya sotāpattiyāḥ aṅgam ti pi sotāpatti yaṅgam paṭividdha sotāpatti maggassa
translated: So the good friend, etc., are called factors of stream-entry because they are a cause for the attainment of stream-entry.🔽The other three are called factors of stream-entry because they are a cause for the stream-entry called the first path.

original: sotāpattimaggo aṅgantipi sotāpattiyaṅgaṃ.
analyzed: sotāpatti maggaḥ
translated: And the stream-entry path is called a factor of stream-entry because it is a cause for the stream-entry that is the path already penetrated.

original: 6. Thapatisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: thapati sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the sixth chapter

original: 1002. Chaṭṭhe sādhuke paṭivasantīti sādhukanāmake attano bhogagāmake vasanti. Tesu
analyzed: chaṭṭhe sādhuke paṭivasanti iti sādhuka nāmake attanaḥ bhoga gāmake vasanti tesu
translated: In Sādhuka, they lived in their own village called Sādhuka.

original: isidatto sakadāgāmī, purāṇo sotāpanno sadārasantuṭṭho. Magge purisaṃ ṭhapesunti tesaṃ🔽kira gāmadvārena bhagavato gamanamaggo. Tasmā “bhagavā kāle vā akāle vā amhākaṃ suttānaṃ
analyzed: isidatto sakadāgāmī purāṇaḥ sotāpanno sa dāra santuṭṭho magge purisam ṭhapesunti tesam  kira gāma dvārena bhagavataḥ gamana maggo tasmai bhagavā kāle vā akāle vā amhākam suttānam
translated: Among them Isidatta was a once-returner, and Purāṇa was a stream-enterer. They were satisfied with their wives. They placed a man on the path.

original: vā pamattānaṃ vā gaccheyya, atha passituṃ na labheyyāmā”ti maggamajjhe purisaṃ ṭhapesuṃ.
analyzed: vā pamattānam vā gaccheyya atha passitum na labheyyāma ati magga majjhe purisam ṭhapesum
translated: It seems that the Blessed One’s path to their village was by way of the village gate. So they placed a man on the path in the middle of the village, thinking, “Whether it is the right time or not, whether we are heedful or heedless, the Blessed One will go by. Then we shall get to see him.”

original: Anubandhiṃsūti na dūratova piṭṭhito piṭṭhito anubandhiṃsu, bhagavā pana sakaṭamaggassa
analyzed: anubandhiṃsu iti na dūratas va piṭṭhitaḥ piṭṭhitaḥ anubandhiṃsu bhagavā pana sakaṭa maggassa
translated: “Followed close behind” : they did not follow far behind, but followed close behind. The Blessed One went by the middle of the road on foot, while the others went on the two sides of the road.

original: majjhe jaṅghamaggena agamāsi, itare ubhosu passesu anugacchantā agamaṃsu. Maggā okkammāti🔽buddhānañhi kenaci saddhiṃ gacchantānaṃyeva paṭisanthāraṃ kātuṃ vaṭṭati kenaci saddhiṃ
analyzed: majjhe jaṅgha maggena agamāsi itare ubhosu passesu anugacchantā agamaṃsu maggā okkamma ati  buddhānam hi kenacid saddhim gacchantānam yeva paṭisanthāram kātum vaṭṭati kenacid saddhim
translated: “Having left the road” :

original: ṭhitakānaṃ, kenaci saddhiṃ divasabhāgaṃ nisinnānaṃ. Tasmā bhagavā cintesi – “imehi
analyzed: ṭhitakānam kenacid saddhim divasa bhāgam nisinnānam tasmai bhagavā cintesi imehi
translated: For it is proper for the Buddhas to exchange greetings with those who are going along with them, with those who are standing, and with those who are sitting for part of the day. Therefore the Blessed One thought:

original: me saddhiṃ gacchantassa paṭisanthāraṃ kātuṃ ayuttaṃ, ṭhitakenapi kātuṃ na yuttaṃ,
analyzed: me saddhim gacchantassa paṭisanthāram kātum ayuttam ṭhitakena api kātum na yuttam
translated: “It is not proper for me to exchange greetings with them while I am going along. It is not proper to do so while standing.

original: ime hi mayhaṃ sāsane sāmino āgataphalā. Imehi saddhiṃ nisīditvāva divasabhāgaṃ paṭisanthāraṃ
analyzed: ime hi mayham sāsane sāminaḥ āgata phalāḥ imehi saddhim nisīditvā ava divasa bhāgam paṭisanthāram
translated: These are the lords of my Dispensation who have attained the fruits. I shall sit down with them and exchange greetings

original: karissāmī”ti maggā okkamma yena aññataraṃ rukkhamūlaṃ tenupasaṅkami.
analyzed: karissāmi iti maggā okkamma yena aññataram rukkha mūlam tena upasaṅkami
translated: while sitting for part of the day.” So he left the road and went to the foot of a certain tree.

original: Paññatte āsane nisīdīti te kira chattupāhanaṃ kattaradaṇḍaṃ pādabbhañjanatelādīni
analyzed: paññatte āsane nisīdi iti te kira chattu pāhanam kattara daṇḍam pāda bbhañjana tela ādīni
translated: “Having sat down on the seat prepared” : they spread out a sunshade, a fan, a walking stick, a water strainer, oil for the feet, etc.

original: ceva aṭṭhavidhañca pānakaṃ sarabhapādapallaṅkañca gāhāpetvā agamaṃsu, ābhataṃ pallaṅkampi
analyzed: ca iva aṭṭhavidham ca pānakam sarabha pāda pallaṅkam ca gāhāpetvā agamaṃsu ābhatam pallaṅkam pi
translated: and eight kinds of beverages, and a couch with legs of gold and a canopy above, and they came. They spread out the couch that they had brought,

original: paññāpetvā adaṃsu, satthā tasmiṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsūti sesāni chattupāhanādīni
analyzed: paññāpetvā adaṃsu satthā tasmin nisīdi ekamantam nisīdiṃsu iti sesāni chattupāhana ādīni
translated: and they gave it to the Teacher, who sat down on it. They sat down at one side. The rest, the sunshade, the sandals, etc.,

original: bhikkhusaṅghassa dethāti vatvā sayampi bhagavantaṃ vanditvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
analyzed: bhikkhu saṅghassa detha iti vatvā sayam pi bhagavantam vanditvā ekamantam nisīdiṃsu
translated: they gave to the Community of Bhikkhus. After they had thus spoken, they paid homage to the Blessed One and sat down at one side.

original: Sāvatthiyā kosalesu cārikaṃ pakkamissatītiādi sabbaṃ majjhimapadesavasenava vuttaṃ.
analyzed: sāvatthiyā kosalesu cārikam pakkamissati itiādi sabbam majjhima padesa vasena eva vuttam
translated: “He will set out on tour in the Kosalan countryside from Sāvatthī” and so on is all said according to the Middle Land.

original: Kasmā? Niyatattā. Bhagavato hi cārikācaraṇampi aruṇuṭṭhāpanampi niyataṃ, majjhimapadeseyeva
analyzed: kasmā niyata ttā bhagavataḥ hi cārikā caraṇam pi niyatam majjhima padeseya iva
translated: Why? Because it is certain. For the Blessed One’s going on tour and his rising of the sun are certain. He goes on tour only in the Middle Land,

original: cārikaṃ carati, majjhimadese aruṇaṃ uṭṭhapetīti niyatattā majjhimadesavasena vuttaṃ.
analyzed: cārikam carati majjhima dese aruṇam uṭṭhapeti iti niyata ttā majjhima desa vasena vuttam
translated: and he rises in the sun only in the Middle Land. Because it is certain, it is said according to the Middle Land.

original: Āsanne no bhagavā bhavissatīti ettha na kevalaṃ āsannattāyeva tesaṃ somanassaṃ hoti,
analyzed: āsanne naḥ bhagavā bhavissati iti ettha na kevalam āsanna ttāya iva tesam somanassam hoti
translated: “The Blessed One will be near to us” is not only because of their nearness that they were glad,🔽but also because they thought “Now we shall be able to give gifts, to make offerings of flowers, incense, etc., to hear the Dhamma,

original: atha kho “idāni dānaṃ dātuṃ gandhamālādīhi pūjaṃ kātuṃ dhammaṃ sotuṃ pañhaṃ pucchituṃ
analyzed: atha kho idāni dānam dātum gandha mālā ādīhi pūjam kātum dhammam sotum pañham pucchitum
translated: and to ask questions,

original: labhissāmā”ti tesaṃ somanassaṃ hoti.🔽Tasmātiha thapatayo sambādho gharāvāsoti thapatayo yasmā tumhākaṃ mayi dūrībhūte🔽anappakaṃ domanassaṃ, āsanne anappakaṃ somanassaṃ hoti, tasmāpi veditabbametaṃ “sambādho
analyzed: labhissāma ati tesam somanassam hoti  tasmāt ati ha thapatayaḥ sambādhaḥ thapatayaḥ tumhākam mayi dūrībhūte  anappakam domanassam āsanne anappakam somanassam hoti tasmā api veditabbam etam sambādho
translated: they are glad.🔽So, gentlemen, it is because of this that you should understand that ‘home life is crowded and dusty.’🔽For when I am far away, you have much sorrow, and when I am near, you have much gladness.

original: gharāvāso”ti. Gharāvāsassa hi dosena tumhākaṃ evaṃ hoti. Sace pana gharāvāsaṃ pahāya
analyzed: gharāvāso ti gharāvāsassa hi dosena tumhākam evam hoti sace pana gharāvāsam pahāya
translated: This is how you should understand that ‘home life is crowded and dusty.’🔽For it is because of the defects of home life that you are like this.

original: pabbajitā, atha evaṃ vo mayā saddhiṃyeva gacchantānañca āgacchantānañca taṃ na bhaveyyāti
analyzed: pabbajitāḥ atha evam vaḥ mayā saddhiṃyā iva gacchantānam ca āgacchantānam ca tam na bhaveyya ati
translated: But if you were to go forth from the home life into homelessness, then you would not be like this, for you would be going with me.”

original: imamatthaṃ dīpento evamāha. Tattha sakiñcanasapalibodhaṭṭhena sambādhatā veditabbā.
analyzed: imam attham dīpentaḥ evam āha tattha sa kiñcana sa pali bodha ṭṭhena sambādha tā veditabbā
translated: Herein, the crowdedness should be understood as the state of being encumbered with possessions and impediments.

original: Mahāvāse vasantassapi hi sakiñcanasapalibodhaṭṭhena gharāvāso sambādhova. Rajāpathoti
analyzed: mahāvāse vasantassa api hi ghara āvāso sambādhaḥ uva rajāpathaḥ ti
translated: For even if one lives in a large house, home life is crowded in the sense of being encumbered with possessions and impediments.

original: rāgadosamoharajānaṃ āpatho, āgamanaṭṭhānanti attho. Abbhokāso pabbajjāti pabbajjā
analyzed: rāga dosa moha rajānam āpathaḥ āgamanaṭṭhānanti attho abbhokāsaḥ pabbajjā ati pabbajjā
translated: The road to action is the road to passion, hatred, and delusion; the meaning is that it is the place where they come from.🔽The going forth is open space.

original: pana akiñcanaapalibodhaṭṭhena abbhokāso. Caturatanikepi hi gabbhe dvinnaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ
analyzed: pana akiñcana a palibodha ṭhena abbhokāso catur atanike pi hi gabbhe dvinnam bhikkhūnam
translated: but the open air is the state of being unencumbered with any possessions.🔽For even in a four-roofed house, if two bhikkhus sit cross-legged one opposite the other,

original: pallaṅkena pallaṅkaṃ ghaṭetvā nisinnānampi akiñcanaapalibodhaṭṭhena pabbajjā abbhokāso
analyzed: pallaṅkena pallaṅkam ghaṭetvā nisinnānam pi akiñcana a palibodha ṭṭhena pabbajjā abbhokāsaḥ
translated: the going forth is the state of being unencumbered with any possessions.

original: nāma hoti. Alañca pana vo thapatayo appamādāyāti evaṃ sambādhe gharāvāse vasantānaṃ
analyzed: nāma hoti alam ca pana vaḥ thapatayo appamādāya ati evam sambādhe ghara āvāse vasantānam
translated: “It is enough, sirs, to be heedful.” The meaning is: it is proper for you to be heedful

original: tumhākaṃ appamādameva kātuṃ yuttanti attho.
analyzed: tumhākam appamādam eva kātum yuttam ti attho
translated: while living in the crowded life of the household.

original: Ekaṃ purato ekaṃ pacchato nisīdāpemāti te kira dvepi janā sabbālaṅkārapaṭimaṇḍitesu
analyzed: ekam puratas ekam pacchatas nisīda āpema ati te kira dve api janā sabba alaṅkāra paṭimaṇḍitesu
translated: “Let one sit in front and one behind” : it seems that they had those women sit on two elephants, each fully caparisoned with all the adornments,

original: dvīsu nāgesu tā itthiyo evaṃ nisīdāpetvā rañño nāgaṃ majjhe katvā ubhosu passesu🔽gacchanti, tasmā evamāhaṃsu. Nāgopi rakkhitabboti yathā kiñci visevitaṃ na karoti,
analyzed: dvīsu nāgesu tāḥ itthiyaḥ evam nisīdāpetvā raññaḥ nāgam majjhe katvā ubhosu passesu  gacchanti tasmai nāgaḥ api rakkhitabbo ti yathā kiñci visevitam na karoti
translated: and then they themselves went along on either side of the king’s elephant, with the women sitting in the middle.🔽“The elephant should be guarded” : it should be guarded so that it does not do anything improper.

original: evaṃ rakkhitabbo hoti. Tāpi bhaginiyoti yathā pamādaṃ nāpajjanti, evaṃ rakkhitabbā
analyzed: evam rakkhitabbaḥ hoti tāḥ api bhaginiyaḥ ti yathā pamādam na āpajjanti evam rakkhitabbā
translated: “And the sisters” : they should be guarded so that they do not fall into negligence.

original: honti. Attāpīti sitahasitakathitavipekkhitādīni akarontehi attāpi rakkhitabbo hoti.
analyzed: honti attā api iti sita hasita kathita vipekkhita ādīni a karontehi attā api rakkhitabbaḥ hoti
translated: “One is one’s own protector”: if one does not laugh, talk, look about, etc., one is one’s own protector.🔽“One is one’s own protector”: if one does not laugh, talk, look about, etc., one is one’s own protector.🔽“One is one’s own protector”: if one does not laugh, talk, look about, etc., one is one’s own protector.🔽“One is one’s own protector”: if one does not laugh, talk, look about, etc., one is one’s own protector.🔽“One is one’s own protector”: if one does not laugh, talk, look about, etc., one is one’s own protector.🔽“One is one’s own protector”: if one does not laugh, talk, look about, etc., one is one’s own protector.🔽“One is one’s own protector”: if one does not laugh, talk, look about, etc., one is one’s own protector.

original: (Tehi tathā karontehi na attāpi rakkhitabbo hoti). Tathā karonto hi “sāmidubbho eso”ti🔽niggahetabbo hoti. Tasmātiha thapatayoti yasmā tumhe rājā niccaṃ rājabhaṇḍaṃ paṭicchāpeti,🔽tasmāpi sambādho gharāvāso rajāpatho. Yasmā pana paṃsukūlikabhikkhuṃ evaṃ paṭicchāpento
analyzed: tehi tathā karontehi na attā api rakkhitabbaḥ hoti tathā karonto hi sāmi dubbhaḥ eso ti  niggahetabbaḥ hoti tasmā atiha thapatayo ti yasmā tumhe rājā niccam rājabhaṇḍam paṭicchāpeti  tasmā api sambādhaḥ ghara āvāsaḥ rajāpathaḥ yasmā pana paṃsukūlika bhikkhum evam paṭicchāpento
translated: “One is one’s own protector”: if one does not laugh, talk, look about, etc., one is one’s own protector.🔽“One is one’s own protector”: if one does not laugh, talk, look about, etc., one is one’s own protector.🔽“One is one’s own protector”: if one does not laugh, talk, look about, etc., one is one’s own protector.🔽“One is one’s own protector”: if one does not laugh, talk, look about, etc., one is one’s own protector.

original: natthi, tasmā abbhokāso pabbajjā. Evaṃ sabbatthāpi alañca pana vo thapatayo appamādāya🔽appamādameva karothāti dasseti.🔽Muttacāgoti vissaṭṭhacāgo. Payatapāṇīti āgatāgatānaṃ dānatthāya dhotahattho. Vossaggaratoti
analyzed: natthi tasmai abbhokāsaḥ pabbajjā evam sabbattha api alam ca pana vaḥ thapatayo appamādāya  appamādam eva karotha ati dasseti  mutta cāgo ti vissaṭṭha cāgo payata pāṇī iti āgata āgatānam dāna atthāya dhota hatthaḥ vossagga rataḥ ti
translated: “One is one’s own protector”: if one does not laugh, talk, look about, etc., one is one’s own protector.🔽“One is one’s own protector”: if one does not laugh, talk, look about, etc., one is one’s own protector.🔽“One is one’s own protector”: if one does not laugh, talk, look about, etc., one is one’s own protector.🔽“One is one’s own protector”: if one does not laugh, talk, look about, etc., one is one’s own protector.

original: vossaggasaṅkhāte cāge rato. Yācayogoti yācitabbakayutto. Dānasaṃvibhāgaratoti dānena
analyzed: vossagga saṅkhāte cāge rataḥ yāca yogo ti yācitabbaka yuttaḥ dāna saṃvibhāga rataḥ iti dānena
translated: “One is one’s own protector”: if one does not laugh, talk, look about, etc., one is one’s own protector.🔽“One is one’s own protector”: if one does not laugh, talk

original: ceva appamattakampi kiñci laddhā tatopi saṃvibhāge rato. Appaṭivibhattanti “idaṃ
analyzed: ca iva appamattakam pi kiñci laddhā tatas pi saṃvibhāge idam
translated: and he was pleased to share whatever he had received, even if it was only a little.

original: amhākaṃ bhavissati, idaṃ bhikkhūna”nti evaṃ akatavibhāgaṃ, sabbaṃ dātabbameva hutvā ṭhitanti attho.
analyzed: amhākam bhavissati idam bhikkhūnam ti evam akata vibhāgam sabbam dātabbam eva hutvā ṭhitanti attho
translated: Not shared: not shared out thus, “This is for us, this for the bhikkhus.” The meaning is: it was all there to be given.

original: 7. Veḷudvāreyyasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: veḷudvāreyya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Discussion of the Veḷudvāra Sutta

original: 1003. Sattame veḷudvāranti gāmadvāre paveṇiāgatassa veḷugacchassa atthitāya evaṃladdhanāmo🔽gāmo. Attupanāyikanti attani upanetabbaṃ. Samphabhāsenāti amantabhāsena. Samphappalāpabhāsenāti
analyzed: sattame gāma dvāre paveṇi āgatassa veḷu gacchassa atthitāya evaṃladdha nāmo  gāmaḥ attupanāyikanti attani upanetabbam sampha bhāsena ati amanta bhāsena samphappalāpa bhāsena ati
translated: In the seventh sutta, Veḷudvāra is the name of a village that had a bamboo grove at the village gate.

original: samphappalāpasambhāsena niratthakena aññāṇavacanenāti attho.
analyzed: sampha ppalāpa sambhāsena niratthakena aññāṇa vacanena ati atthaḥ
translated: Attupanāyika: to be brought to oneself. Samphappalāpabhāsena: with talk that is not worth talking about. The meaning is: with talk that is aimless and foolish.

original: 8-9. Paṭhamagiñjakāvasathasuttādivaṇṇanā🔽1004-5. Aṭṭhame ñātiketi ekaṃ taḷākaṃ nissāya dvinnaṃ cūḷapitimahāpitiputtānaṃ dve
analyzed: aṭṭhame ñātika iti ekam taḷākam nissāya dvinnam cūḷapiti mahāpiti puttānam dve
translated: The Discussion of the First Giñjakāvasatha Sutta, etc.🔽In the eighth sutta, ñāti is the name of a village near a lake. The two villages belonged to two brothers, Cūḷa-Piti and Mahā-Piti.

original: gāmā, tesu ekasmiṃ gāmake. Giñjakāvasatheti iṭṭhakāmaye āvasathe. Orambhāgiyānanti
analyzed: gāmā tesu ekasmin gāmake giñjaka āvasatha iti iṭṭha kāmaye āvasathe
translated: Giñjakāvasatha: a house built of bricks. Orambhāgiyānīti:

original: heṭṭhābhāgiyānaṃ, kāmabhaveyeva paṭisandhiggāhāpakānanti attho. Oranti laddhanāmehi
analyzed: heṭṭhābhāgiyānam laddha nāmehi
translated: and they are called “lower fetters” because they are the fetters that take up rebirth-linking in the sense-desire becoming.

original: vā tīhi maggehi pahātabbānītipi orambhāgiyāni. Tattha kāmacchando byāpādoti imāni🔽dve samāpattiyā vā avikkhambhitāni maggena vā asamucchinnāni nibbattivasena uddhaṃ
analyzed: vā tīhi maggehi pahātabbāni orambhāgiyāni tattha kāmacchandaḥ byāpādaḥ ti imāni  dve samāpattiyā vā a vikkhambhitāni maggena vā asamucchinnāni nibbatti vasena uddhaṃ
translated: Or alternatively, they are called “lower” because they are to be abandoned by the three lower paths.🔽Herein, the two, namely, sensual desire and ill will,

original: bhāgaṃ rūpabhavaṃ arūpabhavaṃ vā gantuṃ na denti. Sakkāyadiṭṭhiādīni tīṇi tattha
analyzed: bhāgam rūpa bhavam arūpa bhavam vā gantum na denti sakkāya diṭṭhi ādīni tīṇi tattha
translated: are not suppressed by the attainment and are not severed by the path. They do not allow the person to go to a rebirth in the upper, that is, fine-material or immaterial, becoming.

original: nibbattampi ānetvā puna idheva nibbattāpentīti sabbānipi orambhāgiyāneva. Anāvattidhammoti
analyzed: nibbattam pi ānetvā puna idha iva nibbattāpenti iti sabbāni pi orambhāgiyāni eva an āvatti dhammo ti
translated: The three, namely, personality view, etc., bring him back again from the rebirth to this very state of existence. So all five are “lower” .

original: paṭisandhivasena anāgamanasabhāvo.🔽Rāgadosamohānaṃ tanuttāti ettha kadāci uppattiyā ca pariyuṭṭhānamandatāya cāti dvedhāpi
analyzed: paṭisandhi vasena an āgamana sabhāvaḥ  rāga dosa mohānam ettha kadāci uppattiyā ca pariyuṭṭhāna manda tāya ca ati dvedhā api
translated: He is incapable of retrogressing : he is incapable of coming back by rebirth-linking.

original: tanubhāvo veditabbo. Sakadāgāmissa hi puthujjanānaṃ viya abhiṇhaṃ rāgādayo na uppajjanti,
analyzed: tanu bhāvaḥ veditabbo sakadāgāmissa hi puthujjanānam viya abhiṇham rāga ādayaḥ na uppajjanti
translated: As to the words, “having weakened greed, hatred, and delusion” , it should be understood that the weakening is twofold, as weakening of occurrence and weakening of latent tendency.

original: kadāci karahaci uppajjanti. Uppajjamānā ca na puthujjanānaṃ viya bahalabahalā uppajjanti,
analyzed: kadāci karahaci uppajjanti uppajjamānā ca na puthujjanānam viya bahala bahalāḥ uppajjanti
translated: They arise only now and then. And when they arise, they do not arise in a strong form, as they do in the case of ordinary men.

original: makkhipattaṃ viya tanukā uppajjanti. Dīghabhāṇakatipiṭakamahāsīvatthero panāha –
analyzed: makkhi pattam viya tanukāḥ uppajjanti dīghabhāṇaka tipiṭaka mahāsīva theraḥ pana āha
translated: They arise in a weak form, like a fly’s footstep on water. But the Elder Mahā-Sīva, a Dīgha-bhāṇaka and a master of the three Piṭakas, said:

original: “yasmā sakadāgāmissa puttadhītaro honti, orodhā ca honti, tasmā bahalā kilesā. Idaṃ
analyzed: yasmā sakadāgāmissa putta dhītaraḥ honti orodhā ca honti tasmā bahalā kilesāḥ idam
translated: “The defilements are strong in the case of the once-returner because he has a son and daughter and because he has fields and land.

original: pana bhavatanukavasena kathita”nti. Taṃ aṭṭhakathāyaṃ “sotāpannassa satta bhave ṭhapetvā
analyzed: pana bhava tanuka vasena kathitan ti tam aṭṭhakathāyam sotāpannassa satta bhave ṭhapetvā
translated: This is said in terms of the weakness of his becoming.🔽In the case of the stream-enterer, there is no weakness of becoming in the eighth existence,

original: aṭṭhame bhave bhavatanukaṃ natthi, sakadāgāmissa dve bhave ṭhapetvā pañcasu bhavesu
analyzed: aṭṭhame bhave bhava tanukam natthi sakadāgāmissa dve bhave ṭhapetvā pañcasu bhavesu
translated: in the case of the once-returner, in the five existences,

original: bhavatanukaṃ natthi, anāgāmissa rūpārūpabhavaṃ ṭhapetvā kāmabhave bhavatanukaṃ natthi,
analyzed: bhava tanukam natthi anāgāmissa rūpa arūpa bhavam ṭhapetvā kāma bhave bhava tanukam natthi
translated: in the case of the non-returner, in the sense-desire realm, and

original: khīṇāsavassa kismiñci bhave bhavatanukaṃ natthī”ti vuttattā paṭikkhittaṃ hoti.
analyzed: khīṇāsavassa kismiñci bhave bhava tanukam natthi iti vutta ttā paṭikkhittam hoti
translated: in the case of the arahat, in any existence.” This is contradicted by the commentary, which says:

original: Imaṃ lokanti imaṃ kāmāvacaralokaṃ sandhāya vuttaṃ. Ayañhettha adhippāyo – sace hi
analyzed: imam lokam ti imam kāmāvacara lokam sandhāya vuttam ayam ha ittha adhippāyaḥ sace hi
translated: “The words ‘in this world’ refer to the sense-desire world. The intention is this: if a stream-enterer were to be reborn in the sense-desire world seven times,

original: manussesu sakadāgāmiphalaṃ patto devesu nibbattitvā arahattaṃ sacchikaroti, iccetaṃ🔽kusalaṃ. Asakkonto pana avassaṃ manussalokaṃ āgantvā sacchikaroti. Devesu sakadāgāmiphalaṃ
analyzed: manussesu sakadāgāmi phalam pattaḥ devesu nibbattitvā arahattam sacchikaroti icca etam  kusalam a sakkontaḥ pana avassam manussa lokam āgantvā sacchikaroti devesu sakadāgāmi phalam
translated: If he attains the fruit of once-returner in the human world and is reborn in the deva world, and then realizes the state of arahantship, that is good.🔽But if he cannot do so, he will certainly come to the human world and realize it.

original: pattopi sace manussesu nibbattitvā arahattaṃ sacchikaroti, iccetaṃ kusalaṃ. Asakkonto
analyzed: pattaḥ api sace manussesu nibbattitvā arahattam sacchikaroti icca etam kusalam a sakkontaḥ
translated: If he attains the fruit of once-returner in the deva world and is reborn in the human world, and then realizes the state of arahantship, that is good.

original: pana avassaṃ devalokaṃ gantvā sacchikarotīti.
analyzed: pana avassam deva lokam gantvā sacchikaroti iti
translated: But if he cannot do so, he will certainly go to the deva world and realize it.

original: Vinipatanaṃ vinipāto, nāssa vinipāto dhammoti avinipātadhammo, catūsu apāyesu avinipātanasabhāvoti🔽attho. Niyatoti dhammaniyāmena niyato. Sambodhiparāyaṇoti uparimaggattayasaṅkhātā
analyzed: vinipatanam vinipātaḥ na assa vinipātaḥ dhammo ti a vinipāta dhammo catūsu apāyesu a vinipātana sabhāvo ti  atthaḥ niyatoti dhamma niyāmena niyataḥ sambodhi parāyaṇaḥ ti upari magga ttaya saṅkhātā
translated: “Non-fall” is vinipāta. He has no vinipāta, thus he is avinipātadhammo. The meaning is: he has no nature of falling into the four lower worlds.🔽“Assured” means assured by the law of dhammas. “Having as his goal supreme enlightenment” means that his going, his course, his destination is the supreme enlightenment consisting of the three higher paths.

original: sambodhi paraṃ ayanaṃ assa gati paṭisaraṇaṃ avassaṃ pattabbāti sambodhiparāyaṇo.
analyzed: sambodhi param ayanam assa gati paṭisaraṇam a vassam pattabbā ati sambodhi parāyaṇaḥ
translated: He will certainly attain it.

original: Vihesāvesāti tesaṃ tesaṃ ñāṇagatiṃ ñāṇūpapattiṃ ñāṇābhisamparāyaṃ olokentassa kāyakilamathova
analyzed: tesam tesam ñāṇa gatim ñāṇa upapattim ñāṇa abhisamparāyam olokentassa kāya kilamathā uva
translated: “Affliction” means the affliction of bodily fatigue.

original: esa, ānanda, tathāgatassāti dīpeti. Cittavihesā pana buddhānaṃ natthi.
analyzed: esaḥ ānanda tathāgatassa ati dīpeti citta vihesā pana buddhānam natthi
translated: But there is no obstruction to the Buddhas’ knowledge.

original: Dhammādāsanti dhammamayaṃ ādāsaṃ. Yenāti yena dhammādāsena samannāgato. Khīṇāpāyaduggativinipātoti
analyzed: dhamma ādāsanti dhamma mayam ādāsam yena ati yena dhamma ādāsena samannāgataḥ khīṇa apāya duggati vinipāto ti
translated: Dhammādāsanti dhammamayaṃ ādāsaṃ. Yenāti yena dhammādāsena samannāgato. Khīṇāpāyaduggativinipātoti

original: idaṃ nirayādīnaṃyeva vevacanavaseneva vuttaṃ. Nirayādayo hi vaḍḍhisaṅkhātato ayato
analyzed: idam vevacana vasena iva vuttam niraya ādayaḥ hi vaḍḍhi saṅkhātataḥ ayataḥ
translated: this is said by way of synonyms for hell, etc., for hell, etc., are called apāya because of the absence of expansion,

original: apetattā apāyo, dukkhassa gati paṭisaraṇanti. Duggati, dukkaṭakārino ettha vivasā
analyzed: apeta ttā apāyaḥ dukkhassa gati paṭisaraṇanti duggati dukkaṭa kārinaḥ ettha vivasā
translated: because of the absence of going there again, and because of the absence of refuge, respectively. They are called duggati because of the going of the wicked there,

original: nipatantīti vinipāto. Navamaṃ uttānameva.
analyzed: nipatanti iti vinipātaḥ navamam uttānam eva
translated: and they are called vinipāta because of the falling there of those who have done evil. The ninth is clear.

original: 10. Tatiyagiñjakāvasathasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tatiya giñjaka āvasatha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary on the Tenth Chapter

original: 1006. Dasame paropaññāsāti atirekapaññāsa. Sādhikanavutīti atirekanavuti. Chātirekānīti
analyzed: dasame sādhika navuti iti atireka navuti cha atirekāni iti
translated: Paropaññāsāti atirekapaññāsa. Sādhikanavutīti atirekanavuti. Chātirekānīti

original: chahi adhikāni. So kira gāmo kiñcāpi nātimahā ahosi, ariyasāvakā panettha bahū. Tattha
analyzed: chahi adhikāni saḥ kira gāmaḥ kiñca api na atimahā ahosi ariya sāvakā pana ittha bahū tattha
translated: chahi adhikāni. So kira gāmo kiñcāpi nātimahā ahosi, ariyasāvakā panettha bahū. Tattha

original: tattha ahivātarogena ekappahāreneva catuvīsati pāṇasatasahassāni kālamakaṃsu, tesu
analyzed: tattha ahi vāta rogena eka ppahārena iva catuvīsati pāṇa sata sahassāni kālam akaṃsu tesu
translated: tattha ahivātarogena ekappahāreneva catuvīsati pāṇasatasahassāni kālamakaṃsu, tesu

original: ariyasāvakā ettakā nāma ahesuṃ. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: ariya sāvakāḥ ettakāḥ nāma ahesum sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: and so many were the Noble Disciples. The rest is clear in every instance.

original: Veḷudvāravaggo paṭhamo.
analyzed: veḷudvāra vaggo paṭhamo
translated: The first sub-chapter on the Bamboo Grove is finished.

original: 2. Rājakārāmavaggo
analyzed: rāja kārāma vaggo
translated: THE SUB-CHAPTER ON THE KING’S PARK

original: 1. Sahassabhikkhunisaṅghasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: sahassa bhikkhuni saṅgha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: THE THOUSAND-BIKKHU SANGHA

original: 1007. Dutiyassa paṭhame rājakārāmeti raññā kāritattā evaṃ laddhanāme ārāme, taṃ raññā
analyzed: dutiyassa paṭhame rājakārāma iti raññā kārita ttā evam laddha nāme ārāme tam raññā
translated: In the first of the second sub-chapter, the King’s Park is so called because it was made by King Pasenadi Kosala.

analyzed: pasenadi kosalena katam paṭhama bodhiyam kira satthāram disvā
translated: It seems that when the monks saw the Teacher had attained gain and fame,

analyzed: titthiyā cintayiṃsu samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ lābha ggaya sagga patto na kho pana esa aññam kiñci

analyzed: sīlam vā samādhim vā nissāya evam bhūmi sīsam pana tena gahitam
translated: but he has not attained it by virtue of any virtue or concentration. He has attained it by virtue of the earth-essence he has taken.

analyzed: te attano attano upaṭṭhāke samādapetvā sata sahassa matte kahāpaṇe labhitvā te ādāya
translated: they took them

analyzed: rañño santikam agamaṃsu rājā kim etat ti pucchi mayam jetavana samīpe titthiya ārāmam  karoma sace samaṇaḥ gotamaḥ vā samaṇassa gotamassa sāvakāḥ vā āgantvā vāressanti vāretum
translated: went to the King. The King asked, “What is this?” (They said,) “We are building a heretical monastery near Jeta’s Wood,🔽if the ascetic Gotama or the ascetic Gotama’s disciples come, they can stop us.”🔽

original: mā adatthāti lañjaṃ adaṃsu. Rājā lañjaṃ gahetvā “gacchatha kārethā”ti āha.
analyzed: mā adattha ati lañjam rājā lañjam gahetvā gacchatha kāretha iti āha
translated: and went to the king. The king asked, “What is this?” They said, “We are building a heretical monastery near Jeta’s Grove. If the monk Gotama or the disciples of the monk Gotama should come and object, we have given a bribe to prevent them from objecting.” The king took the bribe and said, “Go and build.”

original: Te gantvā, attano upaṭṭhākehi dabbasambhāre āharāpetvā, thambhussāpanādīni karontā,

translated: They went and had their supporters bring building materials, and as they were driving in the posts and so on,

translated: and asked, “Ānanda, what is this great noise and racket? It sounds like fishermen netting fish.”

analyzed: titthiyāḥ bhante jetavana samīpe titthiya ārāmam karonti iti ānanda ime sāsanena paṭiviruddhā

translated: will make the Community of monks live uncomfortably. Report this to the king and prevent them from building.”

original: Thero bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ gantvā rājadvāre aṭṭhāsi. Rañño “therā, deva, āgatā”ti
analyzed: theraḥ bhikkhu saṅghena saddhim gantvā rājadvāre aṭṭhāsi raññaḥ therāḥ deva āgatā ati

analyzed: ārocayiṃsu na bhante rājā nikkhanto ti satthā attanaḥ
translated: saying, “Reverend Sir, the king does not come out.”

original: rajje ṭhatvā kālaṃ kātuṃ na labhissatī”ti.🔽Dutiyadivase ca sāmaṃyeva bhikkhusaṅghaparivāro gantvā rājadvāre aṭṭhāsi. Rājā “satthā
analyzed: rajje ṭhatvā kālam kātum na labhissati iti  dutiya divase ca sāmaṃyā iva bhikkhu saṅgha parivāraḥ gantvā rājadvāre aṭṭhāsi rājā satthā
translated: The Teacher at once made this prediction, “He will not be able to die in his own bed.”

original: āgato”ti sutvā nikkhamitvā, nivesanaṃ pavesetvā, sārapallaṅke nisīdāpetvā, yāgukhajjakaṃ

When the Teacher had finished eating, he said, “King, you have a great many enemies.”

original: adāsi. Satthā paribhuttayāgukhādanīyo “yāva bhattaṃ niṭṭhāti, tāva satthu santike
analyzed: adāsi satthā paribhutta yāgu khādanīyaḥ yāva bhattam niṭṭhāti tāva satthu santike

Is not this a great wrong?”🔽“Reverend Sir, I have no enemies whatever.”🔽“Great king, you have no enemies whatever, and yet you have seized the treasurer and thrown him into prison. Is not this a great wrong?”🔽“Reverend Sir, I have no enemies whatever.”

original: nisīdissāmī”ti āgantvā nisinnaṃ rājānaṃ “tayā, mahārāja, idaṃ nāma kata”nti avatvā,🔽“kāraṇeneva naṃ saññāpessāmī”ti idaṃ atītakāraṇaṃ āhari – mahārāja, pabbajite nāma
analyzed: nisīdissāmi iti āgantvā nisinnam rājānam tayā mahā rāja idam nāma katam iti avatvā  kāraṇena iva nam saññāpessāmi iti idam atīta kāraṇam āhari mahā rāja pabbajite nāma
translated: and sat down. He did not say to the king, who was sitting down after coming, “Great king, this and this was done by you,”

analyzed: aññamaññam yujjhāpetum na vaṭṭati atīte pi isayaḥ aññamaññam yujjhāpetvā saha raṭṭhena

analyzed: rājā samuddam paviṭṭhaḥ iti kadā bhagavā iti

analyzed: tumhe iti katham vaḍḍhetvā na tumhe attanā uva manena nikkhamissatha ati hattha ādīsu

translated: and rolling them along, they went to the king’s gate. The king said, “What is this, your majesty?

translated: sent out men and had the ascetics removed.

analyzed: te bahis ṭhitā kim nu khalu da tvā labhiṃsu iti olokayamānāḥ idam nāma ati disvā
translated: The ascetics stood outside and looked to see what the king had given them. When they saw what it was, they said, “We will

analyzed: lañjam da tvā puna gaṇhissāma iti iddhiyā sovaṇṇa mayam ratha pañjaram māpetvā ādāya
translated: give a bribe and get it back.” By their psychic power they made a golden palanquin, and taking it with them,

analyzed: rājā disvā tuṭṭhaḥ kim bhante kātabbanti āha mahā rāja amhākam rukkha mūle
translated: they came back. When the king saw it, he was pleased, and he asked, “What shall I do, Reverend Sirs?”

analyzed: aññaḥ isi gaṇaḥ nisinnaḥ tam naḥ rukkha mūlam dāpehi iti rājā purise pesetvā te nikkaḍḍhāpesi
translated: “Great king,” they said, “there is a group of other ascetics sitting at the tree-root that belongs to us. Please have them removed.” The king sent out men and had them removed.

original: Tāpasā aññamaññaṃ kalahaṃ katvā, “ananucchavikaṃ amhehi kata”nti vippaṭisārino hutvā🔽pabbatapādameva agamaṃsu. Tato devatā “ayaṃ rājā dvinnaṃ isigaṇānaṃ hatthato lañjaṃ
analyzed: tāpasāḥ aññamaññam kalaham katvā ananucchavikam amhehi katanti vippaṭisārinaḥ hutvā  pabbata pādam eva agamaṃsu tatas devatāḥ ayam rājā dvinnam isi gaṇānam hatthataḥ lañjam
translated: The seers, quarrelling with each other, became remorseful, thinking, “This is not proper for us to do.”

analyzed: gahetvā aññamaññam kalaham kārāpesi iti kujjhitvā mahā samuddaṃ ubbaṭṭetvā tassa raññaḥ
translated: So they returned to the foot of the mountain. Then the deities, angry because the king had taken advantage of the quarrel between the two groups of seers,
