analyzed: vijitam yojana sahassa matta ṭṭhānam samuddam eva akaṃsu iti
translated: caused the great ocean to overflow and flooded the whole of the king’s realm, a thousand leagues in extent.

original: “Isīnamantaraṃ katvā, bharurājāti me sutaṃ;
analyzed: isīnam antaram katvā me sutam
translated: “The king called Bharata, I have heard,

original: Ucchinno saha raṭṭhehi, sa rājā vibhavaṅgato”ti. –
analyzed: ucchinnaḥ saha raṭṭhehi sa rājā
translated: Was destroyed with his realm, having caused a quarrel among the seers.”

original: Evaṃ bhagavatā imasmiṃ atīte dassite yasmā buddhānaṃ nāma kathā okappaniyā hoti,
analyzed: evam bhagavatā imasmin atīte dassite yasmā buddhānam nāma kathā okappaniyā hoti
translated: When the Exalted One had thus shown the past, since it is customary for Buddhas to refer to themselves,

analyzed: tasmai rājā attano kiriyam sallakkhetvā an upadhāretvā mayā a kattabbam kammam
translated: “The king reflected, ‘I have done what should not be done. I have not considered and reflected.

original: “gacchatha, bhaṇe, titthiye nikkaḍḍhathā”ti nikkaḍḍhāpetvā cintesi – “mayā kārito
analyzed: gacchatha bhaṇe titthiye nikkaḍḍhatha ati nikkaḍḍhāpetvā cintesi mayā kāritaḥ
translated: “Go, men, and expel the sectarians.” Having them expelled, he thought, “I have done what should not be done.

analyzed: vihāraḥ nāma natthi tasmiṃ yeva ṭhāne vihāram kāressāmi iti tesam dabba sambhāre pi a datvā
translated: There is no dwelling here. I will build a dwelling right here.” And without giving them the building materials,

original: vihāraṃ kāresi. Taṃ sandhāyetaṃ vuttaṃ.
analyzed: vihāram kāresi tam sandhāya itam vuttam
translated: he had a dwelling built. That is what is referred to here.

original: 2-3. Brāhmaṇasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Brahmana sutta, etc.

original: 1008-9. Dutiye udayagāmininti attano samaye vaḍḍhigāminiṃ. Maraṇaṃ āgameyyāsīti maraṇaṃ iccheyyāsi, pattheyyāsi vā. Tatiyaṃ uttānameva.
analyzed: dutiye udaya gāminim ti attano samaye vaḍḍhi gāminim maraṇam āgameyyāsi iti maraṇam iccheyyāsi pattheyyāsi vā tatiyam uttānam eva
translated: In the second , “leading to growth” : leading to increase in one’s own time. “You would welcome death” : you would wish for death, you would long for death. The third is clear.

original: 4. Duggatibhayasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: duggati bhaya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Fear of Ill Conduct sutta

original: 1010. Catutthe sabbaduggatibhayaṃ samatikkantoti manussadobhaggaṃ paṭikkhittaṃ.
analyzed: catutthe sabba duggati bhayam samatikkanto ti manussa dosa bhaggam paṭikkhittaṃ
translated: In the fourth , “he has gone beyond the fear of all the states of deprivation” : the human state of deprivation is excluded.

original: 5. Duggativinipātabhayasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: duggati vinipāta bhaya sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the Fear of the Depths of Hell sutta

original: 1011. Pañcame sabbaduggativinipātabhayaṃ samatikkantoti manussadobhaggena saddhiṃ cattāro apāyā paṭikkhittā.🔽6. Paṭhamamittāmaccasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: pañcame sabba duggati vinipāta bhayam samatikkanto ti manussa dobhaggena saddhim cattāro apāyā paṭikkhittā  paṭhama mittāmacca sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: In the fifth , “he has gone beyond the fear of all the states of deprivation and the depths of hell” : the four states of deprivation together with the human state of deprivation are excluded.🔽The explanation of the first sutta on friends and companions

original: 1012. Chaṭṭhe mittāti aññamaññassa gehe āmisaparibhogavasena vohāramittā. Amaccāti
analyzed: chaṭṭhe mittā ati aññamaññassa gehe āmisa paribhoga vasena vohāra mittā amaccā ati
translated: In the sixth , “friends” : friends in the sense of enjoying material things in each other’s houses. “Companions” :

original: āmantanapaṭimantanairiyāpathādīsu ekato pavattakiccā. Ñātīti sassusasurapakkhikā.
analyzed: āmantana paṭimantana eriyāpatha ādīsu ekatas pavatta kiccā ñātī iti sassusasurapakkhikā
translated: and the duties of inviting, of wearing the mantle, of deportment, etc., are performed together. Kinsmen are those on the mother’s and father’s side.

original: Sālohitāti samānalohitā bhātibhaginimātulādayo.
analyzed: sālohita ati samāna lohitāḥ bhāti bhagini mātula ādayaḥ
translated: Blood relations are those related by blood, such as aunt, uncle, etc.

original: 7. Dutiyamittāmaccasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya mittāmacca sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Exposition of the Second Chapter

original: 1013. Sattame aññathattaṃ nāma pasādaññathattaṃ bhāvaññathattaṃ gatiaññathattaṃ lakkhaṇaññathattaṃ
analyzed: sattame aññathattam nāma pasāda ññathattam bhāva ññathattam gati aññathattam lakkhaṇa ññathattam
translated: In the seventh case, “change-of-lineage” is of several kinds: change-of-lineage of confidence, change-of-lineage of being, change-of-lineage of mode, change-of-lineage of characteristic,

original: vipariṇāmaññathattanti anekavidhaṃ. Tattha mahābhūtesu bhāvaññathattaṃ adhippetaṃ.
analyzed: vipariṇāma ñathattanti anekavidham tattha mahābhūtesu bhāva ñathattam adhippetam
translated: and change-of-lineage of alteration. Herein, change-of-lineage of being is intended.

original: Suvaṇṇādibhāvena hi ghanasaṇṭhitāya pathavidhātuyā vilīyitvā udakabhāvaṃ āpajjamānāya
analyzed: suvaṇṇa ādi bhāvena hi ghana saṇṭhitāya pathavi dhātuyā vilīyitvā udaka bhāvam āpajjamānāya
translated: For when the earth element, which is compact and solid in the form of gold, etc., melts and becomes water,

original: purimabhāvo vigacchati, bhāvaññathattaṃ paññāyati. Lakkhaṇaṃ pana na vigacchati,
analyzed: purima bhāvaḥ vigacchati bhāvaññathattam paññāyati lakkhaṇam pana na vigacchati
translated: its previous being disappears and change-of-lineage of being is evident. But the characteristic does not disappear;

original: kakkhaḷalakkhaṇāva hoti. Ucchurasādibhāvena ca yūsākārasaṇṭhitāya āpodhātuyā sussitvā
analyzed: hoti ucchu rasa ādi bhāvena ca yūsa ākāra saṇṭhitāya āpas dhātuyā sussitvā
translated: it remains the characteristic of hardness. And when the water element, which is fluid in the form of sap, etc., dries up and becomes the earth element,

original: ghanapathavibhāvaṃ āpajjamānāya purimabhāvo vigacchati, bhāvaññathattaṃ paññāyati.
analyzed: ghana pathavi bhāvam āpajjamānāya purima bhāvaḥ vigacchati bhāvaññathattam paññāyati
translated: its previous being disappears and change-of-lineage of being is evident.

original: Lakkhaṇaṃ pana na vigacchati, ābandhanalakkhaṇāva hoti. Tatridaṃ aññathattanti ettha
analyzed: lakkhaṇam pana na vigacchati ābandhana lakkhaṇā ava hoti tatridam aññathattanti ettha
translated: But the characteristic of binding does not depart from it; it remains the characteristic of binding.🔽Herein, the “difference” intended is difference in destiny; for that does not exist in the case of a noble disciple.

original: pana gatiaññathattaṃ adhippetaṃ, tañhi ariyasāvakassa natthi. Pasādaññathattampi
analyzed: pana gati aññathattam adhippetam tat hi ariya sāvakassa natthi pasāda aññathattam pi
translated: And the difference in the state of being a lay follower does not exist either.

original: natthiyeva, idha pana pasādaphalaṃ pakāsetuṃ gatiaññathattameva dassitaṃ. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: natthiyā iva idha pana pasāda phalam pakāsetum gati aññathattam eva dassitam sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: But here only the difference in destiny is shown in order to illustrate the fruit of confidence. The rest is clear in all instances.

original: Rājakārāmavaggo dutiyo.🔽3. Saraṇānivaggo
analyzed: rājakārāma vaggo dutiyaḥ  saraṇā nivaggaḥ
translated: The Second Chapter, “The Royal Park.”🔽The Chapter on Refuges

original: 1-2. Paṭhamamahānāmasuttādivaṇṇanā
translated: The First Discourse on Mahanama🔽In the first of the third group, “prosperous” means rich with oil, honey, molasses, and so on.

original: 1017-18. Tatiyassa paṭhame iddhanti telamadhuphāṇitādīhi samiddhaṃ. Phītanti hatthūpagasīsūpagagīvūpagādialaṅkāravasena🔽supupphitaṃ. Ākiṇṇamanussanti nirantaramanussaṃ. Sambādhabyūhanti byūhā vuccanti
analyzed: tatiyassa paṭhame iddhanti tela madhu phāṇita ādīhi samiddham phītam ti hatthūpaga sīsūpaga gīvūpaga ādi alaṅkāra vasena  su pupphitam ākiṇṇa manussanti nirantara manussam sambādha byūhanti byūhāḥ vuccanti
translated: “Flourishing” means well-flowered with ornaments such as armlets, earrings, necklaces, and so on.🔽“Crowded with people” means with people packed in.🔽“With many obstructions” : obstructions are called🔽the shadows of those who are not dispassionate, which come down on the path as soon as one enters it.

original: avinibbiddharacchāyo, yā paviṭṭhamaggeneva niggacchanti, tā sambādhā byūhā bahukā
analyzed: a vinibbiddha racchāyaḥ yā paviṭṭha maggena iva niggacchanti tā sambādhāḥ byūhāḥ bahukā
translated: “Many obstructions” means many obstructions.

original: etthāti sambādhabyūhaṃ. Imināpi nagarassa ghanavāsameva dīpeti. Bhantenāti ito cito
analyzed: ettha ati sambādha byūham iminā api nagarassa ghana vāsam eva dīpeti bhantena ati itas citas
translated: ‘Here’ means in the crowded market. This also shows the city’s close living. ‘Rotten’ means

original: ca paribbhamantena uddhatacārinā. Dutiyaṃ uttānameva.
analyzed: ca paribbhamantena uddhata cārinā dutiyam uttānam eva
translated: ‘Here’ means in the crowded city. This also shows the city to be a close dwelling. ‘Broken down’: moving about here and there, acting in a restless manner. The second is straightforward.

original: 3. Godhasakkasuttavaṇṇanā🔽1019. Tatiye bhagavāva etaṃ jāneyya etehi dhammehi samannāgataṃ vā asamannāgataṃ🔽vāti idaṃ so sakko tīhi dhammehi samannāgatassa puggalassa sotāpannabhāvaṃ, catūhi
analyzed: godha sakka sutta vaṇṇanā  tatiye bhagavā vai etam jāneyya etehi dhammehi samannāgatam vā a samannāgatam  vāti idam so sakko tīhi dhammehi samannāgatassa puggalassa sotāpanna bhāvam catūhi
translated: The Commentary on the Godha Sutta

original: vā dhammehi samannāgatassa sotāpannabhāvaṃ bhagavāva jānātīti adhippāyena āha.🔽Kocideva dhammasamuppādo uppajjeyyāti kiñcideva kāraṇaṃ uppajjeyya. Ekato assa bhagavā,🔽ekato bhikkhusaṅghoti yasmiṃ kāraṇe uppanne bhagavā bhikkhusaṅghena nānāladdhiko
analyzed: vā dhammehi samannāgatassa sotāpanna bhāvam bhagavā ava jānāti iti adhippāyena āha  kocid eva dhamma samuppādaḥ uppajjeyya ati kiñcid eva kāraṇam uppajjeyya ekatas assa bhagavā  ekatas bhikkhu saṅghaḥ ti yasmim kāraṇe uppanne bhagavā bhikkhu saṅghena nānāladdhikaḥ
translated: In the third sutta, Sakka’s intention in saying ‘The Blessed One would know whether a person is endowed with these things or not’ is that the Blessed One alone knows whether a person is a stream-enterer endowed with three things or a stream-enterer endowed with four things.

original: hutvā ekaṃ vādaṃ vadanto ekato assa, bhikkhusaṅghopi ekaṃ vadanto ekatoti attho.
analyzed: hutvā ekam vādam vadantaḥ ekatas assa bhikkhu saṅghaḥ api ekam vadantaḥ ekatas ti attho
translated: ‘Some cause for dispute might arise’: some reason might arise. ‘The Blessed One on one side, the bhikkhu-saṅgha on the other’: when some cause for dispute arises, the Blessed One, having taken one side by espousing one view, and the bhikkhu-saṅgha, having taken the other side by espousing another view, would be divided.

original: Tenevāhanti yaṃ vādaṃ tumhe vadetha, tamevāhaṃ gaṇheyyanti. Nanu ca ariyasāvakassa
analyzed: tena iva ahanti yam vādam tumhe vadetha tam eva aham gaṇheyyanti nanu ca ariya sāvakassa
translated: Hence he said: “I would take up that view which you would state.”🔽But has not the noble disciple confidence in the Triple Gem?

original: ratanattaye pasādanānattaṃ natthi, atha kasmā esa evamāhāti? Bhagavato sabbaññutāya.
analyzed: ratanattaye pasādanānattam natthi atha kasmai esaḥ evam āha ati bhagavataḥ sabbaññutāya
translated: If so, why does he say this? Because of the Blessed One’s omniscience.

original: Evañhissa hoti “bhikkhusaṅgho attano asabbaññutāya ajānitvāpi katheyya, satthu pana🔽aññāṇaṃ nāma natthī”ti. Tasmā evamāha. Aññatra kalyāṇā aññatra kusalāti kalyāṇameva
analyzed: evam hissa hoti bhikkhu saṅghaḥ attanaḥ a sabbaññu tāya a jānitvā api katheyya satthu pana  aññāṇam nāma natthi iti tasmai evam āha aññatra kalyāṇāḥ aññatra kusalāḥ ati kalyāṇam eva
translated: He thinks: “The bhikkhu-saṅgha might say this not knowing, because of their not being omniscient. But the Blessed One🔽has no ignorance.” Therefore he says this.🔽Apart from the good, apart from the wholesome: I declare only the good, only the wholesome, not apart from the good and the wholesome.

original: kusalameva vadāmi, na kalyāṇakusalavimuttanti. Apicassa anavajjanadoso esoti.
analyzed: kusalam eva vadāmi na kalyāṇa kusala vimuttan ti api ca assa anavajjana doso esaḥ ti
translated: And he has no fault of blame.

original: 4. Paṭhamasaraṇānisakkasuttavaṇṇanā🔽1020. Catutthe idha mahānāma ekacco puggaloti idaṃ na kevalaṃ saraṇāni eva apāyato
analyzed: catutthe idha mahānāma ekacco puggalo ti idam na kevalam saraṇāni eva apāyataḥ
translated: The first sutta of the group of six on the refuges.

original: mutto, imepi puggalā muttāti dassetuṃ āraddhaṃ. Mattaso nijjhānaṃ khamantīti pamāṇena
analyzed: muttaḥ ime api puggalāḥ muttā ati dassetum āraddham mattasaḥ nijjhānam khamanti iti pamāṇena
translated: In the fourth sutta, the passage beginning “Here, Mahānāma, a certain person” is introduced in order to show that not only the one who has gone for refuge is freed from the states of loss, but also these persons are freed.🔽They endure the looking on with a measure: they endure the looking on with a standard.🔽By this he shows the person who is a follower by way of the Dhamma and is on the path.

original: ca olokanaṃ khamanti. Iminā dhammānusārimaggaṭṭhapuggalaṃ dasseti. Agantā nirayanti
analyzed: ca olokanam khamanti iminā dhamma anusāri magga ṭṭha puggalam dasseti agantā nirayanti
translated: He does not go to hell.

original: maggaṭṭhapuggalo hi apāyato parimuttoti vā parimuccissatīti vā vattuṃ na vaṭṭati,
analyzed: maggaṭṭha puggalaḥ hi apāyataḥ parimuttaḥ iti vā parimuccissati iti vā vattum na vaṭṭati
translated: For it is not proper to say that a person on the path is liberated from the states of loss or will be liberated,

original: parimuccatīti pana vattuṃ vaṭṭati. Yasmā ca parimuccati, tasmā gantā nāma na hotīti,
analyzed: parimuccati iti pana vattum vaṭṭati ca parimuccati tasmai gantā nāma na hoti iti
translated: but it is proper to say that he is being liberated. And because he is being liberated, he is not called one who has gone.

original: “agantā”ti vutto, na gacchatīti attho. Saddhāmattaṃ pemamattanti iminā saddhānusārimaggaṭṭhapuggalaṃ
analyzed: agantā iti vuttaḥ na gacchati iti attho saddhā mattam pema mattam ti iminā saddhā anusāri magga ṭṭha puggalam
translated: He is called “one who has not gone,” which means he does not go. “Faith and love” : this shows the person on the path who is a faith-follower.

original: dasseti. Mahāsālāti samīpe ṭhiteva cattāro mahāsārarukkhe dassento āha. Maraṇakāle
analyzed: dasseti mahāsālā ati samīpe ṭhitā iva cattāraḥ mahāsāra rukkhe dassentaḥ āha maraṇa kāle
translated: “Great trees” : he says this, pointing to the four great sala trees standing nearby.

original: sikkhaṃ samādiyīti maraṇasamaye tīsu sikkhāsu paripūrakārī ahosīti dasseti.
analyzed: sikkham samādiyi iti maraṇa samaye tīsu sikkhāsu paripūra kārī ahosi iti dasseti
translated: “At the time of death he undertook the training” : this shows that at the time of death he fulfilled the three trainings.

original: 5. Dutiyasaraṇānisakkasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya saraṇānisakka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the second sutta in the Saranaṇi group is finished.

original: 1021. Pañcame dukkhettanti visamakhettaṃ. Dubbhūmanti ūsarabhūmiṃ loṇūpahataṃ. Khaṇḍānīti
analyzed: pañcame visama khettam dubbhūmanti ūsara bhūmim loṇūpahatam khaṇḍāni iti
translated: In the fifth sutta, “bad field” means an uneven field. “Bad soil” means a field with saline soil. “Broken” means

original: paribhinnāni. Pūtīnīti udakena temetvā pūtibhāvaṃ āpannāni. Vātātapahatānīti vātātapena
analyzed: paribhinnāni pūtīni iti udakena temetvā pūti bhāvam āpannāni vāta ātapa hatāni iti vāta ātapena
translated: cracked. “Rotten” means rotten by being soaked with water. “Burnt by wind and sun” means burnt by wind and sun.

original: hatattā nirojabhāvaṃ gatāni. Asārādānīti anādinnasārāni agahitasārāni. Asukhasayitānīti
analyzed: niroja bhāvam gatāni a sāra ādāni iti an ādinna sārāni a gahita sārāni a sukha sayitāni iti
translated: are destroyed, have become non-existent. ‘Without a core’ means without a core that has been taken out, without a core that has been grasped. ‘Not well stored’ means

original: na koṭṭhādīsu pakkhipitvā suṭṭhu ṭhapitāni. Sukhasayitānīti ṭhapitaṭṭhānato cattāro māse acalitāni.
analyzed: na koṭṭha ādīsu pakkhipitvā suṭṭhu ṭhapitāni sukhasayitāni iti ṭhapita ṭṭhānato cattāraḥ māse acalitāni
translated: not stored in a granary, etc., and well kept. ‘Well stored’ means not moved from the place of storage for four months.

original: 6. Paṭhamaanāthapiṇḍikasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paṭhama anāthapiṇḍika sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary on the First Discourse to Anathapindika

original: 1022. Chaṭṭhe ṭhānaso vedanā paṭippassambheyyāti khaṇena vedanā paṭippassambheyya.
analyzed: chaṭṭhe ṭhānasaḥ vedanā paṭippassambheyya ati khaṇena vedanā paṭippassambheyya
translated: In the sixth, ‘the feeling would be allayed in a moment’ means that the feeling would be allayed in an instant.

original: Micchāñāṇenāti micchāpaccavekkhaṇena micchāvimuttiyāti aniyyānikavimuttiyā. Tasmā
analyzed: micchā ñāṇena ati micchā paccavekkhaṇena micchā vimuttiyā ati aniyyānika vimuttiyā tasmā
translated: ‘By wrong knowledge’ means by wrong reflection. ‘By wrong deliverance’ means by a deliverance that is not emancipating. Therefore

original: saddhañca sīlañcāti gāthā vuttatthā eva. Yatra hi nāmāti yo nāma.
analyzed: saddham ca sīlam ca ati gāthā vuttatthā eva yatra hi nāma ati yaḥ nāma
translated: the verse ‘Faith and virtue’ has the same meaning as before. ‘Yatra hi nāma’ means ‘what is it that’.

original: 7. Dutiyaanāthapiṇḍikasuttavaṇṇanā🔽1023. Sattame samparāyikaṃ maraṇabhayanti samparāyahetukaṃ maraṇabhayaṃ gihisāmīcikānīti gihīnaṃ anucchavikāni. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: dutiya anāthapiṇḍika sutta vaṇṇanā  sattame samparāyikam maraṇa bhayam ti samparāya hetukam maraṇa bhayam gihi sāmīcikāni iti gihīnam anucchavikāni sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: . Commentary on the Second Discourse to Anathapindika

original: Saraṇānivaggo tatiyo.🔽4. Puññābhisandavaggo
analyzed: saraṇānivaggo tatiyaḥ 🔽puñña abhisanda vaggaḥ
translated: In the seventh, ‘the fear of death in the life to come’ means the fear of death that has the life to come as its cause. ‘The duties of householders’ means those duties that are suitable for householders. The rest is all clear.

original: 1. Paṭhamapuññābhisandasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paṭhama puñña abhisanda sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 1. The First Discourse on the Flood of Merit

original: 1027. Catutthassa paṭhame puññābhisandā kusalābhisandāti puññanadiyo kusalanadiyo. Sukhassāhārāti sukhassa paccayā.
analyzed: catutthassa paṭhame puññā abhisandā kusalā abhisandā ati puñña nadiyaḥ kusala nadiyaḥ sukhassa āhārā ati sukhassa paccayā
translated: In the first of the fourth group, the floods of merit are the same as the streams of merit, the streams of the wholesome. The nutriments of happiness are the conditions for happiness.

original: 4. Paṭhamadevapadasuttavaṇṇanā🔽1030. Catutthe devapadānīti devānaṃ ñāṇena, devassa vā ñāṇena akkantapadāni. Visuddhiyāti
analyzed: catutthe deva padāni iti devānam ñāṇena devassa vā ñāṇena akkanta padāni visuddhiyā ati
translated: 1. The First Discourse on the Divine Abodes

original: visujjhanatthāya. Pariyodapanāyāti puriyodapanatthāya jotanatthāya. Imasmiṃ sutte
analyzed: visujjhana tthāya pariyodapanāya ati puriya udapana tthāya jotana tthāya imasmin sutte
translated: In the fourth, the divine abodes are the abodes reached by the knowledge of the gods or by the knowledge of the divine. The purification is for the sake of purification. The cleansing is for the sake of prior cleansing, for the sake of illumination. In this discourse

original: cattāropi phalaṭṭhapuggalā visuddhaṭṭhena devā nāma jātā.
analyzed: cattāraḥ api phala ṭṭha puggalāḥ visuddha ṭṭhena devāḥ nāma jātā
translated: all four types of persons who have attained the fruits are called gods in the sense of being purified.

original: 8. Vassasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vassa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 1. The Discourse on the Rains

original: 1034. Aṭṭhame pāraṃgantvāti pāraṃ vuccati nibbānaṃ, taṃ patvāti attho. Āsavānaṃ khayāya
analyzed: aṭṭhame pāram gantvā ati pāram vuccati nibbānam tam patvā iti atthaḥ āsavānam khayāya
translated: In the eighth, having gone to the other shore: the other shore is called Nibbāna; the meaning is that they have reached it. They lead to the destruction of the taints

original: saṃvattantīti na paṭhamaṃ nibbānaṃ gantvā pacchā saṃvattanti, gacchamānā eva saṃvattanti.
analyzed: saṃvattanti iti na paṭhamam nibbānam gantvā pacchā saṃvattanti gacchamānāḥ eva saṃvattanti
translated: means that they do not first go to Nibbāna and then lead to it; they lead to it while going themselves.

original: Desanā pana evaṃ katā.
analyzed: desanā pana evam katā
translated: But the teaching is given in this way.

original: 10. Nandiyasakkasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: nandiya sakka sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 1. The Discourse with Nandiya the Sakyan

original: 1036. Dasame divā pavivekāya rattiṃ paṭisallānāyāti divā pavivekatthāya rattiṃ paṭisallānatthāya.
analyzed: dasame divā pavivekāya rattim paṭisallānāya ati divā paviveka tthāya rattim paṭisallāna tthāya
translated: 1036. In the tenth, “for seclusion by day and for stillness by night” means for the purpose of seclusion by day and for the purpose of stillness by night.

original: Dhammā na pātubhavantīti samathavipassanā dhammā na uppajjanti. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.🔽Puññābhisandavaggo catuttho.
analyzed: dhammā na pātubhavanti iti samatha vipassanāḥ dhammāḥ na uppajjanti sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati  puñña abhisanda vaggaḥ catutthaḥ
translated: “The ideas do not become clear” means that the ideas of serenity and insight do not arise. The rest is all clear.

original: 5. Sagāthakapuññābhisandavaggo
analyzed: sa gāthaka puñña abhisanda vaggaḥ
translated: The fourth chapter called “The Chapter on the Outcome of Merit”🔽The Chapter on the Outcome of Merit with Verses

original: 1. Paṭhamaabhiasandasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paṭhama abhiasanda sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 1. The first outcome sutta

original: 1037. Pañcamassa paṭhame asaṅkhyeyyoti āḷhakagaṇanāya asaṅkhyeyyo, yojanavasena panassa
analyzed: pañcamassa paṭhame asaṅkhyeyyaḥ ti āḷhaka gaṇanāya asaṅkhyeyyaḥ yojana vasena pana
translated: “Incalculable” : incalculable by counting in terms of “a great aeon” . But it has a count in terms of leagues.

original: saṅkhyā atthi. Bahubheravanti saviññāṇakaaviññāṇakānaṃ bheravārammaṇānaṃ vasena bahubheravaṃ.
analyzed: saṅkhyā atthi bahu bheravanti saviññāṇaka aviññāṇakānam bherava ārammaṇānam vasena bahu bheravam
translated: “With many terrors” : with many objects of terror, both with and without consciousness.

original: Puthūti bahu. Savantīti sandamānā. Upayantīti upagacchanti.
analyzed: puthūti bahu savanti iti sandamānāḥ upayanti iti upagacchanti
translated: “Many” : much. “Flowing” : flowing on. “Approaching” : approaching.

original: 2. Dutiyaabhisandasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya abhisanda sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 2. The second outcome sutta

original: 1038. Dutiye yatthimā mahānadiyo saṃsandanti samentīti yasmiṃ saṃbhajje etā mahānadiyo ekībhavanti, nirantarā bhavantīti attho.
analyzed: dutiye yatthimāḥ mahā nadiyaḥ saṃsandanti samenti iti yasmin saṃbhajje etāḥ mahā nadiyaḥ ekībhavanti nirantarāḥ bhavanti iti attho
translated: “Where these great rivers meet and flow together” : in the confluence where these great rivers become one, become uninterrupted, is the meaning.

original: 3. Tatiyaabhisandasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tatiya abhisanda sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: 3. The Third Chapter

original: 1039. Tatiye puññakāmoti puññatthiko. Kusale patiṭṭhitoti maggakusale patiṭṭhito.
analyzed: tatiye puñña kāmo ti puññatthiko kusale patiṭṭhito ti magga kusale patiṭṭhito
translated: In the third, one who desires merit is one who has the purpose of merit. He is established in what is skillful is established in the path that is skillful.

original: Bhāveti maggaṃ amatassa pattiyāti nibbānassa pāpuṇanatthaṃ arahattamaggaṃ bhāveti.
analyzed: bhāveti maggam amatassa pattiyā ati nibbānassa pāpuṇana tham arahatta maggam bhāveti
translated: He develops the path for attaining the deathless is he develops the noble path for the purpose of reaching Nibbāna.

original: Dhammasārādhigamoti dhammasāro vuccati ariyaphalaṃ dhammasāro, adhigamo assāti dhammasārādhigamo,
analyzed: dhamma sāra adhigamaḥ ti dhamma sāraḥ vuccati ariya phalam dhamma sāraḥ adhigamaḥ assa ati dhamma sāra adhigamaḥ
translated: The attainment of the essence of Dhamma is the noble fruit called the essence of Dhamma. He who has attained it is one who has attained the essence of Dhamma.

original: adhigataphaloti attho. Khaye ratoti kilesakkhaye rato.
analyzed: adhigata phalo ti attho khaye rato ti kilesa khaye rato
translated: The meaning is: he has attained the fruit. He delights in destruction is he delights in the destruction of defilements.

original: 4. Paṭhamamahaddhanasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paṭhama mahat dhana sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The First Discourse on Great Wealth🔽In the fourth, he is rich and has great wealth is he is rich and has great wealth in the seven kinds of noble wealth.

original: 1040. Catutthe aḍḍho mahaddhanoti sattavidhena ariyadhanena aḍḍho ceva mahaddhano ca. Teneva bhogena mahābhogo. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: catutthe aḍḍhaḥ mahat dhanoti sattavidhena ariya dhanena aḍḍhaḥ ca iva mahat dhano ca tena iva bhogena mahā bhogo sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: By that wealth he is a great man. The rest is all clear.

original: Sagāthakapuññābhisandavaggo pañcamo.
analyzed: sa gāthaka puñña abhisanda vaggaḥ pañcamaḥ
translated: The chapter on the outpouring of merit with verses is the fifth.

original: 6. Sappaññavaggo
analyzed: sa pañña vaggaḥ
translated: The Chapter on the Wise

original: 2. Vassaṃvuttasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: vassaṃvutta sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Discourse on the Rains Retreat

original: 1048. Chaṭṭhassa dutiye ayamadhippāyo – sotāpanno bhikkhu ettakena vosānaṃ anāpajjitvā
analyzed: chaṭṭhassa dutiye ayam adhippāyaḥ sotāpannaḥ bhikkhu ettakena vosānam an āpajjitvā
translated: The intention in the second of the sixth is this: a bhikkhu who is a stream-enterer does not reach his end with just that much.

original: tāneva indriyabalabojjhaṅgāni samodhānetvā vipassanaṃ vaḍḍhetvā sakadāgāmimaggaṃ
analyzed: tāni eva indriya bala bojjhaṅgāni samodhānetvā vipassanam vaḍḍhetvā sakadāgāmi maggam
translated: Having combined those same faculties, powers, and factors of enlightenment, and having developed insight, he will reach the fruit of once-returner.

original: pāpuṇissati, sakadāgāmī anāgāmimaggaṃ, anāgāmī arahattamagganti imamatthaṃ sandhāya
analyzed: pāpuṇissati sakadāgāmī anāgāmi maggam anāgāmī arahatta maggam ti imam attham sandhāya
translated: The once-returner will reach the fruit of non-returner, and the non-returner will reach the fruit of arahantship. With this meaning in mind,

original: bhagavatā imasmiṃ sutte sāsane tanti paveṇī kathitāti.
analyzed: bhagavatā imasmin sutte sāsane tanti paveṇī kathitā ati
translated: the Blessed One has taught this thread in the Dispensation in this sutta.”

original: 3. Dhammadinnasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dhammadinna sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: . Commentary to the Dhammadinna Sutta

original: 1049. Tatiye dhammadinnoti sattasu janesu eko. Buddhakālasmiñhi dhammadinno upāsako,
analyzed: tatiye dhammadinno ti sattasu janesu ekaḥ buddha kālasmin hi dhammadinnaḥ upāsako
translated: In the third sutta, Dhammadinna is one of the seven people. For at the time of the Buddha there were seven lay followers: the lay follower Dhammadinna,

original: visākho upāsako, uggo gahapati, citto gahapati, hatthako āḷavako, cūḷaanāthapiṇḍiko,
analyzed: visākhaḥ upāsakaḥ uggaḥ gahapati cittaḥ gahapati hatthakaḥ āḷavakaḥ cūḷa anāthapiṇḍiko
translated: the lay follower Visakha, the householder Ugga, the householder Citta, Hatthaka of Alavi, Culla Anathapindika,

original: mahāanāthapiṇḍikoti ime satta janā pañcasataupāsakaparivārā ahesuṃ. Etesu esa aññataro.
analyzed: mahāanāthapiṇḍiko ti ime satta janā pañca sata upāsaka parivārāḥ ahesuṃ etesu esa aññataro
translated: and Maha Anathapindika. These seven people had a retinue of five hundred lay followers. He was one of them.

original: Gambhīrāti dhammagambhīrā sallasuttādayo. Gambhīratthāti atthagambhīrā cetanāsuttantādayo.
analyzed: gambhīrā ati dhamma gambhīrā salla sutta ādayaḥ gambhīra atthā ati attha gambhīrā cetanā suttanta ādayaḥ
translated: “Deep” means deep in the Dhamma, such as the Sallasutta. “Deep in meaning” means deep in meaning, such as the Cetanasutta.

original: Lokuttarāti lokuttaratthadīpakā asaṅkhatasaṃyuttādayo. Suññatappaṭisaṃyuttāti sattasuññatādīpakā
analyzed: lokuttarā iti lokuttara attha dīpakāḥ asaṅkhata saṃyutta ādayaḥ suññata paṭisaṃyuttā ati satta suññatā dīpakā
translated: “Supramundane” means illuminating the supramundane meaning, such as the Asankhatasamyutta. “Emptiness-related” means illuminating the seven kinds of emptiness, such as the

original: khajjanikasuttantādayo. Upasampajja viharissāmāti paṭilabhitvā viharissāma. Evañhi
analyzed: khajjanika suttanta ādayaḥ upasampajja viharissāma ati paṭilabhitvā viharissāma evam hi
translated: Upasampajja viharissāma = we shall attain and live.

original: vo, dhammadinna, sikkhitabbanti evaṃ tumhehi candopamapaṭipadaṃ rathavinītapaṭipadaṃ🔽moneyyapaṭipadaṃ mahāariyavaṃsapaṭipadaṃ pūrentehi sikkhitabbaṃ. Iti satthā imesaṃ🔽upāsakānaṃ asayhabhāraṃ āropesi. Kasmā? Ete kira na attano bhūmiyaṃ ṭhatvā ovādaṃ🔽yāciṃsu, avisesena pana sabbabhāraṃ ukkhipituṃ samatthā viya “ovadatu no, bhante,
analyzed: vaḥ dhammadinna sikkhitabbanti evam tumhehi canda upama paṭipadam ratha vinīta paṭipadam  moneyya paṭipadam mahāariya vaṃsa paṭipadam pūrentehi sikkhitabbam iti satthā imesam  upāsakānam asayha bhāram āropesi kasmai ete kira na attanaḥ bhūmiyam ṭhatvā ovādam  yāciṃsu avisesena pana sabba bhāram ukkhipitum samatthāḥ viya ovadatu naḥ bhante
translated: Evaṃ hi vo, Dhammadinna, sikkhitabbanti = thus, O Dhammadinna, you should train yourselves. Thus, while fulfilling the practice of the moon-simile, the practice of the chariot-driver,

original: bhagavā”ti yāciṃsu. Tena tesaṃ satthā asayhabhāraṃ āropento evamāha. Na kho netanti
analyzed: bhagavā iti yāciṃsu tena tesam satthā asayha bhāram āropentaḥ evam āha na kho na itanti
translated: the practice of the ferryman, and the practice of the great noble lineage, you should train yourselves. Thus, the Teacher placed a heavy burden on these lay disciples. Why? These lay disciples, it seems, did not ask for advice while remaining in their own place; rather, they asked for advice as if they were able to carry the entire burden without distinction, saying, “Venerable Sir, may the Blessed One advise us.” Therefore, the Teacher, placing a heavy burden on them, said thus.

original: na kho etaṃ. Nakāro panettha byañjanasandhimattamevāti veditabbo. Tasmāti yasmā idāni
analyzed: na kho etam nakāraḥ pana ittha byañjana sandhimattam eva iti veditabbaḥ tasmā iti yasmai idāni
translated: Na kho netanti = not this. But the syllable na should be understood here as merely a sandhi form.

original: attano bhūmiyaṃ ṭhatvā ovādaṃ yācatha, tasmā.
analyzed: attana u bhūmiyam ṭhatvā ovādam yācatha tasmai
translated: Tasmāti = because now you ask for advice while remaining in your own place, therefore.

original: 4. Gilānasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: gilāna sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Commentary on the Discourse on the Sick Person🔽.

original: 1050. Catutthe na kho panetanti na kho amhehi etaṃ. Sappañño upāsakoti sotāpanno🔽adhippeto. Assāsanīyehi dhammehīti assāsakarehi dhammehi. Assāsatāyasmāti assāsatu🔽āyasmā. Mārisoti maraṇapaṭibaddho. Maraṇadhammoti maraṇasabhāvo. Adhimocehīti ṭhapehi.🔽Adhimocitanti ṭhapitaṃ. Evaṃ vimuttacittassāti evaṃ arahattaphalavimuttiyā vimuttacittassa.
analyzed: catutthe na kho pana itanti na kho amhehi etam sappaññaḥ upāsako ti sotāpannaḥ  adhippetaḥ assāsanīyehi dhammehi iti assāsa karehi dhammehi assāsata ayasmā ati assāsatu  mārisaḥ iti maraṇa paṭibaddhaḥ maraṇa dhammo ti maraṇa sabhāvaḥ adhimocehi iti ṭhapehi  adhimocitanti ṭhapitam evam vimutta cittassa ati evam arahatta phala vimuttiyā vimutta cittassa
translated: In the fourth, “But, friend, we have not said this” means “We have not said this to you, friend.” “The wise lay follower” is one who has reached the fruit of stream-entry.🔽“The things that inspire confidence” are the things that inspire confidence. “Inspire confidence, venerable sir” means “inspire confidence in me, venerable sir.” “Death” is bound up with death. “The nature of death” is the nature of death. “Be assured” means “be sure.”🔽“Be assured” means “be sure.” “With mind fully released” means with mind fully released by the fruit of arahantship.

original: Yadidaṃ vimuttiyā vimuttanti yaṃ idaṃ vimuttiṃ ārabbha vimuttiyā nānākaraṇaṃ vattabbaṃ🔽siyā, na taṃ vadāmi. Bhikkhusaṅghassa hi cetiyaṅgaṇabodhiyaṅgaṇavattesu ceva asītikkhandhakavattesu🔽cāti āgamanīyaguṇesu pamāṇaṃ nāma natthi, paṭividdhe pana magge vā phale vā upāsakānañca
analyzed: yat idam vimuttiyāḥ vimuttan ti yam idam vimuttim ārabbha vimuttiyāḥ nānākaraṇam vattabbam  siyā na tam vadāmi bhikkhu saṅghassa hi cetiyaṅgaṇa bodhiyaṅgaṇa vattesu ca iva asīti kkhandhaka vattesu  ca ati āgamanīya guṇesu pamāṇam nāma natthi paṭividdhe pana magge vā phale vā upāsakānam ca
translated: In the fourth, in the words but, monks, I do not say this, he is a lay follower who is wise, a stream-enterer is intended. In the words the things that can be pointed to: the things that can be pointed to as causes for consolation. Consoled, venerable sir: may the venerable one be consoled. Death-bound: bound by death. Subject to death: of the nature of death. He resolved: he made up his mind. Resolved: made up his mind. With his mind liberated thus: with his mind liberated by the fruit of arahantship. In other words, liberated by the liberation: if it were necessary to say how the liberation is different from the liberated one,🔽I would not say it. For there is no limit to the qualities that are worthy of reverence in the case of the Community of monks in the case of the Cetiya-tree terrace and the Bo-tree terrace, and in the case of the eighty-four thousand sections of the Dhamma.

original: bhikkhūnañca nānākaraṇaṃ natthi.
analyzed: bhikkhūnam ca nānākaraṇam natthi
translated: But in the case of the path and fruit that have been penetrated there is no difference between lay followers and monks.

original: 9. Paññāpaṭilābhasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paññā paṭilābha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Exposition of the Conversion of the Conversion of Understanding

original: 1055. Navame paññāpaṭilābhāya saṃvattantīti ettha satta sekkhā paññaṃ paṭilabhanti
analyzed: navame paññā paṭilābhāya saṃvattanti iti ettha satta sekkhā paññam paṭilabhanti
translated: In the ninth, “to the acquiring of understanding”: the seven kinds of trainee acquire understanding;🔽the one whose cankers are destroyed is said to have acquired understanding.

original: nāma, khīṇāsavo paṭiladdhapañño nāmāti veditabbo. Parato paññābuddhiyātiādīsupi eseva
analyzed: nāma khīṇa āsavaḥ paṭiladdha paññaḥ nāma ati veditabbo paratas paññā buddhiyā ti ādīsu pi esā eva
translated: The same method of explanation applies in the case of the rest of the terms beginning with “understanding, cognizance, and awareness” .

original: nayo. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: nayo sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: The rest is clear in all instances.

original: Sappaññavaggo chaṭṭho.🔽7. Mahāpaññavaggo
analyzed: sa pañña vaggaḥ chaṭṭhaḥ  mahāpañña vaggaḥ
translated: The sixth chapter is finished.🔽The chapter on great understanding

original: 1. Mahāpaññāsuttavaṇṇanā🔽1058. Sattame mahāpaññatāya saṃvattantītiādīsu “mahante atthe pariggaṇhātīti mahāpaññā”tiādinā
analyzed: sattame mahā paññatāya saṃvattanti itiādīsu mahante atthe pariggaṇhāti iti mahāpaññā ati ādinā
translated: The explanation of the “Great understanding” sutta🔽In the seventh, “to the state of great understanding” and so on, the meaning of all the terms should be understood by the method stated in the Paṭisambhidā: “Great understanding: she understands great meaning” .

original: paṭisambhidāyaṃ vuttanayeneva sabbattha sabbapadesu attho veditabbo. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānamevāti.
analyzed: paṭisambhidā ayam vutta nayena iva sabbattha sabba padesu attho veditabbaḥ sesam sabbattha uttānam eva ati
translated: The rest is clear in all instances.

original: Sotāpattisaṃyuttavaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā.
analyzed: sotāpatti saṃyutta vaṇṇanā niṭṭhitā
translated: The explanation of the “Stream-Entry” class is finished.

original: 12. Saccasaṃyuttaṃ🔽1. Samādhivaggo
analyzed: sacca saṃyuttam  samādhi vaggo
translated: The Connected Discourses on the Truths🔽The chapter on concentration

original: 1. Samādhisuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: samādhi sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The explanation of the “Concentration” sutta

original: 1071. Saccasaṃyuttassa paṭhame samādhiṃ, bhikkhaveti te kira bhikkhū cittekaggatāya
analyzed: sacca saṃyuttassa paṭhame samādhim bhikkhave ti te kira bhikkhū citta ekagga tāya
translated: In the first of the “Connected Discourses on the Truths,” “Concentration, bhikkhus” : it seems that these bhikkhus had been practicing the unification of cognizance by means of the first jhana.

original: parihāyanti, atha nesaṃ satthā – “evamete cittekaggataṃ labhitvā, kammaṭṭhānaṃ vaḍḍhetvā,
analyzed: parihāyanti atha nesam satthā evam ete citta ekagga tam labhitvā kammaṭṭhānam vaḍḍhetvā
translated: If they do not, then their teacher should begin this teaching: “These bhikkhus have attained one-pointedness of mind and are developing the meditation subject.🔽They will reach distinction.”

original: visesaṃ pāpuṇissantī”ti imaṃ desanaṃ ārabhi. Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, “idaṃ dukkha”nti
analyzed: visesam pāpuṇissanti iti imam desanam ārabhi tasmāt iha bhikkhave idam dukkhanti
translated: “Therefore, bhikkhus, you should train yourselves thus: ‘We will enter upon the way that leads to the cessation of suffering.’

original: yogo karaṇīyoti ettha yathābhūtādivasena kāraṇacchedo veditabbo. Idañhi vuttaṃ hoti
analyzed: yogo karaṇīyaḥ ti ettha yathā bhūta ādi vasena kāraṇa chedo veditabbo idam hi vuttam hoti
translated: “Herein, the analysis of the reason should be understood as follows. This is said:

original: – bhikkhave, yasmā samāhito bhikkhu cattāri saccāni yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti, tasmā tumhehi
analyzed: bhikkhave yasmā samāhitaḥ bhikkhu cattāri saccāni yathābhūtam pajānāti tasmā tumhehi
translated: “Bhikkhus, since a bhikkhu who is concentrated knows and sees things as they are,🔽you should enter upon the way that leads to the cessation of suffering,

original: ca samāhitehi catunnaṃ saccānaṃ yathābhūtaṃ pajānanatthāya “idaṃ dukkha”nti yogo
analyzed: ca samāhitehi catunnam saccānam yathābhūtam pajānana tthāya idam dukkhanti yogaḥ
translated: knowing and seeing things as they are.

original: karaṇīyo. Tathā yasmā cattāri saccāni tathāgatasseva pātubhāvā pākaṭāni honti, yasmā
analyzed: karaṇīyaḥ tathā yasmā cattāri saccāni tathāgatassa iva pātubhāvā pākaṭāni honti yasmā
translated: “Since the four noble truths are manifested only to a Tathāgata,

original: ca tathāgatena suvibhattāni, yasmā ca tesu aparimāṇā vaṇṇā aparimāṇāni padabyañjanāni,
analyzed: ca tathāgatena su vibhattāni yasmā ca tesu aparimāṇāḥ vaṇṇāḥ aparimāṇāni pada byañjanāni
translated: since they are well penetrated by a Tathāgata, since they have a measureless exposition in terms of their meaning and phrasing,

original: yasmā ca tesaṃ appaṭividdhattā vaṭṭaṃ vaḍḍhati, tesaṃ paṭividdhakālato paṭṭhāya na
analyzed: yasmā ca tesam appaṭividdha ttā vaṭṭam vaḍḍhati tesam paṭividdha kālataḥ paṭṭhāya na
translated: since the round of rebirths is measureless because of them, and since the round ceases when they are penetrated,

original: vaḍḍhati, tasmā “evaṃ no vaṭṭaṃ na vaḍḍhissatī”ti tumhehi “idaṃ dukkha”nti yogo karaṇīyo.
analyzed: vaḍḍhati tasmai evam naḥ vaṭṭam na vaḍḍhissati iti tumhehi idam dukkhanti yogaḥ karaṇīyaḥ
translated: it grows. So you should make an effort thus, ‘We shall live so that the round will not grow,’ and you should understand that this is suffering.

original: 2. Paṭisallānasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: paṭisallāna sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Discourses on Seclusion

original: 1072. Dutiyaṃ kāyavivekavikalānaṃ kāyavivekapaṭilābhatthāya vuttaṃ.
analyzed: dutiyam kāya viveka vikalānam kāya viveka paṭilābha atthāya vuttam
translated: The second was spoken for the attainment of bodily seclusion by those who are confused about bodily seclusion.

original: 3. Paṭhamakulaputtasuttādivaṇṇanā🔽1073-75. Tatiye abhisamayāyāti abhisamayatthāya. Samaṇabrāhmaṇāti cettha sāsanāvacarā
analyzed: paṭhama kula putta sutta ādi vaṇṇanā  tatiye abhisamayāya ati abhisamaya tthāya samaṇa brāhmaṇā ati ca ittha sāsana avacarā
translated: The First Discourse on the Noble Son, etc.

original: adhippetā. Tathā catutthapañcamesu, tena tena abhilāpena bujjhanakānaṃ pana ajjhāsayenetāni vuttāni.
analyzed: adhippetā tathā catuttha pañcamesu tena tena abhilāpena bujjhanakānam pana ajjhāsayena itāni vuttāni
translated: In the third, for the breakthrough: for the purpose of the breakthrough. Ascetics and contemplatives: those who are in the Dispensation are intended here. So too in the fourth and fifth. But these were spoken with reference to those who are awakening to the respective terms.

original: 6. Dutiyasamaṇabrāhmaṇasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya samaṇa brāhmaṇa sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Second Discourse on Ascetics and Brahmins

original: 1076. Chaṭṭhe abhisambuddhaṃ pakāsesunti abhisambuddho ahanti evaṃ attānaṃ abhisambuddhaṃ pakāsayiṃsu. Imasmiñhi sutte sabbaññubuddhā ca samaṇagahaṇena gahitā.
analyzed: chaṭṭhe abhisambuddham pakāsesunti abhisambuddhaḥ aham ti evam attānam abhisambuddham pakāsayiṃsu imasmin hi sutte sabbaññu buddhā ca samaṇa gahaṇena gahitā
translated: In the sixth, they proclaimed him fully enlightened: they proclaimed him thus, ‘He is fully enlightened.’ For in this sutta all-knowing Buddhas are included by the word ‘ascetic.’

original: 10. Tiracchānakathāsuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tiracchāna kathā sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Discourse on the Animal Kingdom

original: 1080. Dasame anekavihitanti anekavidhaṃ. Tiracchānakathanti aniyyānikattā saggamokkhamaggānaṃ
analyzed: dasame aneka vihitam ti anekavidham tiracchāna katham aniyyānika ttā sagga mokkha maggānam
translated: In the tenth, “of many kinds” means of many sorts. “Animal talk” is talk about animals, that is, talk that is not concerned with the path to heaven or to liberation.

original: tiracchānabhūtaṃ kathaṃ. Rājakathantiādīsu rājānaṃ ārabbha “mahāsammato mandhātā
analyzed: tiracchāna bhūtam katham rāja kathanti ādīsu rājānam ārabbha mahāsammataḥ mandhātā
translated: “Royal talk” is talk about kings, such as this: “Mahāsammata, Mandhātu,

original: dhammāsoko evaṃ mahānubhāvo”tiādinā nayena pavattakathā rājakathā. Esa nayo corakathādīsu.
analyzed: dhamma āsokaḥ evam mahā anubhāvaḥ ti ādinā nayena pavatta kathā rāja kathā esa nayo cora kathā ādīsu
translated: Dhammāsoka had such and such power.” “Bandit talk” and the rest are to be construed in the same way.

original: Tesu “asuko rājā abhirūpo dassanīyo”tiādinā nayena gehasitakathāva tiracchānakathā🔽hoti. “Sopi nāma evaṃ mahānubhāvo khayaṃ gato”ti evaṃ pavattā pana kammaṭṭhānabhāve🔽tiṭṭhati. Coresupi “mūladevo evaṃ mahānubhāvo meghamālo evaṃ mahānubhāvo”ti tesaṃ🔽kammaṃ paṭicca “aho sūrā”ti gehasitakathāva tiracchānakathā. Yuddhepi bhāratayuddhādīsu
analyzed: tesu asukaḥ rājā abhirūpaḥ dassanīyaḥ ti ādinā nayena tiracchāna kathā  hoti saḥ api nāma evam mahā anubhāvaḥ khayam gataḥ ti evam pavattā pana kammaṭṭhāna bhāve  tiṭṭhati coresu pi mūladevaḥ evam mahā anubhāvaḥ meghamālaḥ evam mahā anubhāvaḥ ti tesam  kammam paṭicca aho tiracchāna kathā yuddhe pi bhārata yuddha ādīsu
translated: Herein, talk that is concerned with what is merely pleasing to the householders, such as “This king is handsome, good-looking,” is “animal talk.” But that which occurs as follows is a meditation subject: “He too has come to this, that he will die” .🔽As regards bandits too, talk that is concerned with what is merely pleasing to the householders, such as this: “Mūladeva had such and such power, Megha the robber had such and such power,” is “animal talk.” But that which occurs as follows is a meditation subject: “They too have come to this, that they have been executed after being defeated in combat” .

original: “asukena asuko evaṃ mārito evaṃ viddho”ti kāmassādavaseneva kathā tiracchānakathā,
analyzed: asukena asukaḥ evam māritaḥ evam viddhaḥ iti kāmaḥ sāda vasena iva kathā tiracchāna kathā
translated: As regards battles too, talk that occurs as follows is “animal talk”: “In the Bhārata war such and such happened, such and such was achieved,” and so on, concerned with what is merely pleasing to the householders.

original: “tepi nāma khayaṃ gatā”ti evaṃ pavattā pana sabbattha kammaṭṭhānameva hoti. Apica🔽annādīsu “evaṃ vaṇṇavantaṃ gandhavantaṃ rasavantaṃ phassasampannaṃ khādimha bhuñjimha🔽pivimha paribhuñjimhā”ti kāmassādavasena kathetuṃ na vaṭṭati. Sātthakaṃ pana katvā🔽“pubbe evaṃ vaṇṇādisampannaṃ annaṃ pānaṃ vatthaṃ sayanaṃ mālaṃ gandhaṃ vilepanaṃ
analyzed: te pi nāma khayam gatā ti evam pavattā pana sabbattha kammaṭṭhānam eva hoti apica  anna ādīsu evam vaṇṇavantam gandhavantam rasavantam phassa sampannam khādimha bhuñjimha  pivimha paribhuñjimha ati kāmassāda vasena kathetum na vaṭṭati sātthakam pana katvā  pubbe evam vaṇṇa ādi sampannam annam pānam vattham sayanam mālam gandham vilepanam
translated: But the meditation subject is still present in all these cases.

original: sīlavantānaṃ adamha, cetiye pūjaṃ akarimhā”ti kathetuṃ vaṭṭati.🔽Ñātikathādīsupi “amhākaṃ ñātakā sūrā samatthā”ti vā, “pubbe mayaṃ evaṃ vicitrehi🔽yānehi vicarimhā”ti vā assādavasena vattuṃ na vaṭṭati. Sātthakaṃ pana katvā “tepi
analyzed: sīlavantānam adamha cetiye pūjam akarimha iti kathetum vaṭṭati  ñāti kathā ādīsu pi amhākam ñātakā sūrā samatthā iti vā pubbe evam vicitrehi  yānehi vicarimha ati vā assāda vasena vattum na vaṭṭati sātthakam pana katvā te pi
translated: Moreover, when talking about food, etc., it is not allowable to talk about the relish of it in this way: “We ate such-and-such food, such-and-such drink, such-and-such clothes, such-and-such a bed, such-and-such scents and garlands and unguents, and we enjoyed it so much.” But it is allowable to talk about it with reference to its meaning in this way: “We gave such-and-such food, drink, etc., to the virtuous, and we made such-and-such offerings in the shrine.”

original: no ñātakā khayaṃ gatā”ti vā, “pubbe mayaṃ evarūpā upāhanā saṅghassa adamhā”ti vā
analyzed: no ñātakā khayam gatā ati vā pubbe mayam evarūpāḥ upāhanā saṅghassa adamha ati vā
translated: And in the case of talk about relatives, etc., it is not allowable to talk about their prowess and ability in this way: “Our relatives are powerful and able,” or to talk about the relish of it in this way: “In the past we travelled about in such-and-such various vehicles.” But it is allowable to talk about it with reference to its meaning in this way: “Those relatives of ours have also passed away,” or in this way: “In the past we gave such-and-such sandals to the Community.”

original: kathetabbā. Gāmakathādīsupi suniviṭṭhadunniviṭṭhasubhikkhadubbhikkhādivasena vā “asukagāmavāsino🔽sūrā samatthā”ti vā evaṃ assādavasena vattuṃ na vaṭṭati, sātthakaṃ pana katvā “saddhā
analyzed: kathetabbāḥ gāma kathā ādīsu pi suniviṭṭha dunniviṭṭha subhikkha dubbhikkha ādi vasena vā asuka gāma vāsinaḥ  sūrā samatthā ati vā evam assāda vasena vattum na vaṭṭati sātthakam pana katvā saddhā
translated: and so on. In the case of talk about villages, etc., it is not allowable to say such things as “The people in such-and-such a village are well off or badly off, prosperous or not, and so on,” or “The people in such-and-such a village are brave and capable,” in this way recommending them. But it is allowable to say it if it has some purpose.

original: pasannā”ti vā, “khayaṃ gatā”ti vā vattuṃ vaṭṭati. Nigamanagarajanapadakathāsupi eseva nayo.🔽Itthikathāpi vaṇṇasaṇṭhānādīni paṭicca assādavasena vattuṃ na vaṭṭati, “saddhā pasannā🔽khayaṃ gatā”ti evameva vaṭṭati. Sūrakathāpi “nandimitto nāma yodho sūro ahosī”ti
analyzed: pasannā ati vā khayam gatā ati vā vattum vaṭṭati nigama nagara janapada kathāsu pi eṣa iva nayaḥ  itthi kathā api vaṇṇa saṇṭhāna ādīni paṭicca assāda vasena vattum na vaṭṭati saddhā pasannā  khayam gatā ati evam eva vaṭṭati sūrakathā api nandimittaḥ nāma yodhaḥ sūraḥ ahosi iti
translated: and so on. In the case of talk about villages, etc., it is not allowable to say, “The people in such-and-such a village are well off or badly off, prosperous or not, and so on,” with relish for the meaning, but it is allowable to say it with reference to a purpose, as follows: “They are faithful and confident,” or “They have reached decay and decline.” So too in the case of talk about towns, countries, and regions.

original: assādavasena vattuṃ na vaṭṭati, “saddho pasanno ahosi, khayaṃ gato”ti evameva vaṭṭati.🔽Surākathātipi pāṭho. Sāpi cesā surākathā “evarūpā nāma surā pītā ratijananī hotī”ti
analyzed: assāda vasena vattum na vaṭṭati saddhaḥ pasannaḥ ahosi khayam gato ti evam eva vaṭṭati  surākathā atipi sā api ca isā surākathā evarūpā nāma surā pītā rati jananī
translated: Talk about women is not allowable with relish for the meaning by way of their beauty, figure, and so on, but it is allowable as follows: “They are faithful and confident,” or “They have reached decay and decline.” Talk about heroes is not allowable with relish for the meaning, as follows: “The hero called So-and-so was brave,” but it is allowable as follows: “He was faithful and confident,” or “He has reached decay and decline.”

original: assādavaseneva na vaṭṭati, ādīnavavasena pana “ummattakasaṃvattanikā”tiādinā nayena
analyzed: assāda vasena iva na vaṭṭati ādīnava vasena pana ummattaka saṃvattanikā ati ādinā nayena
translated: There is also a reading “surāka-kathā.” This talk about surā and so on is not allowable with relish for the meaning, as follows: “Such-and-such a surā, when drunk, gives pleasure,” but it is allowable as follows: “It leads to madness,” and so on, by way of its dangers.

original: vaṭṭati. Visikhākathāpi “asukavisikhā suniviṭṭhā dunniviṭṭhā”ti vā, “asukavisikhāya🔽vāsino sūrā samatthā”ti vā assādavaseneva vattuṃ na vaṭṭati, “saddhā pasannā khayaṃ🔽gatā”ti eccevaṃ vaṭṭati. Kumbhaṭṭhānakathāti udakatitthakathā vuccati, kumbhadāsikathā
analyzed: vaṭṭati visikhā kathā api asuka visikhā su niviṭṭhā dunniviṭṭhā ati vā asuka visikhāya  vāsinaḥ sūrā samatthā ati vā assāda vasena iva vattum na vaṭṭati saddhā pasannā khayam  gatā ati e ca evam vaṭṭati kumbha ṭṭhāna kathā ati udaka tittha kathā vuccati kumbhadāsi kathā
translated: “This row is well-aligned, that one is badly-aligned,” or “The people in this row are strong and capable,” or “The people in that row are weak and incapable.” But it is allowable to say, “They have faith and confidence, they have reached destruction of taints,” and so on. The discussion about the water-trough is a discussion about a bathing place. The discussion about the slave girl is a discussion about a water-carrier.

original: vā. Sāpi “pāsādikā naccituṃ gāyituṃ chekā”ti assādavasena na vaṭṭati, “saddhā pasannā”tiādinā nayeneva vaṭṭati.🔽Pubbapetakathāti atītañātikathā. Tattha vattamānañātikathāsadisova vinicchayo. Nānattakathāti🔽purimapacchimakathāhi vimuttā avasesā nānāsabhāvā niratthakakathā. Lokakkhāyikāti
analyzed: vā sā api pāsādikā naccitum gāyitum chekā ati assāda vasena na vaṭṭati saddhā pasannā ati ādinā nayena iva vaṭṭati  pubba peta kathā āti atīta ñāti kathā tattha vattamāna ñāti kathā sadisaḥ eva vinicchayaḥ nānatta kathā ti  purima pacchima kathāhi vimuttā avasesā nānā sabhāvā niratthaka kathā loka kkhāyikā ti
translated: It is allowable to say, “So-and-so’s crest is well-arranged,” or “The people living in so-and-so’s crest are brave and able,” but not to say it with relish. It is allowable to say, “She has faith and confidence and has reached destruction of taints,” and so on. The discussion of the water-trough is called the discussion of the bathing place or the discussion of the slave girl. It is not allowable to say it with relish, “She is graceful and clever at dancing and singing,” but it is allowable to say it in the way beginning, “She has faith and confidence. ”

original: “ayaṃ loko kena nimmito, asukena nāma nimmito, kāko seto aṭṭhīnaṃ setattā, balākā
analyzed: ayam loko kena nimmitaḥ asukena nāma nimmitaḥ kāko setaḥ aṭṭhīnam seta ttā balākā
translated: The discussion of the past is the discussion of what is past. The decision in it is like that in the discussion of what is present. The various discussions are discussions other than those already mentioned, that is, discussions of various kinds that are pointless. The stories of the world are such as “By whom was this world created? It was created by so-and-so,” or “The crow is white because its bones are white,” or “The heron is white because its roots are white,” or “The partridge is red because its flesh is red,” or “The partridge is red because it eats red rice,” or “The partridge is red because its mother was red,” or “The partridge is red because its father was red,” or “The partridge is red because its grandfather was red,” or “The partridge is red because its great-grandfather was red,” or “The partridge is red because it was created by the creation of red.”

original: rattā lohitassa rattattā”ti evamādikā lokāyatavitaṇḍasallāpakathā. Samuddakkhāyikā🔽nāma “kasmā samuddo sāgaro, sāgaradevena khanitattā sāgaro, khato meti hatthamuddāya🔽niveditattā samuddo”ti evamādikā niratthakasamuddakkhāyikakathā. Iti bhavo iti abhavoti🔽yaṃ vā taṃ vā niratthakakāraṇaṃ vatvā pavattitakathā itibhavābhavakathā. Ettha ca
analyzed: rattā lohitassa ratta ttā ati evamādikā lokāyata vitaṇḍa sallāpa kathā samuddakkhāyikā  nāma kasmā samuddaḥ sāgaraḥ sāgaradevena khanitattā sāgaraḥ khataḥ mā iti hattha muddāya  nivedita ttā samuddaḥ ti evamādikā niratthaka samudda khāyika kathā iti bhavo iti abhavo ti  yam vā tam vā niratthaka kāraṇam vatvā pavattita kathā iti bhava abhava kathā ettha ca
translated: “Because blood is red, the world is red” — such talk as this is called talk about the world’s final release.

original: bhavoti sassataṃ, abhavoti ucchedaṃ. Bhavoti vuddhi, abhavoti hāni. Bhavoti kāmasukhaṃ,🔽abhavoti attakilamatho. Iti imāya chabbidhāya itibhavābhavakathāya saddhiṃ bāttiṃsa🔽tiracchānakathā nāma honti. Sesaṃ sabbattha uttānatthamevāti.🔽Paṭhamo vaggo.🔽2. Dhammacakkappavattanavaggo🔽1. Dhammacakkappavattanasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: bhavoti sassatam abhavoti ucchedam bhavoti vuddhi abhavoti hāni bhavoti kāma sukham 🔽abhavoti iti imāya chabbidhāya iti bhava abhava kathāya saddhim bāttiṃsa 🔽tiracchānakathāḥ nāma honti sesam sabbattha uttāna attham eva ati 🔽paṭhamaḥ vaggo 🔽dhammacakkappavattana vaggo 🔽dhammacakkappavattana sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: Talk about the ocean is talk about the ocean that is pointless and useless, such as: “Why is the ocean called the ocean? Because it is salty, because it has swallowed many great rivers, because it has swallowed many great mountains, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river Vaggumudā, because it has swallowed the great river

original: 1081. Dutiyassa paṭhame bārāṇasiyanti evaṃnāmake nagare. Isipatane migadāyeti isīnaṃ
analyzed: dutiyassa paṭhame bārāṇasiyanti evaṃnāmake nagare isipatane migadāya iti isīnam
translated: In the first of the second, at Bārāṇasī, in the Deer Park at Isipatana.

original: patanuppatanavasena evaṃladdhanāme migānaṃ abhayadānavasena dinnattā migadāyasaṅkhāte
analyzed: patana uppatana vasena evaṃladdha nāme migānam abhaya dāna vasena dinna ttā migadāya saṅkhāte
translated: In the first of the second, at Bārāṇasī, in the city of that name. In the Deer Park at Isipatana: it is called “Deer Park” because deer were given protection there, and it is called “Isipatana” because the abodes of seers fall and descend there.

original: ārāme. Ettha hi uppannuppannā sabbaññuisayo patanti, dhammacakkappavattanatthaṃ nisīdantīti🔽attho. Nandamūlakapabbhārato sattāhaccayena nirodhasamāpattito vuṭṭhitā anotattadahe
analyzed: ārāme ettha hi uppanna uppannā sabbaññu isayo patanti dhamma cakka ppavattana attham nisīdanti iti  atthaḥ nanda mūlaka pabbhārataḥ satta aha cayena nirodha samāpattitaḥ vuṭṭhitāḥ
translated: For seers who have attained the bases of success fall and sit down there for the purpose of setting in motion the Wheel of the Dhamma.

original: katamukhadhovanādikiccā ākāsena āgantvā paccekabuddhaisayopettha otaraṇavasena patanti,
analyzed: kata mukha dhovana ādi kiccāḥ ākāsena āgantvā otaraṇa vasena patanti
translated: Seven days after emerging from the attainment of cessation at the Nandamūla cave, the Buddha, who had gone by way of the air after performing the duties of washing his face, etc., at the Anotatta Lake, descended there, having reached the abode of seers by way of the air.

original: uposathatthañca anuposathatthañca sannipatanti, gandhamādanaṃ paṭigacchantāpi tatova
analyzed: uposatha attham ca an uposatha attham ca sannipatanti gandhamādanam paṭigacchantā api tatas vat
translated: They fall there by way of descending, and they assemble there for the purpose of the Uposatha and for the purpose of the An-uposatha, and they take off from there in the direction of Gandhamādana.

original: uppatantīti iminā isīnaṃ patanuppatanavasena taṃ “isipatana”nti vuccati.
analyzed: uppatanti iti iminā isīnam patana uppatana vasena tat isipatananti vuccati
translated: Thus it is called “Isipatana” because of the falling and descending of seers.

original: Āmantesīti dīpaṅkarapādamūle katābhinīhārato paṭṭhāya pāramiyo pūrento anupubbena
analyzed: āmantesi iti dīpaṅkara pāda mūle kata abhinīhārato paṭṭhāya pāramiyo pūrentaḥ anupubbena
translated: Addressed: while fulfilling the pāramīs after making his aspiration at the feet of Dīpaṅkara, the Buddha-to-be

original: pacchimabhave katābhinikkhamano anupubbena bodhimaṇḍaṃ patvā tattha aparājitapallaṅke🔽nisinno mārabalaṃ bhinditvā paṭhamayāme pubbenivāsaṃ anussaritvā majjhimayāme dibbacakkhuṃ
analyzed: pacchima bhave kata abhinikkhamanaḥ anupubbena bodhimaṇḍam patvā tattha aparājita pallaṅke  nisinnaḥ māra balam bhinditvā paṭhama yāme pubbenivāsam anussaritvā majjhima yāme dibba cakkhum
translated: In his last existence, after going forth, he gradually reached the Bodhi Tree, and sitting there on the invincible seat,

original: visodhetvā pacchimayāmāvasāne dasasahassilokadhātuṃ unnādento sabbaññutaṃ patvā satta
analyzed: visodhetvā pacchima yāma avasāne dasa sahassi lokadhātum unnādento sabbaññutam patvā satta
translated: he broke Māra’s power. In the first watch of the night he recollected his past lives, in the middle watch he purified the divine eye, and in the last watch, after making the ten thousand world systems resound, he attained omniscience.

original: sattāhāni bodhimaṇḍe vītināmetvā mahābrahmunā āyācitadhammadesano buddhacakkhunā
analyzed: satta ahāni bodhimaṇḍe vītināmetvā mahābrahmunā āyācita dhamma desanaḥ buddha cakkhunā
translated: After spending seven weeks at the foot of the Bodhi Tree, he consented to teach the Dhamma at the request of the Great Brahmā. He surveyed the world with his Buddha-eye,

original: lokaṃ voloketvā lokānuggahena bārāṇasiṃ gantvā pañcavaggiye saññāpetvā dhammacakkaṃ🔽pavattetukāmo āmantesi.🔽Dveme, bhikkhave, antāti dve ime, bhikkhave, koṭṭhāsā. Imassa pana padassa saha samudāhārena
analyzed: lokam voloketvā loka anuggahena bārāṇasim gantvā pañcavaggiye saññāpetvā dhammacakkaṃ  pavattetu kāmaḥ āmantesi  dve me bhikkhave antā ati dve ime bhikkhave koṭṭhāsāḥ imassa pana padassa saha samudāhārena
translated: and, out of compassion for the world, he went to Bārāṇasī. He instructed the group-of-five, and, wishing to set the Dhamma Wheel rolling, he addressed them:🔽“Bhikkhus, these two extremes should not be followed by one who has gone forth into homelessness.🔽What two? There is devotion to indulgence of sense pleasures, which is low, vulgar, the way of worldlings, ignoble, unbeneficial; and there is devotion to self-affliction, which is painful, ignoble, unbeneficial.

original: samudāhāranigghoso heṭṭhā avīciṃ upari bhavaggaṃ patvā dasasahassilokadhātuṃ pattharitvā
analyzed: samudāhāra nigghosaḥ heṭṭhā avīcim upari bhavaggam patvā dasa sahassi lokadhātum pattharitvā
translated: Without veering towards either of these extremes, the One Attuned to Reality1020🔽proclaimed a Middle Way that produces vision and knowledge,🔽which leads to peace, direct knowledge, enlightenment, and Nibbāna.🔽And what, bhikkhus, is that Middle Way?🔽It is just this Noble Eightfold Path, that is, right view, right resolve, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right concentration.

original: aṭṭhāsi. Tasmiṃyeva samaye aṭṭhārasakoṭisaṅkhā brahmāno samāgacchiṃsu, pacchimadisāya
analyzed: tasmin yeva samaye aṭṭhārasa koṭi saṅkhāḥ brahmāno samāgacchiṃsu pacchima disāya
translated: and the eighteen koṭis of Brahmās assembled from the western direction.

original: sūriyo atthameti, pācīnadisāya āsāḷhanakkhattena yutto puṇṇacando uggacchati. Tasmiṃ
analyzed: sūriyaḥ attham eti pācīna disāya āsāḷha nakkhattena yuttaḥ puṇṇa candaḥ uggacchati tasmin
translated: The sun was setting in the western direction and the full moon, accompanied by the asterism of Uttarāsāḷha, was rising in the eastern direction.

original: samaye bhagavā imaṃ dhammacakkappavattanasuttaṃ ārabhanto “dveme, bhikkhave, antā”tiādimāha.🔽Tattha pabbajitenāti gihisaṃyojanaṃ chinditvā pabbajjupagatena. Na sevitabbāti na
analyzed: samaye bhagavā imam dhammacakka ppavattana suttam ārabhantaḥ dve me bhikkhave anta iti ādim āha  tattha pabbajitena ati gihi saṃyojanam chinditvā pabbajja upagatena na sevitabbā ati na
translated: At that time, the Blessed One, beginning the discourse on the setting in motion of the Wheel of the Dhamma, said: “Bhikkhus, there are these two extremes that are not to be indulged in by one who has gone forth into homelessness.”

original: vaḷañjetabbā. Yo cāyaṃ kāmesu kāmasukhallikānuyogoti yo ca ayaṃ vatthukāmesu kilesakāmasukhassa
analyzed: vaḷañjetabbā yaḥ ca ayam kāmesu kāma sukhallikā anuyogaḥ iti yaḥ ca ayam vatthu kāmesu kilesa kāma sukhassa
translated: Herein, “one who has gone forth into homelessness” means one who has gone forth after severing the fetters of the house life. “Is not to be indulged in” means is not to be enjoyed. “The pursuit of sensual happiness in sensual pleasures” means the pursuit of the happiness of defilement-lust in regard to the sensual pleasures of objects.

original: anuyogo. Hīnoti lāmako. Gammoti gāmavāsīnaṃ santako. Pothujjanikoti andhabālajanena
analyzed: anuyogaḥ hīnaḥ iti lāmakaḥ gammaḥ iti gāma vāsīnam santako pothujjanikaḥ iti andha bāla janena
translated: “Base” means low. “Vulgar” means common to the dwellers in villages. “Common” means practiced by the blind fools.

original: āciṇṇo. Anariyoti na ariyo na visuddho na uttamo na vā ariyānaṃ santako. Anatthasaṃhitoti
analyzed: āciṇṇaḥ anariyaḥ ti na ariyaḥ na visuddhaḥ na uttamaḥ na vā ariyānam santakaḥ anattha saṃhitaḥ ti
translated: “Unbeneficial” means not beneficial. “Unconnected with the goal” means not connected with the goal of recluseship. “Unsuitable” means not suitable for a clansman gone forth out of faith. “Not to be indulged in” means is not to be enjoyed.

original: na atthasaṃhito, hitasukhāvahakāraṇaṃ anissitoti attho. Attakilamathānuyogoti attano🔽kilamathassa anuyogo, attano dukkhakaraṇanti attho. Dukkhoti kaṇṭakāpassayaseyyādīhi
analyzed: na attha saṃhitaḥ hita sukha āvaha kāraṇam anissitaḥ iti atthaḥ atta kilamatha anuyogaḥ iti  kilamathassa anuyogaḥ attanaḥ dukkha karaṇanti atthaḥ dukkhaḥ ti kaṇṭaka apassaya seyya ādīhi
translated: Not in the interest of self-mortification: not in the interest of a cause that is a means to self-mortification, not in the interest of a cause that is a means to suffering for oneself, is the meaning.🔽The pursuit of self-mortification: the pursuit of self-mortification, the doing of what is painful for oneself, is the meaning.

original: attamāraṇehi dukkhāvaho.
analyzed: atta māraṇehi dukkha āvahaḥ
translated: Painful: it brings suffering by such means as lying on thorns and spikes and by starving oneself to death.

original: Paññācakkhuṃ karotīti cakkhukaraṇī. Dutiyapadaṃ tasseva vevacanaṃ. Upasamāyāti kilesūpasamatthāya.🔽Abhiññāyāti catunnaṃ saccānaṃ abhijānanatthāya. Sambodhāyāti tesaṃyeva sambujjhanatthāya.
analyzed: paññācakkhum karoti iti cakkhukaraṇī dutiya padam tassa iva vevacanam upasamāyāti kilesu upasamatthāya  abhiññāya ati catunnam saccānam abhijānana tthāya sambodhāya ati tesam yeva sambujjhana tthāya
translated: It makes the eye of wisdom: it makes the eye, is the meaning. The second term is a synonym for the first.

original: Nibbānāyāti nibbānasacchikiriyāya. Sesamettha yaṃ vattabbaṃ siyā, taṃ heṭṭhā tattha
analyzed: nibbānāya ati nibbāna sacchikiriyāya sesam ettha yat vattabbam siyā tat heṭṭhā tattha
translated: For the attainment of Nibbana: for the attainment of the Nibbana element. The rest can be understood in the way already stated.

original: tattha vuttameva. Saccakathāpi sabbākāreneva visuddhimagge vitthāritā.
analyzed: tattha vuttam eva sacca kathā api sabba ākārena iva visuddhi magge vitthāritā
translated: The explanation of the four noble truths has been given in all its aspects in the Path of Purity .

original: Tiparivaṭṭanti saccañāṇakiccañāṇakatañāṇasaṅkhātānaṃ tiṇṇaṃ parivaṭṭānaṃ vasena tiparivaṭṭaṃ.
analyzed: ti parivaṭṭanti sacca ñāṇa kicca ñāṇa kata ñāṇa saṅkhātānam tiṇṇam parivaṭṭānam vasena ti parivaṭṭam
translated: The three rounds: the three rounds are the three rounds of knowing the truths, knowing the functions, and knowing what is to be done.

original: Ettha hi “idaṃ dukkhaṃ ariyasaccaṃ, idaṃ dukkhasamudaya”nti evaṃ catūsu saccesu yathābhūtaṃ
analyzed: ettha hi idam dukkham ariya saccam idam dukkha samudaya nti evam catūsu saccesu yathābhūtam
translated: in the way beginning, “This is suffering, this is the origin of suffering,”

original: ñāṇaṃ saccañāṇaṃ nāma. Tesuyeva “pariññeyyaṃ pahātabba”nti evaṃ kattabbakiccajānanañāṇaṃ
analyzed: ñāṇam sacca ñāṇam nāma tesu yeva pariññeyyam pahātabban ti evam kattabba kicca jānana ñāṇam
translated: is called knowledge of the Truths. The knowledge of the function to be performed in regard to those same Truths, in the way beginning, “That which is to be fully understood has been fully understood,”

original: kiccañāṇaṃ nāma. “Pariññātaṃ pahīna”nti evaṃ tassa tassa kiccassa katabhāvajānanañāṇaṃ
analyzed: kicca ñāṇam nāma pariññātam pahīnam ti evam tassa tassa kiccassa kata bhāva jānana ñāṇam
translated: is called knowledge of the function. The knowledge of the state of having done what is to be done, in the way beginning, “That which is to be abandoned has been abandoned,”

original: katañāṇaṃ nāma. Dvādasākāranti tesaṃyeva ekekasmiṃ sacce tiṇṇaṃ tiṇṇaṃ ākārānaṃ vasena
analyzed: nāma dvādasa ākāranti tesam yeva ekekasmin sacce tiṇṇam tiṇṇam ākārānam vasena
translated: is called knowledge of what has been done. Twelve aspects: in each of the four Truths there are three aspects each,

original: dvādasākāraṃ. Ñāṇadassananti etesaṃ tiparivaṭṭānaṃ dvādasannaṃ ākārānaṃ vasena uppannañāṇasaṅkhātaṃ
analyzed: dvādasa ākāram ñāṇa dassanam ti etesam ti parivaṭṭānam dvādasannam ākārānam vasena uppanna ñāṇa saṅkhātam
translated: so there are twelve aspects in all. Knowledge and vision: the vision consisting of the knowledge arisen in regard to those twelve aspects, which are treated in three revolutions,

original: dassanaṃ. Dhammacakkhunti aññattha tayo maggā tīṇi ca phalāni dhammacakkhu nāma honti,
analyzed: dassanam dhammacakkhunti aññattha tayo maggā tīṇi ca phalāni dhammacakkhu nāma honti
translated: is called knowledge and vision. The eye of Dhamma: elsewhere the three paths and the three fruits are called the eye of Dhamma,

original: idha paṭhamamaggova.
analyzed: idha paṭhama maggā uva
translated: but here it is the first path.🔽The wheel of Dhamma: this is the knowledge of penetration and the knowledge of teaching,

original: Dhammacakketi paṭivedhañāṇe ceva desanāñāṇe ca. Bodhipallaṅke nisinnassa hi catūsu
analyzed: dhammacakkā iti paṭivedha ñāṇe ca iva desanā ñāṇe ca bodhi pallaṅke nisinnassa hi catūsu
translated: for when the Blessed One was seated on the seat of enlightenment he turned the wheel of Dhamma in the fourfold and twelvefold way.

original: saccesu uppannaṃ dvādasākāraṃ paṭivedhañāṇampi, isipatane nisinnassa dvādasākārāya🔽saccadesanāya pavattitaṃ desanāñāṇampi dhammacakkaṃ nāma. Ubhayampi hetaṃ dasabalassa
analyzed: saccesu uppannam dvādasa ākāram paṭivedha ñāṇam pi isipatane nisinnassa dvādasa ākārāya  sacca desanāya pavattitam desanā ñāṇam pi dhammacakkam nāma ubhayam pi ha etam dasabalassa
translated: The knowledge of penetration of the four noble truths, which has twelve aspects, and the knowledge of teaching, which is the teaching of the four noble truths with twelve aspects, that the Exalted One set rolling at Isipatana, are both called the Wheel of the Dhamma.🔽🔽Both of these are the Wheel of the Dhamma of the Exalted One, who possesses the ten powers.

original: ure pavattañāṇameva. Imāya desanāya pakāsentena bhagavatā dhammacakkaṃ pavattitaṃ
analyzed: ure pavatta ñāṇam eva imāya desanāya pakāsentena bhagavatā dhammacakkam pavattitam
translated: The knowledge of penetration of the twelve aspects in the four truths that arose in him, and the knowledge of teaching that occurred in him when he gave the teaching of the twelve aspects of the four truths to the group of five bhikkhus at Isipatana, are called the Wheel of the Dhamma. For this knowledge that occurred in the Exalted One’s breast is both the knowledge of penetration and the knowledge of teaching. When the Exalted One, by means of this teaching, set the Wheel of the Dhamma rolling,

original: nāma. Taṃ panetaṃ dhammacakkaṃ yāva aññāsikoṇḍaññatthero aṭṭhārasahi brahmakoṭīhi
analyzed: nāma tam pana itam dhammacakkam yāva aññāsikoṇḍañña theraḥ aṭṭhārasahi brahmakoṭīhi
translated: the Wheel of the Dhamma is said to have been set rolling by the Exalted One. But this Wheel of the Dhamma is said to have been set rolling by the Exalted One as long as the Elder Aññāsikoṇḍañña, together with eighteen koṭis of Brahmās,

original: saddhiṃ sotāpattiphale patiṭṭhāti, tāva naṃ bhagavā pavatteti nāma, patiṭṭhite ca
analyzed: saddhim sotāpatti phale patiṭṭhāti tāva nam bhagavā pavattā iti nāma patiṭṭhite ca
translated: was established in the fruit of stream-entry. And when he was established, the Wheel of the Dhamma was said to have been set rolling. With reference to this, it is said: “When the Wheel of the Dhamma had been set rolling by the Exalted One, the devas of earth raised a cry:🔽‘The Wheel of the Dhamma has been set rolling by the Exalted One, who is perfected and fully enlightened, in the Deer Park at Isipatana, near Bārāṇasī, for the purification of beings, for the overcoming of sorrow and lamentation, for the destruction of pain and grief, for the attainment of the way, for the realization of Nibbāna!’ And this cry of the devas of earth spread through the whole of the four-continent world, and so on up to the world of the highest gods. And the cry spread through the whole world as far as the Brahmā-world, and the cry spread through the whole world as far as the Brahmā-world: ‘The Wheel of the Dhamma has been set rolling by the Exalted One, who is perfected and fully enlightened, in the Deer Park at Isipatana, near Bārāṇasī, for the purification of beings, for the overcoming of sorrow and lamentation, for the destruction of pain and grief, for the attainment of the way, for the realization of Nibbāna!’”

original: pavattitaṃ nāma. Taṃ sandhāya pavattite ca pana bhagavatā dhammacakke bhummā devā🔽saddamanussāvesuntiādi vuttaṃ.🔽Tattha bhummāti bhūmaṭṭhakadevatā. Saddamanussāvesunti ekappahāreneva sādhukāraṃ🔽datvā – “etaṃ bhagavatā”tiādīni vadantā anusāvayiṃsu. Obhāsoti sabbaññutaññāṇobhāso.
analyzed: pavattitam nāma tam sandhāya pavattite ca pana bhagavatā dhammacakke bhummāḥ devāḥ 🔽sadda manussāvesu tiādi vuttam 🔽tattha bhummā ati bhūmaṭṭhaka devatā saddam anussāvesun ti eka ppahārena iva sādhukāram 🔽etam bhagavatā atiādīni vadantāḥ anusāvayiṃsu obhāsaḥ ti sabbaññuta ññāṇa ubhāsaḥ
translated: Herein, the devas of earth are the deities who dwell on the earth. They raised a cry means that they gave a shout of approval all at once, saying: “This is the Wheel of the Dhamma

original: So hi tadā devānaṃ devānubhāvaṃ atikkamitvā virocittha. Aññāsi vata, bho, koṇḍaññoti
analyzed: saḥ hi tadā devānam deva anubhāvam atikkamitvā virocittha aññāsi vata bho koṇḍañño ti
translated: for it shone surpassing the splendour of the gods.

original: imassapi udānassa udāhāranigghoso dasasahassilokadhātuṃ pharitvā aṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: imassa api udānassa udāhāra nigghosaḥ dasa sahassi lokadhātum pharitvā aṭṭhāsi
translated: The sound of the utterance of this exclamation also remained pervading the ten-thousandfold world-element.

original: 9. Saṅkāsanasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: saṅkāsana sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Discourse on the Posture for Lying Down

original: 1089. Navame aparimāṇā vaṇṇāti appamāṇāni akkharāni. Byañjanāti tesaṃyeva vevacanaṃ,
analyzed: navame aparimāṇā vaṇṇāti appamāṇāni akkharāni byañjanāti tesam yeva vevacanam
translated: In the ninth, the “incalculable letters” are the incalculable syllables. The “vowels” are a synonym for them.

original: vaṇṇānaṃ vā ekadesā yadidaṃ byañjanā nāma. Saṅkāsanāti vibhattiyo. Ekamekasmiñhi
analyzed: vaṇṇānam vā eka desāḥ yat idam byañjanāḥ nāma saṅkāsanā ati vibhattiyaḥ ekam ekasmin hi
translated: Or else, the vowels are one part of the letters. The “posture” is the inflections.

original: sacce sabbākārena vitthāriyamāne vaṇṇādīnaṃ anto nāma natthi. Tasmā evamāha.
analyzed: sacce sabba ākārena vitthāriyamāne vaṇṇa ādīnam antaḥ nāma natthi tasmai evam āha
translated: For when each truth is being expounded in all its aspects, there is no end to the syllables, etc. That is why he said thus.

original: 10. Tathasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: tatha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: The Description of the Discourse on Thusness

original: 1090. Dasame sabhāvāvijahanaṭṭhena tathaṃ. Dukkhañhi dukkhameva vuttaṃ. Sabhāvassa
analyzed: dasame sabhāva avijahana ṭṭhena tatham dukkham hi dukkham eva vuttam sabhāvassa
translated: In the tenth, “thus” in the sense of not deviating from individual essences. For suffering is said to be just suffering.

original: amoghatāya avitathaṃ. Na hi dukkhaṃ adukkhaṃ nāma hoti. Aññabhāvānupagamena anaññathaṃ.
analyzed: amogha tāya avitatham na hi dukkham adukkham nāma hoti añña bhāva anupagamena anaññatham
translated: It is “not otherwise” in the sense of not being futile. For suffering is not non-suffering. It is “not otherwise” in the sense of not assuming another individual essence.

original: Na hi dukkhaṃ samudayādibhāvaṃ upagacchati. Samudayādīsupi eseva nayoti.
analyzed: na hi dukkham samudaya ādi bhāvam upagacchati samudaya ādīsu pi
translated: For suffering does not assume the individual essence of origination, etc. The same method applies to origination, etc.

original: Dhammacakkappavattanavaggo dutiyo.
analyzed: dhammacakkappavattana vaggaḥ dutiyaḥ
translated: The second sub-chapter on setting the wheel of Dhamma in motion is finished.

original: 3. Koṭigāmavaggo
analyzed: koṭi gāma vaggo
translated: The second sub-chapter on the setting in motion of the wheel of the Dhamma is finished.🔽THE SUB-CHAPTER ON THE VILLAGE OF KOṬI

original: 1. Koṭigāmasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: koṭigāma sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: THE FIRST DISCOURSE ON THE VILLAGE OF KOṬI

original: 1091. Tatiyassa paṭhame ananubodhāti ananubujjhanena. Appaṭivedhāti appaṭivijjhanena.
analyzed: tatiyassa paṭhame an anubodhāti an anubujjhanena appaṭivedhāti appaṭivijjhanena
translated: As to the first of the third set of ten, as to the not understanding: as to the not understanding. As to the not penetrating: as to the not penetrating.

original: 2. Dutiyakoṭigāmasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiya koṭigāma sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: THE SECOND DISCOURSE ON THE VILLAGE OF KOṬI

original: 1092. Dutiye cetovimutti paññāvimuttīti phalasamāpattiphalapaññānaṃ nāmaṃ.🔽7. Tathasuttavaṇṇanā
analyzed: dutiye cetaḥ vimutti paññā vimutti iti phala samāpatti phala paññānam nāmam  tatha sutta vaṇṇanā
translated: As to the second, as to the deliverance of mind: as to the attainment of fruition. As to the deliverance by understanding: as to the knowledge of fruition.🔽THE DISCOURSE ON THAT

original: 1097. Sattame tasmā ariyasaccānīti yasmā tathāni avitathāni anaññathāni, tasmā ariyānaṃ saccānīti vuccanti. Na hi vitathāni ariyā ariyasaccato paṭivijjhanti.
analyzed: sattame tasmai ariya saccāni iti yasmai tathāni avitathāni anaññathāni tasmai ariyānam saccāni iti vuccanti na hi vitathāni ariyāḥ ariya saccataḥ paṭivijjhanti
translated: As to the seventh, as to the noble truths: as to the truths of the noble ones. For since they are that way, not otherwise, they are called the noble ones’ truths. For the noble ones do not penetrate the noble truths as otherwise than they are.

original: 8. Lokasuttavaṇṇanā
translated: THE DISCOURSE ON THE WORLD
